{"botulismnum_articles": "689", "botulism": [{"archive_id": "8242098", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - USA (02): (CA) wound, injection drug related", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8242098", "date": "2021-01-14 15:27:39", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: (NEW MEXICO) WOUND, DRUG RELATED\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Jan 2021\nSource: KRWG.org [edited]\nhttps://www.krwg.org/post/one-confirmed-case-and-one-suspected-case-wound-botulism-new-mexico\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) is investigating 1 confirmed case - and 1 suspected case - of wound botulism. A 28-year-old male from Eddy County is hospitalized with wound botulism. The suspected source of infection is contaminated black tar heroin, and the nerve toxin that causes botulism was identified from a patient specimen. Another 29-year-old male from Eddy County with a history of injection drug use is hospitalized with suspected wound botulism.\n\nBotulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness caused by a nerve toxin that is produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Wound botulism is caused by a toxin produced in a wound infected with the same bacterium. Injecting heroin under the skin where there is little or no oxygen available allows the organism to grow and produce a deadly toxin that leads to progressive descending muscle paralysis and sometimes death. \"Healthcare providers need to consider wound botulism in patients who are showing symptoms, especially if they have a history of injection drug use,\" said DOH Secretary-Designate Dr. Tracie Collins. \"People who inject drugs should be aware of wound botulism and seek immediate medical attention if they are experiencing any signs or symptoms of the disease.\"\n\nSigns and symptoms of botulism include:\n- double vision\n- blurred vision\n- drooping eyelids\n- slurred speech\n- difficulty swallowing\n- dry mouth\n- muscle weakness/descending paralysis\n- difficulty breathing/shortness of breath\n\nIf left untreated, initial symptoms may progress to include paralysis of the respiratory muscles, arms, legs, and trunk with subsequent death.\n\nNMDOH encourages New Mexicans to:\n- report suspected cases of wound botulism to NMDOH 24/7/365 at (505) 827-0006. If the patient is hospitalized in New Mexico so that antitoxin can be obtained from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention if indicated\n- warn persons who inject drugs about wound botulism and inform them of the signs and symptoms and the need to seek medical care immediately\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Most drug-related cases of wound botulism are related to black tar heroin, which is injected subcutaneously instead of intravenously.\n\nBlack tar heroin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_tar_heroin) is heroin acetate. \"Other forms of heroin require additional steps of purification post acetylation. With black tar, the product's processing stops immediately after acetylation. Its unique consistency, however, is due to acetylation without a reflux apparatus. As in \"homebake heroin\" in Australia and New Zealand, the crude acetylation results in a gooey mass. Black tar as a type holds a variable admixture of morphine derivatives, predominantly 6-MAM (6-monoacetylmorphine), which is another result of crude acetylation. The lack of proper reflux during acetylation fails to remove much of the moisture retained in the acetylating agent, glacial acetic acid.\"\n\n\"Black tar heroin is often produced in Latin America and is most commonly found in the western and southern parts of the USA, while also being occasionally found in western Canada and Europe. It has a varying consistency depending on manufacturing methods, cutting agents, and moisture levels, ranging in quality from a black-brown tarry goo in unrefined form to a uniform, light-brown powder when further processed and cut with lactose.\n\n\"People who intravenously inject black tar heroin are at higher risk of venous sclerosis than those who inject powder heroin. In this condition, the veins narrow and harden, which makes repeated injection there nearly impossible. Researchers at University of California at San Francisco have found that the rapidity with which black tar heroin destroys veins, along with its gummier consistency, may put people who inject it at a lower risk of HIV infection because they may be forced to inject subcutaneously (rather than into veins), and needles must be thoroughly rinsed free of 'black tar' between injections if new sterilized ones are not available.\n\n\"The presence of 6-monoacetylcodeine found in tar heroin has not been tested in humans but has been shown to be toxic alone and more toxic when mixed with mono- or di-acetyl morphine, potentially making tar more toxic than refined diamorphine. At least one study has drawn attention to lower rates of HIV infection among drug injectors in which black tar heroin is the major form of street-available heroin, suggesting that this may be due to the need to heat black tar heroin to dissolve it (which also inactivates any HIV present in the solution).\n\n\"However, black tar heroin injectors can be at increased risk of life-threatening bacterial infections, in particular necrotizing soft tissue infection. The practice of 'skin-popping,' or subcutaneous injection, predisposes to necrotizing fasciitis or necrotizing cellulitis from _Clostridium perfringens_, while deep intramuscular injection predisposes to necrotizing myositis. Tar heroin injection can also be associated with _C. botulinum_ infection.\" - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nNew Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233]\nSee Also\n2020\n----\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, injection drug related 20190103.6241364\n2018\n----\nBotulism - Americas: canned corn, risk, recall 20181213.6208236\nBotulism - USA (08): (CA) 2017, MALDI-TOF MS 20181102.6123995\nBotulism - USA (07): cheese dip, risk, recall 20180804.5946643\nBotulism - USA (06): (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20180709.5895187\nBotulism - USA (02): (AK) 20180323.5706323\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20180214.5628631\n.................................................sb/ll/ao/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Eddy County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8211249", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - Iran: waterfowl", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8211249", "date": "2021-01-14 15:27:39", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: (NEW MEXICO) WOUND, DRUG RELATED\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Jan 2021\nSource: KRWG.org [edited]\nhttps://www.krwg.org/post/one-confirmed-case-and-one-suspected-case-wound-botulism-new-mexico\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) is investigating 1 confirmed case - and 1 suspected case - of wound botulism. A 28-year-old male from Eddy County is hospitalized with wound botulism. The suspected source of infection is contaminated black tar heroin, and the nerve toxin that causes botulism was identified from a patient specimen. Another 29-year-old male from Eddy County with a history of injection drug use is hospitalized with suspected wound botulism.\n\nBotulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness caused by a nerve toxin that is produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Wound botulism is caused by a toxin produced in a wound infected with the same bacterium. Injecting heroin under the skin where there is little or no oxygen available allows the organism to grow and produce a deadly toxin that leads to progressive descending muscle paralysis and sometimes death. \"Healthcare providers need to consider wound botulism in patients who are showing symptoms, especially if they have a history of injection drug use,\" said DOH Secretary-Designate Dr. Tracie Collins. \"People who inject drugs should be aware of wound botulism and seek immediate medical attention if they are experiencing any signs or symptoms of the disease.\"\n\nSigns and symptoms of botulism include:\n- double vision\n- blurred vision\n- drooping eyelids\n- slurred speech\n- difficulty swallowing\n- dry mouth\n- muscle weakness/descending paralysis\n- difficulty breathing/shortness of breath\n\nIf left untreated, initial symptoms may progress to include paralysis of the respiratory muscles, arms, legs, and trunk with subsequent death.\n\nNMDOH encourages New Mexicans to:\n- report suspected cases of wound botulism to NMDOH 24/7/365 at (505) 827-0006. If the patient is hospitalized in New Mexico so that antitoxin can be obtained from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention if indicated\n- warn persons who inject drugs about wound botulism and inform them of the signs and symptoms and the need to seek medical care immediately\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Most drug-related cases of wound botulism are related to black tar heroin, which is injected subcutaneously instead of intravenously.\n\nBlack tar heroin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_tar_heroin) is heroin acetate. \"Other forms of heroin require additional steps of purification post acetylation. With black tar, the product's processing stops immediately after acetylation. Its unique consistency, however, is due to acetylation without a reflux apparatus. As in \"homebake heroin\" in Australia and New Zealand, the crude acetylation results in a gooey mass. Black tar as a type holds a variable admixture of morphine derivatives, predominantly 6-MAM (6-monoacetylmorphine), which is another result of crude acetylation. The lack of proper reflux during acetylation fails to remove much of the moisture retained in the acetylating agent, glacial acetic acid.\"\n\n\"Black tar heroin is often produced in Latin America and is most commonly found in the western and southern parts of the USA, while also being occasionally found in western Canada and Europe. It has a varying consistency depending on manufacturing methods, cutting agents, and moisture levels, ranging in quality from a black-brown tarry goo in unrefined form to a uniform, light-brown powder when further processed and cut with lactose.\n\n\"People who intravenously inject black tar heroin are at higher risk of venous sclerosis than those who inject powder heroin. In this condition, the veins narrow and harden, which makes repeated injection there nearly impossible. Researchers at University of California at San Francisco have found that the rapidity with which black tar heroin destroys veins, along with its gummier consistency, may put people who inject it at a lower risk of HIV infection because they may be forced to inject subcutaneously (rather than into veins), and needles must be thoroughly rinsed free of 'black tar' between injections if new sterilized ones are not available.\n\n\"The presence of 6-monoacetylcodeine found in tar heroin has not been tested in humans but has been shown to be toxic alone and more toxic when mixed with mono- or di-acetyl morphine, potentially making tar more toxic than refined diamorphine. At least one study has drawn attention to lower rates of HIV infection among drug injectors in which black tar heroin is the major form of street-available heroin, suggesting that this may be due to the need to heat black tar heroin to dissolve it (which also inactivates any HIV present in the solution).\n\n\"However, black tar heroin injectors can be at increased risk of life-threatening bacterial infections, in particular necrotizing soft tissue infection. The practice of 'skin-popping,' or subcutaneous injection, predisposes to necrotizing fasciitis or necrotizing cellulitis from _Clostridium perfringens_, while deep intramuscular injection predisposes to necrotizing myositis. Tar heroin injection can also be associated with _C. botulinum_ infection.\" - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nNew Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233]\nSee Also\n2020\n----\nBotulism - Australia: (NS) injection drug related, possible iv route, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8194161", "date": "2021-01-14 15:27:39", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: (NEW MEXICO) WOUND, DRUG RELATED\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Jan 2021\nSource: KRWG.org [edited]\nhttps://www.krwg.org/post/one-confirmed-case-and-one-suspected-case-wound-botulism-new-mexico\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) is investigating 1 confirmed case - and 1 suspected case - of wound botulism. A 28-year-old male from Eddy County is hospitalized with wound botulism. The suspected source of infection is contaminated black tar heroin, and the nerve toxin that causes botulism was identified from a patient specimen. Another 29-year-old male from Eddy County with a history of injection drug use is hospitalized with suspected wound botulism.\n\nBotulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness caused by a nerve toxin that is produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Wound botulism is caused by a toxin produced in a wound infected with the same bacterium. Injecting heroin under the skin where there is little or no oxygen available allows the organism to grow and produce a deadly toxin that leads to progressive descending muscle paralysis and sometimes death. \"Healthcare providers need to consider wound botulism in patients who are showing symptoms, especially if they have a history of injection drug use,\" said DOH Secretary-Designate Dr. Tracie Collins. \"People who inject drugs should be aware of wound botulism and seek immediate medical attention if they are experiencing any signs or symptoms of the disease.\"\n\nSigns and symptoms of botulism include:\n- double vision\n- blurred vision\n- drooping eyelids\n- slurred speech\n- difficulty swallowing\n- dry mouth\n- muscle weakness/descending paralysis\n- difficulty breathing/shortness of breath\n\nIf left untreated, initial symptoms may progress to include paralysis of the respiratory muscles, arms, legs, and trunk with subsequent death.\n\nNMDOH encourages New Mexicans to:\n- report suspected cases of wound botulism to NMDOH 24/7/365 at (505) 827-0006. If the patient is hospitalized in New Mexico so that antitoxin can be obtained from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention if indicated\n- warn persons who inject drugs about wound botulism and inform them of the signs and symptoms and the need to seek medical care immediately\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Most drug-related cases of wound botulism are related to black tar heroin, which is injected subcutaneously instead of intravenously.\n\nBlack tar heroin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_tar_heroin) is heroin acetate. \"Other forms of heroin require additional steps of purification post acetylation. With black tar, the product's processing stops immediately after acetylation. Its unique consistency, however, is due to acetylation without a reflux apparatus. As in \"homebake heroin\" in Australia and New Zealand, the crude acetylation results in a gooey mass. Black tar as a type holds a variable admixture of morphine derivatives, predominantly 6-MAM (6-monoacetylmorphine), which is another result of crude acetylation. The lack of proper reflux during acetylation fails to remove much of the moisture retained in the acetylating agent, glacial acetic acid.\"\n\n\"Black tar heroin is often produced in Latin America and is most commonly found in the western and southern parts of the USA, while also being occasionally found in western Canada and Europe. It has a varying consistency depending on manufacturing methods, cutting agents, and moisture levels, ranging in quality from a black-brown tarry goo in unrefined form to a uniform, light-brown powder when further processed and cut with lactose.\n\n\"People who intravenously inject black tar heroin are at higher risk of venous sclerosis than those who inject powder heroin. In this condition, the veins narrow and harden, which makes repeated injection there nearly impossible. Researchers at University of California at San Francisco have found that the rapidity with which black tar heroin destroys veins, along with its gummier consistency, may put people who inject it at a lower risk of HIV infection because they may be forced to inject subcutaneously (rather than into veins), and needles must be thoroughly rinsed free of 'black tar' between injections if new sterilized ones are not available.\n\n\"The presence of 6-monoacetylcodeine found in tar heroin has not been tested in humans but has been shown to be toxic alone and more toxic when mixed with mono- or di-acetyl morphine, potentially making tar more toxic than refined diamorphine. At least one study has drawn attention to lower rates of HIV infection among drug injectors in which black tar heroin is the major form of street-available heroin, suggesting that this may be due to the need to heat black tar heroin to dissolve it (which also inactivates any HIV present in the solution).\n\n\"However, black tar heroin injectors can be at increased risk of life-threatening bacterial infections, in particular necrotizing soft tissue infection. The practice of 'skin-popping,' or subcutaneous injection, predisposes to necrotizing fasciitis or necrotizing cellulitis from _Clostridium perfringens_, while deep intramuscular injection predisposes to necrotizing myositis. Tar heroin injection can also be associated with _C. botulinum_ infection.\" - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nNew Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233]\nSee Also\n2020\n----\nBotulism - Uzbekistan: home canned tomatoes, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8190626", "date": "2021-01-14 15:27:39", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: (NEW MEXICO) WOUND, DRUG RELATED\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Jan 2021\nSource: KRWG.org [edited]\nhttps://www.krwg.org/post/one-confirmed-case-and-one-suspected-case-wound-botulism-new-mexico\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) is investigating 1 confirmed case - and 1 suspected case - of wound botulism. A 28-year-old male from Eddy County is hospitalized with wound botulism. The suspected source of infection is contaminated black tar heroin, and the nerve toxin that causes botulism was identified from a patient specimen. Another 29-year-old male from Eddy County with a history of injection drug use is hospitalized with suspected wound botulism.\n\nBotulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness caused by a nerve toxin that is produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Wound botulism is caused by a toxin produced in a wound infected with the same bacterium. Injecting heroin under the skin where there is little or no oxygen available allows the organism to grow and produce a deadly toxin that leads to progressive descending muscle paralysis and sometimes death. \"Healthcare providers need to consider wound botulism in patients who are showing symptoms, especially if they have a history of injection drug use,\" said DOH Secretary-Designate Dr. Tracie Collins. \"People who inject drugs should be aware of wound botulism and seek immediate medical attention if they are experiencing any signs or symptoms of the disease.\"\n\nSigns and symptoms of botulism include:\n- double vision\n- blurred vision\n- drooping eyelids\n- slurred speech\n- difficulty swallowing\n- dry mouth\n- muscle weakness/descending paralysis\n- difficulty breathing/shortness of breath\n\nIf left untreated, initial symptoms may progress to include paralysis of the respiratory muscles, arms, legs, and trunk with subsequent death.\n\nNMDOH encourages New Mexicans to:\n- report suspected cases of wound botulism to NMDOH 24/7/365 at (505) 827-0006. If the patient is hospitalized in New Mexico so that antitoxin can be obtained from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention if indicated\n- warn persons who inject drugs about wound botulism and inform them of the signs and symptoms and the need to seek medical care immediately\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Most drug-related cases of wound botulism are related to black tar heroin, which is injected subcutaneously instead of intravenously.\n\nBlack tar heroin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_tar_heroin) is heroin acetate. \"Other forms of heroin require additional steps of purification post acetylation. With black tar, the product's processing stops immediately after acetylation. Its unique consistency, however, is due to acetylation without a reflux apparatus. As in \"homebake heroin\" in Australia and New Zealand, the crude acetylation results in a gooey mass. Black tar as a type holds a variable admixture of morphine derivatives, predominantly 6-MAM (6-monoacetylmorphine), which is another result of crude acetylation. The lack of proper reflux during acetylation fails to remove much of the moisture retained in the acetylating agent, glacial acetic acid.\"\n\n\"Black tar heroin is often produced in Latin America and is most commonly found in the western and southern parts of the USA, while also being occasionally found in western Canada and Europe. It has a varying consistency depending on manufacturing methods, cutting agents, and moisture levels, ranging in quality from a black-brown tarry goo in unrefined form to a uniform, light-brown powder when further processed and cut with lactose.\n\n\"People who intravenously inject black tar heroin are at higher risk of venous sclerosis than those who inject powder heroin. In this condition, the veins narrow and harden, which makes repeated injection there nearly impossible. Researchers at University of California at San Francisco have found that the rapidity with which black tar heroin destroys veins, along with its gummier consistency, may put people who inject it at a lower risk of HIV infection because they may be forced to inject subcutaneously (rather than into veins), and needles must be thoroughly rinsed free of 'black tar' between injections if new sterilized ones are not available.\n\n\"The presence of 6-monoacetylcodeine found in tar heroin has not been tested in humans but has been shown to be toxic alone and more toxic when mixed with mono- or di-acetyl morphine, potentially making tar more toxic than refined diamorphine. At least one study has drawn attention to lower rates of HIV infection among drug injectors in which black tar heroin is the major form of street-available heroin, suggesting that this may be due to the need to heat black tar heroin to dissolve it (which also inactivates any HIV present in the solution).\n\n\"However, black tar heroin injectors can be at increased risk of life-threatening bacterial infections, in particular necrotizing soft tissue infection. The practice of 'skin-popping,' or subcutaneous injection, predisposes to necrotizing fasciitis or necrotizing cellulitis from _Clostridium perfringens_, while deep intramuscular injection predisposes to necrotizing myositis. Tar heroin injection can also be associated with _C. botulinum_ infection.\" - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nNew Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233]\nSee Also\n2020\n----\nBotulism - USA (08): (CO) 20201203.7990724\nBotulism - USA (07): (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20201110.7932451\nBotulism - USA (06): (RI) sea moss products, risk, recall 20201004.7835366\nBotulism - USA (05): (NJ) wound, injection drug related 20201001.7829272\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, injection drug related 20190103.6241364\n2018\n----\nBotulism - Americas: canned corn, risk, recall 20181213.6208236\nBotulism - USA (08): (CA) 2017, MALDI-TOF MS 20181102.6123995\nBotulism - USA (07): cheese dip, risk, recall 20180804.5946643\nBotulism - USA (06): (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20180709.5895187\nBotulism - USA (02): (AK) 20180323.5706323\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20180214.5628631\n.................................................sb/ll/ao/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Eddy County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8173529", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Infant botulism - USA: (ND)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8173529", "date": "2021-01-14 15:27:39", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: (NEW MEXICO) WOUND, DRUG RELATED\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Jan 2021\nSource: KRWG.org [edited]\nhttps://www.krwg.org/post/one-confirmed-case-and-one-suspected-case-wound-botulism-new-mexico\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) is investigating 1 confirmed case - and 1 suspected case - of wound botulism. A 28-year-old male from Eddy County is hospitalized with wound botulism. The suspected source of infection is contaminated black tar heroin, and the nerve toxin that causes botulism was identified from a patient specimen. Another 29-year-old male from Eddy County with a history of injection drug use is hospitalized with suspected wound botulism.\n\nBotulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness caused by a nerve toxin that is produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Wound botulism is caused by a toxin produced in a wound infected with the same bacterium. Injecting heroin under the skin where there is little or no oxygen available allows the organism to grow and produce a deadly toxin that leads to progressive descending muscle paralysis and sometimes death. \"Healthcare providers need to consider wound botulism in patients who are showing symptoms, especially if they have a history of injection drug use,\" said DOH Secretary-Designate Dr. Tracie Collins. \"People who inject drugs should be aware of wound botulism and seek immediate medical attention if they are experiencing any signs or symptoms of the disease.\"\n\nSigns and symptoms of botulism include:\n- double vision\n- blurred vision\n- drooping eyelids\n- slurred speech\n- difficulty swallowing\n- dry mouth\n- muscle weakness/descending paralysis\n- difficulty breathing/shortness of breath\n\nIf left untreated, initial symptoms may progress to include paralysis of the respiratory muscles, arms, legs, and trunk with subsequent death.\n\nNMDOH encourages New Mexicans to:\n- report suspected cases of wound botulism to NMDOH 24/7/365 at (505) 827-0006. If the patient is hospitalized in New Mexico so that antitoxin can be obtained from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention if indicated\n- warn persons who inject drugs about wound botulism and inform them of the signs and symptoms and the need to seek medical care immediately\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Most drug-related cases of wound botulism are related to black tar heroin, which is injected subcutaneously instead of intravenously.\n\nBlack tar heroin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_tar_heroin) is heroin acetate. \"Other forms of heroin require additional steps of purification post acetylation. With black tar, the product's processing stops immediately after acetylation. Its unique consistency, however, is due to acetylation without a reflux apparatus. As in \"homebake heroin\" in Australia and New Zealand, the crude acetylation results in a gooey mass. Black tar as a type holds a variable admixture of morphine derivatives, predominantly 6-MAM (6-monoacetylmorphine), which is another result of crude acetylation. The lack of proper reflux during acetylation fails to remove much of the moisture retained in the acetylating agent, glacial acetic acid.\"\n\n\"Black tar heroin is often produced in Latin America and is most commonly found in the western and southern parts of the USA, while also being occasionally found in western Canada and Europe. It has a varying consistency depending on manufacturing methods, cutting agents, and moisture levels, ranging in quality from a black-brown tarry goo in unrefined form to a uniform, light-brown powder when further processed and cut with lactose.\n\n\"People who intravenously inject black tar heroin are at higher risk of venous sclerosis than those who inject powder heroin. In this condition, the veins narrow and harden, which makes repeated injection there nearly impossible. Researchers at University of California at San Francisco have found that the rapidity with which black tar heroin destroys veins, along with its gummier consistency, may put people who inject it at a lower risk of HIV infection because they may be forced to inject subcutaneously (rather than into veins), and needles must be thoroughly rinsed free of 'black tar' between injections if new sterilized ones are not available.\n\n\"The presence of 6-monoacetylcodeine found in tar heroin has not been tested in humans but has been shown to be toxic alone and more toxic when mixed with mono- or di-acetyl morphine, potentially making tar more toxic than refined diamorphine. At least one study has drawn attention to lower rates of HIV infection among drug injectors in which black tar heroin is the major form of street-available heroin, suggesting that this may be due to the need to heat black tar heroin to dissolve it (which also inactivates any HIV present in the solution).\n\n\"However, black tar heroin injectors can be at increased risk of life-threatening bacterial infections, in particular necrotizing soft tissue infection. The practice of 'skin-popping,' or subcutaneous injection, predisposes to necrotizing fasciitis or necrotizing cellulitis from _Clostridium perfringens_, while deep intramuscular injection predisposes to necrotizing myositis. Tar heroin injection can also be associated with _C. botulinum_ infection.\" - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nNew Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233]\nSee Also\n2020\n----\nBotulism - USA: (NM) wound, injection drug related", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8102850", "date": "2021-01-14 15:27:39", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: (NEW MEXICO) WOUND, DRUG RELATED\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Jan 2021\nSource: KRWG.org [edited]\nhttps://www.krwg.org/post/one-confirmed-case-and-one-suspected-case-wound-botulism-new-mexico\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) is investigating 1 confirmed case - and 1 suspected case - of wound botulism. A 28-year-old male from Eddy County is hospitalized with wound botulism. The suspected source of infection is contaminated black tar heroin, and the nerve toxin that causes botulism was identified from a patient specimen. Another 29-year-old male from Eddy County with a history of injection drug use is hospitalized with suspected wound botulism.\n\nBotulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness caused by a nerve toxin that is produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Wound botulism is caused by a toxin produced in a wound infected with the same bacterium. Injecting heroin under the skin where there is little or no oxygen available allows the organism to grow and produce a deadly toxin that leads to progressive descending muscle paralysis and sometimes death. \"Healthcare providers need to consider wound botulism in patients who are showing symptoms, especially if they have a history of injection drug use,\" said DOH Secretary-Designate Dr. Tracie Collins. \"People who inject drugs should be aware of wound botulism and seek immediate medical attention if they are experiencing any signs or symptoms of the disease.\"\n\nSigns and symptoms of botulism include:\n- double vision\n- blurred vision\n- drooping eyelids\n- slurred speech\n- difficulty swallowing\n- dry mouth\n- muscle weakness/descending paralysis\n- difficulty breathing/shortness of breath\n\nIf left untreated, initial symptoms may progress to include paralysis of the respiratory muscles, arms, legs, and trunk with subsequent death.\n\nNMDOH encourages New Mexicans to:\n- report suspected cases of wound botulism to NMDOH 24/7/365 at (505) 827-0006. If the patient is hospitalized in New Mexico so that antitoxin can be obtained from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention if indicated\n- warn persons who inject drugs about wound botulism and inform them of the signs and symptoms and the need to seek medical care immediately\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Most drug-related cases of wound botulism are related to black tar heroin, which is injected subcutaneously instead of intravenously.\n\nBlack tar heroin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_tar_heroin) is heroin acetate. \"Other forms of heroin require additional steps of purification post acetylation. With black tar, the product's processing stops immediately after acetylation. Its unique consistency, however, is due to acetylation without a reflux apparatus. As in \"homebake heroin\" in Australia and New Zealand, the crude acetylation results in a gooey mass. Black tar as a type holds a variable admixture of morphine derivatives, predominantly 6-MAM (6-monoacetylmorphine), which is another result of crude acetylation. The lack of proper reflux during acetylation fails to remove much of the moisture retained in the acetylating agent, glacial acetic acid.\"\n\n\"Black tar heroin is often produced in Latin America and is most commonly found in the western and southern parts of the USA, while also being occasionally found in western Canada and Europe. It has a varying consistency depending on manufacturing methods, cutting agents, and moisture levels, ranging in quality from a black-brown tarry goo in unrefined form to a uniform, light-brown powder when further processed and cut with lactose.\n\n\"People who intravenously inject black tar heroin are at higher risk of venous sclerosis than those who inject powder heroin. In this condition, the veins narrow and harden, which makes repeated injection there nearly impossible. Researchers at University of California at San Francisco have found that the rapidity with which black tar heroin destroys veins, along with its gummier consistency, may put people who inject it at a lower risk of HIV infection because they may be forced to inject subcutaneously (rather than into veins), and needles must be thoroughly rinsed free of 'black tar' between injections if new sterilized ones are not available.\n\n\"The presence of 6-monoacetylcodeine found in tar heroin has not been tested in humans but has been shown to be toxic alone and more toxic when mixed with mono- or di-acetyl morphine, potentially making tar more toxic than refined diamorphine. At least one study has drawn attention to lower rates of HIV infection among drug injectors in which black tar heroin is the major form of street-available heroin, suggesting that this may be due to the need to heat black tar heroin to dissolve it (which also inactivates any HIV present in the solution).\n\n\"However, black tar heroin injectors can be at increased risk of life-threatening bacterial infections, in particular necrotizing soft tissue infection. The practice of 'skin-popping,' or subcutaneous injection, predisposes to necrotizing fasciitis or necrotizing cellulitis from _Clostridium perfringens_, while deep intramuscular injection predisposes to necrotizing myositis. Tar heroin injection can also be associated with _C. botulinum_ infection.\" - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nNew Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233]\nSee Also\n2020\n----\nBotulism - USA (08): (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7990724", "date": "2021-01-14 15:27:39", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: (NEW MEXICO) WOUND, DRUG RELATED\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Jan 2021\nSource: KRWG.org [edited]\nhttps://www.krwg.org/post/one-confirmed-case-and-one-suspected-case-wound-botulism-new-mexico\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) is investigating 1 confirmed case - and 1 suspected case - of wound botulism. A 28-year-old male from Eddy County is hospitalized with wound botulism. The suspected source of infection is contaminated black tar heroin, and the nerve toxin that causes botulism was identified from a patient specimen. Another 29-year-old male from Eddy County with a history of injection drug use is hospitalized with suspected wound botulism.\n\nBotulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness caused by a nerve toxin that is produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Wound botulism is caused by a toxin produced in a wound infected with the same bacterium. Injecting heroin under the skin where there is little or no oxygen available allows the organism to grow and produce a deadly toxin that leads to progressive descending muscle paralysis and sometimes death. \"Healthcare providers need to consider wound botulism in patients who are showing symptoms, especially if they have a history of injection drug use,\" said DOH Secretary-Designate Dr. Tracie Collins. \"People who inject drugs should be aware of wound botulism and seek immediate medical attention if they are experiencing any signs or symptoms of the disease.\"\n\nSigns and symptoms of botulism include:\n- double vision\n- blurred vision\n- drooping eyelids\n- slurred speech\n- difficulty swallowing\n- dry mouth\n- muscle weakness/descending paralysis\n- difficulty breathing/shortness of breath\n\nIf left untreated, initial symptoms may progress to include paralysis of the respiratory muscles, arms, legs, and trunk with subsequent death.\n\nNMDOH encourages New Mexicans to:\n- report suspected cases of wound botulism to NMDOH 24/7/365 at (505) 827-0006. If the patient is hospitalized in New Mexico so that antitoxin can be obtained from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention if indicated\n- warn persons who inject drugs about wound botulism and inform them of the signs and symptoms and the need to seek medical care immediately\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Most drug-related cases of wound botulism are related to black tar heroin, which is injected subcutaneously instead of intravenously.\n\nBlack tar heroin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_tar_heroin) is heroin acetate. \"Other forms of heroin require additional steps of purification post acetylation. With black tar, the product's processing stops immediately after acetylation. Its unique consistency, however, is due to acetylation without a reflux apparatus. As in \"homebake heroin\" in Australia and New Zealand, the crude acetylation results in a gooey mass. Black tar as a type holds a variable admixture of morphine derivatives, predominantly 6-MAM (6-monoacetylmorphine), which is another result of crude acetylation. The lack of proper reflux during acetylation fails to remove much of the moisture retained in the acetylating agent, glacial acetic acid.\"\n\n\"Black tar heroin is often produced in Latin America and is most commonly found in the western and southern parts of the USA, while also being occasionally found in western Canada and Europe. It has a varying consistency depending on manufacturing methods, cutting agents, and moisture levels, ranging in quality from a black-brown tarry goo in unrefined form to a uniform, light-brown powder when further processed and cut with lactose.\n\n\"People who intravenously inject black tar heroin are at higher risk of venous sclerosis than those who inject powder heroin. In this condition, the veins narrow and harden, which makes repeated injection there nearly impossible. Researchers at University of California at San Francisco have found that the rapidity with which black tar heroin destroys veins, along with its gummier consistency, may put people who inject it at a lower risk of HIV infection because they may be forced to inject subcutaneously (rather than into veins), and needles must be thoroughly rinsed free of 'black tar' between injections if new sterilized ones are not available.\n\n\"The presence of 6-monoacetylcodeine found in tar heroin has not been tested in humans but has been shown to be toxic alone and more toxic when mixed with mono- or di-acetyl morphine, potentially making tar more toxic than refined diamorphine. At least one study has drawn attention to lower rates of HIV infection among drug injectors in which black tar heroin is the major form of street-available heroin, suggesting that this may be due to the need to heat black tar heroin to dissolve it (which also inactivates any HIV present in the solution).\n\n\"However, black tar heroin injectors can be at increased risk of life-threatening bacterial infections, in particular necrotizing soft tissue infection. The practice of 'skin-popping,' or subcutaneous injection, predisposes to necrotizing fasciitis or necrotizing cellulitis from _Clostridium perfringens_, while deep intramuscular injection predisposes to necrotizing myositis. Tar heroin injection can also be associated with _C. botulinum_ infection.\" - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nNew Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233]\nSee Also\n2020\n----\nBotulism - USA (05): (MD) 20190610.6511664\nBotulism - USA (04): (NM) wound, injection drug related 20190521.6479177\nBotulism - USA (03): (NYC) home-canned peas 20190315.6367720\nBotulism - USA (02): (AK) fermented whale flipper 20190206.6303507\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, injection drug related 20190103.6241364\n2018\n----\nBotulism - Americas: canned corn, risk, recall 20181213.6208236\nBotulism - USA (08): (CA) 2017, MALDI-TOF MS 20181102.6123995\nBotulism - USA (07): cheese dip, risk, recall 20180804.5946643\nBotulism - USA (06): (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20180709.5895187\nBotulism - USA (02): (AK) 20180323.5706323\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20180214.5628631\n.................................................sb/ll/ao/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Eddy County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7974357", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Kyrgyzstan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7974357", "date": "2021-01-14 15:27:39", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: (NEW MEXICO) WOUND, DRUG RELATED\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Jan 2021\nSource: KRWG.org [edited]\nhttps://www.krwg.org/post/one-confirmed-case-and-one-suspected-case-wound-botulism-new-mexico\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) is investigating 1 confirmed case - and 1 suspected case - of wound botulism. A 28-year-old male from Eddy County is hospitalized with wound botulism. The suspected source of infection is contaminated black tar heroin, and the nerve toxin that causes botulism was identified from a patient specimen. Another 29-year-old male from Eddy County with a history of injection drug use is hospitalized with suspected wound botulism.\n\nBotulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness caused by a nerve toxin that is produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Wound botulism is caused by a toxin produced in a wound infected with the same bacterium. Injecting heroin under the skin where there is little or no oxygen available allows the organism to grow and produce a deadly toxin that leads to progressive descending muscle paralysis and sometimes death. \"Healthcare providers need to consider wound botulism in patients who are showing symptoms, especially if they have a history of injection drug use,\" said DOH Secretary-Designate Dr. Tracie Collins. \"People who inject drugs should be aware of wound botulism and seek immediate medical attention if they are experiencing any signs or symptoms of the disease.\"\n\nSigns and symptoms of botulism include:\n- double vision\n- blurred vision\n- drooping eyelids\n- slurred speech\n- difficulty swallowing\n- dry mouth\n- muscle weakness/descending paralysis\n- difficulty breathing/shortness of breath\n\nIf left untreated, initial symptoms may progress to include paralysis of the respiratory muscles, arms, legs, and trunk with subsequent death.\n\nNMDOH encourages New Mexicans to:\n- report suspected cases of wound botulism to NMDOH 24/7/365 at (505) 827-0006. If the patient is hospitalized in New Mexico so that antitoxin can be obtained from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention if indicated\n- warn persons who inject drugs about wound botulism and inform them of the signs and symptoms and the need to seek medical care immediately\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Most drug-related cases of wound botulism are related to black tar heroin, which is injected subcutaneously instead of intravenously.\n\nBlack tar heroin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_tar_heroin) is heroin acetate. \"Other forms of heroin require additional steps of purification post acetylation. With black tar, the product's processing stops immediately after acetylation. Its unique consistency, however, is due to acetylation without a reflux apparatus. As in \"homebake heroin\" in Australia and New Zealand, the crude acetylation results in a gooey mass. Black tar as a type holds a variable admixture of morphine derivatives, predominantly 6-MAM (6-monoacetylmorphine), which is another result of crude acetylation. The lack of proper reflux during acetylation fails to remove much of the moisture retained in the acetylating agent, glacial acetic acid.\"\n\n\"Black tar heroin is often produced in Latin America and is most commonly found in the western and southern parts of the USA, while also being occasionally found in western Canada and Europe. It has a varying consistency depending on manufacturing methods, cutting agents, and moisture levels, ranging in quality from a black-brown tarry goo in unrefined form to a uniform, light-brown powder when further processed and cut with lactose.\n\n\"People who intravenously inject black tar heroin are at higher risk of venous sclerosis than those who inject powder heroin. In this condition, the veins narrow and harden, which makes repeated injection there nearly impossible. Researchers at University of California at San Francisco have found that the rapidity with which black tar heroin destroys veins, along with its gummier consistency, may put people who inject it at a lower risk of HIV infection because they may be forced to inject subcutaneously (rather than into veins), and needles must be thoroughly rinsed free of 'black tar' between injections if new sterilized ones are not available.\n\n\"The presence of 6-monoacetylcodeine found in tar heroin has not been tested in humans but has been shown to be toxic alone and more toxic when mixed with mono- or di-acetyl morphine, potentially making tar more toxic than refined diamorphine. At least one study has drawn attention to lower rates of HIV infection among drug injectors in which black tar heroin is the major form of street-available heroin, suggesting that this may be due to the need to heat black tar heroin to dissolve it (which also inactivates any HIV present in the solution).\n\n\"However, black tar heroin injectors can be at increased risk of life-threatening bacterial infections, in particular necrotizing soft tissue infection. The practice of 'skin-popping,' or subcutaneous injection, predisposes to necrotizing fasciitis or necrotizing cellulitis from _Clostridium perfringens_, while deep intramuscular injection predisposes to necrotizing myositis. Tar heroin injection can also be associated with _C. botulinum_ infection.\" - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nNew Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233]\nSee Also\n2020\n----\nBotulism - USA (08): (CO) 20201203.7990724\nBotulism - USA (07): (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20201110.7932451\nBotulism - USA (06): (RI) sea moss products, risk, recall 20201004.7835366\nBotulism - USA (05): (NJ) wound, injection drug related 20201001.7829272\nBotulism - USA (04): (NM) wound, injection drug related 20200818.7689221\nBotulism - USA (03): pet food recall 20200326.7142954\nBotulism - USA (02): (AK) home canned salmon 20200106.6874215\nBotulism - USA: (TX) improperly stored cooked potatoes, fatal 20200105.6872265\n2019\n----\nBotulism - USA (08): (NM) wound, injection drug related 20191116.6782208\nBotulism - USA (07): (NJ) fermented, salt cured fish 20191113.6773367\nBotulism - USA (06): caviar, risk, recall 20190924.6692113\nBotulism - USA (05): (MD) 20190610.6511664\nBotulism - USA (04): (NM) wound, injection drug related 20190521.6479177\nBotulism - USA (03): (NYC) home-canned peas 20190315.6367720\nBotulism - USA (02): (AK) fermented whale flipper 20190206.6303507\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, injection drug related 20190103.6241364\n2018\n----\nBotulism - Americas: canned corn, risk, recall 20181213.6208236\nBotulism - USA (08): (CA) 2017, MALDI-TOF MS 20181102.6123995\nBotulism - USA (07): cheese dip, risk, recall 20180804.5946643\nBotulism - USA (06): (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20180709.5895187\nBotulism - USA (02): (AK) 20180323.5706323\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20180214.5628631\n.................................................sb/ll/ao/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Eddy County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7932451", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - USA (07): (CA) wound, injection drug-related", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7932451", "date": "2020-09-14 10:22:32", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - USA: (CALIFORNIA) GULL, TYPE A\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 10 Sep 2020\nSource: Audubon [edited]\nhttps://www.audubon.org/news/a-disease-outbreak-california-has-killed-estimated-40000-birds\n\n\nA disease outbreak in California has killed an estimated 40 000 birds\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nFirst, an infected bird may lose the ability to walk. Its wings often go next. Finally, its neck goes limp and it drowns.\n\nThis is the sad scene that Caroline Brady, a biologist with the California Waterfowl Association, has observed often this summer [2020]. As wildfires burn across the state, temperatures hit record highs, and communities cope with the COVID-19 crisis, she is helping respond to a different disaster: the worst avian botulism outbreak that anyone can remember at the Klamath Basin National Wildlife Refuge Complex.\n\nThere, thousands of acres of wetland and marsh that should be rich and verdant havens for millions of migrating waterfowl and shorebirds have become a wasteland of dried-up mud ponds strewn with dead ducks, geese, and other victims of avian botulism. Caused by toxin-producing bacteria, the disease -- which is different from the botulism that can infect canned foods -- tends to affect wetlands lacking flowing water that is cool, clean, and aerated. Thanks to drought and limited water deliveries, that's exactly what's missing this summer from much of the refuge.\n\nTo make a bad situation worse, a wildfire storm stalled the botulism response effort. Because firefighting helicopters were scooping water from the refuge to dump on the nearby Caldwell fire, refuge staff were barred from entering even as the disease began to spread. \"The disease outbreak had 2 weeks to fester before anyone was allowed to go in at all,\" Brady explains.\n\nAvian botulism is a regular problem of the Klamath system, which comprises 6 refuges managed by the US Fish and Wildlife Service. A local wildlife care center handled 494 sick birds in 2018 and 233 last year [2019], according to January Bill, founder of the organization Bird Ally X, which runs the refuge's so-called \"Duck Hospital.\" But this summer, between mid-July and early September [2020], her facility had received more than 2750 birds of several dozen species, including mallard, green-winged teal, gadwall, northern pintail, and northern shoveler. \"So, this year is out of control,\" she says.\n\nBill and her team, working in the makeshift field hospital of PVC-framed tents and shallow swimming pools for the birds, have successfully rehabilitated at least 90 percent of their patients and returned them to the wild in botulism-free parts of the refuge. However, the death toll of both waterfowl and shorebirds that don't make it to the facility is soaring off the charts. Field surveyors have collected about 20 000 dead birds, and they guess at least twice that many have perished.\n\n\"Back in the tule reeds, there are sometimes 10 dead birds all on top of each other,\" says Brady, who has personally collected several thousand birds since July [2020]. Removing the carcasses is important; if left in place, they quickly produce fly larvae which carry the disease and can spread it to other birds that eat the small worms. The disease thrives in warm temperatures, and refuge managers don't expect it to disappear until autumn brings subfreezing nighttime lows.\n\nThe disaster comes after a dry spring and summer and highlights challenges in sustainably and equitably using the Klamath River's water. Fish, birds, and other wildlife depend on the resource. So do thousands of local farmers, who grow crops like potatoes, horseradish, hay, and barley.\n\nTo provide water for these users, the US Bureau of Reclamation releases flows from southern Oregon's Upper Klamath Lake, a natural waterway that serves as the basin's major holding pond. The agency also must retain enough water in the lake to support 2 species of endangered suckers. This arrangement, Bureau critics argue, hasn't helped the fish much, and it has many stakeholders feeling shortchanged. In the lower reaches of the watershed, salmon runs have dwindled in part for lack of water, creating dissent among tribal communities and fishing interests. Farmers often want more water, too. In late spring [2020], Klamath Basin growers staged a protest of the Bureau's plans, announced in April, to reduce agricultural allocations.\n\nBut, as in many river basins in the arid West, the Klamath's water has been overallocated to users, leaving insufficient flows for the basin's aquatic ecosystems. Climate change, which is worsening drought conditions and diminishing the mountain snowpack that feeds the Klamath's tributaries, is likely to aggravate the situation.\n\nAmid these challenges, birds are also having a tough time. The Klamath's water allocation system places the basin's refuges last in line to receive flows, which can magnify impacts in dry years like 2020. This summer, the shrinkage of the refuge's wetlands has forced flocks of passing birds to aggregate tightly in warm stagnant water --perfect conditions for a botulism outbreak.\n\nTo try and stave off disaster, the Bureau of Reclamation in August [2020] released an emergency delivery of 4000 acre-feet of water, following a 4600-acre-foot release in July [2020], according to Mary Lee Knecht, a public affairs officer with the agency. It wasn't enough, though, and as the crisis escalated in early September, the Bureau announced it would release another shot of 5400 acre-feet water for the refuge. Altogether, the releases were but a trifle in the grand scheme of Klamath's water equation. Farmers, for instance, are receiving 147 000 acre-feet this year [2020].\n\nAt the US Fish and Wildlife Service, Greg Austin, the manager of the Klamath Basin refuge complex, said in an email that he and his agency \"appreciate every drop of water that [the Bureau of] Reclamation can make available.\" The water, he explains, will help keep portions of the refuge wet for a few more weeks as they wait for freezing temperatures to halt the disease's life cycle.\n\nMeghan Hertel, Audubon California's director of land and water conservation, visited the plague-stricken refuge in late August [2020] when daytime temperatures peaked around 100 deg F [37.8 deg C]. \"It was almost totally dry out there,\" she says. \"There were a few waterholes crammed with birds.\"\n\nHertel and colleagues have been advocating for allowing more water onto important bird refuges for years, both here in the Klamath system and farther south, in the San Joaquin Valley, where refuges are chronically shortchanged the water they're supposed to receive. As droughts, heat waves, and a growing human population add extra strain to water-dependent ecosystems like the Klamath Basin's wetlands, Hertel worries that, unless water allocation policies change, crises like the one now affecting the Klamath refuge will recur with greater frequency and intensity.\n\n\"This die-off should be a wakeup call for all the local stakeholders to sit down and think about how we can get more water out to the refuges,\" she says. \"Putting water out on this landscape is not wasting water.\"\n\n[Byline: Alastair Bland]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin.\n\nSeven immunologically distinct toxins, designated by the letters A to G, are produced by different strains, which are classified into toxinotypes A-G according to the type of toxin produced. Birds (poultry and waterfowl) are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E. Type C toxin is found in waterfowl, shorebirds, colonial waterbirds, and others; whereas type E toxin in gulls, loons, and others. Types A, B, E, and rarely F, cause human botulism. Types C, D, and E cause illness in other mammals, birds, and fish. Type A toxin occasionally causes botulism in domestic chickens. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map of California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/67494]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian - UK: (England) waterfowl, susp. 20200702.7534053\n2019\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA): (CA) gulls, type A 20191112.6774695\n2018\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA: (Lake Michigan) waterfowl, ecology, 2010-2013 20180109.5547447\n2017\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (06): (NJ) waterfowl 20170808.5235811\nBotulism, avian - USA (05): (MI) 20161210.4688849\nBotulism, avian - USA (04): (NC) waterfowl, susp 20160917.4493210\nBotulism, avian - USA (03): (CO) waterfowl, susp 20160912.4482343\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): (MI) waterfowl, susp. 20160711.4338263\nBotulism, avian - USA: (HI) waterfowl, susp 20160413.4157521\n2015\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA: (NY) 20151122.3810135\nBird die-off, avian - New Zealand: botulism susp. 20150219.3177259\n2014\n----\nBotulism, avian - UK (04): (England) aquatic birds 20140822.2713361\nBotulism, avian - UK (03): (England) aquatic birds 20140806.2665651\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): (MI) waterfowl 20140815.2691474\nDie-off, avian - Iceland: (VL) botulism susp., RFI 20140708.2594607\nBotulism, avian - UK: (England) aquatic birds, susp 20140728.2640790\nBotulism, avian - New Zealand (02): (WK) conf 20140409.2393357\nBotulism, avian - New Zealand: (WK) susp. 20140321.2346753\n2013\n----\nBotulism, avian - South Africa: (NC) susp 20131219.2125797\nBotulism, avian - USA (04): (NY) waterfowl 20131207.2097589\nBotulism, avian - USA (03): (ID) waterfowl 20131011.1997409\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): (CA) waterfowl 20130831.1915521\nBotulism, avian - USA: (MI) loon 20130807.1869158\n2012\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (09): (MI) aquatic birds, susp. 20121024.1360129\nBotulism, avian - USA (08): (WI, OR) aquatic birds 20120925.1309132\nBotulism, avian - USA (07): (MI) aquatic birds 20120912.1290085\nBotulism, avian - USA (06): (MD) aquatic birds 20120829.1271009\nBotulism, avian - USA (05): (WY) pheasants 20120824.1262052\nBotulism, avian - USA (04): (CA) waterfowl, susp. 20120802.1225667\nBotulism, avian - USA (03): (OH) waterfowl, susp 20120706.1192230\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): (HI) 20120624.1178706\nBotulism, avian - USA: (CA) 20120430.1117985\n.................................................sb/pmb/mj/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-04-15 00:00:00", "2021-08-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Joaquin Valley", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Bureau", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7840852", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Italy: (SC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7840852", "date": "2020-09-14 10:22:32", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - USA: (CALIFORNIA) GULL, TYPE A\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 10 Sep 2020\nSource: Audubon [edited]\nhttps://www.audubon.org/news/a-disease-outbreak-california-has-killed-estimated-40000-birds\n\n\nA disease outbreak in California has killed an estimated 40 000 birds\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nFirst, an infected bird may lose the ability to walk. This summer, the shrinkage of the refuge's wetlands has forced flocks of passing birds to aggregate tightly in warm stagnant water --perfect conditions for a botulism outbreak.\n\nTo try and stave off disaster, the Bureau of Reclamation in August [2020] released an emergency delivery of 4000 acre-feet of water, following a 4600-acre-foot release in July [2020], according to Mary Lee Knecht, a public affairs officer with the agency. It wasn't enough, though, and as the crisis escalated in early September, the Bureau announced it would release another shot of 5400 acre-feet water for the refuge. Altogether, the releases were but a trifle in the grand scheme of Klamath's water equation. Farmers, for instance, are receiving 147 000 acre-feet this year [2020].\n\nAt the US Fish and Wildlife Service, Greg Austin, the manager of the Klamath Basin refuge complex, said in an email that he and his agency \"appreciate every drop of water that [the Bureau of] Reclamation can make available.\" The water, he explains, will help keep portions of the refuge wet for a few more weeks as they wait for freezing temperatures to halt the disease's life cycle.\n\nMeghan Hertel, Audubon California's director of land and water conservation, visited the plague-stricken refuge in late August [2020] when daytime temperatures peaked around 100 deg F [37.8 deg C]. \"It was almost totally dry out there,\" she says. \"There were a few waterholes crammed with birds.\"\n\nHertel and colleagues have been advocating for allowing more water onto important bird refuges for years, both here in the Klamath system and farther south, in the San Joaquin Valley, where refuges are chronically shortchanged the water they're supposed to receive. As droughts, heat waves, and a growing human population add extra strain to water-dependent ecosystems like the Klamath Basin's wetlands, Hertel worries that, unless water allocation policies change, crises like the one now affecting the Klamath refuge will recur with greater frequency and intensity.\n\n\"This die-off should be a wakeup call for all the local stakeholders to sit down and think about how we can get more water out to the refuges,\" she says. \"Putting water out on this landscape is not wasting water.\"\n\n[Byline: Alastair Bland]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin.\n\nSeven immunologically distinct toxins, designated by the letters A to G, are produced by different strains, which are classified into toxinotypes A-G according to the type of toxin produced. Birds (poultry and waterfowl) are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E. Type C toxin is found in waterfowl, shorebirds, colonial waterbirds, and others; whereas type E toxin in gulls, loons, and others. Types A, B, E, and rarely F, cause human botulism. Types C, D, and E cause illness in other mammals, birds, and fish. Type A toxin occasionally causes botulism in domestic chickens. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map of California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/67494]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian - UK: (England) waterfowl, susp. 20200702.7534053\n2019\n----\nBotulism, avian -
