Emerg Infect Dis 2005; 11(10): 1578-83; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3366733/.\n6.Sobel J. Botulism. Clin Infect Dis 2005; 41(8): 1167-73; https://doi.org/10.1086/444507.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of New Jersey, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/232\n\nMost cases of botulism associated with fish or sea mammal ingestion are type E, as in this case.\n\nThe following is abstracted from the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Regulations Section 540.650: Uneviscerated fish products that are salt-cured, dried, or smoked (CPG 7108.17)\nhttps://www.fda.gov/regulatory-information/search-fda-guidance-documents/cpg-sec-540650-uneviscerated-fish-products-are-salt-cured-dried-or-smoked-revised:\n\nUneviscerated, salt-cured, whole fish products have caused several outbreaks of botulism and death. _C. botulinum_ spores are ubiquitous in fishery products and the marine environment. The spores represent a public health hazard when conditions are suitable for vegetative\ncell growth and toxin production.\n\nThree outbreaks of botulism, causing 3 deaths and 11 illnesses, resulted from \"kapchunka\" in the USA between 1981 and 1987. Kapchunka, an ethnic food usually produced from whitefish, is also known as \"rybetz\", \"ribeyza,\" or \"rostov.\" Kapchunka is an uneviscerated, salt-cured, air-dried, whole fish, which may or may not be smoked. It is consumed without further preparation, such as cooking. The fish are salt-cured under minimum refrigeration conditions for a minimum of 25 days and then air-dried at ambient temperature for 3 to 7 days. Kapchunka may be smoked before packing and are commonly stored under refrigeration.\n\nIn 1991, 2 botulism outbreaks occurred. In one, \"faseikh\" [fesikh] was implicated in at least 91 illnesses and 18 deaths in Egypt. Faseikh is a traditional product made by fermenting uneviscerated fresh mullet for up to one day and then salt-curing it in barrels, which may be tightly sealed from one week to one year. An ethnic fish product called \"moloha\" caused a botulism outbreak involving 4 family members in New Jersey. Moloha is an uneviscerated, salt-cured fish product similar to \"faseikh.\" The preparation steps\nin the New Jersey incident were not identified since the source of the \"moloha\" could not be found.\n\nOther salt-cured products, such as \"bloaters,\" can also pose a public health hazard. Bloaters are prepared by salt-curing uneviscerated whole herring, which may or may not be smoked. Bloaters may be transformed into other products, such as fillets or bloater paste. In addition to the products noted above, whole fish that are dried, pickled, or fermented can also pose a public health hazard. The referenced episodes of botulism are representative of a well-documented history of life-threatening health hazards associated with uneviscerated, salt-cured fish.\n\nThe problems with these products are compounded by the difficulty in attaining sufficient levels of salt in all portions of an uneviscerated fish to inhibit the growth of _C. botulinum_. Consequently, any fish product that is salt-cured and then dried, smoked, pickled, or fermented can pose a public health hazard. Toxin may be present in these products even when there are no outward signs of microbiological spoilage or other clear indications to alert the consumer.\n\nControl of growth and toxin production from _C. botulinum_ in fishery products is based on spore destruction (such as retorting canned foods) or inhibition of vegetative cell growth (such as control of water activity, pH, or use of approved chemical inhibitors). The control measures must be applied rapidly and uniformly throughout the product to protect consumers from this potentially life-threatening toxin.\n\nControl of botulism can also be achieved in salted, dried, or smoked products prepared from small species of uneviscerated fish (generally 3 to 5 inches in length (8-13 cm)). Typically, these products are prepared from small anchovy and herring sprats. As uneviscerated fish under 5 inches in length are processed, their smaller size helps to ensure complete permeation of the flesh with inhibitory levels of salt or drying to a uniformly low water activity, resulting in the attainment of conditions that prevent the growth of _C. botulinum_.\n\nThe FDA considers uneviscerated fish that are salt-cured, dried, or smoked to represent a potentially life-threatening health hazard. In addition, fillets, parts, or other products derived from uneviscerated fish pose the same potential health hazard as the original product. Therefore, with the exception of small, uneviscerated fish as described above, the FDA considers uneviscerated fish that have been salt-cured, dried, or smoked, as well as products made from them, to be adulterated within the meaning of section 402(a)(4) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, in that the product has been prepared, packed, or held under unsanitary conditions whereby it may have been rendered injurious to health.\n\nThese products are hazardous whether stored at ambient temperature, refrigerated, or frozen, or whether packaged in air, vacuum, or modified atmosphere. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (06): caviar, risk, recall 20190924.6692113\nBotulism - USA (05): (MD) 20190610.6511664\nBotulism - USA (04): (NM) wound, injection drug related 20190521.6479177\nBotulism - USA (03): (NYC) home-canned peas 20190315.6367720\nBotulism - USA (02): (AK) fermented whale flipper 20190206.6303507\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, injection drug related 20190103.6241364\n2018\n----\nBotulism - CANADA (02): BREWED COFFEE, RISK, RECALL\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 21 Mar 2019\nSource: Castanet [edited]\nhttps://www.castanet.net/edition/news-story-252136-1-.htm\n\n\nA botulism scare has forced the recall of a local [British Columbia] coffee company's product. Cherry Hill Coffee's N7 Nitro Cold Brew Coffee has been recalled after it was learned that temperature issues during the manufacturing process could have led to a failure to control pathogens, including botulism.\n\nOn Wed 20 Mar 2019, Interior Health put out a warning to the public advising anyone who purchased the cold brew coffee from the Kelowna company to not drink it.\n\n\"Either throw out the product, or return it to the location you bought it from, with proof of purchase for a full refund,\" IH said in its statement. \"N7 Nitro cans and kegs have been pulled from shelves at retail stores as part of a voluntary recall.\"\n\nIH says anyone who is feeling unwell after drinking the product should seek medical advice. At this time, no illnesses linked to the product have been reported.\n\nAccording to Health Canada, symptoms of botulism include fatigue, weakness, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain and eventually paralysis that starts in the shoulders and arms. Symptoms of botulism generally begin 12 to 36 hours after ingestion; however, symptoms can begin as soon as 6 hours after exposure or as long as 10 days later.\n\n[Byline: Nicholas Johansen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nitro coffee is cold brewed and infused with nitrogen gas. A bonus for consumers is that there's no sugar, milk, or alcohol in nitro coffee, and it contains about 30 percent more caffeine per ounce. It is not stated how much and where the distribution was. A similar recall occurred in 2017 in the USA.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures that could, but do not necessarily, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nCanada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Cherry Hill Coffee's N7 Nitro Cold Brew Coffee has been recalled after it was learned that temperature issues during the manufacturing process could have led to a failure to control pathogens, including botulism.\n\nOn Wed 20 Mar 2019, Interior Health put out a warning to the public advising anyone who purchased the cold brew coffee from the Kelowna company to not drink it.\n\n\"Either throw out the product, or return it to the location you bought it from, with proof of purchase for a full refund,\" IH said in its statement. \"N7 Nitro cans and kegs have been pulled from shelves at retail stores as part of a voluntary recall.\"\n\nIH says anyone who is feeling unwell after drinking the product should seek medical advice. At this time, no illnesses linked to the product have been reported.\n\nAccording to Health Canada, symptoms of botulism include fatigue, weakness, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain and eventually paralysis that starts in the shoulders and arms. Symptoms of botulism generally begin 12 to 36 hours after ingestion; however, symptoms can begin as soon as 6 hours after exposure or as long as 10 days later.\n\n[Byline: Nicholas Johansen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nitro coffee is cold brewed and infused with nitrogen gas. USA (05): (MD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6511664", "date": "2019-03-25 20:17:46", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (02): BREWED COFFEE, RISK, RECALL\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 21 Mar 2019\nSource: Castanet [edited]\nhttps://www.castanet.net/edition/news-story-252136-1-.htm\n\n\nA botulism scare has forced the recall of a local [British Columbia] coffee company's product. A similar recall occurred in 2017 in the USA.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures that could, but do not necessarily, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nCanada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Australia: (WA) waterfowl, susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6440356", "date": "2019-03-25 20:17:46", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (02): BREWED COFFEE, RISK, RECALL\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 21 Mar 2019\nSource: Castanet [edited]\nhttps://www.castanet.net/edition/news-story-252136-1-.htm\n\n\nA botulism scare has forced the recall of a local [British Columbia] coffee company's product. Cherry Hill Coffee's N7 Nitro Cold Brew Coffee has been recalled after it was learned that temperature issues during the manufacturing process could have led to a failure to control pathogens, including botulism.\n\nOn Wed 20 Mar 2019, Interior Health put out a warning to the public advising anyone who purchased the cold brew coffee from the Kelowna company to not drink it.\n\n\"Either throw out the product, or return it to the location you bought it from, with proof of purchase for a full refund,\" IH said in its statement. \"N7 Nitro cans and kegs have been pulled from shelves at retail stores as part of a voluntary recall.\"\n\nIH says anyone who is feeling unwell after drinking the product should seek medical advice. At this time, no illnesses linked to the product have been reported.\n\nAccording to Health Canada, symptoms of botulism include fatigue, weakness, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain and eventually paralysis that starts in the shoulders and arms. Symptoms of botulism generally begin 12 to 36 hours after ingestion; however, symptoms can begin as soon as 6 hours after exposure or as long as 10 days later.\n\n[Byline: Nicholas Johansen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nitro coffee is cold brewed and infused with nitrogen gas. A bonus for consumers is that there's no sugar, milk, or alcohol in nitro coffee, and it contains about 30 percent more caffeine per ounce. It is not stated how much and where the distribution was. A similar recall occurred in 2017 in the USA.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Symptoms of botulism generally begin 12 to 36 hours after ingestion; however, symptoms can begin as soon as 6 hours after exposure or as long as 10 days later.\n\n[Byline: Nicholas Johansen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nitro coffee is cold brewed and infused with nitrogen gas. USA (12): (NY) nitrogen-infused coffee, risk, alert, recall 20170920.5329208\nBotulism - Canada (03): (QC) whale meat 20170727.5207171\nBotulism - Canada (02): (QC) whale meat 20170716.5178297\nBotulism - USA (03): (NYC) home-canned peas", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6367720", "date": "2018-12-03 20:07:41", "main_text": "BOTULISM - BRAZIL (02): (PARANA) SANDWICH, CHILDREN\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 1 Dec 2018\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2018/12/foodborne-botulism-suspected-in-two-children/\n\n\nTwo girls, aged 4 and 6, have contracted botulism in the Brazilian state of Parana. Both cases were hospitalized but have now been discharged following treatment.\n\nFoodborne botulism, caused by eating food that was improperly processed or held at improper temperatures, is rare but potentially fatal if not diagnosed rapidly and treated with antitoxin. _Clostridium botulinum_ is the bacterium that produces botulinum toxins.\n\nThe suspected source is a sandwich eaten at a snack bar in Francisco Alves, a municipality in the state of Parana. The children's symptoms began 24 Nov 2018 in the morning. They were treated at a hospital in Francisco Alves before being transferred to Umuarama, a city in Parana. They reacted well to the treatment and were discharged 27 Nov 2018.\n\nOfficials inspected the snack bar and suppliers of the raw materials used in the snacks and collected samples of the food, which were sent for analysis. Results from the laboratory reports are pending to determine botulism and which food was responsible for the contamination.\n\nAuthorities stopped operations at the venue where the children ate after finding issues with the sanitary license and improper storage of food. Another place, where cheese used in preparation of snacks was handled, was also banned due to hygiene problems and lack of a license and authorization for such activity.\n\nFood botulism occurs after ingestion of items contaminated with preformed botulinum toxin. The incubation period can range from 4 hours to 8 days, with an average of 12-36 hours. The higher the toxin concentration in the food ingested, the shorter the incubation period. Symptoms vary but include headache, dizziness, drowsiness, difficulty swallowing and breathing, paralysis, and blurred vision.\n\nAnother type is infant botulism, which occurs mostly in those under 6 months of age related to ingestion of bacterial spores, and the toxin is formed in situ. Four infants in Texas recently developed botulism poisoning after being given pacifiers containing or dipped in honey.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is a review of botulism in Brazil:\n\nRowlands RE, Ristori CA, Lopes GI, et al.: Botulism in Brazil, 2000-2008: epidemiology, clinical findings, and laboratorial diagnosis. Rev Inst Med Trop Sao Paulo. 2010; 52(4):183-6. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1590/S0036-46652010000400003.\n\nAbstract\n------\nBotulism is a rare and potentially lethal illness caused by _Clostridium botulinum_ neurotoxin. We describe the findings of a laboratorial investigation of 117 suspected cases of botulism reported to the surveillance system in Brazil from January 2000 to October 2008. Data on the number and type of samples analyzed, type of toxins identified, reporting of the number of botulism cases, and transmission sources are discussed. A total of 193 clinical samples and 81 food samples were analyzed for detection and identification of the botulism neurotoxin. Among the clinical samples, 22 (11.4%) presented the toxin (9 type A, 5 type AB, and 8 with an unidentified type); in food samples, 8 (9.9%) were positive for the toxin (5 type A, 1 type AB, and 2 with an unidentified type). Of the 38 cases of suspected botulism in Brazil, 27 were confirmed by a mouse bioassay. Laboratorial botulism diagnosis is an important procedure to elucidate cases, especially food-borne botulism, to confirm clinical diagnosis and to identify toxins in food, helping sanitary control measures.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nParana, Brazil: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3985]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Brazil: (PE, SP) 20180208.5606256\n2012\n----\nBotulism - Brazil (02): (SP) sausage, pickled corn, alert, recall 20120824.1261258\nBotulism - Brazil: (PR) sausage, recall 20120305.1060430\n2011\n----\nBotulism - Brazil: (SC) sausage 20110407.1090\n2009\n----\nBotulism - Brazil (02): (SP) jilo, not eggplant 20091109.3879\nBotulism - Brazil: (SP) canned eggplant 20091108.3877\n2006\n----\nBotulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara)(02) 20061230.3652\nBotulism, fatal - The children's symptoms began 24 Nov 2018 in the morning. They were treated at a hospital in Francisco Alves before being transferred to Umuarama, a city in Parana. They reacted well to the treatment and were discharged 27 Nov 2018.\n\nOfficials inspected the snack bar and suppliers of the raw materials used in the snacks and collected samples of the food, which were sent for analysis. Another place, where cheese used in preparation of snacks was handled, was also banned due to hygiene problems and lack of a license and authorization for such activity.\n\nFood botulism occurs after ingestion of items contaminated with preformed botulinum toxin. Symptoms vary but include headache, dizziness, drowsiness, difficulty swallowing and breathing, paralysis, and blurred vision.\n\nAnother type is infant botulism, which occurs mostly in those under 6 months of age related to ingestion of bacterial spores, and the toxin is formed in situ. Rev Inst Med Trop Sao Paulo. 2010; 52(4):183-6. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1590/S0036-46652010000400003.\n\nAbstract\n------\nBotulism is a rare and potentially lethal illness caused by _Clostridium botulinum_ neurotoxin. A total of 193 clinical samples and 81 food samples were analyzed for detection and identification of the botulism neurotoxin. Brazil: (RO) susp. canned corn", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6322337", "date": "2018-12-03 20:07:41", "main_text": "BOTULISM - BRAZIL (02): (PARANA) SANDWICH, CHILDREN\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 1 Dec 2018\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2018/12/foodborne-botulism-suspected-in-two-children/\n\n\nTwo girls, aged 4 and 6, have contracted botulism in the Brazilian state of Parana. The children's symptoms began 24 Nov 2018 in the morning. They were treated at a hospital in Francisco Alves before being transferred to Umuarama, a city in Parana. They reacted well to the treatment and were discharged 27 Nov 2018.\n\nOfficials inspected the snack bar and suppliers of the raw materials used in the snacks and collected samples of the food, which were sent for analysis. Results from the laboratory reports are pending to determine botulism and which food was responsible for the contamination.\n\nAuthorities stopped operations at the venue where the children ate after finding issues with the sanitary license and improper storage of food. Another place, where cheese used in preparation of snacks was handled, was also banned due to hygiene problems and lack of a license and authorization for such activity.\n\nFood botulism occurs after ingestion of items contaminated with preformed botulinum toxin. The incubation period can range from 4 hours to 8 days, with an average of 12-36 hours. The higher the toxin concentration in the food ingested, the shorter the incubation period. Symptoms vary but include headache, dizziness, drowsiness, difficulty swallowing and breathing, paralysis, and blurred vision.\n\nAnother type is infant botulism, which occurs mostly in those under 6 months of age related to ingestion of bacterial spores, and the toxin is formed in situ. Four infants in Texas recently developed botulism poisoning after being given pacifiers containing or dipped in honey.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is a review of botulism in Brazil:\n\nRowlands RE, Ristori CA, Lopes GI, et al.: Botulism in Brazil, 2000-2008: epidemiology, clinical findings, and laboratorial diagnosis. Rev Inst Med Trop Sao Paulo. 2010; 52(4):183-6. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1590/S0036-46652010000400003.\n\nAbstract\n------\nBotulism is a rare and potentially lethal illness caused by _Clostridium botulinum_ neurotoxin. We describe the findings of a laboratorial investigation of 117 suspected cases of botulism reported to the surveillance system in Brazil from January 2000 to October 2008. Data on the number and type of samples analyzed, type of toxins identified, reporting of the number of botulism cases, and transmission sources are discussed. A total of 193 clinical samples and 81 food samples were analyzed for detection and identification of the botulism neurotoxin. Among the clinical samples, 22 (11.4%) presented the toxin (9 type A, 5 type AB, and 8 with an unidentified type); in food samples, 8 (9.9%) were positive for the toxin (5 type A, 1 type AB, and 2 with an unidentified type). Of the 38 cases of suspected botulism in Brazil, 27 were confirmed by a mouse bioassay. Laboratorial botulism diagnosis is an important procedure to elucidate cases, especially food-borne botulism, to confirm clinical diagnosis and to identify toxins in food, helping sanitary control measures.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nParana, Brazil: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3985]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Brazil: (PE, SP) 20180208.5606256\n2012\n----\nBotulism - Brazil (02): (SP) sausage, pickled corn, alert, recall 20120824.1261258\nBotulism - Brazil: (PR) sausage, recall 20120305.1060430\n2011\n----\nBotulism - Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sao Paulo", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Umuarama", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6303507", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - USA (02): (AK) fermented whale flipper", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6303507", "date": "2018-12-03 20:07:41", "main_text": "BOTULISM - BRAZIL (02): (PARANA) SANDWICH, CHILDREN\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 1 Dec 2018\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2018/12/foodborne-botulism-suspected-in-two-children/\n\n\nTwo girls, aged 4 and 6, have contracted botulism in the Brazilian state of Parana. Both cases were hospitalized but have now been discharged following treatment.\n\nFoodborne botulism, caused by eating food that was improperly processed or held at improper temperatures, is rare but potentially fatal if not diagnosed rapidly and treated with antitoxin. _Clostridium botulinum_ is the bacterium that produces botulinum toxins.\n\nThe suspected source is a sandwich eaten at a snack bar in Francisco Alves, a municipality in the state of Parana. The children's symptoms began 24 Nov 2018 in the morning. They were treated at a hospital in Francisco Alves before being transferred to Umuarama, a city in Parana. They reacted well to the treatment and were discharged 27 Nov 2018.\n\nOfficials inspected the snack bar and suppliers of the raw materials used in the snacks and collected samples of the food, which were sent for analysis. Results from the laboratory reports are pending to determine botulism and which food was responsible for the contamination.\n\nAuthorities stopped operations at the venue where the children ate after finding issues with the sanitary license and improper storage of food. Another place, where cheese used in preparation of snacks was handled, was also banned due to hygiene problems and lack of a license and authorization for such activity.\n\nFood botulism occurs after ingestion of items contaminated with preformed botulinum toxin. The incubation period can range from 4 hours to 8 days, with an average of 12-36 hours. The higher the toxin concentration in the food ingested, the shorter the incubation period. Symptoms vary but include headache, dizziness, drowsiness, difficulty swallowing and breathing, paralysis, and blurred vision.\n\nAnother type is infant botulism, which occurs mostly in those under 6 months of age related to ingestion of bacterial spores, and the toxin is formed in situ. Four infants in Texas recently developed botulism poisoning after being given pacifiers containing or dipped in honey.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is a review of botulism in Brazil:\n\nRowlands RE, Ristori CA, Lopes GI, et al.: Botulism in Brazil, 2000-2008: epidemiology, clinical findings, and laboratorial diagnosis. Rev Inst Med Trop Sao Paulo. 2010; 52(4):183-6. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1590/S0036-46652010000400003.\n\nAbstract\n------\nBotulism is a rare and potentially lethal illness caused by _Clostridium botulinum_ neurotoxin. We describe the findings of a laboratorial investigation of 117 suspected cases of botulism reported to the surveillance system in Brazil from January 2000 to October 2008. Data on the number and type of samples analyzed, type of toxins identified, reporting of the number of botulism cases, and transmission sources are discussed. A total of 193 clinical samples and 81 food samples were analyzed for detection and identification of the botulism neurotoxin. Among the clinical samples, 22 (11.4%) presented the toxin (9 type A, 5 type AB, and 8 with an unidentified type); in food samples, 8 (9.9%) were positive for the toxin (5 type A, 1 type AB, and 2 with an unidentified type). Of the 38 cases of suspected botulism in Brazil, 27 were confirmed by a mouse bioassay. Laboratorial botulism diagnosis is an important procedure to elucidate cases, especially food-borne botulism, to confirm clinical diagnosis and to identify toxins in food, helping sanitary control measures.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nParana, Brazil: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3985]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Four infants in Texas recently developed botulism poisoning after being given pacifiers containing or dipped in honey.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is a review of botulism in Brazil:\n\nRowlands RE, Ristori CA, Lopes GI, et al.: Botulism in Brazil, 2000-2008: epidemiology, clinical findings, and laboratorial diagnosis. Rev Inst Med Trop Sao Paulo. 2010; 52(4):183-6. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1590/S0036-46652010000400003.\n\nAbstract\n------\nBotulism is a rare and potentially lethal illness caused by _Clostridium botulinum_ neurotoxin. We describe the findings of a laboratorial investigation of 117 suspected cases of botulism reported to the surveillance system in Brazil from January 2000 to October 2008. Data on the number and type of samples analyzed, type of toxins identified, reporting of the number of botulism cases, and transmission sources are discussed. A total of 193 clinical samples and 81 food samples were analyzed for detection and identification of the botulism neurotoxin. Among the clinical samples, 22 (11.4%) presented the toxin (9 type A, 5 type AB, and 8 with an unidentified type); in food samples, 8 (9.9%) were positive for the toxin (5 type A, 1 type AB, and 2 with an unidentified type). Of the 38 cases of suspected botulism in Brazil, 27 were confirmed by a mouse bioassay. Laboratorial botulism diagnosis is an important procedure to elucidate cases, especially food-borne botulism, to confirm clinical diagnosis and to identify toxins in food, helping sanitary control measures.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nParana, Brazil: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3985]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Brazil: (PE, SP) 20180208.5606256\n2012\n----\nBotulism - Brazil (02): (SP) sausage, pickled corn, alert, recall 20120824.1261258\nBotulism - Brazil: (PR) sausage, recall 20120305.1060430\n2011\n----\nBotulism - Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sao Paulo", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Umuarama", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6152350", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Infant botulism - USA (03): (TX) honey pacifiers", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6152350", "date": "2018-08-04 21:36:04", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (07): CHEESE DIP, RISK, RECALL\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nWed Wed 25 Jul 2018\nSource: 6 ABC [edited]\nhttp://6abc.com/food/taco-bell-queso-dip-recalled-may-cause-botulism/3821598/\n\n\nA Taco Bell dip is being recalled because it can cause an extreme form of food poisoning. Kraft Heinz voluntarily recalled about 7000 cases of Taco Bell's Salsa Con Queso Mild Cheese Dip on Tue 24 Jul 2018. Officials said anyone who has the dip at home should return it for a refund or toss it out. Do not eat the dip, even if it doesn't look or smell spoiled.\n\nThe dip showed signs of product separation, which can allow for the growth of _Clostridium botulinum_ (_C. botulinum_), officials said. The bacterium can cause botulism, which can be fatal. Symptoms include general weakness, dizziness, double vision, trouble with speaking or swallowing, difficulty in breathing, weakness of other muscles, abdominal distension, and constipation. Officials said that so far no one has gotten sick or made any official complaints about the product. But anyone who does experience these symptoms after consuming the dip should call a doctor right away.\n\nTaco Bell's Salsa Con Queso Mild Cheese Dip was distributed only to stores in the USA.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures that could, but do not necessarily, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (02): (TX) comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5949251", "date": "2018-08-04 21:36:04", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (07): CHEESE DIP, RISK, RECALL\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nWed Wed 25 Jul 2018\nSource: 6 ABC [edited]\nhttp://6abc.com/food/taco-bell-queso-dip-recalled-may-cause-botulism/3821598/\n\n\nA Taco Bell dip is being recalled because it can cause an extreme form of food poisoning. Kraft Heinz voluntarily recalled about 7000 cases of Taco Bell's Salsa Con Queso Mild Cheese Dip on Tue 24 Jul 2018. Officials said anyone who has the dip at home should return it for a refund or toss it out. Do not eat the dip, even if it doesn't look or smell spoiled.\n\nThe dip showed signs of product separation, which can allow for the growth of _Clostridium botulinum_ (_C. botulinum_), officials said. The bacterium can cause botulism, which can be fatal. Symptoms include general weakness, dizziness, double vision, trouble with speaking or swallowing, difficulty in breathing, weakness of other muscles, abdominal distension, and constipation. Officials said that so far no one has gotten sick or made any official complaints about the product. But anyone who does experience these symptoms after consuming the dip should call a doctor right away.\n\nTaco Bell's Salsa Con Queso Mild Cheese Dip was distributed only to stores in the USA.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures that could, but do not necessarily, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Kraft Heinz voluntarily recalled about 7000 cases of Taco Bell's Salsa Con Queso Mild Cheese Dip on Tue 24 Jul 2018. Officials said anyone who has the dip at home should return it for a refund or toss it out. Do not eat the dip, even if it doesn't look or smell spoiled.\n\nThe dip showed signs of product separation, which can allow for the growth of _Clostridium botulinum_ (_C. botulinum_), officials said. The bacterium can cause botulism, which can be fatal. Symptoms include general weakness, dizziness, double vision, trouble with speaking or swallowing, difficulty in breathing, weakness of other muscles, abdominal distension, and constipation. Officials said that so far no one has gotten sick or made any official complaints about the product. But anyone who does experience these symptoms after consuming the dip should call a doctor right away.\n\nTaco Bell's Salsa Con Queso Mild Cheese Dip was distributed only to stores in the USA.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Denmark (03): homemade savory jelly", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5933956", "date": "2018-06-25 16:26:57", "main_text": "BOTULISM - DENMARK: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 22 Jun 2018\nSource: Foedevarestyrelsen [Danish Food Administration, in Danish machine trans., edited]\nhttps://www.foedevarestyrelsen.dk/Leksikon/Sider/Udbrud_med_botulisme_poelseforgiftning.aspx\n\n\nThere is an outbreak of clinically confirmed botulism (sausage poisoning) in South Jutland [Sydjylland]. The Food Administration has been involved in the case since Sunday morning [17 Jun 2018]. It is normal for the Board of Patient Safety to involve the Food Administration in cases of suspected food.\n\nThe Danish Food Agency has taken samples of the leftover food that the individuals ate and they are now being analyzed. The result is expected in about 5 days. The information obtained suggests that the source of infection should be found in a food that only the poisoned patients have ate.\n\nManufactured foods are basically very safe in relation to botulism, as pH and salt content are controlled in production. Cases of botulism are very rare in Denmark.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The copyrighted website https://www.foodnavigator.com/Article/2018/06/22/Foodborne-botulism-outbreak-at-private-party-in-Denmark# reports that there are 6 cases and one possible case among 11 individuals who attended a private dinner in the town of Sonderborg on 15 Jun 2018. The suspected vehicle of the intoxication is not yet stated. ProMED would appreciate more information regarding this outbreak.\n\nThe paralytic intoxication botulism, or sausage poisoning as it was originally termed, is caused by one of the neurotoxins produced by (primarily) _Clostridium botulinum_ bacteria in foods not properly prepared. It was first seriously studied following an outbreak in Wildbad, Germany in 1793. The outbreak involved 13 people, 6 of whom died, and was associated with consumption of a locally produced blood sausage. Following this outbreak, the number of reported cases of sausage poisoning rapidly increased, prompting a study of the disease by local health officer Justinius Kerner (1829). He described 230 cases, most of which were attributed to the consumption of sausage. The illness became known as \"botulism\" after \"botulus\", the Latin word for sausage. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of S\u00f8nderborg, Region South Denmark, Denmark: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7943>]\nSee Also\nBotulism - The Food Administration has been involved in the case since Sunday morning [17 Jun 2018]. It is normal for the Board of Patient Safety to involve the Food Administration in cases of suspected food.\n\nThe Danish Food Agency has taken samples of the leftover food that the individuals ate and they are now being analyzed. The result is expected in about 5 days. The information obtained suggests that the source of infection should be found in a food that only the poisoned patients have ate.\n\nManufactured foods are basically very safe in relation to botulism, as pH and salt content are controlled in production. Cases of botulism are very rare in Denmark.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The copyrighted website https://www.foodnavigator.com/Article/2018/06/22/Foodborne-botulism-outbreak-at-private-party-in-Denmark# reports that there are 6 cases and one possible case among 11 individuals who attended a private dinner in the town of Sonderborg on 15 Jun 2018. The suspected vehicle of the intoxication is not yet stated. ProMED would appreciate more information regarding this outbreak.\n\nThe paralytic intoxication botulism, or sausage poisoning as it was originally termed, is caused by one of the neurotoxins produced by (primarily) _Clostridium botulinum_ bacteria in foods not properly prepared. It was first seriously studied following an outbreak in Wildbad, Germany in 1793. The outbreak involved 13 people, 6 of whom died, and was associated with consumption of a locally produced blood sausage. Following this outbreak, the number of reported cases of sausage poisoning rapidly increased, prompting a study of the disease by local health officer Justinius Kerner (1829). He described 230 cases, most of which were attributed to the consumption of sausage. The Food Administration has been involved in the case since Sunday morning [17 Jun 2018]. It is normal for the Board of Patient Safety to involve the Food Administration in cases of suspected food.\n\nThe Danish Food Agency has taken samples of the leftover food that the individuals ate and they are now being analyzed. The result is expected in about 5 days. The information obtained suggests that the source of infection should be found in a food that only the poisoned patients have ate.\n\nManufactured foods are basically very safe in relation to botulism, as pH and salt content are controlled in production. Cases of botulism are very rare in Denmark.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The copyrighted website https://www.foodnavigator.com/Article/2018/06/22/Foodborne-botulism-outbreak-at-private-party-in-Denmark# reports that there are 6 cases and one possible case among 11 individuals who attended a private dinner in the town of Sonderborg on 15 Jun 2018. The suspected vehicle of the intoxication is not yet stated. ProMED would appreciate more information regarding this outbreak.\n\nThe paralytic intoxication botulism, or sausage poisoning as it was originally termed, is caused by one of the neurotoxins produced by (primarily) _Clostridium botulinum_ bacteria in foods not properly prepared. It was first seriously studied following an outbreak in Wildbad, Germany in 1793. The outbreak involved 13 people, 6 of whom died, and was associated with consumption of a locally produced blood sausage. Following this outbreak, the number of reported cases of sausage poisoning rapidly increased, prompting a study of the disease by local health officer Justinius Kerner (1829). He described 230 cases, most of which were attributed to the consumption of sausage. The illness became known as \"botulism\" after \"botulus\", the Latin word for sausage. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of S\u00f8nderborg, Region South Denmark, Denmark: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7943>]\nSee Also\nBotulism - The Food Administration has been involved in the case since Sunday morning [17 Jun 2018]. It is normal for the Board of Patient Safety to involve the Food Administration in cases of suspected food.\n\nThe Danish Food Agency has taken samples of the leftover food that the individuals ate and they are now being analyzed. The result is expected in about 5 days. The information obtained suggests that the source of infection should be found in a food that only the poisoned patients have ate.\n\nManufactured foods are basically very safe in relation to botulism, as pH and salt content are controlled in production. Cases of botulism are very rare in Denmark.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The copyrighted website https://www.foodnavigator.com/Article/2018/06/22/Foodborne-botulism-outbreak-at-private-party-in-Denmark# reports that there are 6 cases and one possible case among 11 individuals who attended a private dinner in the town of Sonderborg on 15 Jun 2018. It was first seriously studied following an outbreak in Wildbad, Germany in 1793. The outbreak involved 13 people, 6 of whom died, and was associated with consumption of a locally produced blood sausage. Ukraine: dried fish 20150607.3417187\nBotulism - Azerbaijan: home pickled tomatoes 20150221.3177167\nBotulism - Tajikistan, Kazakhstan: home canned foods 20150201.3135159\n2014\n----\nBotulism - Tajikistan: (SU) home-canned tomatoes 20140403.2377447\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................sb/ll/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2018-06-17 00:00:00", "2018-06-15 00:00:00", "1793-03-15 00:00:00", "1829-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Denmark", "country": "Denmark"}, {"location": "Vienna", "country": "Austria"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Wildbad", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "ph", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5854985", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - USA (05): (NM) wound, injection drug-related", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5854985", "date": "2018-03-23 19:22:27", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (02): (ALASKA)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 23 Mar 2018\nSource: KYUK [edited]\nhttp://kyuk.org/post/possible-botulism-case-linked-native-salad-sold-cama-i\n\n\nAn adult from Bethel might have contracted botulism from a \"Native Salad\" that they bought at the Cama-i Dance Festival last weekend [17-18 Mar 2018]. While the Yukon-Kuskokwim Health Corporation suspects that this is a botulism case, the diagnosis is still unconfirmed. The Alaska Section of Epidemiology heard about the suspected case on [Wed 21 Mar 2018]. In a press release this afternoon, [Fri 23 Mar 2018], YKHC said that they have sent a sample of the salad to a testing facility in Anchorage. They will know if the salad tests positive for the botulism toxin in about a week.\n\nIn the meantime, the health care provider advises those who ate some of the dish to watch for signs of botulism. Symptoms typically start to appear 1 to 3 days after people eat food that contains the toxin. They include a dry mouth, blurred or double vision, difficulty swallowing, drooping eyelids, dilated pupils, voice changes, dizziness, and shortness of breath.\n\nBotulism can be a life threatening illness. If you have any of these symptoms, YKHC advises going to your local emergency room or calling your clinic immediately.\n\n[byline: Teresa Cotsirilos]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not stated in the posting what ingredients were contained in the \"Native Salad\" but it is certainly possible that the salad contained fermented marine animal products. These products are often associated with type E botulism cases in native American and Canadian populations.\n\nThe following was abstracted from a 2001 CDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] report on foodborne botulism in the native American population in Alaska and underscores changes in the fermentation techniques which appear to have increased the risks of this intoxication (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5032a2.htm):\n\n\"This report illustrates how the use of nontraditional fermentation methods is associated with foodborne botulism in Alaska. Botulism results from eating preformed toxin produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism intoxication can result in death, which most often is caused by respiratory failure. The latent period is typically 12-36 hours but can range from 6 hours to 10 days (1). _C. botulinum_ and closely related organisms produce toxins designated as types A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is most commonly caused by types A, B, and E. Type E is associated with foods of marine or freshwater origin. Alaska's foodborne botulism rates exceed those in any other state and are among the highest in the world (1). During 1950-2000, Alaska recorded 226 cases of foodborne botulism from 114 outbreaks. All patients were Alaska natives, and all cases with known causes were associated with eating fermented foods (1,2). Approximately 27 per cent of US foodborne botulism cases occur in Alaska.\n\n\"In traditional fermentation, food is kept in a grass-lined hole in the ground or a wooden barrel sunken into the ground or is placed in a shady area above ground for several weeks to months. Since the 1970s, however, plastic or glass containers have been used and fermentation has been done above ground or indoors. The anaerobic condition of sealed containers and warmer temperatures make fermentation more rapid and production of botulism toxin more likely (3-5). These nontraditional methods have been associated with increased botulism rates in Alaska during 1970-1989 (4,5).\n\n\"Early diagnosis and antitoxin treatment have contributed to the decline of the case fatality rate from approximately 31 per cent during 1950-1959 to no deaths in Alaska since 1994 (1). However, Alaska continues to have high foodborne botulism rates because fermented foods are part of Alaska Native culture. In a 1999 survey, 107 (77 per cent) of 140 Alaska Natives reported having eaten fermented foods at least once in their lifetime (3).\"\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Beller M. Botulism in Alaska: a guide for physicians and health-care providers -- 1998 update. Anchorage, Alaska: Alaska Department of Health and Social Services, 1998.\n2. Wainwright RB, Heyward WL, Middaugh JP, Hatheway CL, Harpster AP, Bender TR. Food-borne botulism in Alaska, 1947-1985: epidemiology and clinical findings. J Infect Dis. 1988;157(6):1158-62. Abstract available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=3373020.\n3. Chiou L, Hennessy T, Horn A, et al. A survey of knowledge, attitudes, and practices related to fermented foods known to cause botulism among Alaska Natives of southwest Alaska. [Abstract]. Presented at the 2nd International Conference on Emerging Infectious Diseases, Atlanta, Georgia, July 2000.\n4. Eisenberg MS, Bender TR. Plastic bags and botulism: a new twist to an old hazard of the north. Alaska Med. 1976;18(4):47-9.\n5. Shaffer N, Wainwright RB, Middaugh JP, Tauxe RV. Botulism among Alaska Natives: the role of changing food preparation and consumption practices. West J Med. 1990;153(4):390-3.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Alaska, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20180214.5628631\n2017\n---\nBotulism - USA (13): (AK) 20170930.5349662\nBotulism - USA (12): (NY) nitrogen-infused coffee, risk, alert, recall 20170920.5329208\nBotulism - USA (11): (NM) wound, injection drug related 20170719.5189504\nBotulism - USA (10): (CA) nacho cheese, type A toxin, unrelated 2nd death 20170525.5060186\nBotulism - USA (09): (CA) gas station food, nacho cheese conf, fatal 20170523.5056161\nBotulism - USA (08): (CA) gas station food, nacho cheese 20170519.5047996\nBotulism - USA (07): (CA) gas station food, nacho cheese 20170512.5031065\nBotulism - USA (06): (CA) gas station food, RFI 20170508.5021002\nBotulism - USA (05): deer antler herbal tea, FDA recall 20170507.5018201\nBotulism - USA (04): (CA) deer antler tea 20170429.5003486\nBotulism - USA (03): (TX) wound, drug-related, 2005-2015 20170427.4999639\nBotulism - USA (02): (CA) satay, risk, recall 20170420.4982801\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, non-drug-related 20170402.4942916\n.................................................ll/ao/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1994-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anchorage", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Hatheway", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5847037", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Infant botulism - Canada (02): cases spike, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5847037", "date": "2018-03-23 19:22:27", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (02): (ALASKA)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 23 Mar 2018\nSource: KYUK [edited]\nhttp://kyuk.org/post/possible-botulism-case-linked-native-salad-sold-cama-i\n\n\nAn adult from Bethel might have contracted botulism from a \"Native Salad\" that they bought at the Cama-i Dance Festival last weekend [17-18 Mar 2018]. While the Yukon-Kuskokwim Health Corporation suspects that this is a botulism case, the diagnosis is still unconfirmed. The Alaska Section of Epidemiology heard about the suspected case on [Wed 21 Mar 2018]. In a press release this afternoon, [Fri 23 Mar 2018], YKHC said that they have sent a sample of the salad to a testing facility in Anchorage. They will know if the salad tests positive for the botulism toxin in about a week.\n\nIn the meantime, the health care provider advises those who ate some of the dish to watch for signs of botulism. Symptoms typically start to appear 1 to 3 days after people eat food that contains the toxin. They include a dry mouth, blurred or double vision, difficulty swallowing, drooping eyelids, dilated pupils, voice changes, dizziness, and shortness of breath.\n\nBotulism can be a life threatening illness. If you have any of these symptoms, YKHC advises going to your local emergency room or calling your clinic immediately.\n\n[byline: Teresa Cotsirilos]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not stated in the posting what ingredients were contained in the \"Native Salad\" but it is certainly possible that the salad contained fermented marine animal products. These products are often associated with type E botulism cases in native American and Canadian populations.\n\nThe following was abstracted from a 2001 CDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] report on foodborne botulism in the native American population in Alaska and underscores changes in the fermentation techniques which appear to have increased the risks of this intoxication (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5032a2.htm):\n\n\"This report illustrates how the use of nontraditional fermentation methods is associated with foodborne botulism in Alaska. Botulism results from eating preformed toxin produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism intoxication can result in death, which most often is caused by respiratory failure. The latent period is typically 12-36 hours but can range from 6 hours to 10 days (1). _C. botulinum_ and closely related organisms produce toxins designated as types A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is most commonly caused by types A, B, and E. Type E is associated with foods of marine or freshwater origin. Alaska's foodborne botulism rates exceed those in any other state and are among the highest in the world (1). During 1950-2000, Alaska recorded 226 cases of foodborne botulism from 114 outbreaks. All patients were Alaska natives, and all cases with known causes were associated with eating fermented foods (1,2). Approximately 27 per cent of US foodborne botulism cases occur in Alaska.\n\n\"In traditional fermentation, food is kept in a grass-lined hole in the ground or a wooden barrel sunken into the ground or is placed in a shady area above ground for several weeks to months. Since the 1970s, however, plastic or glass containers have been used and fermentation has been done above ground or indoors. The anaerobic condition of sealed containers and warmer temperatures make fermentation more rapid and production of botulism toxin more likely (3-5). These nontraditional methods have been associated with increased botulism rates in Alaska during 1970-1989 (4,5).\n\n\"Early diagnosis and antitoxin treatment have contributed to the decline of the case fatality rate from approximately 31 per cent during 1950-1959 to no deaths in Alaska since 1994 (1). However, Alaska continues to have high foodborne botulism rates because fermented foods are part of Alaska Native culture. In a 1999 survey, 107 (77 per cent) of 140 Alaska Natives reported having eaten fermented foods at least once in their lifetime (3).\"\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Beller M. In a press release this afternoon, [Fri 23 Mar 2018], YKHC said that they have sent a sample of the salad to a testing facility in Anchorage. If you have any of these symptoms, YKHC advises going to your local emergency room or calling your clinic immediately.\n\n[byline: Teresa Cotsirilos]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not stated in the posting what ingredients were contained in the \"Native Salad\" but it is certainly possible that the salad contained fermented marine animal products. These products are often associated with type E botulism cases in native American and Canadian populations.\n\nThe following was abstracted from a 2001 CDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] report on foodborne botulism in the native American population in Alaska and underscores changes in the fermentation techniques which appear to have increased the risks of this intoxication (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5032a2.htm):\n\n\"This report illustrates how the use of nontraditional fermentation methods is associated with foodborne botulism in Alaska. Botulism results from eating preformed toxin produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism intoxication can result in death, which most often is caused by respiratory failure. The latent period is typically 12-36 hours but can range from 6 hours to 10 days (1). _C. botulinum_ and closely related organisms produce toxins designated as types A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is most commonly caused by types A, B, and E. Type E is associated with foods of marine or freshwater origin. Alaska's foodborne botulism rates exceed those in any other state and are among the highest in the world (1). During 1950-2000, Alaska recorded 226 cases of foodborne botulism from 114 outbreaks. All patients were Alaska natives, and all cases with known causes were associated with eating fermented foods (1,2). Approximately 27 per cent of US foodborne botulism cases occur in Alaska.\n\n\"In traditional fermentation, food is kept in a grass-lined hole in the ground or a wooden barrel sunken into the ground or is placed in a shady area above ground for several weeks to months. Since the 1970s, however, plastic or glass containers have been used and fermentation has been done above ground or indoors. The anaerobic condition of sealed containers and warmer temperatures make fermentation more rapid and production of botulism toxin more likely (3-5). These nontraditional methods have been associated with increased botulism rates in Alaska during 1970-1989 (4,5).\n\n\"Early diagnosis and antitoxin treatment have contributed to the decline of the case fatality rate from approximately 31 per cent during 1950-1959 to no deaths in Alaska since 1994 (1). However, Alaska continues to have high foodborne botulism rates because fermented foods are part of Alaska Native culture. In a 1999 survey, 107 (77 per cent) of 140 Alaska Natives reported having eaten fermented foods at least once in their lifetime (3).\"\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Beller M. Botulism in Alaska: a guide for physicians and health-care providers -- 1998 update. Anchorage, Alaska: Alaska Department of Health and Social Services, 1998.\n2. Wainwright RB, Heyward WL, Middaugh JP, Hatheway CL, Harpster AP, Bender TR. Food-borne botulism in Alaska, 1947-1985: epidemiology and clinical findings. J Infect Dis. 1988;157(6):1158-62. Abstract available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=3373020.\n3. Chiou L, Hennessy T, Horn A, et al. A survey of knowledge, attitudes, and practices related to fermented foods known to cause botulism among Alaska Natives of southwest Alaska. [Abstract]. Presented at the 2nd International Conference on Emerging Infectious Diseases, Atlanta, Georgia, July 2000.\n4. Eisenberg MS, Bender TR. Plastic bags and botulism: a new twist to an old hazard of the north. Alaska Med. 1976;18(4):47-9.\n5. Shaffer N, Wainwright RB, Middaugh JP, Tauxe RV. Botulism among Alaska Natives: the role of changing food preparation and consumption practices. West J Med. 1990;153(4):390-3.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Alaska, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20180214.5628631\n2017\n---\nBotulism - USA (10): (CA) nacho cheese, type A toxin, unrelated 2nd death 20170525.5060186\nBotulism - USA (09): (CA) gas station food, nacho cheese conf, fatal 20170523.5056161\nBotulism - USA (08): (CA) gas station food, nacho cheese 20170519.5047996\nBotulism - USA (07): (CA) gas station food, nacho cheese 20170512.5031065\nBotulism - USA (06): (CA) gas station food, RFI 20170508.5021002\nBotulism - USA (05): deer antler herbal tea, FDA recall 20170507.5018201\nBotulism - USA (04): (CA) deer antler tea 20170429.5003486\nBotulism - USA (03): (TX) wound, drug-related, 2005-2015 20170427.4999639\nBotulism - USA (02): (CA) satay, risk, recall 20170420.4982801\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, non-drug-related 20170402.4942916\n.................................................ll/ao/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1994-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anchorage", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Hatheway", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5793869", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - Australia: (NS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5793869", "date": "2018-03-23 19:22:27", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (02): (ALASKA)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 23 Mar 2018\nSource: KYUK [edited]\nhttp://kyuk.org/post/possible-botulism-case-linked-native-salad-sold-cama-i\n\n\nAn adult from Bethel might have contracted botulism from a \"Native Salad\" that they bought at the Cama-i Dance Festival last weekend [17-18 Mar 2018]. While the Yukon-Kuskokwim Health Corporation suspects that this is a botulism case, the diagnosis is still unconfirmed. The Alaska Section of Epidemiology heard about the suspected case on [Wed 21 Mar 2018]. In a press release this afternoon, [Fri 23 Mar 2018], YKHC said that they have sent a sample of the salad to a testing facility in Anchorage. They will know if the salad tests positive for the botulism toxin in about a week.\n\nIn the meantime, the health care provider advises those who ate some of the dish to watch for signs of botulism. Symptoms typically start to appear 1 to 3 days after people eat food that contains the toxin. They include a dry mouth, blurred or double vision, difficulty swallowing, drooping eyelids, dilated pupils, voice changes, dizziness, and shortness of breath.\n\nBotulism can be a life threatening illness. If you have any of these symptoms, YKHC advises going to your local emergency room or calling your clinic immediately.\n\n[byline: Teresa Cotsirilos]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not stated in the posting what ingredients were contained in the \"Native Salad\" but it is certainly possible that the salad contained fermented marine animal products. These products are often associated with type E botulism cases in native American and Canadian populations.\n\nThe following was abstracted from a 2001 CDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] report on foodborne botulism in the native American population in Alaska and underscores changes in the fermentation techniques which appear to have increased the risks of this intoxication (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5032a2.htm):\n\n\"This report illustrates how the use of nontraditional fermentation methods is associated with foodborne botulism in Alaska. Botulism results from eating preformed toxin produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism intoxication can result in death, which most often is caused by respiratory failure. The latent period is typically 12-36 hours but can range from 6 hours to 10 days (1). _C. botulinum_ and closely related organisms produce toxins designated as types A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is most commonly caused by types A, B, and E. Type E is associated with foods of marine or freshwater origin. Alaska's foodborne botulism rates exceed those in any other state and are among the highest in the world (1). During 1950-2000, Alaska recorded 226 cases of foodborne botulism from 114 outbreaks. All patients were Alaska natives, and all cases with known causes were associated with eating fermented foods (1,2). Approximately 27 per cent of US foodborne botulism cases occur in Alaska.\n\n\"In traditional fermentation, food is kept in a grass-lined hole in the ground or a wooden barrel sunken into the ground or is placed in a shady area above ground for several weeks to months. Since the 1970s, however, plastic or glass containers have been used and fermentation has been done above ground or indoors. The anaerobic condition of sealed containers and warmer temperatures make fermentation more rapid and production of botulism toxin more likely (3-5). These nontraditional methods have been associated with increased botulism rates in Alaska during 1970-1989 (4,5).\n\n\"Early diagnosis and antitoxin treatment have contributed to the decline of the case fatality rate from approximately 31 per cent during 1950-1959 to no deaths in Alaska since 1994 (1). However, Alaska continues to have high foodborne botulism rates because fermented foods are part of Alaska Native culture. In a 1999 survey, 107 (77 per cent) of 140 Alaska Natives reported having eaten fermented foods at least once in their lifetime (3).\"\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Beller M. Botulism in Alaska: a guide for physicians and health-care providers -- 1998 update. Anchorage, Alaska: Alaska Department of Health and Social Services, 1998.\n2. Wainwright RB, Heyward WL, Middaugh JP, Hatheway CL, Harpster AP, Bender TR. Food-borne botulism in Alaska, 1947-1985: epidemiology and clinical findings. J Infect Dis. 1988;157(6):1158-62. West J Med. 1990;153(4):390-3.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Alaska, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20180214.5628631\n2017\n---\nBotulism - While the Yukon-Kuskokwim Health Corporation suspects that this is a botulism case, the diagnosis is still unconfirmed. The Alaska Section of Epidemiology heard about the suspected case on [Wed 21 Mar 2018]. In a press release this afternoon, [Fri 23 Mar 2018], YKHC said that they have sent a sample of the salad to a testing facility in Anchorage. They will know if the salad tests positive for the botulism toxin in about a week.\n\nIn the meantime, the health care provider advises those who ate some of the dish to watch for signs of botulism. These products are often associated with type E botulism cases in native American and Canadian populations.\n\nThe following was abstracted from a 2001 CDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] report on foodborne botulism in the native American population in Alaska and underscores changes in the fermentation techniques which appear to have increased the risks of this intoxication (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5032a2.htm):\n\n\"This report illustrates how the use of nontraditional fermentation methods is associated with foodborne botulism in Alaska. Botulism results from eating preformed toxin produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism intoxication can result in death, which most often is caused by respiratory failure. The latent period is typically 12-36 hours but can range from 6 hours to 10 days (1). _C. botulinum_ and closely related organisms produce toxins designated as types A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is most commonly caused by types A, B, and E. Type E is associated with foods of marine or freshwater origin. Alaska's foodborne botulism rates exceed those in any other state and are among the highest in the world (1). During 1950-2000, Alaska recorded 226 cases of foodborne botulism from 114 outbreaks. All patients were Alaska natives, and all cases with known causes were associated with eating fermented foods (1,2). Approximately 27 per cent of US foodborne botulism cases occur in Alaska.\n\n\"In traditional fermentation, food is kept in a grass-lined hole in the ground or a wooden barrel sunken into the ground or is placed in a shady area above ground for several weeks to months. Since the 1970s, however, plastic or glass containers have been used and fermentation has been done above ground or indoors. The anaerobic condition of sealed containers and warmer temperatures make fermentation more rapid and production of botulism toxin more likely (3-5). These nontraditional methods have been associated with increased botulism rates in Alaska during 1970-1989 (4,5).\n\n\"Early diagnosis and antitoxin treatment have contributed to the decline of the case fatality rate from approximately 31 per cent during 1950-1959 to no deaths in Alaska since 1994 (1). However, Alaska continues to have high foodborne botulism rates because fermented foods are part of Alaska Native culture. Botulism results from eating preformed toxin produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism intoxication can result in death, which most often is caused by respiratory failure. The latent period is typically 12-36 hours but can range from 6 hours to 10 days (1). _C. botulinum_ and closely related organisms produce toxins designated as types A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is most commonly caused by types A, B, and E. Type E is associated with foods of marine or freshwater origin. Alaska's foodborne botulism rates exceed those in any other state and are among the highest in the world (1). During 1950-2000, Alaska recorded 226 cases of foodborne botulism from 114 outbreaks. All patients were Alaska natives, and all cases with known causes were associated with eating fermented foods (1,2). Approximately 27 per cent of US foodborne botulism cases occur in Alaska.\n\n\"In traditional fermentation, food is kept in a grass-lined hole in the ground or a wooden barrel sunken into the ground or is placed in a shady area above ground for several weeks to months. Since the 1970s, however, plastic or glass containers have been used and fermentation has been done above ground or indoors. The anaerobic condition of sealed containers and warmer temperatures make fermentation more rapid and production of botulism toxin more likely (3-5).
