USA (10): (CA) nacho cheese, type A toxin, unrelated 2nd death 20170525.5060186\nBotulism - USA (09): (CA) gas station food, nacho cheese conf, fatal 20170523.5056161\nBotulism - USA (08): (CA) gas station food, nacho cheese 20170519.5047996\nBotulism - USA (07): (CA) gas station food, nacho cheese 20170512.5031065\nBotulism - USA (06): (CA) gas station food, RFI 20170508.5021002\nBotulism - USA (05): deer antler herbal tea, FDA recall 20170507.5018201\nBotulism - USA (04): (CA) deer antler tea 20170429.5003486\nBotulism - USA (03): (TX) wound, drug-related, 2005-2015 20170427.4999639\nBotulism - USA (02): (CA) satay, risk, recall 20170420.4982801\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, non-drug-related 20170402.4942916\n.................................................ll/ao/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1994-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anchorage", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Hatheway", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5706323", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - USA (02): (AK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5706323", "date": "2018-03-23 19:22:27", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (02): (ALASKA)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 23 Mar 2018\nSource: KYUK [edited]\nhttp://kyuk.org/post/possible-botulism-case-linked-native-salad-sold-cama-i\n\n\nAn adult from Bethel might have contracted botulism from a \"Native Salad\" that they bought at the Cama-i Dance Festival last weekend [17-18 Mar 2018]. While the Yukon-Kuskokwim Health Corporation suspects that this is a botulism case, the diagnosis is still unconfirmed. The Alaska Section of Epidemiology heard about the suspected case on [Wed 21 Mar 2018]. In a press release this afternoon, [Fri 23 Mar 2018], YKHC said that they have sent a sample of the salad to a testing facility in Anchorage. They will know if the salad tests positive for the botulism toxin in about a week.\n\nIn the meantime, the health care provider advises those who ate some of the dish to watch for signs of botulism. Symptoms typically start to appear 1 to 3 days after people eat food that contains the toxin. They include a dry mouth, blurred or double vision, difficulty swallowing, drooping eyelids, dilated pupils, voice changes, dizziness, and shortness of breath.\n\nBotulism can be a life threatening illness. If you have any of these symptoms, YKHC advises going to your local emergency room or calling your clinic immediately.\n\n[byline: Teresa Cotsirilos]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not stated in the posting what ingredients were contained in the \"Native Salad\" but it is certainly possible that the salad contained fermented marine animal products. These products are often associated with type E botulism cases in native American and Canadian populations.\n\nThe following was abstracted from a 2001 CDC [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] report on foodborne botulism in the native American population in Alaska and underscores changes in the fermentation techniques which appear to have increased the risks of this intoxication (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5032a2.htm):\n\n\"This report illustrates how the use of nontraditional fermentation methods is associated with foodborne botulism in Alaska. Botulism results from eating preformed toxin produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism intoxication can result in death, which most often is caused by respiratory failure. The latent period is typically 12-36 hours but can range from 6 hours to 10 days (1). _C. botulinum_ and closely related organisms produce toxins designated as types A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is most commonly caused by types A, B, and E. Type E is associated with foods of marine or freshwater origin. Alaska's foodborne botulism rates exceed those in any other state and are among the highest in the world (1). During 1950-2000, Alaska recorded 226 cases of foodborne botulism from 114 outbreaks. All patients were Alaska natives, and all cases with known causes were associated with eating fermented foods (1,2). Approximately 27 per cent of US foodborne botulism cases occur in Alaska.\n\n\"In traditional fermentation, food is kept in a grass-lined hole in the ground or a wooden barrel sunken into the ground or is placed in a shady area above ground for several weeks to months. Since the 1970s, however, plastic or glass containers have been used and fermentation has been done above ground or indoors. The anaerobic condition of sealed containers and warmer temperatures make fermentation more rapid and production of botulism toxin more likely (3-5). These nontraditional methods have been associated with increased botulism rates in Alaska during 1970-1989 (4,5).\n\n\"Early diagnosis and antitoxin treatment have contributed to the decline of the case fatality rate from approximately 31 per cent during 1950-1959 to no deaths in Alaska since 1994 (1). However, Alaska continues to have high foodborne botulism rates because fermented foods are part of Alaska Native culture. In a 1999 survey, 107 (77 per cent) of 140 Alaska Natives reported having eaten fermented foods at least once in their lifetime (3).\"\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Beller M. Botulism in Alaska: a guide for physicians and health-care providers -- 1998 update. Anchorage, Alaska: Alaska Department of Health and Social Services, 1998.\n2. Wainwright RB, Heyward WL, Middaugh JP, Hatheway CL, Harpster AP, Bender TR. Food-borne botulism in Alaska, 1947-1985: epidemiology and clinical findings. J Infect Dis. 1988;157(6):1158-62. Abstract available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=3373020.\n3. Chiou L, Hennessy T, Horn A, et al. A survey of knowledge, attitudes, and practices related to fermented foods known to cause botulism among Alaska Natives of southwest Alaska. [Abstract]. Presented at the 2nd International Conference on Emerging Infectious Diseases, Atlanta, Georgia, July 2000.\n4. Eisenberg MS, Bender TR. Plastic bags and botulism: a new twist to an old hazard of the north. Alaska Med. 1976;18(4):47-9.\n5. Shaffer N, Wainwright RB, Middaugh JP, Tauxe RV. Botulism among Alaska Natives: the role of changing food preparation and consumption practices. West J Med. 1990;153(4):390-3.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Alaska, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, injection drug-related 20180214.5628631\n2017\n---\nBotulism - USA (13): (AK) 20170930.5349662\nBotulism - USA (12): (NY) nitrogen-infused coffee, risk, alert, recall 20170920.5329208\nBotulism - USA (11): (NM) wound, injection drug related 20170719.5189504\nBotulism - USA (10): (CA) nacho cheese, type A toxin, unrelated 2nd death 20170525.5060186\nBotulism - USA (09): (CA) gas station food, nacho cheese conf, fatal 20170523.5056161\nBotulism - USA (08): (CA) gas station food, nacho cheese 20170519.5047996\nBotulism - USA (07): (CA) gas station food, nacho cheese 20170512.5031065\nBotulism - USA (06): (CA) gas station food, RFI 20170508.5021002\nBotulism - USA (05): deer antler herbal tea, FDA recall 20170507.5018201\nBotulism - USA (04): (CA) deer antler tea 20170429.5003486\nBotulism - USA (03): (TX) wound, drug-related, 2005-2015 20170427.4999639\nBotulism - USA (02): (CA) satay, risk, recall 20170420.4982801\nBotulism - USA: (CA) wound, non-drug-related 20170402.4942916\n.................................................ll/ao/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1994-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anchorage", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Hatheway", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5686836", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Kyrgyzstan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5686836", "date": "2018-02-03 16:52:10", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (02): TROUT CAVIAR, RISK, FURTHER EXPANDED RECALL\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 3 Feb 2018\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2018/02/canadian-authorities-update-caviar-recall-again/#.WnXBWeZOmhA\n\n\nFor the 10th time since late November 2017, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency has expanded a recall of Imperial Caviar and Seafood brand and VIP Caviar Club brand whitefish and salmon roe due to the potential presence of the dangerous bacterium, _Clostridium botulinum_ The update posted [Thu 1 Feb 2018],includes additional product information identified during the CFIA investigation.\n\nConsumers in Canada, particularly New Brunswick, Ontario and Quebec, should not consume the recalled products described below. \"If you think you got sick from eating a recalled product, call your doctor. Also, check to see if you have recalled products in your home and throw them out or return them to the store where they were purchased,\" according to the recall notice.\n\nFood contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_ toxin may not look or smell spoiled but can still make you sick. Symptoms of botulism poisoning paralyzes muscles, included those necessary for breathing, so anyone who has eaten any of the recalled caviar and developed early signs of symptoms should immediately seek medical attention. Symptoms can include facial paralysis or loss of facial expression, unreactive or fixed pupils, difficulty swallowing, drooping eyelids, blurred or double vision, difficulty speaking or slurred speech and a change in sound of voice, including hoarseness.\n\nSo far, there have been no reported illnesses associated with the consumption of these products, according to the recall notice.\n\n[Brand Name, Common Name, Size, Code(s) on Product, and UPC can be found at the original URL. - Imperial Caviar & Seafood and VIP Caviar Club brand Trout Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2017-12-09 - VIP Caviar Club brand Trout Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2017-11-25 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood and VIP Caviar Club brand Trout Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nA map of (Canada): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12. - Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nA map of (Canada): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12. - New Zealand (02): (WL) waterfowl, susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5644290", "date": "2018-02-03 16:52:10", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (02): TROUT CAVIAR, RISK, FURTHER EXPANDED RECALL\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 3 Feb 2018\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2018/02/canadian-authorities-update-caviar-recall-again/#.WnXBWeZOmhA\n\n\nFor the 10th time since late November 2017, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency has expanded a recall of Imperial Caviar and Seafood brand and VIP Caviar Club brand whitefish and salmon roe due to the potential presence of the dangerous bacterium, _Clostridium botulinum_ The update posted [Thu 1 Feb 2018],includes additional product information identified during the CFIA investigation.\n\nConsumers in Canada, particularly New Brunswick, Ontario and Quebec, should not consume the recalled products described below. \"If you think you got sick from eating a recalled product, call your doctor. Also, check to see if you have recalled products in your home and throw them out or return them to the store where they were purchased,\" according to the recall notice.\n\nFood contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_ toxin may not look or smell spoiled but can still make you sick. Symptoms of botulism poisoning paralyzes muscles, included those necessary for breathing, so anyone who has eaten any of the recalled caviar and developed early signs of symptoms should immediately seek medical attention. Symptoms can include facial paralysis or loss of facial expression, unreactive or fixed pupils, difficulty swallowing, drooping eyelids, blurred or double vision, difficulty speaking or slurred speech and a change in sound of voice, including hoarseness.\n\nSo far, there have been no reported illnesses associated with the consumption of these products, according to the recall notice.\n\n[Brand Name, Common Name, Size, Code(s) on Product, and UPC can be found at the original URL. - Mod.LL]\n\nImperial Caviar recalls, in reverse date order, since Nov. 25, 2017\n2018-01-27 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood brand and VIP Caviar Club brand Whitefish Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2018-01-23 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood / VIP Caviar Club brands Golden Whitefish Roe / Whitefish Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2018-01-11 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood / VIP Caviar Club* brands Golden Whitefish Roe / Whitefish Roe* due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2018-01-10 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood and VIP Caviar Club brand Trout Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2017-12-09 - VIP Caviar Club brand Trout Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2017-11-25 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood and VIP Caviar Club brand Trout Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nA map of (Canada): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12. - Canada (03): smoked fish, risk, recall 20140604.2518390\nBotulism - Canada (02): rice-abalone porridge, risk, recall 20140405.2384021\nBotulism - Canada: (AB) jarred bacon spread, risk, recall 20140205.2257139\n2013\n----\nBotulism - Canada (04): (ON) bottled relish, risk, recall 20131106.2042043\nBotulism, paralytic shellfish poisoning - Canada: (BC) alert 20131018.2008893\nBotulism - Canada (03): jarred lobster meat, risk, recall 20130411.1638646\nBotulism - Canada (02): (ON, QC) gefilte fish 20130331.1611463\nBotulism - Canada: jarred clams, risk, recall 20130325.1602821\n.................................................ll/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-11-25 00:00:00", "2017-12-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5604359", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Canada (02): trout caviar, risk, further expanded recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5604359", "date": "2018-02-03 16:52:10", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (02): TROUT CAVIAR, RISK, FURTHER EXPANDED RECALL\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 3 Feb 2018\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttp://www.foodsafetynews.com/2018/02/canadian-authorities-update-caviar-recall-again/#.WnXBWeZOmhA\n\n\nFor the 10th time since late November 2017, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency has expanded a recall of Imperial Caviar and Seafood brand and VIP Caviar Club brand whitefish and salmon roe due to the potential presence of the dangerous bacterium, _Clostridium botulinum_ The update posted [Thu 1 Feb 2018],includes additional product information identified during the CFIA investigation.\n\nConsumers in Canada, particularly New Brunswick, Ontario and Quebec, should not consume the recalled products described below. \"If you think you got sick from eating a recalled product, call your doctor. Also, check to see if you have recalled products in your home and throw them out or return them to the store where they were purchased,\" according to the recall notice.\n\nFood contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_ toxin may not look or smell spoiled but can still make you sick. Symptoms of botulism poisoning paralyzes muscles, included those necessary for breathing, so anyone who has eaten any of the recalled caviar and developed early signs of symptoms should immediately seek medical attention. Symptoms can include facial paralysis or loss of facial expression, unreactive or fixed pupils, difficulty swallowing, drooping eyelids, blurred or double vision, difficulty speaking or slurred speech and a change in sound of voice, including hoarseness.\n\nSo far, there have been no reported illnesses associated with the consumption of these products, according to the recall notice.\n\n[Brand Name, Common Name, Size, Code(s) on Product, and UPC can be found at the original URL. - Mod.LL]\n\nImperial Caviar recalls, in reverse date order, since Nov. 25, 2017\n2018-01-27 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood brand and VIP Caviar Club brand Whitefish Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2018-01-23 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood brand and VIP Caviar Club brand Whitefish and Salmon Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2018-01-19b - Imperial Caviar & Seafood brand Whitefish Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2018-01-12 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood / VIP Caviar Club brands Golden Whitefish Roe / Whitefish Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2018-01-11 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood / VIP Caviar Club* brands Golden Whitefish Roe / Whitefish Roe* due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2018-01-10 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood brand Whitefish Roe and VIP Caviar Club brand Salmon Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2018-01-03 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood brand Whitefish Roe and VIP Caviar Club brand Salmon Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2017-12-15 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood and VIP Caviar Club brand Trout Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2017-12-09 - VIP Caviar Club brand Trout Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n2017-11-25 - Imperial Caviar & Seafood and VIP Caviar Club brand Trout Roe recalled due to potential presence of dangerous bacteria\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nA map of (Canada): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12. - Canada (03): smoked fish, risk, recall 20140604.2518390\nBotulism - Canada (02): rice-abalone porridge, risk, recall 20140405.2384021\nBotulism - Canada: (AB) jarred bacon spread, risk, recall 20140205.2257139\n2013\n----\nBotulism - Canada (04): (ON) bottled relish, risk, recall 20131106.2042043\nBotulism, paralytic shellfish poisoning - Canada: (BC) alert 20131018.2008893\nBotulism - Canada (03): jarred lobster meat, risk, recall 20130411.1638646\nBotulism - Canada (02): (ON, QC) gefilte fish 20130331.1611463\nBotulism - Canada: jarred clams, risk, recall 20130325.1602821\n.................................................ll/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-11-25 00:00:00", "2017-12-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5595302", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - New Zealand: (WK/BP) waterfowl", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5595302", "date": "2017-12-10 12:20:23", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - UK: ENGLAND (LANCASHIRE)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Dec 2017\nSource: Farmers Guardian [summarized, edited]\nhttps://www.fginsight.com/news/news/it-was-absolutely-horrific---heartbroken-farmer-loses-50-cows-to-botulism-46625\n\n\n[A farmer] likened the scenes in his shed to those of a horror film, with cows quickly being paralysed, as the disease, which attacks the nervous system, took hold.\n\n[This farmer] from Clitheroe, Lancashire, 1st saw signs of the disease on a routine lunchtime check of the herd, predominantly Holstein-Friesians, and found one cow dead in the passageway.\n\nHe said: \"Another cow was floppy and weak. I rang the vet who came to do a post-mortem, and in that time another 2 had fallen.\n\n\"In just a few minutes, the floppy cow had died. It continued like that, and by Monday [4 Dec 2017], 38 were dead. I do not think anything can prepare you for it; it was absolutely horrific. Our cows are like pets to us, and to see them in such a state is heartbreaking.\"\n\nSome cows were injected with an anti-inflammatory and penicillin, but [the farmer] said it seemed to accelerate the disease.\n\nHe added: \"We tried to care for the cows by feeding them charcoal and even burnt toast to try to attempt to absorb the toxin, but with no success.\"\n\nOther cows which showed advanced signs were euthanised, with only one cow in the affected high-yielding herd, a Montbeliarde cross, remaining unscathed.\n\nDry cows and the low yielders, which were housed about 15ft [about 5 meters] away at the other side of the shed were not affected.\n\nTests on feed have all come back negative, but [the farm owner] said it was likely silage fed to cows had been contaminated with dead game or poultry birds, which are prolific carriers of the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, which causes botulism.\n\nIn total, [the farmer] who farms in partnership with his father, lost 47 high yielding milkers and 3 bulling heifers out of the 80-strong herd. He is now working with his vet to source a vaccine for his remaining cattle.\n\n[The farmer] said: \"Speaking to a lot of our friends and colleagues, this is extremely rare, but it could happen to anyone, and awareness is vital. My advice would be to vaccinate. I will be vaccinating all my cattle from now on.\"\n\n[Byline: Olivia Midgley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Following a marked increase in the reported incidence of suspected cattle botulism in England, Wales and Ireland since 2003, the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) in UK's Food Safety Agency, set in 2004 an ad-hoc Group on Botulism in Cattle. The group submitted its final report in 2006. One of their main recommendations involved the main source of the toxin, considered to be broiler litter, including carcasses of birds that have died during production. It was speculated that even small fragments of carcasses transferred onto pasture by scavenger animals, such as foxes, dogs or crows, can pose a risk to grazing cattle.\n\nOne of their points of discussion was the official status of the disease in cattle. They concluded: \"Reporting of botulism outbreaks in cattle is conducted on a voluntary basis. This may result in under-reporting of the disease. However, clinically affected animals are likely to be investigated, and, based on the low apparent risk to humans presented by toxin types C and D, which predominate in recent UK cattle outbreaks, statutory notification does not currently appear to be merited.\"\n\nThey further said that if litter has been spread on silage ground, it is advisable to raise the cutting blades so that the grass is cut less close to the ground. This will reduce the risk of decaying matter being included in the silage cut. Washings from poultry houses and yards should be collected in tanks rather than be allowed to flow onto adjacent land. Annexes 4 and 5 of the report present guidance to farmers on methods for the control of botulism in cattle. Vaccination is recommended, while indicating that it \"should not be used as a substitute for preventing exposure of cattle to broiler litter that may contain carcasses.\"\n\nAdditional observations, conclusions, recommendations and references are available in the full report, at https://acmsf.food.gov.uk/sites/default/files/mnt/drupal_data/sources/files/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nFor subscribers' convenience, we provide extracts from the \"Diagnostic tests\" (for animals) chapter in the \"Botulism\" review published by The Center for Food Security & Public Health at Iowa State University (CFSPH), updated June 2010 (for the entire review, see http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/botulism.pdf.):\n\n\"Botulism can be difficult to diagnose, as the toxin is not always found in clinical samples or the feed. Diagnosis is often a matter of excluding other diseases. A definitive diagnosis can be made if botulinum toxin is identified in the feed, serum/blood, stomach, crop or intestinal contents, vomitus, feces, or tissues. The toxin can usually be found in the blood or serum only in the early stages of the disease. Botulinum toxin is typically detected with a mouse bioassay. ELISAs may also be used, but they detect both active and inactivated (such as heat treated) toxins, and false positives are possible with this test. Botulinum toxins can be typed using neutralization tests in mice.\n\n\"_Clostridium botulinum_ organisms may also be isolated from the feed. In toxicoinfectious botulism, the organism may be cultured from the gastrointestinal contents, feces, wounds, or other tissues. Because healthy animals can have _C. botulinum_ spores in the gastrointestinal tract, finding them in this location should be interpreted with caution [_C. botulinum_ isolation techniques are described in detail in the original document].\n\n\"Biochemical tests and the detection of volatile metabolic products using gas-liquid chromatography are helpful in identification. The metabolic patterns and other characteristics vary with the strain/group. Definitive identification is by demonstration of the toxin. Molecular techniques can be used for the genetic characterization of _C. botulinum_ and may be helpful in determining the source of an outbreak.\n\n\"Serology is not used routinely in diagnosis, but antibodies to botulinum toxin have been reported in some animals that recovered, including horses, cattle, and a dog.\"\n\nThe preliminary suspicion of botulism in cattle may be based upon the very typical symptomatology. However, laboratory confirmation is required to exclude other possible etiologies, such as ionophores [polyether compounds] intoxication.\n\nBotulism in animals is not notifiable in the UK, nor in most countries. Hence, the actual number of events is not available. The UK 2006 report, mentioned above, addressed (in table 1) 67 incidents, identified in cattle in England and Wales during the years 2003-2005. The authors advised farmers to report any suspicion immediately to their practitioners. Botulism is not included in OIE's list of notifiable diseases. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nLancashire, England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/913]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBotulism, bovine - UK: (Wales) susp, RFI 20140523.2492126\n2006\n----\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, bovine - UK (England) 20060925.2743\nBotulism, bovine - UK (Scotland) 20060717.1962\n2003\n----\nBotulism, bovine - Ireland: poultry litter origin 20030701.1623\n.................................................sb/arn/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-06-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Cattle", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Lancashire", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5580039", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Nigeria: (Abuja) fish, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5580039", "date": "2017-12-10 12:20:23", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - UK: ENGLAND (LANCASHIRE)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Dec 2017\nSource: Farmers Guardian [summarized, edited]\nhttps://www.fginsight.com/news/news/it-was-absolutely-horrific---heartbroken-farmer-loses-50-cows-to-botulism-46625\n\n\n[A farmer] likened the scenes in his shed to those of a horror film, with cows quickly being paralysed, as the disease, which attacks the nervous system, took hold.\n\n[This farmer] from Clitheroe, Lancashire, 1st saw signs of the disease on a routine lunchtime check of the herd, predominantly Holstein-Friesians, and found one cow dead in the passageway.\n\nHe said: \"Another cow was floppy and weak. I rang the vet who came to do a post-mortem, and in that time another 2 had fallen.\n\n\"In just a few minutes, the floppy cow had died. It continued like that, and by Monday [4 Dec 2017], 38 were dead. I do not think anything can prepare you for it; it was absolutely horrific. Our cows are like pets to us, and to see them in such a state is heartbreaking.\"\n\nSome cows were injected with an anti-inflammatory and penicillin, but [the farmer] said it seemed to accelerate the disease.\n\nHe added: \"We tried to care for the cows by feeding them charcoal and even burnt toast to try to attempt to absorb the toxin, but with no success.\"\n\nOther cows which showed advanced signs were euthanised, with only one cow in the affected high-yielding herd, a Montbeliarde cross, remaining unscathed.\n\nDry cows and the low yielders, which were housed about 15ft [about 5 meters] away at the other side of the shed were not affected.\n\nTests on feed have all come back negative, but [the farm owner] said it was likely silage fed to cows had been contaminated with dead game or poultry birds, which are prolific carriers of the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, which causes botulism.\n\nIn total, [the farmer] who farms in partnership with his father, lost 47 high yielding milkers and 3 bulling heifers out of the 80-strong herd. He is now working with his vet to source a vaccine for his remaining cattle.\n\n[The farmer] said: \"Speaking to a lot of our friends and colleagues, this is extremely rare, but it could happen to anyone, and awareness is vital. My advice would be to vaccinate. I will be vaccinating all my cattle from now on.\"\n\n[Byline: Olivia Midgley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Following a marked increase in the reported incidence of suspected cattle botulism in England, Wales and Ireland since 2003, the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) in UK's Food Safety Agency, set in 2004 an ad-hoc Group on Botulism in Cattle. They concluded: \"Reporting of botulism outbreaks in cattle is conducted on a voluntary basis. This may result in under-reporting of the disease. However, clinically affected animals are likely to be investigated, and, based on the low apparent risk to humans presented by toxin types C and D, which predominate in recent UK cattle outbreaks, statutory notification does not currently appear to be merited.\"\n\nThey further said that if litter has been spread on silage ground, it is advisable to raise the cutting blades so that the grass is cut less close to the ground. This will reduce the risk of decaying matter being included in the silage cut. Washings from poultry houses and yards should be collected in tanks rather than be allowed to flow onto adjacent land. Annexes 4 and 5 of the report present guidance to farmers on methods for the control of botulism in cattle. Vaccination is recommended, while indicating that it \"should not be used as a substitute for preventing exposure of cattle to broiler litter that may contain carcasses.\"\n\nAdditional observations, conclusions, recommendations and references are available in the full report, at https://acmsf.food.gov.uk/sites/default/files/mnt/drupal_data/sources/files/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nFor subscribers' convenience, we provide extracts from the \"Diagnostic tests\" (for animals) chapter in the \"Botulism\" review published by The Center for Food Security & Public Health at Iowa State University (CFSPH), updated June 2010 (for the entire review, see http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/botulism.pdf.):\n\n\"Botulism can be difficult to diagnose, as the toxin is not always found in clinical samples or the feed. Diagnosis is often a matter of excluding other diseases. The toxin can usually be found in the blood or serum only in the early stages of the disease. Botulinum toxin is typically detected with a mouse bioassay. Molecular techniques can be used for the genetic characterization of _C. botulinum_ and may be helpful in determining the source of an outbreak.\n\n\"Serology is not used routinely in diagnosis, but antibodies to botulinum toxin have been reported in some animals that recovered, including horses, cattle, and a dog.\"\n\nThe preliminary suspicion of botulism in cattle may be based upon the very typical symptomatology. Ireland: poultry litter origin 20030701.1623\n.................................................sb/arn/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-06-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Cattle", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Lancashire", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5552344", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Canada: trout caviar, risk, expanded recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5552344", "date": "2017-12-10 12:20:23", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - UK: ENGLAND (LANCASHIRE)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Dec 2017\nSource: Farmers Guardian [summarized, edited]\nhttps://www.fginsight.com/news/news/it-was-absolutely-horrific---heartbroken-farmer-loses-50-cows-to-botulism-46625\n\n\n[A farmer] likened the scenes in his shed to those of a horror film, with cows quickly being paralysed, as the disease, which attacks the nervous system, took hold.\n\n[This farmer] from Clitheroe, Lancashire, 1st saw signs of the disease on a routine lunchtime check of the herd, predominantly Holstein-Friesians, and found one cow dead in the passageway.\n\nHe said: \"Another cow was floppy and weak. I rang the vet who came to do a post-mortem, and in that time another 2 had fallen.\n\n\"In just a few minutes, the floppy cow had died. It continued like that, and by Monday [4 Dec 2017], 38 were dead. I do not think anything can prepare you for it; it was absolutely horrific. Our cows are like pets to us, and to see them in such a state is heartbreaking.\"\n\nSome cows were injected with an anti-inflammatory and penicillin, but [the farmer] said it seemed to accelerate the disease.\n\nHe added: \"We tried to care for the cows by feeding them charcoal and even burnt toast to try to attempt to absorb the toxin, but with no success.\"\n\nOther cows which showed advanced signs were euthanised, with only one cow in the affected high-yielding herd, a Montbeliarde cross, remaining unscathed.\n\nDry cows and the low yielders, which were housed about 15ft [about 5 meters] away at the other side of the shed were not affected.\n\nTests on feed have all come back negative, but [the farm owner] said it was likely silage fed to cows had been contaminated with dead game or poultry birds, which are prolific carriers of the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, which causes botulism.\n\nIn total, [the farmer] who farms in partnership with his father, lost 47 high yielding milkers and 3 bulling heifers out of the 80-strong herd. He is now working with his vet to source a vaccine for his remaining cattle.\n\n[The farmer] said: \"Speaking to a lot of our friends and colleagues, this is extremely rare, but it could happen to anyone, and awareness is vital. My advice would be to vaccinate. I will be vaccinating all my cattle from now on.\"\n\n[Byline: Olivia Midgley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Following a marked increase in the reported incidence of suspected cattle botulism in England, Wales and Ireland since 2003, the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) in UK's Food Safety Agency, set in 2004 an ad-hoc Group on Botulism in Cattle. The group submitted its final report in 2006. One of their main recommendations involved the main source of the toxin, considered to be broiler litter, including carcasses of birds that have died during production. It was speculated that even small fragments of carcasses transferred onto pasture by scavenger animals, such as foxes, dogs or crows, can pose a risk to grazing cattle.\n\nOne of their points of discussion was the official status of the disease in cattle. They concluded: \"Reporting of botulism outbreaks in cattle is conducted on a voluntary basis. This may result in under-reporting of the disease. However, clinically affected animals are likely to be investigated, and, based on the low apparent risk to humans presented by toxin types C and D, which predominate in recent UK cattle outbreaks, statutory notification does not currently appear to be merited.\"\n\nThey further said that if litter has been spread on silage ground, it is advisable to raise the cutting blades so that the grass is cut less close to the ground. This will reduce the risk of decaying matter being included in the silage cut. Washings from poultry houses and yards should be collected in tanks rather than be allowed to flow onto adjacent land. Annexes 4 and 5 of the report present guidance to farmers on methods for the control of botulism in cattle. Vaccination is recommended, while indicating that it \"should not be used as a substitute for preventing exposure of cattle to broiler litter that may contain carcasses.\"\n\nAdditional observations, conclusions, recommendations and references are available in the full report, at https://acmsf.food.gov.uk/sites/default/files/mnt/drupal_data/sources/files/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nFor subscribers' convenience, we provide extracts from the \"Diagnostic tests\" (for animals) chapter in the \"Botulism\" review published by The Center for Food Security & Public Health at Iowa State University (CFSPH), updated June 2010 (for the entire review, see http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/botulism.pdf.):\n\n\"Botulism can be difficult to diagnose, as the toxin is not always found in clinical samples or the feed. Diagnosis is often a matter of excluding other diseases. A definitive diagnosis can be made if botulinum toxin is identified in the feed, serum/blood, stomach, crop or intestinal contents, vomitus, feces, or tissues. The toxin can usually be found in the blood or serum only in the early stages of the disease. Botulinum toxin is typically detected with a mouse bioassay. ELISAs may also be used, but they detect both active and inactivated (such as heat treated) toxins, and false positives are possible with this test. Botulinum toxins can be typed using neutralization tests in mice.\n\n\"_Clostridium botulinum_ organisms may also be isolated from the feed. In toxicoinfectious botulism, the organism may be cultured from the gastrointestinal contents, feces, wounds, or other tissues. Because healthy animals can have _C. botulinum_ spores in the gastrointestinal tract, finding them in this location should be interpreted with caution [_C. botulinum_ isolation techniques are described in detail in the original document].\n\n\"Biochemical tests and the detection of volatile metabolic products using gas-liquid chromatography are helpful in identification. The metabolic patterns and other characteristics vary with the strain/group. Definitive identification is by demonstration of the toxin. Molecular techniques can be used for the genetic characterization of _C. botulinum_ and may be helpful in determining the source of an outbreak.\n\n\"Serology is not used routinely in diagnosis, but antibodies to botulinum toxin have been reported in some animals that recovered, including horses, cattle, and a dog.\"\n\nThe preliminary suspicion of botulism in cattle may be based upon the very typical symptomatology. However, laboratory confirmation is required to exclude other possible etiologies, such as ionophores [polyether compounds] intoxication.\n\nBotulism in animals is not notifiable in the UK, nor in most countries. Hence, the actual number of events is not available. The UK 2006 report, mentioned above, addressed (in table 1) 67 incidents, identified in cattle in England and Wales during the years 2003-2005. The authors advised farmers to report any suspicion immediately to their practitioners. Botulism is not included in OIE's list of notifiable diseases. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nLancashire, England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/913]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBotulism, bovine - UK: (Wales) susp, RFI 20140523.2492126\n2006\n----\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, bovine - UK (England) 20060925.2743\nBotulism, bovine - UK (Scotland) 20060717.1962\n2003\n----\nBotulism, bovine - Ireland: poultry litter origin 20030701.1623\n.................................................sb/arn/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-06-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Cattle", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Lancashire", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5547447", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - USA: (Lake Michigan) waterfowl, ecology, 2010-2013", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5547447", "date": "2017-12-10 12:20:23", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - UK: ENGLAND (LANCASHIRE)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Dec 2017\nSource: Farmers Guardian [summarized, edited]\nhttps://www.fginsight.com/news/news/it-was-absolutely-horrific---heartbroken-farmer-loses-50-cows-to-botulism-46625\n\n\n[A farmer] likened the scenes in his shed to those of a horror film, with cows quickly being paralysed, as the disease, which attacks the nervous system, took hold.\n\n[This farmer] from Clitheroe, Lancashire, 1st saw signs of the disease on a routine lunchtime check of the herd, predominantly Holstein-Friesians, and found one cow dead in the passageway.\n\nHe said: \"Another cow was floppy and weak. I rang the vet who came to do a post-mortem, and in that time another 2 had fallen.\n\n\"In just a few minutes, the floppy cow had died. It continued like that, and by Monday [4 Dec 2017], 38 were dead. I do not think anything can prepare you for it; it was absolutely horrific. Our cows are like pets to us, and to see them in such a state is heartbreaking.\"\n\nSome cows were injected with an anti-inflammatory and penicillin, but [the farmer] said it seemed to accelerate the disease.\n\nHe added: \"We tried to care for the cows by feeding them charcoal and even burnt toast to try to attempt to absorb the toxin, but with no success.\"\n\nOther cows which showed advanced signs were euthanised, with only one cow in the affected high-yielding herd, a Montbeliarde cross, remaining unscathed.\n\nDry cows and the low yielders, which were housed about 15ft [about 5 meters] away at the other side of the shed were not affected.\n\nTests on feed have all come back negative, but [the farm owner] said it was likely silage fed to cows had been contaminated with dead game or poultry birds, which are prolific carriers of the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, which causes botulism.\n\nIn total, [the farmer] who farms in partnership with his father, lost 47 high yielding milkers and 3 bulling heifers out of the 80-strong herd. He is now working with his vet to source a vaccine for his remaining cattle.\n\n[The farmer] said: \"Speaking to a lot of our friends and colleagues, this is extremely rare, but it could happen to anyone, and awareness is vital. My advice would be to vaccinate. I will be vaccinating all my cattle from now on.\"\n\n[Byline: Olivia Midgley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Following a marked increase in the reported incidence of suspected cattle botulism in England, Wales and Ireland since 2003, the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) in UK's Food Safety Agency, set in 2004 an ad-hoc Group on Botulism in Cattle. The group submitted its final report in 2006. One of their main recommendations involved the main source of the toxin, considered to be broiler litter, including carcasses of birds that have died during production. It was speculated that even small fragments of carcasses transferred onto pasture by scavenger animals, such as foxes, dogs or crows, can pose a risk to grazing cattle.\n\nOne of their points of discussion was the official status of the disease in cattle. They concluded: \"Reporting of botulism outbreaks in cattle is conducted on a voluntary basis. This may result in under-reporting of the disease. However, clinically affected animals are likely to be investigated, and, based on the low apparent risk to humans presented by toxin types C and D, which predominate in recent UK cattle outbreaks, statutory notification does not currently appear to be merited.\"\n\nThey further said that if litter has been spread on silage ground, it is advisable to raise the cutting blades so that the grass is cut less close to the ground. This will reduce the risk of decaying matter being included in the silage cut. Washings from poultry houses and yards should be collected in tanks rather than be allowed to flow onto adjacent land. Annexes 4 and 5 of the report present guidance to farmers on methods for the control of botulism in cattle. Vaccination is recommended, while indicating that it \"should not be used as a substitute for preventing exposure of cattle to broiler litter that may contain carcasses.\"\n\nAdditional observations, conclusions, recommendations and references are available in the full report, at https://acmsf.food.gov.uk/sites/default/files/mnt/drupal_data/sources/files/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nFor subscribers' convenience, we provide extracts from the \"Diagnostic tests\" (for animals) chapter in the \"Botulism\" review published by The Center for Food Security & Public Health at Iowa State University (CFSPH), updated June 2010 (for the entire review, see http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/botulism.pdf.):\n\n\"Botulism can be difficult to diagnose, as the toxin is not always found in clinical samples or the feed. Diagnosis is often a matter of excluding other diseases. A definitive diagnosis can be made if botulinum toxin is identified in the feed, serum/blood, stomach, crop or intestinal contents, vomitus, feces, or tissues. The toxin can usually be found in the blood or serum only in the early stages of the disease. Botulinum toxin is typically detected with a mouse bioassay. ELISAs may also be used, but they detect both active and inactivated (such as heat treated) toxins, and false positives are possible with this test. Botulinum toxins can be typed using neutralization tests in mice.\n\n\"_Clostridium botulinum_ organisms may also be isolated from the feed. In toxicoinfectious botulism, the organism may be cultured from the gastrointestinal contents, feces, wounds, or other tissues. Because healthy animals can have _C. botulinum_ spores in the gastrointestinal tract, finding them in this location should be interpreted with caution [_C. botulinum_ isolation techniques are described in detail in the original document].\n\n\"Biochemical tests and the detection of volatile metabolic products using gas-liquid chromatography are helpful in identification. The metabolic patterns and other characteristics vary with the strain/group. Definitive identification is by demonstration of the toxin. Molecular techniques can be used for the genetic characterization of _C. botulinum_ and may be helpful in determining the source of an outbreak.\n\n\"Serology is not used routinely in diagnosis, but antibodies to botulinum toxin have been reported in some animals that recovered, including horses, cattle, and a dog.\"\n\nThe preliminary suspicion of botulism in cattle may be based upon the very typical symptomatology. However, laboratory confirmation is required to exclude other possible etiologies, such as ionophores [polyether compounds] intoxication.\n\nBotulism in animals is not notifiable in the UK, nor in most countries. Hence, the actual number of events is not available. The UK 2006 report, mentioned above, addressed (in table 1) 67 incidents, identified in cattle in England and Wales during the years 2003-2005. The authors advised farmers to report any suspicion immediately to their practitioners. Botulism is not included in OIE's list of notifiable diseases. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nLancashire, England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/913]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBotulism, bovine - Ireland: poultry litter origin 20030701.1623\n.................................................sb/arn/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-06-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Cattle", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Lancashire", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5522825", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - UK (03): (Scotland) haggis, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5522825", "date": "2017-12-10 12:20:23", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - UK: ENGLAND (LANCASHIRE)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Dec 2017\nSource: Farmers Guardian [summarized, edited]\nhttps://www.fginsight.com/news/news/it-was-absolutely-horrific---heartbroken-farmer-loses-50-cows-to-botulism-46625\n\n\n[A farmer] likened the scenes in his shed to those of a horror film, with cows quickly being paralysed, as the disease, which attacks the nervous system, took hold.\n\n[This farmer] from Clitheroe, Lancashire, 1st saw signs of the disease on a routine lunchtime check of the herd, predominantly Holstein-Friesians, and found one cow dead in the passageway.\n\nHe said: \"Another cow was floppy and weak. I rang the vet who came to do a post-mortem, and in that time another 2 had fallen.\n\n\"In just a few minutes, the floppy cow had died. It continued like that, and by Monday [4 Dec 2017], 38 were dead. I do not think anything can prepare you for it; it was absolutely horrific. Our cows are like pets to us, and to see them in such a state is heartbreaking.\"\n\nSome cows were injected with an anti-inflammatory and penicillin, but [the farmer] said it seemed to accelerate the disease.\n\nHe added: \"We tried to care for the cows by feeding them charcoal and even burnt toast to try to attempt to absorb the toxin, but with no success.\"\n\nOther cows which showed advanced signs were euthanised, with only one cow in the affected high-yielding herd, a Montbeliarde cross, remaining unscathed.\n\nDry cows and the low yielders, which were housed about 15ft [about 5 meters] away at the other side of the shed were not affected.\n\nTests on feed have all come back negative, but [the farm owner] said it was likely silage fed to cows had been contaminated with dead game or poultry birds, which are prolific carriers of the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, which causes botulism.\n\nIn total, [the farmer] who farms in partnership with his father, lost 47 high yielding milkers and 3 bulling heifers out of the 80-strong herd. He is now working with his vet to source a vaccine for his remaining cattle.\n\n[The farmer] said: \"Speaking to a lot of our friends and colleagues, this is extremely rare, but it could happen to anyone, and awareness is vital. My advice would be to vaccinate. I will be vaccinating all my cattle from now on.\"\n\n[Byline: Olivia Midgley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Following a marked increase in the reported incidence of suspected cattle botulism in England, Wales and Ireland since 2003, the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) in UK's Food Safety Agency, set in 2004 an ad-hoc Group on Botulism in Cattle. The group submitted its final report in 2006. One of their main recommendations involved the main source of the toxin, considered to be broiler litter, including carcasses of birds that have died during production. It was speculated that even small fragments of carcasses transferred onto pasture by scavenger animals, such as foxes, dogs or crows, can pose a risk to grazing cattle.\n\nOne of their points of discussion was the official status of the disease in cattle. They concluded: \"Reporting of botulism outbreaks in cattle is conducted on a voluntary basis. This may result in under-reporting of the disease. However, clinically affected animals are likely to be investigated, and, based on the low apparent risk to humans presented by toxin types C and D, which predominate in recent UK cattle outbreaks, statutory notification does not currently appear to be merited.\"\n\nThey further said that if litter has been spread on silage ground, it is advisable to raise the cutting blades so that the grass is cut less close to the ground. This will reduce the risk of decaying matter being included in the silage cut. Washings from poultry houses and yards should be collected in tanks rather than be allowed to flow onto adjacent land. Annexes 4 and 5 of the report present guidance to farmers on methods for the control of botulism in cattle. Vaccination is recommended, while indicating that it \"should not be used as a substitute for preventing exposure of cattle to broiler litter that may contain carcasses.\"\n\nAdditional observations, conclusions, recommendations and references are available in the full report, at https://acmsf.food.gov.uk/sites/default/files/mnt/drupal_data/sources/files/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nFor subscribers' convenience, we provide extracts from the \"Diagnostic tests\" (for animals) chapter in the \"Botulism\" review published by The Center for Food Security & Public Health at Iowa State University (CFSPH), updated June 2010 (for the entire review, see http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/botulism.pdf.):\n\n\"Botulism can be difficult to diagnose, as the toxin is not always found in clinical samples or the feed. Diagnosis is often a matter of excluding other diseases. A definitive diagnosis can be made if botulinum toxin is identified in the feed, serum/blood, stomach, crop or intestinal contents, vomitus, feces, or tissues. The toxin can usually be found in the blood or serum only in the early stages of the disease. Botulinum toxin is typically detected with a mouse bioassay. ELISAs may also be used, but they detect both active and inactivated (such as heat treated) toxins, and false positives are possible with this test. Botulinum toxins can be typed using neutralization tests in mice.\n\n\"_Clostridium botulinum_ organisms may also be isolated from the feed. In toxicoinfectious botulism, the organism may be cultured from the gastrointestinal contents, feces, wounds, or other tissues. Because healthy animals can have _C. botulinum_ spores in the gastrointestinal tract, finding them in this location should be interpreted with caution [_C. botulinum_ isolation techniques are described in detail in the original document].\n\n\"Biochemical tests and the detection of volatile metabolic products using gas-liquid chromatography are helpful in identification. The metabolic patterns and other characteristics vary with the strain/group. Definitive identification is by demonstration of the toxin. Molecular techniques can be used for the genetic characterization of _C. botulinum_ and may be helpful in determining the source of an outbreak.\n\n\"Serology is not used routinely in diagnosis, but antibodies to botulinum toxin have been reported in some animals that recovered, including horses, cattle, and a dog.\"\n\nThe preliminary suspicion of botulism in cattle may be based upon the very typical symptomatology. However, laboratory confirmation is required to exclude other possible etiologies, such as ionophores [polyether compounds] intoxication.\n\nBotulism in animals is not notifiable in the UK, nor in most countries. Hence, the actual number of events is not available. The UK 2006 report, mentioned above, addressed (in table 1) 67 incidents, identified in cattle in England and Wales during the years 2003-2005. The authors advised farmers to report any suspicion immediately to their practitioners. Botulism is not included in OIE's list of notifiable diseases. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nLancashire, England, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/913]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBotulism, bovine -
