In a news release, the department says it is investigating the reports.\n\nBotulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness, according to Health Canada. The spores of the _Clostridium botulinum_ bacterium can be found in soil and dust and tends to cause problems when certain foods are stored or prepared improperly.\n\nHealth Canada says food may not look or smell spoiled but it can make people sick.\n\nNunavut's Department of Health says people that have eaten fermented seal should watch for symptoms, such as:\n- diarrhea, nausea and vomiting;\n- feeling weak or tired;\n- blurred vision;\n- weakness of the arms, chest muscles, and legs;\n- trouble breathing.\n\nAnyone with symptoms should contact the health centre in Sanikiluaq. The department is also asking anyone with leftover fermented seal that could be used for testing to call their regional environmental health officer.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/Canada_Provinces_and_territories_map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16751.\n\nThe following publication summarizes 2 decades of botulism in Canada, a great majority occurring due to type E in the native population,\n\nLeclair D, Fung J, Isaac-Renton JL, et al. Foodborne botulism in Canada, 1985-2005. Emerg Infect Dis. 2013; 19(6): 961-8; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3713816/\n\nAbstract\n--------\nDuring 1985-2005, a total of 91 laboratory-confirmed outbreaks of foodborne botulism occurred in Canada; these outbreaks involved 205 cases and 11 deaths. Of the outbreaks, 75 (86.2 per cent) were caused by _Clostridium botulinum_ type E, followed by types A (7, 8.1 per cent) and B (5, 5.7 per cent). Approximately 85 per cent of the outbreaks occurred in Alaska Native communities, particularly the Inuit of Nunavik in northern Quebec and the First Nations population of the Pacific coast of British Columbia. These populations were predominantly exposed to type E botulinum toxin through the consumption of traditionally prepared marine mammal and fish products. 2 botulism outbreaks were attributed to commercial ready-to-eat meat products and 3 to foods served in restaurants; several cases were attributed to non-Native home-prepared foods. 3 affected pregnant women delivered healthy infants. Improvements in botulism case identification and early treatment have resulted in a reduction in the case-fatality rate in Canada.\n\nThe following was abstracted from a 2001 CDC report on foodborne botulism in the native American population in Alaska and underscores changes in the fermentation techniques which appear to have increased the risks of this intoxication\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5032a2.htm):\n\nThis report illustrates how the use of nontraditional fermentation methods is associated with foodborne botulism in Alaska. Botulism results from eating preformed toxin produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism intoxication can result in death, which most often is caused by respiratory failure. The latent period is typically 12-36 hours but can range from 6 hours to 10 days (1). _C. botulinum_ and closely related organisms produce toxins designated as types A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is most commonly caused by types A, B, and E. Type E is associated with foods of marine or freshwater origin. Alaska's foodborne botulism rates exceed those in any other state and are among the highest in the world (1). During 1950-2000, Alaska recorded 226 cases of foodborne botulism from 114 outbreaks. All patients were Alaska Natives, and all cases with known causes were associated with eating fermented foods (1,2). Approximately 27 per cent of US foodborne botulism cases occur in Alaska.\n\nIn traditional fermentation, food is kept in a grass-lined hole in the ground or a wooden barrel sunken into the ground or is placed in a shady area above ground for several weeks to months. Since the 1970s, however, plastic or glass containers have been used and fermentation has been done above ground or indoors. The anaerobic condition of sealed containers and warmer temperatures make fermentation more rapid and production of botulism toxin more likely (3-5). These nontraditional methods have been associated with increased botulism rates in Alaska during 1970-1989 (4,5). Although a plastic container was not used in this outbreak, the beaver tail and paw were fermented in a closed rice sack and stored in a warm area.\n\nEarly diagnosis and antitoxin treatment have contributed to the decline of the case fatality rate from approximately 31 per cent during 1950-1959 to no deaths in Alaska since 1994 (1). However, Alaska continues to have high foodborne botulism rates because fermented foods are part of Alaska Native culture. In a 1999 survey, 107 (77 per cent) of 140 Alaska Natives reported having eaten fermented foods at least once in their lifetime (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Beller M. Botulism in Alaska: a guide for physicians and health-care providers -- 1998 update. Anchorage, Alaska: Alaska Department of Health and Social Services, 1998.\n2. Wainwright RB, Heyward WL, Middaugh JP, et al. Food-borne botulism in Alaska, 1947-1985: epidemiology and clinical findings. J Infect Dis. 1988; 157: 1158-62.\n3. Chiou L, Hennessy T, Horn A, Carter G, Butler J. A survey of knowledge, attitudes, and practices related to fermented foods known to cause botulism among Alaska Natives of southwest Alaska. [Abstract]. Presented at the 2nd International Conference on Emerging Infectious Diseases, Atlanta, Georgia, July 2000.\n4. Eisenberg MS, Bender TR. Plastic bags and botulism: a new twist to an old hazard of the north. Alaska Med 1976; July: 47-9.\n5. Shaffer N, Wainwright RB, Middaugh JP. Botulism among Alaska Natives: the role of changing food preparation and consumption practices. West J Med. 1990;153: 390-3.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2015\n---\nBotulism - USA (10): (AK, NC) fermented seal flipper, home canned carrots 20150515.3364683\n2014\n---\nBotulism - USA (13): (AK) seal oil, large cluster, alert 20141225.3054025\n2007\n---\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\n2003\n---\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\nBotulism, humans - USA (Alaska) 20020721.4823\n1997\n---\nBotulism - Canada (02) 19970926.2019\nBotulism - Canada 19970921.1985\n.................................................ll/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "1975-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1994-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1988-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Sanikiluaq", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4535918", "headline": "PRO/EDR>  Botulism - USA (11): (NM) wound, drug-related", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4535918", "date": "2016-09-13 12:40:58", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (02): (NUNAVUT) FERMENTED SEAL\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Sep 2016\nSource: CBC (Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) News\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/beta/news/canada/north/nunavut-botulism-fermented-seal-1.3758946\n\n\nNunavut's health department is warning people in Sanikiluaq not to eat fermented seal, after it received reports of people becoming sick with botulism after consuming the meat. In a news release, the department says it is investigating the reports.\n\nBotulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness, according to Health Canada. The spores of the _Clostridium botulinum_ bacterium can be found in soil and dust and tends to cause problems when certain foods are stored or prepared improperly.\n\nHealth Canada says food may not look or smell spoiled but it can make people sick.\n\nNunavut's Department of Health says people that have eaten fermented seal should watch for symptoms, such as:\n- diarrhea, nausea and vomiting;\n- feeling weak or tired;\n- blurred vision;\n- weakness of the arms, chest muscles, and legs;\n- trouble breathing.\n\nAnyone with symptoms should contact the health centre in Sanikiluaq. The department is also asking anyone with leftover fermented seal that could be used for testing to call their regional environmental health officer.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/Canada_Provinces_and_territories_map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16751.\n\nThe following publication summarizes 2 decades of botulism in Canada, a great majority occurring due to type E in the native population,\n\nLeclair D, Fung J, Isaac-Renton JL, et al. Foodborne botulism in Canada, 1985-2005. Emerg Infect Dis. 2013; 19(6): 961-8; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3713816/\n\nAbstract\n--------\nDuring 1985-2005, a total of 91 laboratory-confirmed outbreaks of foodborne botulism occurred in Canada; these outbreaks involved 205 cases and 11 deaths. Of the outbreaks, 75 (86.2 per cent) were caused by _Clostridium botulinum_ type E, followed by types A (7, 8.1 per cent) and B (5, 5.7 per cent). Approximately 85 per cent of the outbreaks occurred in Alaska Native communities, particularly the Inuit of Nunavik in northern Quebec and the First Nations population of the Pacific coast of British Columbia. These populations were predominantly exposed to type E botulinum toxin through the consumption of traditionally prepared marine mammal and fish products. 2 botulism outbreaks were attributed to commercial ready-to-eat meat products and 3 to foods served in restaurants; several cases were attributed to non-Native home-prepared foods. 3 affected pregnant women delivered healthy infants. Improvements in botulism case identification and early treatment have resulted in a reduction in the case-fatality rate in Canada.\n\nThe following was abstracted from a 2001 CDC report on foodborne botulism in the native American population in Alaska and underscores changes in the fermentation techniques which appear to have increased the risks of this intoxication\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5032a2.htm):\n\nThis report illustrates how the use of nontraditional fermentation methods is associated with foodborne botulism in Alaska. Botulism results from eating preformed toxin produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism intoxication can result in death, which most often is caused by respiratory failure. The latent period is typically 12-36 hours but can range from 6 hours to 10 days (1). _C. botulinum_ and closely related organisms produce toxins designated as types A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is most commonly caused by types A, B, and E. Type E is associated with foods of marine or freshwater origin. Alaska's foodborne botulism rates exceed those in any other state and are among the highest in the world (1). During 1950-2000, Alaska recorded 226 cases of foodborne botulism from 114 outbreaks. All patients were Alaska Natives, and all cases with known causes were associated with eating fermented foods (1,2). Approximately 27 per cent of US foodborne botulism cases occur in Alaska.\n\nIn traditional fermentation, food is kept in a grass-lined hole in the ground or a wooden barrel sunken into the ground or is placed in a shady area above ground for several weeks to months. Since the 1970s, however, plastic or glass containers have been used and fermentation has been done above ground or indoors. The anaerobic condition of sealed containers and warmer temperatures make fermentation more rapid and production of botulism toxin more likely (3-5). These nontraditional methods have been associated with increased botulism rates in Alaska during 1970-1989 (4,5). Although a plastic container was not used in this outbreak, the beaver tail and paw were fermented in a closed rice sack and stored in a warm area.\n\nEarly diagnosis and antitoxin treatment have contributed to the decline of the case fatality rate from approximately 31 per cent during 1950-1959 to no deaths in Alaska since 1994 (1). However, Alaska continues to have high foodborne botulism rates because fermented foods are part of Alaska Native culture. In a 1999 survey, 107 (77 per cent) of 140 Alaska Natives reported having eaten fermented foods at least once in their lifetime (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Beller M. Botulism in Alaska: a guide for physicians and health-care providers -- 1998 update. Anchorage, Alaska: Alaska Department of Health and Social Services, 1998.\n2. Wainwright RB, Heyward WL, Middaugh JP, et al. Food-borne botulism in Alaska, 1947-1985: epidemiology and clinical findings. J Infect Dis. 1988; 157: 1158-62.\n3. Chiou L, Hennessy T, Horn A, Carter G, Butler J. A survey of knowledge, attitudes, and practices related to fermented foods known to cause botulism among Alaska Natives of southwest Alaska. [Abstract]. Presented at the 2nd International Conference on Emerging Infectious Diseases, Atlanta, Georgia, July 2000.\n4. Eisenberg MS, Bender TR. Plastic bags and botulism: a new twist to an old hazard of the north. Alaska Med 1976; July: 47-9.\n5. Shaffer N, Wainwright RB, Middaugh JP. Botulism among Alaska Natives: the role of changing food preparation and consumption practices. West J Med. 1990;153: 390-3.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2015\n---\nBotulism - USA (10): (AK, NC) fermented seal flipper, home canned carrots 20150515.3364683\n2014\n---\nBotulism - USA (13): (AK) seal oil, large cluster, alert 20141225.3054025\n2007\n---\nBotulism, native foods - In a news release, the department says it is investigating the reports.\n\nBotulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness, according to Health Canada. The spores of the _Clostridium botulinum_ bacterium can be found in soil and dust and tends to cause problems when certain foods are stored or prepared improperly.\n\nHealth Canada says food may not look or smell spoiled but it can make people sick.\n\nNunavut's Department of Health says people that have eaten fermented seal should watch for symptoms, such as:\n- diarrhea, nausea and vomiting;\n- feeling weak or tired;\n- blurred vision;\n- weakness of the arms, chest muscles, and legs;\n- trouble breathing.\n\nAnyone with symptoms should contact the health centre in Sanikiluaq. Foodborne botulism in Canada, 1985-2005. Emerg Infect Dis. 2013; 19(6): 961-8; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3713816/\n\nAbstract\n--------\nDuring 1985-2005, a total of 91 laboratory-confirmed outbreaks of foodborne botulism occurred in Canada; these outbreaks involved 205 cases and 11 deaths. Improvements in botulism case identification and early treatment have resulted in a reduction in the case-fatality rate in Canada.\n\nThe following was abstracted from a 2001 CDC report on foodborne botulism in the native American population in Alaska and underscores changes in the fermentation techniques which appear to have increased the risks of this intoxication\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5032a2.htm):\n\nThis report illustrates how the use of nontraditional fermentation methods is associated with foodborne botulism in Alaska. Botulism results from eating preformed toxin produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism intoxication can result in death, which most often is caused by respiratory failure. The latent period is typically 12-36 hours but can range from 6 hours to 10 days (1). _C. botulinum_ and closely related organisms produce toxins designated as types A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is most commonly caused by types A, B, and E. Type E is associated with foods of marine or freshwater origin. Alaska's foodborne botulism rates exceed those in any other state and are among the highest in the world (1). During 1950-2000, Alaska recorded 226 cases of foodborne botulism from 114 outbreaks. All patients were Alaska Natives, and all cases with known causes were associated with eating fermented foods (1,2). Approximately 27 per cent of US foodborne botulism cases occur in Alaska.\n\nIn traditional fermentation, food is kept in a grass-lined hole in the ground or a wooden barrel sunken into the ground or is placed in a shady area above ground for several weeks to months. Since the 1970s, however, plastic or glass containers have been used and fermentation has been done above ground or indoors. The anaerobic condition of sealed containers and warmer temperatures make fermentation more rapid and production of botulism toxin more likely (3-5). These nontraditional methods have been associated with increased botulism rates in Alaska during 1970-1989 (4,5). Although a plastic container was not used in this outbreak, the beaver tail and paw were fermented in a closed rice sack and stored in a warm area.\n\nEarly diagnosis and antitoxin treatment have contributed to the decline of the case fatality rate from approximately 31 per cent during 1950-1959 to no deaths in Alaska since 1994 (1). However, Alaska continues to have high foodborne botulism rates because fermented foods are part of Alaska Native culture. In a 1999 survey, 107 (77 per cent) of 140 Alaska Natives reported having eaten fermented foods at least once in their lifetime (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Beller M. In a news release, the department says it is investigating the reports.\n\nBotulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness, according to Health Canada. The spores of the _Clostridium botulinum_ bacterium can be found in soil and dust and tends to cause problems when certain foods are stored or prepared improperly.\n\nHealth Canada says food may not look or smell spoiled but it can make people sick.\n\nNunavut's Department of Health says people that have eaten fermented seal should watch for symptoms, such as:\n- diarrhea, nausea and vomiting;\n- feeling weak or tired;\n- blurred vision;\n- weakness of the arms, chest muscles, and legs;\n- trouble breathing.\n\nAnyone with symptoms should contact the health centre in Sanikiluaq. Foodborne botulism in Canada, 1985-2005. Emerg Infect Dis. 2013; 19(6): 961-8; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3713816/\n\nAbstract\n--------\nDuring 1985-2005, a total of 91 laboratory-confirmed outbreaks of foodborne botulism occurred in Canada; these outbreaks involved 205 cases and 11 deaths. Of the outbreaks, 75 (86.2 per cent) were caused by _Clostridium botulinum_ type E, followed by types A (7, 8.1 per cent) and B (5, 5.7 per cent). Approximately 85 per cent of the outbreaks occurred in Alaska Native communities, particularly the Inuit of Nunavik in northern Quebec and the First Nations population of the Pacific coast of British Columbia. These populations were predominantly exposed to type E botulinum toxin through the consumption of traditionally prepared marine mammal and fish products. 2 botulism outbreaks were attributed to commercial ready-to-eat meat products and 3 to foods served in restaurants; several cases were attributed to non-Native home-prepared foods. 3 affected pregnant women delivered healthy infants. Improvements in botulism case identification and early treatment have resulted in a reduction in the case-fatality rate in Canada.\n\nThe following was abstracted from a 2001 CDC report on foodborne botulism in the native American population in Alaska and underscores changes in the fermentation techniques which appear to have increased the risks of this intoxication\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5032a2.htm):\n\nThis report illustrates how the use of nontraditional fermentation methods is associated with foodborne botulism in Alaska. Botulism results from eating preformed toxin produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism intoxication can result in death, which most often is caused by respiratory failure. The latent period is typically 12-36 hours but can range from 6 hours to 10 days (1). _C. botulinum_ and closely related organisms produce toxins designated as types A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is most commonly caused by types A, B, and E. Type E is associated with foods of marine or freshwater origin. Alaska's foodborne botulism rates exceed those in any other state and are among the highest in the world (1). During 1950-2000, Alaska recorded 226 cases of foodborne botulism from 114 outbreaks. All patients were Alaska Natives, and all cases with known causes were associated with eating fermented foods (1,2). Approximately 27 per cent of US foodborne botulism cases occur in Alaska.\n\nIn traditional fermentation, food is kept in a grass-lined hole in the ground or a wooden barrel sunken into the ground or is placed in a shady area above ground for several weeks to months. Since the 1970s, however, plastic or glass containers have been used and fermentation has been done above ground or indoors. The anaerobic condition of sealed containers and warmer temperatures make fermentation more rapid and production of botulism toxin more likely (3-5). These nontraditional methods have been associated with increased botulism rates in Alaska during 1970-1989 (4,5). Although a plastic container was not used in this outbreak, the beaver tail and paw were fermented in a closed rice sack and stored in a warm area.\n\nEarly diagnosis and antitoxin treatment have contributed to the decline of the case fatality rate from approximately 31 per cent during 1950-1959 to no deaths in Alaska since 1994 (1). However, Alaska continues to have high foodborne botulism rates because fermented foods are part of Alaska Native culture. In a 1999 survey, 107 (77 per cent) of 140 Alaska Natives reported having eaten fermented foods at least once in their lifetime (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Beller M. [Abstract]. Presented at the 2nd International Conference on Emerging Infectious Diseases, Atlanta, Georgia, July 2000.\n4. Eisenberg MS, Bender TR. Plastic bags and botulism: a new twist to an old hazard of the north. Alaska Med 1976; July: 47-9.\n5. Shaffer N, Wainwright RB, Middaugh JP. Botulism among Alaska Natives: the role of changing food preparation and consumption practices. West J Med. 1990;153: 390-3.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2015\n---\nBotulism - USA (10): (AK, NC) fermented seal flipper, home canned carrots 20150515.3364683\n2014\n---\nBotulism - USA (13): (AK) seal oil, large cluster, alert 20141225.3054025\n2007\n---\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\n2003\n---\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\nBotulism, humans - USA (Alaska) 20020721.4823\n1997\n---\nBotulism - Canada (02) 19970926.2019\nBotulism - Canada 19970921.1985\n.................................................ll/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "1975-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1994-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1988-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Sanikiluaq", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4484992", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Canada : (NU) fermented seal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4484992", "date": "2016-09-13 12:40:58", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (02): (NUNAVUT) FERMENTED SEAL\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Sep 2016\nSource: CBC (Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) News\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/beta/news/canada/north/nunavut-botulism-fermented-seal-1.3758946\n\n\nNunavut's health department is warning people in Sanikiluaq not to eat fermented seal, after it received reports of people becoming sick with botulism after consuming the meat. In a news release, the department says it is investigating the reports.\n\nBotulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness, according to Health Canada. The spores of the _Clostridium botulinum_ bacterium can be found in soil and dust and tends to cause problems when certain foods are stored or prepared improperly.\n\nHealth Canada says food may not look or smell spoiled but it can make people sick.\n\nNunavut's Department of Health says people that have eaten fermented seal should watch for symptoms, such as:\n- diarrhea, nausea and vomiting;\n- feeling weak or tired;\n- blurred vision;\n- weakness of the arms, chest muscles, and legs;\n- trouble breathing.\n\nAnyone with symptoms should contact the health centre in Sanikiluaq. The department is also asking anyone with leftover fermented seal that could be used for testing to call their regional environmental health officer.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Canada can be seen at http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/Canada_Provinces_and_territories_map.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16751.\n\nThe following publication summarizes 2 decades of botulism in Canada, a great majority occurring due to type E in the native population,\n\nLeclair D, Fung J, Isaac-Renton JL, et al. Foodborne botulism in Canada, 1985-2005. Emerg Infect Dis. 2013; 19(6): 961-8; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3713816/\n\nAbstract\n--------\nDuring 1985-2005, a total of 91 laboratory-confirmed outbreaks of foodborne botulism occurred in Canada; these outbreaks involved 205 cases and 11 deaths. Of the outbreaks, 75 (86.2 per cent) were caused by _Clostridium botulinum_ type E, followed by types A (7, 8.1 per cent) and B (5, 5.7 per cent). Approximately 85 per cent of the outbreaks occurred in Alaska Native communities, particularly the Inuit of Nunavik in northern Quebec and the First Nations population of the Pacific coast of British Columbia. These populations were predominantly exposed to type E botulinum toxin through the consumption of traditionally prepared marine mammal and fish products. 2 botulism outbreaks were attributed to commercial ready-to-eat meat products and 3 to foods served in restaurants; several cases were attributed to non-Native home-prepared foods. 3 affected pregnant women delivered healthy infants. Improvements in botulism case identification and early treatment have resulted in a reduction in the case-fatality rate in Canada.\n\nThe following was abstracted from a 2001 CDC report on foodborne botulism in the native American population in Alaska and underscores changes in the fermentation techniques which appear to have increased the risks of this intoxication\n(http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5032a2.htm):\n\nThis report illustrates how the use of nontraditional fermentation methods is associated with foodborne botulism in Alaska. Botulism results from eating preformed toxin produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism intoxication can result in death, which most often is caused by respiratory failure. The latent period is typically 12-36 hours but can range from 6 hours to 10 days (1). _C. botulinum_ and closely related organisms produce toxins designated as types A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is most commonly caused by types A, B, and E. Type E is associated with foods of marine or freshwater origin. Alaska's foodborne botulism rates exceed those in any other state and are among the highest in the world (1). During 1950-2000, Alaska recorded 226 cases of foodborne botulism from 114 outbreaks. All patients were Alaska Natives, and all cases with known causes were associated with eating fermented foods (1,2). Approximately 27 per cent of US foodborne botulism cases occur in Alaska.\n\nIn traditional fermentation, food is kept in a grass-lined hole in the ground or a wooden barrel sunken into the ground or is placed in a shady area above ground for several weeks to months. Since the 1970s, however, plastic or glass containers have been used and fermentation has been done above ground or indoors. The anaerobic condition of sealed containers and warmer temperatures make fermentation more rapid and production of botulism toxin more likely (3-5). These nontraditional methods have been associated with increased botulism rates in Alaska during 1970-1989 (4,5). Although a plastic container was not used in this outbreak, the beaver tail and paw were fermented in a closed rice sack and stored in a warm area.\n\nEarly diagnosis and antitoxin treatment have contributed to the decline of the case fatality rate from approximately 31 per cent during 1950-1959 to no deaths in Alaska since 1994 (1). However, Alaska continues to have high foodborne botulism rates because fermented foods are part of Alaska Native culture. In a 1999 survey, 107 (77 per cent) of 140 Alaska Natives reported having eaten fermented foods at least once in their lifetime (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Beller M. Botulism in Alaska: a guide for physicians and health-care providers -- 1998 update. Anchorage, Alaska: Alaska Department of Health and Social Services, 1998.\n2. Wainwright RB, Heyward WL, Middaugh JP, et al. Food-borne botulism in Alaska, 1947-1985: epidemiology and clinical findings. J Infect Dis. 1988; 157: 1158-62.\n3. Chiou L, Hennessy T, Horn A, Carter G, Butler J. A survey of knowledge, attitudes, and practices related to fermented foods known to cause botulism among Alaska Natives of southwest Alaska. [Abstract]. Presented at the 2nd International Conference on Emerging Infectious Diseases, Atlanta, Georgia, July 2000.\n4. Eisenberg MS, Bender TR. Plastic bags and botulism: a new twist to an old hazard of the north. Alaska Med 1976; July: 47-9.\n5. Shaffer N, Wainwright RB, Middaugh JP. Botulism among Alaska Natives: the role of changing food preparation and consumption practices. West J Med. 1990;153: 390-3.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2015\n---\nBotulism - USA (10): (AK, NC) fermented seal flipper, home canned carrots 20150515.3364683\n2014\n---\nBotulism - USA (13): (AK) seal oil, large cluster, alert 20141225.3054025\n2007\n---\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\n2003\n---\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\nBotulism, humans - USA (Alaska) 20020721.4823\n1997\n---\nBotulism - Canada (02) 19970926.2019\nBotulism - Canada 19970921.1985\n.................................................ll/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "1975-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1994-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1988-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Sanikiluaq", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4482343", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism, avian - USA (03): (CO) waterfowl, susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4482343", "date": "2016-07-28 18:13:24", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND) WATERFOWL, SUSPECTED\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 22 Jul 2016\nSource: The Herts Advertiser [edited]\nhttp://www.hertsad.co.uk/news/three_swans_dead_from_suspected_botulism_at_verulamium_lake_1_4628883\n\n\nHundreds of waterfowl died from avian botulism last year [2015] and concerns have been voiced that it might return again if Verulamium Lake (Hertforshire) is not cleared.\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by bacteria (_Clostridium botulinum_) produced from silt in warmer temperatures.\n\nA number of dead ducks have been spotted in recent weeks but the district council will not confirm the deaths are caused by botulism.\n\nNow 3 swans, which were retrieved by Swan Rescue Hertfordshire working with the Swan Sanctuary, have died, while another is currently in their care.\n\nThere are 2 further swans that are thought to be at risk which will be re-located later this week [18-24 Jul 2016].\n\nSteve Knight, a Swan Sanctuary trustee, said that he was very sure that botulism was the cause of the swan deaths, despite the fact that there have been no official tests yet.\n\nSteve said that he did not understand how the council could deny that it was botulism.\n\nHe said: \"We've been doing this for over 30 years. It is a bit like when you know your child has a cold, it is as simple as that. We are a registered vet practice at the end of the day as well as being a charity.\"\n\nFollowing calls from members of the public 2 swans were retrieved from Verulamium Lake on Sunday (17 Jul 2016), and a further 2 on Monday (18 Jul 2016). Two of the 4 were already dead and another has since died with the 4th on a drip and other medication.\n\nSteve added: \"It takes them a long time to recover.\"\n\nSt Albans council's head of community services, Richard Shwe, said: \"We are aware that a Swan Rescue official has suggested the swans may have contracted botulism which can emerge during very hot weather.\n\n\"However, that is only speculation and they have not carried out any tests to try and determine this.\n\n\"We are monitoring the health of the park's wildlife and looking at ways to improve their welfare, particularly the water quality of the lakes.\"\n\nThe council is planning to remove 60 tonnes of silt, but has maintained it will not dredge the lake.\n\nMr Shwe added: \"In the longer term, we are working with the Environment Agency on a scheme to restore the River Ver to its more natural state.\"\n\n[Byline: Sophie Crockett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/279.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (10): soups, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4480731", "date": "2016-07-28 18:13:24", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND) WATERFOWL, SUSPECTED\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 22 Jul 2016\nSource: The Herts Advertiser [edited]\nhttp://www.hertsad.co.uk/news/three_swans_dead_from_suspected_botulism_at_verulamium_lake_1_4628883\n\n\nHundreds of waterfowl died from avian botulism last year [2015] and concerns have been voiced that it might return again if Verulamium Lake (Hertforshire) is not cleared.\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by bacteria (_Clostridium botulinum_) produced from silt in warmer temperatures.\n\nA number of dead ducks have been spotted in recent weeks but the district council will not confirm the deaths are caused by botulism.\n\nNow 3 swans, which were retrieved by Swan Rescue Hertfordshire working with the Swan Sanctuary, have died, while another is currently in their care.\n\nThere are 2 further swans that are thought to be at risk which will be re-located later this week [18-24 Jul 2016].\n\nSteve Knight, a Swan Sanctuary trustee, said that he was very sure that botulism was the cause of the swan deaths, despite the fact that there have been no official tests yet.\n\nSteve said that he did not understand how the council could deny that it was botulism.\n\nHe said: \"We've been doing this for over 30 years. It is a bit like when you know your child has a cold, it is as simple as that. We are a registered vet practice at the end of the day as well as being a charity.\"\n\nFollowing calls from members of the public 2 swans were retrieved from Verulamium Lake on Sunday (17 Jul 2016), and a further 2 on Monday (18 Jul 2016). Two of the 4 were already dead and another has since died with the 4th on a drip and other medication.\n\nSteve added: \"It takes them a long time to recover.\"\n\nSt Albans council's head of community services, Richard Shwe, said: \"We are aware that a Swan Rescue official has suggested the swans may have contracted botulism which can emerge during very hot weather.\n\n\"However, that is only speculation and they have not carried out any tests to try and determine this.\n\n\"We are monitoring the health of the park's wildlife and looking at ways to improve their welfare, particularly the water quality of the lakes.\"\n\nThe council is planning to remove 60 tonnes of silt, but has maintained it will not dredge the lake.\n\nMr Shwe added: \"In the longer term, we are working with the Environment Agency on a scheme to restore the River Ver to its more natural state.\"\n\n[Byline: Sophie Crockett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/279.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBotulism, avian - China (08): (HK ex GD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4428848", "date": "2016-07-28 18:13:24", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND) WATERFOWL, SUSPECTED\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 22 Jul 2016\nSource: The Herts Advertiser [edited]\nhttp://www.hertsad.co.uk/news/three_swans_dead_from_suspected_botulism_at_verulamium_lake_1_4628883\n\n\nHundreds of waterfowl died from avian botulism last year [2015] and concerns have been voiced that it might return again if Verulamium Lake (Hertforshire) is not cleared.\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by bacteria (_Clostridium botulinum_) produced from silt in warmer temperatures.\n\nA number of dead ducks have been spotted in recent weeks but the district council will not confirm the deaths are caused by botulism.\n\nNow 3 swans, which were retrieved by Swan Rescue Hertfordshire working with the Swan Sanctuary, have died, while another is currently in their care.\n\nThere are 2 further swans that are thought to be at risk which will be re-located later this week [18-24 Jul 2016].\n\nSteve Knight, a Swan Sanctuary trustee, said that he was very sure that botulism was the cause of the swan deaths, despite the fact that there have been no official tests yet.\n\nSteve said that he did not understand how the council could deny that it was botulism.\n\nHe said: \"We've been doing this for over 30 years. It is a bit like when you know your child has a cold, it is as simple as that. We are a registered vet practice at the end of the day as well as being a charity.\"\n\nFollowing calls from members of the public 2 swans were retrieved from Verulamium Lake on Sunday (17 Jul 2016), and a further 2 on Monday (18 Jul 2016). Two of the 4 were already dead and another has since died with the 4th on a drip and other medication.\n\nSteve added: \"It takes them a long time to recover.\"\n\nSt Albans council's head of community services, Richard Shwe, said: \"We are aware that a Swan Rescue official has suggested the swans may have contracted botulism which can emerge during very hot weather.\n\n\"However, that is only speculation and they have not carried out any tests to try and determine this.\n\n\"We are monitoring the health of the park's wildlife and looking at ways to improve their welfare, particularly the water quality of the lakes.\"\n\nThe council is planning to remove 60 tonnes of silt, but has maintained it will not dredge the lake.\n\nMr Shwe added: \"In the longer term, we are working with the Environment Agency on a scheme to restore the River Ver to its more natural state.\"\n\n[Byline: Sophie Crockett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/279.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBotulism, avian - It is a bit like when you know your child has a cold, it is as simple as that. We are a registered vet practice at the end of the day as well as being a charity.\"\n\nFollowing calls from members of the public 2 swans were retrieved from Verulamium Lake on Sunday (17 Jul 2016), and a further 2 on Monday (18 Jul 2016). Two of the 4 were already dead and another has since died with the 4th on a drip and other medication.\n\nSteve added: \"It takes them a long time to recover.\"\n\nSt Albans council's head of community services, Richard Shwe, said: \"We are aware that a Swan Rescue official has suggested the swans may have contracted botulism which can emerge during very hot weather.\n\n\"However, that is only speculation and they have not carried out any tests to try and determine this.\n\n\"We are monitoring the health of the park's wildlife and looking at ways to improve their welfare, particularly the water quality of the lakes.\"\n\nThe council is planning to remove 60 tonnes of silt, but has maintained it will not dredge the lake.\n\nMr Shwe added: \"In the longer term, we are working with the Environment Agency on a scheme to restore the River Ver to its more natural state.\"\n\n[Byline: Sophie Crockett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/279.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBotulism, avian - UK (04): (England) aquatic birds Botulism, avian - UK (03): (England) aquatic birds 20140806.2665651\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): (MI) waterfowl 20140815.2691474\nBotulism, avian - UK: (England) aquatic birds, susp 20140728.2640790\n2013\n----\nBotulism, avian - UK: (England) aquatic birds 20130731.1856632\n.................................................sb/pmb/je/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-07-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4400520", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, cosmetic use - China (07): (HK ex GD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4400520", "date": "2016-07-28 18:13:24", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND) WATERFOWL, SUSPECTED\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 22 Jul 2016\nSource: The Herts Advertiser [edited]\nhttp://www.hertsad.co.uk/news/three_swans_dead_from_suspected_botulism_at_verulamium_lake_1_4628883\n\n\nHundreds of waterfowl died from avian botulism last year [2015] and concerns have been voiced that it might return again if Verulamium Lake (Hertforshire) is not cleared.\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by bacteria (_Clostridium botulinum_) produced from silt in warmer temperatures.\n\nA number of dead ducks have been spotted in recent weeks but the district council will not confirm the deaths are caused by botulism.\n\nNow 3 swans, which were retrieved by Swan Rescue Hertfordshire working with the Swan Sanctuary, have died, while another is currently in their care.\n\nThere are 2 further swans that are thought to be at risk which will be re-located later this week [18-24 Jul 2016].\n\nSteve Knight, a Swan Sanctuary trustee, said that he was very sure that botulism was the cause of the swan deaths, despite the fact that there have been no official tests yet.\n\nSteve said that he did not understand how the council could deny that it was botulism.\n\nHe said: \"We've been doing this for over 30 years. It is a bit like when you know your child has a cold, it is as simple as that. We are a registered vet practice at the end of the day as well as being a charity.\"\n\nFollowing calls from members of the public 2 swans were retrieved from Verulamium Lake on Sunday (17 Jul 2016), and a further 2 on Monday (18 Jul 2016). Two of the 4 were already dead and another has since died with the 4th on a drip and other medication.\n\nSteve added: \"It takes them a long time to recover.\"\n\nSt Albans council's head of community services, Richard Shwe, said: \"We are aware that a Swan Rescue official has suggested the swans may have contracted botulism which can emerge during very hot weather.\n\n\"However, that is only speculation and they have not carried out any tests to try and determine this.\n\n\"We are monitoring the health of the park's wildlife and looking at ways to improve their welfare, particularly the water quality of the lakes.\"\n\nThe council is planning to remove 60 tonnes of silt, but has maintained it will not dredge the lake.\n\nMr Shwe added: \"In the longer term, we are working with the Environment Agency on a scheme to restore the River Ver to its more natural state.\"\n\n[Byline: Sophie Crockett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/279.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBotulism, avian - It is a bit like when you know your child has a cold, it is as simple as that. We are a registered vet practice at the end of the day as well as being a charity.\"\n\nFollowing calls from members of the public 2 swans were retrieved from Verulamium Lake on Sunday (17 Jul 2016), and a further 2 on Monday (18 Jul 2016). Two of the 4 were already dead and another has since died with the 4th on a drip and other medication.\n\nSteve added: \"It takes them a long time to recover.\"\n\nSt Albans council's head of community services, Richard Shwe, said: \"We are aware that a Swan Rescue official has suggested the swans may have contracted botulism which can emerge during very hot weather.\n\n\"However, that is only speculation and they have not carried out any tests to try and determine this.\n\n\"We are monitoring the health of the park's wildlife and looking at ways to improve their welfare, particularly the water quality of the lakes.\"\n\nThe council is planning to remove 60 tonnes of silt, but has maintained it will not dredge the lake.\n\nMr Shwe added: \"In the longer term, we are working with the Environment Agency on a scheme to restore the River Ver to its more natural state.\"\n\n[Byline: Sophie Crockett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/279.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBotulism, avian - It is a bit like when you know your child has a cold, it is as simple as that. We are a registered vet practice at the end of the day as well as being a charity.\"\n\nFollowing calls from members of the public 2 swans were retrieved from Verulamium Lake on Sunday (17 Jul 2016), and a further 2 on Monday (18 Jul 2016). Two of the 4 were already dead and another has since died with the 4th on a drip and other medication.\n\nSteve added: \"It takes them a long time to recover.\"\n\nSt Albans council's head of community services, Richard Shwe, said: \"We are aware that a Swan Rescue official has suggested the swans may have contracted botulism which can emerge during very hot weather.\n\n\"However, that is only speculation and they have not carried out any tests to try and determine this.\n\n\"We are monitoring the health of the park's wildlife and looking at ways to improve their welfare, particularly the water quality of the lakes.\"\n\nThe council is planning to remove 60 tonnes of silt, but has maintained it will not dredge the lake.\n\nMr Shwe added: \"In the longer term, we are working with the Environment Agency on a scheme to restore the River Ver to its more natural state.\"\n\n[Byline: Sophie Crockett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. UK (07): (Scotland) wound, drug-related"}, {"archive_id": "3712452", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - USA (13): canned seafood, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3712452", "date": "2015-06-07 17:53:32", "main_text": "BOTULISM - UKRAINE: DRIED FISH\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 30 May 2015\nSource: Ukraina.ru [translated by Mod.NP, edited]\nhttp://ukraina.ru/news/20150529/1013210970.html\n\n\n2 people died last week from botulism in the Zaporozhye region, and 2 patients are in the hospital. A 32 year old woman and her 9 year old son were hospitalized with the same diagnosis to the regional hospital in Ivano-Frankivsk. Later a 20 year old man also fell ill with botulism. 3 people in the village of Piatykhatky in the Dnipropetrovsk region also fell ill with botulism in late April 2015.\n\nAccording to physicians, almost all cases of illness are associated with the consumption of dried fish.\n\nDoctors report that the recovery from infection is serum [anti-botulinum], which is almost absent in Ukraine now. \"There are several types of this serum. It was purchased in 2013. A sufficient amount of serum was through 2014 but the shelf life has expired. The drugs were destroyed.\n\nIndeed currently there is a shortage of these vaccines, reported Larisa Ryndina, the employee of the health Department of Zaporozhye regional administration.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The lack of availability of polyvalent botulism antiserum no doubt can contribute to the deaths here. The antiserum can inactivate toxin that has not yet bound to its target at the neuromuscular junction.\n\nThe method of diagnosis of botulism is not stated here. Individual cases of the paralysis can be confused with other diseases, but a cluster of such cases is certainly likely to be botulism. Type E botulism is the type frequently associated with fish products (1).\n\nClassically, botulism is a foodborne disease caused by the ingestion of preformed toxin, although there also exists wound botulism (in\nwhich _Clostridium botulinum_ spores germinate in a wound), and infant botulism (in which the spores germinate in the intestinal tract).\n\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the commonest. Although all types have a similar symptom complex, Hughes and colleagues report that type E is much more likely to produce initial lethargic mental status and more autonomic dysfunction (2).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Weber JT, Hibbs RG, Darwish A, et al. A massive outbreak of type E botulism associated with traditional salted fish in Cairo. J Infect Dis 1993; 167: 451-4.\n2. Hughes JM, Hatheway CL, Ostroff SM: Botulism. In: Scheld WM, Whitley RJ, Durack DT, editors. Infections of the central nervous\nsystem. 2nd edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott-Raven, 1997, 615-28.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/123.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Azerbaijan: home pickled tomatoes 20150221.3177167\nBotulism - Tajikistan, Kazakhstan: home canned foods 20150201.3135159\n2014\n---\nBotulism - Tajikistan: (SU) home-canned tomatoes 20140403.2377447\n2013\n---\nBotulism - Kyrgyzstan: home canning 20130520.1725795\nBotulism - Armenia: home canned vegetable 20130206.1531916\n2010\n---\nBotulism - Russia: (RO, UL), fish 20100831.3099\nBotulism - Russia (04): (IRK) preserved fish 20080728.2308\n2009\n---\nBotulism - Russia: (CL) cheese, susp 20091109.3880\nBotulism - Russia (04): (IRK) preserved fish 20080728.2308\nBotulism, canned eggplant - Kazakhstan: (YUZ, ALM) 20090128.0395\n2007\n---\nBotulism, fatal, canned food - Azerbaijan 20070124.0321\n2006\n---\nBotulism, fish - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20061006.2864\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20060724.2036\n2005\n---\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\n2004\n---\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Kharkov) 20041030.2930\n2003\n---\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n.................................................np/ll/pg/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "1993-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Zaporozhye", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Hatheway", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Weber JT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3703216", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Portugal: smoked sausage, alert, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3703216", "date": "2015-06-07 17:53:32", "main_text": "BOTULISM - UKRAINE: DRIED FISH\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 30 May 2015\nSource: Ukraina.ru [translated by Mod.NP, edited]\nhttp://ukraina.ru/news/20150529/1013210970.html\n\n\n2 people died last week from botulism in the Zaporozhye region, and 2 patients are in the hospital. A 32 year old woman and her 9 year old son were hospitalized with the same diagnosis to the regional hospital in Ivano-Frankivsk. Later a 20 year old man also fell ill with botulism. 3 people in the village of Piatykhatky in the Dnipropetrovsk region also fell ill with botulism in late April 2015.\n\nAccording to physicians, almost all cases of illness are associated with the consumption of dried fish.\n\nDoctors report that the recovery from infection is serum [anti-botulinum], which is almost absent in Ukraine now. \"There are several types of this serum. It was purchased in 2013. A sufficient amount of serum was through 2014 but the shelf life has expired. The drugs were destroyed.\n\nIndeed currently there is a shortage of these vaccines, reported Larisa Ryndina, the employee of the health Department of Zaporozhye regional administration.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The lack of availability of polyvalent botulism antiserum no doubt can contribute to the deaths here. The antiserum can inactivate toxin that has not yet bound to its target at the neuromuscular junction.\n\nThe method of diagnosis of botulism is not stated here. Individual cases of the paralysis can be confused with other diseases, but a cluster of such cases is certainly likely to be botulism. Type E botulism is the type frequently associated with fish products (1).\n\nClassically, botulism is a foodborne disease caused by the ingestion of preformed toxin, although there also exists wound botulism (in\nwhich _Clostridium botulinum_ spores germinate in a wound), and infant botulism (in which the spores germinate in the intestinal tract).\n\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the commonest. Although all types have a similar symptom complex, Hughes and colleagues report that type E is much more likely to produce initial lethargic mental status and more autonomic dysfunction (2).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Weber JT, Hibbs RG, Darwish A, et al. A massive outbreak of type E botulism associated with traditional salted fish in Cairo. J Infect Dis 1993; 167: 451-4.\n2. Hughes JM, Hatheway CL, Ostroff SM: Botulism. In: Scheld WM, Whitley RJ, Durack DT, editors. Infections of the central nervous\nsystem. 2nd edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott-Raven, 1997, 615-28.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/123.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Azerbaijan: home pickled tomatoes 20150221.3177167\nBotulism - USA (12): (OH) church dinner, home-canned potatoes, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3548624", "date": "2015-06-07 17:53:32", "main_text": "BOTULISM - UKRAINE: DRIED FISH\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 30 May 2015\nSource: Ukraina.ru [translated by Mod.NP, edited]\nhttp://ukraina.ru/news/20150529/1013210970.html\n\n\n2 people died last week from botulism in the Zaporozhye region, and 2 patients are in the hospital. A 32 year old woman and her 9 year old son were hospitalized with the same diagnosis to the regional hospital in Ivano-Frankivsk. Later a 20 year old man also fell ill with botulism. 3 people in the village of Piatykhatky in the Dnipropetrovsk region also fell ill with botulism in late April 2015.\n\nAccording to physicians, almost all cases of illness are associated with the consumption of dried fish.\n\nDoctors report that the recovery from infection is serum [anti-botulinum], which is almost absent in Ukraine now. \"There are several types of this serum. It was purchased in 2013. A sufficient amount of serum was through 2014 but the shelf life has expired. The drugs were destroyed.\n\nIndeed currently there is a shortage of these vaccines, reported Larisa Ryndina, the employee of the health Department of Zaporozhye regional administration.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The lack of availability of polyvalent botulism antiserum no doubt can contribute to the deaths here. The antiserum can inactivate toxin that has not yet bound to its target at the neuromuscular junction.\n\nThe method of diagnosis of botulism is not stated here. Individual cases of the paralysis can be confused with other diseases, but a cluster of such cases is certainly likely to be botulism. Type E botulism is the type frequently associated with fish products (1).\n\nClassically, botulism is a foodborne disease caused by the ingestion of preformed toxin, although there also exists wound botulism (in\nwhich _Clostridium botulinum_ spores germinate in a wound), and infant botulism (in which the spores germinate in the intestinal tract).\n\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the commonest. Although all types have a similar symptom complex, Hughes and colleagues report that type E is much more likely to produce initial lethargic mental status and more autonomic dysfunction (2).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Weber JT, Hibbs RG, Darwish A, et al. A massive outbreak of type E botulism associated with traditional salted fish in Cairo. J Infect Dis 1993; 167: 451-4.\n2. Later a 20 year old man also fell ill with botulism. 3 people in the village of Piatykhatky in the Dnipropetrovsk region also fell ill with botulism in late April 2015.\n\nAccording to physicians, almost all cases of illness are associated with the consumption of dried fish.\n\nDoctors report that the recovery from infection is serum [anti-botulinum], which is almost absent in Ukraine now. \"There are several types of this serum. Individual cases of the paralysis can be confused with other diseases, but a cluster of such cases is certainly likely to be botulism. Type E botulism is the type frequently associated with fish products (1).\n\nClassically, botulism is a foodborne disease caused by the ingestion of preformed toxin, although there also exists wound botulism (in\nwhich _Clostridium botulinum_ spores germinate in a wound), and infant botulism (in which the spores germinate in the intestinal tract).\n\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the commonest. UK (06): (Scotland) wound, drug-related", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3437174", "date": "2015-06-07 17:53:32", "main_text": "BOTULISM - UKRAINE: DRIED FISH\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 30 May 2015\nSource: Ukraina.ru [translated by Mod.NP, edited]\nhttp://ukraina.ru/news/20150529/1013210970.html\n\n\n2 people died last week from botulism in the Zaporozhye region, and 2 patients are in the hospital. A 32 year old woman and her 9 year old son were hospitalized with the same diagnosis to the regional hospital in Ivano-Frankivsk. Later a 20 year old man also fell ill with botulism. 3 people in the village of Piatykhatky in the Dnipropetrovsk region also fell ill with botulism in late April 2015.\n\nAccording to physicians, almost all cases of illness are associated with the consumption of dried fish.\n\nDoctors report that the recovery from infection is serum [anti-botulinum], which is almost absent in Ukraine now. \"There are several types of this serum. It was purchased in 2013. A sufficient amount of serum was through 2014 but the shelf life has expired. The drugs were destroyed.\n\nIndeed currently there is a shortage of these vaccines, reported Larisa Ryndina, the employee of the health Department of Zaporozhye regional administration.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The lack of availability of polyvalent botulism antiserum no doubt can contribute to the deaths here. The antiserum can inactivate toxin that has not yet bound to its target at the neuromuscular junction.\n\nThe method of diagnosis of botulism is not stated here. Individual cases of the paralysis can be confused with other diseases, but a cluster of such cases is certainly likely to be botulism. Type E botulism is the type frequently associated with fish products (1).\n\nClassically, botulism is a foodborne disease caused by the ingestion of preformed toxin, although there also exists wound botulism (in\nwhich _Clostridium botulinum_ spores germinate in a wound), and infant botulism (in which the spores germinate in the intestinal tract).\n\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the commonest. Although all types have a similar symptom complex, Hughes and colleagues report that type E is much more likely to produce initial lethargic mental status and more autonomic dysfunction (2).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Weber JT, Hibbs RG, Darwish A, et al. A massive outbreak of type E botulism associated with traditional salted fish in Cairo. J Infect Dis 1993; 167: 451-4.\n2. Hughes JM, Hatheway CL, Ostroff SM: Botulism. In: Scheld WM, Whitley RJ, Durack DT, editors. Infections of the central nervous\nsystem. 2nd edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott-Raven, 1997, 615-28.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/123.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Azerbaijan: home pickled tomatoes 20150221.3177167\nBotulism - Ukraine: dried fish", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3417187", "date": "2015-06-07 17:53:32", "main_text": "BOTULISM - UKRAINE: DRIED FISH\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 30 May 2015\nSource: Ukraina.ru [translated by Mod.NP, edited]\nhttp://ukraina.ru/news/20150529/1013210970.html\n\n\n2 people died last week from botulism in the Zaporozhye region, and 2 patients are in the hospital. A 32 year old woman and her 9 year old son were hospitalized with the same diagnosis to the regional hospital in Ivano-Frankivsk. Later a 20 year old man also fell ill with botulism. 3 people in the village of Piatykhatky in the Dnipropetrovsk region also fell ill with botulism in late April 2015.\n\nAccording to physicians, almost all cases of illness are associated with the consumption of dried fish.\n\nDoctors report that the recovery from infection is serum [anti-botulinum], which is almost absent in Ukraine now. \"There are several types of this serum. It was purchased in 2013. A sufficient amount of serum was through 2014 but the shelf life has expired. The drugs were destroyed.\n\nIndeed currently there is a shortage of these vaccines, reported Larisa Ryndina, the employee of the health Department of Zaporozhye regional administration.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The lack of availability of polyvalent botulism antiserum no doubt can contribute to the deaths here. The antiserum can inactivate toxin that has not yet bound to its target at the neuromuscular junction.\n\nThe method of diagnosis of botulism is not stated here. Individual cases of the paralysis can be confused with other diseases, but a cluster of such cases is certainly likely to be botulism. Type E botulism is the type frequently associated with fish products (1).\n\nClassically, botulism is a foodborne disease caused by the ingestion of preformed toxin, although there also exists wound botulism (in\nwhich _Clostridium botulinum_ spores germinate in a wound), and infant botulism (in which the spores germinate in the intestinal tract).\n\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the commonest. USA (11): (OH, MD) jarred salsa, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3391672", "date": "2015-04-22 15:25:54", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (05): (OHIO) CHURCH DINNER, FATAL\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 22 Apr 2015\nSource: CNN [edited]\nhttp://www.cnn.com/2015/04/22/health/church-potluck-botulism/\n\n\n1 person has died and at least 20 others were hospitalized after an outbreak of botulism following a potluck dinner at a church in central Ohio. All of the patients attended a potluck on Sunday, 19 Apr 2015, at Cross Pointe Free Will Baptist Church in Lancaster, about 30 miles south east of Columbus. Up to 60 people ate at the event. 5 patients are in critical condition and 10 were taken to hospitals in Columbus, according to Fairfield Medical Center in Lancaster.\n\nAntitoxin is on the way from the CDC in Atlanta. \"It is being sent in as quickly as we can get it,\" said Dr Andrew Murry with the medical center.\n\nBotulism can be fatal, with symptoms typically beginning within 36 hours of consuming contaminated food. The infection can result in paralysis, double vision, difficulty swallowing and respiratory failure, \"In this day and age botulism from food is fairly rare; generally it's canned foods,\" Murry said. \"The fatality rate is usually fairly low.\"\n\nAnd it is not contagious. \"It is not a threat to our patients, visitors or staff or the community at large,\" Murry said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail awaits more information regarding this relatively large outbreak. In a potluck dinner where everyone brings a different dish, there will be lots of potential reservoirs to investigate. Home-canned foods should be high on the list. With a case attack rate of more than 30 per cent, a food diary could be useful in knowing which foods the affected individuals consumed. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/237.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - All of the patients attended a potluck on Sunday, 19 Apr 2015, at Cross Pointe Free Will Baptist Church in Lancaster, about 30 miles south east of Columbus. Up to 60 people ate at the event. 5 patients are in critical condition and 10 were taken to hospitals in Columbus, according to Fairfield Medical Center in Lancaster.\n\nAntitoxin is on the way from the CDC in Atlanta. \"It is being sent in as quickly as we can get it,\" said Dr Andrew Murry with the medical center.\n\nBotulism can be fatal, with symptoms typically beginning within 36 hours of consuming contaminated food. The infection can result in paralysis, double vision, difficulty swallowing and respiratory failure, \"In this day and age botulism from food is fairly rare; generally it's canned foods,\" Murry said. \"The fatality rate is usually fairly low.\"\n\nAnd it is not contagious. \"It is not a threat to our patients, visitors or staff or the community at large,\" Murry said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail awaits more information regarding this relatively large outbreak. In a potluck dinner where everyone brings a different dish, there will be lots of potential reservoirs to investigate. Home-canned foods should be high on the list. With a case attack rate of more than 30 per cent, a food diary could be useful in knowing which foods the affected individuals consumed. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/237.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - All of the patients attended a potluck on Sunday, 19 Apr 2015, at Cross Pointe Free Will Baptist Church in Lancaster, about 30 miles south east of Columbus. Up to 60 people ate at the event. 5 patients are in critical condition and 10 were taken to hospitals in Columbus, according to Fairfield Medical Center in Lancaster.\n\nAntitoxin is on the way from the CDC in Atlanta. \"It is being sent in as quickly as we can get it,\" said Dr Andrew Murry with the medical center.\n\nBotulism can be fatal, with symptoms typically beginning within 36 hours of consuming contaminated food. The infection can result in paralysis, double vision, difficulty swallowing and respiratory failure, \"In this day and age botulism from food is fairly rare; generally it's canned foods,\" Murry said. \"The fatality rate is usually fairly low.\"\n\nAnd it is not contagious. \"It is not a threat to our patients, visitors or staff or the community at large,\" Murry said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail awaits more information regarding this relatively large outbreak. In a potluck dinner where everyone brings a different dish, there will be lots of potential reservoirs to investigate. Home-canned foods should be high on the list. With a case attack rate of more than 30 per cent, a food diary could be useful in knowing which foods the affected individuals consumed. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/237.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (04): (NY) uneviscerated fish, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3312199", "date": "2015-04-21 12:54:01", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (04): (NEW YORK) UNEVISCERATED FISH, RISK, RECALL\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 Apr 2015\nSource: New York State Department of Agriculture [edited]\nhttp://www.agriculture.ny.gov/AD/alert.asp?ReleaseID=1056\n\n\nNew York State agriculture commissioner Richard A Ball today warned consumers not to eat \"dry bream-lesh (fish)\" sold by Tatuka, Inc, located at 393 Ave P in Brooklyn, New York 11223 and distributed by Royal Sweet Bakery, located at 119 49th Street in Brooklyn, New York 11232, because the product was found to be uneviscerated.\n\nThe \"dry bream-lesh (fish)\" was sold from retail stores to consumers in the NYC Metro area. The product was packaged in a clear, vacuum-packed, flexible plastic pouch and offered for sale at refrigerated temperatures. The product is coded with a \"best before: 01:08:2015\" date and is a product of Russia.\n\nUneviscerated processed fish is prohibited under New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets' regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any other portion of the fish.\n\nThe \"dry bream-lesh (fish)\" was found by New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets food inspectors during a routine inspection of the retail firm. Subsequent analysis by New York State Food Laboratory personnel confirmed the product to be uneviscerated.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with the product. Consumers who have this product are advised not to eat it.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photograph of the label of this product can be seen at: http://www.agriculture.ny.gov/FoodSafetyAlets/uneviscerated_fish.jpg.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could -- but do not necessarily -- result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (03): (NM) RFI 20150418.3306389\nBotulism - USA (02): smoked fish ex Greece, risk, recall 20150215.3168432\nBotulism - USA: uneviscerated fish, risk, recall 20150129.3130000\n2014\n---\nBotulism - USA (13): (AK) seal oil, large cluster, alert 20141225.3054025\nBotulism - USA (12): (CA) wound, drug-related 20141218.3041400\nBotulism - USA (11): jarred pesto, risk, recall 20141011.2853907\nBotulism - USA (10): dried fish, risk, recall 20140920.2790079\nBotulism - USA (09): (WA) pasta sauce, risk, recall 20140909.2759984\nBotulism - USA (08): (VA) jarred foods, risk, recall 20140821.2708738\nBotulism - USA (07): (AK) fatality, fermented fish 20140819.2703023\nBotulism - USA (06): (OH) canned pesto, alert, recall 20140807.2665838\nBotulism - USA (05): (OH, CA) canned pesto, alert, recall 20140731.2647937\nBotulism -
