USA (03): (NM) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3306389", "date": "2015-04-21 12:54:01", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (04): (NEW YORK) UNEVISCERATED FISH, RISK, RECALL\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 Apr 2015\nSource: New York State Department of Agriculture [edited]\nhttp://www.agriculture.ny.gov/AD/alert.asp?ReleaseID=1056\n\n\nNew York State agriculture commissioner Richard A Ball today warned consumers not to eat \"dry bream-lesh (fish)\" sold by Tatuka, Inc, located at 393 Ave P in Brooklyn, New York 11223 and distributed by Royal Sweet Bakery, located at 119 49th Street in Brooklyn, New York 11232, because the product was found to be uneviscerated.\n\nThe \"dry bream-lesh (fish)\" was sold from retail stores to consumers in the NYC Metro area. The product was packaged in a clear, vacuum-packed, flexible plastic pouch and offered for sale at refrigerated temperatures. The product is coded with a \"best before: 01:08:2015\" date and is a product of Russia.\n\nUneviscerated processed fish is prohibited under New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets' regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any other portion of the fish.\n\nThe \"dry bream-lesh (fish)\" was found by New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets food inspectors during a routine inspection of the retail firm. Subsequent analysis by New York State Food Laboratory personnel confirmed the product to be uneviscerated.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with the product. Consumers who have this product are advised not to eat it.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photograph of the label of this product can be seen at: http://www.agriculture.ny.gov/FoodSafetyAlets/uneviscerated_fish.jpg.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could -- but do not necessarily -- result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Argentina: (RN) marinated octopus", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3283964", "date": "2015-04-21 12:54:01", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (04): (NEW YORK) UNEVISCERATED FISH, RISK, RECALL\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 Apr 2015\nSource: New York State Department of Agriculture [edited]\nhttp://www.agriculture.ny.gov/AD/alert.asp?ReleaseID=1056\n\n\nNew York State agriculture commissioner Richard A Ball today warned consumers not to eat \"dry bream-lesh (fish)\" sold by Tatuka, Inc, located at 393 Ave P in Brooklyn, New York 11223 and distributed by Royal Sweet Bakery, located at 119 49th Street in Brooklyn, New York 11232, because the product was found to be uneviscerated.\n\nThe \"dry bream-lesh (fish)\" was sold from retail stores to consumers in the NYC Metro area. The product was packaged in a clear, vacuum-packed, flexible plastic pouch and offered for sale at refrigerated temperatures. The product is coded with a \"best before: 01:08:2015\" date and is a product of Russia.\n\nUneviscerated processed fish is prohibited under New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets' regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any other portion of the fish.\n\nThe \"dry bream-lesh (fish)\" was found by New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets food inspectors during a routine inspection of the retail firm. Subsequent analysis by New York State Food Laboratory personnel confirmed the product to be uneviscerated.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with the product. Consumers who have this product are advised not to eat it.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photograph of the label of this product can be seen at: http://www.agriculture.ny.gov/FoodSafetyAlets/uneviscerated_fish.jpg.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could -- but do not necessarily -- result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - UK (03): (Scotland) wound, drug-related", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3122599", "date": "2015-04-21 12:54:01", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (04): (NEW YORK) UNEVISCERATED FISH, RISK, RECALL\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 Apr 2015\nSource: New York State Department of Agriculture [edited]\nhttp://www.agriculture.ny.gov/AD/alert.asp?ReleaseID=1056\n\n\nNew York State agriculture commissioner Richard A Ball today warned consumers not to eat \"dry bream-lesh (fish)\" sold by Tatuka, Inc, located at 393 Ave P in Brooklyn, New York 11223 and distributed by Royal Sweet Bakery, located at 119 49th Street in Brooklyn, New York 11232, because the product was found to be uneviscerated.\n\nThe \"dry bream-lesh (fish)\" was sold from retail stores to consumers in the NYC Metro area. The product was packaged in a clear, vacuum-packed, flexible plastic pouch and offered for sale at refrigerated temperatures. The product is coded with a \"best before: 01:08:2015\" date and is a product of Russia.\n\nUneviscerated processed fish is prohibited under New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets' regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any other portion of the fish.\n\nThe \"dry bream-lesh (fish)\" was found by New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets food inspectors during a routine inspection of the retail firm. Subsequent analysis by New York State Food Laboratory personnel confirmed the product to be uneviscerated.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with the product. Consumers who have this product are advised not to eat it.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photograph of the label of this product can be seen at: http://www.agriculture.ny.gov/FoodSafetyAlets/uneviscerated_fish.jpg.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could -- but do not necessarily -- result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/234.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - The product is coded with a \"best before: 01:08:2015\" date and is a product of Russia.\n\nUneviscerated processed fish is prohibited under New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets' regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any other portion of the fish.\n\nThe \"dry bream-lesh (fish)\" was found by New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets food inspectors during a routine inspection of the retail firm. Subsequent analysis by New York State Food Laboratory personnel confirmed the product to be uneviscerated.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with the product. Norway: (OS) wound, drug-related", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3084384", "date": "2014-09-29 13:59:53", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (05): (QUEBEC) TOMALLEY SPREAD, RISK, RECALL\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Sep 2014\nSource: Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) [edited]\nhttp://www.inspection.gc.ca/about-the-cfia/newsroom/food-recall-warnings/complete-listing/2014-09-26/eng/1411775566923/1411775567532?print=1#recall-photos\n\n\nRecall date: 26 Sep 2014\nReason for recall: Microbiological -- _Clostridium botulinum_\nHazard classification: class 1\nCompany/Firm: Fruits de Mer Madeleine Inc.\nDistribution: Quebec\nExtent of the distribution: retail\n\nFruits de Mer Madeleine Inc. is recalling Madeleine brand Tomalley Spread from the marketplace because it may permit the growth of _Clostridium botulinum_. Consumers should not consume the recalled product described below.\n\nRecalled products:\nBrand Name / Common Name / Size / Code(s) on Product / UPC\nMadeleine / Tomalley Spread / 80 g / None / 6 87090 30020 5\n\nWhat you should do:\nCheck to see if you have recalled products in your home. Recalled products should be thrown out or returned to the store where they were purchased.\n\nThis recall was triggered by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency's (CFIA) inspection activities. The CFIA is conducting a food safety investigation, which may lead to the recall of other products. If other high-risk products are recalled, the CFIA will notify the public through updated Food Recall Warnings. The CFIA is verifying that industry is removing recalled products from the marketplace.\n\nIllnesses: There have been no reported illnesses associated with the consumption of this product.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nTomalley (http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tomalley), from the Carib word 'tumale', meaning a sauce of lobster liver), crab fat, or lobster paste is the soft, green substance found in the body cavity of lobsters, that fulfills the functions of both the liver and the pancreas. Tomalley corresponds to the hepatopancreas in other arthropods. It is considered a delicacy, and may be eaten alone but is often added to sauces for flavour and as a thickening agent. The term lobster paste or lobster pate can also be used to indicate a mixture of tomalley and lobster roe. Lobster bisque, lobster stock, and lobster consomme are made using lobster bodies (heads), often including the lobster liver.\n\nThe tomalley in general can be consumed in moderation (as with the livers of other animals). It can, however, contain high levels of PCBs which can give a number of negative health effects in large concentrations. It may also contain toxins that are associated with paralytic shellfish poisoning (saxitoxin and gonyautoxin). Those toxins do not leach out when the lobster is cooked in boiling water. The toxins responsible for most shellfish poisonings are water-insoluble, heat- and acid-stable, and thus are not diminished by cooking. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/268.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Canada: (AB) jarred bacon spread, risk, recall 20140205.2257139\n2013\n----\nBotulism - Canada (04): (ON) bottled relish, risk, recall 20131106.2042043\nBotulism, paralytic shellfish poisoning - Canada: (BC) alert 20131018.2008893\nBotulism - UK: (Scotland) wound, drug-related", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3068219", "date": "2014-09-29 13:59:53", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (05): (QUEBEC) TOMALLEY SPREAD, RISK, RECALL\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Sep 2014\nSource: Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) [edited]\nhttp://www.inspection.gc.ca/about-the-cfia/newsroom/food-recall-warnings/complete-listing/2014-09-26/eng/1411775566923/1411775567532?print=1#recall-photos\n\n\nRecall date: 26 Sep 2014\nReason for recall: Microbiological -- _Clostridium botulinum_\nHazard classification: class 1\nCompany/Firm: Fruits de Mer Madeleine Inc.\nDistribution: Quebec\nExtent of the distribution: retail\n\nFruits de Mer Madeleine Inc. is recalling Madeleine brand Tomalley Spread from the marketplace because it may permit the growth of _Clostridium botulinum_. Consumers should not consume the recalled product described below.\n\nRecalled products:\nBrand Name / Common Name / Size / Code(s) on Product / UPC\nMadeleine / Tomalley Spread / 80 g / None / 6 87090 30020 5\n\nWhat you should do:\nCheck to see if you have recalled products in your home. Recalled products should be thrown out or returned to the store where they were purchased.\n\nThis recall was triggered by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency's (CFIA) inspection activities. If other high-risk products are recalled, the CFIA will notify the public through updated Food Recall Warnings. The CFIA is verifying that industry is removing recalled products from the marketplace.\n\nIllnesses: There have been no reported illnesses associated with the consumption of this product.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nTomalley (http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tomalley), from the Carib word 'tumale', meaning a sauce of lobster liver), crab fat, or lobster paste is the soft, green substance found in the body cavity of lobsters, that fulfills the functions of both the liver and the pancreas. Tomalley corresponds to the hepatopancreas in other arthropods. It is considered a delicacy, and may be eaten alone but is often added to sauces for flavour and as a thickening agent. The term lobster paste or lobster pate can also be used to indicate a mixture of tomalley and lobster roe. Lobster bisque, lobster stock, and lobster consomme are made using lobster bodies (heads), often including the lobster liver.\n\nThe tomalley in general can be consumed in moderation (as with the livers of other animals). It can, however, contain high levels of PCBs which can give a number of negative health effects in large concentrations. It may also contain toxins that are associated with paralytic shellfish poisoning (saxitoxin and gonyautoxin). Those toxins do not leach out when the lobster is cooked in boiling water. The toxins responsible for most shellfish poisonings are water-insoluble, heat- and acid-stable, and thus are not diminished by cooking. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/268.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Canada: (AB) jarred bacon spread, risk, recall 20140205.2257139\n2013\n----\nBotulism - Canada (04): (ON) bottled relish, risk, recall 20131106.2042043\nBotulism, paralytic shellfish poisoning - Canada: (BC) alert 20131018.2008893\nBotulism - USA (13): (AK) seal oil, large cluster, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3054025", "date": "2014-09-29 13:59:53", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (05): (QUEBEC) TOMALLEY SPREAD, RISK, RECALL\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Sep 2014\nSource: Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) [edited]\nhttp://www.inspection.gc.ca/about-the-cfia/newsroom/food-recall-warnings/complete-listing/2014-09-26/eng/1411775566923/1411775567532?print=1#recall-photos\n\n\nRecall date: 26 Sep 2014\nReason for recall: Microbiological -- _Clostridium botulinum_\nHazard classification: class 1\nCompany/Firm: Fruits de Mer Madeleine Inc.\nDistribution: Quebec\nExtent of the distribution: retail\n\nFruits de Mer Madeleine Inc. is recalling Madeleine brand Tomalley Spread from the marketplace because it may permit the growth of _Clostridium botulinum_. Consumers should not consume the recalled product described below.\n\nRecalled products:\nBrand Name / Common Name / Size / Code(s) on Product / UPC\nMadeleine / Tomalley Spread / 80 g / None / 6 87090 30020 5\n\nWhat you should do:\nCheck to see if you have recalled products in your home. Recalled products should be thrown out or returned to the store where they were purchased.\n\nThis recall was triggered by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency's (CFIA) inspection activities. The CFIA is conducting a food safety investigation, which may lead to the recall of other products. If other high-risk products are recalled, the CFIA will notify the public through updated Food Recall Warnings. The CFIA is verifying that industry is removing recalled products from the marketplace.\n\nIllnesses: There have been no reported illnesses associated with the consumption of this product.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nTomalley (http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tomalley), from the Carib word 'tumale', meaning a sauce of lobster liver), crab fat, or lobster paste is the soft, green substance found in the body cavity of lobsters, that fulfills the functions of both the liver and the pancreas. Tomalley corresponds to the hepatopancreas in other arthropods. It is considered a delicacy, and may be eaten alone but is often added to sauces for flavour and as a thickening agent. The term lobster paste or lobster pate can also be used to indicate a mixture of tomalley and lobster roe. Lobster bisque, lobster stock, and lobster consomme are made using lobster bodies (heads), often including the lobster liver.\n\nThe tomalley in general can be consumed in moderation (as with the livers of other animals). It can, however, contain high levels of PCBs which can give a number of negative health effects in large concentrations. It may also contain toxins that are associated with paralytic shellfish poisoning (saxitoxin and gonyautoxin). Those toxins do not leach out when the lobster is cooked in boiling water. The toxins responsible for most shellfish poisonings are water-insoluble, heat- and acid-stable, and thus are not diminished by cooking. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/268.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Canada (05): (QC) tomalley spread, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2813324", "date": "2014-09-29 13:59:53", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (05): (QUEBEC) TOMALLEY SPREAD, RISK, RECALL\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Sep 2014\nSource: Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) [edited]\nhttp://www.inspection.gc.ca/about-the-cfia/newsroom/food-recall-warnings/complete-listing/2014-09-26/eng/1411775566923/1411775567532?print=1#recall-photos\n\n\nRecall date: 26 Sep 2014\nReason for recall: Microbiological -- _Clostridium botulinum_\nHazard classification: class 1\nCompany/Firm: Fruits de Mer Madeleine Inc.\nDistribution: Quebec\nExtent of the distribution: retail\n\nFruits de Mer Madeleine Inc. is recalling Madeleine brand Tomalley Spread from the marketplace because it may permit the growth of _Clostridium botulinum_. Consumers should not consume the recalled product described below.\n\nRecalled products:\nBrand Name / Common Name / Size / Code(s) on Product / UPC\nMadeleine / Tomalley Spread / 80 g / None / 6 87090 30020 5\n\nWhat you should do:\nCheck to see if you have recalled products in your home. Recalled products should be thrown out or returned to the store where they were purchased.\n\nThis recall was triggered by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency's (CFIA) inspection activities. The CFIA is conducting a food safety investigation, which may lead to the recall of other products. If other high-risk products are recalled, the CFIA will notify the public through updated Food Recall Warnings. The CFIA is verifying that industry is removing recalled products from the marketplace.\n\nIllnesses: There have been no reported illnesses associated with the consumption of this product.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nTomalley (http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tomalley), from the Carib word 'tumale', meaning a sauce of lobster liver), crab fat, or lobster paste is the soft, green substance found in the body cavity of lobsters, that fulfills the functions of both the liver and the pancreas. Tomalley corresponds to the hepatopancreas in other arthropods. It is considered a delicacy, and may be eaten alone but is often added to sauces for flavour and as a thickening agent. The term lobster paste or lobster pate can also be used to indicate a mixture of tomalley and lobster roe. Lobster bisque, lobster stock, and lobster consomme are made using lobster bodies (heads), often including the lobster liver.\n\nThe tomalley in general can be consumed in moderation (as with the livers of other animals). It can, however, contain high levels of PCBs which can give a number of negative health effects in large concentrations. It may also contain toxins that are associated with paralytic shellfish poisoning (saxitoxin and gonyautoxin). Those toxins do not leach out when the lobster is cooked in boiling water. The toxins responsible for most shellfish poisonings are water-insoluble, heat- and acid-stable, and thus are not diminished by cooking. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/268.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Canada: (AB) jarred bacon spread, risk, recall 20140205.2257139\n2013\n----\nBotulism - Canada (04): (ON) bottled relish, risk, recall 20131106.2042043\nBotulism, paralytic shellfish poisoning - Canada: (BC) alert 20131018.2008893\nBotulism - Canada: risk, recall 20111030.3229\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall, ex Canada 20111014.3078\nBotulism - Canada (02): (BC) alert, expanded recall 20110317.0846\nBotulism - Canada: (BC) watermelon jelly, alert, recall 20110310.0776\n.................................................ll/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-09-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2790079", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - USA (10): dried fish, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2790079", "date": "2014-08-15 00:17:03", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - USA (02): (MICHIGAN) WATERFOWL\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Aug 2014\nSource: Record-Eagle [edited]\nhttp://www.record-eagle.com/news/local_news/article_5667c548-0672-56ef-8acc-259fb0e07323.html\n\n\nAbout 30 dead ducks dotted beaches along the east arm of Grand Traverse Bay [Lake Michigan, Michigan, USA] in the last few weeks.\n\nDepartment of Natural Resources (DNR) officials sent the waterfowl, all mallards, to a laboratory where they tested positive for botulism, a paralytic condition caused by a toxin. Birds with botulism typically are unable to hold up their heads and ultimately drown. [This condition is often called \"limber neck.\" - Mod.TG]\n\nThe birds were infected with type C botulism, a toxin that naturally occurs in soil. Experts attributed the impacted birds to elevated lake levels this year [2014].\n\n\"It's over the area that hadn't been water-covered in the past couple years,\" said Katie Keen, a wildlife technician at the DNR. \"The ducks wouldn't be feeding in that area if it didn't have water.\"\n\nThe botulism [in this case] does not pose a threat to humans, but Keen said dogs and other pets should be kept on leashes and away from dead animals to avoid ingesting the toxin.\n\nThe dead birds were found on the shore near the North Shore Inn and the Pointes North Beachfront Resort Hotel on U.S. 31 [Traverse City, Michigan].\n\nKeen urged anyone who sees a dead duck to call the Traverse City DNR offices.\n\n[Byline: Michelle Merlin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hopefully, the DNR is picking up all the dead birds. To leave the dead birds to decompose is to perpetuate the situation. As the birds decompose, and maggots develop, those maggots will be filled with botulinum toxin. When another bird consumes the maggot, the cycle continues.\n\nBotulinum toxin causes botulism. The toxin is a neurotoxic protein. The toxic protein is produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism is an extremely potent toxin, one of the most toxic agents known.\n\nWhile botulism is extremely toxic, it has been used medically in treating strokes and migraines, and cosmetically in treating wrinkles, to name a few uses. There are other appropriate medical uses.\n\nMichigan may be located on the interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian - USA: (CA) waterfowl 20140801.2651373\n2013\n----\nBotulism, avian - Birds with botulism typically are unable to hold up their heads and ultimately drown. [This condition is often called \"limber neck.\" - Mod.TG]\n\nThe birds were infected with type C botulism, a toxin that naturally occurs in soil. Experts attributed the impacted birds to elevated lake levels this year [2014].\n\n\"It's over the area that hadn't been water-covered in the past couple years,\" said Katie Keen, a wildlife technician at the DNR. \"The ducks wouldn't be feeding in that area if it didn't have water.\"\n\nThe botulism [in this case] does not pose a threat to humans, but Keen said dogs and other pets should be kept on leashes and away from dead animals to avoid ingesting the toxin.\n\nThe dead birds were found on the shore near the North Shore Inn and the Pointes North Beachfront Resort Hotel on U.S. 31 [Traverse City, Michigan].\n\nKeen urged anyone who sees a dead duck to call the Traverse City DNR offices.\n\n[Byline: Michelle Merlin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hopefully, the DNR is picking up all the dead birds. To leave the dead birds to decompose is to perpetuate the situation. As the birds decompose, and maggots develop, those maggots will be filled with botulinum toxin. When another bird consumes the maggot, the cycle continues.\n\nBotulinum toxin causes botulism. The toxin is a neurotoxic protein. The toxic protein is produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism is an extremely potent toxin, one of the most toxic agents known.\n\nWhile botulism is extremely toxic, it has been used medically in treating strokes and migraines, and cosmetically in treating wrinkles, to name a few uses. There are other appropriate medical uses.\n\nMichigan may be located on the interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian - USA: (CA) waterfowl 20140801.2651373\n2013\n----\nBotulism, avian - When another bird consumes the maggot, the cycle continues.\n\nBotulinum toxin causes botulism. The toxin is a neurotoxic protein. The toxic protein is produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism is an extremely potent toxin, one of the most toxic agents known.\n\nWhile botulism is extremely toxic, it has been used medically in treating strokes and migraines, and cosmetically in treating wrinkles, to name a few uses. [This condition is often called \"limber neck.\" - Mod.TG]\n\nThe birds were infected with type C botulism, a toxin that naturally occurs in soil. Experts attributed the impacted birds to elevated lake levels this year [2014].\n\n\"It's over the area that hadn't been water-covered in the past couple years,\" said Katie Keen, a wildlife technician at the DNR. \"The ducks wouldn't be feeding in that area if it didn't have water.\"\n\nThe botulism [in this case] does not pose a threat to humans, but Keen said dogs and other pets should be kept on leashes and away from dead animals to avoid ingesting the toxin.\n\nThe dead birds were found on the shore near the North Shore Inn and the Pointes North Beachfront Resort Hotel on U.S. 31 [Traverse City, Michigan].\n\nKeen urged anyone who sees a dead duck to call the Traverse City DNR offices.\n\n[Byline: Michelle Merlin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hopefully, the DNR is picking up all the dead birds. USA (08): (VA) jarred foods, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2708738", "date": "2014-08-15 00:17:03", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - USA (02): (MICHIGAN) WATERFOWL\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Aug 2014\nSource: Record-Eagle [edited]\nhttp://www.record-eagle.com/news/local_news/article_5667c548-0672-56ef-8acc-259fb0e07323.html\n\n\nAbout 30 dead ducks dotted beaches along the east arm of Grand Traverse Bay [Lake Michigan, Michigan, USA] in the last few weeks.\n\nDepartment of Natural Resources (DNR) officials sent the waterfowl, all mallards, to a laboratory where they tested positive for botulism, a paralytic condition caused by a toxin. Birds with botulism typically are unable to hold up their heads and ultimately drown. [This condition is often called \"limber neck.\" - Mod.TG]\n\nThe birds were infected with type C botulism, a toxin that naturally occurs in soil. Experts attributed the impacted birds to elevated lake levels this year [2014].\n\n\"It's over the area that hadn't been water-covered in the past couple years,\" said Katie Keen, a wildlife technician at the DNR. \"The ducks wouldn't be feeding in that area if it didn't have water.\"\n\nThe botulism [in this case] does not pose a threat to humans, but Keen said dogs and other pets should be kept on leashes and away from dead animals to avoid ingesting the toxin.\n\nThe dead birds were found on the shore near the North Shore Inn and the Pointes North Beachfront Resort Hotel on U.S. 31 [Traverse City, Michigan].\n\nKeen urged anyone who sees a dead duck to call the Traverse City DNR offices.\n\n[Byline: Michelle Merlin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hopefully, the DNR is picking up all the dead birds. To leave the dead birds to decompose is to perpetuate the situation. As the birds decompose, and maggots develop, those maggots will be filled with botulinum toxin. When another bird consumes the maggot, the cycle continues.\n\nBotulinum toxin causes botulism. The toxin is a neurotoxic protein. The toxic protein is produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism is an extremely potent toxin, one of the most toxic agents known.\n\nWhile botulism is extremely toxic, it has been used medically in treating strokes and migraines, and cosmetically in treating wrinkles, to name a few uses. There are other appropriate medical uses.\n\nMichigan may be located on the interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian - USA: (CA) waterfowl 20140801.2651373\n2013\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (07): (AK) fatality, fermented fish", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2703023", "date": "2014-08-15 00:17:03", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - USA (02): (MICHIGAN) WATERFOWL\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Aug 2014\nSource: Record-Eagle [edited]\nhttp://www.record-eagle.com/news/local_news/article_5667c548-0672-56ef-8acc-259fb0e07323.html\n\n\nAbout 30 dead ducks dotted beaches along the east arm of Grand Traverse Bay [Lake Michigan, Michigan, USA] in the last few weeks.\n\nDepartment of Natural Resources (DNR) officials sent the waterfowl, all mallards, to a laboratory where they tested positive for botulism, a paralytic condition caused by a toxin. Birds with botulism typically are unable to hold up their heads and ultimately drown. [This condition is often called \"limber neck.\" - Mod.TG]\n\nThe birds were infected with type C botulism, a toxin that naturally occurs in soil. Experts attributed the impacted birds to elevated lake levels this year [2014].\n\n\"It's over the area that hadn't been water-covered in the past couple years,\" said Katie Keen, a wildlife technician at the DNR. \"The ducks wouldn't be feeding in that area if it didn't have water.\"\n\nThe botulism [in this case] does not pose a threat to humans, but Keen said dogs and other pets should be kept on leashes and away from dead animals to avoid ingesting the toxin.\n\nThe dead birds were found on the shore near the North Shore Inn and the Pointes North Beachfront Resort Hotel on U.S. 31 [Traverse City, Michigan].\n\nKeen urged anyone who sees a dead duck to call the Traverse City DNR offices.\n\n[Byline: Michelle Merlin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hopefully, the DNR is picking up all the dead birds. To leave the dead birds to decompose is to perpetuate the situation. As the birds decompose, and maggots develop, those maggots will be filled with botulinum toxin. When another bird consumes the maggot, the cycle continues.\n\nBotulinum toxin causes botulism. The toxin is a neurotoxic protein. The toxic protein is produced by _Clostridium botulinum_. Botulism is an extremely potent toxin, one of the most toxic agents known.\n\nWhile botulism is extremely toxic, it has been used medically in treating strokes and migraines, and cosmetically in treating wrinkles, to name a few uses. There are other appropriate medical uses.\n\nMichigan may be located on the interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian - USA: (CA) waterfowl 20140801.2651373\n2013\n----\nBotulism, avian - Birds with botulism typically are unable to hold up their heads and ultimately drown. [This condition is often called \"limber neck.\" - Mod.TG]\n\nThe birds were infected with type C botulism, a toxin that naturally occurs in soil. Experts attributed the impacted birds to elevated lake levels this year [2014].\n\n\"It's over the area that hadn't been water-covered in the past couple years,\" said Katie Keen, a wildlife technician at the DNR. \"The ducks wouldn't be feeding in that area if it didn't have water.\"\n\nThe botulism [in this case] does not pose a threat to humans, but Keen said dogs and other pets should be kept on leashes and away from dead animals to avoid ingesting the toxin.\n\nThe dead birds were found on the shore near the North Shore Inn and the Pointes North Beachfront Resort Hotel on U.S. 31 [Traverse City, Michigan].\n\nKeen urged anyone who sees a dead duck to call the Traverse City DNR offices.\n\n[Byline: Michelle Merlin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hopefully, the DNR is picking up all the dead birds. USA (06): (OH) canned pesto, alert, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2665838", "date": "2014-07-19 16:48:36", "main_text": "INFANT BOTULISM - USA: (NEW JERSEY)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Jul 2014\nSource: ABC 7 [edited]\nhttp://7online.com/health/race-against-time-to-save-baby-diagnosed-with-botulism/192894/\n\n\nParents panicked when their 3-month-old baby suddenly became sick and ended up in the hospital. He was diagnosed with botulism, a potentially deadly condition, and getting the treatment wasn't easy. \"All you want is your baby to be back to normal,\" said the baby's mother.\n\nBut the 3-month-old was lethargic, losing muscle tone, and getting worse. And on 2 Jul 2014, he ended up in intensive care at St. Barnabas Medical Center [Essex County, New Jersey]. \"His cry was weak, he wouldn't eat, he was miserable,\" the mother said. The baby had no fever, normal blood work, and wanted to eat but couldn't.\n\nChief of Infectious Disease Dr. Uzma Hassan says those are clues that led her to diagnosis of botulism. \"Botulism is a very serious illness. Botulism toxin is the most potent neurotoxin known to man,\" said Dr. Uzma Hassan, of St. Barnabas Medical Center. The toxin paralyzes muscles, leaving babies unable to eat or breathe. There is a treatment, baby-BIG (botulism immune globulin), but you can only get it from the California Department of Public Health and it costs USD 45 000.\n\nFor that antitoxin to work, it has to be given within a few days. But the test to confirm the diagnosis can take up to a week. That means doctors have to act fast and make a decision before it's too late. \"He needed to get this as soon as possible. He was deteriorating and he was deteriorating really quickly,\" the mother said. After the treatment, the baby immediately started to get better. Soon after, the test results came back confirming that he had botulism. The condition affects about 100 babies a year.\n\nDr. Hassan says construction and dust may play a role. \"It may be that the soil turning around could have triggered a release of spores in the environment,\" Dr. Hassan said. Botulism spores are also found in honey. That's the reason new parents are told to never give their baby honey.\n\n[Byline: Dr. Sapna Parikh]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is extracted from the CDC report on infant botulism in New York City (ProMED-mail post Infant botulism - USA (New York City) 20030117.0144):\n\n\"Intestinal botulism is the commonest form of human botulism in the USA; about 100 cases are reported among infants in the USA annually. Intestinal botulism occurs rarely in older children and adults [this form has been also referred to as adult colonization botulism - Mod.LL]. Intestinal botulism results from colonization and bacterial production of botulinum toxin in the colon. Swallowing ambient _Clostridium botulinum_ spores, which exist worldwide in soil and dust, has been proposed as the principal route of exposure; honey is an avoidable source of some causative spores. A common source of exposure is not usually identified; apparent clusters are rare and often remain unexplained after investigations are complete. In a cluster of infant botulism cases identified previously in the mid-Atlantic region of the USA, no common source of exposure was identified.\n\nBotulism should be suspected in previously healthy infants aged less than 12 months old who are constipated and who exhibit weakness in sucking, swallowing, or crying; hypotonia [decreased muscle tone]; and progressive bulbar and extremity muscle weakness. About half of patients require mechanical ventilation during hospitalization. Lumbar puncture and brain imaging generally yield normal results but can help differentiate among other causes of flaccid weakness. When infant botulism is suspected, local and state health departments should be notified promptly to arrange diagnostic stool testing.\"\n\nAs was done in the case above, botulism immune globulin (BIG) is indicated in infants with clinically diagnosed infant botulism, before diagnostic confirmation. The prompt use of this specific immunoglobulin leads to a significant decrease in both ICU and total hospital stay. Reviews regarding BIG use and infant botulism can be found in the references below.\n\nReferences:\n1. Underwood K, Rubin S, Deaker T, Newth C: Infant botulism: A 30-year experience spanning the introduction of botulism immune globulin intravenous in the intensive care Unit at Childrens Hospital Los Angeles. Pediatrics 2007; 120(6): e1380-5; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/120/6/e1380.long.\n2. Pifko E, Price A, Sterner S: Infant botulism and indications for administration of botulism immune globulin. Pediatric Emerg Care 2014; 30(2): 120-4; quiz 125-7. doi: 10.1097/PEC.0000000000000079; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24488164.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/232.]\nSee Also\nInfant botulism - Israel: (HM) 20140530.2506775\nInfant botulism - UK: (England) 20140126.2232740\n2013\n----\nInfant botulism - USA (06): (OR) 20130801.1859319\nInfant botulism - USA (05): (VA) 20130717.1830448\nInfant botulism - USA (04): comment 20130502.1686628\nInfant botulism - USA (03): comment 20130429.1679793\nInfant botulism - USA (02): (KS) 20130428.1678643\nInfant botulism - USA: (CO) 20130120.1507024\n2009\n----\nInfant botulism - UK: (Scotland) 20091106.3837\n2008\n----\nInfant botulism, neurotoxin type F - USA: (CO) 20080225.0767\n2007\n----\nInfant botulism, possible baby food link - USA (CA)(02) 20070423.1326\nInfant botulism, poss. baby food link - USA (CA): recall 20070420.1295\nBotulism, baby food - North America: alert, recall (02) 20070220.0636\nBotulism, baby food - North America: alert, recall 20070218.0618\nInfant botulism - USA (MD) (03) 20070202.0419\nInfant botulism - USA (MD) 20070112.0148\n2005\n----\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex Georgia (02): susp 20050426.1159\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex Georgia: susp 20050420.1108\n2003\n----\nInfant botulism - USA (New York City) 20030117.0144\n.................................................ll/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Jersey", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lumbar", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2665651", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - UK (03): (England) aquatic birds", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2665651", "date": "2014-07-19 16:48:36", "main_text": "INFANT BOTULISM - USA: (NEW JERSEY)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Jul 2014\nSource: ABC 7 [edited]\nhttp://7online.com/health/race-against-time-to-save-baby-diagnosed-with-botulism/192894/\n\n\nParents panicked when their 3-month-old baby suddenly became sick and ended up in the hospital. He was diagnosed with botulism, a potentially deadly condition, and getting the treatment wasn't easy. \"All you want is your baby to be back to normal,\" said the baby's mother.\n\nBut the 3-month-old was lethargic, losing muscle tone, and getting worse. And on 2 Jul 2014, he ended up in intensive care at St. Barnabas Medical Center [Essex County, New Jersey]. \"His cry was weak, he wouldn't eat, he was miserable,\" the mother said. The baby had no fever, normal blood work, and wanted to eat but couldn't.\n\nChief of Infectious Disease Dr. Uzma Hassan says those are clues that led her to diagnosis of botulism. \"Botulism is a very serious illness. Botulism toxin is the most potent neurotoxin known to man,\" said Dr. Uzma Hassan, of St. Barnabas Medical Center. The toxin paralyzes muscles, leaving babies unable to eat or breathe. There is a treatment, baby-BIG (botulism immune globulin), but you can only get it from the California Department of Public Health and it costs USD 45 000.\n\nFor that antitoxin to work, it has to be given within a few days. But the test to confirm the diagnosis can take up to a week. That means doctors have to act fast and make a decision before it's too late. \"He needed to get this as soon as possible. He was deteriorating and he was deteriorating really quickly,\" the mother said. After the treatment, the baby immediately started to get better. Soon after, the test results came back confirming that he had botulism. The condition affects about 100 babies a year.\n\nDr. Hassan says construction and dust may play a role. \"It may be that the soil turning around could have triggered a release of spores in the environment,\" Dr. Hassan said. Botulism spores are also found in honey. That's the reason new parents are told to never give their baby honey.\n\n[Byline: Dr. Sapna Parikh]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is extracted from the CDC report on infant botulism in New York City (ProMED-mail post Infant botulism - USA (New York City) 20030117.0144):\n\n\"Intestinal botulism is the commonest form of human botulism in the USA; about 100 cases are reported among infants in the USA annually. Intestinal botulism occurs rarely in older children and adults [this form has been also referred to as adult colonization botulism - Mod.LL]. Intestinal botulism results from colonization and bacterial production of botulinum toxin in the colon. Swallowing ambient _Clostridium botulinum_ spores, which exist worldwide in soil and dust, has been proposed as the principal route of exposure; honey is an avoidable source of some causative spores. A common source of exposure is not usually identified; apparent clusters are rare and often remain unexplained after investigations are complete. In a cluster of infant botulism cases identified previously in the mid-Atlantic region of the USA, no common source of exposure was identified.\n\nBotulism should be suspected in previously healthy infants aged less than 12 months old who are constipated and who exhibit weakness in sucking, swallowing, or crying; hypotonia [decreased muscle tone]; and progressive bulbar and extremity muscle weakness. About half of patients require mechanical ventilation during hospitalization. Lumbar puncture and brain imaging generally yield normal results but can help differentiate among other causes of flaccid weakness. When infant botulism is suspected, local and state health departments should be notified promptly to arrange diagnostic stool testing.\"\n\nAs was done in the case above, botulism immune globulin (BIG) is indicated in infants with clinically diagnosed infant botulism, before diagnostic confirmation. The prompt use of this specific immunoglobulin leads to a significant decrease in both ICU and total hospital stay. Reviews regarding BIG use and infant botulism can be found in the references below.\n\nReferences:\n1. Underwood K, Rubin S, Deaker T, Newth C: Infant botulism: A 30-year experience spanning the introduction of botulism immune globulin intravenous in the intensive care Unit at Childrens Hospital Los Angeles. Pediatrics 2007; 120(6): e1380-5; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/120/6/e1380.long.\n2. Pifko E, Price A, Sterner S: Infant botulism and indications for administration of botulism immune globulin. Pediatric Emerg Care 2014; 30(2): 120-4; quiz 125-7. doi: 10.1097/PEC.0000000000000079; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24488164.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/232.]\nSee Also\nInfant botulism - USA (New York City) 20030117.0144\n.................................................ll/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Jersey", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lumbar", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2658049", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - UK (02): (England) aquatic birds", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2658049", "date": "2014-07-19 16:48:36", "main_text": "INFANT BOTULISM - USA: (NEW JERSEY)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Jul 2014\nSource: ABC 7 [edited]\nhttp://7online.com/health/race-against-time-to-save-baby-diagnosed-with-botulism/192894/\n\n\nParents panicked when their 3-month-old baby suddenly became sick and ended up in the hospital. He was diagnosed with botulism, a potentially deadly condition, and getting the treatment wasn't easy. \"All you want is your baby to be back to normal,\" said the baby's mother.\n\nBut the 3-month-old was lethargic, losing muscle tone, and getting worse. And on 2 Jul 2014, he ended up in intensive care at St. Barnabas Medical Center [Essex County, New Jersey]. \"His cry was weak, he wouldn't eat, he was miserable,\" the mother said. The baby had no fever, normal blood work, and wanted to eat but couldn't.\n\nChief of Infectious Disease Dr. Uzma Hassan says those are clues that led her to diagnosis of botulism. \"Botulism is a very serious illness. Botulism toxin is the most potent neurotoxin known to man,\" said Dr. Uzma Hassan, of St. Barnabas Medical Center. The toxin paralyzes muscles, leaving babies unable to eat or breathe. There is a treatment, baby-BIG (botulism immune globulin), but you can only get it from the California Department of Public Health and it costs USD 45 000.\n\nFor that antitoxin to work, it has to be given within a few days. But the test to confirm the diagnosis can take up to a week. That means doctors have to act fast and make a decision before it's too late. \"He needed to get this as soon as possible. He was deteriorating and he was deteriorating really quickly,\" the mother said. After the treatment, the baby immediately started to get better. Soon after, the test results came back confirming that he had botulism. The condition affects about 100 babies a year.\n\nDr. Hassan says construction and dust may play a role. \"It may be that the soil turning around could have triggered a release of spores in the environment,\" Dr. Hassan said. Botulism spores are also found in honey. That's the reason new parents are told to never give their baby honey.\n\n[Byline: Dr. Sapna Parikh]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is extracted from the CDC report on infant botulism in New York City (ProMED-mail post Infant botulism - USA (New York City) 20030117.0144):\n\n\"Intestinal botulism is the commonest form of human botulism in the USA; about 100 cases are reported among infants in the USA annually. Intestinal botulism occurs rarely in older children and adults [this form has been also referred to as adult colonization botulism - Mod.LL]. Intestinal botulism results from colonization and bacterial production of botulinum toxin in the colon. Swallowing ambient _Clostridium botulinum_ spores, which exist worldwide in soil and dust, has been proposed as the principal route of exposure; honey is an avoidable source of some causative spores. A common source of exposure is not usually identified; apparent clusters are rare and often remain unexplained after investigations are complete. In a cluster of infant botulism cases identified previously in the mid-Atlantic region of the USA, no common source of exposure was identified.\n\nBotulism should be suspected in previously healthy infants aged less than 12 months old who are constipated and who exhibit weakness in sucking, swallowing, or crying; hypotonia [decreased muscle tone]; and progressive bulbar and extremity muscle weakness. About half of patients require mechanical ventilation during hospitalization. Lumbar puncture and brain imaging generally yield normal results but can help differentiate among other causes of flaccid weakness. When infant botulism is suspected, local and state health departments should be notified promptly to arrange diagnostic stool testing.\"\n\nAs was done in the case above, botulism immune globulin (BIG) is indicated in infants with clinically diagnosed infant botulism, before diagnostic confirmation. The prompt use of this specific immunoglobulin leads to a significant decrease in both ICU and total hospital stay. Reviews regarding BIG use and infant botulism can be found in the references below.\n\nReferences:\n1. Underwood K, Rubin S, Deaker T, Newth C: Infant botulism: A 30-year experience spanning the introduction of botulism immune globulin intravenous in the intensive care Unit at Childrens Hospital Los Angeles. Intestinal botulism occurs rarely in older children and adults [this form has been also referred to as adult colonization botulism - Mod.LL]. Intestinal botulism results from colonization and bacterial production of botulinum toxin in the colon. Swallowing ambient _Clostridium botulinum_ spores, which exist worldwide in soil and dust, has been proposed as the principal route of exposure; honey is an avoidable source of some causative spores. A common source of exposure is not usually identified; apparent clusters are rare and often remain unexplained after investigations are complete. In a cluster of infant botulism cases identified previously in the mid-Atlantic region of the USA, no common source of exposure was identified.\n\nBotulism should be suspected in previously healthy infants aged less than 12 months old who are constipated and who exhibit weakness in sucking, swallowing, or crying; hypotonia [decreased muscle tone]; and progressive bulbar and extremity muscle weakness. About half of patients require mechanical ventilation during hospitalization. Lumbar puncture and brain imaging generally yield normal results but can help differentiate among other causes of flaccid weakness. When infant botulism is suspected, local and state health departments should be notified promptly to arrange diagnostic stool testing.\"\n\nAs was done in the case above, botulism immune globulin (BIG) is indicated in infants with clinically diagnosed infant botulism, before diagnostic confirmation. The prompt use of this specific immunoglobulin leads to a significant decrease in both ICU and total hospital stay. USA (05): (OH, CA) canned pesto, alert, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2647937", "date": "2014-07-19 16:48:36", "main_text": "INFANT BOTULISM - USA: (NEW JERSEY)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Jul 2014\nSource: ABC 7 [edited]\nhttp://7online.com/health/race-against-time-to-save-baby-diagnosed-with-botulism/192894/\n\n\nParents panicked when their 3-month-old baby suddenly became sick and ended up in the hospital. He was diagnosed with botulism, a potentially deadly condition, and getting the treatment wasn't easy. \"All you want is your baby to be back to normal,\" said the baby's mother.\n\nBut the 3-month-old was lethargic, losing muscle tone, and getting worse. And on 2 Jul 2014, he ended up in intensive care at St. Barnabas Medical Center [Essex County, New Jersey]. \"His cry was weak, he wouldn't eat, he was miserable,\" the mother said. The baby had no fever, normal blood work, and wanted to eat but couldn't.\n\nChief of Infectious Disease Dr. Uzma Hassan says those are clues that led her to diagnosis of botulism. \"Botulism is a very serious illness. Botulism toxin is the most potent neurotoxin known to man,\" said Dr. Uzma Hassan, of St. Barnabas Medical Center. The toxin paralyzes muscles, leaving babies unable to eat or breathe. There is a treatment, baby-BIG (botulism immune globulin), but you can only get it from the California Department of Public Health and it costs USD 45 000.\n\nFor that antitoxin to work, it has to be given within a few days. But the test to confirm the diagnosis can take up to a week. That means doctors have to act fast and make a decision before it's too late. \"He needed to get this as soon as possible. He was deteriorating and he was deteriorating really quickly,\" the mother said. After the treatment, the baby immediately started to get better. Soon after, the test results came back confirming that he had botulism. The condition affects about 100 babies a year.\n\nDr. Hassan says construction and dust may play a role. \"It may be that the soil turning around could have triggered a release of spores in the environment,\" Dr. Hassan said. Botulism spores are also found in honey. That's the reason new parents are told to never give their baby honey.\n\n[Byline: Dr. Sapna Parikh]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is extracted from the CDC report on infant botulism in New York City (ProMED-mail post Infant botulism - USA (New York City) 20030117.0144):\n\n\"Intestinal botulism is the commonest form of human botulism in the USA; about 100 cases are reported among infants in the USA annually. Intestinal botulism occurs rarely in older children and adults [this form has been also referred to as adult colonization botulism - Mod.LL]. Intestinal botulism results from colonization and bacterial production of botulinum toxin in the colon. Swallowing ambient _Clostridium botulinum_ spores, which exist worldwide in soil and dust, has been proposed as the principal route of exposure; honey is an avoidable source of some causative spores. A common source of exposure is not usually identified; apparent clusters are rare and often remain unexplained after investigations are complete. In a cluster of infant botulism cases identified previously in the mid-Atlantic region of the USA, no common source of exposure was identified.\n\nBotulism should be suspected in previously healthy infants aged less than 12 months old who are constipated and who exhibit weakness in sucking, swallowing, or crying; hypotonia [decreased muscle tone]; and progressive bulbar and extremity muscle weakness. About half of patients require mechanical ventilation during hospitalization. Lumbar puncture and brain imaging generally yield normal results but can help differentiate among other causes of flaccid weakness. When infant botulism is suspected, local and state health departments should be notified promptly to arrange diagnostic stool testing.\"\n\nAs was done in the case above, botulism immune globulin (BIG) is indicated in infants with clinically diagnosed infant botulism, before diagnostic confirmation. The prompt use of this specific immunoglobulin leads to a significant decrease in both ICU and total hospital stay. Reviews regarding BIG use and infant botulism can be found in the references below.\n\nReferences:\n1. Underwood K, Rubin S, Deaker T, Newth C: Infant botulism: A 30-year experience spanning the introduction of botulism immune globulin intravenous in the intensive care Unit at Childrens Hospital Los Angeles. Pediatrics 2007; 120(6): e1380-5; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/120/6/e1380.long.\n2. Pifko E, Price A, Sterner S: Infant botulism and indications for administration of botulism immune globulin. Pediatric Emerg Care 2014; 30(2): 120-4; quiz 125-7. doi: 10.1097/PEC.0000000000000079; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24488164.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/232.]\nSee Also\nInfant botulism - USA (New York City) 20030117.0144\n.................................................ll/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Jersey", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lumbar", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2640790", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - UK: (England) aquatic birds, susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2640790", "date": "2014-07-19 16:48:36", "main_text": "INFANT BOTULISM - USA: (NEW JERSEY)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 16 Jul 2014\nSource: ABC 7 [edited]\nhttp://7online.com/health/race-against-time-to-save-baby-diagnosed-with-botulism/192894/\n\n\nParents panicked when their 3-month-old baby suddenly became sick and ended up in the hospital. He was diagnosed with botulism, a potentially deadly condition, and getting the treatment wasn't easy. \"All you want is your baby to be back to normal,\" said the baby's mother.\n\nBut the 3-month-old was lethargic, losing muscle tone, and getting worse. And on 2 Jul 2014, he ended up in intensive care at St. Barnabas Medical Center [Essex County, New Jersey]. \"His cry was weak, he wouldn't eat, he was miserable,\" the mother said. The baby had no fever, normal blood work, and wanted to eat but couldn't.\n\nChief of Infectious Disease Dr. Uzma Hassan says those are clues that led her to diagnosis of botulism. \"Botulism is a very serious illness. Botulism toxin is the most potent neurotoxin known to man,\" said Dr. Uzma Hassan, of St. Barnabas Medical Center. The toxin paralyzes muscles, leaving babies unable to eat or breathe. There is a treatment, baby-BIG (botulism immune globulin), but you can only get it from the California Department of Public Health and it costs USD 45 000.\n\nFor that antitoxin to work, it has to be given within a few days. But the test to confirm the diagnosis can take up to a week. That means doctors have to act fast and make a decision before it's too late. \"He needed to get this as soon as possible. He was deteriorating and he was deteriorating really quickly,\" the mother said. After the treatment, the baby immediately started to get better. Soon after, the test results came back confirming that he had botulism. The condition affects about 100 babies a year.\n\nDr. Hassan says construction and dust may play a role. \"It may be that the soil turning around could have triggered a release of spores in the environment,\" Dr. Hassan said. Botulism spores are also found in honey. That's the reason new parents are told to never give their baby honey.\n\n[Byline: Dr. Sapna Parikh]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following is extracted from the CDC report on infant botulism in New York City (ProMED-mail post Infant botulism - USA (New York City) 20030117.0144):\n\n\"Intestinal botulism is the commonest form of human botulism in the USA; about 100 cases are reported among infants in the USA annually. Intestinal botulism occurs rarely in older children and adults [this form has been also referred to as adult colonization botulism - Mod.LL]. Intestinal botulism results from colonization and bacterial production of botulinum toxin in the colon. Swallowing ambient _Clostridium botulinum_ spores, which exist worldwide in soil and dust, has been proposed as the principal route of exposure; honey is an avoidable source of some causative spores. A common source of exposure is not usually identified; apparent clusters are rare and often remain unexplained after investigations are complete. In a cluster of infant botulism cases identified previously in the mid-Atlantic region of the USA, no common source of exposure was identified.\n\nBotulism should be suspected in previously healthy infants aged less than 12 months old who are constipated and who exhibit weakness in sucking, swallowing, or crying; hypotonia [decreased muscle tone]; and progressive bulbar and extremity muscle weakness. About half of patients require mechanical ventilation during hospitalization. Lumbar puncture and brain imaging generally yield normal results but can help differentiate among other causes of flaccid weakness. When infant botulism is suspected, local and state health departments should be notified promptly to arrange diagnostic stool testing.\"\n\nAs was done in the case above, botulism immune globulin (BIG) is indicated in infants with clinically diagnosed infant botulism, before diagnostic confirmation. The prompt use of this specific immunoglobulin leads to a significant decrease in both ICU and total hospital stay. Reviews regarding BIG use and infant botulism can be found in the references below.\n\nReferences:\n1. Underwood K, Rubin S, Deaker T, Newth C: Infant botulism: A 30-year experience spanning the introduction of botulism immune globulin intravenous in the intensive care Unit at Childrens Hospital Los Angeles. Pediatrics 2007; 120(6): e1380-5; available at http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/120/6/e1380.long.\n2. Intestinal botulism occurs rarely in older children and adults [this form has been also referred to as adult colonization botulism - Mod.LL]. Intestinal botulism results from colonization and bacterial production of botulinum toxin in the colon. Swallowing ambient _Clostridium botulinum_ spores, which exist worldwide in soil and dust, has been proposed as the principal route of exposure; honey is an avoidable source of some causative spores. A common source of exposure is not usually identified; apparent clusters are rare and often remain unexplained after investigations are complete. Intestinal botulism results from colonization and bacterial production of botulinum toxin in the colon. Swallowing ambient _Clostridium botulinum_ spores, which exist worldwide in soil and dust, has been proposed as the principal route of exposure; honey is an avoidable source of some causative spores.
