USA (New York City) 20030117.0144\n.................................................ll/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Jersey", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lumbar", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2572542", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - USA (04): (WA) sauces, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2572542", "date": "2014-04-18 19:33:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - CAYMAN ISLANDS: CHICKEN\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Apr 2014\nSource: cayCompass.com [edited]\nhttp://www.compasscayman.com/caycompass/2014/04/17/Hundreds-of-chickens-die-of-botulism/\n\n\nMore than 400 feral chickens in Bodden Town have died of botulism, according to a post-mortem examination carried out by the Department of Agriculture. The birds began dying more than 2 weeks ago, residents in the area said. Brian Crichlow of the Department of Agriculture said a post-mortem exam on one of the birds revealed botulism. The bird was also tested for avian flu, with negative results. Mr Crichlow said botulism is not spread by direct contact with affected chickens, but there is a \"low potential for spreading to humans and other animals through consumption of dead chickens\" contaminated with the botulism toxin.\n\nBotulism is a micro-organism that occurs naturally in the soil and in decaying flesh. Since chickens are scavengers, they likely ate a dead animal and got sick, said Mr. Crichlow.\n\nThe Department of Environmental Health was expected to begin removing the birds from the site, near the Bodden Town Mission House, on Wednesday afternoon [16 Apr 2014], according to the department's director, Roydell Carter. \"We are aware of the situation. We were notified by the Department of Agriculture about it. We went on site today [Wed 16 Apr 2014] and we will be assisting them in getting the birds removed and disinfecting the area,\" he said. \"We're putting together the resources we need -- there are so many [dead chickens] all over the place ... We will go in and help. There could probably be public health implications as well [if the carcasses are not removed]. We don't want all these dead birds lying around ... where other animals might feed on their carcasses,\" he added.\n\nOn Wednesday [16 Apr 2014], many of the dead chickens could be seen around the Mission House and Harry McCoy Park, and under the home of an elderly couple nearby. Mr Crichlow advised that if the dead or dying birds are not removed and disposed of properly, other chickens will feed on the carcasses and the maggots from the dead chickens, leading to more chickens contracting botulism. Botulism is also known as \"limberneck,\" he said, reflecting the neck paralysis typically seen in affected birds. [The son] of the couple under whose home many of the decaying carcasses were seen, said he had picked up as many as he could, but those under the house would have to stay there until he had help removing them.\n\n\"The chickens just get crippled, lie down and die,\" said [the man], who often fed the chickens. For the past 2 weeks, the chickens have been \"dropping off like flies,\" he said.\n\nThe feral chickens roam the neighborhood and are considered pests by many in the area. Mr Crichlow said there had been no reports of domestic flocks of chickens owned by local farmers being affected by botulism. However, he said the department had seen similar episodes before of local wild chickens dying, adding that botulism is common in feral chickens in Cayman and elsewhere. Over the past 2 years, his department has responded to deaths of feral chickens in George Town, West Bay and Bodden Town districts, he said.\n\nKaren Rosenthal, a St. Matthews Veterinary School veterinarian who studies birds, said, \"It is not so easy for people to get botulism the same way chickens do. But you would never eat the eggs or meat from a chicken with botulism,\" she said. \"What we should worry about is if the people are using the same water source as the dead birds.\"\n\nKiran Kumar, medical officer of health at the public health department, said botulism from dead chickens does not spread to human beings through the air, and there is also no evidence of it spreading to humans by consumption of chickens with botulism. However, he advised against eating infected chickens to \"prevent any rarest possibility of such occurrence.\"\n\n[Byline: Jewel Levy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is much more often seen in wild ducks and other water birds. But we do have a prior report of an Australian incident which is very similar to this Cayman report. The Australians ascribed it to a buildup of the causative organism, _Clostridium botulinum_, in the soil. - Mod.MHJ\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38613.]\nSee Also\n2001\n----\nBotulism, chickens - Australia (Queensland) 20011107.2759\n.................................................sb/mpp/mhj/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "George Town", "country": "Cayman Islands"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Bodden Town", "country": "Cayman Islands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2556754", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Canada (04): (ON) canned salmon, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2556754", "date": "2014-04-18 19:33:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - CAYMAN ISLANDS: CHICKEN\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Apr 2014\nSource: cayCompass.com [edited]\nhttp://www.compasscayman.com/caycompass/2014/04/17/Hundreds-of-chickens-die-of-botulism/\n\n\nMore than 400 feral chickens in Bodden Town have died of botulism, according to a post-mortem examination carried out by the Department of Agriculture. The birds began dying more than 2 weeks ago, residents in the area said. Brian Crichlow of the Department of Agriculture said a post-mortem exam on one of the birds revealed botulism. The bird was also tested for avian flu, with negative results. Mr Crichlow said botulism is not spread by direct contact with affected chickens, but there is a \"low potential for spreading to humans and other animals through consumption of dead chickens\" contaminated with the botulism toxin.\n\nBotulism is a micro-organism that occurs naturally in the soil and in decaying flesh. Since chickens are scavengers, they likely ate a dead animal and got sick, said Mr. Crichlow.\n\nThe Department of Environmental Health was expected to begin removing the birds from the site, near the Bodden Town Mission House, on Wednesday afternoon [16 Apr 2014], according to the department's director, Roydell Carter. \"We are aware of the situation. We were notified by the Department of Agriculture about it. We went on site today [Wed 16 Apr 2014] and we will be assisting them in getting the birds removed and disinfecting the area,\" he said. \"We're putting together the resources we need -- there are so many [dead chickens] all over the place ... We will go in and help. There could probably be public health implications as well [if the carcasses are not removed]. We don't want all these dead birds lying around ... where other animals might feed on their carcasses,\" he added.\n\nOn Wednesday [16 Apr 2014], many of the dead chickens could be seen around the Mission House and Harry McCoy Park, and under the home of an elderly couple nearby. Mr Crichlow advised that if the dead or dying birds are not removed and disposed of properly, other chickens will feed on the carcasses and the maggots from the dead chickens, leading to more chickens contracting botulism. Botulism is also known as \"limberneck,\" he said, reflecting the neck paralysis typically seen in affected birds. [The son] of the couple under whose home many of the decaying carcasses were seen, said he had picked up as many as he could, but those under the house would have to stay there until he had help removing them.\n\n\"The chickens just get crippled, lie down and die,\" said [the man], who often fed the chickens. For the past 2 weeks, the chickens have been \"dropping off like flies,\" he said.\n\nThe feral chickens roam the neighborhood and are considered pests by many in the area. Mr Crichlow said there had been no reports of domestic flocks of chickens owned by local farmers being affected by botulism. However, he said the department had seen similar episodes before of local wild chickens dying, adding that botulism is common in feral chickens in Cayman and elsewhere. Over the past 2 years, his department has responded to deaths of feral chickens in George Town, West Bay and Bodden Town districts, he said.\n\nKaren Rosenthal, a St. Matthews Veterinary School veterinarian who studies birds, said, \"It is not so easy for people to get botulism the same way chickens do. But you would never eat the eggs or meat from a chicken with botulism,\" she said. \"What we should worry about is if the people are using the same water source as the dead birds.\"\n\nKiran Kumar, medical officer of health at the public health department, said botulism from dead chickens does not spread to human beings through the air, and there is also no evidence of it spreading to humans by consumption of chickens with botulism. However, he advised against eating infected chickens to \"prevent any rarest possibility of such occurrence.\"\n\n[Byline: Jewel Levy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is much more often seen in wild ducks and other water birds. But we do have a prior report of an Australian incident which is very similar to this Cayman report. The Australians ascribed it to a buildup of the causative organism, _Clostridium botulinum_, in the soil. - Mod.MHJ\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38613.]\nSee Also\n2001\n----\nBotulism, chickens - Australia (Queensland) 20011107.2759\n.................................................sb/mpp/mhj/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "George Town", "country": "Cayman Islands"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Bodden Town", "country": "Cayman Islands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2540143", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - USA (03): (CA) pickled vegetables, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2540143", "date": "2014-04-18 19:33:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - CAYMAN ISLANDS: CHICKEN\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Apr 2014\nSource: cayCompass.com [edited]\nhttp://www.compasscayman.com/caycompass/2014/04/17/Hundreds-of-chickens-die-of-botulism/\n\n\nMore than 400 feral chickens in Bodden Town have died of botulism, according to a post-mortem examination carried out by the Department of Agriculture. We will go in and help. There could probably be public health implications as well [if the carcasses are not removed]. We don't want all these dead birds lying around ... where other animals might feed on their carcasses,\" he added.\n\nOn Wednesday [16 Apr 2014], many of the dead chickens could be seen around the Mission House and Harry McCoy Park, and under the home of an elderly couple nearby. Mr Crichlow advised that if the dead or dying birds are not removed and disposed of properly, other chickens will feed on the carcasses and the maggots from the dead chickens, leading to more chickens contracting botulism. Botulism is also known as \"limberneck,\" he said, reflecting the neck paralysis typically seen in affected birds. [The son] of the couple under whose home many of the decaying carcasses were seen, said he had picked up as many as he could, but those under the house would have to stay there until he had help removing them.\n\n\"The chickens just get crippled, lie down and die,\" said [the man], who often fed the chickens. For the past 2 weeks, the chickens have been \"dropping off like flies,\" he said.\n\nThe feral chickens roam the neighborhood and are considered pests by many in the area. Mr Crichlow said there had been no reports of domestic flocks of chickens owned by local farmers being affected by botulism. However, he said the department had seen similar episodes before of local wild chickens dying, adding that botulism is common in feral chickens in Cayman and elsewhere. Over the past 2 years, his department has responded to deaths of feral chickens in George Town, West Bay and Bodden Town districts, he said.\n\nKaren Rosenthal, a St. Matthews Veterinary School veterinarian who studies birds, said, \"It is not so easy for people to get botulism the same way chickens do. But you would never eat the eggs or meat from a chicken with botulism,\" she said. \"What we should worry about is if the people are using the same water source as the dead birds.\"\n\nKiran Kumar, medical officer of health at the public health department, said botulism from dead chickens does not spread to human beings through the air, and there is also no evidence of it spreading to humans by consumption of chickens with botulism. However, he advised against eating infected chickens to \"prevent any rarest possibility of such occurrence.\"\n\n[Byline: Jewel Levy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is much more often seen in wild ducks and other water birds. Mr Crichlow said there had been no reports of domestic flocks of chickens owned by local farmers being affected by botulism. However, he said the department had seen similar episodes before of local wild chickens dying, adding that botulism is common in feral chickens in Cayman and elsewhere. Over the past 2 years, his department has responded to deaths of feral chickens in George Town, West Bay and Bodden Town districts, he said.\n\nKaren Rosenthal, a St. Matthews Veterinary School veterinarian who studies birds, said, \"It is not so easy for people to get botulism the same way chickens do. But you would never eat the eggs or meat from a chicken with botulism,\" she said. \"What we should worry about is if the people are using the same water source as the dead birds.\"\n\nKiran Kumar, medical officer of health at the public health department, said botulism from dead chickens does not spread to human beings through the air, and there is also no evidence of it spreading to humans by consumption of chickens with botulism. Mr Crichlow said botulism is not spread by direct contact with affected chickens, but there is a \"low potential for spreading to humans and other animals through consumption of dead chickens\" contaminated with the botulism toxin.\n\nBotulism is a micro-organism that occurs naturally in the soil and in decaying flesh. We will go in and help. There could probably be public health implications as well [if the carcasses are not removed]. For the past 2 weeks, the chickens have been \"dropping off like flies,\" he said.\n\nThe feral chickens roam the neighborhood and are considered pests by many in the area. Mr Crichlow said there had been no reports of domestic flocks of chickens owned by local farmers being affected by botulism. However, he said the department had seen similar episodes before of local wild chickens dying, adding that botulism is common in feral chickens in Cayman and elsewhere. Over the past 2 years, his department has responded to deaths of feral chickens in George Town, West Bay and Bodden Town districts, he said.\n\nKaren Rosenthal, a St. Matthews Veterinary School veterinarian who studies birds, said, \"It is not so easy for people to get botulism the same way chickens do. But you would never eat the eggs or meat from a chicken with botulism,\" she said. \"What we should worry about is if the people are using the same water source as the dead birds.\"\n\nKiran Kumar, medical officer of health at the public health department, said botulism from dead chickens does not spread to human beings through the air, and there is also no evidence of it spreading to humans by consumption of chickens with botulism. The bird was also tested for avian flu, with negative results. Mr Crichlow said botulism is not spread by direct contact with affected chickens, but there is a \"low potential for spreading to humans and other animals through consumption of dead chickens\" contaminated with the botulism toxin.\n\nBotulism is a micro-organism that occurs naturally in the soil and in decaying flesh. We were notified by the Department of Agriculture about it. We went on site today [Wed 16 Apr 2014] and we will be assisting them in getting the birds removed and disinfecting the area,\" he said. \"We're putting together the resources we need -- there are so many [dead chickens] all over the place ... We will go in and help. There could probably be public health implications as well [if the carcasses are not removed]. We don't want all these dead birds lying around ... where other animals might feed on their carcasses,\" he added.\n\nOn Wednesday [16 Apr 2014], many of the dead chickens could be seen around the Mission House and Harry McCoy Park, and under the home of an elderly couple nearby. Mr Crichlow advised that if the dead or dying birds are not removed and disposed of properly, other chickens will feed on the carcasses and the maggots from the dead chickens, leading to more chickens contracting botulism. Botulism is also known as \"limberneck,\" he said, reflecting the neck paralysis typically seen in affected birds. [The son] of the couple under whose home many of the decaying carcasses were seen, said he had picked up as many as he could, but those under the house would have to stay there until he had help removing them.\n\n\"The chickens just get crippled, lie down and die,\" said [the man], who often fed the chickens. For the past 2 weeks, the chickens have been \"dropping off like flies,\" he said.\n\nThe feral chickens roam the neighborhood and are considered pests by many in the area. Mr Crichlow said there had been no reports of domestic flocks of chickens owned by local farmers being affected by botulism. However, he said the department had seen similar episodes before of local wild chickens dying, adding that botulism is common in feral chickens in Cayman and elsewhere. Over the past 2 years, his department has responded to deaths of feral chickens in George Town, West Bay and Bodden Town districts, he said.\n\nKaren Rosenthal, a St. Matthews Veterinary School veterinarian who studies birds, said, \"It is not so easy for people to get botulism the same way chickens do. But you would never eat the eggs or meat from a chicken with botulism,\" she said. \"What we should worry about is if the people are using the same water source as the dead birds.\"\n\nKiran Kumar, medical officer of health at the public health department, said botulism from dead chickens does not spread to human beings through the air, and there is also no evidence of it spreading to humans by consumption of chickens with botulism. However, he advised against eating infected chickens to \"prevent any rarest possibility of such occurrence.\"\n\n[Byline: Jewel Levy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is much more often seen in wild ducks and other water birds. But we do have a prior report of an Australian incident which is very similar to this Cayman report. The Australians ascribed it to a buildup of the causative organism, _Clostridium botulinum_, in the soil. - Mod.MHJ\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38613.]\nSee Also\n2001\n----\nBotulism, chickens - Australia (Queensland) 20011107.2759\n.................................................sb/mpp/mhj/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "George Town", "country": "Cayman Islands"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Bodden Town", "country": "Cayman Islands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2492126", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism, bovine - UK: (Wales) susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2492126", "date": "2014-04-18 19:33:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - CAYMAN ISLANDS: CHICKEN\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Apr 2014\nSource: cayCompass.com [edited]\nhttp://www.compasscayman.com/caycompass/2014/04/17/Hundreds-of-chickens-die-of-botulism/\n\n\nMore than 400 feral chickens in Bodden Town have died of botulism, according to a post-mortem examination carried out by the Department of Agriculture. The birds began dying more than 2 weeks ago, residents in the area said. Brian Crichlow of the Department of Agriculture said a post-mortem exam on one of the birds revealed botulism. The bird was also tested for avian flu, with negative results. Mr Crichlow said botulism is not spread by direct contact with affected chickens, but there is a \"low potential for spreading to humans and other animals through consumption of dead chickens\" contaminated with the botulism toxin.\n\nBotulism is a micro-organism that occurs naturally in the soil and in decaying flesh. Since chickens are scavengers, they likely ate a dead animal and got sick, said Mr. Crichlow.\n\nThe Department of Environmental Health was expected to begin removing the birds from the site, near the Bodden Town Mission House, on Wednesday afternoon [16 Apr 2014], according to the department's director, Roydell Carter. \"We are aware of the situation. We were notified by the Department of Agriculture about it. We went on site today [Wed 16 Apr 2014] and we will be assisting them in getting the birds removed and disinfecting the area,\" he said. \"We're putting together the resources we need -- there are so many [dead chickens] all over the place ... We will go in and help. There could probably be public health implications as well [if the carcasses are not removed]. We don't want all these dead birds lying around ... where other animals might feed on their carcasses,\" he added.\n\nOn Wednesday [16 Apr 2014], many of the dead chickens could be seen around the Mission House and Harry McCoy Park, and under the home of an elderly couple nearby. Mr Crichlow advised that if the dead or dying birds are not removed and disposed of properly, other chickens will feed on the carcasses and the maggots from the dead chickens, leading to more chickens contracting botulism. Botulism is also known as \"limberneck,\" he said, reflecting the neck paralysis typically seen in affected birds. [The son] of the couple under whose home many of the decaying carcasses were seen, said he had picked up as many as he could, but those under the house would have to stay there until he had help removing them.\n\n\"The chickens just get crippled, lie down and die,\" said [the man], who often fed the chickens. For the past 2 weeks, the chickens have been \"dropping off like flies,\" he said.\n\nThe feral chickens roam the neighborhood and are considered pests by many in the area. Mr Crichlow said there had been no reports of domestic flocks of chickens owned by local farmers being affected by botulism. However, he said the department had seen similar episodes before of local wild chickens dying, adding that botulism is common in feral chickens in Cayman and elsewhere. Over the past 2 years, his department has responded to deaths of feral chickens in George Town, West Bay and Bodden Town districts, he said.\n\nKaren Rosenthal, a St. Matthews Veterinary School veterinarian who studies birds, said, \"It is not so easy for people to get botulism the same way chickens do. But you would never eat the eggs or meat from a chicken with botulism,\" she said. \"What we should worry about is if the people are using the same water source as the dead birds.\"\n\nKiran Kumar, medical officer of health at the public health department, said botulism from dead chickens does not spread to human beings through the air, and there is also no evidence of it spreading to humans by consumption of chickens with botulism. However, he advised against eating infected chickens to \"prevent any rarest possibility of such occurrence.\"\n\n[Byline: Jewel Levy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is much more often seen in wild ducks and other water birds. But we do have a prior report of an Australian incident which is very similar to this Cayman report. The Australians ascribed it to a buildup of the causative organism, _Clostridium botulinum_, in the soil. - Mod.MHJ\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38613.]\nSee Also\n2001\n----\nBotulism, chickens - Australia (Queensland) 20011107.2759\n.................................................sb/mpp/mhj/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "George Town", "country": "Cayman Islands"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Bodden Town", "country": "Cayman Islands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2414654", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - Cayman Islands: chicken", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2414654", "date": "2014-04-18 19:33:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - CAYMAN ISLANDS: CHICKEN\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Apr 2014\nSource: cayCompass.com [edited]\nhttp://www.compasscayman.com/caycompass/2014/04/17/Hundreds-of-chickens-die-of-botulism/\n\n\nMore than 400 feral chickens in Bodden Town have died of botulism, according to a post-mortem examination carried out by the Department of Agriculture. The birds began dying more than 2 weeks ago, residents in the area said. Brian Crichlow of the Department of Agriculture said a post-mortem exam on one of the birds revealed botulism. The bird was also tested for avian flu, with negative results. Mr Crichlow said botulism is not spread by direct contact with affected chickens, but there is a \"low potential for spreading to humans and other animals through consumption of dead chickens\" contaminated with the botulism toxin.\n\nBotulism is a micro-organism that occurs naturally in the soil and in decaying flesh. Since chickens are scavengers, they likely ate a dead animal and got sick, said Mr. Crichlow.\n\nThe Department of Environmental Health was expected to begin removing the birds from the site, near the Bodden Town Mission House, on Wednesday afternoon [16 Apr 2014], according to the department's director, Roydell Carter. \"We are aware of the situation. We were notified by the Department of Agriculture about it. We went on site today [Wed 16 Apr 2014] and we will be assisting them in getting the birds removed and disinfecting the area,\" he said. \"We're putting together the resources we need -- there are so many [dead chickens] all over the place ... We will go in and help. There could probably be public health implications as well [if the carcasses are not removed]. We don't want all these dead birds lying around ... where other animals might feed on their carcasses,\" he added.\n\nOn Wednesday [16 Apr 2014], many of the dead chickens could be seen around the Mission House and Harry McCoy Park, and under the home of an elderly couple nearby. Mr Crichlow advised that if the dead or dying birds are not removed and disposed of properly, other chickens will feed on the carcasses and the maggots from the dead chickens, leading to more chickens contracting botulism. Botulism is also known as \"limberneck,\" he said, reflecting the neck paralysis typically seen in affected birds. [The son] of the couple under whose home many of the decaying carcasses were seen, said he had picked up as many as he could, but those under the house would have to stay there until he had help removing them.\n\n\"The chickens just get crippled, lie down and die,\" said [the man], who often fed the chickens. For the past 2 weeks, the chickens have been \"dropping off like flies,\" he said.\n\nThe feral chickens roam the neighborhood and are considered pests by many in the area. Mr Crichlow said there had been no reports of domestic flocks of chickens owned by local farmers being affected by botulism. However, he said the department had seen similar episodes before of local wild chickens dying, adding that botulism is common in feral chickens in Cayman and elsewhere. Over the past 2 years, his department has responded to deaths of feral chickens in George Town, West Bay and Bodden Town districts, he said.\n\nKaren Rosenthal, a St. Matthews Veterinary School veterinarian who studies birds, said, \"It is not so easy for people to get botulism the same way chickens do. But you would never eat the eggs or meat from a chicken with botulism,\" she said. \"What we should worry about is if the people are using the same water source as the dead birds.\"\n\nKiran Kumar, medical officer of health at the public health department, said botulism from dead chickens does not spread to human beings through the air, and there is also no evidence of it spreading to humans by consumption of chickens with botulism. However, he advised against eating infected chickens to \"prevent any rarest possibility of such occurrence.\"\n\n[Byline: Jewel Levy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian botulism is much more often seen in wild ducks and other water birds. But we do have a prior report of an Australian incident which is very similar to this Cayman report. The Australians ascribed it to a buildup of the causative organism, _Clostridium botulinum_, in the soil. - Mod.MHJ\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38613.]\nSee Also\n2001\n----\nBotulism, chickens - Australia (Queensland) 20011107.2759\n.................................................sb/mpp/mhj/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "George Town", "country": "Cayman Islands"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Bodden Town", "country": "Cayman Islands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2393357", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism, avian - New Zealand (02): (WK) conf", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2393357", "date": "2014-02-22 13:17:41", "main_text": "BOTULISM - ARGENTINA: (MENDOZA) FATALITY, VIZCACHA MEAT\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 15 Feb 2014\nSource: Ono San Rafael [in Spanish, machine transl, edited]\nhttp://www.unosanrafael.com.ar/policiales/Una-nia-de-8-aos-murio-por-un-probable-caso-de-botulismo--20140215-0005.html\n\n\nA girl of 8 years living in Villa 25 de Mayo died on Friday night, 14 Feb 2014, and it is suspected that she contracted botulism after eating marinated vizcacha at a family dinner. It all began the night before when the girl, her father, a friend and 2 other women related to the family ate the homemade product.\n\nThe next day, they all began to have fever, vomiting and diarrhea until, for unknown reasons, the girl suffered from asthenopia [an ophthalmological condition with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, red eyes, eye strain, pain in or around the eyes, blurred vision, headache and occasional double vision] and had a cardiac arrest. Apparently, according to the preliminary results of the autopsy, it was found that the girl \"suffered a pulmonary edema which would have caused death,\" noted reliable sources. After the autopsy, the medical corps from forensic samples sent gastric fluids and stool to the National University of Cuyo to determine if the girl had botulism.\n\nThe suspicion of botulism grew after her father and a friend began to have difficulty speaking and forced hospitalizations in the intensive care units of the Schestakow and the Spanish Hospital of San Rafael, Mendoza Province. These symptoms, according to the specialists, \"are very common in patients with botulism.\" In this context it was learned that 2 more women who had consumed the escabeche had vomiting and diarrhea.\n\nThe director of the Schestakow, Armando Dauverne, reported that \"speaking with Aldo Sergio Saracco, [head of] the provincial level of Toxicology, accelerated studies of the samples sent to the National University of Cuyo will be done,\" and added that \"for now, all indicate that we are faced with 3 cases of botulism and [2 other suspected cases].\" Regarding the death of the girl, the Director pointed out that \"the girl was pronounced dead on arrival at the health center and then transferred to the Judicial Morgue,\" and he added that \"apparently choking was the cause of death.\"\n\nIn this framework, the pediatrician Gonzalo Herrera, who works at the hospital, explained that \"it is very likely that the girl had the toxin in her body, because she had vomiting, diarrhea and fever, as [did] the father, who is now in the hospital intensive care.\"\n\nBackground: A woman of 84 years and a man of 69 died of botulism in 2013 as a result of having ingested homemade food. The 1st case took place in March 2013 in General Alvear, when the man died, and the 2nd was in October 2013 when a woman died after a month of confinement in the Spanish Hospital. In the latter case, 2 other women became ill after consuming packaged peppers. All patients underwent treatment with antitoxin that the Ministry of Health of the province provided.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viscachas or vizcachas (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha) are rodents of 2 genera (_Lagidium_ and _Lagostomus_) in the family Chinchillidae. They are closely related to chinchillas, and look similar to rabbits, apart from their longer tails. Pictures of viscachas can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha.\n\nEscabeche (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escabeche) is a typical Mediterranean cuisine which refers to a dish of either poached or fried fish (escabeche of chicken, rabbit or pork is common in Spain) marinated in an acidic mixture before serving, and to the marinade itself. The dish is common in Spain and Latin America, and popular in Catalonia, Portugal, Provence and the Philippines. Influences of the dish appear as far as Asia-Pacific with adjustments to local food staples. It is usually served cold after marinating in a refrigerator overnight or longer. The acid in the marinade is usually vinegar, but can also include citrus juice. Escabeche is a popular presentation of canned or potted preserved fish, such as tuna, bonito or sardines. In the New World, versions of the basic marinade are often used with foods other than fish and meats -- for example, cassava or green bananas and chicken gizzards (Puerto Rico), jalapeno peppers (Mexico), etc. The origin of the word escabeche is Persian, and was brought to Spain by the Arabs during the Moorish conquests. The word derives from al-sikbaj, the name of a popular meat dish cooked in a sweet and sour sauce, usually vinegar and honey or date molasses.\n\nGiven this background information regarding the source of the meat and how escabeche is prepared, it is certainly possible that either the source of presumed botulism was not the meat dish or the preparation was not escabeche as the vinegar in the marinade should provide enough of an acidic environment to prevent germination of botulinum spores.\n\nThese cases may well be botulism as clusters of individuals with muscular weakness which can produce respiratory paralysis and begin with eye muscle weakness almost always represent botulism. The initial combination of gastrointestinal symptoms of nausea, vomiting and diarrhea with fever are probably not due to botulism altogether. As stated by Sobel (references removed): \"In foodborne botulism, particularly types B and E, gastrointestinal symptoms of nausea and vomiting may precede neurological symptoms. It is unknown if these are caused by direct action of botulinum toxin, other products of _C. botulinum_, or some other contaminant of spoiled food. These symptoms have never been reported in wound botulism nor have corresponding signs been observed in primate experiments in which pure toxin was administered intragastrically or intravenously\" (1). The diarrhea and fever are not linked to botulism and also may represent other agents in the food.\n\nReference:\n1. Sobel J: Botulism. In, Beyond Anthrax: The Weaponization of Infectious Diseases, Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM (eds), Humana Press, NY, 2005, pgs 85-106.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/35AZ.]\nSee Also\n2013\n----\nBotulism - Argentina (02): background 20130317.1590119\nBotulism - Argentina: (MZ) canned food 20130315.1588524\nBotulism - Armenia: home canned vegetable 20130206.1531916\n.................................................jt/ll/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-02-14 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-10-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Rafael", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Toxicology", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mendoza Province", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "lagostomus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "Portugal"}, {"location": "Puerto Rico", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "Botulism - USA (02): (TX) salted fish, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2389778", "date": "2014-02-22 13:17:41", "main_text": "BOTULISM - ARGENTINA: (MENDOZA) FATALITY, VIZCACHA MEAT\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 15 Feb 2014\nSource: Ono San Rafael [in Spanish, machine transl, edited]\nhttp://www.unosanrafael.com.ar/policiales/Una-nia-de-8-aos-murio-por-un-probable-caso-de-botulismo--20140215-0005.html\n\n\nA girl of 8 years living in Villa 25 de Mayo died on Friday night, 14 Feb 2014, and it is suspected that she contracted botulism after eating marinated vizcacha at a family dinner. It all began the night before when the girl, her father, a friend and 2 other women related to the family ate the homemade product.\n\nThe next day, they all began to have fever, vomiting and diarrhea until, for unknown reasons, the girl suffered from asthenopia [an ophthalmological condition with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, red eyes, eye strain, pain in or around the eyes, blurred vision, headache and occasional double vision] and had a cardiac arrest. Apparently, according to the preliminary results of the autopsy, it was found that the girl \"suffered a pulmonary edema which would have caused death,\" noted reliable sources. The 1st case took place in March 2013 in General Alvear, when the man died, and the 2nd was in October 2013 when a woman died after a month of confinement in the Spanish Hospital. In the latter case, 2 other women became ill after consuming packaged peppers. All patients underwent treatment with antitoxin that the Ministry of Health of the province provided.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viscachas or vizcachas (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha) are rodents of 2 genera (_Lagidium_ and _Lagostomus_) in the family Chinchillidae. Pictures of viscachas can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha.\n\nEscabeche (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escabeche) is a typical Mediterranean cuisine which refers to a dish of either poached or fried fish (escabeche of chicken, rabbit or pork is common in Spain) marinated in an acidic mixture before serving, and to the marinade itself. As stated by Sobel (references removed): \"In foodborne botulism, particularly types B and E, gastrointestinal symptoms of nausea and vomiting may precede neurological symptoms. It is unknown if these are caused by direct action of botulinum toxin, other products of _C. botulinum_, or some other contaminant of spoiled food. Argentina (02): background 20130317.1590119\nBotulism - Argentina: (MZ) canned food 20130315.1588524\nBotulism - Armenia: home canned vegetable 20130206.1531916\n.................................................jt/ll/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-02-14 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-10-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Rafael", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Toxicology", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mendoza Province", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "lagostomus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "Portugal"}, {"location": "Puerto Rico", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "Botulism - Argentina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Provence", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Schestakow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Judicial Morgue", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2384021", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Canada (02): rice-abalone porridge, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2384021", "date": "2014-02-22 13:17:41", "main_text": "BOTULISM - ARGENTINA: (MENDOZA) FATALITY, VIZCACHA MEAT\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 15 Feb 2014\nSource: Ono San Rafael [in Spanish, machine transl, edited]\nhttp://www.unosanrafael.com.ar/policiales/Una-nia-de-8-aos-murio-por-un-probable-caso-de-botulismo--20140215-0005.html\n\n\nA girl of 8 years living in Villa 25 de Mayo died on Friday night, 14 Feb 2014, and it is suspected that she contracted botulism after eating marinated vizcacha at a family dinner. It all began the night before when the girl, her father, a friend and 2 other women related to the family ate the homemade product.\n\nThe next day, they all began to have fever, vomiting and diarrhea until, for unknown reasons, the girl suffered from asthenopia [an ophthalmological condition with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, red eyes, eye strain, pain in or around the eyes, blurred vision, headache and occasional double vision] and had a cardiac arrest. Apparently, according to the preliminary results of the autopsy, it was found that the girl \"suffered a pulmonary edema which would have caused death,\" noted reliable sources. After the autopsy, the medical corps from forensic samples sent gastric fluids and stool to the National University of Cuyo to determine if the girl had botulism.\n\nThe suspicion of botulism grew after her father and a friend began to have difficulty speaking and forced hospitalizations in the intensive care units of the Schestakow and the Spanish Hospital of San Rafael, Mendoza Province. These symptoms, according to the specialists, \"are very common in patients with botulism.\" In this context it was learned that 2 more women who had consumed the escabeche had vomiting and diarrhea.\n\nThe director of the Schestakow, Armando Dauverne, reported that \"speaking with Aldo Sergio Saracco, [head of] the provincial level of Toxicology, accelerated studies of the samples sent to the National University of Cuyo will be done,\" and added that \"for now, all indicate that we are faced with 3 cases of botulism and [2 other suspected cases].\" Regarding the death of the girl, the Director pointed out that \"the girl was pronounced dead on arrival at the health center and then transferred to the Judicial Morgue,\" and he added that \"apparently choking was the cause of death.\"\n\nIn this framework, the pediatrician Gonzalo Herrera, who works at the hospital, explained that \"it is very likely that the girl had the toxin in her body, because she had vomiting, diarrhea and fever, as [did] the father, who is now in the hospital intensive care.\"\n\nBackground: A woman of 84 years and a man of 69 died of botulism in 2013 as a result of having ingested homemade food. The 1st case took place in March 2013 in General Alvear, when the man died, and the 2nd was in October 2013 when a woman died after a month of confinement in the Spanish Hospital. In the latter case, 2 other women became ill after consuming packaged peppers. All patients underwent treatment with antitoxin that the Ministry of Health of the province provided.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viscachas or vizcachas (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha) are rodents of 2 genera (_Lagidium_ and _Lagostomus_) in the family Chinchillidae. They are closely related to chinchillas, and look similar to rabbits, apart from their longer tails. Pictures of viscachas can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha.\n\nEscabeche (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escabeche) is a typical Mediterranean cuisine which refers to a dish of either poached or fried fish (escabeche of chicken, rabbit or pork is common in Spain) marinated in an acidic mixture before serving, and to the marinade itself. The dish is common in Spain and Latin America, and popular in Catalonia, Portugal, Provence and the Philippines. Influences of the dish appear as far as Asia-Pacific with adjustments to local food staples. It is usually served cold after marinating in a refrigerator overnight or longer. The acid in the marinade is usually vinegar, but can also include citrus juice. Escabeche is a popular presentation of canned or potted preserved fish, such as tuna, bonito or sardines. In the New World, versions of the basic marinade are often used with foods other than fish and meats -- for example, cassava or green bananas and chicken gizzards (Puerto Rico), jalapeno peppers (Mexico), etc. The origin of the word escabeche is Persian, and was brought to Spain by the Arabs during the Moorish conquests. The word derives from al-sikbaj, the name of a popular meat dish cooked in a sweet and sour sauce, usually vinegar and honey or date molasses.\n\nGiven this background information regarding the source of the meat and how escabeche is prepared, it is certainly possible that either the source of presumed botulism was not the meat dish or the preparation was not escabeche as the vinegar in the marinade should provide enough of an acidic environment to prevent germination of botulinum spores.\n\nThese cases may well be botulism as clusters of individuals with muscular weakness which can produce respiratory paralysis and begin with eye muscle weakness almost always represent botulism. The initial combination of gastrointestinal symptoms of nausea, vomiting and diarrhea with fever are probably not due to botulism altogether. As stated by Sobel (references removed): \"In foodborne botulism, particularly types B and E, gastrointestinal symptoms of nausea and vomiting may precede neurological symptoms. It is unknown if these are caused by direct action of botulinum toxin, other products of _C. botulinum_, or some other contaminant of spoiled food. These symptoms have never been reported in wound botulism nor have corresponding signs been observed in primate experiments in which pure toxin was administered intragastrically or intravenously\" (1). The diarrhea and fever are not linked to botulism and also may represent other agents in the food.\n\nReference:\n1. Sobel J: Botulism. In, Beyond Anthrax: The Weaponization of Infectious Diseases, Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM (eds), Humana Press, NY, 2005, pgs 85-106.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/35AZ.]\nSee Also\n2013\n----\nBotulism - Argentina (02): background 20130317.1590119\nBotulism - Argentina: (MZ) canned food 20130315.1588524\nBotulism - Armenia: home canned vegetable 20130206.1531916\n.................................................jt/ll/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-02-14 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-10-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Rafael", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Toxicology", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mendoza Province", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "lagostomus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "Portugal"}, {"location": "Puerto Rico", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "Botulism - Argentina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Provence", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Schestakow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Judicial Morgue", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2377447", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Tajikistan: (SU) home-canned tomatoes", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2377447", "date": "2014-02-22 13:17:41", "main_text": "BOTULISM - ARGENTINA: (MENDOZA) FATALITY, VIZCACHA MEAT\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 15 Feb 2014\nSource: Ono San Rafael [in Spanish, machine transl, edited]\nhttp://www.unosanrafael.com.ar/policiales/Una-nia-de-8-aos-murio-por-un-probable-caso-de-botulismo--20140215-0005.html\n\n\nA girl of 8 years living in Villa 25 de Mayo died on Friday night, 14 Feb 2014, and it is suspected that she contracted botulism after eating marinated vizcacha at a family dinner. It all began the night before when the girl, her father, a friend and 2 other women related to the family ate the homemade product.\n\nThe next day, they all began to have fever, vomiting and diarrhea until, for unknown reasons, the girl suffered from asthenopia [an ophthalmological condition with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, red eyes, eye strain, pain in or around the eyes, blurred vision, headache and occasional double vision] and had a cardiac arrest. Apparently, according to the preliminary results of the autopsy, it was found that the girl \"suffered a pulmonary edema which would have caused death,\" noted reliable sources. After the autopsy, the medical corps from forensic samples sent gastric fluids and stool to the National University of Cuyo to determine if the girl had botulism.\n\nThe suspicion of botulism grew after her father and a friend began to have difficulty speaking and forced hospitalizations in the intensive care units of the Schestakow and the Spanish Hospital of San Rafael, Mendoza Province. These symptoms, according to the specialists, \"are very common in patients with botulism.\" In this context it was learned that 2 more women who had consumed the escabeche had vomiting and diarrhea.\n\nThe director of the Schestakow, Armando Dauverne, reported that \"speaking with Aldo Sergio Saracco, [head of] the provincial level of Toxicology, accelerated studies of the samples sent to the National University of Cuyo will be done,\" and added that \"for now, all indicate that we are faced with 3 cases of botulism and [2 other suspected cases].\" Regarding the death of the girl, the Director pointed out that \"the girl was pronounced dead on arrival at the health center and then transferred to the Judicial Morgue,\" and he added that \"apparently choking was the cause of death.\"\n\nIn this framework, the pediatrician Gonzalo Herrera, who works at the hospital, explained that \"it is very likely that the girl had the toxin in her body, because she had vomiting, diarrhea and fever, as [did] the father, who is now in the hospital intensive care.\"\n\nBackground: A woman of 84 years and a man of 69 died of botulism in 2013 as a result of having ingested homemade food. The 1st case took place in March 2013 in General Alvear, when the man died, and the 2nd was in October 2013 when a woman died after a month of confinement in the Spanish Hospital. In the latter case, 2 other women became ill after consuming packaged peppers. All patients underwent treatment with antitoxin that the Ministry of Health of the province provided.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viscachas or vizcachas (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha) are rodents of 2 genera (_Lagidium_ and _Lagostomus_) in the family Chinchillidae. They are closely related to chinchillas, and look similar to rabbits, apart from their longer tails. Pictures of viscachas can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha.\n\nEscabeche (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escabeche) is a typical Mediterranean cuisine which refers to a dish of either poached or fried fish (escabeche of chicken, rabbit or pork is common in Spain) marinated in an acidic mixture before serving, and to the marinade itself. The dish is common in Spain and Latin America, and popular in Catalonia, Portugal, Provence and the Philippines. Influences of the dish appear as far as Asia-Pacific with adjustments to local food staples. It is usually served cold after marinating in a refrigerator overnight or longer. The acid in the marinade is usually vinegar, but can also include citrus juice. Escabeche is a popular presentation of canned or potted preserved fish, such as tuna, bonito or sardines. In the New World, versions of the basic marinade are often used with foods other than fish and meats -- for example, cassava or green bananas and chicken gizzards (Puerto Rico), jalapeno peppers (Mexico), etc. The origin of the word escabeche is Persian, and was brought to Spain by the Arabs during the Moorish conquests. The word derives from al-sikbaj, the name of a popular meat dish cooked in a sweet and sour sauce, usually vinegar and honey or date molasses.\n\nGiven this background information regarding the source of the meat and how escabeche is prepared, it is certainly possible that either the source of presumed botulism was not the meat dish or the preparation was not escabeche as the vinegar in the marinade should provide enough of an acidic environment to prevent germination of botulinum spores.\n\nThese cases may well be botulism as clusters of individuals with muscular weakness which can produce respiratory paralysis and begin with eye muscle weakness almost always represent botulism. The initial combination of gastrointestinal symptoms of nausea, vomiting and diarrhea with fever are probably not due to botulism altogether. As stated by Sobel (references removed): \"In foodborne botulism, particularly types B and E, gastrointestinal symptoms of nausea and vomiting may precede neurological symptoms. It is unknown if these are caused by direct action of botulinum toxin, other products of _C. botulinum_, or some other contaminant of spoiled food. These symptoms have never been reported in wound botulism nor have corresponding signs been observed in primate experiments in which pure toxin was administered intragastrically or intravenously\" (1). The diarrhea and fever are not linked to botulism and also may represent other agents in the food.\n\nReference:\n1. Sobel J: Botulism. In, Beyond Anthrax: The Weaponization of Infectious Diseases, Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM (eds), Humana Press, NY, 2005, pgs 85-106.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/35AZ.]\nSee Also\n2013\n----\nBotulism - The 1st case took place in March 2013 in General Alvear, when the man died, and the 2nd was in October 2013 when a woman died after a month of confinement in the Spanish Hospital. In the latter case, 2 other women became ill after consuming packaged peppers. All patients underwent treatment with antitoxin that the Ministry of Health of the province provided.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viscachas or vizcachas (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha) are rodents of 2 genera (_Lagidium_ and _Lagostomus_) in the family Chinchillidae. They are closely related to chinchillas, and look similar to rabbits, apart from their longer tails. Pictures of viscachas can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha.\n\nEscabeche (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escabeche) is a typical Mediterranean cuisine which refers to a dish of either poached or fried fish (escabeche of chicken, rabbit or pork is common in Spain) marinated in an acidic mixture before serving, and to the marinade itself. Influences of the dish appear as far as Asia-Pacific with adjustments to local food staples. It is usually served cold after marinating in a refrigerator overnight or longer. The acid in the marinade is usually vinegar, but can also include citrus juice. Escabeche is a popular presentation of canned or potted preserved fish, such as tuna, bonito or sardines. In the New World, versions of the basic marinade are often used with foods other than fish and meats -- for example, cassava or green bananas and chicken gizzards (Puerto Rico), jalapeno peppers (Mexico), etc. The origin of the word escabeche is Persian, and was brought to Spain by the Arabs during the Moorish conquests. All patients underwent treatment with antitoxin that the Ministry of Health of the province provided.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viscachas or vizcachas (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha) are rodents of 2 genera (_Lagidium_ and _Lagostomus_) in the family Chinchillidae. Pictures of viscachas can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha.\n\nEscabeche (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escabeche) is a typical Mediterranean cuisine which refers to a dish of either poached or fried fish (escabeche of chicken, rabbit or pork is common in Spain) marinated in an acidic mixture before serving, and to the marinade itself. The word derives from al-sikbaj, the name of a popular meat dish cooked in a sweet and sour sauce, usually vinegar and honey or date molasses.\n\nGiven this background information regarding the source of the meat and how escabeche is prepared, it is certainly possible that either the source of presumed botulism was not the meat dish or the preparation was not escabeche as the vinegar in the marinade should provide enough of an acidic environment to prevent germination of botulinum spores.\n\nThese cases may well be botulism as clusters of individuals with muscular weakness which can produce respiratory paralysis and begin with eye muscle weakness almost always represent botulism. The diarrhea and fever are not linked to botulism and also may represent other agents in the food.\n\nReference:\n1. Sobel J: Botulism. In, Beyond Anthrax: The Weaponization of Infectious Diseases, Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM (eds), Humana Press, NY, 2005, pgs 85-106.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/35AZ.]\nSee Also\n2013\n----\nBotulism - Argentina (02): background 20130317.1590119\nBotulism - Argentina: (MZ) canned food 20130315.1588524\nBotulism - Armenia: home canned vegetable 20130206.1531916\n.................................................jt/ll/je/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-02-14 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-10-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Rafael", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Toxicology", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mendoza Province", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "lagostomus", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "Portugal"}, {"location": "Puerto Rico", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "Botulism - Argentina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Provence", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Schestakow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Judicial Morgue", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2346753", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - New Zealand: (WK) susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2346753", "date": "2014-02-22 13:17:41", "main_text": "BOTULISM - ARGENTINA: (MENDOZA) FATALITY, VIZCACHA MEAT\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 15 Feb 2014\nSource: Ono San Rafael [in Spanish, machine transl, edited]\nhttp://www.unosanrafael.com.ar/policiales/Una-nia-de-8-aos-murio-por-un-probable-caso-de-botulismo--20140215-0005.html\n\n\nA girl of 8 years living in Villa 25 de Mayo died on Friday night, 14 Feb 2014, and it is suspected that she contracted botulism after eating marinated vizcacha at a family dinner. It all began the night before when the girl, her father, a friend and 2 other women related to the family ate the homemade product.\n\nThe next day, they all began to have fever, vomiting and diarrhea until, for unknown reasons, the girl suffered from asthenopia [an ophthalmological condition with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, red eyes, eye strain, pain in or around the eyes, blurred vision, headache and occasional double vision] and had a cardiac arrest. Apparently, according to the preliminary results of the autopsy, it was found that the girl \"suffered a pulmonary edema which would have caused death,\" noted reliable sources. After the autopsy, the medical corps from forensic samples sent gastric fluids and stool to the National University of Cuyo to determine if the girl had botulism.\n\nThe suspicion of botulism grew after her father and a friend began to have difficulty speaking and forced hospitalizations in the intensive care units of the Schestakow and the Spanish Hospital of San Rafael, Mendoza Province. These symptoms, according to the specialists, \"are very common in patients with botulism.\" In this context it was learned that 2 more women who had consumed the escabeche had vomiting and diarrhea.\n\nThe director of the Schestakow, Armando Dauverne, reported that \"speaking with Aldo Sergio Saracco, [head of] the provincial level of Toxicology, accelerated studies of the samples sent to the National University of Cuyo will be done,\" and added that \"for now, all indicate that we are faced with 3 cases of botulism and [2 other suspected cases].\" Regarding the death of the girl, the Director pointed out that \"the girl was pronounced dead on arrival at the health center and then transferred to the Judicial Morgue,\" and he added that \"apparently choking was the cause of death.\"\n\nIn this framework, the pediatrician Gonzalo Herrera, who works at the hospital, explained that \"it is very likely that the girl had the toxin in her body, because she had vomiting, diarrhea and fever, as [did] the father, who is now in the hospital intensive care.\"\n\nBackground: A woman of 84 years and a man of 69 died of botulism in 2013 as a result of having ingested homemade food. The 1st case took place in March 2013 in General Alvear, when the man died, and the 2nd was in October 2013 when a woman died after a month of confinement in the Spanish Hospital. In the latter case, 2 other women became ill after consuming packaged peppers. All patients underwent treatment with antitoxin that the Ministry of Health of the province provided.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viscachas or vizcachas (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha) are rodents of 2 genera (_Lagidium_ and _Lagostomus_) in the family Chinchillidae. They are closely related to chinchillas, and look similar to rabbits, apart from their longer tails. Pictures of viscachas can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha.\n\nEscabeche (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escabeche) is a typical Mediterranean cuisine which refers to a dish of either poached or fried fish (escabeche of chicken, rabbit or pork is common in Spain) marinated in an acidic mixture before serving, and to the marinade itself. The dish is common in Spain and Latin America, and popular in Catalonia, Portugal, Provence and the Philippines. Influences of the dish appear as far as Asia-Pacific with adjustments to local food staples. It is usually served cold after marinating in a refrigerator overnight or longer. The acid in the marinade is usually vinegar, but can also include citrus juice. Escabeche is a popular presentation of canned or potted preserved fish, such as tuna, bonito or sardines. In the New World, versions of the basic marinade are often used with foods other than fish and meats -- for example, cassava or green bananas and chicken gizzards (Puerto Rico), jalapeno peppers (Mexico), etc. The origin of the word escabeche is Persian, and was brought to Spain by the Arabs during the Moorish conquests. The word derives from al-sikbaj, the name of a popular meat dish cooked in a sweet and sour sauce, usually vinegar and honey or date molasses.\n\nGiven this background information regarding the source of the meat and how escabeche is prepared, it is certainly possible that either the source of presumed botulism was not the meat dish or the preparation was not escabeche as the vinegar in the marinade should provide enough of an acidic environment to prevent germination of botulinum spores.\n\nThese cases may well be botulism as clusters of individuals with muscular weakness which can produce respiratory paralysis and begin with eye muscle weakness almost always represent botulism. The initial combination of gastrointestinal symptoms of nausea, vomiting and diarrhea with fever are probably not due to botulism altogether. As stated by Sobel (references removed): \"In foodborne botulism, particularly types B and E, gastrointestinal symptoms of nausea and vomiting may precede neurological symptoms. It is unknown if these are caused by direct action of botulinum toxin, other products of _C. botulinum_, or some other contaminant of spoiled food. These symptoms have never been reported in wound botulism nor have corresponding signs been observed in primate experiments in which pure toxin was administered intragastrically or intravenously\" (1). The diarrhea and fever are not linked to botulism and also may represent other agents in the food.\n\nReference:\n1. Sobel J: Botulism. In, Beyond Anthrax: The Weaponization of Infectious Diseases, Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM (eds), Humana Press, NY, 2005, pgs 85-106.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/35AZ.]\nSee Also\n2013\n----\nBotulism - In the latter case, 2 other women became ill after consuming packaged peppers. All patients underwent treatment with antitoxin that the Ministry of Health of the province provided.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viscachas or vizcachas (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha) are rodents of 2 genera (_Lagidium_ and _Lagostomus_) in the family Chinchillidae. Pictures of viscachas can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viscacha.\n\nEscabeche (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escabeche) is a typical Mediterranean cuisine which refers to a dish of either poached or fried fish (escabeche of chicken, rabbit or pork is common in Spain) marinated in an acidic mixture before serving, and to the marinade itself. Canada: (AB) jarred bacon spread, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2257139", "date": "2013-11-20 10:42:47", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND - ARGENTINA: (MENDOZA)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Nov 2013\nSource: Diario Uno [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://www.diariouno.com.ar/mendoza/Un-extrao-caso-de-botulismo-fue-descubierto-en-el-Valle-de-Uco--20131117-0010.html\n\n\nLast February [2013], a 23 year old man arrived in the Antonio J Scaravelli hospital [in Tunuyan, Valle de Uco, Mendoza province] trauma unit with a very dirty, open arm fracture which required multiple surgical cleanings. The patient suffered progressive deterioration, further complicated by his asthma, which left him in a coma for a few days, requiring mechanical ventilation and a tracheostomy, and subsequently spent 67 days in the intensive care unit.\n\nThe cause of his neurological deterioration was difficult to discern but eventually he was diagnosed with wound-related botulism, confirmed by the laboratory of the Cuyo National University [San Rafael, Mendoza province].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _Clostridium botulinum_ contaminate a wound, germinate, and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most, but not all, cases of wound botulism have been among injecting drug users (IDUs). - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Argentina can be seen at http://www.zonu.com/imapa/americas/Argentina_Political_Map_3.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/9cuh. - UK: (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2232740", "date": "2013-11-20 10:42:47", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND - ARGENTINA: (MENDOZA)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Nov 2013\nSource: Diario Uno [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://www.diariouno.com.ar/mendoza/Un-extrao-caso-de-botulismo-fue-descubierto-en-el-Valle-de-Uco--20131117-0010.html\n\n\nLast February [2013], a 23 year old man arrived in the Antonio J Scaravelli hospital [in Tunuyan, Valle de Uco, Mendoza province] trauma unit with a very dirty, open arm fracture which required multiple surgical cleanings. The patient suffered progressive deterioration, further complicated by his asthma, which left him in a coma for a few days, requiring mechanical ventilation and a tracheostomy, and subsequently spent 67 days in the intensive care unit.\n\nThe cause of his neurological deterioration was difficult to discern but eventually he was diagnosed with wound-related botulism, confirmed by the laboratory of the Cuyo National University [San Rafael, Mendoza province].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _Clostridium botulinum_ contaminate a wound, germinate, and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most, but not all, cases of wound botulism have been among injecting drug users (IDUs). - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Argentina can be seen at http://www.zonu.com/imapa/americas/Argentina_Political_Map_3.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/9cuh. - South Africa: (NC) susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2125797", "date": "2013-11-20 10:42:47", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND - ARGENTINA: (MENDOZA)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Nov 2013\nSource: Diario Uno [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://www.diariouno.com.ar/mendoza/Un-extrao-caso-de-botulismo-fue-descubierto-en-el-Valle-de-Uco--20131117-0010.html\n\n\nLast February [2013], a 23 year old man arrived in the Antonio J Scaravelli hospital [in Tunuyan, Valle de Uco, Mendoza province] trauma unit with a very dirty, open arm fracture which required multiple surgical cleanings. The patient suffered progressive deterioration, further complicated by his asthma, which left him in a coma for a few days, requiring mechanical ventilation and a tracheostomy, and subsequently spent 67 days in the intensive care unit.\n\nThe cause of his neurological deterioration was difficult to discern but eventually he was diagnosed with wound-related botulism, confirmed by the laboratory of the Cuyo National University [San Rafael, Mendoza province].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _Clostridium botulinum_ contaminate a wound, germinate, and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most, but not all, cases of wound botulism have been among injecting drug users (IDUs). - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Argentina can be seen at http://www.zonu.com/imapa/americas/Argentina_Political_Map_3.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/9cuh. -
