USA: (WA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2045181", "date": "2013-10-07 10:06:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - ISRAEL: SUSPECTED, WIDE-SCALE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 6 Oct 2013\nSource: Hachaklait Clinical Veterinary Services, Head Veterinarian's weekly report no 40 [in Hebrew, by subscription, trans. Mod.AS, summ., edited]\nhttp://www.hachaklait.org.il/showarticle.asp?recid=3305&catid=0\n\n\nBotulism in cattle\n------------------\nSince 29 Sep 2013, hundreds of clinical cases suspected to be botulism have been reported from 21 cattle farms in 17 (named) locations throughout Israel, distributed in Hazafon (North) and Hadarom (South) provinces. About 100 of the affected cattle have reportedly died or been euthanised. The disease affected mainly young animals, predominantly fattening calves. The source of intoxication/infection has been suspected to be poultry manure fed to the cattle. In several of the affected farms, a common source for the poultry manure was found, namely a company which specializes in the treatment and supply of poultry litter to the cattle industry. Farmers have been advised to discontinue at present deriving poultry litter for cattle feeding from the said source; investigations into the matter by the producer/distributor and by the State Veterinary Services have been initiated.\n\nThe farming industry and veterinary practitioners, countrywide, have been updated in detail about the events. Farmers have been encouraged to check the vaccination history of their stock with the recommended vaccine (against _Clostridium botulinum_ C and D) and to fill any gaps, following manufacturer's instructions.\n\nMaterials sampled from affected cattle are under investigation in the Kimron Veterinary Institute [KVI].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The preliminary suspicion of botulism, likely to be accurately suggested based on the typical symptomatology, is yet to be laboratory confirmed. According to a flowchart of botulism testing in the KVI, attached to the report above, it may take more than 7 days to confirm (or otherwise) _C. botulinum_/toxins in the tested material.\n\nOne of the etiologies for consideration when poultry litter is suspected as the cause of neuromuscular signs and death in cattle are ionophores; this may happen if the litter derived from poultry was recently treated with a ionophore [substance able to transport particular ions across a lipid membrane in a cell] coccidiostat [a chemical agent added to animal feed (as for poultry) that serves to retard the growth and reproduction of pathogenic coccidia so that disease is minimized and the host develops immunity], such as maduromycin. Cattle are highly susceptible to residues of this drug.\n\nBotulism in cattle, caused by recycled poultry litter, has been recorded from various industrialised countries in recent years.\n\nIn the UK, an ad hoc group of the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) looked into the matter following an increase in the incidence of bovine botulism associated primarily with exposure of livestock to poultry (broiler) litter. Their report (2006) is found at http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nThe Group assessed the risk to the public from food produced by herds affected by botulism and concluded that for disease associated with toxin types C and D, \"there should be no requirement to restrict sales of meat or milk from clinically healthy cattle from farms where there have been clinically suspected cases of botulism in cattle. In addition, there should be no requirement to restrict the slaughter of healthy cattle from herds where cases of confirmed or suspected botulism have occurred.\" (see ProMED-mail post 20120829.1271101).\n\nIsrael has witnessed several outbreaks of botulism in domestic ruminants throughout the years. In 1978, a major outbreak of botulism type D caused the deaths and emergency slaughter of more than 1000 animals, most of them dairy cattle. Spores of _C. botulinum_ type D spread to many farms from 2 central animal feed plants by recycled, non-sterilized poultry manure that included remains of avian cadavers. Subsequently, annual botulism vaccinations of cattle and of other vulnerable animals with a vaccine, including toxoids of _C. botulinum_ types C and D adsorbed onto aluminum hydroxide gel, have been introduced and are routinely voluntarily applied in most parts of the country. Sporadic cases involving unvaccinated animals (mainly young cows) have been reported to occur every year.\n\nThe feeding of milking cows, sheep, and goats with poultry manure has been officially banned since 1996, while feeding of all animals is prohibited during 15 days prior to slaughter.\n\nBotulism in animals is not reportable in Israel, or OIE-listed. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1z-1.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBotulism, bovine - Israel (03): (HZ) raw milk, type D, safety 20120829.1271101\nBotulism, bovine - Israel (02): (HZ) raw milk, type D 20120823.1259805\nBotulism, bovine - Israel: (HZ) raw milk, RFI 20120815.1245834\n2002\n----\nBotulism, cattle - Israel 20020618.4531\n.................................................arn/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-09-29 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "1978-03-15 00:00:00", "1996-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Hazafon", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Hadarom", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2044021", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, wound - Norway", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2044021", "date": "2013-10-07 10:06:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - ISRAEL: SUSPECTED, WIDE-SCALE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 6 Oct 2013\nSource: Hachaklait Clinical Veterinary Services, Head Veterinarian's weekly report no 40 [in Hebrew, by subscription, trans. Mod.AS, summ., edited]\nhttp://www.hachaklait.org.il/showarticle.asp?recid=3305&catid=0\n\n\nBotulism in cattle\n------------------\nSince 29 Sep 2013, hundreds of clinical cases suspected to be botulism have been reported from 21 cattle farms in 17 (named) locations throughout Israel, distributed in Hazafon (North) and Hadarom (South) provinces. About 100 of the affected cattle have reportedly died or been euthanised. The disease affected mainly young animals, predominantly fattening calves. The source of intoxication/infection has been suspected to be poultry manure fed to the cattle. In several of the affected farms, a common source for the poultry manure was found, namely a company which specializes in the treatment and supply of poultry litter to the cattle industry. Farmers have been advised to discontinue at present deriving poultry litter for cattle feeding from the said source; investigations into the matter by the producer/distributor and by the State Veterinary Services have been initiated.\n\nThe farming industry and veterinary practitioners, countrywide, have been updated in detail about the events. Farmers have been encouraged to check the vaccination history of their stock with the recommended vaccine (against _Clostridium botulinum_ C and D) and to fill any gaps, following manufacturer's instructions.\n\nMaterials sampled from affected cattle are under investigation in the Kimron Veterinary Institute [KVI].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The preliminary suspicion of botulism, likely to be accurately suggested based on the typical symptomatology, is yet to be laboratory confirmed. According to a flowchart of botulism testing in the KVI, attached to the report above, it may take more than 7 days to confirm (or otherwise) _C. botulinum_/toxins in the tested material.\n\nOne of the etiologies for consideration when poultry litter is suspected as the cause of neuromuscular signs and death in cattle are ionophores; this may happen if the litter derived from poultry was recently treated with a ionophore [substance able to transport particular ions across a lipid membrane in a cell] coccidiostat [a chemical agent added to animal feed (as for poultry) that serves to retard the growth and reproduction of pathogenic coccidia so that disease is minimized and the host develops immunity], such as maduromycin. Cattle are highly susceptible to residues of this drug.\n\nBotulism in cattle, caused by recycled poultry litter, has been recorded from various industrialised countries in recent years.\n\nIn the UK, an ad hoc group of the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) looked into the matter following an increase in the incidence of bovine botulism associated primarily with exposure of livestock to poultry (broiler) litter. Their report (2006) is found at http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nThe Group assessed the risk to the public from food produced by herds affected by botulism and concluded that for disease associated with toxin types C and D, \"there should be no requirement to restrict sales of meat or milk from clinically healthy cattle from farms where there have been clinically suspected cases of botulism in cattle. In addition, there should be no requirement to restrict the slaughter of healthy cattle from herds where cases of confirmed or suspected botulism have occurred.\" (see ProMED-mail post 20120829.1271101).\n\nIsrael has witnessed several outbreaks of botulism in domestic ruminants throughout the years. In 1978, a major outbreak of botulism type D caused the deaths and emergency slaughter of more than 1000 animals, most of them dairy cattle. Spores of _C. botulinum_ type D spread to many farms from 2 central animal feed plants by recycled, non-sterilized poultry manure that included remains of avian cadavers. Subsequently, annual botulism vaccinations of cattle and of other vulnerable animals with a vaccine, including toxoids of _C. botulinum_ types C and D adsorbed onto aluminum hydroxide gel, have been introduced and are routinely voluntarily applied in most parts of the country. Sporadic cases involving unvaccinated animals (mainly young cows) have been reported to occur every year.\n\nThe feeding of milking cows, sheep, and goats with poultry manure has been officially banned since 1996, while feeding of all animals is prohibited during 15 days prior to slaughter.\n\nBotulism in animals is not reportable in Israel, or OIE-listed. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1z-1.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBotulism, bovine - Israel (03): (HZ) raw milk, type D, safety 20120829.1271101\nBotulism, bovine - Israel (02): (HZ) raw milk, type D 20120823.1259805\nBotulism, bovine - Israel: (HZ) raw milk, RFI 20120815.1245834\n2002\n----\nBotulism, cattle - Israel 20020618.4531\n.................................................arn/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-09-29 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "1978-03-15 00:00:00", "1996-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Hazafon", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Hadarom", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2042043", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Canada (04): (ON) bottled relish, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2042043", "date": "2013-10-07 10:06:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - ISRAEL: SUSPECTED, WIDE-SCALE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 6 Oct 2013\nSource: Hachaklait Clinical Veterinary Services, Head Veterinarian's weekly report no 40 [in Hebrew, by subscription, trans. Mod.AS, summ., edited]\nhttp://www.hachaklait.org.il/showarticle.asp?recid=3305&catid=0\n\n\nBotulism in cattle\n------------------\nSince 29 Sep 2013, hundreds of clinical cases suspected to be botulism have been reported from 21 cattle farms in 17 (named) locations throughout Israel, distributed in Hazafon (North) and Hadarom (South) provinces. About 100 of the affected cattle have reportedly died or been euthanised. The disease affected mainly young animals, predominantly fattening calves. The source of intoxication/infection has been suspected to be poultry manure fed to the cattle. In several of the affected farms, a common source for the poultry manure was found, namely a company which specializes in the treatment and supply of poultry litter to the cattle industry. Farmers have been advised to discontinue at present deriving poultry litter for cattle feeding from the said source; investigations into the matter by the producer/distributor and by the State Veterinary Services have been initiated.\n\nThe farming industry and veterinary practitioners, countrywide, have been updated in detail about the events. Farmers have been encouraged to check the vaccination history of their stock with the recommended vaccine (against _Clostridium botulinum_ C and D) and to fill any gaps, following manufacturer's instructions.\n\nMaterials sampled from affected cattle are under investigation in the Kimron Veterinary Institute [KVI].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The preliminary suspicion of botulism, likely to be accurately suggested based on the typical symptomatology, is yet to be laboratory confirmed. According to a flowchart of botulism testing in the KVI, attached to the report above, it may take more than 7 days to confirm (or otherwise) _C. botulinum_/toxins in the tested material.\n\nOne of the etiologies for consideration when poultry litter is suspected as the cause of neuromuscular signs and death in cattle are ionophores; this may happen if the litter derived from poultry was recently treated with a ionophore [substance able to transport particular ions across a lipid membrane in a cell] coccidiostat [a chemical agent added to animal feed (as for poultry) that serves to retard the growth and reproduction of pathogenic coccidia so that disease is minimized and the host develops immunity], such as maduromycin. Cattle are highly susceptible to residues of this drug.\n\nBotulism in cattle, caused by recycled poultry litter, has been recorded from various industrialised countries in recent years.\n\nIn the UK, an ad hoc group of the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) looked into the matter following an increase in the incidence of bovine botulism associated primarily with exposure of livestock to poultry (broiler) litter. Their report (2006) is found at http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nThe Group assessed the risk to the public from food produced by herds affected by botulism and concluded that for disease associated with toxin types C and D, \"there should be no requirement to restrict sales of meat or milk from clinically healthy cattle from farms where there have been clinically suspected cases of botulism in cattle. In addition, there should be no requirement to restrict the slaughter of healthy cattle from herds where cases of confirmed or suspected botulism have occurred.\" (see ProMED-mail post 20120829.1271101).\n\nIsrael has witnessed several outbreaks of botulism in domestic ruminants throughout the years. In 1978, a major outbreak of botulism type D caused the deaths and emergency slaughter of more than 1000 animals, most of them dairy cattle. Spores of _C. botulinum_ type D spread to many farms from 2 central animal feed plants by recycled, non-sterilized poultry manure that included remains of avian cadavers. Subsequently, annual botulism vaccinations of cattle and of other vulnerable animals with a vaccine, including toxoids of _C. botulinum_ types C and D adsorbed onto aluminum hydroxide gel, have been introduced and are routinely voluntarily applied in most parts of the country. Sporadic cases involving unvaccinated animals (mainly young cows) have been reported to occur every year.\n\nThe feeding of milking cows, sheep, and goats with poultry manure has been officially banned since 1996, while feeding of all animals is prohibited during 15 days prior to slaughter.\n\nBotulism in animals is not reportable in Israel, or OIE-listed. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1z-1.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBotulism, bovine - Israel (03): (HZ) raw milk, type D, safety 20120829.1271101\nBotulism, bovine - Israel (02): (HZ) raw milk, type D 20120823.1259805\nBotulism, bovine - Israel: (HZ) raw milk, RFI 20120815.1245834\n2002\n----\nBotulism, cattle - Israel 20020618.4531\n.................................................arn/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-09-29 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "1978-03-15 00:00:00", "1996-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Hazafon", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Hadarom", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2003561", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, bovine - Israel (02): susp. wide scale, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2003561", "date": "2013-10-07 10:06:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - ISRAEL: SUSPECTED, WIDE-SCALE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 6 Oct 2013\nSource: Hachaklait Clinical Veterinary Services, Head Veterinarian's weekly report no 40 [in Hebrew, by subscription, trans. Mod.AS, summ., edited]\nhttp://www.hachaklait.org.il/showarticle.asp?recid=3305&catid=0\n\n\nBotulism in cattle\n------------------\nSince 29 Sep 2013, hundreds of clinical cases suspected to be botulism have been reported from 21 cattle farms in 17 (named) locations throughout Israel, distributed in Hazafon (North) and Hadarom (South) provinces. About 100 of the affected cattle have reportedly died or been euthanised. The disease affected mainly young animals, predominantly fattening calves. The source of intoxication/infection has been suspected to be poultry manure fed to the cattle. In several of the affected farms, a common source for the poultry manure was found, namely a company which specializes in the treatment and supply of poultry litter to the cattle industry. Farmers have been advised to discontinue at present deriving poultry litter for cattle feeding from the said source; investigations into the matter by the producer/distributor and by the State Veterinary Services have been initiated.\n\nThe farming industry and veterinary practitioners, countrywide, have been updated in detail about the events. Farmers have been encouraged to check the vaccination history of their stock with the recommended vaccine (against _Clostridium botulinum_ C and D) and to fill any gaps, following manufacturer's instructions.\n\nMaterials sampled from affected cattle are under investigation in the Kimron Veterinary Institute [KVI].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The preliminary suspicion of botulism, likely to be accurately suggested based on the typical symptomatology, is yet to be laboratory confirmed. According to a flowchart of botulism testing in the KVI, attached to the report above, it may take more than 7 days to confirm (or otherwise) _C. botulinum_/toxins in the tested material.\n\nOne of the etiologies for consideration when poultry litter is suspected as the cause of neuromuscular signs and death in cattle are ionophores; this may happen if the litter derived from poultry was recently treated with a ionophore [substance able to transport particular ions across a lipid membrane in a cell] coccidiostat [a chemical agent added to animal feed (as for poultry) that serves to retard the growth and reproduction of pathogenic coccidia so that disease is minimized and the host develops immunity], such as maduromycin. Cattle are highly susceptible to residues of this drug.\n\nBotulism in cattle, caused by recycled poultry litter, has been recorded from various industrialised countries in recent years.\n\nIn the UK, an ad hoc group of the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) looked into the matter following an increase in the incidence of bovine botulism associated primarily with exposure of livestock to poultry (broiler) litter. Their report (2006) is found at http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nThe Group assessed the risk to the public from food produced by herds affected by botulism and concluded that for disease associated with toxin types C and D, \"there should be no requirement to restrict sales of meat or milk from clinically healthy cattle from farms where there have been clinically suspected cases of botulism in cattle. In addition, there should be no requirement to restrict the slaughter of healthy cattle from herds where cases of confirmed or suspected botulism have occurred.\" (see ProMED-mail post 20120829.1271101).\n\nIsrael has witnessed several outbreaks of botulism in domestic ruminants throughout the years. In 1978, a major outbreak of botulism type D caused the deaths and emergency slaughter of more than 1000 animals, most of them dairy cattle. Spores of _C. botulinum_ type D spread to many farms from 2 central animal feed plants by recycled, non-sterilized poultry manure that included remains of avian cadavers. Subsequently, annual botulism vaccinations of cattle and of other vulnerable animals with a vaccine, including toxoids of _C. botulinum_ types C and D adsorbed onto aluminum hydroxide gel, have been introduced and are routinely voluntarily applied in most parts of the country. Sporadic cases involving unvaccinated animals (mainly young cows) have been reported to occur every year.\n\nThe feeding of milking cows, sheep, and goats with poultry manure has been officially banned since 1996, while feeding of all animals is prohibited during 15 days prior to slaughter.\n\nBotulism in animals is not reportable in Israel, or OIE-listed. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1z-1.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBotulism, bovine - Israel (03): (HZ) raw milk, type D, safety 20120829.1271101\nBotulism, bovine - Israel (02): (HZ) raw milk, type D 20120823.1259805\nBotulism, bovine - Israel: (HZ) raw milk, RFI 20120815.1245834\n2002\n----\nBotulism, cattle - Israel 20020618.4531\n.................................................arn/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-09-29 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "1978-03-15 00:00:00", "1996-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Hazafon", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Hadarom", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2001671", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Infant botulism - USA (07): 8th botulinum toxin", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2001671", "date": "2013-10-07 10:06:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - ISRAEL: SUSPECTED, WIDE-SCALE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 6 Oct 2013\nSource: Hachaklait Clinical Veterinary Services, Head Veterinarian's weekly report no 40 [in Hebrew, by subscription, trans. Mod.AS, summ., edited]\nhttp://www.hachaklait.org.il/showarticle.asp?recid=3305&catid=0\n\n\nBotulism in cattle\n------------------\nSince 29 Sep 2013, hundreds of clinical cases suspected to be botulism have been reported from 21 cattle farms in 17 (named) locations throughout Israel, distributed in Hazafon (North) and Hadarom (South) provinces. About 100 of the affected cattle have reportedly died or been euthanised. The disease affected mainly young animals, predominantly fattening calves. The source of intoxication/infection has been suspected to be poultry manure fed to the cattle. In several of the affected farms, a common source for the poultry manure was found, namely a company which specializes in the treatment and supply of poultry litter to the cattle industry. Farmers have been advised to discontinue at present deriving poultry litter for cattle feeding from the said source; investigations into the matter by the producer/distributor and by the State Veterinary Services have been initiated.\n\nThe farming industry and veterinary practitioners, countrywide, have been updated in detail about the events. Farmers have been encouraged to check the vaccination history of their stock with the recommended vaccine (against _Clostridium botulinum_ C and D) and to fill any gaps, following manufacturer's instructions.\n\nMaterials sampled from affected cattle are under investigation in the Kimron Veterinary Institute [KVI].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The preliminary suspicion of botulism, likely to be accurately suggested based on the typical symptomatology, is yet to be laboratory confirmed. According to a flowchart of botulism testing in the KVI, attached to the report above, it may take more than 7 days to confirm (or otherwise) _C. botulinum_/toxins in the tested material.\n\nOne of the etiologies for consideration when poultry litter is suspected as the cause of neuromuscular signs and death in cattle are ionophores; this may happen if the litter derived from poultry was recently treated with a ionophore [substance able to transport particular ions across a lipid membrane in a cell] coccidiostat [a chemical agent added to animal feed (as for poultry) that serves to retard the growth and reproduction of pathogenic coccidia so that disease is minimized and the host develops immunity], such as maduromycin. Cattle are highly susceptible to residues of this drug.\n\nBotulism in cattle, caused by recycled poultry litter, has been recorded from various industrialised countries in recent years.\n\nIn the UK, an ad hoc group of the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) looked into the matter following an increase in the incidence of bovine botulism associated primarily with exposure of livestock to poultry (broiler) litter. Their report (2006) is found at http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nThe Group assessed the risk to the public from food produced by herds affected by botulism and concluded that for disease associated with toxin types C and D, \"there should be no requirement to restrict sales of meat or milk from clinically healthy cattle from farms where there have been clinically suspected cases of botulism in cattle. In addition, there should be no requirement to restrict the slaughter of healthy cattle from herds where cases of confirmed or suspected botulism have occurred.\" (see ProMED-mail post 20120829.1271101).\n\nIsrael has witnessed several outbreaks of botulism in domestic ruminants throughout the years. In 1978, a major outbreak of botulism type D caused the deaths and emergency slaughter of more than 1000 animals, most of them dairy cattle. Spores of _C. botulinum_ type D spread to many farms from 2 central animal feed plants by recycled, non-sterilized poultry manure that included remains of avian cadavers. Subsequently, annual botulism vaccinations of cattle and of other vulnerable animals with a vaccine, including toxoids of _C. botulinum_ types C and D adsorbed onto aluminum hydroxide gel, have been introduced and are routinely voluntarily applied in most parts of the country. Sporadic cases involving unvaccinated animals (mainly young cows) have been reported to occur every year.\n\nThe feeding of milking cows, sheep, and goats with poultry manure has been officially banned since 1996, while feeding of all animals is prohibited during 15 days prior to slaughter.\n\nBotulism in animals is not reportable in Israel, or OIE-listed. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1z-1.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBotulism, bovine - Israel (03): (HZ) raw milk, type D, safety 20120829.1271101\nBotulism, bovine - Israel (02): (HZ) raw milk, type D 20120823.1259805\nBotulism, bovine - Israel: (HZ) raw milk, RFI 20120815.1245834\n2002\n----\nBotulism, cattle - Israel 20020618.4531\n.................................................arn/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-09-29 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "1978-03-15 00:00:00", "1996-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Hazafon", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Hadarom", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1997409", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - USA (03): (ID) waterfowl", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1997409", "date": "2013-10-07 10:06:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - ISRAEL: SUSPECTED, WIDE-SCALE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 6 Oct 2013\nSource: Hachaklait Clinical Veterinary Services, Head Veterinarian's weekly report no 40 [in Hebrew, by subscription, trans. Mod.AS, summ., edited]\nhttp://www.hachaklait.org.il/showarticle.asp?recid=3305&catid=0\n\n\nBotulism in cattle\n------------------\nSince 29 Sep 2013, hundreds of clinical cases suspected to be botulism have been reported from 21 cattle farms in 17 (named) locations throughout Israel, distributed in Hazafon (North) and Hadarom (South) provinces. About 100 of the affected cattle have reportedly died or been euthanised. The disease affected mainly young animals, predominantly fattening calves. The source of intoxication/infection has been suspected to be poultry manure fed to the cattle. In several of the affected farms, a common source for the poultry manure was found, namely a company which specializes in the treatment and supply of poultry litter to the cattle industry. Farmers have been advised to discontinue at present deriving poultry litter for cattle feeding from the said source; investigations into the matter by the producer/distributor and by the State Veterinary Services have been initiated.\n\nThe farming industry and veterinary practitioners, countrywide, have been updated in detail about the events. Farmers have been encouraged to check the vaccination history of their stock with the recommended vaccine (against _Clostridium botulinum_ C and D) and to fill any gaps, following manufacturer's instructions.\n\nMaterials sampled from affected cattle are under investigation in the Kimron Veterinary Institute [KVI].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The preliminary suspicion of botulism, likely to be accurately suggested based on the typical symptomatology, is yet to be laboratory confirmed. According to a flowchart of botulism testing in the KVI, attached to the report above, it may take more than 7 days to confirm (or otherwise) _C. botulinum_/toxins in the tested material.\n\nOne of the etiologies for consideration when poultry litter is suspected as the cause of neuromuscular signs and death in cattle are ionophores; this may happen if the litter derived from poultry was recently treated with a ionophore [substance able to transport particular ions across a lipid membrane in a cell] coccidiostat [a chemical agent added to animal feed (as for poultry) that serves to retard the growth and reproduction of pathogenic coccidia so that disease is minimized and the host develops immunity], such as maduromycin. Cattle are highly susceptible to residues of this drug.\n\nBotulism in cattle, caused by recycled poultry litter, has been recorded from various industrialised countries in recent years.\n\nIn the UK, an ad hoc group of the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) looked into the matter following an increase in the incidence of bovine botulism associated primarily with exposure of livestock to poultry (broiler) litter. Their report (2006) is found at http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nThe Group assessed the risk to the public from food produced by herds affected by botulism and concluded that for disease associated with toxin types C and D, \"there should be no requirement to restrict sales of meat or milk from clinically healthy cattle from farms where there have been clinically suspected cases of botulism in cattle. In addition, there should be no requirement to restrict the slaughter of healthy cattle from herds where cases of confirmed or suspected botulism have occurred.\" (see ProMED-mail post 20120829.1271101).\n\nIsrael has witnessed several outbreaks of botulism in domestic ruminants throughout the years. In 1978, a major outbreak of botulism type D caused the deaths and emergency slaughter of more than 1000 animals, most of them dairy cattle. Spores of _C. botulinum_ type D spread to many farms from 2 central animal feed plants by recycled, non-sterilized poultry manure that included remains of avian cadavers. Subsequently, annual botulism vaccinations of cattle and of other vulnerable animals with a vaccine, including toxoids of _C. botulinum_ types C and D adsorbed onto aluminum hydroxide gel, have been introduced and are routinely voluntarily applied in most parts of the country. Sporadic cases involving unvaccinated animals (mainly young cows) have been reported to occur every year.\n\nThe feeding of milking cows, sheep, and goats with poultry manure has been officially banned since 1996, while feeding of all animals is prohibited during 15 days prior to slaughter.\n\nBotulism in animals is not reportable in Israel, or OIE-listed. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1z-1.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBotulism, bovine - Israel (03): (HZ) raw milk, type D, safety 20120829.1271101\nBotulism, bovine - Israel (02): (HZ) raw milk, type D 20120823.1259805\nBotulism, bovine - Israel: (HZ) raw milk, RFI 20120815.1245834\n2002\n----\nBotulism, cattle - Israel 20020618.4531\n.................................................arn/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-09-29 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "1978-03-15 00:00:00", "1996-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Hazafon", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Hadarom", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1988102", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, bovine - Israel: susp, wide-scale, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1988102", "date": "2013-10-07 10:06:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - ISRAEL: SUSPECTED, WIDE-SCALE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 6 Oct 2013\nSource: Hachaklait Clinical Veterinary Services, Head Veterinarian's weekly report no 40 [in Hebrew, by subscription, trans. In addition, there should be no requirement to restrict the slaughter of healthy cattle from herds where cases of confirmed or suspected botulism have occurred.\" (see ProMED-mail post 20120829.1271101).\n\nIsrael has witnessed several outbreaks of botulism in domestic ruminants throughout the years. USA (08): Alaskan smoked salmon, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1980337", "date": "2013-08-03 15:41:20", "main_text": "BOTULISM - NEW ZEALAND: WHEY CONCENTRATE, RISK, RECALL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 3 Aug 2013\nSource: One News [edited]\nhttp://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/botulism-alert-over-fonterra-infant-formula-sports-drinks-5525787\n\n\nSome Fonterra products used in infant formula and sports drinks may contain a bacterium that causes botulism, the company announced early today [3 Aug 2013]. Fonterra said that on Wednesday [31 Jul 2013] tests indicated the potential presence of a strain of Clostridium (_Clostridium botulinum_) in a whey concentrate sample, which can produce a potent neurotoxin that causes botulism.\n\nThe company said that it today [3 Aug 2013] had advised 8 of its customers of a \"quality issue\" involving 3 batches of a particular type of whey protein concentrate (WPC80) produced at a single New Zealand manufacturing site in May 2012. As a result, these customers are urgently investigating whether any of the affected product is in their supply chains. If need be, they will initiate consumer product recalls.\n\nThere have been no reports of any illness linked to consumption of the affected whey protein, Fonterra said in a statement. Dairy products such as fresh milk, yoghurt, cheese, spreads and UHT milk products are not affected, it said. Fonterra had initially identified a potential quality issue in March 2013, when a product tested positive for _Clostridium_. There are hundreds of different strains of _Clostridium_, the majority of which are harmless, the company said.\n\nProduct samples were put through intensive testing over the following months. On Wed 31 Jul 2013, tests indicated the potential presence of a strain (_Clostridium botulinum_) in a sample, which can cause botulism.\n\nThe particular whey protein concentrate concerned is used by Fonterra's customers in a range of products including infant formula, growing up milk powder and sports drinks, said Gary Romano, Managing Director, NZ Milk Products. \"For this reason, we immediately contacted our customers and the appropriate authorities so that any potentially affected product could be removed from the marketplace. We are working with our customers and will provide more information and updates as they become available,\" Mr Romano said.\n\nFonterra told a news conference today [3 Aug 2013] that investigations had isolated the cause of the contamination. A piece of pipe was not sterilized properly and was used during production of 3 batches. The piece of equipment was subsequently cleaned and further product tested was clear.\n\nThe organism is present in soils, and small amounts of dust accumulated in the pipe and triggered the contamination, the company said. Any consumer product recalls that may need to take place will be initiated by the respective food companies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated with the food products. Most of the food recalls (as in this case) are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_. This posting specifically mentions that _C. botulinum_ did contaminate the product. In the usual case of foodborne botulism, preformed toxin has been produced in the food which is ingested. In infant botulism, however, spores of the bacterium are ingested and germinate in the gut, producing toxin in vivo. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\n\n[It would have been helpful if the brand names of the contaminated products (infant formula and sports drinks) had been given, to alert consumers. These products have been in the marketplace for at least 6 months, and may still be on consumers' food storage shelves. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\n1997\n----\nBotulism - New Zealand 19970929.2054\n.................................................ll/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2012-05-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Botulism - New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1915818", "headline": "PRO> Botulism - New Zealand (04): whey concentrate, risk, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1915818", "date": "2013-08-03 15:41:20", "main_text": "BOTULISM - NEW ZEALAND: WHEY CONCENTRATE, RISK, RECALL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 3 Aug 2013\nSource: One News [edited]\nhttp://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/botulism-alert-over-fonterra-infant-formula-sports-drinks-5525787\n\n\nSome Fonterra products used in infant formula and sports drinks may contain a bacterium that causes botulism, the company announced early today [3 Aug 2013]. Fonterra said that on Wednesday [31 Jul 2013] tests indicated the potential presence of a strain of Clostridium (_Clostridium botulinum_) in a whey concentrate sample, which can produce a potent neurotoxin that causes botulism.\n\nThe company said that it today [3 Aug 2013] had advised 8 of its customers of a \"quality issue\" involving 3 batches of a particular type of whey protein concentrate (WPC80) produced at a single New Zealand manufacturing site in May 2012. As a result, these customers are urgently investigating whether any of the affected product is in their supply chains. If need be, they will initiate consumer product recalls.\n\nThere have been no reports of any illness linked to consumption of the affected whey protein, Fonterra said in a statement. Dairy products such as fresh milk, yoghurt, cheese, spreads and UHT milk products are not affected, it said. Fonterra had initially identified a potential quality issue in March 2013, when a product tested positive for _Clostridium_. There are hundreds of different strains of _Clostridium_, the majority of which are harmless, the company said.\n\nProduct samples were put through intensive testing over the following months. On Wed 31 Jul 2013, tests indicated the potential presence of a strain (_Clostridium botulinum_) in a sample, which can cause botulism.\n\nThe particular whey protein concentrate concerned is used by Fonterra's customers in a range of products including infant formula, growing up milk powder and sports drinks, said Gary Romano, Managing Director, NZ Milk Products. \"For this reason, we immediately contacted our customers and the appropriate authorities so that any potentially affected product could be removed from the marketplace. We are working with our customers and will provide more information and updates as they become available,\" Mr Romano said.\n\nFonterra told a news conference today [3 Aug 2013] that investigations had isolated the cause of the contamination. A piece of pipe was not sterilized properly and was used during production of 3 batches. The piece of equipment was subsequently cleaned and further product tested was clear.\n\nThe organism is present in soils, and small amounts of dust accumulated in the pipe and triggered the contamination, the company said. Any consumer product recalls that may need to take place will be initiated by the respective food companies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated with the food products. Most of the food recalls (as in this case) are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_. This posting specifically mentions that _C. botulinum_ did contaminate the product. In the usual case of foodborne botulism, preformed toxin has been produced in the food which is ingested. In infant botulism, however, spores of the bacterium are ingested and germinate in the gut, producing toxin in vivo. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\n\n[It would have been helpful if the brand names of the contaminated products (infant formula and sports drinks) had been given, to alert consumers. These products have been in the marketplace for at least 6 months, and may still be on consumers' food storage shelves. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\n1997\n----\nBotulism - New Zealand 19970929.2054\n.................................................ll/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2012-05-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Botulism - New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1915521", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - USA (02): (CA) waterfowl", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1915521", "date": "2013-08-03 15:41:20", "main_text": "BOTULISM - NEW ZEALAND: WHEY CONCENTRATE, RISK, RECALL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 3 Aug 2013\nSource: One News [edited]\nhttp://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/botulism-alert-over-fonterra-infant-formula-sports-drinks-5525787\n\n\nSome Fonterra products used in infant formula and sports drinks may contain a bacterium that causes botulism, the company announced early today [3 Aug 2013]. Fonterra said that on Wednesday [31 Jul 2013] tests indicated the potential presence of a strain of Clostridium (_Clostridium botulinum_) in a whey concentrate sample, which can produce a potent neurotoxin that causes botulism.\n\nThe company said that it today [3 Aug 2013] had advised 8 of its customers of a \"quality issue\" involving 3 batches of a particular type of whey protein concentrate (WPC80) produced at a single New Zealand manufacturing site in May 2012. As a result, these customers are urgently investigating whether any of the affected product is in their supply chains. If need be, they will initiate consumer product recalls.\n\nThere have been no reports of any illness linked to consumption of the affected whey protein, Fonterra said in a statement. Dairy products such as fresh milk, yoghurt, cheese, spreads and UHT milk products are not affected, it said. Fonterra had initially identified a potential quality issue in March 2013, when a product tested positive for _Clostridium_. There are hundreds of different strains of _Clostridium_, the majority of which are harmless, the company said.\n\nProduct samples were put through intensive testing over the following months. On Wed 31 Jul 2013, tests indicated the potential presence of a strain (_Clostridium botulinum_) in a sample, which can cause botulism.\n\nThe particular whey protein concentrate concerned is used by Fonterra's customers in a range of products including infant formula, growing up milk powder and sports drinks, said Gary Romano, Managing Director, NZ Milk Products. \"For this reason, we immediately contacted our customers and the appropriate authorities so that any potentially affected product could be removed from the marketplace. We are working with our customers and will provide more information and updates as they become available,\" Mr Romano said.\n\nFonterra told a news conference today [3 Aug 2013] that investigations had isolated the cause of the contamination. A piece of pipe was not sterilized properly and was used during production of 3 batches. The piece of equipment was subsequently cleaned and further product tested was clear.\n\nThe organism is present in soils, and small amounts of dust accumulated in the pipe and triggered the contamination, the company said. Any consumer product recalls that may need to take place will be initiated by the respective food companies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated with the food products. Most of the food recalls (as in this case) are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_. This posting specifically mentions that _C. botulinum_ did contaminate the product. In the usual case of foodborne botulism, preformed toxin has been produced in the food which is ingested. In infant botulism, however, spores of the bacterium are ingested and germinate in the gut, producing toxin in vivo. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\n\n[It would have been helpful if the brand names of the contaminated products (infant formula and sports drinks) had been given, to alert consumers. These products have been in the marketplace for at least 6 months, and may still be on consumers' food storage shelves. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\n1997\n----\nBotulism - New Zealand 19970929.2054\n.................................................ll/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2012-05-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Botulism - New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1910893", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - New Zealand (03): whey concentrate, risk", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1910893", "date": "2013-08-03 15:41:20", "main_text": "BOTULISM - NEW ZEALAND: WHEY CONCENTRATE, RISK, RECALL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 3 Aug 2013\nSource: One News [edited]\nhttp://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/botulism-alert-over-fonterra-infant-formula-sports-drinks-5525787\n\n\nSome Fonterra products used in infant formula and sports drinks may contain a bacterium that causes botulism, the company announced early today [3 Aug 2013]. Fonterra said that on Wednesday [31 Jul 2013] tests indicated the potential presence of a strain of Clostridium (_Clostridium botulinum_) in a whey concentrate sample, which can produce a potent neurotoxin that causes botulism.\n\nThe company said that it today [3 Aug 2013] had advised 8 of its customers of a \"quality issue\" involving 3 batches of a particular type of whey protein concentrate (WPC80) produced at a single New Zealand manufacturing site in May 2012. As a result, these customers are urgently investigating whether any of the affected product is in their supply chains. If need be, they will initiate consumer product recalls.\n\nThere have been no reports of any illness linked to consumption of the affected whey protein, Fonterra said in a statement. Dairy products such as fresh milk, yoghurt, cheese, spreads and UHT milk products are not affected, it said. Fonterra had initially identified a potential quality issue in March 2013, when a product tested positive for _Clostridium_. There are hundreds of different strains of _Clostridium_, the majority of which are harmless, the company said.\n\nProduct samples were put through intensive testing over the following months. On Wed 31 Jul 2013, tests indicated the potential presence of a strain (_Clostridium botulinum_) in a sample, which can cause botulism.\n\nThe particular whey protein concentrate concerned is used by Fonterra's customers in a range of products including infant formula, growing up milk powder and sports drinks, said Gary Romano, Managing Director, NZ Milk Products. \"For this reason, we immediately contacted our customers and the appropriate authorities so that any potentially affected product could be removed from the marketplace. We are working with our customers and will provide more information and updates as they become available,\" Mr Romano said.\n\nFonterra told a news conference today [3 Aug 2013] that investigations had isolated the cause of the contamination. A piece of pipe was not sterilized properly and was used during production of 3 batches. The piece of equipment was subsequently cleaned and further product tested was clear.\n\nThe organism is present in soils, and small amounts of dust accumulated in the pipe and triggered the contamination, the company said. Any consumer product recalls that may need to take place will be initiated by the respective food companies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated with the food products. Most of the food recalls (as in this case) are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_. This posting specifically mentions that _C. botulinum_ did contaminate the product. In the usual case of foodborne botulism, preformed toxin has been produced in the food which is ingested. These products have been in the marketplace for at least 6 months, and may still be on consumers' food storage shelves. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\n1997\n----\nBotulism - New Zealand 19970929.2054\n.................................................ll/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2012-05-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Botulism - New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1859319", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Infant botulism - USA (06): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1859319", "date": "2013-07-01 15:46:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (04): (WASHINGTON STATE) CONCENTRATED TEA, RISK, RECALL\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 28 Jun 2013\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Recalls, Market Withdrawals, & Safety Alerts [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm359139.htm\n\n\nHarmony Chai of Eastsound, Washington, is voluntarily recalling its Concentrated Black Spiced Chai and Decaffeinated Rooibos Chai because it may not be properly processed. Although Harmony Chai has received no complaints of illness related to the consumption of the recalled product, there is a potential hazard that can occur when tea beverages are inadequately processed. These batches have the potential to be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_, a bacterium which can cause life-threatening illness or death. Consumers are warned not to use the product even if it does not look or smell spoiled. Illness due to foodborne botulism is extremely rare. According to Washington State Department of Health, during the last 10 years, Communicable Disease Epidemiology (CDE) has received 0-2 reports of foodborne botulism each year.\n\nAll lots of the following products have been recalled:\n- concentrated Black Spiced Chai bottled in 22 oz (650 mL) amber glass UPC 0510501311 and 64 oz (1892.7 mL) amber glass jugs UPC 0510501301\n- decaffeinated Rooibos Chai bottled in 22 oz (624.25 mL) amber glass UPC 9450402431 and 64 oz (1892.7 mL) amber glass jugs UPC 0510501301\n\nConcentrated Black Spiced Chai and Decaffeinated Rooibos Chai were distributed through farmers markets, grocery stores, and cafes in Western Washington. Areas of distribution include the San Juan, Skagit, Snohomish, and King Counties.\n\nIt was discovered through Washington State Department of Agriculture (WSDA) testing of routine samples that the tea was not properly processed. Harmony Chai and WSDA are working together to determine the cause of this problem. Harmony Chai has not had any reported illnesses to date but consumers who have purchased Harmony Chai Concentrated Black Spiced Chai or Decaffeinated Rooibos Chai recently are urged to return it to the place of purchase for a full refund.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nIt should be noted that the FDA has recently approved the 1st heptavalent equine derived botulinum antiserum for the treatment of botulism disease http://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm345128.htm. - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/6dEe. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (03): juices, risk 20130511.1706074\nBotulism - USA (02): (CA) smoked fish, risk, recall 20130411.1638640\nBotulism - UK: (England) aquatic birds", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1856632", "date": "2013-07-01 15:46:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (04): (WASHINGTON STATE) CONCENTRATED TEA, RISK, RECALL\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 28 Jun 2013\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Recalls, Market Withdrawals, & Safety Alerts [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm359139.htm\n\n\nHarmony Chai of Eastsound, Washington, is voluntarily recalling its Concentrated Black Spiced Chai and Decaffeinated Rooibos Chai because it may not be properly processed. Although Harmony Chai has received no complaints of illness related to the consumption of the recalled product, there is a potential hazard that can occur when tea beverages are inadequately processed. These batches have the potential to be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_, a bacterium which can cause life-threatening illness or death. Consumers are warned not to use the product even if it does not look or smell spoiled. Illness due to foodborne botulism is extremely rare. According to Washington State Department of Health, during the last 10 years, Communicable Disease Epidemiology (CDE) has received 0-2 reports of foodborne botulism each year.\n\nAll lots of the following products have been recalled:\n- concentrated Black Spiced Chai bottled in 22 oz (650 mL) amber glass UPC 0510501311 and 64 oz (1892.7 mL) amber glass jugs UPC 0510501301\n- decaffeinated Rooibos Chai bottled in 22 oz (624.25 mL) amber glass UPC 9450402431 and 64 oz (1892.7 mL) amber glass jugs UPC 0510501301\n\nConcentrated Black Spiced Chai and Decaffeinated Rooibos Chai were distributed through farmers markets, grocery stores, and cafes in Western Washington. Areas of distribution include the San Juan, Skagit, Snohomish, and King Counties.\n\nIt was discovered through Washington State Department of Agriculture (WSDA) testing of routine samples that the tea was not properly processed. Harmony Chai and WSDA are working together to determine the cause of this problem. Harmony Chai has not had any reported illnesses to date but consumers who have purchased Harmony Chai Concentrated Black Spiced Chai or Decaffeinated Rooibos Chai recently are urged to return it to the place of purchase for a full refund.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nIt should be noted that the FDA has recently approved the 1st heptavalent equine derived botulinum antiserum for the treatment of botulism disease http://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm345128.htm. - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/6dEe. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (03): juices, risk 20130511.1706074\nBotulism - USA (02): (CA) smoked fish, risk, recall 20130411.1638640\nBotulism - USA (06): (New York City) tofu, 2012", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1805565", "date": "2013-07-01 15:46:51", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (04): (WASHINGTON STATE) CONCENTRATED TEA, RISK, RECALL\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 28 Jun 2013\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Recalls, Market Withdrawals, & Safety Alerts [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm359139.htm\n\n\nHarmony Chai of Eastsound, Washington, is voluntarily recalling its Concentrated Black Spiced Chai and Decaffeinated Rooibos Chai because it may not be properly processed. Although Harmony Chai has received no complaints of illness related to the consumption of the recalled product, there is a potential hazard that can occur when tea beverages are inadequately processed. These batches have the potential to be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_, a bacterium which can cause life-threatening illness or death. Consumers are warned not to use the product even if it does not look or smell spoiled. Illness due to foodborne botulism is extremely rare. According to Washington State Department of Health, during the last 10 years, Communicable Disease Epidemiology (CDE) has received 0-2 reports of foodborne botulism each year.\n\nAll lots of the following products have been recalled:\n- concentrated Black Spiced Chai bottled in 22 oz (650 mL) amber glass UPC 0510501311 and 64 oz (1892.7 mL) amber glass jugs UPC 0510501301\n- decaffeinated Rooibos Chai bottled in 22 oz (624.25 mL) amber glass UPC 9450402431 and 64 oz (1892.7 mL) amber glass jugs UPC 0510501301\n\nConcentrated Black Spiced Chai and Decaffeinated Rooibos Chai were distributed through farmers markets, grocery stores, and cafes in Western Washington. Areas of distribution include the San Juan, Skagit, Snohomish, and King Counties.\n\nIt was discovered through Washington State Department of Agriculture (WSDA) testing of routine samples that the tea was not properly processed. Harmony Chai and WSDA are working together to determine the cause of this problem. Harmony Chai has not had any reported illnesses to date but consumers who have purchased Harmony Chai Concentrated Black Spiced Chai or Decaffeinated Rooibos Chai recently are urged to return it to the place of purchase for a full refund.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nIt should be noted that the FDA has recently approved the 1st heptavalent equine derived botulinum antiserum for the treatment of botulism disease http://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm345128.htm. - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of Washington can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/6dEe. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/washington.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (03): juices, risk 20130511.1706074\nBotulism - USA (02): (CA) smoked fish, risk, recall 20130411.1638640\nBotulism - Australia: (NT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1794268", "date": "2013-04-11 15:54:54", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (03): JARRED LOBSTER MEAT, RISK, RECALL\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Apr 2013\nSource: CBC (Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/story/2013/04/08/nb-jar-lobster-recall.html\n\n\nJars of lobster meat produced in New Brunswick and sold nationally have been recalled over concerns they may contain a toxin-producing bacteria, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency [CFIA] is warning.\n\nThe 285 gram bottles of lobster from the St. Thomas Fish Market are the 2nd product from the company the CFIA has recalled in the last few weeks.\n\nThe company voluntarily complied with the recall after a routine CFIA inspection found that some of the seafood products may contain the bacteria. There have been no illnesses reported, the agency said.\n\nA total of 7 code lots of lobster have been recalled: 13921, 14021, 19121, 19521, 20221, 20521 and 20822. The UPC code for the cans is 0 81971 90072 8.\n\nIn March [2013], jars of bar clams produced at the Bouctouche facility were recalled because there was a chance the products contained _Clostridium botulinum_. Toxins produced by the bacteria can cause botulism, a life-threatening illness. Food contaminated with these bacteria might not look or smell spoiled.\n\nThe CFIA could not confirm the manufacture date of the recalled products, but a spokesperson for the agency said the recalled production lots go back a number of months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photo of the recalled product label can be seen at the source URL above.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1ALd.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Australia: (QL) duck, susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1745775", "date": "2013-04-11 15:54:54", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (03): JARRED LOBSTER MEAT, RISK, RECALL\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Apr 2013\nSource: CBC (Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/story/2013/04/08/nb-jar-lobster-recall.html\n\n\nJars of lobster meat produced in New Brunswick and sold nationally have been recalled over concerns they may contain a toxin-producing bacteria, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency [CFIA] is warning.\n\nThe 285 gram bottles of lobster from the St. Thomas Fish Market are the 2nd product from the company the CFIA has recalled in the last few weeks.\n\nThe company voluntarily complied with the recall after a routine CFIA inspection found that some of the seafood products may contain the bacteria. There have been no illnesses reported, the agency said.\n\nA total of 7 code lots of lobster have been recalled: 13921, 14021, 19121, 19521, 20221, 20521 and 20822. The UPC code for the cans is 0 81971 90072 8.\n\nIn March [2013], jars of bar clams produced at the Bouctouche facility were recalled because there was a chance the products contained _Clostridium botulinum_. Toxins produced by the bacteria can cause botulism, a life-threatening illness. Food contaminated with these bacteria might not look or smell spoiled.\n\nThe CFIA could not confirm the manufacture date of the recalled products, but a spokesperson for the agency said the recalled production lots go back a number of months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photo of the recalled product label can be seen at the source URL above.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1ALd.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - There have been no illnesses reported, the agency said.\n\nA total of 7 code lots of lobster have been recalled: 13921, 14021, 19121, 19521, 20221, 20521 and 20822. The UPC code for the cans is 0 81971 90072 8.\n\nIn March [2013], jars of bar clams produced at the Bouctouche facility were recalled because there was a chance the products contained _Clostridium botulinum_. Toxins produced by the bacteria can cause botulism, a life-threatening illness. Food contaminated with these bacteria might not look or smell spoiled.\n\nThe CFIA could not confirm the manufacture date of the recalled products, but a spokesperson for the agency said the recalled production lots go back a number of months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photo of the recalled product label can be seen at the source URL above.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. USA (03): juices, risk", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1706074", "date": "2013-04-11 15:54:54", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (03): JARRED LOBSTER MEAT, RISK, RECALL\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Apr 2013\nSource: CBC (Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/story/2013/04/08/nb-jar-lobster-recall.html\n\n\nJars of lobster meat produced in New Brunswick and sold nationally have been recalled over concerns they may contain a toxin-producing bacteria, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency [CFIA] is warning.\n\nThe 285 gram bottles of lobster from the St. Thomas Fish Market are the 2nd product from the company the CFIA has recalled in the last few weeks.\n\nThe company voluntarily complied with the recall after a routine CFIA inspection found that some of the seafood products may contain the bacteria. There have been no illnesses reported, the agency said.\n\nA total of 7 code lots of lobster have been recalled: 13921, 14021, 19121, 19521, 20221, 20521 and 20822. The UPC code for the cans is 0 81971 90072 8.\n\nIn March [2013], jars of bar clams produced at the Bouctouche facility were recalled because there was a chance the products contained _Clostridium botulinum_. Toxins produced by the bacteria can cause botulism, a life-threatening illness. Food contaminated with these bacteria might not look or smell spoiled.\n\nThe CFIA could not confirm the manufacture date of the recalled products, but a spokesperson for the agency said the recalled production lots go back a number of months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photo of the recalled product label can be seen at the source URL above.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1ALd.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (04): comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1686628", "date": "2013-04-11 15:54:54", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA (03): JARRED LOBSTER MEAT, RISK, RECALL\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Apr 2013\nSource: CBC (Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/story/2013/04/08/nb-jar-lobster-recall.html\n\n\nJars of lobster meat produced in New Brunswick and sold nationally have been recalled over concerns they may contain a toxin-producing bacteria, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency [CFIA] is warning.\n\nThe 285 gram bottles of lobster from the St. Thomas Fish Market are the 2nd product from the company the CFIA has recalled in the last few weeks.\n\nThe company voluntarily complied with the recall after a routine CFIA inspection found that some of the seafood products may contain the bacteria. There have been no illnesses reported, the agency said.\n\nA total of 7 code lots of lobster have been recalled: 13921, 14021, 19121, 19521, 20221, 20521 and 20822. The UPC code for the cans is 0 81971 90072 8.\n\nIn March [2013], jars of bar clams produced at the Bouctouche facility were recalled because there was a chance the products contained _Clostridium botulinum_. Toxins produced by the bacteria can cause botulism, a life-threatening illness. Food contaminated with these bacteria might not look or smell spoiled.\n\nThe CFIA could not confirm the manufacture date of the recalled products, but a spokesperson for the agency said the recalled production lots go back a number of months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photo of the recalled product label can be seen at the source URL above.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1ALd.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - There have been no illnesses reported, the agency said.\n\nA total of 7 code lots of lobster have been recalled: 13921, 14021, 19121, 19521, 20221, 20521 and 20822. The UPC code for the cans is 0 81971 90072 8.\n\nIn March [2013], jars of bar clams produced at the Bouctouche facility were recalled because there was a chance the products contained _Clostridium botulinum_. Toxins produced by the bacteria can cause botulism, a life-threatening illness. Food contaminated with these bacteria might not look or smell spoiled.\n\nThe CFIA could not confirm the manufacture date of the recalled products, but a spokesperson for the agency said the recalled production lots go back a number of months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photo of the recalled product label can be seen at the source URL above.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. There have been no illnesses reported, the agency said.\n\nA total of 7 code lots of lobster have been recalled: 13921, 14021, 19121, 19521, 20221, 20521 and 20822. The UPC code for the cans is 0 81971 90072 8.\n\nIn March [2013], jars of bar clams produced at the Bouctouche facility were recalled because there was a chance the products contained _Clostridium botulinum_. Toxins produced by the bacteria can cause botulism, a life-threatening illness. Food contaminated with these bacteria might not look or smell spoiled.\n\nThe CFIA could not confirm the manufacture date of the recalled products, but a spokesperson for the agency said the recalled production lots go back a number of months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photo of the recalled product label can be seen at the source URL above.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. There have been no illnesses reported, the agency said.\n\nA total of 7 code lots of lobster have been recalled: 13921, 14021, 19121, 19521, 20221, 20521 and 20822. The UPC code for the cans is 0 81971 90072 8.\n\nIn March [2013], jars of bar clams produced at the Bouctouche facility were recalled because there was a chance the products contained _Clostridium botulinum_. Toxins produced by the bacteria can cause botulism, a life-threatening illness. Food contaminated with these bacteria might not look or smell spoiled.\n\nThe CFIA could not confirm the manufacture date of the recalled products, but a spokesperson for the agency said the recalled production lots go back a number of months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photo of the recalled product label can be seen at the source URL above.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products.
