"2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Brunswick", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "ON , QC", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1638640", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - USA (02): (CA) smoked fish, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1638640", "date": "2013-02-13 18:20:47", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN, FISH - AUSTRALIA (03): (NEW SOUTH WALES) DUCKS\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Feb 2013\nSource: South Coast Register [edited]\nhttp://www.southcoastregister.com.au/story/1287988/botulism-caused-duck-deaths/?cs=203\n\n\nTests have confirmed that botulism caused the death of more than 200 wild ducks on 2 ponds in Nowra.\n\nDuring December [2012] and January [2013] wild ducks were found dead or dying on the ponds in Harry Sawkins and Marriott Parks.\n\nTesting by the Environment Protection Authority ruled out chemical poisoning, with the Cumberland Livestock Health and Pest Authority discovering the birds had died from botulism.\n\nLHPA [Livestock Health and Pest Authorities] senior district veterinarian, Dr Keith Hart, said botulism is a paralytic disease which is difficult to diagnose. \"It is caused by the ingestion of a toxin, in this case created through a combination of low water levels and warm temperatures,\" he said.\n\n\"Several dead and dying ducks and a dying seagull were examined,\" he said, adding that botulism was a difficult disease to identify.\n\n\"Swabs were also taken to exclude virulent avian influenza -- a potentially serious viral disease that could show up initially as water bird mortalities on or near the coast.\n\n\"My diagnosis has been based on the history and clinical signs exhibited by the sick birds examined and described by council staff, and the fact that botulism is a fairly common cause of waterbird deaths under these conditions.\"\n\nDr Hart says while the recent rainfall and cooler weather will assist in flushing out the toxins, people should stay away from any duck carcasses. \"It is important that the public don't touch duck carcasses or allow dogs to touch them,\" he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the text, is not entirely clear whether botulism was confirmed by laboratory tests, or if the diagnosis was based on a presumption after other possible causes have been ruled out\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Spores of these bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.\n\nFrom the NWHC (USGS National Wildlife Health Center) field manual (Chapter 38):\n\"A presumptive diagnosis of avian botulism is often based on a combination of signs observed in sick birds and the absence of obvious lesions of disease when the internal organs and tissues of sick and dead birds are examined. However, this initial diagnosis must be confirmed by the mouse-protection or ELISA test to separate avian botulism from algal poisoning, castorbean poisoning, and other toxic processes that cause similar signs of disease.\" (...) \"The most widely used test for avian botulism is the mouse-protection test, although an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for type C toxin has been developed recently\".\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5mhm. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian, fish - Australia (02): (NS) 20130127.1517277\nBotulism, avian, fish - Australia: (QL) 20130124.1512183\n2012\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (09): (MI) aquatic birds, susp. 20121024.1360129\nBotulism, avian - USA (08): (WI, OR) aquatic birds 20120925.1309132\nBotulism, avian - USA (07): (MI) aquatic birds 20120912.1290085\nBotulism, avian - USA (06): (MD) aquatic birds 20120829.1271009\nBotulism, avian - USA (05): (WY) pheasants 20120824.1262052\nBotulism, avian - USA (04): (CA) waterfowl, susp. 20120802.1225667\nBotulism, avian - USA (03): (OH) waterfowl, susp 20120706.1192230\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): (HI) 20120624.1178706\nBotulism, avian - USA: (CA) 20120430.1117985\nBotulism, avian - New Zealand: (CB) susp 20120213.1040575\n2011\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA: (CO) 20110914.2797\n2010\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (05): (FL) susp. 20100817.2848\nUndiagnosed die-off, avian - USA (08): (CA) botulism susp. 20110923.2878\n.................................................sb/pmb/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "BOTULISM, AVIAN, FISH - AUSTRALIA (03): (NEW SOUTH WALES) DUCKS\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Feb 2013\nSource: South Coast Register [edited]\nhttp://www.southcoastregister.com.au/story/1287988/botulism-caused-duck-deaths/?cs=203\n\n\nTests have confirmed that botulism caused the death of more than 200 wild ducks on 2 ponds in Nowra.\n\nDuring December [2012] and January [2013] wild ducks were found dead or dying on the ponds in Harry Sawkins and Marriott Parks.\n\nTesting by the Environment Protection Authority ruled out chemical poisoning, with the Cumberland Livestock Health and Pest Authority discovering the birds had died from botulism.\n\nLHPA [Livestock Health and Pest Authorities] senior district veterinarian, Dr Keith Hart, said botulism is a paralytic disease which is difficult to diagnose. \"It is caused by the ingestion of a toxin, in this case created through a combination of low water levels and warm temperatures,\" he said.\n\n\"Several dead and dying ducks and a dying seagull were examined,\" he said, adding that botulism was a difficult disease to identify.\n\n\"Swabs were also taken to exclude virulent avian influenza -- a potentially serious viral disease that could show up initially as water bird mortalities on or near the coast.\n\n\"My diagnosis has been based on the history and clinical signs exhibited by the sick birds examined and described by council staff, and the fact that botulism is a fairly common cause of waterbird deaths under these conditions.\"\n\nDr Hart says while the recent rainfall and cooler weather will assist in flushing out the toxins, people should stay away from any duck carcasses. \"It is important that the public don't touch duck carcasses or allow dogs to touch them,\" he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the text, is not entirely clear whether botulism was confirmed by laboratory tests, or if the diagnosis was based on a presumption after other possible causes have been ruled out\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Spores of these bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.\n\nFrom the NWHC (USGS National Wildlife Health Center) field manual (Chapter 38):\n\"A presumptive diagnosis of avian botulism is often based on a combination of signs observed in sick birds and the absence of obvious lesions of disease when the internal organs and tissues of sick and dead birds are examined. However, this initial diagnosis must be confirmed by the mouse-protection or ELISA test to separate avian botulism from algal poisoning, castorbean poisoning, and other toxic processes that cause similar signs of disease.\" (...) \"The most widely used test for avian botulism is the mouse-protection test, although an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for type C toxin has been developed recently\".\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5mhm. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian, fish - Australia (02): (NS) 20130127.1517277\nBotulism, avian, fish - "BOTULISM, AVIAN, FISH - AUSTRALIA (03): (NEW SOUTH WALES) DUCKS\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a Nowra.\n\nDuring December [2012] and January [2013] wild ducks were found dead or dying on the ponds in Harry Sawkins and Marriott Parks.\n\nTesting by the Environment Protection Authority ruled out chemical poisoning, with the Cumberland Livestock Health and Pest Authority discovering the birds had died from botulism.\n\nLHPA [Livestock Health and Pest Authorities] senior district veterinarian, Dr Keith Hart, said botulism is a paralytic disease which is difficult to diagnose. \"It is caused by the ingestion of a toxin, in this case created through a combination of low water levels and warm temperatures,\" he said.\n\n\"Several dead and dying ducks and a dying seagull were examined,\" he said, adding that botulism was a difficult disease to identify.\n\n\"Swabs were also taken to exclude virulent avian influenza -- a potentially serious viral disease that could show up initially as water bird mortalities on or near the coast.\n\n\"My diagnosis has been based on the history and clinical signs exhibited by the sick birds examined and described by council staff, and the fact that botulism is a fairly common cause of waterbird deaths under these conditions.\"\n\nDr Hart says while the recent rainfall and cooler weather will assist in flushing out the toxins, people should stay away from any duck carcasses. \"It is important that the public don't touch duck carcasses or allow dogs to touch them,\" he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the text, is not entirely clear whether botulism was confirmed by laboratory tests, or if the diagnosis was based on a presumption after other possible causes have been ruled out\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Spores of these bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.\n\nFrom the NWHC (USGS National Wildlife Health Center) field manual (Chapter 38):\n\"A presumptive diagnosis of avian botulism is often based on a combination of signs observed in sick birds and the absence of obvious lesions of disease when the internal organs and tissues of sick and dead birds are examined. However, this initial diagnosis must be confirmed by the mouse-protection or ELISA test to separate avian botulism from algal poisoning, castorbean poisoning, and other toxic processes that cause similar signs of disease.\" (...) \"The most widely used test for avian botulism is the mouse-protection test, although an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for type C toxin has been developed recently\".\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5mhm. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian, fish - Australia (02): (NS) 20130127.1517277\nBotulism, avian, fish - "BOTULISM, AVIAN, FISH - AUSTRALIA (03): (NEW SOUTH WALES) DUCKS\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Feb 2013\nSource: South Coast Register [edited]\nhttp://www.southcoastregister.com.au/story/1287988/botulism-caused-duck-deaths/?cs=203\n\n\nTests have confirmed that botulism caused the death of more than 200 wild ducks on 2 ponds in Nowra.\n\nDuring December [2012] and January [2013] wild ducks were found dead or dying on the ponds in Harry Sawkins and Marriott Parks.\n\nTesting by the Environment Protection Authority ruled out chemical poisoning, with the Cumberland Livestock Health and Pest Authority discovering the birds had died from botulism.\n\nLHPA [Livestock Health and Pest Authorities] senior district veterinarian, Dr Keith Hart, said botulism is a paralytic disease which is difficult to diagnose. \"It is caused by the ingestion of a toxin, in this case created through a combination of low water levels and warm temperatures,\" he said.\n\n\"Several dead and dying ducks and a dying seagull were examined,\" he said, adding that botulism was a difficult disease to identify.\n\n\"Swabs were also taken to exclude virulent avian influenza -- a potentially serious viral disease that could show up initially as water bird mortalities on or near the coast.\n\n\"My diagnosis has been based on the history and clinical signs exhibited by the sick birds examined and described by council staff, and the fact that botulism is a fairly common cause of waterbird deaths under these conditions.\"\n\nDr Hart says while the recent rainfall and cooler weather will assist in flushing out the toxins, people should stay away from any duck carcasses. \"It is important that the public don't touch duck carcasses or allow dogs to touch them,\" he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the text, is not entirely clear whether botulism was confirmed by laboratory tests, or if the diagnosis was based on a presumption after other possible causes have been ruled out\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Spores of these bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.\n\nFrom the NWHC (USGS National Wildlife Health Center) field manual (Chapter 38):\n\"A presumptive diagnosis of avian botulism is often based on a combination of signs observed in sick birds and the absence of obvious lesions of disease when the internal organs and tissues of sick and dead birds are examined. However, this initial diagnosis must be confirmed by the mouse-protection or ELISA test to separate avian botulism from algal poisoning, castorbean poisoning, and other toxic processes that cause similar signs of disease.\" (...) \"The most widely used test for avian botulism is the mouse-protection test, although an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for type C toxin has been developed recently\".\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5mhm. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian, fish - Australia (02): (NS) 20130127.1517277\nBotulism, avian, fish - {"archive_id": "1590119", "headline": "PRO> Botulism - Argentina (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1590119", "date": "2013-02-13 18:20:47", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN, FISH - AUSTRALIA (03): (NEW SOUTH WALES) DUCKS\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Feb 2013\nSource: South Coast Register [edited]\nhttp://www.southcoastregister.com.au/story/1287988/botulism-caused-duck-deaths/?cs=203\n\n\nTests have confirmed that botulism caused the death of more than 200 wild ducks on 2 ponds in Nowra.\n\nDuring December [2012] and January [2013] wild ducks were found dead or dying on the ponds in Harry Sawkins and Marriott Parks.\n\nTesting by the Environment Protection Authority ruled out chemical poisoning, with the Cumberland Livestock Health and Pest Authority discovering the birds had died from botulism.\n\nLHPA [Livestock Health and Pest Authorities] senior district veterinarian, Dr Keith Hart, said botulism is a paralytic disease which is difficult to diagnose. \"It is caused by the ingestion of a toxin, in this case created through a combination of low water levels and warm temperatures,\" he said.\n\n\"Several dead and dying ducks and a dying seagull were examined,\" he said, adding that botulism was a difficult disease to identify.\n\n\"Swabs were also taken to exclude virulent avian influenza -- a potentially serious viral disease that could show up initially as water bird mortalities on or near the coast.\n\n\"My diagnosis has been based on the history and clinical signs exhibited by the sick birds examined and described by council staff, and the fact that botulism is a fairly common cause of waterbird deaths under these conditions.\"\n\nDr Hart says while the recent rainfall and cooler weather will assist in flushing out the toxins, people should stay away from any duck carcasses. \"It is important that the public don't touch duck carcasses or allow dogs to touch them,\" he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the text, is not entirely clear whether botulism was confirmed by laboratory tests, or if the diagnosis was based on a presumption after other possible causes have been ruled out\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Spores of these bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.\n\nFrom the NWHC (USGS National Wildlife Health Center) field manual (Chapter 38):\n\"A presumptive diagnosis of avian botulism is often based on a combination of signs observed in sick birds and the absence of obvious lesions of disease when the internal organs and tissues of sick and dead birds are examined. However, this initial diagnosis must be confirmed by the mouse-protection or ELISA test to separate avian botulism from algal poisoning, castorbean poisoning, and other toxic processes that cause similar signs of disease.\" (...) \"The most widely used test for avian botulism is the mouse-protection test, although an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for type C toxin has been developed recently\".\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5mhm. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian, fish - Australia (02): (NS) 20130127.1517277\nBotulism, avian, fish - {"archive_id": "1588524", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Argentina: (MZ) canned food", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1588524", "date": "2013-02-13 18:20:47", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN, FISH - AUSTRALIA (03): (NEW SOUTH WALES) DUCKS\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Feb 2013\nSource: South Coast Register [edited]\nhttp://www.southcoastregister.com.au/story/1287988/botulism-caused-duck-deaths/?cs=203\n\n\nTests have confirmed that botulism caused the death of more than 200 wild ducks on 2 ponds in Nowra.\n\nDuring December [2012] and January [2013] wild ducks were found dead or dying on the ponds in Harry Sawkins and Marriott Parks.\n\nTesting by the Environment Protection Authority ruled out chemical poisoning, with the Cumberland Livestock Health and Pest Authority discovering the birds had died from botulism.\n\nLHPA [Livestock Health and Pest Authorities] senior district veterinarian, Dr Keith Hart, said botulism is a paralytic disease which is difficult to diagnose. \"It is caused by the ingestion of a toxin, in this case created through a combination of low water levels and warm temperatures,\" he said.\n\n\"Several dead and dying ducks and a dying seagull were examined,\" he said, adding that botulism was a difficult disease to identify.\n\n\"Swabs were also taken to exclude virulent avian influenza -- a potentially serious viral disease that could show up initially as water bird mortalities on or near the coast.\n\n\"My diagnosis has been based on the history and clinical signs exhibited by the sick birds examined and described by council staff, and the fact that botulism is a fairly common cause of waterbird deaths under these conditions.\"\n\nDr Hart says while the recent rainfall and cooler weather will assist in flushing out the toxins, people should stay away from any duck carcasses. \"It is important that the public don't touch duck carcasses or allow dogs to touch them,\" he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the text, is not entirely clear whether botulism was confirmed by laboratory tests, or if the diagnosis was based on a presumption after other possible causes have been ruled out\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Spores of these bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.\n\nFrom the NWHC (USGS National Wildlife Health Center) field manual (Chapter 38):\n\"A presumptive diagnosis of avian botulism is often based on a combination of signs observed in sick birds and the absence of obvious lesions of disease when the internal organs and tissues of sick and dead birds are examined. However, this initial diagnosis must be confirmed by the mouse-protection or ELISA test to separate avian botulism from algal poisoning, castorbean poisoning, and other toxic processes that cause similar signs of disease.\" (...) \"The most widely used test for avian botulism is the mouse-protection test, although an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for type C toxin has been developed recently\".\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5mhm. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian, fish - Australia (02): (NS) 20130127.1517277\nBotulism, avian, fish - "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN, FISH - AUSTRALIA (03): (NEW SOUTH WALES) DUCKS\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Feb 2013\nSource: South Coast Register [edited]\nhttp://www.southcoastregister.com.au/story/1287988/botulism-caused-duck-deaths/?cs=203\n\n\nTests have confirmed that botulism caused the death of more than 200 wild ducks on 2 ponds in Nowra.\n\nDuring December [2012] and January [2013] wild ducks were found dead or dying on the ponds in Harry Sawkins and Marriott Parks.\n\nTesting by the Environment Protection Authority ruled out chemical poisoning, with the Cumberland Livestock Health and Pest Authority discovering the birds had died from botulism.\n\nLHPA [Livestock Health and Pest Authorities] senior district veterinarian, Dr Keith Hart, said botulism is a paralytic disease which is difficult to diagnose. \"It is caused by the ingestion of a toxin, in this case created through a combination of low water levels and warm temperatures,\" he said.\n\n\"Several dead and dying ducks and a dying seagull were examined,\" he said, adding that botulism was a difficult disease to identify.\n\n\"Swabs were also taken to exclude virulent avian influenza -- a potentially serious viral disease that could show up initially as water bird mortalities on or near the coast.\n\n\"My diagnosis has been based on the history and clinical signs exhibited by the sick birds examined and described by council staff, and the fact that botulism is a fairly common cause of waterbird deaths under these conditions.\"\n\nDr Hart says while the recent rainfall and cooler weather will assist in flushing out the toxins, people should stay away from any duck carcasses. \"It is important that the public don't touch duck carcasses or allow dogs to touch them,\" he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the text, is not entirely clear whether botulism was confirmed by laboratory tests, or if the diagnosis was based on a presumption after other possible causes have been ruled out\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Spores of these bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.\n\nFrom the NWHC (USGS National Wildlife Health Center) field manual (Chapter 38):\n\"A presumptive diagnosis of avian botulism is often based on a combination of signs observed in sick birds and the absence of obvious lesions of disease when the internal organs and tissues of sick and dead birds are examined. However, this initial diagnosis must be confirmed by the mouse-protection or ELISA test to separate avian botulism from algal poisoning, castorbean poisoning, and other toxic processes that cause similar signs of disease.\" (...) \"The most widely used test for avian botulism is the mouse-protection test, although an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for type C toxin has been developed recently\".\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5mhm. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian, fish - Australia (02): (NS) 20130127.1517277\nBotulism, avian, fish - bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Spores of these bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. Armenia: home canned vegetable", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1531916", "date": "2012-12-15 15:28:14", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: (RHODE ISLAND) (16): MULTIPLE JARRED FOODS, RISK, RECALL\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Dec 2012\nSource: Providence (RI) Journal [edited]\nhttp://news.providencejournal.com/breaking-news/2012/12/farmstead-foods-recalls-cheeses-meats-jarred-vegetables-on-botulism-or-list.html\n\n\nA local artisan food shop is voluntarily recalling some of its products after an inspection by the Rhode Island Department of Health, but the company said it hasn't changed its production methods since it passed inspection in 2010.\n\nThe health department, on Fri 15 Dec 2012, advised consumers not to eat certain cheeses, meats and jarred vegetables produced by Farmstead Inc. and sold at a shop at 186 Wayland Ave., Providence, Rhode Island, and through <www.farmsteadinc.com>.\n\nHealth inspectors initiated an investigation after receiving a tip, the Health Department said, and no one has reported an illness associated with Farmstead foods. The recalled products, which include carrots, beets, eggplant, zucchini, pickles and tomato jam in 8- or 16-ounce jars and chicken liver mousse and pork rillettes in 4-ounce jars, all with a screw-on metal lid and without a production or date code, were produced without the required controls to prevent a toxin that causes botulism.\n\nAlso recalled are certain soft and semi-soft cheeses, raw milk cheeses, goat cheeses, and any cheeses that are labeled \"Keep Refrigerated\" that were sold at room temperature in the retail store.\n\nD'Artagnan salami (labeled \"Keep Refrigerated\") and prosciutto, salamis, liverwurst, and other meats processed at the store are also being recalled because they were improperly processed, the health department said.\n\nConsumers who have any of these recalled products at home should discard them or return them to the store, the health department said.\n\n[Byline: Donita Naylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1yvH.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Australia (02): (NS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1517277", "date": "2012-12-15 15:28:14", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: (RHODE ISLAND) (16): MULTIPLE JARRED FOODS, RISK, RECALL\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Dec 2012\nSource: Providence (RI) Journal [edited]\nhttp://news.providencejournal.com/breaking-news/2012/12/farmstead-foods-recalls-cheeses-meats-jarred-vegetables-on-botulism-or-list.html\n\n\nA local artisan food shop is voluntarily recalling some of its products after an inspection by the Rhode Island Department of Health, but the company said it hasn't changed its production methods since it passed inspection in 2010.\n\nThe health department, on Fri 15 Dec 2012, advised consumers not to eat certain cheeses, meats and jarred vegetables produced by Farmstead Inc. and sold at a shop at 186 Wayland Ave., Providence, Rhode Island, and through <www.farmsteadinc.com>.\n\nHealth inspectors initiated an investigation after receiving a tip, the Health Department said, and no one has reported an illness associated with Farmstead foods. The recalled products, which include carrots, beets, eggplant, zucchini, pickles and tomato jam in 8- or 16-ounce jars and chicken liver mousse and pork rillettes in 4-ounce jars, all with a screw-on metal lid and without a production or date code, were produced without the required controls to prevent a toxin that causes botulism.\n\nAlso recalled are certain soft and semi-soft cheeses, raw milk cheeses, goat cheeses, and any cheeses that are labeled \"Keep Refrigerated\" that were sold at room temperature in the retail store.\n\nD'Artagnan salami (labeled \"Keep Refrigerated\") and prosciutto, salamis, liverwurst, and other meats processed at the store are also being recalled because they were improperly processed, the health department said.\n\nConsumers who have any of these recalled products at home should discard them or return them to the store, the health department said.\n\n[Byline: Donita Naylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1yvH.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (18): salted duck eggs, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1466530", "date": "2012-12-15 15:28:14", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: (RHODE ISLAND) (16): MULTIPLE JARRED FOODS, RISK, RECALL\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Dec 2012\nSource: Providence (RI) Journal [edited]\nhttp://news.providencejournal.com/breaking-news/2012/12/farmstead-foods-recalls-cheeses-meats-jarred-vegetables-on-botulism-or-list.html\n\n\nA local artisan food shop is voluntarily recalling some of its products after an inspection by the Rhode Island Department of Health, but the company said it hasn't changed its production methods since it passed inspection in 2010.\n\nThe health department, on Fri 15 Dec 2012, advised consumers not to eat certain cheeses, meats and jarred vegetables produced by Farmstead Inc. and sold at a shop at 186 Wayland Ave., Providence, Rhode Island, and through <www.farmsteadinc.com>.\n\nHealth inspectors initiated an investigation after receiving a tip, the Health Department said, and no one has reported an illness associated with Farmstead foods. The recalled products, which include carrots, beets, eggplant, zucchini, pickles and tomato jam in 8- or 16-ounce jars and chicken liver mousse and pork rillettes in 4-ounce jars, all with a screw-on metal lid and without a production or date code, were produced without the required controls to prevent a toxin that causes botulism.\n\nAlso recalled are certain soft and semi-soft cheeses, raw milk cheeses, goat cheeses, and any cheeses that are labeled \"Keep Refrigerated\" that were sold at room temperature in the retail store.\n\nD'Artagnan salami (labeled \"Keep Refrigerated\") and prosciutto, salamis, liverwurst, and other meats processed at the store are also being recalled because they were improperly processed, the health department said.\n\nConsumers who have any of these recalled products at home should discard them or return them to the store, the health department said.\n\n[Byline: Donita Naylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1yvH.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Australia: (QL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1462935", "date": "2012-12-15 15:28:14", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: (RHODE ISLAND) (16): MULTIPLE JARRED FOODS, RISK, RECALL\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Dec 2012\nSource: Providence (RI) Journal [edited]\nhttp://news.providencejournal.com/breaking-news/2012/12/farmstead-foods-recalls-cheeses-meats-jarred-vegetables-on-botulism-or-list.html\n\n\nA local artisan food shop is voluntarily recalling some of its products after an inspection by the Rhode Island Department of Health, but the company said it hasn't changed its production methods since it passed inspection in 2010.\n\nThe health department, on Fri 15 Dec 2012, advised consumers not to eat certain cheeses, meats and jarred vegetables produced by Farmstead Inc. and sold at a shop at 186 Wayland Ave., Providence, Rhode Island, and through <www.farmsteadinc.com>.\n\nHealth inspectors initiated an investigation after receiving a tip, the Health Department said, and no one has reported an illness associated with Farmstead foods. The recalled products, which include carrots, beets, eggplant, zucchini, pickles and tomato jam in 8- or 16-ounce jars and chicken liver mousse and pork rillettes in 4-ounce jars, all with a screw-on metal lid and without a production or date code, were produced without the required controls to prevent a toxin that causes botulism.\n\nAlso recalled are certain soft and semi-soft cheeses, raw milk cheeses, goat cheeses, and any cheeses that are labeled \"Keep Refrigerated\" that were sold at room temperature in the retail store.\n\nD'Artagnan salami (labeled \"Keep Refrigerated\") and prosciutto, salamis, liverwurst, and other meats processed at the store are also being recalled because they were improperly processed, the health department said.\n\nConsumers who have any of these recalled products at home should discard them or return them to the store, the health department said.\n\n[Byline: Donita Naylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1yvH.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (16): (RI) multiple jarred foods, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1453660", "date": "2012-12-15 15:28:14", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: (RHODE ISLAND) (16): MULTIPLE JARRED FOODS, RISK, RECALL\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Dec 2012\nSource: Providence (RI) Journal [edited]\nhttp://news.providencejournal.com/breaking-news/2012/12/farmstead-foods-recalls-cheeses-meats-jarred-vegetables-on-botulism-or-list.html\n\n\nA local artisan food shop is voluntarily recalling some of its products after an inspection by the Rhode Island Department of Health, but the company said it hasn't changed its production methods since it passed inspection in 2010.\n\nThe health department, on Fri 15 Dec 2012, advised consumers not to eat certain cheeses, meats and jarred vegetables produced by Farmstead Inc. and sold at a shop at 186 Wayland Ave., Providence, Rhode Island, and through <www.farmsteadinc.com>.\n\nHealth inspectors initiated an investigation after receiving a tip, the Health Department said, and no one has reported an illness associated with Farmstead foods. The recalled products, which include carrots, beets, eggplant, zucchini, pickles and tomato jam in 8- or 16-ounce jars and chicken liver mousse and pork rillettes in 4-ounce jars, all with a screw-on metal lid and without a production or date code, were produced without the required controls to prevent a toxin that causes botulism.\n\nAlso recalled are certain soft and semi-soft cheeses, raw milk cheeses, goat cheeses, and any cheeses that are labeled \"Keep Refrigerated\" that were sold at room temperature in the retail store.\n\nD'Artagnan salami (labeled \"Keep Refrigerated\") and prosciutto, salamis, liverwurst, and other meats processed at the store are also being recalled because they were improperly processed, the health department said.\n\nConsumers who have any of these recalled products at home should discard them or return them to the store, the health department said.\n\n[Byline: Donita Naylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1yvH.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (15): (CA) jarred beans, salsa, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1451996", "date": "2012-08-29 15:33:10", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - ISRAEL (03): (HAZAFON) RAW MILK, TYPE D, SAFETY\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 29 Aug 2012\nFrom: Robert Hogg <Robert.Hogg@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Botulism, bovine - Israel (02): (HZ) raw milk, type D, archived 20120823.1259805\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAn ad hoc group of the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) looked into this matter following an increase in the incidence of bovine botulism in the UK associated primarily with exposure of livestock to poultry (broiler) litter.\n\nReaders interested in this matter are directed to the ACMSF report (2006) which can be found at http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nThe Group assessed the risk to the public from food produced by herds affected by botulism and concluded that for disease associated with toxin types C and D, \"there should be no requirement to restrict sales of meat or milk from clinically healthy cattle from farms where there have been clinically suspected cases of botulism in cattle. In addition, there should be no requirement to restrict the slaughter of healthy cattle from herds where cases of confirmed or suspected botulism have occurred.\"\n\n--\nRobert Hogg BVSc, MVSc, MRCVS\nVeterinary Investigation Officer (Botulism Disease Consultant)\nAnimal Health and Veterinary Laboratories Agency (AHVLA)\nBarton Hall, Garstang Road, Barton Preston\nUK PR3 5HE\n<Robert.Hogg@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk>\n\n[We are very grateful for the authoritative information above, which addresses ProMED-mail's call for discussion (posting 20120823.1259805).\n\nFor details of the event, subscribers are referred to the 2 referenced previous postings in the thread.\n\nThe ACMSF report on botulism in cattle (2006) was presented and discussed in ProMED-mail posting 20061208.3463. - Israel (02): (HZ) raw milk, type D, archived 20120823.1259805\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAn ad hoc group of the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) looked into this matter following an increase in the incidence of bovine botulism in the UK associated primarily with exposure of livestock to poultry (broiler) litter.\n\nReaders interested in this matter are directed to the ACMSF report (2006) which can be found at http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nThe Group assessed the risk to the public from food produced by herds affected by botulism and concluded that for disease associated with toxin types C and D, \"there should be no requirement to restrict sales of meat or milk from clinically healthy cattle from farms where there have been clinically suspected cases of botulism in cattle. USA (09): (MI) aquatic birds, susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1360129", "date": "2012-08-29 15:33:10", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - ISRAEL (03): (HAZAFON) RAW MILK, TYPE D, SAFETY\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 29 Aug 2012\nFrom: Robert Hogg <Robert.Hogg@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Botulism, bovine - Israel (02): (HZ) raw milk, type D, archived 20120823.1259805\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAn ad hoc group of the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) looked into this matter following an increase in the incidence of bovine botulism in the UK associated primarily with exposure of livestock to poultry (broiler) litter.\n\nReaders interested in this matter are directed to the ACMSF report (2006) which can be found at http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nThe Group assessed the risk to the public from food produced by herds affected by botulism and concluded that for disease associated with toxin types C and D, \"there should be no requirement to restrict sales of meat or milk from clinically healthy cattle from farms where there have been clinically suspected cases of botulism in cattle. In addition, there should be no requirement to restrict the slaughter of healthy cattle from herds where cases of confirmed or suspected botulism have occurred.\"\n\n--\nRobert Hogg BVSc, MVSc, MRCVS\nVeterinary Investigation Officer (Botulism Disease Consultant)\nAnimal Health and Veterinary Laboratories Agency (AHVLA)\nBarton Hall, Garstang Road, Barton Preston\nUK PR3 5HE\n<Robert.Hogg@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk>\n\n[We are very grateful for the authoritative information above, which addresses ProMED-mail's call for discussion (posting 20120823.1259805).\n\nFor details of the event, subscribers are referred to the 2 referenced previous postings in the thread.\n\nThe ACMSF report on botulism in cattle (2006) was presented and discussed in ProMED-mail posting 20061208.3463. - In addition, there should be no requirement to restrict the slaughter of healthy cattle from herds where cases of confirmed or suspected botulism have occurred.\"\n\n--\nRobert Hogg BVSc, MVSc, MRCVS\nVeterinary Investigation Officer (Botulism Disease Consultant)\nAnimal Health and Veterinary Laboratories Agency (AHVLA)\nBarton Hall, Garstang Road, Barton Preston\nUK PR3 5HE\n<Robert.Hogg@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk>\n\n[We are very grateful for the authoritative information above, which addresses ProMED-mail's call for discussion (posting 20120823.1259805).\n\nFor details of the event, subscribers are referred to the 2 referenced previous postings in the thread.\n\nThe ACMSF report on botulism in cattle (2006) was presented and discussed in ProMED-mail posting 20061208.3463. - Israel (02): (HZ) raw milk, type D, archived 20120823.1259805\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAn ad hoc group of the Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Safety of Food (ACMSF) looked into this matter following an increase in the incidence of bovine botulism in the UK associated primarily with exposure of livestock to poultry (broiler) litter.\n\nReaders interested in this matter are directed to the ACMSF report (2006) which can be found at http://www.food.gov.uk/multimedia/pdfs/botulismincattlereport1206.pdf.\n\nThe Group assessed the risk to the public from food produced by herds affected by botulism and concluded that for disease associated with toxin types C and D, \"there should be no requirement to restrict sales of meat or milk from clinically healthy cattle from farms where there have been clinically suspected cases of botulism in cattle. In addition, there should be no requirement to restrict the slaughter of healthy cattle from herds where cases of confirmed or suspected botulism have occurred.\"\n\n--\nRobert Hogg BVSc, MVSc, MRCVS\nVeterinary Investigation Officer (Botulism Disease Consultant)\nAnimal Health and Veterinary Laboratories Agency (AHVLA)\nBarton Hall, Garstang Road, Barton Preston\nUK PR3 5HE\n<Robert.Hogg@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk>\n\n[We are very grateful for the authoritative information above, which addresses ProMED-mail's call for discussion (posting 20120823.1259805).\n\nFor details of the event, subscribers are referred to the 2 referenced previous postings in the thread.\n\nThe ACMSF report on botulism in cattle (2006) was presented and discussed in ProMED-mail posting 20061208.3463. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBotulism, bovine - Israel (02): (HZ) raw milk, type D 20120823.1259805\nBotulism, bovine - Israel: (HZ) raw milk, RFI 20120815.1245834\n2006\n----\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\n.................................................arn/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1271009", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - USA (06): (MD) aquatic birds", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1271009", "date": "2012-08-08 10:56:38", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (11): (OREGON) HOME CANNED FOOD, BEETS\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Aug 2012\nSource: Kansas State University Bites [edited]\nhttp://bites.ksu.edu/sites/default/files/foodsafetyinfosheet-8-2-12.pdf\n\n\nThree attendees at a private gathering in Oregon were hospitalized in July 2012 after eating foods that contained botulism toxin. The ill individuals shared beets that had not been canned properly. The beets had been placed into jars, heated in a boiling water bath, and then stored at room temperature. The lack of oxygen, low-acid environment, and room temperature creates ideal conditions for _Clostridium botulinum_ spores to germinate and produce the toxin. While boiling water bath temperatures will kill many foodborne pathogens, _C. botulinum_ spores are tough and require higher heat to be inactivated. The only way to do this in a home kitchen is through the use of a pressure canner.\n\n- Low acid foods (pH greater than 4.6) like beets cannot be safely canned using a boiling water bath unless acidi\ufb01ed according to a tested recipe.\n- _Clostridium botulinum_ occur in soil and foods that come from the soil. After heating the spores can germinate into cells that create a toxin leading to botulism in oxygen-free environment (like canned foods).\n- A pint of beets needs to be processed for 30 min at 11 psi if using a dial gauge (or 10 psi using a weighted gauge) pressure canner at sea level.\n- Required pressure will increase at higher altitudes; time will increase for larger containers (quarts).\n- Consult the National Center for Home Food Preservation, http://www.uga.edu/nchfp/ for altitude adjustments and tested recipes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Low acid foods, such as olives and beets, are much more likely to be associated with canned food-associated botulism. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1fWb.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (10): (AZ) prison brew 20120808.1233534\nBotulism - USA (09): (OR) home canned food 20120703.1188516\nBotulism - USA (13): (PA) protein drinks, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1268024", "date": "2012-08-08 10:56:38", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (11): (OREGON) HOME CANNED FOOD, BEETS\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Aug 2012\nSource: Kansas State University Bites [edited]\nhttp://bites.ksu.edu/sites/default/files/foodsafetyinfosheet-8-2-12.pdf\n\n\nThree attendees at a private gathering in Oregon were hospitalized in July 2012 after eating foods that contained botulism toxin. The ill individuals shared beets that had not been canned properly. The beets had been placed into jars, heated in a boiling water bath, and then stored at room temperature. The lack of oxygen, low-acid environment, and room temperature creates ideal conditions for _Clostridium botulinum_ spores to germinate and produce the toxin. While boiling water bath temperatures will kill many foodborne pathogens, _C. botulinum_ spores are tough and require higher heat to be inactivated. The only way to do this in a home kitchen is through the use of a pressure canner.\n\n- Low acid foods (pH greater than 4.6) like beets cannot be safely canned using a boiling water bath unless acidi\ufb01ed according to a tested recipe.\n- _Clostridium botulinum_ occur in soil and foods that come from the soil. After heating the spores can germinate into cells that create a toxin leading to botulism in oxygen-free environment (like canned foods).\n- A pint of beets needs to be processed for 30 min at 11 psi if using a dial gauge (or 10 psi using a weighted gauge) pressure canner at sea level.\n- Required pressure will increase at higher altitudes; time will increase for larger containers (quarts).\n- Consult the National Center for Home Food Preservation, http://www.uga.edu/nchfp/ for altitude adjustments and tested recipes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Low acid foods, such as olives and beets, are much more likely to be associated with canned food-associated botulism. - The ill individuals shared beets that had not been canned properly. The beets had been placed into jars, heated in a boiling water bath, and then stored at room temperature. The lack of oxygen, low-acid environment, and room temperature creates ideal conditions for _Clostridium botulinum_ spores to germinate and produce the toxin. While boiling water bath temperatures will kill many foodborne pathogens, _C. botulinum_ spores are tough and require higher heat to be inactivated. The only way to do this in a home kitchen is through the use of a pressure canner.\n\n- Low acid foods (pH greater than 4.6) like beets cannot be safely canned using a boiling water bath unless acidi\ufb01ed according to a tested recipe.\n- _Clostridium botulinum_ occur in soil and foods that come from the soil. After heating the spores can germinate into cells that create a toxin leading to botulism in oxygen-free environment (like canned foods).\n- A pint of beets needs to be processed for 30 min at 11 psi if using a dial gauge (or 10 psi using a weighted gauge) pressure canner at sea level.\n- Required pressure will increase at higher altitudes; time will increase for larger containers (quarts).\n- Consult the National Center for Home Food Preservation, http://www.uga.edu/nchfp/ for altitude adjustments and tested recipes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Low acid foods, such as olives and beets, are much more likely to be associated with canned food-associated botulism. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1fWb.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (10): (AZ) prison brew 20120808.1233534\nBotulism - USA (09): (OR) home canned food 20120703.1188516\nBotulism - USA (12): (CA) spreads, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1257178", "date": "2012-08-08 10:56:38", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (11): (OREGON) HOME CANNED FOOD, BEETS\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Aug 2012\nSource: Kansas State University Bites [edited]\nhttp://bites.ksu.edu/sites/default/files/foodsafetyinfosheet-8-2-12.pdf\n\n\nThree attendees at a private gathering in Oregon were hospitalized in July 2012 after eating foods that contained botulism toxin. The ill individuals shared beets that had not been canned properly. The beets had been placed into jars, heated in a boiling water bath, and then stored at room temperature. The lack of oxygen, low-acid environment, and room temperature creates ideal conditions for _Clostridium botulinum_ spores to germinate and produce the toxin. While boiling water bath temperatures will kill many foodborne pathogens, _C. botulinum_ spores are tough and require higher heat to be inactivated. The only way to do this in a home kitchen is through the use of a pressure canner.\n\n- Low acid foods (pH greater than 4.6) like beets cannot be safely canned using a boiling water bath unless acidi\ufb01ed according to a tested recipe.\n- _Clostridium botulinum_ occur in soil and foods that come from the soil. After heating the spores can germinate into cells that create a toxin leading to botulism in oxygen-free environment (like canned foods).\n- A pint of beets needs to be processed for 30 min at 11 psi if using a dial gauge (or 10 psi using a weighted gauge) pressure canner at sea level.\n- Required pressure will increase at higher altitudes; time will increase for larger containers (quarts).\n- Consult the National Center for Home Food Preservation, http://www.uga.edu/nchfp/ for altitude adjustments and tested recipes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Low acid foods, such as olives and beets, are much more likely to be associated with canned food-associated botulism. - The lack of oxygen, low-acid environment, and room temperature creates ideal conditions for _Clostridium botulinum_ spores to germinate and produce the toxin. While boiling water bath temperatures will kill many foodborne pathogens, _C. botulinum_ spores are tough and require higher heat to be inactivated. The only way to do this in a home kitchen is through the use of a pressure canner.\n\n- Low acid foods (pH greater than 4.6) like beets cannot be safely canned using a boiling water bath unless acidi\ufb01ed according to a tested recipe.\n- _Clostridium botulinum_ occur in soil and foods that come from the soil. USA (10): (AZ) prison brew", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1233534", "date": "2012-06-12 16:11:57", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (07): (CALIFORNIA) JARRED SOUP, RISK, RECALL\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 11 Jun 2012\nSource: CBS [edited]\nhttp://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2012/06/11/2-brands-of-soup-sold-at-farmers-markets-may-contain-bacteria-causing-botulism/\n\n\nTwo brands of soup sold only at local farmers markets may have been improperly produced, exposing consumers to botulism. Dr Ron Chapman, of the state's Department of Public Health, says no illnesses have been linked to any of the affected products at this time.\n\nMalibu-based One Gun Ranch manufactured one of the brands of soups, which were only sold at the Pacific Palisades Farmers Market on 13 May 2012 and 3 Jun 2012. The affected soups include: Campfire Kitchen Cauliflower Soup, Heirloom Tomato Fennel Gazpacho Soup, Sequoia's Skinny Spiced Coconut, Parsnip and Turmeric Soup, Ossian's Pumpkin Stew, and Freddy's Firegrilled Meatballs, all sold in 16-ounce glass jars with screw-on metal lids.\n\nSanta Barbara-based Organic Soup Kitchen manufactured the following soups: Fire Roasted Yam, Curried Potato Leek, Curry Lentil Bisque, Tomato Bean and Wild Herb, and Mediterranean Chipotle Chili, which were packaged in one-quart glass jars with screw-on metal lids. These soups were sold at the Calabasas and Studio City Farmers markets on 6 Jun 2011 and 6 May 2012.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 2nd recall this month (June 2012) relating to botulism risk from soups sold at Farmers Markets in California.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated [yet] with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hcv.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - These soups were sold at the Calabasas and Studio City Farmers markets on 6 Jun 2011 and 6 May 2012.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 2nd recall this month (June 2012) relating to botulism risk from soups sold at Farmers Markets in California.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated [yet] with the food products. Dr Ron Chapman, of the state's Department of Public Health, says no illnesses have been linked to any of the affected products at this time.\n\nMalibu-based One Gun Ranch manufactured one of the brands of soups, which were only sold at the Pacific Palisades Farmers Market on 13 May 2012 and 3 Jun 2012. The affected soups include: Campfire Kitchen Cauliflower Soup, Heirloom Tomato Fennel Gazpacho Soup, Sequoia's Skinny Spiced Coconut, Parsnip and Turmeric Soup, Ossian's Pumpkin Stew, and Freddy's Firegrilled Meatballs, all sold in 16-ounce glass jars with screw-on metal lids.\n\nSanta Barbara-based Organic Soup Kitchen manufactured the following soups: Fire Roasted Yam, Curried Potato Leek, Curry Lentil Bisque, Tomato Bean and Wild Herb, and Mediterranean Chipotle Chili, which were packaged in one-quart glass jars with screw-on metal lids. These soups were sold at the Calabasas and Studio City Farmers markets on 6 Jun 2011 and 6 May 2012.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 2nd recall this month (June 2012) relating to botulism risk from soups sold at Farmers Markets in California.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated [yet] with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hcv.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (06): (CA) canned soup, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1153382", "date": "2012-04-20 23:34:03", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA: (ONTARIO), SALTED FISH, ALERT, RECALL\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Apr 2012\nSource: Canadian Food Inspection Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.marketwatch.com/story/cfiahealth-hazard-alert-lotus-fine-foods-whole-fesikh-mullet-salted-and-cured-fish-may-contain-dangerous-bacteria-2012-04-20\n\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) is warning the public not to consume the salted and cured fish product (fesikh) described below because it may be contaminated with spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. Toxins produced by this bacteria may cause botulism, a life-threatening illness.\n\nThe affected product, whole fesikh mullet, was sold in clear vacuum-packaged bags of varying count and weight, bearing no code or date information. This product was sold from Lotus Catering and Fine Food, 1960 Lawrence Ave. E, Toronto, ON, on or before 17 Apr 2012.\n\nThere have been 3 reported illnesses associated with the consumption of this product.\n\nFood contaminated with _C. botulinum_ toxin may not look or smell spoiled. Consumption of food contaminated with the toxin may cause nausea, vomiting, fatigue, dizziness, headache, double vision, dry throat, respiratory failure and paralysis. In severe cases of illness, people may die.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Many of the botulism risks related to salted, cured fish are a result of the fish not being adequately eviscerated. The viscera of the fish are the parts most likely to be contaminated. Although not stated, most cases of botulism associated with the aquatic environment are serotype E whereas most other cases in humans are either type A or B. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1tBo.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA: (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1117985", "date": "2012-04-20 23:34:03", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA: (ONTARIO), SALTED FISH, ALERT, RECALL\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Apr 2012\nSource: Canadian Food Inspection Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.marketwatch.com/story/cfiahealth-hazard-alert-lotus-fine-foods-whole-fesikh-mullet-salted-and-cured-fish-may-contain-dangerous-bacteria-2012-04-20\n\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) is warning the public not to consume the salted and cured fish product (fesikh) described below because it may be contaminated with spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. Toxins produced by this bacteria may cause botulism, a life-threatening illness.\n\nThe affected product, whole fesikh mullet, was sold in clear vacuum-packaged bags of varying count and weight, bearing no code or date information. This product was sold from Lotus Catering and Fine Food, 1960 Lawrence Ave. E, Toronto, ON, on or before 17 Apr 2012.\n\nThere have been 3 reported illnesses associated with the consumption of this product.\n\nFood contaminated with _C. botulinum_ toxin may not look or smell spoiled. Consumption of food contaminated with the toxin may cause nausea, vomiting, fatigue, dizziness, headache, double vision, dry throat, respiratory failure and paralysis. In severe cases of illness, people may die.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Many of the botulism risks related to salted, cured fish are a result of the fish not being adequately eviscerated. The viscera of the fish are the parts most likely to be contaminated. Although not stated, most cases of botulism associated with the aquatic environment are serotype E whereas most other cases in humans are either type A or B. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1tBo.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - India: (KA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1115055", "date": "2012-04-20 23:34:03", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA: (ONTARIO), SALTED FISH, ALERT, RECALL\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Apr 2012\nSource: Canadian Food Inspection Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.marketwatch.com/story/cfiahealth-hazard-alert-lotus-fine-foods-whole-fesikh-mullet-salted-and-cured-fish-may-contain-dangerous-bacteria-2012-04-20\n\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) is warning the public not to consume the salted and cured fish product (fesikh) described below because it may be contaminated with spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. Toxins produced by this bacteria may cause botulism, a life-threatening illness.\n\nThe affected product, whole fesikh mullet, was sold in clear vacuum-packaged bags of varying count and weight, bearing no code or date information. This product was sold from Lotus Catering and Fine Food, 1960 Lawrence Ave. E, Toronto, ON, on or before 17 Apr 2012.\n\nThere have been 3 reported illnesses associated with the consumption of this product.\n\nFood contaminated with _C. botulinum_ toxin may not look or smell spoiled. Consumption of food contaminated with the toxin may cause nausea, vomiting, fatigue, dizziness, headache, double vision, dry throat, respiratory failure and paralysis. In severe cases of illness, people may die.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Many of the botulism risks related to salted, cured fish are a result of the fish not being adequately eviscerated. The viscera of the fish are the parts most likely to be contaminated. Although not stated, most cases of botulism associated with the aquatic environment are serotype E whereas most other cases in humans are either type A or B. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1tBo.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA: uneviscerated fish, ex China, risk, recall 20120203.1031109\n2011\n----\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (02): risk, recall, ex Canada 20111124.3439\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish, bean tortillas - USA: (WA) 20090310.0990\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (02): risk, recall 20090228.0827\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: (NY, NJ) risk, recall 20090120.0247\nBotulism, dessert sauces - USA: risk, recall 20090126.0343\n2008\n----\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n.................................................ll/ejp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1960-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norway", "country": "Norway"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Guyana", "country": "Guyana"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "AZ", "country": "Libya"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1111009", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Canada (02):(ON) salted fish, expanded recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1111009", "date": "2012-04-20 23:34:03", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA: (ONTARIO), SALTED FISH, ALERT, RECALL\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Apr 2012\nSource: Canadian Food Inspection Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.marketwatch.com/story/cfiahealth-hazard-alert-lotus-fine-foods-whole-fesikh-mullet-salted-and-cured-fish-may-contain-dangerous-bacteria-2012-04-20\n\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) is warning the public not to consume the salted and cured fish product (fesikh) described below because it may be contaminated with spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. Toxins produced by this bacteria may cause botulism, a life-threatening illness.\n\nThe affected product, whole fesikh mullet, was sold in clear vacuum-packaged bags of varying count and weight, bearing no code or date information. This product was sold from Lotus Catering and Fine Food, 1960 Lawrence Ave. E, Toronto, ON, on or before 17 Apr 2012.\n\nThere have been 3 reported illnesses associated with the consumption of this product.\n\nFood contaminated with _C. botulinum_ toxin may not look or smell spoiled. Consumption of food contaminated with the toxin may cause nausea, vomiting, fatigue, dizziness, headache, double vision, dry throat, respiratory failure and paralysis. In severe cases of illness, people may die.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Many of the botulism risks related to salted, cured fish are a result of the fish not being adequately eviscerated. The viscera of the fish are the parts most likely to be contaminated. Although not stated, most cases of botulism associated with the aquatic environment are serotype E whereas most other cases in humans are either type A or B. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1tBo.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Canada:(ON), salted fish, alert, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1108660", "date": "2012-04-20 23:34:03", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA: (ONTARIO), SALTED FISH, ALERT, RECALL\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Apr 2012\nSource: Canadian Food Inspection Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.marketwatch.com/story/cfiahealth-hazard-alert-lotus-fine-foods-whole-fesikh-mullet-salted-and-cured-fish-may-contain-dangerous-bacteria-2012-04-20\n\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) is warning the public not to consume the salted and cured fish product (fesikh) described below because it may be contaminated with spores of _Clostridium botulinum_. Toxins produced by this bacteria may cause botulism, a life-threatening illness.\n\nThe affected product, whole fesikh mullet, was sold in clear vacuum-packaged bags of varying count and weight, bearing no code or date information. This product was sold from Lotus Catering and Fine Food, 1960 Lawrence Ave. E, Toronto, ON, on or before 17 Apr 2012.\n\nThere have been 3 reported illnesses associated with the consumption of this product.\n\nFood contaminated with _C. botulinum_ toxin may not look or smell spoiled. Consumption of food contaminated with the toxin may cause nausea, vomiting, fatigue, dizziness, headache, double vision, dry throat, respiratory failure and paralysis. In severe cases of illness, people may die.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Many of the botulism risks related to salted, cured fish are a result of the fish not being adequately eviscerated. The viscera of the fish are the parts most likely to be contaminated. Although not stated, most cases of botulism associated with the aquatic environment are serotype E whereas most other cases in humans are either type A or B. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1tBo.]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA (04): uneviscerated fish ex Guyana, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1098565", "date": "2012-02-03 18:01:39", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: UNEVISCERATED FISH, ex CHINA, RISK, RECALL\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] FDA recall: uneviscerated sardine anchovies\n[2] FDA recall: uneviscerated dried yellow croaker\n\n******\n[1] FDA recall: uneviscerated sardine anchovies\nDate: Wed 1 Feb 2012\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm290067.htm?source=govdelivery\n\n\nW & International Import Inc. is recalling \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies because the product was found to be uneviscerated. The recalled \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies were distributed nationwide in 7.0 oz. plastic packages and are a product of China.\n\nThe \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies were sampled by a New York State Department of Agriculture Food Inspector during inspection. Subsequent analysis of the product by New York State Food Laboratory personnel confirmed that the \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies were not properly eviscerated prior to processing. The sale of uneviscerated fish is prohibited under New York State Agriculture and Markets regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any other portion of the fish. Uneviscerated fish have been linked to outbreaks of botulinum poisoning.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with this problem.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A picture of the product can be found at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm290069.htm. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] FDA recall: uneviscerated dried yellow croaker\nDate: Wed 1 Feb 2012\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm290084.htm?source=govdelivery\n\n\nW & International Import Inc. is recalling \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker because the product was found to be uneviscerated.\n\nThe recalled \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker was distributed nationwide in bulk cardboard boxes. The \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker is a product of China.\n\nThe \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker was sampled by a New York State Department of Agriculture Food Inspector during inspection. Subsequent analysis of the product by New York State Food Laboratory personnel confirmed that the \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker was not properly eviscerated prior to processing.\n\nThe sale of uneviscerated fish is prohibited under New York State Agriculture and Markets regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any other portion of the fish. Uneviscerated fish have been linked to outbreaks of botulinum poisoning.\n\nThis product may be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_ spores, which can cause botulism, a serious and potentially fatal food-borne illness. Symptoms of botulism include blurred or double vision, general weakness, poor reflexes, difficulty in swallowing, and respiratory paralysis.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with this problem.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A picture of the product can be found at http://img.21food.com/20110609/product/1305629084656.jpg. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated [yet] with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish -
