USA: risk, recall, ex Philippines 20111105.3300\nBotulism, fish products - Canada: risk, recall 20111030.3229\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall, ex Canada 20111014.3078\nBotulism, prison brew - USA (02): (UT) 20111012.3050\nBotulism, human - France: homemade tapenade 20110906.2720\nBotulism, commercial potato soup - USA: (OH,GA) 20110707.2058\n2010\n----\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: ex Norway, risk, recall 20100208.0427\n2009\n----\nBotulism, baby food, uneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall 20091020.3599\nBotulism, home canned green beans - USA: (WA) 20090310.0990\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (02): risk, recall 20090228.0827\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: (NY, NJ) risk, recall 20090120.0247\nBotulism, dessert sauces - USA: risk, recall 20090126.0343\n2008\n----\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\nBotulism, tea concentrate - USA: (MT, AZ) risk, recall 20080618.1903\nBotulism, pesto - USA: risk, recall 20080429.1474\nBotulism, olive oil dip - USA: risk, recall 20080204.0448\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n.................................................ll/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norway", "country": "Norway"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "AZ", "country": "Libya"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1097209", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - USA (03): (MN) uneviscerated fish, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1097209", "date": "2012-02-03 18:01:39", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: UNEVISCERATED FISH, ex CHINA, RISK, RECALL\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] FDA recall: uneviscerated sardine anchovies\n[2] FDA recall: uneviscerated dried yellow croaker\n\n******\n[1] FDA recall: uneviscerated sardine anchovies\nDate: Wed 1 Feb 2012\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm290067.htm?source=govdelivery\n\n\nW & International Import Inc. is recalling \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies because the product was found to be uneviscerated. The recalled \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies were distributed nationwide in 7.0 oz. plastic packages and are a product of China.\n\nThe \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies were sampled by a New York State Department of Agriculture Food Inspector during inspection. Subsequent analysis of the product by New York State Food Laboratory personnel confirmed that the \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies were not properly eviscerated prior to processing. The sale of uneviscerated fish is prohibited under New York State Agriculture and Markets regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any other portion of the fish. Uneviscerated fish have been linked to outbreaks of botulinum poisoning.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with this problem.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A picture of the product can be found at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm290069.htm. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] FDA recall: uneviscerated dried yellow croaker\nDate: Wed 1 Feb 2012\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm290084.htm?source=govdelivery\n\n\nW & International Import Inc. is recalling \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker because the product was found to be uneviscerated.\n\nThe recalled \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker was distributed nationwide in bulk cardboard boxes. The \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker is a product of China.\n\nThe \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker was sampled by a New York State Department of Agriculture Food Inspector during inspection. Subsequent analysis of the product by New York State Food Laboratory personnel confirmed that the \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker was not properly eviscerated prior to processing.\n\nThe sale of uneviscerated fish is prohibited under New York State Agriculture and Markets regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any other portion of the fish. Uneviscerated fish have been linked to outbreaks of botulinum poisoning.\n\nThis product may be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_ spores, which can cause botulism, a serious and potentially fatal food-borne illness. Symptoms of botulism include blurred or double vision, general weakness, poor reflexes, difficulty in swallowing, and respiratory paralysis.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with this problem.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A picture of the product can be found at http://img.21food.com/20110609/product/1305629084656.jpg. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated [yet] with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall 20090126.0343\n2008\n----\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\nBotulism, tea concentrate - USA: (MT, AZ) risk, recall 20080618.1903\nBotulism, pesto - USA: risk, recall 20080429.1474\nBotulism, olive oil dip - USA: risk, recall 20080204.0448\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n.................................................ll/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norway", "country": "Norway"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "AZ", "country": "Libya"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1086556", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - USA (02): (NYC), tofu susp., alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1086556", "date": "2012-02-03 18:01:39", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: UNEVISCERATED FISH, ex CHINA, RISK, RECALL\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] FDA recall: uneviscerated sardine anchovies\n[2] FDA recall: uneviscerated dried yellow croaker\n\n******\n[1] FDA recall: uneviscerated sardine anchovies\nDate: Wed 1 Feb 2012\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm290067.htm?source=govdelivery\n\n\nW & International Import Inc. is recalling \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies because the product was found to be uneviscerated. The recalled \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies were distributed nationwide in 7.0 oz. plastic packages and are a product of China.\n\nThe \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies were sampled by a New York State Department of Agriculture Food Inspector during inspection. Subsequent analysis of the product by New York State Food Laboratory personnel confirmed that the \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies were not properly eviscerated prior to processing. The sale of uneviscerated fish is prohibited under New York State Agriculture and Markets regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any other portion of the fish. Uneviscerated fish have been linked to outbreaks of botulinum poisoning.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with this problem.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A picture of the product can be found at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm290069.htm. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] FDA recall: uneviscerated dried yellow croaker\nDate: Wed 1 Feb 2012\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm290084.htm?source=govdelivery\n\n\nW & International Import Inc. is recalling \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker because the product was found to be uneviscerated.\n\nThe recalled \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker was distributed nationwide in bulk cardboard boxes. The \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker is a product of China.\n\nThe \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker was sampled by a New York State Department of Agriculture Food Inspector during inspection. Subsequent analysis of the product by New York State Food Laboratory personnel confirmed that the \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker was not properly eviscerated prior to processing.\n\nThe sale of uneviscerated fish is prohibited under New York State Agriculture and Markets regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any other portion of the fish. Uneviscerated fish have been linked to outbreaks of botulinum poisoning.\n\nThis product may be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_ spores, which can cause botulism, a serious and potentially fatal food-borne illness. Symptoms of botulism include blurred or double vision, general weakness, poor reflexes, difficulty in swallowing, and respiratory paralysis.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with this problem.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A picture of the product can be found at http://img.21food.com/20110609/product/1305629084656.jpg. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated [yet] with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall 20090126.0343\n2008\n----\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\nBotulism, tea concentrate - USA: (MT, AZ) risk, recall 20080618.1903\nBotulism, pesto - USA: risk, recall 20080429.1474\nBotulism, olive oil dip - New Zealand: (CB) susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1040575", "date": "2012-02-03 18:01:39", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: UNEVISCERATED FISH, ex CHINA, RISK, RECALL\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] FDA recall: uneviscerated sardine anchovies\n[2] FDA recall: uneviscerated dried yellow croaker\n\n******\n[1] FDA recall: uneviscerated sardine anchovies\nDate: Wed 1 Feb 2012\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm290067.htm?source=govdelivery\n\n\nW & International Import Inc. is recalling \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies because the product was found to be uneviscerated. The recalled \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies were distributed nationwide in 7.0 oz. plastic packages and are a product of China.\n\nThe \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies were sampled by a New York State Department of Agriculture Food Inspector during inspection. Subsequent analysis of the product by New York State Food Laboratory personnel confirmed that the \"Rely\" Sardine Anchovies were not properly eviscerated prior to processing. The sale of uneviscerated fish is prohibited under New York State Agriculture and Markets regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any other portion of the fish. Uneviscerated fish have been linked to outbreaks of botulinum poisoning.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with this problem.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A picture of the product can be found at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm290069.htm. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] FDA recall: uneviscerated dried yellow croaker\nDate: Wed 1 Feb 2012\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) [edited]\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm290084.htm?source=govdelivery\n\n\nW & International Import Inc. is recalling \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker because the product was found to be uneviscerated.\n\nThe recalled \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker was distributed nationwide in bulk cardboard boxes. The \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker is a product of China.\n\nThe \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker was sampled by a New York State Department of Agriculture Food Inspector during inspection. Subsequent analysis of the product by New York State Food Laboratory personnel confirmed that the \"Rely\" Dried Yellow Croaker was not properly eviscerated prior to processing.\n\nThe sale of uneviscerated fish is prohibited under New York State Agriculture and Markets regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any other portion of the fish. Uneviscerated fish have been linked to outbreaks of botulinum poisoning.\n\nThis product may be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_ spores, which can cause botulism, a serious and potentially fatal food-borne illness. Symptoms of botulism include blurred or double vision, general weakness, poor reflexes, difficulty in swallowing, and respiratory paralysis.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with this problem.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A picture of the product can be found at http://img.21food.com/20110609/product/1305629084656.jpg. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated [yet] with the food products. Most of the food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - Germany: (B-W) alert, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=996247", "date": "2011-11-24 11:43:42", "main_text": "BOTULISM, UNEVISCERATED FISH - USA (02): RISK, RECALL, ex CANADA\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Nov 2011\nSource: Alpha Trade, Business Wire, Quirch Foods, Co. report [edited]\nhttp://finance.alphatrade.com/story/2011-11-22/BIZ/201111221259BIZWIRE_USPR_____BW6251.html\n\n\nQuirch Foods Co. of Miami, Florida is voluntary recalling a lot of\nCap-Pele Herring Export, Inc brand, Salted Smoked Split Herring, Plant\nReg No. 4108-2931, Processor: Petite Cap Fisheries Ltd. 2015 Route\n950, Petite-Cap, NB, E4N 2H5, Canada. A sample collected by FDA at a\nFlorida Distributor was found to be uneviscerated. _Clostridium\nbotulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera\nthan any other portion of the fish.\n\nThe product was distributed in 18 lb, 8.2 kg, bulk packed wooden\nboxes, with a \"REG No 4108-2931\" stamp. The product was sold to\nsupermarkets and a distributor in Florida, and St. Thomas VI and is\npackaged at retail per customer request.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date.\n\nConsumers are cautioned not to consume this product, even if it does\nnot look or smell spoiled. The product should immediately be returned\nto the store where it was purchased.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This recall is related to the same Canadian processor and same type\nof product as had been previously reported 5 weeks ago (Botulism,\nuneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall, ex Canada 20111014.3078). It\nis not clear that the current recall is from the same group as then.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such\nrecalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated\nwith the food products.\n\nMost of the food recalls (as in these cases) are related to defective\npreparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in\nthe germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_. - Finland (05): ex Italy, bottled olives", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=975146", "date": "2011-11-24 11:43:42", "main_text": "BOTULISM, UNEVISCERATED FISH - USA (02): RISK, RECALL, ex CANADA\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Nov 2011\nSource: Alpha Trade, Business Wire, Quirch Foods, Co. report [edited]\nhttp://finance.alphatrade.com/story/2011-11-22/BIZ/201111221259BIZWIRE_USPR_____BW6251.html\n\n\nQuirch Foods Co. of Miami, Florida is voluntary recalling a lot of\nCap-Pele Herring Export, Inc brand, Salted Smoked Split Herring, Plant\nReg No. 4108-2931, Processor: Petite Cap Fisheries Ltd. 2015 Route\n950, Petite-Cap, NB, E4N 2H5, Canada. A sample collected by FDA at a\nFlorida Distributor was found to be uneviscerated. _Clostridium\nbotulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera\nthan any other portion of the fish.\n\nThe product was distributed in 18 lb, 8.2 kg, bulk packed wooden\nboxes, with a \"REG No 4108-2931\" stamp. The product was sold to\nsupermarkets and a distributor in Florida, and St. Thomas VI and is\npackaged at retail per customer request.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date.\n\nConsumers are cautioned not to consume this product, even if it does\nnot look or smell spoiled. The product should immediately be returned\nto the store where it was purchased.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This recall is related to the same Canadian processor and same type\nof product as had been previously reported 5 weeks ago (Botulism,\nuneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall, ex Canada 20111014.3078). It\nis not clear that the current recall is from the same group as then.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such\nrecalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated\nwith the food products.\n\nMost of the food recalls (as in these cases) are related to defective\npreparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in\nthe germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_. - USA (02): risk, recall, ex Canada", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=957857", "date": "2011-11-24 11:43:42", "main_text": "BOTULISM, UNEVISCERATED FISH - USA (02): RISK, RECALL, ex CANADA\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Nov 2011\nSource: Alpha Trade, Business Wire, Quirch Foods, Co. report [edited]\nhttp://finance.alphatrade.com/story/2011-11-22/BIZ/201111221259BIZWIRE_USPR_____BW6251.html\n\n\nQuirch Foods Co. of Miami, Florida is voluntary recalling a lot of\nCap-Pele Herring Export, Inc brand, Salted Smoked Split Herring, Plant\nReg No. 4108-2931, Processor: Petite Cap Fisheries Ltd. 2015 Route\n950, Petite-Cap, NB, E4N 2H5, Canada. A sample collected by FDA at a\nFlorida Distributor was found to be uneviscerated. _Clostridium\nbotulinum_ spores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera\nthan any other portion of the fish.\n\nThe product was distributed in 18 lb, 8.2 kg, bulk packed wooden\nboxes, with a \"REG No 4108-2931\" stamp. The product was sold to\nsupermarkets and a distributor in Florida, and St. Thomas VI and is\npackaged at retail per customer request.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date.\n\nConsumers are cautioned not to consume this product, even if it does\nnot look or smell spoiled. The product should immediately be returned\nto the store where it was purchased.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This recall is related to the same Canadian processor and same type\nof product as had been previously reported 5 weeks ago (Botulism,\nuneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall, ex Canada 20111014.3078). It\nis not clear that the current recall is from the same group as then.\n\nBecause of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts such\nrecalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated\nwith the food products.\n\nMost of the food recalls (as in these cases) are related to defective\npreparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily do, result in\nthe germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish, bean tortillas - USA: risk, recalls\n20111119.3408\nBotulism, olives, bean soup, bean tortilla - USA: risk, recall\n20111112.3351\nBotulism, smoked fish - USA: risk, recalls", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=952984", "date": "2011-11-12 11:02:06", "main_text": "BOTULISM - UK: (SCOTLAND), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2011\nSource: The Scotsman [edited]\nhttp://www.scotsman.com/news/health/health_alert_as_two_botulism_cases_are_confirmed_1_1961682\n\n\nHealth officials in Scotland are urging the public to be aware of the\nsymptoms of botulism after 2 members of the same family were\nhospitalised with an illness which is now thought likely to be the\nintoxication. Health Protection Scotland (HPS) said the pair remained\nin a stable condition. HPS has notified clinicians and has so far\nreceived no reports of any further suspected cases.\n\nInvestigations are continuing into the possible cause, but botulism is\noften food-borne. Botulism is caused by toxins produced by the\nbacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, which attacks the nervous system\nand can affect people of any age. The infection is not contagious and\ncannot be spread from person to person. Symptoms of food-borne\nbotulism typically begin between 12 and 36 hours after ingestion of\ncontaminated food, but may become apparent in as little as 6 hours.\n\nDr John Cowden, consultant epidemiologist at HPS, said: \"Botulism is\nrare in the UK. Symptoms are a combination of blurred vision,\ndifficulty swallowing and difficulty speaking -- which rapidly get\nworse, followed by general muscle weakness. Any person, child or\nadult, with these symptoms should seek urgent medical advice.\nAntitoxins have proved very effective in treating the condition.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED awaits more information regarding the source of the botulinum\ntoxin in these 2 linked cases. It is likely that the source was a\nhome-prepared food but more information is required. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Finland (04): ex Italy, jarred olives, USA alert\n20111103.3278\nBotulism - Finland: (Helsinki) ex Italy, jarred olives 20111026.3182\nBotulism, human - UK: (SCOTLAND), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2011\nSource: The Scotsman [edited]\nhttp://www.scotsman.com/news/health/health_alert_as_two_botulism_cases_are_confirmed_1_1961682\n\n\nHealth officials in Scotland are urging the public to be aware of the\nsymptoms of botulism after 2 members of the same family were\nhospitalised with an illness which is now thought likely to be the\nintoxication. Health Protection Scotland (HPS) said the pair remained\nin a stable condition. HPS has notified clinicians and has so far\nreceived no reports of any further suspected cases.\n\nInvestigations are continuing into the possible cause, but botulism is\noften food-borne. Botulism is caused by toxins produced by the\nbacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, which attacks the nervous system\nand can affect people of any age. The infection is not contagious and\ncannot be spread from person to person. Symptoms of food-borne\nbotulism typically begin between 12 and 36 hours after ingestion of\ncontaminated food, but may become apparent in as little as 6 hours.\n\nDr John Cowden, consultant epidemiologist at HPS, said: \"Botulism is\nrare in the UK. Symptoms are a combination of blurred vision,\ndifficulty swallowing and difficulty speaking -- which rapidly get\nworse, followed by general muscle weakness. Any person, child or\nadult, with these symptoms should seek urgent medical advice.\nAntitoxins have proved very effective in treating the condition.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED awaits more information regarding the source of the botulinum\ntoxin in these 2 linked cases. UK: (SCOTLAND), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2011\nSource: The Scotsman [edited]\nhttp://www.scotsman.com/news/health/health_alert_as_two_botulism_cases_are_confirmed_1_1961682\n\n\nHealth officials in Scotland are urging the public to be aware of the\nsymptoms of botulism after 2 members of the same family were\nhospitalised with an illness which is now thought likely to be the\nintoxication. Health Protection Scotland (HPS) said the pair remained\nin a stable condition. HPS has notified clinicians and has so far\nreceived no reports of any further suspected cases.\n\nInvestigations are continuing into the possible cause, but botulism is\noften food-borne. Botulism is caused by toxins produced by the\nbacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, which attacks the nervous system\nand can affect people of any age. The infection is not contagious and\ncannot be spread from person to person. Symptoms of food-borne\nbotulism typically begin between 12 and 36 hours after ingestion of\ncontaminated food, but may become apparent in as little as 6 hours.\n\nDr John Cowden, consultant epidemiologist at HPS, said: \"Botulism is\nrare in the UK. Symptoms are a combination of blurred vision,\ndifficulty swallowing and difficulty speaking -- which rapidly get\nworse, followed by general muscle weakness. Any person, child or\nadult, with these symptoms should seek urgent medical advice.\nAntitoxins have proved very effective in treating the condition.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED awaits more information regarding the source of the botulinum\ntoxin in these 2 linked cases. UK: (SCOTLAND), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2011\nSource: The Scotsman [edited]\nhttp://www.scotsman.com/news/health/health_alert_as_two_botulism_cases_are_confirmed_1_1961682\n\n\nHealth officials in Scotland are urging the public to be aware of the\nsymptoms of botulism after 2 members of the same family were\nhospitalised with an illness which is now thought likely to be the\nintoxication. Health Protection Scotland (HPS) said the pair remained\nin a stable condition. HPS has notified clinicians and has so far\nreceived no reports of any further suspected cases.\n\nInvestigations are continuing into the possible cause, but botulism is\noften food-borne. Botulism is caused by toxins produced by the\nbacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, which attacks the nervous system\nand can affect people of any age. The infection is not contagious and\ncannot be spread from person to person. Symptoms of food-borne\nbotulism typically begin between 12 and 36 hours after ingestion of\ncontaminated food, but may become apparent in as little as 6 hours.\n\nDr John Cowden, consultant epidemiologist at HPS, said: \"Botulism is\nrare in the UK. Symptoms are a combination of blurred vision,\ndifficulty swallowing and difficulty speaking -- which rapidly get\nworse, followed by general muscle weakness. Any person, child or\nadult, with these symptoms should seek urgent medical advice.\nAntitoxins have proved very effective in treating the condition.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED awaits more information regarding the source of the botulinum\ntoxin in these 2 linked cases. It is likely that the source was a\nhome-prepared food but more information is required. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Finland (04): ex Italy, jarred olives, USA alert\n20111103.3278\nBotulism - Finland: (Helsinki) ex Italy, jarred olives 20111026.3182\nBotulism, human - Health Protection Scotland (HPS) said the pair remained\nin a stable condition. HPS has notified clinicians and has so far\nreceived no reports of any further suspected cases.\n\nInvestigations are continuing into the possible cause, but botulism is\noften food-borne. Botulism is caused by toxins produced by the\nbacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, which attacks the nervous system\nand can affect people of any age. The infection is not contagious and\ncannot be spread from person to person. Symptoms of food-borne\nbotulism typically begin between 12 and 36 hours after ingestion of\ncontaminated food, but may become apparent in as little as 6 hours.\n\nDr John Cowden, consultant epidemiologist at HPS, said: \"Botulism is\nrare in the UK. Symptoms are a combination of blurred vision,\ndifficulty swallowing and difficulty speaking -- which rapidly get\nworse, followed by general muscle weakness. Any person, child or\nadult, with these symptoms should seek urgent medical advice.\nAntitoxins have proved very effective in treating the condition.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED awaits more information regarding the source of the botulinum\ntoxin in these 2 linked cases. UK: (SCOTLAND), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2011\nSource: The Scotsman [edited]\nhttp://www.scotsman.com/news/health/health_alert_as_two_botulism_cases_are_confirmed_1_1961682\n\n\nHealth officials in Scotland are urging the public to be aware of the\nsymptoms of botulism after 2 members of the same family were\nhospitalised with an illness which is now thought likely to be the\nintoxication. Health Protection Scotland (HPS) said the pair remained\nin a stable condition. HPS has notified clinicians and has so far\nreceived no reports of any further suspected cases.\n\nInvestigations are continuing into the possible cause, but botulism is\noften food-borne. Botulism is caused by toxins produced by the\nbacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, which attacks the nervous system\nand can affect people of any age. The infection is not contagious and\ncannot be spread from person to person. Symptoms of food-borne\nbotulism typically begin between 12 and 36 hours after ingestion of\ncontaminated food, but may become apparent in as little as 6 hours.\n\nDr John Cowden, consultant epidemiologist at HPS, said: \"Botulism is\nrare in the UK. Symptoms are a combination of blurred vision,\ndifficulty swallowing and difficulty speaking -- which rapidly get\nworse, followed by general muscle weakness. Any person, child or\nadult, with these symptoms should seek urgent medical advice.\nAntitoxins have proved very effective in treating the condition.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED awaits more information regarding the source of the botulinum\ntoxin in these 2 linked cases. Finland (03): ex Italy, jarred olives, int'l alert"}, {"archive_id": "928661", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, fish products - Canada: risk, recall"}, {"archive_id": "925152", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Finland (02): ex Italy, jarred olives, int'l alert"}, {"archive_id": "924198", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Finland: (Helsinki) ex Italy, jarred olives"}, {"archive_id": "923645", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, fish, avian - Canada (02): (ON)"}, {"archive_id": "919589", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism, fish, avian - Canada"}, {"archive_id": "909361", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall, ex Canada"}, {"archive_id": "907996", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Undiagnosed deaths, equine - Australia (03): (QL) botulism susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=907996", "date": "2011-09-23 17:10:25", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DIE-OFF, AVIAN - USA (08): (CALIFORNIA) BOTULISM SUSPECTED\n**********************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Sep 2011\nSource: The Orange County Register [edited]\nhttp://articles.ocregister.com/2011-09-19/news/30181585_1_dead-ducks-botulism-village-pond-park\n\n\nMallards dying in Lake Forest lakes\n-----------------------------------\nIn the last 2 weeks, more than 30 dead or dying ducks have been found\nat ponds and lakes around the city.\n\nResidents of the Lake I and Lake II communities have reported finding\nhen and drake mallards floating in the lakes there and flopping on\nnearby grass. Dead ducks also have been found at Village Pond Park and\nnearby at the Forest Gardens Mobile Home Park. Officials from Orange\nCounty Animal Care have picked up some of the dead birds, and\nresidents have tried to save some birds by taking them to the Wetlands\n& Wildlife Care Center in Huntington Beach.\n\nA Lake I resident is concerned bread being fed to the ducks at Village\nPond Park coupled with the recent heat and algae forming in the water\nare contributing to the growth of botulism.\n\n\"The city does no enforcement,\" [she] said of regulations prohibiting\nfeeding ducks. \"I've seen a baker's truck unload at the duck pond and\npeople out there all day with non-duck food. It's very sad to see them\njust dying and flopping around.\"\n\n[Byline: Erika I Ritchie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The photo in the original article at the source URL above shows a\nduck with a limp bent over neck. This is some times called\n\"limberneck\" and is another name for botulism. The conditions\nmentioned above may have contributed to this situation but it is\nimpossible to comment on where the botulism came from with only the\ninformation in this article. However, if the dead bodies are not\nremoved from the site, they continue to be part of the cycle. As\nmaggots form in the carcasses they are filled with botulism. Those\nmaggots are great bird food, as well as a source of more botulism.\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin\nproduced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are\nwidespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source,\nand an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and\nproduce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with\nwarm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism\nbacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of\ntoxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly\naffected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.\n\nBirds either ingest the toxin directly or may eat invertebrates (such\nas chironomids [non-biting midges], fly larvae) containing the toxin.\nInvertebrates are not affected by the toxin and store it in their\nbody. A cycle develops in a botulism outbreak when fly larvae\n(maggots), feed on animal carcasses and ingest toxin. Ducks that\nconsume toxin-laden maggots can develop botulism after eating as few\nas 3 or 4 maggots.\n\nHealthy birds, affected birds, and dead birds in various stages of\ndecay are commonly found in the same area. The toxin affects the\nnervous system by preventing impulse transmission to muscles. Birds\nare unable to use their wings and legs normally or control the 3rd\neyelid, neck muscles, and other muscles. Birds with paralyzed neck\nmuscles cannot hold their heads up and often drown (the disease has\noccasionally been called \"limberneck\"). Death can also result from\nwater deprivation, electrolyte imbalance, respiratory failure, or\npredation.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\nhttp://www.nwhc.usgs.gov/disease_information/avian_botulism/. -\nMod.TG]\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of California can be seen at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1h2c. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian - USA: (CO) 20110914.2797\n2010\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (05): (FL) susp. 20100817.2848\nBotulism, avian - USA (04): (OH) 20100718.2407\nBotulism, avian - USA (03): (CA) 20100709.2294\nBotulism - USA: canned tuna, risk, recall 20100708.2280\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): (CO) 20100627.2145\nBotulism, avian - USA: (MI) susp 20100618.2047\n.................................................sb/tg/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Huntington Beach", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "906661", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, prison brew - USA (02): (UT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=906661", "date": "2011-09-23 17:10:25", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DIE-OFF, AVIAN - USA (08): (CALIFORNIA) BOTULISM SUSPECTED\n**********************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Sep 2011\nSource: The Orange County Register [edited]\nhttp://articles.ocregister.com/2011-09-19/news/30181585_1_dead-ducks-botulism-village-pond-park\n\n\nMallards dying in Lake Forest lakes\n-----------------------------------\nIn the last 2 weeks, more than 30 dead or dying ducks have been found\nat ponds and lakes around the city.\n\nResidents of the Lake I and Lake II communities have reported finding\nhen and drake mallards floating in the lakes there and flopping on\nnearby grass. Dead ducks also have been found at Village Pond Park and\nnearby at the Forest Gardens Mobile Home Park. Officials from Orange\nCounty Animal Care have picked up some of the dead birds, and\nresidents have tried to save some birds by taking them to the Wetlands\n& Wildlife Care Center in Huntington Beach.\n\nA Lake I resident is concerned bread being fed to the ducks at Village\nPond Park coupled with the recent heat and algae forming in the water\nare contributing to the growth of botulism.\n\n\"The city does no enforcement,\" [she] said of regulations prohibiting\nfeeding ducks. \"I've seen a baker's truck unload at the duck pond and\npeople out there all day with non-duck food. It's very sad to see them\njust dying and flopping around.\"\n\n[Byline: Erika I Ritchie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The photo in the original article at the source URL above shows a\nduck with a limp bent over neck. This is some times called\n\"limberneck\" and is another name for botulism. The conditions\nmentioned above may have contributed to this situation but it is\nimpossible to comment on where the botulism came from with only the\ninformation in this article. However, if the dead bodies are not\nremoved from the site, they continue to be part of the cycle. As\nmaggots form in the carcasses they are filled with botulism. Those\nmaggots are great bird food, as well as a source of more botulism.\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin\nproduced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are\nwidespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source,\nand an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and\nproduce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with\nwarm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism\nbacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of\ntoxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly\naffected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.\n\nBirds either ingest the toxin directly or may eat invertebrates (such\nas chironomids [non-biting midges], fly larvae) containing the toxin.\nInvertebrates are not affected by the toxin and store it in their\nbody. A cycle develops in a botulism outbreak when fly larvae\n(maggots), feed on animal carcasses and ingest toxin. Ducks that\nconsume toxin-laden maggots can develop botulism after eating as few\nas 3 or 4 maggots.\n\nHealthy birds, affected birds, and dead birds in various stages of\ndecay are commonly found in the same area. The toxin affects the\nnervous system by preventing impulse transmission to muscles. Birds\nare unable to use their wings and legs normally or control the 3rd\neyelid, neck muscles, and other muscles. Birds with paralyzed neck\nmuscles cannot hold their heads up and often drown (the disease has\noccasionally been called \"limberneck\"). Death can also result from\nwater deprivation, electrolyte imbalance, respiratory failure, or\npredation.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\nhttp://www.nwhc.usgs.gov/disease_information/avian_botulism/. -\nMod.TG]\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of California can be seen at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1h2c. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian - USA: (CO) 20110914.2797\n2010\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (05): (FL) susp. 20100817.2848\nBotulism, avian - USA (04): (OH) 20100718.2407\nBotulism, avian - USA (03): (CA) 20100709.2294\nBotulism - USA: canned tuna, risk, recall 20100708.2280\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): (CO) 20100627.2145\nBotulism, avian - USA: (MI) susp 20100618.2047\n.................................................sb/tg/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Huntington Beach", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "903017", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - USA (04): (NV)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=903017", "date": "2011-09-23 17:10:25", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DIE-OFF, AVIAN - USA (08): (CALIFORNIA) BOTULISM SUSPECTED\n**********************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Sep 2011\nSource: The Orange County Register [edited]\nhttp://articles.ocregister.com/2011-09-19/news/30181585_1_dead-ducks-botulism-village-pond-park\n\n\nMallards dying in Lake Forest lakes\n-----------------------------------\nIn the last 2 weeks, more than 30 dead or dying ducks have been found\nat ponds and lakes around the city.\n\nResidents of the Lake I and Lake II communities have reported finding\nhen and drake mallards floating in the lakes there and flopping on\nnearby grass. Dead ducks also have been found at Village Pond Park and\nnearby at the Forest Gardens Mobile Home Park. Officials from Orange\nCounty Animal Care have picked up some of the dead birds, and\nresidents have tried to save some birds by taking them to the Wetlands\n& Wildlife Care Center in Huntington Beach.\n\nA Lake I resident is concerned bread being fed to the ducks at Village\nPond Park coupled with the recent heat and algae forming in the water\nare contributing to the growth of botulism.\n\n\"The city does no enforcement,\" [she] said of regulations prohibiting\nfeeding ducks. \"I've seen a baker's truck unload at the duck pond and\npeople out there all day with non-duck food. It's very sad to see them\njust dying and flopping around.\"\n\n[Byline: Erika I Ritchie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The photo in the original article at the source URL above shows a\nduck with a limp bent over neck. This is some times called\n\"limberneck\" and is another name for botulism. The conditions\nmentioned above may have contributed to this situation but it is\nimpossible to comment on where the botulism came from with only the\ninformation in this article. However, if the dead bodies are not\nremoved from the site, they continue to be part of the cycle. As\nmaggots form in the carcasses they are filled with botulism. Those\nmaggots are great bird food, as well as a source of more botulism.\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin\nproduced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are\nwidespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source,\nand an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and\nproduce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with\nwarm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism\nbacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of\ntoxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly\naffected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.\n\nBirds either ingest the toxin directly or may eat invertebrates (such\nas chironomids [non-biting midges], fly larvae) containing the toxin.\nInvertebrates are not affected by the toxin and store it in their\nbody. A cycle develops in a botulism outbreak when fly larvae\n(maggots), feed on animal carcasses and ingest toxin. Ducks that\nconsume toxin-laden maggots can develop botulism after eating as few\nas 3 or 4 maggots.\n\nHealthy birds, affected birds, and dead birds in various stages of\ndecay are commonly found in the same area. The toxin affects the\nnervous system by preventing impulse transmission to muscles. Birds\nare unable to use their wings and legs normally or control the 3rd\neyelid, neck muscles, and other muscles. Birds with paralyzed neck\nmuscles cannot hold their heads up and often drown (the disease has\noccasionally been called \"limberneck\"). Death can also result from\nwater deprivation, electrolyte imbalance, respiratory failure, or\npredation.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\nhttp://www.nwhc.usgs.gov/disease_information/avian_botulism/. -\nMod.TG]\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of California can be seen at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1h2c. - However, if the dead bodies are not\nremoved from the site, they continue to be part of the cycle. As\nmaggots form in the carcasses they are filled with botulism. Those\nmaggots are great bird food, as well as a source of more botulism.\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin\nproduced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. Birds\nare unable to use their wings and legs normally or control the 3rd\neyelid, neck muscles, and other muscles. The conditions\nmentioned above may have contributed to this situation but it is\nimpossible to comment on where the botulism came from with only the\ninformation in this article. However, if the dead bodies are not\nremoved from the site, they continue to be part of the cycle. As\nmaggots form in the carcasses they are filled with botulism. Those\nmaggots are great bird food, as well as a source of more botulism.\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin\nproduced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are\nwidespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source,\nand an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and\nproduce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with\nwarm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism\nbacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of\ntoxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly\naffected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.\n\nBirds either ingest the toxin directly or may eat invertebrates (such\nas chironomids [non-biting midges], fly larvae) containing the toxin.\nInvertebrates are not affected by the toxin and store it in their\nbody. Ducks that\nconsume toxin-laden maggots can develop botulism after eating as few\nas 3 or 4 maggots.\n\nHealthy birds, affected birds, and dead birds in various stages of\ndecay are commonly found in the same area. The toxin affects the\nnervous system by preventing impulse transmission to muscles. Birds\nare unable to use their wings and legs normally or control the 3rd\neyelid, neck muscles, and other muscles. Birds with paralyzed neck\nmuscles cannot hold their heads up and often drown (the disease has\noccasionally been called \"limberneck\"). Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian - USA: (CO) 20110914.2797\n2010\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (05): (FL) susp. 20100817.2848\nBotulism, avian - USA (04): (OH) 20100718.2407\nBotulism, avian - USA (03): (CA) 20100709.2294\nBotulism - USA: canned tuna, risk, recall 20100708.2280\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): (CO) 20100627.2145\nBotulism, avian - USA: (MI) susp 20100618.2047\n.................................................sb/tg/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Huntington Beach", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "884337", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - USA (02): (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=884337", "date": "2011-09-23 17:10:25", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DIE-OFF, AVIAN - USA (08): (CALIFORNIA) BOTULISM SUSPECTED\n**********************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Sep 2011\nSource: The Orange County Register [edited]\nhttp://articles.ocregister.com/2011-09-19/news/30181585_1_dead-ducks-botulism-village-pond-park\n\n\nMallards dying in Lake Forest lakes\n-----------------------------------\nIn the last 2 weeks, more than 30 dead or dying ducks have been found\nat ponds and lakes around the city.\n\nResidents of the Lake I and Lake II communities have reported finding\nhen and drake mallards floating in the lakes there and flopping on\nnearby grass. Dead ducks also have been found at Village Pond Park and\nnearby at the Forest Gardens Mobile Home Park. Officials from Orange\nCounty Animal Care have picked up some of the dead birds, and\nresidents have tried to save some birds by taking them to the Wetlands\n& Wildlife Care Center in Huntington Beach.\n\nA Lake I resident is concerned bread being fed to the ducks at Village\nPond Park coupled with the recent heat and algae forming in the water\nare contributing to the growth of botulism.\n\n\"The city does no enforcement,\" [she] said of regulations prohibiting\nfeeding ducks. \"I've seen a baker's truck unload at the duck pond and\npeople out there all day with non-duck food. It's very sad to see them\njust dying and flopping around.\"\n\n[Byline: Erika I Ritchie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The photo in the original article at the source URL above shows a\nduck with a limp bent over neck. This is some times called\n\"limberneck\" and is another name for botulism. The conditions\nmentioned above may have contributed to this situation but it is\nimpossible to comment on where the botulism came from with only the\ninformation in this article. However, if the dead bodies are not\nremoved from the site, they continue to be part of the cycle. As\nmaggots form in the carcasses they are filled with botulism. Those\nmaggots are great bird food, as well as a source of more botulism.\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin\nproduced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are\nwidespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source,\nand an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and\nproduce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with\nwarm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism\nbacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of\ntoxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly\naffected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.\n\nBirds either ingest the toxin directly or may eat invertebrates (such\nas chironomids [non-biting midges], fly larvae) containing the toxin.\nInvertebrates are not affected by the toxin and store it in their\nbody. A cycle develops in a botulism outbreak when fly larvae\n(maggots), feed on animal carcasses and ingest toxin. Ducks that\nconsume toxin-laden maggots can develop botulism after eating as few\nas 3 or 4 maggots.\n\nHealthy birds, affected birds, and dead birds in various stages of\ndecay are commonly found in the same area. The toxin affects the\nnervous system by preventing impulse transmission to muscles. Birds\nare unable to use their wings and legs normally or control the 3rd\neyelid, neck muscles, and other muscles. Birds with paralyzed neck\nmuscles cannot hold their heads up and often drown (the disease has\noccasionally been called \"limberneck\"). Death can also result from\nwater deprivation, electrolyte imbalance, respiratory failure, or\npredation.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\nhttp://www.nwhc.usgs.gov/disease_information/avian_botulism/. -\nMod.TG]\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of California can be seen at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1h2c. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian - USA: (CO) 20110914.2797\n2010\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (05): (FL) susp. 20100817.2848\nBotulism, avian - USA (04): (OH) 20100718.2407\nBotulism, avian - USA (03): (CA) 20100709.2294\nBotulism - USA: canned tuna, risk, recall 20100708.2280\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): (CO) 20100627.2145\nBotulism, avian - USA: (MI) susp 20100618.2047\n.................................................sb/tg/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Huntington Beach", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "883651", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Undiagnosed die-off, avian - USA (08): (CA) botulism susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=883651", "date": "2011-09-23 17:10:25", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DIE-OFF, AVIAN - USA (08): (CALIFORNIA) BOTULISM SUSPECTED\n**********************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Sep 2011\nSource: The Orange County Register [edited]\nhttp://articles.ocregister.com/2011-09-19/news/30181585_1_dead-ducks-botulism-village-pond-park\n\n\nMallards dying in Lake Forest lakes\n-----------------------------------\nIn the last 2 weeks, more than 30 dead or dying ducks have been found\nat ponds and lakes around the city.\n\nResidents of the Lake I and Lake II communities have reported finding\nhen and drake mallards floating in the lakes there and flopping on\nnearby grass. Dead ducks also have been found at Village Pond Park and\nnearby at the Forest Gardens Mobile Home Park. Officials from Orange\nCounty Animal Care have picked up some of the dead birds, and\nresidents have tried to save some birds by taking them to the Wetlands\n& Wildlife Care Center in Huntington Beach.\n\nA Lake I resident is concerned bread being fed to the ducks at Village\nPond Park coupled with the recent heat and algae forming in the water\nare contributing to the growth of botulism.\n\n\"The city does no enforcement,\" [she] said of regulations prohibiting\nfeeding ducks. \"I've seen a baker's truck unload at the duck pond and\npeople out there all day with non-duck food. It's very sad to see them\njust dying and flopping around.\"\n\n[Byline: Erika I Ritchie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The photo in the original article at the source URL above shows a\nduck with a limp bent over neck. This is some times called\n\"limberneck\" and is another name for botulism. The conditions\nmentioned above may have contributed to this situation but it is\nimpossible to comment on where the botulism came from with only the\ninformation in this article. However, if the dead bodies are not\nremoved from the site, they continue to be part of the cycle. As\nmaggots form in the carcasses they are filled with botulism. Those\nmaggots are great bird food, as well as a source of more botulism.\n\nAvian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin\nproduced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are\nwidespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source,\nand an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and\nproduce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with\nwarm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism\nbacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of\ntoxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly\naffected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.\n\nBirds either ingest the toxin directly or may eat invertebrates (such\nas chironomids [non-biting midges], fly larvae) containing the toxin.\nInvertebrates are not affected by the toxin and store it in their\nbody. A cycle develops in a botulism outbreak when fly larvae\n(maggots), feed on animal carcasses and ingest toxin. Ducks that\nconsume toxin-laden maggots can develop botulism after eating as few\nas 3 or 4 maggots.\n\nHealthy birds, affected birds, and dead birds in various stages of\ndecay are commonly found in the same area. The toxin affects the\nnervous system by preventing impulse transmission to muscles. Birds\nare unable to use their wings and legs normally or control the 3rd\neyelid, neck muscles, and other muscles. Birds with paralyzed neck\nmuscles cannot hold their heads up and often drown (the disease has\noccasionally been called \"limberneck\"). Death can also result from\nwater deprivation, electrolyte imbalance, respiratory failure, or\npredation.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\nhttp://www.nwhc.usgs.gov/disease_information/avian_botulism/. -\nMod.TG]\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of California can be seen at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1h2c. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBotulism, avian - USA: (CO) 20110914.2797\n2010\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (05): (FL) susp. 20100817.2848\nBotulism, avian - USA (04): (OH) 20100718.2407\nBotulism, avian - USA (03): (CA) 20100709.2294\nBotulism - USA: canned tuna, risk, recall 20100708.2280\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): (CO) 20100627.2145\nBotulism, avian - USA: (MI) susp 20100618.2047\n.................................................sb/tg/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Huntington Beach", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "870562", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - USA: (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=870562", "date": "2011-07-25 10:08:42", "main_text": "BOTULISM - TAIWAN: (NANTOU) HOMEMADE PRESERVES SUSPECTED\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 22 Jul 2011\nSource: The China Post [edited]\nhttp://www.chinapost.com.tw/taiwan/local/nantou/2011/07/22/310649/Deaths-in.htm\n\n\nA senior prosecutor in [Nantou County] said Thu 21 Jul 2011, 4 of the\n5 people who died suddenly between 6 and 8 Jul 2011 in the county may\nhave been killed by botulism toxin. In the initial forensics tests,\ntraces of botulism toxin were found in 4 of the bodies, but it was not\ncertain whether the toxins were from eating homemade vegetable\npreserves, said Chu Kun-mao, chief of the Nantou District Prosecutors\nOffice.\n\nIt will require further microbiology tests by Department of Health\nagencies to confirm the results, he said. The Institute of Forensic\nMedicine will deliver the final report on the causes of death after\nthe results of the microbiology tests become available 26 Jul 2011,\nthe prosecutor said.\n\nOn 6 Jul 2011, 4 residents of Hsinyi Township in Nantou died\nsuddenly. It was found that the people, a vegetable farmer, his wife,\nand their 2 helpers, had shared a meal earlier in the day. 2 days\nlater, another Hsinyi resident died suddenly from what was initially\nthought to be food poisoning, but that was later ruled out.\n\nAmid fears of an epidemic in the township, the Centers for Disease\nControl (CDC) reported that the latest victim had died of septicemia\ncaused by inflammation of the pancreas and cellulitis, according to\nprosecutors. The families of people at first suspected murder, but\nhave since accepted the findings of the experts, prosecutors said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is no description of the clinical illnesses here. Botulism is\na symmetrical flaccid paralysis, which usually begins with visual\ndisturbances related to extraocular muscle weakness beginning 18-36\nhours after ingestion of the food vehicle. - Mod.LL]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Taiwan can be seen at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/14He. - In the initial forensics tests,\ntraces of botulism toxin were found in 4 of the bodies, but it was not\ncertain whether the toxins were from eating homemade vegetable\npreserves, said Chu Kun-mao, chief of the Nantou District Prosecutors\nOffice.\n\nIt will require further microbiology tests by Department of Health\nagencies to confirm the results, he said. The Institute of Forensic\nMedicine will deliver the final report on the causes of death after\nthe results of the microbiology tests become available 26 Jul 2011,\nthe prosecutor said.\n\nOn 6 Jul 2011, 4 residents of Hsinyi Township in Nantou died\nsuddenly. It was found that the people, a vegetable farmer, his wife,\nand their 2 helpers, had shared a meal earlier in the day. 2 days\nlater, another Hsinyi resident died suddenly from what was initially\nthought to be food poisoning, but that was later ruled out.\n\nAmid fears of an epidemic in the township, the Centers for Disease\nControl (CDC) reported that the latest victim had died of septicemia\ncaused by inflammation of the pancreas and cellulitis, according to\nprosecutors. The families of people at first suspected murder, but\nhave since accepted the findings of the experts, prosecutors said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is no description of the clinical illnesses here. In the initial forensics tests,\ntraces of botulism toxin were found in 4 of the bodies, but it was not\ncertain whether the toxins were from eating homemade vegetable\npreserves, said Chu Kun-mao, chief of the Nantou District Prosecutors\nOffice.\n\nIt will require further microbiology tests by Department of Health\nagencies to confirm the results, he said. The Institute of Forensic\nMedicine will deliver the final report on the causes of death after\nthe results of the microbiology tests become available 26 Jul 2011,\nthe prosecutor said.\n\nOn 6 Jul 2011, 4 residents of Hsinyi Township in Nantou died\nsuddenly. The families of people at first suspected murder, but\nhave since accepted the findings of the experts, prosecutors said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is no description of the clinical illnesses here. In the initial forensics tests,\ntraces of botulism toxin were found in 4 of the bodies, but it was not\ncertain whether the toxins were from eating homemade vegetable\npreserves, said Chu Kun-mao, chief of the Nantou District Prosecutors\nOffice.\n\nIt will require further microbiology tests by Department of Health\nagencies to confirm the results, he said. The Institute of Forensic\nMedicine will deliver the final report on the causes of death after\nthe results of the microbiology tests become available 26 Jul 2011,\nthe prosecutor said.\n\nOn 6 Jul 2011, 4 residents of Hsinyi Township in Nantou died\nsuddenly. It was found that the people, a vegetable farmer, his wife,\nand their 2 helpers, had shared a meal earlier in the day. 2 days\nlater, another Hsinyi resident died suddenly from what was initially\nthought to be food poisoning, but that was later ruled out.\n\nAmid fears of an epidemic in the township, the Centers for Disease\nControl (CDC) reported that the latest victim had died of septicemia\ncaused by inflammation of the pancreas and cellulitis, according to\nprosecutors. The families of people at first suspected murder, but\nhave since accepted the findings of the experts, prosecutors said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is no description of the clinical illnesses here. Botulism is\na symmetrical flaccid paralysis, which usually begins with visual\ndisturbances related to extraocular muscle weakness beginning 18-36\nhours after ingestion of the food vehicle. - Mod.LL]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Taiwan can be seen at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/14He. - In the initial forensics tests,\ntraces of botulism toxin were found in 4 of the bodies, but it was not\ncertain whether the toxins were from eating homemade vegetable\npreserves, said Chu Kun-mao, chief of the Nantou District Prosecutors\nOffice.\n\nIt will require further microbiology tests by Department of Health\nagencies to confirm the results, he said. The Institute of Forensic\nMedicine will deliver the final report on the causes of death after\nthe results of the microbiology tests become available 26 Jul 2011,\nthe prosecutor said.\n\nOn 6 Jul 2011, 4 residents of Hsinyi Township in Nantou died\nsuddenly. It was found that the people, a vegetable farmer, his wife,\nand their 2 helpers, had shared a meal earlier in the day. 2 days\nlater, another Hsinyi resident died suddenly from what was initially\nthought to be food poisoning, but that was later ruled out.\n\nAmid fears of an epidemic in the township, the Centers for Disease\nControl (CDC) reported that the latest victim had died of septicemia\ncaused by inflammation of the pancreas and cellulitis, according to\nprosecutors. USA: (OH,GA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=779930", "date": "2010-10-25 17:00:04", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA (02): DRIED SEAFOOD, RISK, RECALL\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 21 Oct 2010\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) press release [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm230558.htm>\n\n\nForemost Foods, International, Inc. of Pomona, California, is issuing\na voluntary recall on certain Tomi brand dried seafood products\nbecause they have the potential to be contaminated with _Clostridium\nbotulinum_, a bacterium which can cause life-threatening illness or\ndeath. Consumers are warned not to use the product even if it does\nnot look or smell spoiled. The products were manufactured by Kien\nLong Seafood Company Ltd. of Viet Nam.\n\nBotulism, a potentially fatal form of food poisoning, can cause the\nfollowing symptoms: general weakness, dizziness, double-vision, and\ntrouble with speaking or swallowing. Difficulty in breathing,\nweakness of other muscles, abdominal distension, and constipation may\nalso be common symptoms. People experiencing these problems should\nseek immediate medical attention.\n\nThese products were distributed in the States of California, Nevada,\nand Washington through Seafood City and Manila Seafood retail stores.\nThis recall involves products sold between 23 Sep 2009 and 20 Oct\n2010. The products are sold in a clear plastic package marked with\nthe specific descriptions listed below:\n\nUPC/Description/Pack/Size\n00000070187/Tomi Dried Baby Squid/40/8 oz\n79598107170/Tomi Dried Golden Threadfin Beam/40/8 OZ\n79598107166/Tomi Dried Indian Mackeral/40/8 OZ\n79598107164/Tomi Dried Trevally/40/8 OZ\n00000079922/Tomi Dried Shrimp Fry/40/4 OZ\n79598107175/Tomi Dried Tuyo Herring/40/4 OZ\n893509680073/Dried Anchovy (Kien Long)/40/3.5 OZ\n79598107173/Tomi Dried Round Scad/40/8 OZ\n79598107179/Tomi Dried Mullet Kapak/40/8 OZ\n\nThe recall was initiated after it was discovered that the\nmanufacturer of these products was not in compliance with US FDA food\nmanufacturing standards. There have been no illnesses reported to date.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food products. Most of the food recalls (as in\nthese cases) are related to defective preparation procedures, which\ncould, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable\nspores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA: canned tuna, risk, recall 20100708.2280\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: ex Norway, risk, recall 20100208.0427\n2009\n----\nBotulism, baby food, uneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall 20091020.3599\nBotulism, home canned green beans - USA: (WA) 20090310.0990\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (02): risk, recall 20090228.0827\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: (NY, NJ) risk, recall 20090120.0247\nBotulism, dessert sauces - USA: risk, recall 20090126.0343\n2008\n----\nBotulism, human, home canned green beans - USA: (OH) 20080919.2947\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\nBotulism, tea concentrate - USA: (MT, AZ) risk, recall 20080618.1903\nBotulism, pesto - USA: risk, recall 20080429.1474\nBotulism, canned bean salad - USA: risk, recall 20080229.0821\nBotulism, olive oil dip - USA: risk, recall 20080204.0448\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n...................................ll/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Consumers are warned not to use the product even if it does\nnot look or smell spoiled. The products were manufactured by Kien\nLong Seafood Company Ltd. of Viet Nam.\n\nBotulism, a potentially fatal form of food poisoning, can cause the\nfollowing symptoms: general weakness, dizziness, double-vision, and\ntrouble with speaking or swallowing. Difficulty in breathing,\nweakness of other muscles, abdominal distension, and constipation may\nalso be common symptoms. People experiencing these problems should\nseek immediate medical attention.\n\nThese products were distributed in the States of California, Nevada,\nand Washington through Seafood City and Manila Seafood retail stores.\nThis recall involves products sold between 23 Sep 2009 and 20 Oct\n2010. The products are sold in a clear plastic package marked with\nthe specific descriptions listed below:\n\nUPC/Description/Pack/Size\n00000070187/Tomi Dried Baby Squid/40/8 oz\n79598107170/Tomi Dried Golden Threadfin Beam/40/8 OZ\n79598107166/Tomi Dried Indian Mackeral/40/8 OZ\n79598107164/Tomi Dried Trevally/40/8 OZ\n00000079922/Tomi Dried Shrimp Fry/40/4 OZ\n79598107175/Tomi Dried Tuyo Herring/40/4 OZ\n893509680073/Dried Anchovy (Kien Long)/40/3.5 OZ\n79598107173/Tomi Dried Round Scad/40/8 OZ\n79598107179/Tomi Dried Mullet Kapak/40/8 OZ\n\nThe recall was initiated after it was discovered that the\nmanufacturer of these products was not in compliance with US FDA food\nmanufacturing standards. There have been no illnesses reported to date.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food products. Most of the food recalls (as in\nthese cases) are related to defective preparation procedures, which\ncould, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable\nspores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA: canned tuna, risk, recall 20100708.2280\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: ex Norway, risk, recall 20100208.0427\n2009\n----\nBotulism, baby food, uneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall 20091020.3599\nBotulism, home canned green beans - USA: (WA) 20090310.0990\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (02): risk, recall 20090228.0827\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: (NY, NJ) risk, recall 20090120.0247\nBotulism, dessert sauces - USA: risk, recall 20090126.0343\n2008\n----\nBotulism, human, home canned green beans - USA: (OH) 20080919.2947\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\nBotulism, tea concentrate - USA: (MT, AZ) risk, recall 20080618.1903\nBotulism, pesto - USA: risk, recall 20080429.1474\nBotulism, canned bean salad - USA: risk, recall 20080229.0821\nBotulism, olive oil dip - USA: risk, recall 20080204.0448\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n...................................ll/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
