Consumers are warned not to use the product even if it does\nnot look or smell spoiled. The products were manufactured by Kien\nLong Seafood Company Ltd. of Viet Nam.\n\nBotulism, a potentially fatal form of food poisoning, can cause the\nfollowing symptoms: general weakness, dizziness, double-vision, and\ntrouble with speaking or swallowing. Difficulty in breathing,\nweakness of other muscles, abdominal distension, and constipation may\nalso be common symptoms. People experiencing these problems should\nseek immediate medical attention.\n\nThese products were distributed in the States of California, Nevada,\nand Washington through Seafood City and Manila Seafood retail stores.\nThis recall involves products sold between 23 Sep 2009 and 20 Oct\n2010. The products are sold in a clear plastic package marked with\nthe specific descriptions listed below:\n\nUPC/Description/Pack/Size\n00000070187/Tomi Dried Baby Squid/40/8 oz\n79598107170/Tomi Dried Golden Threadfin Beam/40/8 OZ\n79598107166/Tomi Dried Indian Mackeral/40/8 OZ\n79598107164/Tomi Dried Trevally/40/8 OZ\n00000079922/Tomi Dried Shrimp Fry/40/4 OZ\n79598107175/Tomi Dried Tuyo Herring/40/4 OZ\n893509680073/Dried Anchovy (Kien Long)/40/3.5 OZ\n79598107173/Tomi Dried Round Scad/40/8 OZ\n79598107179/Tomi Dried Mullet Kapak/40/8 OZ\n\nThe recall was initiated after it was discovered that the\nmanufacturer of these products was not in compliance with US FDA food\nmanufacturing standards. There have been no illnesses reported to date.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food products. Most of the food recalls (as in\nthese cases) are related to defective preparation procedures, which\ncould, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable\nspores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism - USA: canned tuna, risk, recall 20100708.2280\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: ex Norway, risk, recall 20100208.0427\n2009\n----\nBotulism, baby food, uneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall 20091020.3599\nBotulism, home canned green beans - USA: (WA) 20090310.0990\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (02): risk, recall 20090228.0827\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: (NY, NJ) risk, recall 20090120.0247\nBotulism, dessert sauces - USA: risk, recall 20090126.0343\n2008\n----\nBotulism, human, home canned green beans - USA: (OH) 20080919.2947\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\nBotulism, tea concentrate - USA: (MT, AZ) risk, recall 20080618.1903\nBotulism, pesto - USA: risk, recall 20080429.1474\nBotulism, canned bean salad - USA: risk, recall 20080229.0821\nBotulism, olive oil dip - USA: risk, recall 20080204.0448\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n...................................ll/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Consumers are warned not to use the product even if it does\nnot look or smell spoiled. There have been no illnesses reported to date.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food products. The\nFDA has specific guidelines on canned foods and the sealing process\nand the tuna recalled did not meet those standards.\n\nThese products were distributed in 10 states including Wisconsin,\nNebraska, Utah, Pennsylvania, New York, Maine, Colorado, Indiana,\nCalifornia and Oregon. The distribution dates were in February and\nMay [2010]. The 12 ounce Chicken of the Sea solid white tuna packed\nin water has a upc code of 4800000262, \"Best By Date 2/10/2014\" and\nproduct code 7OA1E ASWAB, 7OA2E ASWAB, 7OA3E ASWAB, 7OA4E ASWAB,\n7OA5E ASWAB, 7OAEE ASWAB, or 7OAFE ASWAB. The best by dates and\nproduct code numbers are imprinted on the bottom of the cans. No\nother Chicken of the Sea products are affected by this recall.\n\nThere have been no reports of sickness identified with the\nconsumption of this product.\n\nCanned food with loose seals can spoil quickly and has the potential\nto cause sickness. Although rare, botulism can sometimes be found in\nimproperly sealed canned foods and according to an FDA fact sheet on\nbotulism, canned fish has been identified as a food that is commonly\ncontaminated.\n\n[Byline: Vanessa Houk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food products. Most of the food recalls (as in\nthese cases) are related to defective preparation procedures, which\ncould, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable\nspores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: ex Norway, risk, recall 20100208.0427\n2009\n----\nBotulism, baby food, uneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall 20091020.3599\nBotulism, home canned green beans - USA: (WA) 20090310.0990\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (02): risk, recall 20090228.0827\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: (NY, NJ) risk, recall 20090120.0247\nBotulism, dessert sauces - USA: risk, recall 20090126.0343\n2008\n----\nBotulism, human, home canned green beans - USA: (OH) 20080919.2947\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\nBotulism, tea concentrate - USA: (MT, AZ) risk, recall 20080618.1903\nBotulism, pesto - USA: risk, recall 20080429.1474\nBotulism, canned bean salad - USA: risk, recall 20080229.0821\nBotulism, olive oil dip - USA: risk, recall 20080204.0448\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n...................................ll/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Spain: (CM), water birds, susp., RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=482843", "date": "2010-07-08 17:00:03", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: CANNED TUNA, RISK, RECALL\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 2 Jul 2010\nSource: Examiner.com [edited]\n<http://www.examiner.com/x-38960-Ashland-Frugal-Living-Examiner~y2010m7d2-Food-recall-26520-cans-of-Chicken-of-the-Sea-Tuna-recalled-over-Botulism-concerns-in-10-states>\n\n\nOn 1 Jul 2010, Tri-Union Seafoods announced a recall of Chicken of\nthe Sea 12 ounce cans of solid white tuna packed in water, citing\nthat a production error caused some issues with proper sealing. The\nFDA has specific guidelines on canned foods and the sealing process\nand the tuna recalled did not meet those standards.\n\nThese products were distributed in 10 states including Wisconsin,\nNebraska, Utah, Pennsylvania, New York, Maine, Colorado, Indiana,\nCalifornia and Oregon. The distribution dates were in February and\nMay [2010]. The 12 ounce Chicken of the Sea solid white tuna packed\nin water has a upc code of 4800000262, \"Best By Date 2/10/2014\" and\nproduct code 7OA1E ASWAB, 7OA2E ASWAB, 7OA3E ASWAB, 7OA4E ASWAB,\n7OA5E ASWAB, 7OAEE ASWAB, or 7OAFE ASWAB. The best by dates and\nproduct code numbers are imprinted on the bottom of the cans. No\nother Chicken of the Sea products are affected by this recall.\n\nThere have been no reports of sickness identified with the\nconsumption of this product.\n\nCanned food with loose seals can spoil quickly and has the potential\nto cause sickness. Although rare, botulism can sometimes be found in\nimproperly sealed canned foods and according to an FDA fact sheet on\nbotulism, canned fish has been identified as a food that is commonly\ncontaminated.\n\n[Byline: Vanessa Houk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food products. Most of the food recalls (as in\nthese cases) are related to defective preparation procedures, which\ncould, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable\nspores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: ex Norway, risk, recall 20100208.0427\n2009\n----\nBotulism, baby food, uneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall 20091020.3599\nBotulism, home canned green beans - USA: (WA) 20090310.0990\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (02): risk, recall 20090228.0827\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: (NY, NJ) risk, recall 20090120.0247\nBotulism, dessert sauces - USA: risk, recall 20090126.0343\n2008\n----\nBotulism, human, home canned green beans - USA: (OH) 20080919.2947\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\nBotulism, tea concentrate - USA: (MT, AZ) risk, recall 20080618.1903\nBotulism, pesto - USA: risk, recall 20080429.1474\nBotulism, canned bean salad - USA: risk, recall 20080229.0821\nBotulism, olive oil dip - USA: risk, recall 20080204.0448\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n...................................ll/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA: canned tuna, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=461735", "date": "2010-07-08 17:00:03", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: CANNED TUNA, RISK, RECALL\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 2 Jul 2010\nSource: Examiner.com [edited]\n<http://www.examiner.com/x-38960-Ashland-Frugal-Living-Examiner~y2010m7d2-Food-recall-26520-cans-of-Chicken-of-the-Sea-Tuna-recalled-over-Botulism-concerns-in-10-states>\n\n\nOn 1 Jul 2010, Tri-Union Seafoods announced a recall of Chicken of\nthe Sea 12 ounce cans of solid white tuna packed in water, citing\nthat a production error caused some issues with proper sealing. The\nFDA has specific guidelines on canned foods and the sealing process\nand the tuna recalled did not meet those standards.\n\nThese products were distributed in 10 states including Wisconsin,\nNebraska, Utah, Pennsylvania, New York, Maine, Colorado, Indiana,\nCalifornia and Oregon. The distribution dates were in February and\nMay [2010]. The 12 ounce Chicken of the Sea solid white tuna packed\nin water has a upc code of 4800000262, \"Best By Date 2/10/2014\" and\nproduct code 7OA1E ASWAB, 7OA2E ASWAB, 7OA3E ASWAB, 7OA4E ASWAB,\n7OA5E ASWAB, 7OAEE ASWAB, or 7OAFE ASWAB. The best by dates and\nproduct code numbers are imprinted on the bottom of the cans. No\nother Chicken of the Sea products are affected by this recall.\n\nThere have been no reports of sickness identified with the\nconsumption of this product.\n\nCanned food with loose seals can spoil quickly and has the potential\nto cause sickness. Although rare, botulism can sometimes be found in\nimproperly sealed canned foods and according to an FDA fact sheet on\nbotulism, canned fish has been identified as a food that is commonly\ncontaminated.\n\n[Byline: Vanessa Houk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food products. Most of the food recalls (as in\nthese cases) are related to defective preparation procedures, which\ncould, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable\nspores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: ex Norway, risk, recall 20100208.0427\n2009\n----\nBotulism, baby food, uneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall 20091020.3599\nBotulism, home canned green beans - USA: (WA) 20090310.0990\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (02): risk, recall 20090228.0827\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: (NY, NJ) risk, recall 20090120.0247\nBotulism, dessert sauces - USA: risk, recall 20090126.0343\n2008\n----\nBotulism, human, home canned green beans - USA: (OH) 20080919.2947\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\nBotulism, tea concentrate - USA: (MT, AZ) risk, recall 20080618.1903\nBotulism, pesto - USA: risk, recall 20080429.1474\nBotulism, canned bean salad - USA: risk, recall 20080229.0821\nBotulism, olive oil dip - USA: risk, recall 20080204.0448\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n...................................ll/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (02): (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=454051", "date": "2010-07-08 17:00:03", "main_text": "BOTULISM - USA: CANNED TUNA, RISK, RECALL\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 2 Jul 2010\nSource: Examiner.com [edited]\n<http://www.examiner.com/x-38960-Ashland-Frugal-Living-Examiner~y2010m7d2-Food-recall-26520-cans-of-Chicken-of-the-Sea-Tuna-recalled-over-Botulism-concerns-in-10-states>\n\n\nOn 1 Jul 2010, Tri-Union Seafoods announced a recall of Chicken of\nthe Sea 12 ounce cans of solid white tuna packed in water, citing\nthat a production error caused some issues with proper sealing. The\nFDA has specific guidelines on canned foods and the sealing process\nand the tuna recalled did not meet those standards.\n\nThese products were distributed in 10 states including Wisconsin,\nNebraska, Utah, Pennsylvania, New York, Maine, Colorado, Indiana,\nCalifornia and Oregon. The distribution dates were in February and\nMay [2010]. The 12 ounce Chicken of the Sea solid white tuna packed\nin water has a upc code of 4800000262, \"Best By Date 2/10/2014\" and\nproduct code 7OA1E ASWAB, 7OA2E ASWAB, 7OA3E ASWAB, 7OA4E ASWAB,\n7OA5E ASWAB, 7OAEE ASWAB, or 7OAFE ASWAB. The best by dates and\nproduct code numbers are imprinted on the bottom of the cans. No\nother Chicken of the Sea products are affected by this recall.\n\nThere have been no reports of sickness identified with the\nconsumption of this product.\n\nCanned food with loose seals can spoil quickly and has the potential\nto cause sickness. Although rare, botulism can sometimes be found in\nimproperly sealed canned foods and according to an FDA fact sheet on\nbotulism, canned fish has been identified as a food that is commonly\ncontaminated.\n\n[Byline: Vanessa Houk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food products. Most of the food recalls (as in\nthese cases) are related to defective preparation procedures, which\ncould, but not necessarily do, result in the germination of viable\nspores of _Clostridium botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: ex Norway, risk, recall 20100208.0427\n2009\n----\nBotulism, baby food, uneviscerated fish - USA: risk, recall 20091020.3599\nBotulism, home canned green beans - USA: (WA) 20090310.0990\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (02): risk, recall 20090228.0827\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: (NY, NJ) risk, recall 20090120.0247\nBotulism, dessert sauces - USA: risk, recall 20090126.0343\n2008\n----\nBotulism, human, home canned green beans - USA: (OH) 20080919.2947\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\nBotulism, tea concentrate - USA: (MT, AZ) risk, recall 20080618.1903\nBotulism, pesto - USA: risk, recall 20080429.1474\nBotulism, canned bean salad - USA: risk, recall 20080229.0821\nBotulism, olive oil dip - USA: risk, recall 20080204.0448\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n...................................ll/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A 2nd case is\nsuspected. Both individuals, a man and a woman, are hospitalized and\non ventilators.\n\nThe individuals became ill in December 2009, said Marianne Patnode,\ncommunicable disease services coordinator for the Yakima Health\nDistrict. An educational outreach campaign has been underway to warn\nintravenous drug users that they are at risk from a contaminated\nsupply of heroin.\n\nPatnode said Yakima sees sporadic cases of botulism among intravenous\ndrug users who cut their heroin with a substance, often dirt or honey,\nthat contains the spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nWhile the 1st case was confirmed the 3rd week of December 2009, the\n2nd person's illness was too far along to be diagnosed. That is, the\npatient didn't have enough free toxin to be tested, but Patnode said\nclinically, physicians know the individual was poisoned with botulism.\nSymptoms include blurred vision and difficulty breathing. The illness\ncan progress to paralysis. Individuals have to be ventilated for\nseveral weeks and then weaned from the ventilators.\n\nYakima County's last significant outbreak of wound botulism was in\n2003, when there were 5 cases.\n\n[Byline: Leah Beth Ward]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a\nwound, germinate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the\nwound botulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs).\nThose IDUs who intentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or\nintramuscularly may be particularly vulnerable to infection.\n\nBlack tar heroin continues to be associated with clusters of wound\nbotulism, both in the USA and in Europe. This form of heroin is a\ngummy black substance usually produced in makeshift factories, mostly\nin Mexico, adjacent to opium poppy fields (1). It is generally\ninjected subcutaneously in a process referred to as skin popping. The\nlocal area may be unremarkable or may be necrotic or abscess-forming.\n\nThe tarry nature of the drug has led to a number of diluents\n(\"cutting\" agents), which have been postulated to be the source of the\n_Clostridium botulinum_ spores. In Passaro's study (1), the\ndevelopment of wound botulism was not affected by cleaning the skin,\ncleaning the injection paraphernalia or sharing needles.\n\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a descending,\nflaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the\nseverity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early\nin the course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results\nof microbiological testing.\n\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical\ndebridement are necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse\nafter antitoxin treatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl\npenicillin and metronidazole.\n\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of\nboth foodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by\ntoxin type A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis\nand a higher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation.\nAll toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic system at the\npresynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine\ntransmission across the neuromuscular junction.\n\nYakima County, Washington, as noted, has been the location for\nprevious clusters of cases (2; see ProMED postings \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20060329.0953 and \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20070603.1795).\n\n1. Passaro DJ, Werner SB, McGee J, et al: Wound botulism associated\nwith black tar heroin among injecting drug users. JAMA 1998; 279:\n859-63.\n\n2. CDC: Wound botulism among black tar heroin users - Washington,\n2003. MMWR 2003; 52: 885-6.\n\nA map of the state of Washington, which highlights Yakima County, can\nbe found at:\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/2/27/Map_of_Washington_highlighting_Yakima_County.png>. -\nMod.LL]\n\n[Photos of preparing a black tar heroin shot\n<http://takingdrugs.tumblr.com/post/143018524/submission-from-anon-1-2-gram-of-black-tar> -\nMod.JW]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland (02) 20081212.3907\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland 20081128.3753\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA: (CA) 20081121.3679\n2007\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20070603.1795\n2006\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20060329.0953\n2005\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Germany (NRW) 20051219.3636\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n...................................................ll/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2010-01-08 00:00:00", "2009-12-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yakima County 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WASHINGTON STATE", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima Herald - Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "430426", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, equine - USA: (TN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=430426", "date": "2010-01-13 20:00:02", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - USA: (WASHINGTON STATE)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 8 Jan 2010\nSource: Yakima Herald-Republic (WA) [edited]\n<http://www.yakima-herald.com/stories/2010/01/08/wound-botulism-case-reported-in-county>\n\n\nHealth officials said Friday [8 Jan 2010] there is a confirmed case of\nwound botulism in a heroin user in Yakima County. A 2nd case is\nsuspected. Both individuals, a man and a woman, are hospitalized and\non ventilators.\n\nThe individuals became ill in December 2009, said Marianne Patnode,\ncommunicable disease services coordinator for the Yakima Health\nDistrict. An educational outreach campaign has been underway to warn\nintravenous drug users that they are at risk from a contaminated\nsupply of heroin.\n\nPatnode said Yakima sees sporadic cases of botulism among intravenous\ndrug users who cut their heroin with a substance, often dirt or honey,\nthat contains the spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nWhile the 1st case was confirmed the 3rd week of December 2009, the\n2nd person's illness was too far along to be diagnosed. That is, the\npatient didn't have enough free toxin to be tested, but Patnode said\nclinically, physicians know the individual was poisoned with botulism.\nSymptoms include blurred vision and difficulty breathing. The illness\ncan progress to paralysis. Individuals have to be ventilated for\nseveral weeks and then weaned from the ventilators.\n\nYakima County's last significant outbreak of wound botulism was in\n2003, when there were 5 cases.\n\n[Byline: Leah Beth Ward]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a\nwound, germinate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the\nwound botulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs).\nThose IDUs who intentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or\nintramuscularly may be particularly vulnerable to infection.\n\nBlack tar heroin continues to be associated with clusters of wound\nbotulism, both in the USA and in Europe. This form of heroin is a\ngummy black substance usually produced in makeshift factories, mostly\nin Mexico, adjacent to opium poppy fields (1). It is generally\ninjected subcutaneously in a process referred to as skin popping. The\nlocal area may be unremarkable or may be necrotic or abscess-forming.\n\nThe tarry nature of the drug has led to a number of diluents\n(\"cutting\" agents), which have been postulated to be the source of the\n_Clostridium botulinum_ spores. In Passaro's study (1), the\ndevelopment of wound botulism was not affected by cleaning the skin,\ncleaning the injection paraphernalia or sharing needles.\n\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a descending,\nflaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the\nseverity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early\nin the course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results\nof microbiological testing.\n\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical\ndebridement are necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse\nafter antitoxin treatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl\npenicillin and metronidazole.\n\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of\nboth foodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by\ntoxin type A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis\nand a higher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation.\nAll toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic system at the\npresynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine\ntransmission across the neuromuscular junction.\n\nYakima County, Washington, as noted, has been the location for\nprevious clusters of cases (2; see ProMED postings \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20060329.0953 and \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20070603.1795).\n\n1. Passaro DJ, Werner SB, McGee J, et al: Wound botulism associated\nwith black tar heroin among injecting drug users. JAMA 1998; 279:\n859-63.\n\n2. CDC: Wound botulism among black tar heroin users - Washington,\n2003. MMWR 2003; 52: 885-6.\n\nA map of the state of Washington, which highlights Yakima County, can\nbe found at:\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/2/27/Map_of_Washington_highlighting_Yakima_County.png>. -\nMod.LL]\n\n[Photos of preparing a black tar heroin shot\n<http://takingdrugs.tumblr.com/post/143018524/submission-from-anon-1-2-gram-of-black-tar> -\nMod.JW]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland (02) 20081212.3907\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland 20081128.3753\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA: (CA) 20081121.3679\n2007\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20070603.1795\n2006\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20060329.0953\n2005\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Germany (NRW) 20051219.3636\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n...................................................ll/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2010-01-08 00:00:00", "2009-12-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yakima County 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WASHINGTON STATE", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima Herald - Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "407021", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism, equine, bovine - USA (02): (WI), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=407021", "date": "2010-01-13 20:00:02", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - USA: (WASHINGTON STATE)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 8 Jan 2010\nSource: Yakima Herald-Republic (WA) [edited]\n<http://www.yakima-herald.com/stories/2010/01/08/wound-botulism-case-reported-in-county>\n\n\nHealth officials said Friday [8 Jan 2010] there is a confirmed case of\nwound botulism in a heroin user in Yakima County. A 2nd case is\nsuspected. Both individuals, a man and a woman, are hospitalized and\non ventilators.\n\nThe individuals became ill in December 2009, said Marianne Patnode,\ncommunicable disease services coordinator for the Yakima Health\nDistrict. An educational outreach campaign has been underway to warn\nintravenous drug users that they are at risk from a contaminated\nsupply of heroin.\n\nPatnode said Yakima sees sporadic cases of botulism among intravenous\ndrug users who cut their heroin with a substance, often dirt or honey,\nthat contains the spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nWhile the 1st case was confirmed the 3rd week of December 2009, the\n2nd person's illness was too far along to be diagnosed. That is, the\npatient didn't have enough free toxin to be tested, but Patnode said\nclinically, physicians know the individual was poisoned with botulism.\nSymptoms include blurred vision and difficulty breathing. The illness\ncan progress to paralysis. Individuals have to be ventilated for\nseveral weeks and then weaned from the ventilators.\n\nYakima County's last significant outbreak of wound botulism was in\n2003, when there were 5 cases.\n\n[Byline: Leah Beth Ward]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a\nwound, germinate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the\nwound botulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs).\nThose IDUs who intentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or\nintramuscularly may be particularly vulnerable to infection.\n\nBlack tar heroin continues to be associated with clusters of wound\nbotulism, both in the USA and in Europe. This form of heroin is a\ngummy black substance usually produced in makeshift factories, mostly\nin Mexico, adjacent to opium poppy fields (1). It is generally\ninjected subcutaneously in a process referred to as skin popping. The\nlocal area may be unremarkable or may be necrotic or abscess-forming.\n\nThe tarry nature of the drug has led to a number of diluents\n(\"cutting\" agents), which have been postulated to be the source of the\n_Clostridium botulinum_ spores. In Passaro's study (1), the\ndevelopment of wound botulism was not affected by cleaning the skin,\ncleaning the injection paraphernalia or sharing needles.\n\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a descending,\nflaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the\nseverity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early\nin the course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results\nof microbiological testing.\n\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical\ndebridement are necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse\nafter antitoxin treatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl\npenicillin and metronidazole.\n\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of\nboth foodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by\ntoxin type A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis\nand a higher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation.\nAll toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic system at the\npresynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine\ntransmission across the neuromuscular junction.\n\nYakima County, Washington, as noted, has been the location for\nprevious clusters of cases (2; see ProMED postings \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20060329.0953 and \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20070603.1795).\n\n1. Passaro DJ, Werner SB, McGee J, et al: Wound botulism associated\nwith black tar heroin among injecting drug users. JAMA 1998; 279:\n859-63.\n\n2. CDC: Wound botulism among black tar heroin users - Washington,\n2003. MMWR 2003; 52: 885-6.\n\nA map of the state of Washington, which highlights Yakima County, can\nbe found at:\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/2/27/Map_of_Washington_highlighting_Yakima_County.png>. -\nMod.LL]\n\n[Photos of preparing a black tar heroin shot\n<http://takingdrugs.tumblr.com/post/143018524/submission-from-anon-1-2-gram-of-black-tar> -\nMod.JW]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland (02) 20081212.3907\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland 20081128.3753\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA: (CA) 20081121.3679\n2007\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20070603.1795\n2006\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20060329.0953\n2005\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Germany (NRW) 20051219.3636\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n...................................................ll/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A 2nd case is\nsuspected. Both individuals, a man and a woman, are hospitalized and\non ventilators.\n\nThe individuals became ill in December 2009, said Marianne Patnode,\ncommunicable disease services coordinator for the Yakima Health\nDistrict. An educational outreach campaign has been underway to warn\nintravenous drug users that they are at risk from a contaminated\nsupply of heroin.\n\nPatnode said Yakima sees sporadic cases of botulism among intravenous\ndrug users who cut their heroin with a substance, often dirt or honey,\nthat contains the spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nWhile the 1st case was confirmed the 3rd week of December 2009, the\n2nd person's illness was too far along to be diagnosed. That is, the\npatient didn't have enough free toxin to be tested, but Patnode said\nclinically, physicians know the individual was poisoned with botulism.\nSymptoms include blurred vision and difficulty breathing. The illness\ncan progress to paralysis. Individuals have to be ventilated for\nseveral weeks and then weaned from the ventilators.\n\nYakima County's last significant outbreak of wound botulism was in\n2003, when there were 5 cases.\n\n[Byline: Leah Beth Ward]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a\nwound, germinate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the\nwound botulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs).\nThose IDUs who intentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or\nintramuscularly may be particularly vulnerable to infection.\n\nBlack tar heroin continues to be associated with clusters of wound\nbotulism, both in the USA and in Europe. This form of heroin is a\ngummy black substance usually produced in makeshift factories, mostly\nin Mexico, adjacent to opium poppy fields (1). It is generally\ninjected subcutaneously in a process referred to as skin popping. The\nlocal area may be unremarkable or may be necrotic or abscess-forming.\n\nThe tarry nature of the drug has led to a number of diluents\n(\"cutting\" agents), which have been postulated to be the source of the\n_Clostridium botulinum_ spores. In Passaro's study (1), the\ndevelopment of wound botulism was not affected by cleaning the skin,\ncleaning the injection paraphernalia or sharing needles.\n\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a descending,\nflaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the\nseverity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early\nin the course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results\nof microbiological testing.\n\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical\ndebridement are necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse\nafter antitoxin treatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl\npenicillin and metronidazole.\n\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of\nboth foodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by\ntoxin type A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis\nand a higher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation.\nAll toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic system at the\npresynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine\ntransmission across the neuromuscular junction.\n\nYakima County, Washington, as noted, has been the location for\nprevious clusters of cases (2; see ProMED postings \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20060329.0953 and \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20070603.1795).\n\n1. Passaro DJ, Werner SB, McGee J, et al: Wound botulism associated\nwith black tar heroin among injecting drug users. JAMA 1998; 279:\n859-63.\n\n2. CDC: Wound botulism among black tar heroin users - Washington,\n2003. MMWR 2003; 52: 885-6.\n\nA map of the state of Washington, which highlights Yakima County, can\nbe found at:\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/2/27/Map_of_Washington_highlighting_Yakima_County.png>. -\nMod.LL]\n\n[Photos of preparing a black tar heroin shot\n<http://takingdrugs.tumblr.com/post/143018524/submission-from-anon-1-2-gram-of-black-tar> -\nMod.JW]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland (02) 20081212.3907\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland 20081128.3753\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA: (CA) 20081121.3679\n2007\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20070603.1795\n2006\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20060329.0953\n2005\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Germany (NRW) 20051219.3636\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n...................................................ll/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A 2nd case is\nsuspected. Both individuals, a man and a woman, are hospitalized and\non ventilators.\n\nThe individuals became ill in December 2009, said Marianne Patnode,\ncommunicable disease services coordinator for the Yakima Health\nDistrict. An educational outreach campaign has been underway to warn\nintravenous drug users that they are at risk from a contaminated\nsupply of heroin.\n\nPatnode said Yakima sees sporadic cases of botulism among intravenous\ndrug users who cut their heroin with a substance, often dirt or honey,\nthat contains the spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nWhile the 1st case was confirmed the 3rd week of December 2009, the\n2nd person's illness was too far along to be diagnosed. That is, the\npatient didn't have enough free toxin to be tested, but Patnode said\nclinically, physicians know the individual was poisoned with botulism.\nSymptoms include blurred vision and difficulty breathing. The illness\ncan progress to paralysis. Individuals have to be ventilated for\nseveral weeks and then weaned from the ventilators.\n\nYakima County's last significant outbreak of wound botulism was in\n2003, when there were 5 cases.\n\n[Byline: Leah Beth Ward]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a\nwound, germinate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the\nwound botulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs).\nThose IDUs who intentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or\nintramuscularly may be particularly vulnerable to infection.\n\nBlack tar heroin continues to be associated with clusters of wound\nbotulism, both in the USA and in Europe. This form of heroin is a\ngummy black substance usually produced in makeshift factories, mostly\nin Mexico, adjacent to opium poppy fields (1). It is generally\ninjected subcutaneously in a process referred to as skin popping. The\nlocal area may be unremarkable or may be necrotic or abscess-forming.\n\nThe tarry nature of the drug has led to a number of diluents\n(\"cutting\" agents), which have been postulated to be the source of the\n_Clostridium botulinum_ spores. In Passaro's study (1), the\ndevelopment of wound botulism was not affected by cleaning the skin,\ncleaning the injection paraphernalia or sharing needles.\n\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a descending,\nflaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the\nseverity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early\nin the course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results\nof microbiological testing.\n\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical\ndebridement are necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse\nafter antitoxin treatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl\npenicillin and metronidazole.\n\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of\nboth foodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by\ntoxin type A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis\nand a higher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation.\nAll toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic system at the\npresynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine\ntransmission across the neuromuscular junction.\n\nYakima County, Washington, as noted, has been the location for\nprevious clusters of cases (2; see ProMED postings \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20060329.0953 and \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20070603.1795).\n\n1. Passaro DJ, Werner SB, McGee J, et al: Wound botulism associated\nwith black tar heroin among injecting drug users. JAMA 1998; 279:\n859-63.\n\n2. CDC: Wound botulism among black tar heroin users - Washington,\n2003. MMWR 2003; 52: 885-6.\n\nA map of the state of Washington, which highlights Yakima County, can\nbe found at:\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/2/27/Map_of_Washington_highlighting_Yakima_County.png>. -\nMod.LL]\n\n[Photos of preparing a black tar heroin shot\n<http://takingdrugs.tumblr.com/post/143018524/submission-from-anon-1-2-gram-of-black-tar> -\nMod.JW]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland (02) 20081212.3907\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland 20081128.3753\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA: (CA) 20081121.3679\n2007\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20070603.1795\n2006\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20060329.0953\n2005\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Germany (NRW) 20051219.3636\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n...................................................ll/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2010-01-08 00:00:00", "2009-12-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yakima County 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WASHINGTON STATE", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima Herald - Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "378325", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, canine - USA: (FL) susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=378325", "date": "2010-01-13 20:00:02", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - USA: (WASHINGTON STATE)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 8 Jan 2010\nSource: Yakima Herald-Republic (WA) [edited]\n<http://www.yakima-herald.com/stories/2010/01/08/wound-botulism-case-reported-in-county>\n\n\nHealth officials said Friday [8 Jan 2010] there is a confirmed case of\nwound botulism in a heroin user in Yakima County. A 2nd case is\nsuspected. Both individuals, a man and a woman, are hospitalized and\non ventilators.\n\nThe individuals became ill in December 2009, said Marianne Patnode,\ncommunicable disease services coordinator for the Yakima Health\nDistrict. An educational outreach campaign has been underway to warn\nintravenous drug users that they are at risk from a contaminated\nsupply of heroin.\n\nPatnode said Yakima sees sporadic cases of botulism among intravenous\ndrug users who cut their heroin with a substance, often dirt or honey,\nthat contains the spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nWhile the 1st case was confirmed the 3rd week of December 2009, the\n2nd person's illness was too far along to be diagnosed. That is, the\npatient didn't have enough free toxin to be tested, but Patnode said\nclinically, physicians know the individual was poisoned with botulism.\nSymptoms include blurred vision and difficulty breathing. The illness\ncan progress to paralysis. Individuals have to be ventilated for\nseveral weeks and then weaned from the ventilators.\n\nYakima County's last significant outbreak of wound botulism was in\n2003, when there were 5 cases.\n\n[Byline: Leah Beth Ward]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a\nwound, germinate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the\nwound botulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs).\nThose IDUs who intentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or\nintramuscularly may be particularly vulnerable to infection.\n\nBlack tar heroin continues to be associated with clusters of wound\nbotulism, both in the USA and in Europe. This form of heroin is a\ngummy black substance usually produced in makeshift factories, mostly\nin Mexico, adjacent to opium poppy fields (1). It is generally\ninjected subcutaneously in a process referred to as skin popping. The\nlocal area may be unremarkable or may be necrotic or abscess-forming.\n\nThe tarry nature of the drug has led to a number of diluents\n(\"cutting\" agents), which have been postulated to be the source of the\n_Clostridium botulinum_ spores. In Passaro's study (1), the\ndevelopment of wound botulism was not affected by cleaning the skin,\ncleaning the injection paraphernalia or sharing needles.\n\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a descending,\nflaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the\nseverity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early\nin the course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results\nof microbiological testing.\n\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical\ndebridement are necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse\nafter antitoxin treatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl\npenicillin and metronidazole.\n\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of\nboth foodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by\ntoxin type A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis\nand a higher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation.\nAll toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic system at the\npresynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine\ntransmission across the neuromuscular junction.\n\nYakima County, Washington, as noted, has been the location for\nprevious clusters of cases (2; see ProMED postings \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20060329.0953 and \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20070603.1795).\n\n1. Passaro DJ, Werner SB, McGee J, et al: Wound botulism associated\nwith black tar heroin among injecting drug users. JAMA 1998; 279:\n859-63.\n\n2. CDC: Wound botulism among black tar heroin users - Washington,\n2003. MMWR 2003; 52: 885-6.\n\nA map of the state of Washington, which highlights Yakima County, can\nbe found at:\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/2/27/Map_of_Washington_highlighting_Yakima_County.png>. -\nMod.LL]\n\n[Photos of preparing a black tar heroin shot\n<http://takingdrugs.tumblr.com/post/143018524/submission-from-anon-1-2-gram-of-black-tar> -\nMod.JW]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland (02) 20081212.3907\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland 20081128.3753\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA: (CA) 20081121.3679\n2007\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20070603.1795\n2006\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20060329.0953\n2005\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Germany (NRW) 20051219.3636\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n...................................................ll/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2010-01-08 00:00:00", "2009-12-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yakima County 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WASHINGTON STATE", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima Herald - Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "378155", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, uneviscerated fish - USA: ex Norway, risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=378155", "date": "2010-01-13 20:00:02", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - USA: (WASHINGTON STATE)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 8 Jan 2010\nSource: Yakima Herald-Republic (WA) [edited]\n<http://www.yakima-herald.com/stories/2010/01/08/wound-botulism-case-reported-in-county>\n\n\nHealth officials said Friday [8 Jan 2010] there is a confirmed case of\nwound botulism in a heroin user in Yakima County. A 2nd case is\nsuspected. Both individuals, a man and a woman, are hospitalized and\non ventilators.\n\nThe individuals became ill in December 2009, said Marianne Patnode,\ncommunicable disease services coordinator for the Yakima Health\nDistrict. An educational outreach campaign has been underway to warn\nintravenous drug users that they are at risk from a contaminated\nsupply of heroin.\n\nPatnode said Yakima sees sporadic cases of botulism among intravenous\ndrug users who cut their heroin with a substance, often dirt or honey,\nthat contains the spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nWhile the 1st case was confirmed the 3rd week of December 2009, the\n2nd person's illness was too far along to be diagnosed. That is, the\npatient didn't have enough free toxin to be tested, but Patnode said\nclinically, physicians know the individual was poisoned with botulism.\nSymptoms include blurred vision and difficulty breathing. The illness\ncan progress to paralysis. Individuals have to be ventilated for\nseveral weeks and then weaned from the ventilators.\n\nYakima County's last significant outbreak of wound botulism was in\n2003, when there were 5 cases.\n\n[Byline: Leah Beth Ward]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a\nwound, germinate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the\nwound botulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs).\nThose IDUs who intentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or\nintramuscularly may be particularly vulnerable to infection.\n\nBlack tar heroin continues to be associated with clusters of wound\nbotulism, both in the USA and in Europe. This form of heroin is a\ngummy black substance usually produced in makeshift factories, mostly\nin Mexico, adjacent to opium poppy fields (1). It is generally\ninjected subcutaneously in a process referred to as skin popping. The\nlocal area may be unremarkable or may be necrotic or abscess-forming.\n\nThe tarry nature of the drug has led to a number of diluents\n(\"cutting\" agents), which have been postulated to be the source of the\n_Clostridium botulinum_ spores. In Passaro's study (1), the\ndevelopment of wound botulism was not affected by cleaning the skin,\ncleaning the injection paraphernalia or sharing needles.\n\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a descending,\nflaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the\nseverity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early\nin the course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results\nof microbiological testing.\n\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical\ndebridement are necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse\nafter antitoxin treatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl\npenicillin and metronidazole.\n\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of\nboth foodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by\ntoxin type A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis\nand a higher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation.\nAll toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic system at the\npresynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine\ntransmission across the neuromuscular junction.\n\nYakima County, Washington, as noted, has been the location for\nprevious clusters of cases (2; see ProMED postings \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20060329.0953 and \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20070603.1795).\n\n1. Passaro DJ, Werner SB, McGee J, et al: Wound botulism associated\nwith black tar heroin among injecting drug users. JAMA 1998; 279:\n859-63.\n\n2. CDC: Wound botulism among black tar heroin users - Washington,\n2003. MMWR 2003; 52: 885-6.\n\nA map of the state of Washington, which highlights Yakima County, can\nbe found at:\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/2/27/Map_of_Washington_highlighting_Yakima_County.png>. -\nMod.LL]\n\n[Photos of preparing a black tar heroin shot\n<http://takingdrugs.tumblr.com/post/143018524/submission-from-anon-1-2-gram-of-black-tar> -\nMod.JW]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland (02) 20081212.3907\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland 20081128.3753\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA: (CA) 20081121.3679\n2007\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20070603.1795\n2006\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20060329.0953\n2005\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Germany (NRW) 20051219.3636\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n...................................................ll/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A 2nd case is\nsuspected. Both individuals, a man and a woman, are hospitalized and\non ventilators.\n\nThe individuals became ill in December 2009, said Marianne Patnode,\ncommunicable disease services coordinator for the Yakima Health\nDistrict. An educational outreach campaign has been underway to warn\nintravenous drug users that they are at risk from a contaminated\nsupply of heroin.\n\nPatnode said Yakima sees sporadic cases of botulism among intravenous\ndrug users who cut their heroin with a substance, often dirt or honey,\nthat contains the spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.\n\nWhile the 1st case was confirmed the 3rd week of December 2009, the\n2nd person's illness was too far along to be diagnosed. That is, the\npatient didn't have enough free toxin to be tested, but Patnode said\nclinically, physicians know the individual was poisoned with botulism.\nSymptoms include blurred vision and difficulty breathing. The illness\ncan progress to paralysis. Individuals have to be ventilated for\nseveral weeks and then weaned from the ventilators.\n\nYakima County's last significant outbreak of wound botulism was in\n2003, when there were 5 cases.\n\n[Byline: Leah Beth Ward]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a\nwound, germinate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the\nwound botulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs).\nThose IDUs who intentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or\nintramuscularly may be particularly vulnerable to infection.\n\nBlack tar heroin continues to be associated with clusters of wound\nbotulism, both in the USA and in Europe. This form of heroin is a\ngummy black substance usually produced in makeshift factories, mostly\nin Mexico, adjacent to opium poppy fields (1). It is generally\ninjected subcutaneously in a process referred to as skin popping. The\nlocal area may be unremarkable or may be necrotic or abscess-forming.\n\nThe tarry nature of the drug has led to a number of diluents\n(\"cutting\" agents), which have been postulated to be the source of the\n_Clostridium botulinum_ spores. In Passaro's study (1), the\ndevelopment of wound botulism was not affected by cleaning the skin,\ncleaning the injection paraphernalia or sharing needles.\n\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a descending,\nflaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the\nseverity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early\nin the course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results\nof microbiological testing.\n\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical\ndebridement are necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse\nafter antitoxin treatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl\npenicillin and metronidazole.\n\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of\nboth foodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by\ntoxin type A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis\nand a higher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation.\nAll toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic system at the\npresynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine\ntransmission across the neuromuscular junction.\n\nYakima County, Washington, as noted, has been the location for\nprevious clusters of cases (2; see ProMED postings \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20060329.0953 and \"Botulism, wound,\ndrug-related - USA (WA)\" 20070603.1795).\n\n1. Passaro DJ, Werner SB, McGee J, et al: Wound botulism associated\nwith black tar heroin among injecting drug users. JAMA 1998; 279:\n859-63.\n\n2. CDC: Wound botulism among black tar heroin users - Washington,\n2003. MMWR 2003; 52: 885-6.\n\nA map of the state of Washington, which highlights Yakima County, can\nbe found at:\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/2/27/Map_of_Washington_highlighting_Yakima_County.png>. -\nMod.LL]\n\n[Photos of preparing a black tar heroin shot\n<http://takingdrugs.tumblr.com/post/143018524/submission-from-anon-1-2-gram-of-black-tar> -\nMod.JW]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland (02) 20081212.3907\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Ireland 20081128.3753\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA: (CA) 20081121.3679\n2007\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20070603.1795\n2006\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20060329.0953\n2005\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Germany (NRW) 20051219.3636\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n...................................................ll/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2010-01-08 00:00:00", "2009-12-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yakima County 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WASHINGTON STATE", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yakima Herald - Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "335267", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, smoked Canadian fish - France ex Finland", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=335267", "date": "2009-07-08 11:00:08", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN, FISH - IRELAND: (CORK), SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 7 Jul 2009\nSource: Irish Examiner on-line [edited]\n<http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/botulism-likely-cause-of--deaths-at-the-lough-95753.html>\n\n\nBotulism likely cause of deaths at The Lough\n--------------------------------------------\nA strain of botulism, caused by bacteria emitting lethal toxins, seems\nthe most likely explanation for the large number of deaths of swans,\nducks and fish at The Lough in Cork.\n\nCork City Council's chief veterinary officer, Diarmuid Dooge, said\nboth [wild]fowl and fish would be affected by _Clostridium botulinum_,\na form of bacteria released from spores on the silt bed of the lake.\n\nMore than 30 previously healthy swans and ducks and 5 carp are\nsuspected to have been killed by the toxic bacteria attaching to\nvegetation that is eaten by both the birds and fish at the picturesque\nwildlife sanctuary.\n\nThe sprouting of the spores, and the subsequent release of toxins that\nattack the fish and birds' central nervous systems [In fact, the\nperipheral nervous system is affected. - Mod.AS], may be attributed to\nthe recent humidity and a lowering of the water level. These\nconditions will have encouraged the bacteria to \"flower.\"\n\nIt was initially thought that a virus had been transmitted to the\nresident fowl by a wild duck. But that has been ruled out following\ntests at the Regional Veterinary Laboratory at Model Farm Road. Avian\ninfluenza, more commonly known as the dreaded bird flu, was also\nquickly ruled out, leaving _Clostridium botulinum_ as the likely\nculprit.\n\nMr Dooge said it was vital that all carcasses were removed from the\nwater and the central island as quickly as possible to prevent the\nlethal disease from attacking more wildlife. He predicted more fowl\nwould die before the situation was brought under control. \"It is vital\nwe continue to remove all dead and dying birds. If maggots get onto a\ncarcass they will concentrate the toxins and make them easier to\nspread,\" he said.\n\nAs there is no laboratory in Ireland equipped to confirm cases of\nbotulism -- commonly known as a potentially lethal strain of food\npoisoning -- samples will have to be sent to Scotland and it is\nexpected it will take days before the results are known. \"We need\nconfirmation of this. We need a scientific explanation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nHe has also called in the aquatic services section at University\nCollege Cork to analyse the water quality at the 9-acre lake near\nTogher. \"It fits the pattern of _Clostridium botulinum_ as both ducks\nand fish are susceptible to it. We want to get on top of this as soon\nas possible. It is a dreadful situation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nThe chief veterinary officer has also held discussions on the problem\nwith the coarse angling club, which stocks the lake. The Lough is one\nof the premier carp fisheries in Ireland. About 2000 carp are in the\nlake and it attracts thousands of coarse anglers every year, providing\na welcome financial boost to the local economy.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNick Honhold\n4/5 Grandville\nEdinburgh\n<nick.honhold@gmail.com>\n\n[We are grateful to Dr Honhold for forwarding the above newswire,\nfurther to our RFI of Tue 7 Jul 2009.\n\nBotulism in waterfowl is generally caused by one of 2 toxin types.\nType E toxin is found primarily in decaying fish and causes\nintoxication in those feeding on them. It may also cause intoxication\nin humans.\n\nType C toxin, on the other hand, is not related to fish. It occurs in\ncarcasses of dead invertebrates, in the flesh of birds dying of\nbotulism, and in maggots feeding on toxic carcasses. Type C, which is\nregarded as responsible for most outbreaks in waterfowl world-wide,\ndoes not pose a risk to humans.\n\nLaboratory identification of the causative toxin in the Cork lake\noutbreak is anticipated soon.\n\nFor further background, subscribers are encouraged to read Mod TG\ncommentary in ProMED post 20090117.0197. For the location of The Lough\n(lake) in Cork, see\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?name=The%20Lough,%20Cork,%20Co.%20Cork,%20Republic%20of%20Ireland&g=&v=51.891,-8.488,5>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed die-off, swans - Ireland: (CK), RFI 20090707.2439\nBotulism, avian - Australia (02): (NSW) 20090121.0254\nBotulism, avian - Australia 20090117.0197\nBotulism, avian - Finland 20090117.0194\n2008\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): Great Lakes 20080817.2556\nUndiagnosed duck die-off - Cyprus: botulism susp 20060826.2430\n2004\n----\nBotulism, avian - South Africa 20041214.3306\nBotulism, avian - USA (AZ) 20041017.2822\nBotulism, avian - New Zealand 20040119.0218\n2003\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (NJ) 20030726.1833\n2002\n----\nBotulism, avian type E - USA, Canada 20020304.3678\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n1996\n----\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (05) 19961020.1759\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (04) 19961009.1713\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (03) 19961007.1702\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (2) 19961005.1682\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA 19961003.1667\n....................arn/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
