For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cork", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "328117", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Russia: (CL) cheese, susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=328117", "date": "2009-07-08 11:00:08", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN, FISH - IRELAND: (CORK), SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 7 Jul 2009\nSource: Irish Examiner on-line [edited]\n<http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/botulism-likely-cause-of--deaths-at-the-lough-95753.html>\n\n\nBotulism likely cause of deaths at The Lough\n--------------------------------------------\nA strain of botulism, caused by bacteria emitting lethal toxins, seems\nthe most likely explanation for the large number of deaths of swans,\nducks and fish at The Lough in Cork.\n\nCork City Council's chief veterinary officer, Diarmuid Dooge, said\nboth [wild]fowl and fish would be affected by _Clostridium botulinum_,\na form of bacteria released from spores on the silt bed of the lake.\n\nMore than 30 previously healthy swans and ducks and 5 carp are\nsuspected to have been killed by the toxic bacteria attaching to\nvegetation that is eaten by both the birds and fish at the picturesque\nwildlife sanctuary.\n\nThe sprouting of the spores, and the subsequent release of toxins that\nattack the fish and birds' central nervous systems [In fact, the\nperipheral nervous system is affected. - Mod.AS], may be attributed to\nthe recent humidity and a lowering of the water level. These\nconditions will have encouraged the bacteria to \"flower.\"\n\nIt was initially thought that a virus had been transmitted to the\nresident fowl by a wild duck. But that has been ruled out following\ntests at the Regional Veterinary Laboratory at Model Farm Road. Avian\ninfluenza, more commonly known as the dreaded bird flu, was also\nquickly ruled out, leaving _Clostridium botulinum_ as the likely\nculprit.\n\nMr Dooge said it was vital that all carcasses were removed from the\nwater and the central island as quickly as possible to prevent the\nlethal disease from attacking more wildlife. He predicted more fowl\nwould die before the situation was brought under control. \"It is vital\nwe continue to remove all dead and dying birds. If maggots get onto a\ncarcass they will concentrate the toxins and make them easier to\nspread,\" he said.\n\nAs there is no laboratory in Ireland equipped to confirm cases of\nbotulism -- commonly known as a potentially lethal strain of food\npoisoning -- samples will have to be sent to Scotland and it is\nexpected it will take days before the results are known. \"We need\nconfirmation of this. We need a scientific explanation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nHe has also called in the aquatic services section at University\nCollege Cork to analyse the water quality at the 9-acre lake near\nTogher. \"It fits the pattern of _Clostridium botulinum_ as both ducks\nand fish are susceptible to it. We want to get on top of this as soon\nas possible. It is a dreadful situation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nThe chief veterinary officer has also held discussions on the problem\nwith the coarse angling club, which stocks the lake. The Lough is one\nof the premier carp fisheries in Ireland. About 2000 carp are in the\nlake and it attracts thousands of coarse anglers every year, providing\na welcome financial boost to the local economy.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNick Honhold\n4/5 Grandville\nEdinburgh\n<nick.honhold@gmail.com>\n\n[We are grateful to Dr Honhold for forwarding the above newswire,\nfurther to our RFI of Tue 7 Jul 2009.\n\nBotulism in waterfowl is generally caused by one of 2 toxin types.\nType E toxin is found primarily in decaying fish and causes\nintoxication in those feeding on them. It may also cause intoxication\nin humans.\n\nType C toxin, on the other hand, is not related to fish. It occurs in\ncarcasses of dead invertebrates, in the flesh of birds dying of\nbotulism, and in maggots feeding on toxic carcasses. Type C, which is\nregarded as responsible for most outbreaks in waterfowl world-wide,\ndoes not pose a risk to humans.\n\nLaboratory identification of the causative toxin in the Cork lake\noutbreak is anticipated soon.\n\nFor further background, subscribers are encouraged to read Mod TG\ncommentary in ProMED post 20090117.0197. For the location of The Lough\n(lake) in Cork, see\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?name=The%20Lough,%20Cork,%20Co.%20Cork,%20Republic%20of%20Ireland&g=&v=51.891,-8.488,5>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed die-off, swans - Ireland: (CK), RFI 20090707.2439\nBotulism, avian - Australia (02): (NSW) 20090121.0254\nBotulism, avian - Australia 20090117.0197\nBotulism, avian - Finland 20090117.0194\n2008\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): Great Lakes 20080817.2556\nUndiagnosed duck die-off - Cyprus: botulism susp 20060826.2430\n2004\n----\nBotulism, avian - South Africa 20041214.3306\nBotulism, avian - USA (AZ) 20041017.2822\nBotulism, avian - New Zealand 20040119.0218\n2003\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (NJ) 20030726.1833\n2002\n----\nBotulism, avian type E - USA, Canada 20020304.3678\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n1996\n----\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (05) 19961020.1759\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (04) 19961009.1713\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (03) 19961007.1702\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (2) 19961005.1682\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA 19961003.1667\n....................arn/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Mod.AS], may be attributed to\nthe recent humidity and a lowering of the water level. These\nconditions will have encouraged the bacteria to \"flower.\"\n\nIt was initially thought that a virus had been transmitted to the\nresident fowl by a wild duck. But that has been ruled out following\ntests at the Regional Veterinary Laboratory at Model Farm Road. Avian\ninfluenza, more commonly known as the dreaded bird flu, was also\nquickly ruled out, leaving _Clostridium botulinum_ as the likely\nculprit.\n\nMr Dooge said it was vital that all carcasses were removed from the\nwater and the central island as quickly as possible to prevent the\nlethal disease from attacking more wildlife. He predicted more fowl\nwould die before the situation was brought under control. \"It is vital\nwe continue to remove all dead and dying birds. If maggots get onto a\ncarcass they will concentrate the toxins and make them easier to\nspread,\" he said.\n\nAs there is no laboratory in Ireland equipped to confirm cases of\nbotulism -- commonly known as a potentially lethal strain of food\npoisoning -- samples will have to be sent to Scotland and it is\nexpected it will take days before the results are known. \"We need\nconfirmation of this. We need a scientific explanation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nHe has also called in the aquatic services section at University\nCollege Cork to analyse the water quality at the 9-acre lake near\nTogher. \"It fits the pattern of _Clostridium botulinum_ as both ducks\nand fish are susceptible to it. We want to get on top of this as soon\nas possible. It is a dreadful situation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nThe chief veterinary officer has also held discussions on the problem\nwith the coarse angling club, which stocks the lake. The Lough is one\nof the premier carp fisheries in Ireland. About 2000 carp are in the\nlake and it attracts thousands of coarse anglers every year, providing\na welcome financial boost to the local economy.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNick Honhold\n4/5 Grandville\nEdinburgh\n<nick.honhold@gmail.com>\n\n[We are grateful to Dr Honhold for forwarding the above newswire,\nfurther to our RFI of Tue 7 Jul 2009.\n\nBotulism in waterfowl is generally caused by one of 2 toxin types.\nType E toxin is found primarily in decaying fish and causes\nintoxication in those feeding on them. It may also cause intoxication\nin humans.\n\nType C toxin, on the other hand, is not related to fish. It occurs in\ncarcasses of dead invertebrates, in the flesh of birds dying of\nbotulism, and in maggots feeding on toxic carcasses. Type C, which is\nregarded as responsible for most outbreaks in waterfowl world-wide,\ndoes not pose a risk to humans.\n\nLaboratory identification of the causative toxin in the Cork lake\noutbreak is anticipated soon.\n\nFor further background, subscribers are encouraged to read Mod TG\ncommentary in ProMED post 20090117.0197. Brazil: (SP) canned eggplant", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=327514", "date": "2009-07-08 11:00:08", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN, FISH - IRELAND: (CORK), SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 7 Jul 2009\nSource: Irish Examiner on-line [edited]\n<http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/botulism-likely-cause-of--deaths-at-the-lough-95753.html>\n\n\nBotulism likely cause of deaths at The Lough\n--------------------------------------------\nA strain of botulism, caused by bacteria emitting lethal toxins, seems\nthe most likely explanation for the large number of deaths of swans,\nducks and fish at The Lough in Cork.\n\nCork City Council's chief veterinary officer, Diarmuid Dooge, said\nboth [wild]fowl and fish would be affected by _Clostridium botulinum_,\na form of bacteria released from spores on the silt bed of the lake.\n\nMore than 30 previously healthy swans and ducks and 5 carp are\nsuspected to have been killed by the toxic bacteria attaching to\nvegetation that is eaten by both the birds and fish at the picturesque\nwildlife sanctuary.\n\nThe sprouting of the spores, and the subsequent release of toxins that\nattack the fish and birds' central nervous systems [In fact, the\nperipheral nervous system is affected. - Mod.AS], may be attributed to\nthe recent humidity and a lowering of the water level. These\nconditions will have encouraged the bacteria to \"flower.\"\n\nIt was initially thought that a virus had been transmitted to the\nresident fowl by a wild duck. But that has been ruled out following\ntests at the Regional Veterinary Laboratory at Model Farm Road. Avian\ninfluenza, more commonly known as the dreaded bird flu, was also\nquickly ruled out, leaving _Clostridium botulinum_ as the likely\nculprit.\n\nMr Dooge said it was vital that all carcasses were removed from the\nwater and the central island as quickly as possible to prevent the\nlethal disease from attacking more wildlife. He predicted more fowl\nwould die before the situation was brought under control. \"It is vital\nwe continue to remove all dead and dying birds. If maggots get onto a\ncarcass they will concentrate the toxins and make them easier to\nspread,\" he said.\n\nAs there is no laboratory in Ireland equipped to confirm cases of\nbotulism -- commonly known as a potentially lethal strain of food\npoisoning -- samples will have to be sent to Scotland and it is\nexpected it will take days before the results are known. \"We need\nconfirmation of this. We need a scientific explanation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nHe has also called in the aquatic services section at University\nCollege Cork to analyse the water quality at the 9-acre lake near\nTogher. \"It fits the pattern of _Clostridium botulinum_ as both ducks\nand fish are susceptible to it. We want to get on top of this as soon\nas possible. It is a dreadful situation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nThe chief veterinary officer has also held discussions on the problem\nwith the coarse angling club, which stocks the lake. The Lough is one\nof the premier carp fisheries in Ireland. About 2000 carp are in the\nlake and it attracts thousands of coarse anglers every year, providing\na welcome financial boost to the local economy.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNick Honhold\n4/5 Grandville\nEdinburgh\n<nick.honhold@gmail.com>\n\n[We are grateful to Dr Honhold for forwarding the above newswire,\nfurther to our RFI of Tue 7 Jul 2009.\n\nBotulism in waterfowl is generally caused by one of 2 toxin types.\nType E toxin is found primarily in decaying fish and causes\nintoxication in those feeding on them. It may also cause intoxication\nin humans.\n\nType C toxin, on the other hand, is not related to fish. It occurs in\ncarcasses of dead invertebrates, in the flesh of birds dying of\nbotulism, and in maggots feeding on toxic carcasses. Type C, which is\nregarded as responsible for most outbreaks in waterfowl world-wide,\ndoes not pose a risk to humans.\n\nLaboratory identification of the causative toxin in the Cork lake\noutbreak is anticipated soon.\n\nFor further background, subscribers are encouraged to read Mod TG\ncommentary in ProMED post 20090117.0197. For the location of The Lough\n(lake) in Cork, see\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?name=The%20Lough,%20Cork,%20Co.%20Cork,%20Republic%20of%20Ireland&g=&v=51.891,-8.488,5>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed die-off, swans - Ireland: (CK), RFI 20090707.2439\nBotulism, avian - Australia (02): (NSW) 20090121.0254\nBotulism, avian - Australia 20090117.0197\nBotulism, avian - Finland 20090117.0194\n2008\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): Great Lakes 20080817.2556\nUndiagnosed duck die-off - Cyprus: botulism susp 20060826.2430\n2004\n----\nBotulism, avian - South Africa 20041214.3306\nBotulism, avian - USA (AZ) 20041017.2822\nBotulism, avian - New Zealand 20040119.0218\n2003\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (NJ) 20030726.1833\n2002\n----\nBotulism, avian type E - USA, Canada 20020304.3678\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n1996\n----\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (05) 19961020.1759\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (04) 19961009.1713\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (03) 19961007.1702\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (2) 19961005.1682\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA 19961003.1667\n....................arn/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cork", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "326475", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Infant botulism - UK: (Scotland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=326475", "date": "2009-07-08 11:00:08", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN, FISH - IRELAND: (CORK), SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 7 Jul 2009\nSource: Irish Examiner on-line [edited]\n<http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/botulism-likely-cause-of--deaths-at-the-lough-95753.html>\n\n\nBotulism likely cause of deaths at The Lough\n--------------------------------------------\nA strain of botulism, caused by bacteria emitting lethal toxins, seems\nthe most likely explanation for the large number of deaths of swans,\nducks and fish at The Lough in Cork.\n\nCork City Council's chief veterinary officer, Diarmuid Dooge, said\nboth [wild]fowl and fish would be affected by _Clostridium botulinum_,\na form of bacteria released from spores on the silt bed of the lake.\n\nMore than 30 previously healthy swans and ducks and 5 carp are\nsuspected to have been killed by the toxic bacteria attaching to\nvegetation that is eaten by both the birds and fish at the picturesque\nwildlife sanctuary.\n\nThe sprouting of the spores, and the subsequent release of toxins that\nattack the fish and birds' central nervous systems [In fact, the\nperipheral nervous system is affected. - Mod.AS], may be attributed to\nthe recent humidity and a lowering of the water level. These\nconditions will have encouraged the bacteria to \"flower.\"\n\nIt was initially thought that a virus had been transmitted to the\nresident fowl by a wild duck. But that has been ruled out following\ntests at the Regional Veterinary Laboratory at Model Farm Road. Avian\ninfluenza, more commonly known as the dreaded bird flu, was also\nquickly ruled out, leaving _Clostridium botulinum_ as the likely\nculprit.\n\nMr Dooge said it was vital that all carcasses were removed from the\nwater and the central island as quickly as possible to prevent the\nlethal disease from attacking more wildlife. He predicted more fowl\nwould die before the situation was brought under control. \"It is vital\nwe continue to remove all dead and dying birds. If maggots get onto a\ncarcass they will concentrate the toxins and make them easier to\nspread,\" he said.\n\nAs there is no laboratory in Ireland equipped to confirm cases of\nbotulism -- commonly known as a potentially lethal strain of food\npoisoning -- samples will have to be sent to Scotland and it is\nexpected it will take days before the results are known. \"We need\nconfirmation of this. We need a scientific explanation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nHe has also called in the aquatic services section at University\nCollege Cork to analyse the water quality at the 9-acre lake near\nTogher. \"It fits the pattern of _Clostridium botulinum_ as both ducks\nand fish are susceptible to it. We want to get on top of this as soon\nas possible. It is a dreadful situation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nThe chief veterinary officer has also held discussions on the problem\nwith the coarse angling club, which stocks the lake. The Lough is one\nof the premier carp fisheries in Ireland. About 2000 carp are in the\nlake and it attracts thousands of coarse anglers every year, providing\na welcome financial boost to the local economy.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNick Honhold\n4/5 Grandville\nEdinburgh\n<nick.honhold@gmail.com>\n\n[We are grateful to Dr Honhold for forwarding the above newswire,\nfurther to our RFI of Tue 7 Jul 2009.\n\nBotulism in waterfowl is generally caused by one of 2 toxin types.\nType E toxin is found primarily in decaying fish and causes\nintoxication in those feeding on them. It may also cause intoxication\nin humans.\n\nType C toxin, on the other hand, is not related to fish. It occurs in\ncarcasses of dead invertebrates, in the flesh of birds dying of\nbotulism, and in maggots feeding on toxic carcasses. Type C, which is\nregarded as responsible for most outbreaks in waterfowl world-wide,\ndoes not pose a risk to humans.\n\nLaboratory identification of the causative toxin in the Cork lake\noutbreak is anticipated soon.\n\nFor further background, subscribers are encouraged to read Mod TG\ncommentary in ProMED post 20090117.0197. For the location of The Lough\n(lake) in Cork, see\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?name=The%20Lough,%20Cork,%20Co.%20Cork,%20Republic%20of%20Ireland&g=&v=51.891,-8.488,5>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed die-off, swans - Ireland: (CK), RFI 20090707.2439\nBotulism, avian - Australia (02): (NSW) 20090121.0254\nBotulism, avian - Australia 20090117.0197\nBotulism, avian - Finland 20090117.0194\n2008\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): Great Lakes 20080817.2556\nUndiagnosed duck die-off - Cyprus: botulism susp 20060826.2430\n2004\n----\nBotulism, avian - South Africa 20041214.3306\nBotulism, avian - USA (AZ) 20041017.2822\nBotulism, avian - New Zealand 20040119.0218\n2003\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (NJ) 20030726.1833\n2002\n----\nBotulism, avian type E - USA, Canada 20020304.3678\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n1996\n----\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (05) 19961020.1759\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (04) 19961009.1713\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (03) 19961007.1702\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (2) 19961005.1682\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA 19961003.1667\n....................arn/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA: risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=312922", "date": "2009-07-08 11:00:08", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN, FISH - IRELAND: (CORK), SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 7 Jul 2009\nSource: Irish Examiner on-line [edited]\n<http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/botulism-likely-cause-of--deaths-at-the-lough-95753.html>\n\n\nBotulism likely cause of deaths at The Lough\n--------------------------------------------\nA strain of botulism, caused by bacteria emitting lethal toxins, seems\nthe most likely explanation for the large number of deaths of swans,\nducks and fish at The Lough in Cork.\n\nCork City Council's chief veterinary officer, Diarmuid Dooge, said\nboth [wild]fowl and fish would be affected by _Clostridium botulinum_,\na form of bacteria released from spores on the silt bed of the lake.\n\nMore than 30 previously healthy swans and ducks and 5 carp are\nsuspected to have been killed by the toxic bacteria attaching to\nvegetation that is eaten by both the birds and fish at the picturesque\nwildlife sanctuary.\n\nThe sprouting of the spores, and the subsequent release of toxins that\nattack the fish and birds' central nervous systems [In fact, the\nperipheral nervous system is affected. - Mod.AS], may be attributed to\nthe recent humidity and a lowering of the water level. These\nconditions will have encouraged the bacteria to \"flower.\"\n\nIt was initially thought that a virus had been transmitted to the\nresident fowl by a wild duck. But that has been ruled out following\ntests at the Regional Veterinary Laboratory at Model Farm Road. Avian\ninfluenza, more commonly known as the dreaded bird flu, was also\nquickly ruled out, leaving _Clostridium botulinum_ as the likely\nculprit.\n\nMr Dooge said it was vital that all carcasses were removed from the\nwater and the central island as quickly as possible to prevent the\nlethal disease from attacking more wildlife. He predicted more fowl\nwould die before the situation was brought under control. \"It is vital\nwe continue to remove all dead and dying birds. If maggots get onto a\ncarcass they will concentrate the toxins and make them easier to\nspread,\" he said.\n\nAs there is no laboratory in Ireland equipped to confirm cases of\nbotulism -- commonly known as a potentially lethal strain of food\npoisoning -- samples will have to be sent to Scotland and it is\nexpected it will take days before the results are known. \"We need\nconfirmation of this. We need a scientific explanation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nHe has also called in the aquatic services section at University\nCollege Cork to analyse the water quality at the 9-acre lake near\nTogher. \"It fits the pattern of _Clostridium botulinum_ as both ducks\nand fish are susceptible to it. We want to get on top of this as soon\nas possible. It is a dreadful situation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nThe chief veterinary officer has also held discussions on the problem\nwith the coarse angling club, which stocks the lake. The Lough is one\nof the premier carp fisheries in Ireland. About 2000 carp are in the\nlake and it attracts thousands of coarse anglers every year, providing\na welcome financial boost to the local economy.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNick Honhold\n4/5 Grandville\nEdinburgh\n<nick.honhold@gmail.com>\n\n[We are grateful to Dr Honhold for forwarding the above newswire,\nfurther to our RFI of Tue 7 Jul 2009.\n\nBotulism in waterfowl is generally caused by one of 2 toxin types.\nType E toxin is found primarily in decaying fish and causes\nintoxication in those feeding on them. It may also cause intoxication\nin humans.\n\nType C toxin, on the other hand, is not related to fish. It occurs in\ncarcasses of dead invertebrates, in the flesh of birds dying of\nbotulism, and in maggots feeding on toxic carcasses. Type C, which is\nregarded as responsible for most outbreaks in waterfowl world-wide,\ndoes not pose a risk to humans.\n\nLaboratory identification of the causative toxin in the Cork lake\noutbreak is anticipated soon.\n\nFor further background, subscribers are encouraged to read Mod TG\ncommentary in ProMED post 20090117.0197. For the location of The Lough\n(lake) in Cork, see\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?name=The%20Lough,%20Cork,%20Co.%20Cork,%20Republic%20of%20Ireland&g=&v=51.891,-8.488,5>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed die-off, swans - Ireland: (CK), RFI 20090707.2439\nBotulism, avian - Australia (02): (NSW) 20090121.0254\nBotulism, avian - Australia 20090117.0197\nBotulism, avian - Finland 20090117.0194\n2008\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): Great Lakes 20080817.2556\nUndiagnosed duck die-off - Cyprus: botulism susp 20060826.2430\n2004\n----\nBotulism, avian - South Africa 20041214.3306\nBotulism, avian - USA (AZ) 20041017.2822\nBotulism, avian - New Zealand 20040119.0218\n2003\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (NJ) 20030726.1833\n2002\n----\nBotulism, avian type E - USA, Canada 20020304.3678\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n1996\n----\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (05) 19961020.1759\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (04) 19961009.1713\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (03) 19961007.1702\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (2) 19961005.1682\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA 19961003.1667\n....................arn/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Mod.AS], may be attributed to\nthe recent humidity and a lowering of the water level. These\nconditions will have encouraged the bacteria to \"flower.\"\n\nIt was initially thought that a virus had been transmitted to the\nresident fowl by a wild duck. But that has been ruled out following\ntests at the Regional Veterinary Laboratory at Model Farm Road. Avian\ninfluenza, more commonly known as the dreaded bird flu, was also\nquickly ruled out, leaving _Clostridium botulinum_ as the likely\nculprit.\n\nMr Dooge said it was vital that all carcasses were removed from the\nwater and the central island as quickly as possible to prevent the\nlethal disease from attacking more wildlife. He predicted more fowl\nwould die before the situation was brought under control. \"It is vital\nwe continue to remove all dead and dying birds. If maggots get onto a\ncarcass they will concentrate the toxins and make them easier to\nspread,\" he said.\n\nAs there is no laboratory in Ireland equipped to confirm cases of\nbotulism -- commonly known as a potentially lethal strain of food\npoisoning -- samples will have to be sent to Scotland and it is\nexpected it will take days before the results are known. \"We need\nconfirmation of this. We need a scientific explanation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nHe has also called in the aquatic services section at University\nCollege Cork to analyse the water quality at the 9-acre lake near\nTogher. \"It fits the pattern of _Clostridium botulinum_ as both ducks\nand fish are susceptible to it. We want to get on top of this as soon\nas possible. It is a dreadful situation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nThe chief veterinary officer has also held discussions on the problem\nwith the coarse angling club, which stocks the lake. The Lough is one\nof the premier carp fisheries in Ireland. About 2000 carp are in the\nlake and it attracts thousands of coarse anglers every year, providing\na welcome financial boost to the local economy.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNick Honhold\n4/5 Grandville\nEdinburgh\n<nick.honhold@gmail.com>\n\n[We are grateful to Dr Honhold for forwarding the above newswire,\nfurther to our RFI of Tue 7 Jul 2009.\n\nBotulism in waterfowl is generally caused by one of 2 toxin types.\nType E toxin is found primarily in decaying fish and causes\nintoxication in those feeding on them. It may also cause intoxication\nin humans.\n\nType C toxin, on the other hand, is not related to fish. It occurs in\ncarcasses of dead invertebrates, in the flesh of birds dying of\nbotulism, and in maggots feeding on toxic carcasses. Type C, which is\nregarded as responsible for most outbreaks in waterfowl world-wide,\ndoes not pose a risk to humans.\n\nLaboratory identification of the causative toxin in the Cork lake\noutbreak is anticipated soon.\n\nFor further background, subscribers are encouraged to read Mod TG\ncommentary in ProMED post 20090117.0197. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cork", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "236418", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian, fish - Ireland: (CK), susp., RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=236418", "date": "2009-07-08 11:00:08", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN, FISH - IRELAND: (CORK), SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 7 Jul 2009\nSource: Irish Examiner on-line [edited]\n<http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/botulism-likely-cause-of--deaths-at-the-lough-95753.html>\n\n\nBotulism likely cause of deaths at The Lough\n--------------------------------------------\nA strain of botulism, caused by bacteria emitting lethal toxins, seems\nthe most likely explanation for the large number of deaths of swans,\nducks and fish at The Lough in Cork.\n\nCork City Council's chief veterinary officer, Diarmuid Dooge, said\nboth [wild]fowl and fish would be affected by _Clostridium botulinum_,\na form of bacteria released from spores on the silt bed of the lake.\n\nMore than 30 previously healthy swans and ducks and 5 carp are\nsuspected to have been killed by the toxic bacteria attaching to\nvegetation that is eaten by both the birds and fish at the picturesque\nwildlife sanctuary.\n\nThe sprouting of the spores, and the subsequent release of toxins that\nattack the fish and birds' central nervous systems [In fact, the\nperipheral nervous system is affected. - Mod.AS], may be attributed to\nthe recent humidity and a lowering of the water level. These\nconditions will have encouraged the bacteria to \"flower.\"\n\nIt was initially thought that a virus had been transmitted to the\nresident fowl by a wild duck. But that has been ruled out following\ntests at the Regional Veterinary Laboratory at Model Farm Road. Avian\ninfluenza, more commonly known as the dreaded bird flu, was also\nquickly ruled out, leaving _Clostridium botulinum_ as the likely\nculprit.\n\nMr Dooge said it was vital that all carcasses were removed from the\nwater and the central island as quickly as possible to prevent the\nlethal disease from attacking more wildlife. He predicted more fowl\nwould die before the situation was brought under control. \"It is vital\nwe continue to remove all dead and dying birds. If maggots get onto a\ncarcass they will concentrate the toxins and make them easier to\nspread,\" he said.\n\nAs there is no laboratory in Ireland equipped to confirm cases of\nbotulism -- commonly known as a potentially lethal strain of food\npoisoning -- samples will have to be sent to Scotland and it is\nexpected it will take days before the results are known. \"We need\nconfirmation of this. We need a scientific explanation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nHe has also called in the aquatic services section at University\nCollege Cork to analyse the water quality at the 9-acre lake near\nTogher. \"It fits the pattern of _Clostridium botulinum_ as both ducks\nand fish are susceptible to it. We want to get on top of this as soon\nas possible. It is a dreadful situation,\" Mr Dooge said.\n\nThe chief veterinary officer has also held discussions on the problem\nwith the coarse angling club, which stocks the lake. The Lough is one\nof the premier carp fisheries in Ireland. About 2000 carp are in the\nlake and it attracts thousands of coarse anglers every year, providing\na welcome financial boost to the local economy.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nNick Honhold\n4/5 Grandville\nEdinburgh\n<nick.honhold@gmail.com>\n\n[We are grateful to Dr Honhold for forwarding the above newswire,\nfurther to our RFI of Tue 7 Jul 2009.\n\nBotulism in waterfowl is generally caused by one of 2 toxin types.\nType E toxin is found primarily in decaying fish and causes\nintoxication in those feeding on them. It may also cause intoxication\nin humans.\n\nType C toxin, on the other hand, is not related to fish. It occurs in\ncarcasses of dead invertebrates, in the flesh of birds dying of\nbotulism, and in maggots feeding on toxic carcasses. Type C, which is\nregarded as responsible for most outbreaks in waterfowl world-wide,\ndoes not pose a risk to humans.\n\nLaboratory identification of the causative toxin in the Cork lake\noutbreak is anticipated soon.\n\nFor further background, subscribers are encouraged to read Mod TG\ncommentary in ProMED post 20090117.0197. For the location of The Lough\n(lake) in Cork, see\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?name=The%20Lough,%20Cork,%20Co.%20Cork,%20Republic%20of%20Ireland&g=&v=51.891,-8.488,5>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nUndiagnosed die-off, swans - Ireland: (CK), RFI 20090707.2439\nBotulism, avian - Australia (02): (NSW) 20090121.0254\nBotulism, avian - Australia 20090117.0197\nBotulism, avian - Finland 20090117.0194\n2008\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (02): Great Lakes 20080817.2556\nUndiagnosed duck die-off - Cyprus: botulism susp 20060826.2430\n2004\n----\nBotulism, avian - South Africa 20041214.3306\nBotulism, avian - USA (AZ) 20041017.2822\nBotulism, avian - New Zealand 20040119.0218\n2003\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (NJ) 20030726.1833\n2002\n----\nBotulism, avian type E - USA, Canada 20020304.3678\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n1996\n----\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (05) 19961020.1759\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (04) 19961009.1713\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (03) 19961007.1702\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA (2) 19961005.1682\nBotulism, avian & fish - California, USA 19961003.1667\n....................arn/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cork", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "185923", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, equine - USA: (WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=185923", "date": "2009-01-20 15:00:42", "main_text": "BOTULISM, UNEVISCERATED FISH - USA: (NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY) RISK, RECALL\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 16 Jan 2009\nSource: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), press release [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/oc/po/firmrecalls/kfat01_09.html>\n\n\nK-Fat Inc., Brooklyn, NY is recalling \"Golden Dragon Fish brand\nFrozen Cooked Mackerel Fish\" because the product was found to be\nuneviscerated prior to processing. It was discovered by New York\nState Department of Agriculture and Markets Food Inspectors during a\nroutine inspection.\n\nThis product may be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_ spores,\nwhich can cause botulism, a serious and potentially fatal food-borne illness.\n\nThe sale of this type of fish is prohibited under New York State\nAgriculture and Markets regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_\nspores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any\nother portion of the fish. Uneviscerated fish has been linked to\noutbreaks of botulism poisoning.\n\nThe recalled \"Golden Dragon Fish brand Frozen Cooked Mackerel Fish\"\ncomes in an uncoded 250G plastic bag and basket and is a product of\nVietnam. \"Golden Dragon Fish brand Frozen Cooked Mackerel Fish\" was\nsold in New York and New Jersey.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with this problem.\n\nConsumers who have \"Golden Dragon Fish brand Frozen Cooked Mackerel\nFish\" are advised not to eat it, and return it to the place of purchase.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food. Most of the food recalls are related to\ndefective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily\ndo, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_.\n\nWith fish like this, many recalls are related to the lack of\nevisceration. - Mod.LL\n\nThe states of New York and New Jersey in the northeastern United\nStates can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=5128638&g=5101760&v=43,-75.5,5>. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBotulism, salted fish - USA (03): (FL) ex Canada, risk, recall 20081215.3936\nBotulism, salted fish - USA (02): (NY, NJ), risk, recall 20081010.3209\nBotulism, salted fish - USA: risk, recall 20080403.1232\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\n2007\n----\nBotulism, dried fish - USA ex Latvia: (NY, PA), recall 20071221.4106\nBotulism, canned fish - USA (NY) ex Russia: recall 20070815.2668\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (nationwide): recalls 20070813.2641\nBotulism, dried fish, canned vegetables - Russia (Rostov) 20070714.2264\nBotulism, smoked uneviscerated fish - USA (NY): recall 20070326.1043\n...................................ll/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It was discovered by New York\nState Department of Agriculture and Markets Food Inspectors during a\nroutine inspection.\n\nThis product may be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_ spores,\nwhich can cause botulism, a serious and potentially fatal food-borne illness.\n\nThe sale of this type of fish is prohibited under New York State\nAgriculture and Markets regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_\nspores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any\nother portion of the fish. Uneviscerated fish has been linked to\noutbreaks of botulism poisoning.\n\nThe recalled \"Golden Dragon Fish brand Frozen Cooked Mackerel Fish\"\ncomes in an uncoded 250G plastic bag and basket and is a product of\nVietnam. \"Golden Dragon Fish brand Frozen Cooked Mackerel Fish\" was\nsold in New York and New Jersey.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with this problem.\n\nConsumers who have \"Golden Dragon Fish brand Frozen Cooked Mackerel\nFish\" are advised not to eat it, and return it to the place of purchase.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food. Most of the food recalls are related to\ndefective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily\ndo, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_.\n\nWith fish like this, many recalls are related to the lack of\nevisceration. - Mod.LL\n\nThe states of New York and New Jersey in the northeastern United\nStates can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=5128638&g=5101760&v=43,-75.5,5>. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBotulism, salted fish - USA (03): (FL) ex Canada, risk, recall 20081215.3936\nBotulism, salted fish - USA (02): (NY, NJ), risk, recall 20081010.3209\nBotulism, salted fish - USA: risk, recall 20080403.1232\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\n2007\n----\nBotulism, dried fish - USA ex Latvia: (NY, PA), recall 20071221.4106\nBotulism, canned fish - USA (NY) ex Russia: recall 20070815.2668\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (nationwide): recalls 20070813.2641\nBotulism, dried fish, canned vegetables - Russia (Rostov) 20070714.2264\nBotulism, smoked uneviscerated fish - USA (NY): recall 20070326.1043\n...................................ll/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It was discovered by New York\nState Department of Agriculture and Markets Food Inspectors during a\nroutine inspection.\n\nThis product may be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_ spores,\nwhich can cause botulism, a serious and potentially fatal food-borne illness.\n\nThe sale of this type of fish is prohibited under New York State\nAgriculture and Markets regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_\nspores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any\nother portion of the fish. Uneviscerated fish has been linked to\noutbreaks of botulism poisoning.\n\nThe recalled \"Golden Dragon Fish brand Frozen Cooked Mackerel Fish\"\ncomes in an uncoded 250G plastic bag and basket and is a product of\nVietnam. \"Golden Dragon Fish brand Frozen Cooked Mackerel Fish\" was\nsold in New York and New Jersey.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with this problem.\n\nConsumers who have \"Golden Dragon Fish brand Frozen Cooked Mackerel\nFish\" are advised not to eat it, and return it to the place of purchase.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food. Most of the food recalls are related to\ndefective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily\ndo, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_.\n\nWith fish like this, many recalls are related to the lack of\nevisceration. - Mod.LL\n\nThe states of New York and New Jersey in the northeastern United\nStates can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=5128638&g=5101760&v=43,-75.5,5>. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBotulism, salted fish - USA (03): (FL) ex Canada, risk, recall 20081215.3936\nBotulism, salted fish - USA (02): (NY, NJ), risk, recall 20081010.3209\nBotulism, salted fish - USA: risk, recall 20080403.1232\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\n2007\n----\nBotulism, dried fish - USA ex Latvia: (NY, PA), recall 20071221.4106\nBotulism, canned fish - USA (NY) ex Russia: recall 20070815.2668\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (nationwide): recalls 20070813.2641\nBotulism, dried fish, canned vegetables - Russia (Rostov) 20070714.2264\nBotulism, smoked uneviscerated fish - USA (NY): recall 20070326.1043\n...................................ll/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It was discovered by New York\nState Department of Agriculture and Markets Food Inspectors during a\nroutine inspection.\n\nThis product may be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_ spores,\nwhich can cause botulism, a serious and potentially fatal food-borne illness.\n\nThe sale of this type of fish is prohibited under New York State\nAgriculture and Markets regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_\nspores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any\nother portion of the fish. Uneviscerated fish has been linked to\noutbreaks of botulism poisoning.\n\nThe recalled \"Golden Dragon Fish brand Frozen Cooked Mackerel Fish\"\ncomes in an uncoded 250G plastic bag and basket and is a product of\nVietnam. \"Golden Dragon Fish brand Frozen Cooked Mackerel Fish\" was\nsold in New York and New Jersey.\n\nNo illnesses have been reported to date in connection with this problem.\n\nConsumers who have \"Golden Dragon Fish brand Frozen Cooked Mackerel\nFish\" are advised not to eat it, and return it to the place of purchase.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food. Most of the food recalls are related to\ndefective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily\ndo, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_.\n\nWith fish like this, many recalls are related to the lack of\nevisceration. - Mod.LL\n\nThe states of New York and New Jersey in the northeastern United\nStates can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=5128638&g=5101760&v=43,-75.5,5>. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBotulism, salted fish - USA (03): (FL) ex Canada, risk, recall 20081215.3936\nBotulism, salted fish - USA (02): (NY, NJ), risk, recall 20081010.3209\nBotulism, salted fish - USA: risk, recall 20080403.1232\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\n2007\n----\nBotulism, dried fish - USA ex Latvia: (NY, PA), recall 20071221.4106\nBotulism, canned fish - USA (NY) ex Russia: recall 20070815.2668\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (nationwide): recalls 20070813.2641\nBotulism, dried fish, canned vegetables - Russia (Rostov) 20070714.2264\nBotulism, smoked uneviscerated fish - USA (NY): recall 20070326.1043\n...................................ll/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It was discovered by New York\nState Department of Agriculture and Markets Food Inspectors during a\nroutine inspection.\n\nThis product may be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_ spores,\nwhich can cause botulism, a serious and potentially fatal food-borne illness.\n\nThe sale of this type of fish is prohibited under New York State\nAgriculture and Markets regulations because _Clostridium botulinum_\nspores are more likely to be concentrated in the viscera than any\nother portion of the fish. The cases,\nall in the Long Beach-South Bay area, have led authorities to suspect\nthat the local heroin supply may be contaminated with [spores of the]\ntoxin-producing bacteria.\n\nMost of the heroin sold in California comes from Mexico and is sold\nas a viscous dark-colored liquid, instead of the refined, white\npowder variety from Asia.\n\nDr Jonathan Fielding, Los Angeles County's public health director,\nsaid anyone with symptoms of botulism needs to go to an emergency room.\n\nThere are about 30 cases of wound botulism nationwide every year.\n\n[Byline: Rong-Gong Lin II]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a\nwound, germinate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of\nthe wound botulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs).\nThose IDUs who intentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or\nintramuscularly may be particularly vulnerable to infection.\n\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a descending,\nflaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the\nseverity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early\nin the course of the disease and should not be delayed for the\nresults of microbiological testing.\n\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical\ndebridement are necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse\nafter antitoxin treatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl\npenicillin and metronidazole.\n\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of\nboth foodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced\nby toxin type A is most severe, with more rapid progression of\nparalysis and a higher proportion of patients requiring mechanical\nventilation. All toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic\nsystem at the presynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking\nacetylcholine transmission across the neuromuscular junction. - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of California can be seen on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the USA at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=5368381&v=35.367,-118.201,6>.\nLong Beach and South Bay are located in Los Angeles County, southern\nCalifornia. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20070603.1795\n2006\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20060329.0953\n2005\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - The cases,\nall in the Long Beach-South Bay area, have led authorities to suspect\nthat the local heroin supply may be contaminated with [spores of the]\ntoxin-producing bacteria.\n\nMost of the heroin sold in California comes from Mexico and is sold\nas a viscous dark-colored liquid, instead of the refined, white\npowder variety from Asia.\n\nDr Jonathan Fielding, Los Angeles County's public health director,\nsaid anyone with symptoms of botulism needs to go to an emergency room.\n\nThere are about 30 cases of wound botulism nationwide every year.\n\n[Byline: Rong-Gong Lin II]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a\nwound, germinate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of\nthe wound botulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs).\nThose IDUs who intentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or\nintramuscularly may be particularly vulnerable to infection.\n\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a descending,\nflaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the\nseverity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early\nin the course of the disease and should not be delayed for the\nresults of microbiological testing.\n\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical\ndebridement are necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse\nafter antitoxin treatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl\npenicillin and metronidazole.\n\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of\nboth foodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced\nby toxin type A is most severe, with more rapid progression of\nparalysis and a higher proportion of patients requiring mechanical\nventilation. All toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic\nsystem at the presynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking\nacetylcholine transmission across the neuromuscular junction. - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of California can be seen on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the USA at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=5368381&v=35.367,-118.201,6>.\nLong Beach and South Bay are located in Los Angeles County, southern\nCalifornia. - The cases,\nall in the Long Beach-South Bay area, have led authorities to suspect\nthat the local heroin supply may be contaminated with [spores of the]\ntoxin-producing bacteria.\n\nMost of the heroin sold in California comes from Mexico and is sold\nas a viscous dark-colored liquid, instead of the refined, white\npowder variety from Asia.\n\nDr Jonathan Fielding, Los Angeles County's public health director,\nsaid anyone with symptoms of botulism needs to go to an emergency room.\n\nThere are about 30 cases of wound botulism nationwide every year.\n\n[Byline: Rong-Gong Lin II]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a\nwound, germinate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of\nthe wound botulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs).\nThose IDUs who intentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or\nintramuscularly may be particularly vulnerable to infection.\n\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a descending,\nflaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the\nseverity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early\nin the course of the disease and should not be delayed for the\nresults of microbiological testing.\n\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical\ndebridement are necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse\nafter antitoxin treatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl\npenicillin and metronidazole.\n\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of\nboth foodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced\nby toxin type A is most severe, with more rapid progression of\nparalysis and a higher proportion of patients requiring mechanical\nventilation. All toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic\nsystem at the presynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking\nacetylcholine transmission across the neuromuscular junction. - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of California can be seen on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the USA at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=5368381&v=35.367,-118.201,6>.\nLong Beach and South Bay are located in Los Angeles County, southern\nCalifornia. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20070603.1795\n2006\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (WA) 20060329.0953\n2005\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Long Beach", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Long Beach -", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "- Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Los Angeles County 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "128417", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, students - Uganda (02): (Kampala), conf.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=128417", "date": "2008-09-19 16:00:32", "main_text": "BOTULISM, HUMAN, HOME CANNED GREEN BEANS - USA: (OHIO)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 17 Sep 2008\nSource: Mansfield (OH) News Journal [edited]\n<http://www.mansfieldnewsjournal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080917/UPDATES01/80917023>\n\n\nA man and his grandson remain in the hospital after coming down with\nfood-borne botulism last weekend [13-14 Sep 2008]. The man is listed\nin critical condition at MedCentral/Mansfield Hospital and his\ngrandson is in serious condition at Akron Children's Hospital after\neating home-canned green beans. 2 grandaughters also were treated for\nbotulism and have been released from Akron Children's.\n\nStephanie Zmuda, Environmental Health Director at the Galion City\nHealth Department, said after 10 years in the field, this is the\nfirst time she's dealt with such cases of contamination. \"Botulism is\na type of food poisoning and is the most dangerous,\" she said. \"6\norganisms is the infectious dose, so just a little bit of this germ\ncan get you sick. You do not have to have a whole serving of the food\nto get sick.\" [See Moderator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nZmuda said home-canning is by far the most common way to get\nbotulism, which can block nerve function and lead to musculoskeletal\nand respiratory paralysis, which can be fatal. Even after being\ntreated with an antitoxin, which comes from the CDC in Atlanta, GA,\nthose with severe botulism often require a breathing machine and\nintensive medical care for weeks. Botulism survivors may feel\nfatigued and short of breath for years to come.\n\n\"The processing is what is generally not done correctly,\" Zmuda said\nof food that is preserved at home. \"There is a heat step at the end\nof canning that is often forgotten.\" Zmuda said although the toxins\nin the food can be destroyed through heating, the spores are\nheat-stable, that is, cooking it will not kill the spores.\" [See\nModerator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nLiz Smith of the Ohio State University Wyandot County Extension said\nthere are 2 different ways to can: By pressure cooker and boiling\nwater method. \"It can be a very complicated process,\" Smith said. \"If\nyou don't have the proper temperature or amount of time, the can will\nnot seal correctly. If you use the boiling method, and don't boil the\nproper length of time, again, it will not seal correctly.\" Smith\nadded that people who can at home need to make sure the gauge on\ntheir old pressure cookers is properly adjusted and in good working order.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most USA botulism postings relate to the alert that a particular\ncommercially prepared food was not adequately made which would\nincrease a risk of intoxication with _C. botulinum toxin_. In most of\nthese, no clear evidence of botulism is found in the food product.\nWhen botulism does occur related to food, it is most likely to be\nhome-prepared as here. It should be noted that in typical food-borne\nbotulism, the toxin is preformed in the food when ingested rather\nthan disease being produced with ingestion of spores or bacilli as\nimplied in the posting. Infant botulism (and its very rare adult\nequivalent, adult intestinal toxemia botulism) are caused by\ningestion of spores which germinate and toxin is formed _in situ_.\n\nAdditionally, it is also not true that the canning process is\nineffective in killing the spores. The toxin can be destroyed by\nheating contaminated food to 85 degrees C (185 degrees F) for at\nleast 5 minutes. Spores are inactivated by heating to 121 degrees C\n(250 degrees F) under 15-20 lb/square inch pressure for at least 20\nminutes (1).\n\n1. Sobel J: Botulism. In, Beyond Anthrax: The Weaponization of\nInfectious Diseases, Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM, eds, Springer Press, New\nYork, 2008, pg 92, in press. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\n2007\n----\nBotulism, human - USA (02): (VA) 20071121.3773\nBotulism, human - USA: (VA), RFI 20071114.3700\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N. America: recall 20070802.2494\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. America (06) 20070807.2566\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA (03) 20070729.2433\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. America 20070725.2385\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA (02) 20070724.2377\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall (02) 20070720.2331\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall 20070719.2316\n................ll/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The man is listed\nin critical condition at MedCentral/Mansfield Hospital and his\ngrandson is in serious condition at Akron Children's Hospital after\neating home-canned green beans. 2 grandaughters also were treated for\nbotulism and have been released from Akron Children's.\n\nStephanie Zmuda, Environmental Health Director at the Galion City\nHealth Department, said after 10 years in the field, this is the\nfirst time she's dealt with such cases of contamination. \"Botulism is\na type of food poisoning and is the most dangerous,\" she said. \"6\norganisms is the infectious dose, so just a little bit of this germ\ncan get you sick. You do not have to have a whole serving of the food\nto get sick.\" [See Moderator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nZmuda said home-canning is by far the most common way to get\nbotulism, which can block nerve function and lead to musculoskeletal\nand respiratory paralysis, which can be fatal. Even after being\ntreated with an antitoxin, which comes from the CDC in Atlanta, GA,\nthose with severe botulism often require a breathing machine and\nintensive medical care for weeks. Botulism survivors may feel\nfatigued and short of breath for years to come.\n\n\"The processing is what is generally not done correctly,\" Zmuda said\nof food that is preserved at home. \"There is a heat step at the end\nof canning that is often forgotten.\" Zmuda said although the toxins\nin the food can be destroyed through heating, the spores are\nheat-stable, that is, cooking it will not kill the spores.\" [See\nModerator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nLiz Smith of the Ohio State University Wyandot County Extension said\nthere are 2 different ways to can: By pressure cooker and boiling\nwater method. \"It can be a very complicated process,\" Smith said. \"If\nyou don't have the proper temperature or amount of time, the can will\nnot seal correctly. If you use the boiling method, and don't boil the\nproper length of time, again, it will not seal correctly.\" Smith\nadded that people who can at home need to make sure the gauge on\ntheir old pressure cookers is properly adjusted and in good working order.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most USA botulism postings relate to the alert that a particular\ncommercially prepared food was not adequately made which would\nincrease a risk of intoxication with _C. botulinum toxin_. In most of\nthese, no clear evidence of botulism is found in the food product.\nWhen botulism does occur related to food, it is most likely to be\nhome-prepared as here. It should be noted that in typical food-borne\nbotulism, the toxin is preformed in the food when ingested rather\nthan disease being produced with ingestion of spores or bacilli as\nimplied in the posting. Infant botulism (and its very rare adult\nequivalent, adult intestinal toxemia botulism) are caused by\ningestion of spores which germinate and toxin is formed _in situ_.\n\nAdditionally, it is also not true that the canning process is\nineffective in killing the spores. The toxin can be destroyed by\nheating contaminated food to 85 degrees C (185 degrees F) for at\nleast 5 minutes. Spores are inactivated by heating to 121 degrees C\n(250 degrees F) under 15-20 lb/square inch pressure for at least 20\nminutes (1).\n\n1. Sobel J: Botulism. In, Beyond Anthrax: The Weaponization of\nInfectious Diseases, Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM, eds, Springer Press, New\nYork, 2008, pg 92, in press. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\n2007\n----\nBotulism, human - USA (02): (VA) 20071121.3773\nBotulism, human - USA: (VA), RFI 20071114.3700\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New \n York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "127424", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, students - Uganda: (Kampala), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=127424", "date": "2008-09-19 16:00:32", "main_text": "BOTULISM, HUMAN, HOME CANNED GREEN BEANS - USA: (OHIO)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 17 Sep 2008\nSource: Mansfield (OH) News Journal [edited]\n<http://www.mansfieldnewsjournal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080917/UPDATES01/80917023>\n\n\nA man and his grandson remain in the hospital after coming down with\nfood-borne botulism last weekend [13-14 Sep 2008]. The man is listed\nin critical condition at MedCentral/Mansfield Hospital and his\ngrandson is in serious condition at Akron Children's Hospital after\neating home-canned green beans. 2 grandaughters also were treated for\nbotulism and have been released from Akron Children's.\n\nStephanie Zmuda, Environmental Health Director at the Galion City\nHealth Department, said after 10 years in the field, this is the\nfirst time she's dealt with such cases of contamination. \"Botulism is\na type of food poisoning and is the most dangerous,\" she said. \"6\norganisms is the infectious dose, so just a little bit of this germ\ncan get you sick. You do not have to have a whole serving of the food\nto get sick.\" [See Moderator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nZmuda said home-canning is by far the most common way to get\nbotulism, which can block nerve function and lead to musculoskeletal\nand respiratory paralysis, which can be fatal. Even after being\ntreated with an antitoxin, which comes from the CDC in Atlanta, GA,\nthose with severe botulism often require a breathing machine and\nintensive medical care for weeks. Botulism survivors may feel\nfatigued and short of breath for years to come.\n\n\"The processing is what is generally not done correctly,\" Zmuda said\nof food that is preserved at home. \"There is a heat step at the end\nof canning that is often forgotten.\" Zmuda said although the toxins\nin the food can be destroyed through heating, the spores are\nheat-stable, that is, cooking it will not kill the spores.\" [See\nModerator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nLiz Smith of the Ohio State University Wyandot County Extension said\nthere are 2 different ways to can: By pressure cooker and boiling\nwater method. \"It can be a very complicated process,\" Smith said. \"If\nyou don't have the proper temperature or amount of time, the can will\nnot seal correctly. If you use the boiling method, and don't boil the\nproper length of time, again, it will not seal correctly.\" Smith\nadded that people who can at home need to make sure the gauge on\ntheir old pressure cookers is properly adjusted and in good working order.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most USA botulism postings relate to the alert that a particular\ncommercially prepared food was not adequately made which would\nincrease a risk of intoxication with _C. botulinum toxin_. In most of\nthese, no clear evidence of botulism is found in the food product.\nWhen botulism does occur related to food, it is most likely to be\nhome-prepared as here. It should be noted that in typical food-borne\nbotulism, the toxin is preformed in the food when ingested rather\nthan disease being produced with ingestion of spores or bacilli as\nimplied in the posting. Infant botulism (and its very rare adult\nequivalent, adult intestinal toxemia botulism) are caused by\ningestion of spores which germinate and toxin is formed _in situ_.\n\nAdditionally, it is also not true that the canning process is\nineffective in killing the spores. The toxin can be destroyed by\nheating contaminated food to 85 degrees C (185 degrees F) for at\nleast 5 minutes. Spores are inactivated by heating to 121 degrees C\n(250 degrees F) under 15-20 lb/square inch pressure for at least 20\nminutes (1).\n\n1. Sobel J: Botulism. In, Beyond Anthrax: The Weaponization of\nInfectious Diseases, Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM, eds, Springer Press, New\nYork, 2008, pg 92, in press. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\n2007\n----\nBotulism, human - USA (02): (VA) 20071121.3773\nBotulism, human - USA: (VA), RFI 20071114.3700\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N. America 20070725.2385\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA (02) 20070724.2377\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall (02) 20070720.2331\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall 20070719.2316\n................ll/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The man is listed\nin critical condition at MedCentral/Mansfield Hospital and his\ngrandson is in serious condition at Akron Children's Hospital after\neating home-canned green beans. 2 grandaughters also were treated for\nbotulism and have been released from Akron Children's.\n\nStephanie Zmuda, Environmental Health Director at the Galion City\nHealth Department, said after 10 years in the field, this is the\nfirst time she's dealt with such cases of contamination. \"Botulism is\na type of food poisoning and is the most dangerous,\" she said. \"6\norganisms is the infectious dose, so just a little bit of this germ\ncan get you sick. You do not have to have a whole serving of the food\nto get sick.\" [See Moderator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nZmuda said home-canning is by far the most common way to get\nbotulism, which can block nerve function and lead to musculoskeletal\nand respiratory paralysis, which can be fatal. Even after being\ntreated with an antitoxin, which comes from the CDC in Atlanta, GA,\nthose with severe botulism often require a breathing machine and\nintensive medical care for weeks. Botulism survivors may feel\nfatigued and short of breath for years to come.\n\n\"The processing is what is generally not done correctly,\" Zmuda said\nof food that is preserved at home. \"There is a heat step at the end\nof canning that is often forgotten.\" Zmuda said although the toxins\nin the food can be destroyed through heating, the spores are\nheat-stable, that is, cooking it will not kill the spores.\" [See\nModerator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nLiz Smith of the Ohio State University Wyandot County Extension said\nthere are 2 different ways to can: By pressure cooker and boiling\nwater method. \"It can be a very complicated process,\" Smith said. \"If\nyou don't have the proper temperature or amount of time, the can will\nnot seal correctly. If you use the boiling method, and don't boil the\nproper length of time, again, it will not seal correctly.\" Smith\nadded that people who can at home need to make sure the gauge on\ntheir old pressure cookers is properly adjusted and in good working order.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most USA botulism postings relate to the alert that a particular\ncommercially prepared food was not adequately made which would\nincrease a risk of intoxication with _C. botulinum toxin_. In most of\nthese, no clear evidence of botulism is found in the food product.\nWhen botulism does occur related to food, it is most likely to be\nhome-prepared as here. It should be noted that in typical food-borne\nbotulism, the toxin is preformed in the food when ingested rather\nthan disease being produced with ingestion of spores or bacilli as\nimplied in the posting. Infant botulism (and its very rare adult\nequivalent, adult intestinal toxemia botulism) are caused by\ningestion of spores which germinate and toxin is formed _in situ_.\n\nAdditionally, it is also not true that the canning process is\nineffective in killing the spores. The toxin can be destroyed by\nheating contaminated food to 85 degrees C (185 degrees F) for at\nleast 5 minutes. Spores are inactivated by heating to 121 degrees C\n(250 degrees F) under 15-20 lb/square inch pressure for at least 20\nminutes (1).\n\n1. Sobel J: Botulism. In, Beyond Anthrax: The Weaponization of\nInfectious Diseases, Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM, eds, Springer Press, New\nYork, 2008, pg 92, in press. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\n2007\n----\nBotulism, human - USA (02): (VA) 20071121.3773\nBotulism, human - USA: (VA), RFI 20071114.3700\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N.
