For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New \n York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "113457", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Russia (05): (Dagestan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=113457", "date": "2008-09-19 16:00:32", "main_text": "BOTULISM, HUMAN, HOME CANNED GREEN BEANS - USA: (OHIO)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 17 Sep 2008\nSource: Mansfield (OH) News Journal [edited]\n<http://www.mansfieldnewsjournal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080917/UPDATES01/80917023>\n\n\nA man and his grandson remain in the hospital after coming down with\nfood-borne botulism last weekend [13-14 Sep 2008]. The man is listed\nin critical condition at MedCentral/Mansfield Hospital and his\ngrandson is in serious condition at Akron Children's Hospital after\neating home-canned green beans. 2 grandaughters also were treated for\nbotulism and have been released from Akron Children's.\n\nStephanie Zmuda, Environmental Health Director at the Galion City\nHealth Department, said after 10 years in the field, this is the\nfirst time she's dealt with such cases of contamination. \"Botulism is\na type of food poisoning and is the most dangerous,\" she said. \"6\norganisms is the infectious dose, so just a little bit of this germ\ncan get you sick. You do not have to have a whole serving of the food\nto get sick.\" [See Moderator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nZmuda said home-canning is by far the most common way to get\nbotulism, which can block nerve function and lead to musculoskeletal\nand respiratory paralysis, which can be fatal. Even after being\ntreated with an antitoxin, which comes from the CDC in Atlanta, GA,\nthose with severe botulism often require a breathing machine and\nintensive medical care for weeks. Botulism survivors may feel\nfatigued and short of breath for years to come.\n\n\"The processing is what is generally not done correctly,\" Zmuda said\nof food that is preserved at home. \"There is a heat step at the end\nof canning that is often forgotten.\" Zmuda said although the toxins\nin the food can be destroyed through heating, the spores are\nheat-stable, that is, cooking it will not kill the spores.\" [See\nModerator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nLiz Smith of the Ohio State University Wyandot County Extension said\nthere are 2 different ways to can: By pressure cooker and boiling\nwater method. \"It can be a very complicated process,\" Smith said. \"If\nyou don't have the proper temperature or amount of time, the can will\nnot seal correctly. If you use the boiling method, and don't boil the\nproper length of time, again, it will not seal correctly.\" Smith\nadded that people who can at home need to make sure the gauge on\ntheir old pressure cookers is properly adjusted and in good working order.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most USA botulism postings relate to the alert that a particular\ncommercially prepared food was not adequately made which would\nincrease a risk of intoxication with _C. botulinum toxin_. In most of\nthese, no clear evidence of botulism is found in the food product.\nWhen botulism does occur related to food, it is most likely to be\nhome-prepared as here. It should be noted that in typical food-borne\nbotulism, the toxin is preformed in the food when ingested rather\nthan disease being produced with ingestion of spores or bacilli as\nimplied in the posting. Infant botulism (and its very rare adult\nequivalent, adult intestinal toxemia botulism) are caused by\ningestion of spores which germinate and toxin is formed _in situ_.\n\nAdditionally, it is also not true that the canning process is\nineffective in killing the spores. The toxin can be destroyed by\nheating contaminated food to 85 degrees C (185 degrees F) for at\nleast 5 minutes. Spores are inactivated by heating to 121 degrees C\n(250 degrees F) under 15-20 lb/square inch pressure for at least 20\nminutes (1).\n\n1. Sobel J: Botulism. In, Beyond Anthrax: The Weaponization of\nInfectious Diseases, Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM, eds, Springer Press, New\nYork, 2008, pg 92, in press. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\n2007\n----\nBotulism, human - USA (02): (VA) 20071121.3773\nBotulism, human - USA: (VA), RFI 20071114.3700\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N. America: recall 20070802.2494\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. America (06) 20070807.2566\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA (03) 20070729.2433\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. America 20070725.2385\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA (02) 20070724.2377\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall (02) 20070720.2331\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall 20070719.2316\n................ll/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New \n York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "112822", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, human, home canned green beans - USA: (OH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=112822", "date": "2008-09-19 16:00:32", "main_text": "BOTULISM, HUMAN, HOME CANNED GREEN BEANS - USA: (OHIO)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 17 Sep 2008\nSource: Mansfield (OH) News Journal [edited]\n<http://www.mansfieldnewsjournal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080917/UPDATES01/80917023>\n\n\nA man and his grandson remain in the hospital after coming down with\nfood-borne botulism last weekend [13-14 Sep 2008]. The man is listed\nin critical condition at MedCentral/Mansfield Hospital and his\ngrandson is in serious condition at Akron Children's Hospital after\neating home-canned green beans. 2 grandaughters also were treated for\nbotulism and have been released from Akron Children's.\n\nStephanie Zmuda, Environmental Health Director at the Galion City\nHealth Department, said after 10 years in the field, this is the\nfirst time she's dealt with such cases of contamination. \"Botulism is\na type of food poisoning and is the most dangerous,\" she said. \"6\norganisms is the infectious dose, so just a little bit of this germ\ncan get you sick. You do not have to have a whole serving of the food\nto get sick.\" [See Moderator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nZmuda said home-canning is by far the most common way to get\nbotulism, which can block nerve function and lead to musculoskeletal\nand respiratory paralysis, which can be fatal. Even after being\ntreated with an antitoxin, which comes from the CDC in Atlanta, GA,\nthose with severe botulism often require a breathing machine and\nintensive medical care for weeks. Botulism survivors may feel\nfatigued and short of breath for years to come.\n\n\"The processing is what is generally not done correctly,\" Zmuda said\nof food that is preserved at home. \"There is a heat step at the end\nof canning that is often forgotten.\" Zmuda said although the toxins\nin the food can be destroyed through heating, the spores are\nheat-stable, that is, cooking it will not kill the spores.\" [See\nModerator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nLiz Smith of the Ohio State University Wyandot County Extension said\nthere are 2 different ways to can: By pressure cooker and boiling\nwater method. \"It can be a very complicated process,\" Smith said. \"If\nyou don't have the proper temperature or amount of time, the can will\nnot seal correctly. If you use the boiling method, and don't boil the\nproper length of time, again, it will not seal correctly.\" Smith\nadded that people who can at home need to make sure the gauge on\ntheir old pressure cookers is properly adjusted and in good working order.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most USA botulism postings relate to the alert that a particular\ncommercially prepared food was not adequately made which would\nincrease a risk of intoxication with _C. botulinum toxin_. In most of\nthese, no clear evidence of botulism is found in the food product.\nWhen botulism does occur related to food, it is most likely to be\nhome-prepared as here. It should be noted that in typical food-borne\nbotulism, the toxin is preformed in the food when ingested rather\nthan disease being produced with ingestion of spores or bacilli as\nimplied in the posting. Infant botulism (and its very rare adult\nequivalent, adult intestinal toxemia botulism) are caused by\ningestion of spores which germinate and toxin is formed _in situ_.\n\nAdditionally, it is also not true that the canning process is\nineffective in killing the spores. The toxin can be destroyed by\nheating contaminated food to 85 degrees C (185 degrees F) for at\nleast 5 minutes. Spores are inactivated by heating to 121 degrees C\n(250 degrees F) under 15-20 lb/square inch pressure for at least 20\nminutes (1).\n\n1. Sobel J: Botulism. In, Beyond Anthrax: The Weaponization of\nInfectious Diseases, Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM, eds, Springer Press, New\nYork, 2008, pg 92, in press. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\n2007\n----\nBotulism, human - USA (02): (VA) 20071121.3773\nBotulism, human - USA: (VA), RFI 20071114.3700\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N. The man is listed\nin critical condition at MedCentral/Mansfield Hospital and his\ngrandson is in serious condition at Akron Children's Hospital after\neating home-canned green beans. 2 grandaughters also were treated for\nbotulism and have been released from Akron Children's.\n\nStephanie Zmuda, Environmental Health Director at the Galion City\nHealth Department, said after 10 years in the field, this is the\nfirst time she's dealt with such cases of contamination. \"Botulism is\na type of food poisoning and is the most dangerous,\" she said. \"6\norganisms is the infectious dose, so just a little bit of this germ\ncan get you sick. You do not have to have a whole serving of the food\nto get sick.\" [See Moderator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nZmuda said home-canning is by far the most common way to get\nbotulism, which can block nerve function and lead to musculoskeletal\nand respiratory paralysis, which can be fatal. Even after being\ntreated with an antitoxin, which comes from the CDC in Atlanta, GA,\nthose with severe botulism often require a breathing machine and\nintensive medical care for weeks. Botulism survivors may feel\nfatigued and short of breath for years to come.\n\n\"The processing is what is generally not done correctly,\" Zmuda said\nof food that is preserved at home. \"There is a heat step at the end\nof canning that is often forgotten.\" Zmuda said although the toxins\nin the food can be destroyed through heating, the spores are\nheat-stable, that is, cooking it will not kill the spores.\" [See\nModerator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nLiz Smith of the Ohio State University Wyandot County Extension said\nthere are 2 different ways to can: By pressure cooker and boiling\nwater method. \"It can be a very complicated process,\" Smith said. \"If\nyou don't have the proper temperature or amount of time, the can will\nnot seal correctly. If you use the boiling method, and don't boil the\nproper length of time, again, it will not seal correctly.\" Smith\nadded that people who can at home need to make sure the gauge on\ntheir old pressure cookers is properly adjusted and in good working order.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most USA botulism postings relate to the alert that a particular\ncommercially prepared food was not adequately made which would\nincrease a risk of intoxication with _C. botulinum toxin_. In most of\nthese, no clear evidence of botulism is found in the food product.\nWhen botulism does occur related to food, it is most likely to be\nhome-prepared as here. It should be noted that in typical food-borne\nbotulism, the toxin is preformed in the food when ingested rather\nthan disease being produced with ingestion of spores or bacilli as\nimplied in the posting. Infant botulism (and its very rare adult\nequivalent, adult intestinal toxemia botulism) are caused by\ningestion of spores which germinate and toxin is formed _in situ_.\n\nAdditionally, it is also not true that the canning process is\nineffective in killing the spores. The toxin can be destroyed by\nheating contaminated food to 85 degrees C (185 degrees F) for at\nleast 5 minutes. Spores are inactivated by heating to 121 degrees C\n(250 degrees F) under 15-20 lb/square inch pressure for at least 20\nminutes (1).\n\n1. Sobel J: Botulism. In, Beyond Anthrax: The Weaponization of\nInfectious Diseases, Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM, eds, Springer Press, New\nYork, 2008, pg 92, in press. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007 20080811.2472\n2007\n----\nBotulism, human - USA (02): (VA) 20071121.3773\nBotulism, human - USA: (VA), RFI 20071114.3700\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N. The man is listed\nin critical condition at MedCentral/Mansfield Hospital and his\ngrandson is in serious condition at Akron Children's Hospital after\neating home-canned green beans. 2 grandaughters also were treated for\nbotulism and have been released from Akron Children's.\n\nStephanie Zmuda, Environmental Health Director at the Galion City\nHealth Department, said after 10 years in the field, this is the\nfirst time she's dealt with such cases of contamination. \"Botulism is\na type of food poisoning and is the most dangerous,\" she said. \"6\norganisms is the infectious dose, so just a little bit of this germ\ncan get you sick. Botulism survivors may feel\nfatigued and short of breath for years to come.\n\n\"The processing is what is generally not done correctly,\" Zmuda said\nof food that is preserved at home. \"There is a heat step at the end\nof canning that is often forgotten.\" Zmuda said although the toxins\nin the food can be destroyed through heating, the spores are\nheat-stable, that is, cooking it will not kill the spores.\" [See\nModerator's Comments - Mod.LL]\n\nLiz Smith of the Ohio State University Wyandot County Extension said\nthere are 2 different ways to can: By pressure cooker and boiling\nwater method. \"It can be a very complicated process,\" Smith said. \"If\nyou don't have the proper temperature or amount of time, the can will\nnot seal correctly. If you use the boiling method, and don't boil the\nproper length of time, again, it will not seal correctly.\" Smith\nadded that people who can at home need to make sure the gauge on\ntheir old pressure cookers is properly adjusted and in good working order.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most USA botulism postings relate to the alert that a particular\ncommercially prepared food was not adequately made which would\nincrease a risk of intoxication with _C. botulinum toxin_. In most of\nthese, no clear evidence of botulism is found in the food product.\nWhen botulism does occur related to food, it is most likely to be\nhome-prepared as here. It should be noted that in typical food-borne\nbotulism, the toxin is preformed in the food when ingested rather\nthan disease being produced with ingestion of spores or bacilli as\nimplied in the posting. Infant botulism (and its very rare adult\nequivalent, adult intestinal toxemia botulism) are caused by\ningestion of spores which germinate and toxin is formed _in situ_.\n\nAdditionally, it is also not true that the canning process is\nineffective in killing the spores. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New \n York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "102130", "headline": "PRO> Botulism, native foods - USA: (AK) 2007", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=102130", "date": "2008-04-29 13:00:20", "main_text": "BOTULISM, PESTO - USA: RISK, RECALL\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 28 Apr 2008\nSource: Associated Press (AP) [edited]\n<http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gQ7dKIXx1kLxgzGPaDLMv3nn_M0gD90B3KGO0>\n\n\nBella Cucina is recalling 6-ounce glass jars of porcini and parmesan\npesto, because of the potential for bacterial contamination. The\npesto's pH is higher than it should be and as a result the jars could\nharbor _Clostridium botulinum_. This bacterium can produce the toxin\nthat causes botulism, a potentially fatal form of food poisoning. No\nillnesses have been reported. The pesto was sold through mail orders\nand in stores around the country in jars marked with lot numbers\n0081028 and 0081018. Details by phone at 678-539-8400.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food. Most of the food recalls are related to\ndefective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily\ndo, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned bean salad - USA: risk, recall 20080229.0821\nBotulism, olive oil dip - USA: risk, recall 20080204.0448\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n2007\n----\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA (02): recall, positive culture\n20071228.4164\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA: recall 20071222.4111\nBotulism, dried fish - USA ex Latvia: (NY, PA), recall 20071221.4106\nBotulism, canned fish - USA (NY) ex Russia: recall 20070815.2668\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (nationwide): recalls 20070813.2641\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. The\npesto's pH is higher than it should be and as a result the jars could\nharbor _Clostridium botulinum_. This bacterium can produce the toxin\nthat causes botulism, a potentially fatal form of food poisoning. No\nillnesses have been reported. The pesto was sold through mail orders\nand in stores around the country in jars marked with lot numbers\n0081028 and 0081018. The\npesto's pH is higher than it should be and as a result the jars could\nharbor _Clostridium botulinum_. This bacterium can produce the toxin\nthat causes botulism, a potentially fatal form of food poisoning. No\nillnesses have been reported. The pesto was sold through mail orders\nand in stores around the country in jars marked with lot numbers\n0081028 and 0081018. Details by phone at 678-539-8400.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food. Most of the food recalls are related to\ndefective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily\ndo, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned bean salad - USA: risk, recall 20080229.0821\nBotulism, olive oil dip - USA: risk, recall 20080204.0448\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n2007\n----\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA (02): recall, positive culture\n20071228.4164\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA: recall 20071222.4111\nBotulism, dried fish - USA ex Latvia: (NY, PA), recall 20071221.4106\nBotulism, canned fish - USA (NY) ex Russia: recall 20070815.2668\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (nationwide): recalls 20070813.2641\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. The\npesto's pH is higher than it should be and as a result the jars could\nharbor _Clostridium botulinum_. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "Latvia"}, {"location": "pH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "72004", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - China: (HK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=72004", "date": "2008-02-04 16:00:15", "main_text": "BOTULISM, OLIVE OIL DIP - USA: RISK, RECALL\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 1 Feb 2008\nSource: San Francisco Chronicle (CA) [edited]\n<http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2008/02/01/BAGSHUQDUB.DTL>\n\n\nA St. Helena, California, maker of an olive oil dip sold through\nWilliams-Sonoma retail stores is recalling thousands of jars of the\nproduct after a routine state inspection found that it could\npotentially harbor the bacteria that cause botulism poisoning.\n\nState health officials are urging consumers not to eat Olivier brand\nParmesan & Asiago Dip with Garlic and Basil, even if the contents of\nthe product's 11.76 ounce jars do not smell spoiled.\n\nNo one has been sickened, and no specimens of the botulism producing\n_Clostridium botulinum_ bacterium have been found, said Patrick\nKennelly, chief of the Food Safety section at the California\nDepartment of Public Health. However, state inspectors on Wednesday\n[30 Jan 2008] at the Olivier Olive Oil Products Inc. plant found that\nacid levels in the jars of dip were too low to kill such bacteria. In\nan insufficiently acidic environment, the bacteria can grow in sealed\njars, producing one of the most potent and deadly toxins known.\n\n\"This is all a precaution,\" Kennelly said. \"We have no evidence of\ntoxin production.\"\n\nThe company immediately ordered a voluntary recall of 10 000 jars,\nabout a year's production of the olive oil dip, which contains garlic\nand basil as well as Parmesan and Asiago cheeses. The products were\nsold through Olivier stores in St. Helena and Truckee, and are\ndistributed nationwide through Williams-Sonoma.\n\nAffected lots are numbered OPA 34171, OPA 23471, OAP 17271, OAP\n17671, OAP 36061, OAP 36161, and OPA 33961. Consumers who find a jar\nwith one of those lot numbers are encouraged to call the state hot\nline at (800) 495-3232.\n\n[Byline: Sabin Russell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food. Most of the food recalls are related to\ndefective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily\ndo, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_.\n\nInfused oils have previously been implicated in botulism outbreaks in\nthe USA and worldwide (1-4). An acidification step in the preparation\nof herb-infused oil may be necessary to prevent the potential\nproduction of botulism toxins.\n\nAs a result of previous outbreaks in BC (Canada) and in New York\n(USA) the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Food Code requires 2\nbarriers in the destruction of spores and in the prevention of toxin\nproduction in a commercial product of this type (reduced oxygen\npackaging): 1) destruction of the spores by heat (thermal processing)\n2) inhibition of toxin production by altering the food through\nacidification, controlling aw (water activity), the use of salt and\npreservatives, or refrigeration. Also, it is because some single\nbarriers can result in a product unacceptable to consumers that\nmultiple barriers are used. The common 2nd barrier in infused oil of\nthis kind is acidification via phosphoric or citric acid, for\nexample. The pH of the final product should be 4.6 or less.\n\nReferences:\n1. Morse DL, Pickard LK, Guzewich JJ, et al: Garlic-in-oil associated\nbotulism: episode leads to product modification. Am J Pub Health\n1990; 80: 1372-3.\n2. Solomon H, Kautter DA, Rhodehamel EJ, et al: Evaluation of\nunacidified products bottled in oil for outgrowth and toxin\nproduction by _Clostridium botulinum_. J Food Protect 1990; 54: 648-9.\n3. Solomon HM, Kautter DA: Outgrowth and toxin production by\n_Clostridium botulinum_ in bottled chopped garlic. J Food Protect\n1988; 51: 862-5.\n4. St. Louis, ME, et al: Botulism from chopped garlic: delayed\nrecognition of a major outbreak. Ann Intern Med 1988; 108: 363-8. -\nMod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n2007\n----\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA (02): recall, positive culture\n20071228.4164\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA: recall 20071222.4111\nBotulism, dried fish - USA ex Latvia: (NY,PA), recall 20071221.4106\nBotulism, canned fish - USA (NY) ex Russia: recall 20070815.2668\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (nationwide): recalls 20070813.2641\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. America (06) 20070807.2566\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N. America: recall 20070802.2494\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA (03) 20070729.2433\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. America 20070725.2385\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall 20070719.2316\nBotulism, dried fish, canned vegetables - Russia (Rostov) 20070714.2264\nBotulism, smoked uneviscerated fish - USA (NY): recall 20070326.1043\nBotulism, fatal, canned food - Azerbaijan 20070124.0321\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzoa) (02) 20070120.0261\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzcoa) 20070116.0203\n2006\n----\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, fish - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20061006.2864\nBotulism, canned food, fish - Russia (Lipetsk) 20060916.2640\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20060724.2036\nBotulism, smoked fish - Finland ex Canada 20060721.2000\n2005\n----\nBotulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya) 20051017.3029\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20051014.2998\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\n2004\n---\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Kharkov) 20041030.2930\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (04) 20041028.2914\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\nBotulism, fish-related 2003 - Norway, Germany 20040120.0224\n2003\n----\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark (03): discussion 20030209.0342\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark 20030131.0267\n........................................ll/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA: risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=70081", "date": "2008-02-04 16:00:15", "main_text": "BOTULISM, OLIVE OIL DIP - USA: RISK, RECALL\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 1 Feb 2008\nSource: San Francisco Chronicle (CA) [edited]\n<http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2008/02/01/BAGSHUQDUB.DTL>\n\n\nA St. Helena, California, maker of an olive oil dip sold through\nWilliams-Sonoma retail stores is recalling thousands of jars of the\nproduct after a routine state inspection found that it could\npotentially harbor the bacteria that cause botulism poisoning.\n\nState health officials are urging consumers not to eat Olivier brand\nParmesan & Asiago Dip with Garlic and Basil, even if the contents of\nthe product's 11.76 ounce jars do not smell spoiled.\n\nNo one has been sickened, and no specimens of the botulism producing\n_Clostridium botulinum_ bacterium have been found, said Patrick\nKennelly, chief of the Food Safety section at the California\nDepartment of Public Health. However, state inspectors on Wednesday\n[30 Jan 2008] at the Olivier Olive Oil Products Inc. plant found that\nacid levels in the jars of dip were too low to kill such bacteria. In\nan insufficiently acidic environment, the bacteria can grow in sealed\njars, producing one of the most potent and deadly toxins known.\n\n\"This is all a precaution,\" Kennelly said. \"We have no evidence of\ntoxin production.\"\n\nThe company immediately ordered a voluntary recall of 10 000 jars,\nabout a year's production of the olive oil dip, which contains garlic\nand basil as well as Parmesan and Asiago cheeses. The products were\nsold through Olivier stores in St. Helena and Truckee, and are\ndistributed nationwide through Williams-Sonoma.\n\nAffected lots are numbered OPA 34171, OPA 23471, OAP 17271, OAP\n17671, OAP 36061, OAP 36161, and OPA 33961. An acidification step in the preparation\nof herb-infused oil may be necessary to prevent the potential\nproduction of botulism toxins.\n\nAs a result of previous outbreaks in BC (Canada) and in New York\n(USA) the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Food Code requires 2\nbarriers in the destruction of spores and in the prevention of toxin\nproduction in a commercial product of this type (reduced oxygen\npackaging): 1) destruction of the spores by heat (thermal processing)\n2) inhibition of toxin production by altering the food through\nacidification, controlling aw (water activity), the use of salt and\npreservatives, or refrigeration. Also, it is because some single\nbarriers can result in a product unacceptable to consumers that\nmultiple barriers are used. The common 2nd barrier in infused oil of\nthis kind is acidification via phosphoric or citric acid, for\nexample. The pH of the final product should be 4.6 or less.\n\nReferences:\n1. Morse DL, Pickard LK, Guzewich JJ, et al: Garlic-in-oil associated\nbotulism: episode leads to product modification. Am J Pub Health\n1990; 80: 1372-3.\n2. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2008-01-30 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "1990-03-15 00:00:00", "1372-03-15 00:00:00", "1988-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "1988-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norway", "country": "Norway"}, {"location": "Truckee", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "St. Louis , ME", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "St. Helena", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "Latvia"}, {"location": "Zaporozhye", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "62713", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, canned bean salad - USA: risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=62713", "date": "2008-02-04 16:00:15", "main_text": "BOTULISM, OLIVE OIL DIP - USA: RISK, RECALL\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 1 Feb 2008\nSource: San Francisco Chronicle (CA) [edited]\n<http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2008/02/01/BAGSHUQDUB.DTL>\n\n\nA St. Helena, California, maker of an olive oil dip sold through\nWilliams-Sonoma retail stores is recalling thousands of jars of the\nproduct after a routine state inspection found that it could\npotentially harbor the bacteria that cause botulism poisoning.\n\nState health officials are urging consumers not to eat Olivier brand\nParmesan & Asiago Dip with Garlic and Basil, even if the contents of\nthe product's 11.76 ounce jars do not smell spoiled.\n\nNo one has been sickened, and no specimens of the botulism producing\n_Clostridium botulinum_ bacterium have been found, said Patrick\nKennelly, chief of the Food Safety section at the California\nDepartment of Public Health. However, state inspectors on Wednesday\n[30 Jan 2008] at the Olivier Olive Oil Products Inc. plant found that\nacid levels in the jars of dip were too low to kill such bacteria. In\nan insufficiently acidic environment, the bacteria can grow in sealed\njars, producing one of the most potent and deadly toxins known.\n\n\"This is all a precaution,\" Kennelly said. \"We have no evidence of\ntoxin production.\"\n\nThe company immediately ordered a voluntary recall of 10 000 jars,\nabout a year's production of the olive oil dip, which contains garlic\nand basil as well as Parmesan and Asiago cheeses. The products were\nsold through Olivier stores in St. Helena and Truckee, and are\ndistributed nationwide through Williams-Sonoma.\n\nAffected lots are numbered OPA 34171, OPA 23471, OAP 17271, OAP\n17671, OAP 36061, OAP 36161, and OPA 33961. Consumers who find a jar\nwith one of those lot numbers are encouraged to call the state hot\nline at (800) 495-3232.\n\n[Byline: Sabin Russell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food. Most of the food recalls are related to\ndefective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily\ndo, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_.\n\nInfused oils have previously been implicated in botulism outbreaks in\nthe USA and worldwide (1-4). An acidification step in the preparation\nof herb-infused oil may be necessary to prevent the potential\nproduction of botulism toxins.\n\nAs a result of previous outbreaks in BC (Canada) and in New York\n(USA) the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Food Code requires 2\nbarriers in the destruction of spores and in the prevention of toxin\nproduction in a commercial product of this type (reduced oxygen\npackaging): 1) destruction of the spores by heat (thermal processing)\n2) inhibition of toxin production by altering the food through\nacidification, controlling aw (water activity), the use of salt and\npreservatives, or refrigeration. Also, it is because some single\nbarriers can result in a product unacceptable to consumers that\nmultiple barriers are used. The common 2nd barrier in infused oil of\nthis kind is acidification via phosphoric or citric acid, for\nexample. The pH of the final product should be 4.6 or less.\n\nReferences:\n1. Morse DL, Pickard LK, Guzewich JJ, et al: Garlic-in-oil associated\nbotulism: episode leads to product modification. Am J Pub Health\n1990; 80: 1372-3.\n2. Solomon H, Kautter DA, Rhodehamel EJ, et al: Evaluation of\nunacidified products bottled in oil for outgrowth and toxin\nproduction by _Clostridium botulinum_. J Food Protect 1990; 54: 648-9.\n3. Solomon HM, Kautter DA: Outgrowth and toxin production by\n_Clostridium botulinum_ in bottled chopped garlic. J Food Protect\n1988; 51: 862-5.\n4. St. Louis, ME, et al: Botulism from chopped garlic: delayed\nrecognition of a major outbreak. Ann Intern Med 1988; 108: 363-8. -\nMod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n2007\n----\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA (02): recall, positive culture\n20071228.4164\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA: recall 20071222.4111\nBotulism, dried fish - USA ex Latvia: (NY,PA), recall 20071221.4106\nBotulism, canned fish - USA (NY) ex Russia: recall 20070815.2668\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (nationwide): recalls 20070813.2641\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. America (06) 20070807.2566\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N. America: recall 20070802.2494\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA (03) 20070729.2433\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. America 20070725.2385\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall 20070719.2316\nBotulism, dried fish, canned vegetables - Russia (Rostov) 20070714.2264\nBotulism, smoked uneviscerated fish - USA (NY): recall 20070326.1043\nBotulism, fatal, canned food - Azerbaijan 20070124.0321\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzoa) (02) 20070120.0261\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzcoa) 20070116.0203\n2006\n----\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, fish - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20061006.2864\nBotulism, canned food, fish - Russia (Lipetsk) 20060916.2640\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20060724.2036\nBotulism, smoked fish - Finland ex Canada 20060721.2000\n2005\n----\nBotulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya) 20051017.3029\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20051014.2998\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\n2004\n---\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Kharkov) 20041030.2930\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (04) 20041028.2914\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\nBotulism, fish-related 2003 - Norway, Germany 20040120.0224\n2003\n----\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark (03): discussion 20030209.0342\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark 20030131.0267\n........................................ll/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Russia (02): (Khanty-Mansi)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=59174", "date": "2008-02-04 16:00:15", "main_text": "BOTULISM, OLIVE OIL DIP - USA: RISK, RECALL\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 1 Feb 2008\nSource: San Francisco Chronicle (CA) [edited]\n<http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2008/02/01/BAGSHUQDUB.DTL>\n\n\nA St. Helena, California, maker of an olive oil dip sold through\nWilliams-Sonoma retail stores is recalling thousands of jars of the\nproduct after a routine state inspection found that it could\npotentially harbor the bacteria that cause botulism poisoning.\n\nState health officials are urging consumers not to eat Olivier brand\nParmesan & Asiago Dip with Garlic and Basil, even if the contents of\nthe product's 11.76 ounce jars do not smell spoiled.\n\nNo one has been sickened, and no specimens of the botulism producing\n_Clostridium botulinum_ bacterium have been found, said Patrick\nKennelly, chief of the Food Safety section at the California\nDepartment of Public Health. However, state inspectors on Wednesday\n[30 Jan 2008] at the Olivier Olive Oil Products Inc. plant found that\nacid levels in the jars of dip were too low to kill such bacteria. In\nan insufficiently acidic environment, the bacteria can grow in sealed\njars, producing one of the most potent and deadly toxins known.\n\n\"This is all a precaution,\" Kennelly said. \"We have no evidence of\ntoxin production.\"\n\nThe company immediately ordered a voluntary recall of 10 000 jars,\nabout a year's production of the olive oil dip, which contains garlic\nand basil as well as Parmesan and Asiago cheeses. The products were\nsold through Olivier stores in St. Helena and Truckee, and are\ndistributed nationwide through Williams-Sonoma.\n\nAffected lots are numbered OPA 34171, OPA 23471, OAP 17271, OAP\n17671, OAP 36061, OAP 36161, and OPA 33961. Consumers who find a jar\nwith one of those lot numbers are encouraged to call the state hot\nline at (800) 495-3232.\n\n[Byline: Sabin Russell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food. Most of the food recalls are related to\ndefective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily\ndo, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_.\n\nInfused oils have previously been implicated in botulism outbreaks in\nthe USA and worldwide (1-4). An acidification step in the preparation\nof herb-infused oil may be necessary to prevent the potential\nproduction of botulism toxins.\n\nAs a result of previous outbreaks in BC (Canada) and in New York\n(USA) the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Food Code requires 2\nbarriers in the destruction of spores and in the prevention of toxin\nproduction in a commercial product of this type (reduced oxygen\npackaging): 1) destruction of the spores by heat (thermal processing)\n2) inhibition of toxin production by altering the food through\nacidification, controlling aw (water activity), the use of salt and\npreservatives, or refrigeration. Also, it is because some single\nbarriers can result in a product unacceptable to consumers that\nmultiple barriers are used. The common 2nd barrier in infused oil of\nthis kind is acidification via phosphoric or citric acid, for\nexample. The pH of the final product should be 4.6 or less.\n\nReferences:\n1. Morse DL, Pickard LK, Guzewich JJ, et al: Garlic-in-oil associated\nbotulism: episode leads to product modification. Am J Pub Health\n1990; 80: 1372-3.\n2. Solomon H, Kautter DA, Rhodehamel EJ, et al: Evaluation of\nunacidified products bottled in oil for outgrowth and toxin\nproduction by _Clostridium botulinum_. J Food Protect 1990; 54: 648-9.\n3. Solomon HM, Kautter DA: Outgrowth and toxin production by\n_Clostridium botulinum_ in bottled chopped garlic. J Food Protect\n1988; 51: 862-5.\n4. St. Louis, ME, et al: Botulism from chopped garlic: delayed\nrecognition of a major outbreak. Ann Intern Med 1988; 108: 363-8. -\nMod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n2007\n----\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA (02): recall, positive culture\n20071228.4164\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA: recall 20071222.4111\nBotulism, dried fish - USA ex Latvia: (NY,PA), recall 20071221.4106\nBotulism, canned fish - USA (NY) ex Russia: recall 20070815.2668\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (nationwide): recalls 20070813.2641\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2008-01-30 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "1990-03-15 00:00:00", "1372-03-15 00:00:00", "1988-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "1988-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norway", "country": "Norway"}, {"location": "Truckee", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "St. Louis , ME", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "St. Helena", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "Latvia"}, {"location": "Zaporozhye", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "58471", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, canned tomatoes - Russia: (Khanty-Mansi)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=58471", "date": "2008-02-04 16:00:15", "main_text": "BOTULISM, OLIVE OIL DIP - USA: RISK, RECALL\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 1 Feb 2008\nSource: San Francisco Chronicle (CA) [edited]\n<http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2008/02/01/BAGSHUQDUB.DTL>\n\n\nA St. Helena, California, maker of an olive oil dip sold through\nWilliams-Sonoma retail stores is recalling thousands of jars of the\nproduct after a routine state inspection found that it could\npotentially harbor the bacteria that cause botulism poisoning.\n\nState health officials are urging consumers not to eat Olivier brand\nParmesan & Asiago Dip with Garlic and Basil, even if the contents of\nthe product's 11.76 ounce jars do not smell spoiled.\n\nNo one has been sickened, and no specimens of the botulism producing\n_Clostridium botulinum_ bacterium have been found, said Patrick\nKennelly, chief of the Food Safety section at the California\nDepartment of Public Health. However, state inspectors on Wednesday\n[30 Jan 2008] at the Olivier Olive Oil Products Inc. plant found that\nacid levels in the jars of dip were too low to kill such bacteria. In\nan insufficiently acidic environment, the bacteria can grow in sealed\njars, producing one of the most potent and deadly toxins known.\n\n\"This is all a precaution,\" Kennelly said. \"We have no evidence of\ntoxin production.\"\n\nThe company immediately ordered a voluntary recall of 10 000 jars,\nabout a year's production of the olive oil dip, which contains garlic\nand basil as well as Parmesan and Asiago cheeses. The products were\nsold through Olivier stores in St. Helena and Truckee, and are\ndistributed nationwide through Williams-Sonoma.\n\nAffected lots are numbered OPA 34171, OPA 23471, OAP 17271, OAP\n17671, OAP 36061, OAP 36161, and OPA 33961. Consumers who find a jar\nwith one of those lot numbers are encouraged to call the state hot\nline at (800) 495-3232.\n\n[Byline: Sabin Russell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food. Most of the food recalls are related to\ndefective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily\ndo, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_.\n\nInfused oils have previously been implicated in botulism outbreaks in\nthe USA and worldwide (1-4). An acidification step in the preparation\nof herb-infused oil may be necessary to prevent the potential\nproduction of botulism toxins.\n\nAs a result of previous outbreaks in BC (Canada) and in New York\n(USA) the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Food Code requires 2\nbarriers in the destruction of spores and in the prevention of toxin\nproduction in a commercial product of this type (reduced oxygen\npackaging): 1) destruction of the spores by heat (thermal processing)\n2) inhibition of toxin production by altering the food through\nacidification, controlling aw (water activity), the use of salt and\npreservatives, or refrigeration. Also, it is because some single\nbarriers can result in a product unacceptable to consumers that\nmultiple barriers are used. The common 2nd barrier in infused oil of\nthis kind is acidification via phosphoric or citric acid, for\nexample. The pH of the final product should be 4.6 or less.\n\nReferences:\n1. Morse DL, Pickard LK, Guzewich JJ, et al: Garlic-in-oil associated\nbotulism: episode leads to product modification. Am J Pub Health\n1990; 80: 1372-3.\n2. Solomon H, Kautter DA, Rhodehamel EJ, et al: Evaluation of\nunacidified products bottled in oil for outgrowth and toxin\nproduction by _Clostridium botulinum_. J Food Protect 1990; 54: 648-9.\n3. Solomon HM, Kautter DA: Outgrowth and toxin production by\n_Clostridium botulinum_ in bottled chopped garlic. J Food Protect\n1988; 51: 862-5.\n4. St. Louis, ME, et al: Botulism from chopped garlic: delayed\nrecognition of a major outbreak. Ann Intern Med 1988; 108: 363-8. -\nMod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n2007\n----\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA (02): recall, positive culture\n20071228.4164\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA: recall 20071222.4111\nBotulism, dried fish - USA ex Latvia: (NY,PA), recall 20071221.4106\nBotulism, canned fish - USA (NY) ex Russia: recall 20070815.2668\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (nationwide): recalls 20070813.2641\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. However, state inspectors on Wednesday\n[30 Jan 2008] at the Olivier Olive Oil Products Inc. plant found that\nacid levels in the jars of dip were too low to kill such bacteria. In\nan insufficiently acidic environment, the bacteria can grow in sealed\njars, producing one of the most potent and deadly toxins known.\n\n\"This is all a precaution,\" Kennelly said. \"We have no evidence of\ntoxin production.\"\n\nThe company immediately ordered a voluntary recall of 10 000 jars,\nabout a year's production of the olive oil dip, which contains garlic\nand basil as well as Parmesan and Asiago cheeses. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2008-01-30 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "1990-03-15 00:00:00", "1372-03-15 00:00:00", "1988-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "1988-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norway", "country": "Norway"}, {"location": "Truckee", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "St. Louis , ME", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "St. Helena", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "Latvia"}, {"location": "Zaporozhye", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "55337", "headline": "PRO/ALL> Botulism, olive oil dip - USA: risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=55337", "date": "2008-02-04 16:00:15", "main_text": "BOTULISM, OLIVE OIL DIP - USA: RISK, RECALL\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 1 Feb 2008\nSource: San Francisco Chronicle (CA) [edited]\n<http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2008/02/01/BAGSHUQDUB.DTL>\n\n\nA St. Helena, California, maker of an olive oil dip sold through\nWilliams-Sonoma retail stores is recalling thousands of jars of the\nproduct after a routine state inspection found that it could\npotentially harbor the bacteria that cause botulism poisoning.\n\nState health officials are urging consumers not to eat Olivier brand\nParmesan & Asiago Dip with Garlic and Basil, even if the contents of\nthe product's 11.76 ounce jars do not smell spoiled.\n\nNo one has been sickened, and no specimens of the botulism producing\n_Clostridium botulinum_ bacterium have been found, said Patrick\nKennelly, chief of the Food Safety section at the California\nDepartment of Public Health. However, state inspectors on Wednesday\n[30 Jan 2008] at the Olivier Olive Oil Products Inc. plant found that\nacid levels in the jars of dip were too low to kill such bacteria. In\nan insufficiently acidic environment, the bacteria can grow in sealed\njars, producing one of the most potent and deadly toxins known.\n\n\"This is all a precaution,\" Kennelly said. \"We have no evidence of\ntoxin production.\"\n\nThe company immediately ordered a voluntary recall of 10 000 jars,\nabout a year's production of the olive oil dip, which contains garlic\nand basil as well as Parmesan and Asiago cheeses. The products were\nsold through Olivier stores in St. Helena and Truckee, and are\ndistributed nationwide through Williams-Sonoma.\n\nAffected lots are numbered OPA 34171, OPA 23471, OAP 17271, OAP\n17671, OAP 36061, OAP 36161, and OPA 33961. Consumers who find a jar\nwith one of those lot numbers are encouraged to call the state hot\nline at (800) 495-3232.\n\n[Byline: Sabin Russell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED-mail posts\nsuch recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases\nassociated with the food. Most of the food recalls are related to\ndefective preparation procedures, which could, but not necessarily\ndo, result in the germination of viable spores of _C. botulinum_.\n\nInfused oils have previously been implicated in botulism outbreaks in\nthe USA and worldwide (1-4). An acidification step in the preparation\nof herb-infused oil may be necessary to prevent the potential\nproduction of botulism toxins.\n\nAs a result of previous outbreaks in BC (Canada) and in New York\n(USA) the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Food Code requires 2\nbarriers in the destruction of spores and in the prevention of toxin\nproduction in a commercial product of this type (reduced oxygen\npackaging): 1) destruction of the spores by heat (thermal processing)\n2) inhibition of toxin production by altering the food through\nacidification, controlling aw (water activity), the use of salt and\npreservatives, or refrigeration. Also, it is because some single\nbarriers can result in a product unacceptable to consumers that\nmultiple barriers are used. The common 2nd barrier in infused oil of\nthis kind is acidification via phosphoric or citric acid, for\nexample. The pH of the final product should be 4.6 or less.\n\nReferences:\n1. Morse DL, Pickard LK, Guzewich JJ, et al: Garlic-in-oil associated\nbotulism: episode leads to product modification. Am J Pub Health\n1990; 80: 1372-3.\n2. Solomon H, Kautter DA, Rhodehamel EJ, et al: Evaluation of\nunacidified products bottled in oil for outgrowth and toxin\nproduction by _Clostridium botulinum_. J Food Protect 1990; 54: 648-9.\n3. Solomon HM, Kautter DA: Outgrowth and toxin production by\n_Clostridium botulinum_ in bottled chopped garlic. J Food Protect\n1988; 51: 862-5.\n4. St. Louis, ME, et al: Botulism from chopped garlic: delayed\nrecognition of a major outbreak. Ann Intern Med 1988; 108: 363-8. -\nMod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, fish - USA: (NY, NJ, MD), risk, recall 20080124.0299\nBotulism, canned beans - USA (03): risk, bean salad recall 20080122.0264\nBotulism, canned beans - USA: risk, expanded recall 20080109.0117\nBotulism, canned soup - USA: (PA) recall, RFI 20080103.0030\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n2007\n----\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA (02): recall, positive culture\n20071228.4164\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA: recall 20071222.4111\nBotulism, dried fish - USA ex Latvia: (NY,PA), recall 20071221.4106\nBotulism, canned fish - USA (NY) ex Russia: recall 20070815.2668\nBotulism, uneviscerated fish - USA (nationwide): recalls 20070813.2641\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. America (06) 20070807.2566\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N. America: recall 20070802.2494\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA (03) 20070729.2433\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. America 20070725.2385\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall 20070719.2316\nBotulism, dried fish, canned vegetables - Russia (Rostov) 20070714.2264\nBotulism, smoked uneviscerated fish - USA (NY): recall 20070326.1043\nBotulism, fatal, canned food - Azerbaijan 20070124.0321\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzoa) (02) 20070120.0261\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzcoa) 20070116.0203\n2006\n----\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, fish - Ukraine (Donetsk) 20061006.2864\nBotulism, canned food, fish - Russia (Lipetsk) 20060916.2640\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20060724.2036\nBotulism, smoked fish - Finland ex Canada 20060721.2000\n2005\n----\nBotulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya) 20051017.3029\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20051014.2998\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\n2004\n---\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Kharkov) 20041030.2930\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (04) 20041028.2914\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\nBotulism, fish-related 2003 - Norway, Germany 20040120.0224\n2003\n----\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark (03): discussion 20030209.0342\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark 20030131.0267\n........................................ll/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA: alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=53088", "date": "2008-01-03 22:00:14", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED SOUP - USA: (PENNSYLVANIA) RECALL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 3 Jan 2008\nSource: Pennsylvania Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/01-03-2008/0004730080&EDATE=>\n\nConsumers who purchased or were given \"home-canned\" soup or other\ncanned products from the Schumacher's Inn in Austin, Potter County,\nshould not open the jars due to the risk of botulism contamination,\nHealth Secretary Dr Calvin B. Johnson said today [3 Jan 2008].\nThe state became involved after a 43-year-old Potter County woman,\nand some of the chicken soup she said she purchased from the\nrestaurant, tested positive for botulism.\nThe Department of Agriculture, which oversees food safety, has\nquarantined the product and ordered the restaurant not to sell or\ngive away any canned product. Any soup or other products canned by\nthis restaurant should be submitted to the state for testing.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[No information is available regarding the diagnosis of botulism in\nthe affected woman, such as how the diagnosis was made and which\nserotype of botulinum toxin was involved.\nThere are 7 toxins produced by different _C. botulinum_ types which\nare immunologically distinct but produce a clinically similar and\nhighly recognizable syndrome by similar pharmacological mechanisms.\nThe molecular site of action and some clinical features, however,\ndiffer.\nAll the toxins are translated as single polypeptide chains of similar\nstructure that are nicked by proteases. The protease nick yields a\nlight chain of approximately 50kD containing a catalytic subunit (a\nzinc-dependent metallo-endopeptidase) responsible for the toxic\neffects and a heavy chain of about 100kD that binds the target\ntissue. Both clostridial proteolytic enzymes and human digestive\nenzymes such as trypsin can activate the toxin.\nAll toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic system at the\npresynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine\ntransmission across the neuromuscular junction. Toxins types A and E\nenzymatically cleave a specific presynaptic membrane-associated\nprotein; toxin types B, D, F, and G cleave a synaptic\nvesicle-associated protein. Type C toxin cleaves both the\nmembrane-associated protein targeted by types A and E and an\nadditional protein associated with exocytosis. The effect in all\ncases is neuromuscular blockade resulting in flaccid paralysis. The\ntoxins also affect the adrenergic system but apparently with\ninsignificant consequences.\nToxin type A causes most cases of foodborne and wound botulism in the\nUnited States. The syndrome produced by toxin type A is most severe,\nwith more rapid progression of paralysis and a higher proportion of\npatients requiring mechanical ventilation.\nPotter County, Pennsylvania is located in the north central part of\nthe state as can be found on a map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potter_County,_Pennsylvania>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n2007\n----\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA (02): recall, positive culture\n20071228.4164\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA: recall 20071222.4111\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, fatal, canned food - Azerbaijan 20070124.0321\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzoa) (02) 20070120.0261\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzcoa) 20070116.0203\n2006\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, canned food, fish - Russia (Lipetsk) 20060916.2640\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism, canned salad - Kyrgyzstan (Kant) 20050406.0991\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\n2004\n----\nBotulism, canned eggplant - Kyrgyzstan (Osh) 20041203.3225\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\nBotulism, canned sausage suspected - South Korea 20030629.1602\n2002\n----\nBotulism, Canned Asparagus - Johnson said today [3 Jan 2008].\nThe state became involved after a 43-year-old Potter County woman,\nand some of the chicken soup she said she purchased from the\nrestaurant, tested positive for botulism.\nThe Department of Agriculture, which oversees food safety, has\nquarantined the product and ordered the restaurant not to sell or\ngive away any canned product. Any soup or other products canned by\nthis restaurant should be submitted to the state for testing.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[No information is available regarding the diagnosis of botulism in\nthe affected woman, such as how the diagnosis was made and which\nserotype of botulinum toxin was involved.\nThere are 7 toxins produced by different _C. botulinum_ types which\nare immunologically distinct but produce a clinically similar and\nhighly recognizable syndrome by similar pharmacological mechanisms.\nThe molecular site of action and some clinical features, however,\ndiffer.\nAll the toxins are translated as single polypeptide chains of similar\nstructure that are nicked by proteases. The protease nick yields a\nlight chain of approximately 50kD containing a catalytic subunit (a\nzinc-dependent metallo-endopeptidase) responsible for the toxic\neffects and a heavy chain of about 100kD that binds the target\ntissue. Both clostridial proteolytic enzymes and human digestive\nenzymes such as trypsin can activate the toxin.\nAll toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic system at the\npresynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine\ntransmission across the neuromuscular junction. Toxins types A and E\nenzymatically cleave a specific presynaptic membrane-associated\nprotein; toxin types B, D, F, and G cleave a synaptic\nvesicle-associated protein. Type C toxin cleaves both the\nmembrane-associated protein targeted by types A and E and an\nadditional protein associated with exocytosis. The effect in all\ncases is neuromuscular blockade resulting in flaccid paralysis. The\ntoxins also affect the adrenergic system but apparently with\ninsignificant consequences.\nToxin type A causes most cases of foodborne and wound botulism in the\nUnited States. The syndrome produced by toxin type A is most severe,\nwith more rapid progression of paralysis and a higher proportion of\npatients requiring mechanical ventilation.\nPotter County, Pennsylvania is located in the north central part of\nthe state as can be found on a map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potter_County,_Pennsylvania>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n2007\n----\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA (02): recall, positive culture\n20071228.4164\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA: recall 20071222.4111\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, fatal, canned food - Azerbaijan 20070124.0321\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzoa) (02) 20070120.0261\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzcoa) 20070116.0203\n2006\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, canned food, fish - Russia (Lipetsk) 20060916.2640\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism, canned salad - Kyrgyzstan (Kant) 20050406.0991\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\n2004\n----\nBotulism, canned eggplant - Kyrgyzstan (Osh) 20041203.3225\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\nBotulism, canned sausage suspected - South Korea 20030629.1602\n2002\n----\nBotulism, Canned Asparagus - USA: Recall 20020209.3521\nBotulism, canned clams - USA (Northeast): recall 20020112.3233\n2001\n----\nBotulism, canned organic beans - Canada: recall 20011115.2812\n........................................ll/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Johnson said today [3 Jan 2008].\nThe state became involved after a 43-year-old Potter County woman,\nand some of the chicken soup she said she purchased from the\nrestaurant, tested positive for botulism.\nThe Department of Agriculture, which oversees food safety, has\nquarantined the product and ordered the restaurant not to sell or\ngive away any canned product. Any soup or other products canned by\nthis restaurant should be submitted to the state for testing.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[No information is available regarding the diagnosis of botulism in\nthe affected woman, such as how the diagnosis was made and which\nserotype of botulinum toxin was involved.\nThere are 7 toxins produced by different _C. botulinum_ types which\nare immunologically distinct but produce a clinically similar and\nhighly recognizable syndrome by similar pharmacological mechanisms.\nThe molecular site of action and some clinical features, however,\ndiffer.\nAll the toxins are translated as single polypeptide chains of similar\nstructure that are nicked by proteases. The protease nick yields a\nlight chain of approximately 50kD containing a catalytic subunit (a\nzinc-dependent metallo-endopeptidase) responsible for the toxic\neffects and a heavy chain of about 100kD that binds the target\ntissue. Both clostridial proteolytic enzymes and human digestive\nenzymes such as trypsin can activate the toxin.\nAll toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic system at the\npresynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine\ntransmission across the neuromuscular junction. Toxins types A and E\nenzymatically cleave a specific presynaptic membrane-associated\nprotein; toxin types B, D, F, and G cleave a synaptic\nvesicle-associated protein. Type C toxin cleaves both the\nmembrane-associated protein targeted by types A and E and an\nadditional protein associated with exocytosis. The effect in all\ncases is neuromuscular blockade resulting in flaccid paralysis. The\ntoxins also affect the adrenergic system but apparently with\ninsignificant consequences.\nToxin type A causes most cases of foodborne and wound botulism in the\nUnited States. The syndrome produced by toxin type A is most severe,\nwith more rapid progression of paralysis and a higher proportion of\npatients requiring mechanical ventilation.\nPotter County, Pennsylvania is located in the north central part of\nthe state as can be found on a map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potter_County,_Pennsylvania>. - Johnson said today [3 Jan 2008].\nThe state became involved after a 43-year-old Potter County woman,\nand some of the chicken soup she said she purchased from the\nrestaurant, tested positive for botulism.\nThe Department of Agriculture, which oversees food safety, has\nquarantined the product and ordered the restaurant not to sell or\ngive away any canned product. Any soup or other products canned by\nthis restaurant should be submitted to the state for testing.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[No information is available regarding the diagnosis of botulism in\nthe affected woman, such as how the diagnosis was made and which\nserotype of botulinum toxin was involved.\nThere are 7 toxins produced by different _C. botulinum_ types which\nare immunologically distinct but produce a clinically similar and\nhighly recognizable syndrome by similar pharmacological mechanisms.\nThe molecular site of action and some clinical features, however,\ndiffer.\nAll the toxins are translated as single polypeptide chains of similar\nstructure that are nicked by proteases. The protease nick yields a\nlight chain of approximately 50kD containing a catalytic subunit (a\nzinc-dependent metallo-endopeptidase) responsible for the toxic\neffects and a heavy chain of about 100kD that binds the target\ntissue. Both clostridial proteolytic enzymes and human digestive\nenzymes such as trypsin can activate the toxin.\nAll toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic system at the\npresynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine\ntransmission across the neuromuscular junction. Toxins types A and E\nenzymatically cleave a specific presynaptic membrane-associated\nprotein; toxin types B, D, F, and G cleave a synaptic\nvesicle-associated protein. Type C toxin cleaves both the\nmembrane-associated protein targeted by types A and E and an\nadditional protein associated with exocytosis. The effect in all\ncases is neuromuscular blockade resulting in flaccid paralysis. The\ntoxins also affect the adrenergic system but apparently with\ninsignificant consequences.\nToxin type A causes most cases of foodborne and wound botulism in the\nUnited States. The syndrome produced by toxin type A is most severe,\nwith more rapid progression of paralysis and a higher proportion of\npatients requiring mechanical ventilation.\nPotter County, Pennsylvania is located in the north central part of\nthe state as can be found on a map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potter_County,_Pennsylvania>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, foie gras - France: risk, recall 20080102.0016\nBotulism, canned food: aerosol risk 20080101.0008\n2007\n----\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA (02): recall, positive culture\n20071228.4164\nBotulism, canned green beans - USA: recall 20071222.4111\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, fatal, canned food - Azerbaijan 20070124.0321\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzoa) (02) 20070120.0261\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzcoa) 20070116.0203\n2006\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, canned food, fish - Russia (Lipetsk) 20060916.2640\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism, canned salad - Kyrgyzstan (Kant) 20050406.0991\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\n2004\n----\nBotulism, canned eggplant - Kyrgyzstan (Osh) 20041203.3225\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\nBotulism, canned sausage suspected - South Korea 20030629.1602\n2002\n----\nBotulism, Canned Asparagus - USA: Recall 20020209.3521\nBotulism, canned clams - USA (Northeast): recall 20020112.3233\n2001\n----\nBotulism, canned organic beans - Canada: recall 20011115.2812\n........................................ll/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
