Johnson said today [3 Jan 2008].\nThe state became involved after a 43-year-old Potter County woman,\nand some of the chicken soup she said she purchased from the\nrestaurant, tested positive for botulism.\nThe Department of Agriculture, which oversees food safety, has\nquarantined the product and ordered the restaurant not to sell or\ngive away any canned product. Any soup or other products canned by\nthis restaurant should be submitted to the state for testing.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[No information is available regarding the diagnosis of botulism in\nthe affected woman, such as how the diagnosis was made and which\nserotype of botulinum toxin was involved.\nThere are 7 toxins produced by different _C. botulinum_ types which\nare immunologically distinct but produce a clinically similar and\nhighly recognizable syndrome by similar pharmacological mechanisms.\nThe molecular site of action and some clinical features, however,\ndiffer.\nAll the toxins are translated as single polypeptide chains of similar\nstructure that are nicked by proteases. The protease nick yields a\nlight chain of approximately 50kD containing a catalytic subunit (a\nzinc-dependent metallo-endopeptidase) responsible for the toxic\neffects and a heavy chain of about 100kD that binds the target\ntissue. Both clostridial proteolytic enzymes and human digestive\nenzymes such as trypsin can activate the toxin.\nAll toxin types exert their action on the cholinergic system at the\npresynaptic motor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine\ntransmission across the neuromuscular junction. Toxins types A and E\nenzymatically cleave a specific presynaptic membrane-associated\nprotein; toxin types B, D, F, and G cleave a synaptic\nvesicle-associated protein. Type C toxin cleaves both the\nmembrane-associated protein targeted by types A and E and an\nadditional protein associated with exocytosis. The effect in all\ncases is neuromuscular blockade resulting in flaccid paralysis. The\ntoxins also affect the adrenergic system but apparently with\ninsignificant consequences.\nToxin type A causes most cases of foodborne and wound botulism in the\nUnited States. The syndrome produced by toxin type A is most severe,\nwith more rapid progression of paralysis and a higher proportion of\npatients requiring mechanical ventilation.\nPotter County, Pennsylvania is located in the north central part of\nthe state as can be found on a map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potter_County,_Pennsylvania>. - A relative\nsaid that medical authorities told the family of the 57-year-old\nfemale physician that her death may be related to botulism poisoning.\nThe doctor's younger brother said the family is still awaiting\nlaboratory results to confirm that the death was caused by botulism.\nThey expect those results Thu 15 Nov 2007, he said.\n\nThe brother said the state health department approached the family\nlast week about the doctor's illness. The doctor's husband is also\nill and was still hospitalized, he said, and added that he doesn't\nknow whether that illness is also related to botulism.\n\nThe relative's comments come a day after the Virginia Department of\nHealth said it is investigating 2 reported cases of possible\nfood-borne botulism in the Alleghany-Roanoke City Health District,\nwhich includes Roanoke County, where the couple lives.\n\nOn Tue 13 Nov 2007, the health department would not specify when and\nwhere the cases originated or whether either one was fatal. They said\nthe 2 cases are related to home-canned food and are isolated\nincidents confined to a single household.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED would appreciate more information regarding all 4 cases,\nwhether botulism is indeed proven, and what the toxin type(s) are. It\nwould seem unusual to have a number of suspected or proven cases over\na short period of time.\n\nThe city and county of Roanoke are located in the central part of\nVirginia just west of the Blue Ridge Mountains and can be found on a\nmap at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roanoke,_Virginia>.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N. America: recall 20070802.2494\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. America (06) 20070807.2566\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA (03) 20070729.2433\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. A relative\nsaid that medical authorities told the family of the 57-year-old\nfemale physician that her death may be related to botulism poisoning.\nThe doctor's younger brother said the family is still awaiting\nlaboratory results to confirm that the death was caused by botulism.\nThey expect those results Thu 15 Nov 2007, he said.\n\nThe brother said the state health department approached the family\nlast week about the doctor's illness. The doctor's husband is also\nill and was still hospitalized, he said, and added that he doesn't\nknow whether that illness is also related to botulism.\n\nThe relative's comments come a day after the Virginia Department of\nHealth said it is investigating 2 reported cases of possible\nfood-borne botulism in the Alleghany-Roanoke City Health District,\nwhich includes Roanoke County, where the couple lives.\n\nOn Tue 13 Nov 2007, the health department would not specify when and\nwhere the cases originated or whether either one was fatal. They said\nthe 2 cases are related to home-canned food and are isolated\nincidents confined to a single household.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED would appreciate more information regarding all 4 cases,\nwhether botulism is indeed proven, and what the toxin type(s) are. It\nwould seem unusual to have a number of suspected or proven cases over\na short period of time.\n\nThe city and county of Roanoke are located in the central part of\nVirginia just west of the Blue Ridge Mountains and can be found on a\nmap at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roanoke,_Virginia>.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N. A relative\nsaid that medical authorities told the family of the 57-year-old\nfemale physician that her death may be related to botulism poisoning.\nThe doctor's younger brother said the family is still awaiting\nlaboratory results to confirm that the death was caused by botulism.\nThey expect those results Thu 15 Nov 2007, he said.\n\nThe brother said the state health department approached the family\nlast week about the doctor's illness. The doctor's husband is also\nill and was still hospitalized, he said, and added that he doesn't\nknow whether that illness is also related to botulism.\n\nThe relative's comments come a day after the Virginia Department of\nHealth said it is investigating 2 reported cases of possible\nfood-borne botulism in the Alleghany-Roanoke City Health District,\nwhich includes Roanoke County, where the couple lives.\n\nOn Tue 13 Nov 2007, the health department would not specify when and\nwhere the cases originated or whether either one was fatal. They said\nthe 2 cases are related to home-canned food and are isolated\nincidents confined to a single household.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED would appreciate more information regarding all 4 cases,\nwhether botulism is indeed proven, and what the toxin type(s) are. It\nwould seem unusual to have a number of suspected or proven cases over\na short period of time.\n\nThe city and county of Roanoke are located in the central part of\nVirginia just west of the Blue Ridge Mountains and can be found on a\nmap at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roanoke,_Virginia>.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N. A relative\nsaid that medical authorities told the family of the 57-year-old\nfemale physician that her death may be related to botulism poisoning.\nThe doctor's younger brother said the family is still awaiting\nlaboratory results to confirm that the death was caused by botulism.\nThey expect those results Thu 15 Nov 2007, he said.\n\nThe brother said the state health department approached the family\nlast week about the doctor's illness. The doctor's husband is also\nill and was still hospitalized, he said, and added that he doesn't\nknow whether that illness is also related to botulism.\n\nThe relative's comments come a day after the Virginia Department of\nHealth said it is investigating 2 reported cases of possible\nfood-borne botulism in the Alleghany-Roanoke City Health District,\nwhich includes Roanoke County, where the couple lives.\n\nOn Tue 13 Nov 2007, the health department would not specify when and\nwhere the cases originated or whether either one was fatal. They said\nthe 2 cases are related to home-canned food and are isolated\nincidents confined to a single household.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED would appreciate more information regarding all 4 cases,\nwhether botulism is indeed proven, and what the toxin type(s) are. It\nwould seem unusual to have a number of suspected or proven cases over\na short period of time.\n\nThe city and county of Roanoke are located in the central part of\nVirginia just west of the Blue Ridge Mountains and can be found on a\nmap at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roanoke,_Virginia>.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism risk, canned green beans - N. A relative\nsaid that medical authorities told the family of the 57-year-old\nfemale physician that her death may be related to botulism poisoning.\nThe doctor's younger brother said the family is still awaiting\nlaboratory results to confirm that the death was caused by botulism.\nThey expect those results Thu 15 Nov 2007, he said.\n\nThe brother said the state health department approached the family\nlast week about the doctor's illness. The doctor's husband is also\nill and was still hospitalized, he said, and added that he doesn't\nknow whether that illness is also related to botulism.\n\nThe relative's comments come a day after the Virginia Department of\nHealth said it is investigating 2 reported cases of possible\nfood-borne botulism in the Alleghany-Roanoke City Health District,\nwhich includes Roanoke County, where the couple lives.\n\nOn Tue 13 Nov 2007, the health department would not specify when and\nwhere the cases originated or whether either one was fatal. They said\nthe 2 cases are related to home-canned food and are isolated\nincidents confined to a single household.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED would appreciate more information regarding all 4 cases,\nwhether botulism is indeed proven, and what the toxin type(s) are. A relative\nsaid that medical authorities told the family of the 57-year-old\nfemale physician that her death may be related to botulism poisoning.\nThe doctor's younger brother said the family is still awaiting\nlaboratory results to confirm that the death was caused by botulism.\nThey expect those results Thu 15 Nov 2007, he said.\n\nThe brother said the state health department approached the family\nlast week about the doctor's illness. The doctor's husband is also\nill and was still hospitalized, he said, and added that he doesn't\nknow whether that illness is also related to botulism.\n\nThe relative's comments come a day after the Virginia Department of\nHealth said it is investigating 2 reported cases of possible\nfood-borne botulism in the Alleghany-Roanoke City Health District,\nwhich includes Roanoke County, where the couple lives.\n\nOn Tue 13 Nov 2007, the health department would not specify when and\nwhere the cases originated or whether either one was fatal. The department received a preliminary\npositive sample for botulism from the CDC, Busemeyer said. \"We're\nconfident he does have botulism,\" she said.\nThe department is trying to determine whether the man became ill by\neating canned food that has been recalled, Busemeyer said.\nThe CDC said that as of 22 Jul 2007, 4 people had been hospitalized\nwith botulism poisoning: 2 from Indiana and 2 from Texas.\nCastleberry's Food Co. has recalled more than 90 potentially\ncontaminated products nationwide, including canned chili, hash and\nstew, over fears of botulism contamination.\nThe recall includes 2 years' production and tens of millions of cans\nat the company's Augusta, GA, company.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It appears that this case is indeed botulism but it is, as yet, to\nbe determined whether the case is neurotoxin type A and linked to the\nrecall. Sandoval County, NM, is in the north-central part of the\nstate as can be seen at:\n<http://county-map.digital-topo-maps.com/new-mexico-county-map.gif>. - Mod.LL]\n*****\n[2] One of 2 Hawaii cases discounted\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2007\nSource: Honolulu Star Bulletin [edited]\n<http://starbulletin.com/2007/08/01/news/story09.html>\n\nThe Hawaii state Health Department has sent blood samples from a Maui\nman for federal testing for botulism but did not send samples of a\n2nd man who did not have the symptoms, said spokeswoman Janice Okubo.\nBlood samples from one person were sent to the CDC in Atlanta, but\nstate health officials decided not to send blood samples from another\nMaui resident.\nOkubo said a determination was made to send only Stockton's sample\nafter a health investigator conducted interviews with the men.\nThe 1st case, a 33 year old man, said he ate a can of Cattle Drive\nbrand chili on 24 Jul 2007 and suffered symptoms similar to botulism,\nincluding paralysis in the face and muscle weakness. He was admitted\nto Maui Memorial Medical Center on Thu 26 Jul 2007. He was released\nfrom the hospital on Sat 28 Jul 2007, and samples of his blood have\nbeen sent to the CDC.\nOkubo said the department officially has no confirmed case of botulism.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It remains to be determined if either of the cases were actually\nbotulism, let alone whether the case(s) are linked to this multistate outbreak.\n[There are 2 linked cases in Indiana and 2 in Texas. With the one\npossible case in Hawaii, there are 11 possibly-linked other cases, 8\nin Ohio, 1 in Indiana, and 1 in New Mexico (see above) along with the\nHawaiian case. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. USA: (MI), susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=35190", "date": "2007-08-01 22:00:06", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED FOOD, HUMAN, PET - NORTH AMERICA (05)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[ProMED-mail apologizes for the inconvenience of a duplicate posting,\nbut it is necessary for clarity of comprehension. - Mod.MPP]\n[1] New Mexico: suspected case\n[2] One of 2 Hawaii cases discounted\n*****\n[1] New Mexico: suspected case\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2007\nSource: Las Cruces (NM) Sun-News [edited]\n<http://www.lcsun-news.com/latest/ci_6517322>\n\nA New Mexico man suffering from botulism poisoning is in serious\ncondition and is able to only wiggle his toes, state health officials\nsay. \"We can communicate with him only by him basically moving his\ntoes,\" Deborah Busemeyer, New Mexico Department of Health spokesman,\nsaid Wed 1 Aug 2007.\nThe 52-year-old Sandoval County man, whose name was not released, was\nhospitalized 26 Jul 2007. The department received a preliminary\npositive sample for botulism from the CDC, Busemeyer said. \"We're\nconfident he does have botulism,\" she said.\nThe department is trying to determine whether the man became ill by\neating canned food that has been recalled, Busemeyer said.\nThe CDC said that as of 22 Jul 2007, 4 people had been hospitalized\nwith botulism poisoning: 2 from Indiana and 2 from Texas.\nCastleberry's Food Co. has recalled more than 90 potentially\ncontaminated products nationwide, including canned chili, hash and\nstew, over fears of botulism contamination.\nThe recall includes 2 years' production and tens of millions of cans\nat the company's Augusta, GA, company.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It appears that this case is indeed botulism but it is, as yet, to\nbe determined whether the case is neurotoxin type A and linked to the\nrecall. Sandoval County, NM, is in the north-central part of the\nstate as can be seen at:\n<http://county-map.digital-topo-maps.com/new-mexico-county-map.gif>. - Mod.LL]\n*****\n[2] One of 2 Hawaii cases discounted\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2007\nSource: Honolulu Star Bulletin [edited]\n<http://starbulletin.com/2007/08/01/news/story09.html>\n\nThe Hawaii state Health Department has sent blood samples from a Maui\nman for federal testing for botulism but did not send samples of a\n2nd man who did not have the symptoms, said spokeswoman Janice Okubo.\nBlood samples from one person were sent to the CDC in Atlanta, but\nstate health officials decided not to send blood samples from another\nMaui resident.\nOkubo said a determination was made to send only Stockton's sample\nafter a health investigator conducted interviews with the men.\nThe 1st case, a 33 year old man, said he ate a can of Cattle Drive\nbrand chili on 24 Jul 2007 and suffered symptoms similar to botulism,\nincluding paralysis in the face and muscle weakness. He was admitted\nto Maui Memorial Medical Center on Thu 26 Jul 2007. He was released\nfrom the hospital on Sat 28 Jul 2007, and samples of his blood have\nbeen sent to the CDC.\nOkubo said the department officially has no confirmed case of botulism.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It remains to be determined if either of the cases were actually\nbotulism, let alone whether the case(s) are linked to this multistate outbreak.\n[There are 2 linked cases in Indiana and 2 in Texas. With the one\npossible case in Hawaii, there are 11 possibly-linked other cases, 8\nin Ohio, 1 in Indiana, and 1 in New Mexico (see above) along with the\nHawaiian case. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. Mod.MPP]\n[1] New Mexico: suspected case\n[2] One of 2 Hawaii cases discounted\n*****\n[1] New Mexico: suspected case\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2007\nSource: Las Cruces (NM) Sun-News [edited]\n<http://www.lcsun-news.com/latest/ci_6517322>\n\nA New Mexico man suffering from botulism poisoning is in serious\ncondition and is able to only wiggle his toes, state health officials\nsay. \"We can communicate with him only by him basically moving his\ntoes,\" Deborah Busemeyer, New Mexico Department of Health spokesman,\nsaid Wed 1 Aug 2007.\nThe 52-year-old Sandoval County man, whose name was not released, was\nhospitalized 26 Jul 2007. The department received a preliminary\npositive sample for botulism from the CDC, Busemeyer said. \"We're\nconfident he does have botulism,\" she said.\nThe department is trying to determine whether the man became ill by\neating canned food that has been recalled, Busemeyer said.\nThe CDC said that as of 22 Jul 2007, 4 people had been hospitalized\nwith botulism poisoning: 2 from Indiana and 2 from Texas.\nCastleberry's Food Co. has recalled more than 90 potentially\ncontaminated products nationwide, including canned chili, hash and\nstew, over fears of botulism contamination.\nThe recall includes 2 years' production and tens of millions of cans\nat the company's Augusta, GA, company.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It appears that this case is indeed botulism but it is, as yet, to\nbe determined whether the case is neurotoxin type A and linked to the\nrecall. Sandoval County, NM, is in the north-central part of the\nstate as can be seen at:\n<http://county-map.digital-topo-maps.com/new-mexico-county-map.gif>. - Mod.LL]\n*****\n[2] One of 2 Hawaii cases discounted\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2007\nSource: Honolulu Star Bulletin [edited]\n<http://starbulletin.com/2007/08/01/news/story09.html>\n\nThe Hawaii state Health Department has sent blood samples from a Maui\nman for federal testing for botulism but did not send samples of a\n2nd man who did not have the symptoms, said spokeswoman Janice Okubo.\nBlood samples from one person were sent to the CDC in Atlanta, but\nstate health officials decided not to send blood samples from another\nMaui resident.\nOkubo said a determination was made to send only Stockton's sample\nafter a health investigator conducted interviews with the men.\nThe 1st case, a 33 year old man, said he ate a can of Cattle Drive\nbrand chili on 24 Jul 2007 and suffered symptoms similar to botulism,\nincluding paralysis in the face and muscle weakness. He was admitted\nto Maui Memorial Medical Center on Thu 26 Jul 2007. He was released\nfrom the hospital on Sat 28 Jul 2007, and samples of his blood have\nbeen sent to the CDC.\nOkubo said the department officially has no confirmed case of botulism.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It remains to be determined if either of the cases were actually\nbotulism, let alone whether the case(s) are linked to this multistate outbreak.\n[There are 2 linked cases in Indiana and 2 in Texas. With the one\npossible case in Hawaii, there are 11 possibly-linked other cases, 8\nin Ohio, 1 in Indiana, and 1 in New Mexico (see above) along with the\nHawaiian case. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. USA (NY): susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=22378", "date": "2007-08-01 22:00:06", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED FOOD, HUMAN, PET - NORTH AMERICA (05)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[ProMED-mail apologizes for the inconvenience of a duplicate posting,\nbut it is necessary for clarity of comprehension. - Mod.MPP]\n[1] New Mexico: suspected case\n[2] One of 2 Hawaii cases discounted\n*****\n[1] New Mexico: suspected case\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2007\nSource: Las Cruces (NM) Sun-News [edited]\n<http://www.lcsun-news.com/latest/ci_6517322>\n\nA New Mexico man suffering from botulism poisoning is in serious\ncondition and is able to only wiggle his toes, state health officials\nsay. \"We can communicate with him only by him basically moving his\ntoes,\" Deborah Busemeyer, New Mexico Department of Health spokesman,\nsaid Wed 1 Aug 2007.\nThe 52-year-old Sandoval County man, whose name was not released, was\nhospitalized 26 Jul 2007. The department received a preliminary\npositive sample for botulism from the CDC, Busemeyer said. \"We're\nconfident he does have botulism,\" she said.\nThe department is trying to determine whether the man became ill by\neating canned food that has been recalled, Busemeyer said.\nThe CDC said that as of 22 Jul 2007, 4 people had been hospitalized\nwith botulism poisoning: 2 from Indiana and 2 from Texas.\nCastleberry's Food Co. has recalled more than 90 potentially\ncontaminated products nationwide, including canned chili, hash and\nstew, over fears of botulism contamination.\nThe recall includes 2 years' production and tens of millions of cans\nat the company's Augusta, GA, company.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It appears that this case is indeed botulism but it is, as yet, to\nbe determined whether the case is neurotoxin type A and linked to the\nrecall. Sandoval County, NM, is in the north-central part of the\nstate as can be seen at:\n<http://county-map.digital-topo-maps.com/new-mexico-county-map.gif>. - Mod.LL]\n*****\n[2] One of 2 Hawaii cases discounted\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2007\nSource: Honolulu Star Bulletin [edited]\n<http://starbulletin.com/2007/08/01/news/story09.html>\n\nThe Hawaii state Health Department has sent blood samples from a Maui\nman for federal testing for botulism but did not send samples of a\n2nd man who did not have the symptoms, said spokeswoman Janice Okubo.\nBlood samples from one person were sent to the CDC in Atlanta, but\nstate health officials decided not to send blood samples from another\nMaui resident.\nOkubo said a determination was made to send only Stockton's sample\nafter a health investigator conducted interviews with the men.\nThe 1st case, a 33 year old man, said he ate a can of Cattle Drive\nbrand chili on 24 Jul 2007 and suffered symptoms similar to botulism,\nincluding paralysis in the face and muscle weakness. He was admitted\nto Maui Memorial Medical Center on Thu 26 Jul 2007. He was released\nfrom the hospital on Sat 28 Jul 2007, and samples of his blood have\nbeen sent to the CDC.\nOkubo said the department officially has no confirmed case of botulism.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It remains to be determined if either of the cases were actually\nbotulism, let alone whether the case(s) are linked to this multistate outbreak.\n[There are 2 linked cases in Indiana and 2 in Texas. With the one\npossible case in Hawaii, there are 11 possibly-linked other cases, 8\nin Ohio, 1 in Indiana, and 1 in New Mexico (see above) along with the\nHawaiian case. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. America (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=21573", "date": "2007-08-01 22:00:06", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED FOOD, HUMAN, PET - NORTH AMERICA (05)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[ProMED-mail apologizes for the inconvenience of a duplicate posting,\nbut it is necessary for clarity of comprehension. - Mod.MPP]\n[1] New Mexico: suspected case\n[2] One of 2 Hawaii cases discounted\n*****\n[1] New Mexico: suspected case\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2007\nSource: Las Cruces (NM) Sun-News [edited]\n<http://www.lcsun-news.com/latest/ci_6517322>\n\nA New Mexico man suffering from botulism poisoning is in serious\ncondition and is able to only wiggle his toes, state health officials\nsay. \"We can communicate with him only by him basically moving his\ntoes,\" Deborah Busemeyer, New Mexico Department of Health spokesman,\nsaid Wed 1 Aug 2007.\nThe 52-year-old Sandoval County man, whose name was not released, was\nhospitalized 26 Jul 2007. The department received a preliminary\npositive sample for botulism from the CDC, Busemeyer said. \"We're\nconfident he does have botulism,\" she said.\nThe department is trying to determine whether the man became ill by\neating canned food that has been recalled, Busemeyer said.\nThe CDC said that as of 22 Jul 2007, 4 people had been hospitalized\nwith botulism poisoning: 2 from Indiana and 2 from Texas.\nCastleberry's Food Co. has recalled more than 90 potentially\ncontaminated products nationwide, including canned chili, hash and\nstew, over fears of botulism contamination.\nThe recall includes 2 years' production and tens of millions of cans\nat the company's Augusta, GA, company.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It appears that this case is indeed botulism but it is, as yet, to\nbe determined whether the case is neurotoxin type A and linked to the\nrecall. Sandoval County, NM, is in the north-central part of the\nstate as can be seen at:\n<http://county-map.digital-topo-maps.com/new-mexico-county-map.gif>. - Mod.LL]\n*****\n[2] One of 2 Hawaii cases discounted\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2007\nSource: Honolulu Star Bulletin [edited]\n<http://starbulletin.com/2007/08/01/news/story09.html>\n\nThe Hawaii state Health Department has sent blood samples from a Maui\nman for federal testing for botulism but did not send samples of a\n2nd man who did not have the symptoms, said spokeswoman Janice Okubo.\nBlood samples from one person were sent to the CDC in Atlanta, but\nstate health officials decided not to send blood samples from another\nMaui resident.\nOkubo said a determination was made to send only Stockton's sample\nafter a health investigator conducted interviews with the men.\nThe 1st case, a 33 year old man, said he ate a can of Cattle Drive\nbrand chili on 24 Jul 2007 and suffered symptoms similar to botulism,\nincluding paralysis in the face and muscle weakness. He was admitted\nto Maui Memorial Medical Center on Thu 26 Jul 2007. He was released\nfrom the hospital on Sat 28 Jul 2007, and samples of his blood have\nbeen sent to the CDC.\nOkubo said the department officially has no confirmed case of botulism.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It remains to be determined if either of the cases were actually\nbotulism, let alone whether the case(s) are linked to this multistate outbreak.\n[There are 2 linked cases in Indiana and 2 in Texas. With the one\npossible case in Hawaii, there are 11 possibly-linked other cases, 8\nin Ohio, 1 in Indiana, and 1 in New Mexico (see above) along with the\nHawaiian case. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. The department received a preliminary\npositive sample for botulism from the CDC, Busemeyer said. \"We're\nconfident he does have botulism,\" she said.\nThe department is trying to determine whether the man became ill by\neating canned food that has been recalled, Busemeyer said.\nThe CDC said that as of 22 Jul 2007, 4 people had been hospitalized\nwith botulism poisoning: 2 from Indiana and 2 from Texas.\nCastleberry's Food Co. has recalled more than 90 potentially\ncontaminated products nationwide, including canned chili, hash and\nstew, over fears of botulism contamination.\nThe recall includes 2 years' production and tens of millions of cans\nat the company's Augusta, GA, company.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It appears that this case is indeed botulism but it is, as yet, to\nbe determined whether the case is neurotoxin type A and linked to the\nrecall. Sandoval County, NM, is in the north-central part of the\nstate as can be seen at:\n<http://county-map.digital-topo-maps.com/new-mexico-county-map.gif>. - Mod.LL]\n*****\n[2] One of 2 Hawaii cases discounted\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2007\nSource: Honolulu Star Bulletin [edited]\n<http://starbulletin.com/2007/08/01/news/story09.html>\n\nThe Hawaii state Health Department has sent blood samples from a Maui\nman for federal testing for botulism but did not send samples of a\n2nd man who did not have the symptoms, said spokeswoman Janice Okubo.\nBlood samples from one person were sent to the CDC in Atlanta, but\nstate health officials decided not to send blood samples from another\nMaui resident.\nOkubo said a determination was made to send only Stockton's sample\nafter a health investigator conducted interviews with the men.\nThe 1st case, a 33 year old man, said he ate a can of Cattle Drive\nbrand chili on 24 Jul 2007 and suffered symptoms similar to botulism,\nincluding paralysis in the face and muscle weakness. He was admitted\nto Maui Memorial Medical Center on Thu 26 Jul 2007. He was released\nfrom the hospital on Sat 28 Jul 2007, and samples of his blood have\nbeen sent to the CDC.\nOkubo said the department officially has no confirmed case of botulism.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It remains to be determined if either of the cases were actually\nbotulism, let alone whether the case(s) are linked to this multistate outbreak.\n[There are 2 linked cases in Indiana and 2 in Texas. America (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=20183", "date": "2007-08-01 22:00:06", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED FOOD, HUMAN, PET - NORTH AMERICA (05)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[ProMED-mail apologizes for the inconvenience of a duplicate posting,\nbut it is necessary for clarity of comprehension. - Mod.MPP]\n[1] New Mexico: suspected case\n[2] One of 2 Hawaii cases discounted\n*****\n[1] New Mexico: suspected case\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2007\nSource: Las Cruces (NM) Sun-News [edited]\n<http://www.lcsun-news.com/latest/ci_6517322>\n\nA New Mexico man suffering from botulism poisoning is in serious\ncondition and is able to only wiggle his toes, state health officials\nsay. \"We can communicate with him only by him basically moving his\ntoes,\" Deborah Busemeyer, New Mexico Department of Health spokesman,\nsaid Wed 1 Aug 2007.\nThe 52-year-old Sandoval County man, whose name was not released, was\nhospitalized 26 Jul 2007. The department received a preliminary\npositive sample for botulism from the CDC, Busemeyer said. \"We're\nconfident he does have botulism,\" she said.\nThe department is trying to determine whether the man became ill by\neating canned food that has been recalled, Busemeyer said.\nThe CDC said that as of 22 Jul 2007, 4 people had been hospitalized\nwith botulism poisoning: 2 from Indiana and 2 from Texas.\nCastleberry's Food Co. has recalled more than 90 potentially\ncontaminated products nationwide, including canned chili, hash and\nstew, over fears of botulism contamination.\nThe recall includes 2 years' production and tens of millions of cans\nat the company's Augusta, GA, company.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It appears that this case is indeed botulism but it is, as yet, to\nbe determined whether the case is neurotoxin type A and linked to the\nrecall. Sandoval County, NM, is in the north-central part of the\nstate as can be seen at:\n<http://county-map.digital-topo-maps.com/new-mexico-county-map.gif>. - Mod.LL]\n*****\n[2] One of 2 Hawaii cases discounted\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2007\nSource: Honolulu Star Bulletin [edited]\n<http://starbulletin.com/2007/08/01/news/story09.html>\n\nThe Hawaii state Health Department has sent blood samples from a Maui\nman for federal testing for botulism but did not send samples of a\n2nd man who did not have the symptoms, said spokeswoman Janice Okubo.\nBlood samples from one person were sent to the CDC in Atlanta, but\nstate health officials decided not to send blood samples from another\nMaui resident.\nOkubo said a determination was made to send only Stockton's sample\nafter a health investigator conducted interviews with the men.\nThe 1st case, a 33 year old man, said he ate a can of Cattle Drive\nbrand chili on 24 Jul 2007 and suffered symptoms similar to botulism,\nincluding paralysis in the face and muscle weakness. He was admitted\nto Maui Memorial Medical Center on Thu 26 Jul 2007. He was released\nfrom the hospital on Sat 28 Jul 2007, and samples of his blood have\nbeen sent to the CDC.\nOkubo said the department officially has no confirmed case of botulism.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It remains to be determined if either of the cases were actually\nbotulism, let alone whether the case(s) are linked to this multistate outbreak.\n[There are 2 linked cases in Indiana and 2 in Texas. With the one\npossible case in Hawaii, there are 11 possibly-linked other cases, 8\nin Ohio, 1 in Indiana, and 1 in New Mexico (see above) along with the\nHawaiian case. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - N. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ohio", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Augusta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Sandoval County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NM", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "20132", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, canned food, human, pet - N. America (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=20132", "date": "2007-07-24 16:00:08", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED FOOD, HUMAN, PET - USA (02)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 24 Jul 2007\nFrom: Alan Shlosberg\n<alans@moag.gov.il>\n\nThe FDA wrote about botulism\n(<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/NEWS/2007/NEW01670.html>) that \"the\ndisease has only been seen occasionally in dogs and has not been\nreported in cats.\nIn fact a fatal such toxicosis has been reported in cats:\n1. Shlosberg A, Elad D, Greenberg K, et al: Mortality in a group of\ncats probably caused by Clostridium botulinum type C toxin. World\nCongress on Animal, Plant and Microbial Toxins, Adelaide, Australia, 2003.\n2. Elad D, Yas-Natan E, Aroch I, et al: Natural Clostridium botulinum\ntype C toxicosis in a group of cats. J Clin Microbiol 2004;42: 5406-408.\n--\nDr. Alan Shlosberg\nKimron Veterinary Institute\nIsrael\n<alans@moag.gov.il>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Shlosberg for pointing out the misstatement in the\nFDA report and indeed neurotoxin type C botulism has been reported in\ncats. The citations refer to botulism that developed in a group of 8\n\"backyard\" cats that were feed meat from a dead pelican that was\nthought to have been accidentally electrocuted by a high-tension wire.\nIn this discussion part of the paper, the authors (including Dr.\nShlosberg) state (with citation numbers changed to be consecutive and\nreformatted) that:\n\"The occurrence of botulism in carnivores is very rare. Several\nreports of type C botulism in dogs (1), including one following\ncarrion consumption (2), and lions (3) have been published. To the\nbest of our knowledge, however, there are no reports of natural\nbotulism in cats, although these animals have been used as\nexperimental models (4). Interestingly, the cats were found to be\nmuch more susceptible to parenteral exposure to botulism toxin than\nto oral exposure (5). Attempts to elucidate the mechanism upon which\nthis difference in susceptibility is based using toxin neutralization\nby natural antibodies, tissues, and digestive enzymes were unsuccessful (5).\n1. Shelton, GD: Myasthenia gravis and disorders of the neuromuscular\ntransmission. Vet Clin N Am Small Anim Pract 2002;32: 189-206.\n2. Farrow BR, Murrell WG, Revington ML, et al: 1983. Type C botulism\nin young dogs. Aust Vet J 1983;60: 374-77.\n3. Greenwood AG: 1985. Diagnosis and treatment of botulism in lions.\nVet Rec 1985;117: 58-60.\n4. Dimitrova, DM, Shall MS, Goldberg SJ: Short-term effects of\nbotulinum toxin on the lateral rectus muscle of the cat. Exp Brain\nRes 2002;147: 449-55.\n5. Prevot AR, Sillioc R: Biological enigma: cat and botulism. Ann.\nInst. Pasteur 1955;89: 354-57.\"\nIndeed, it appears to be the case that this Israeli cat cluster was\nthe first natural cases of botulism in cats seen while alive.\nHowever, Galey and colleagues reported in 2000 that a cluster of type\nC botulism in dairy cattle was due ingestion of a rotten bale of oat\nhay that (in retrospect!) contained a dead cat. Testing of the cat\ncarcass did find the neurotoxin. Of note, the toxin was not found in\nthe cow's milk.\nCitation: Galey FD, Terra R. Walker R, et al: Type C botulism in\ndairy cattle from feed contaminated with a dead cat. J Vet Diagn\nInvest 2000;12: 204-209. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall (02) 20070720.2331\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall 20070719.2316\nBotulism, seafood - Canada (QC): recall 20070609.1889\nBotulism, olives - USA ex Italy: recall 20070329.1085\nBotulism, smoked uneviscerated fish - USA (NY): recall 20070326.1043\nBotulism, olives - Canada ex Italy: recall 20070326.1042\nBotulism, olives - USA: recall 20070311.0861\nBotulism, olives - USA (FL, GA, NY): recall 20070310.0847\nBotulism, baby food - North America: alert, recall (02) 20070220.0636\nBotulism, baby food - North America: alert, recall 20070218.0618\n2006\n----\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada) (03) 20061021.3026\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada) 20061012.2925\nBotulism, carrot juice - Canada (ON) ex USA 20061009.2899\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate) (02) 20061007.2880\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate): FL 20060930.2808\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (GA): alert 20060916.2638\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada (02): background 20060927.2760\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada: recall 20060926.2748\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\n...................................ll/ejp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. America (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=19813", "date": "2007-07-24 16:00:08", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED FOOD, HUMAN, PET - USA (02)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 24 Jul 2007\nFrom: Alan Shlosberg\n<alans@moag.gov.il>\n\nThe FDA wrote about botulism\n(<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/NEWS/2007/NEW01670.html>) that \"the\ndisease has only been seen occasionally in dogs and has not been\nreported in cats.\nIn fact a fatal such toxicosis has been reported in cats:\n1. Shlosberg A, Elad D, Greenberg K, et al: Mortality in a group of\ncats probably caused by Clostridium botulinum type C toxin. World\nCongress on Animal, Plant and Microbial Toxins, Adelaide, Australia, 2003.\n2. Elad D, Yas-Natan E, Aroch I, et al: Natural Clostridium botulinum\ntype C toxicosis in a group of cats. J Clin Microbiol 2004;42: 5406-408.\n--\nDr. Alan Shlosberg\nKimron Veterinary Institute\nIsrael\n<alans@moag.gov.il>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Shlosberg for pointing out the misstatement in the\nFDA report and indeed neurotoxin type C botulism has been reported in\ncats. The citations refer to botulism that developed in a group of 8\n\"backyard\" cats that were feed meat from a dead pelican that was\nthought to have been accidentally electrocuted by a high-tension wire.\nIn this discussion part of the paper, the authors (including Dr.\nShlosberg) state (with citation numbers changed to be consecutive and\nreformatted) that:\n\"The occurrence of botulism in carnivores is very rare. Several\nreports of type C botulism in dogs (1), including one following\ncarrion consumption (2), and lions (3) have been published. To the\nbest of our knowledge, however, there are no reports of natural\nbotulism in cats, although these animals have been used as\nexperimental models (4). Interestingly, the cats were found to be\nmuch more susceptible to parenteral exposure to botulism toxin than\nto oral exposure (5). Attempts to elucidate the mechanism upon which\nthis difference in susceptibility is based using toxin neutralization\nby natural antibodies, tissues, and digestive enzymes were unsuccessful (5).\n1. Shelton, GD: Myasthenia gravis and disorders of the neuromuscular\ntransmission. Vet Clin N Am Small Anim Pract 2002;32: 189-206.\n2. Farrow BR, Murrell WG, Revington ML, et al: 1983. Type C botulism\nin young dogs. Aust Vet J 1983;60: 374-77.\n3. Greenwood AG: 1985. Diagnosis and treatment of botulism in lions.\nVet Rec 1985;117: 58-60.\n4. Dimitrova, DM, Shall MS, Goldberg SJ: Short-term effects of\nbotulinum toxin on the lateral rectus muscle of the cat. Exp Brain\nRes 2002;147: 449-55.\n5. Prevot AR, Sillioc R: Biological enigma: cat and botulism. Ann.\nInst. Pasteur 1955;89: 354-57.\"\nIndeed, it appears to be the case that this Israeli cat cluster was\nthe first natural cases of botulism in cats seen while alive.\nHowever, Galey and colleagues reported in 2000 that a cluster of type\nC botulism in dairy cattle was due ingestion of a rotten bale of oat\nhay that (in retrospect!) contained a dead cat. Testing of the cat\ncarcass did find the neurotoxin. Of note, the toxin was not found in\nthe cow's milk.\nCitation: Galey FD, Terra R. Walker R, et al: Type C botulism in\ndairy cattle from feed contaminated with a dead cat. J Vet Diagn\nInvest 2000;12: 204-209. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall (02) 20070720.2331\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall 20070719.2316\nBotulism, seafood - Canada (QC): recall 20070609.1889\nBotulism, olives - USA ex Italy: recall 20070329.1085\nBotulism, smoked uneviscerated fish - USA (NY): recall 20070326.1043\nBotulism, olives - Canada ex Italy: recall 20070326.1042\nBotulism, olives - USA: recall 20070311.0861\nBotulism, olives - USA (FL, GA, NY): recall 20070310.0847\nBotulism, baby food - North America: alert, recall (02) 20070220.0636\nBotulism, baby food - North America: alert, recall 20070218.0618\n2006\n----\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada) (03) 20061021.3026\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada) 20061012.2925\nBotulism, carrot juice - Canada (ON) ex USA 20061009.2899\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate) (02) 20061007.2880\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate): FL 20060930.2808\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (GA): alert 20060916.2638\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada (02): background 20060927.2760\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada: recall 20060926.2748\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\n...................................ll/ejp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Shlosberg A, Elad D, Greenberg K, et al: Mortality in a group of\ncats probably caused by Clostridium botulinum type C toxin. World\nCongress on Animal, Plant and Microbial Toxins, Adelaide, Australia, 2003.\n2. Elad D, Yas-Natan E, Aroch I, et al: Natural Clostridium botulinum\ntype C toxicosis in a group of cats. J Clin Microbiol 2004;42: 5406-408.\n--\nDr. Alan Shlosberg\nKimron Veterinary Institute\nIsrael\n<alans@moag.gov.il>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Shlosberg for pointing out the misstatement in the\nFDA report and indeed neurotoxin type C botulism has been reported in\ncats. The citations refer to botulism that developed in a group of 8\n\"backyard\" cats that were feed meat from a dead pelican that was\nthought to have been accidentally electrocuted by a high-tension wire.\nIn this discussion part of the paper, the authors (including Dr.\nShlosberg) state (with citation numbers changed to be consecutive and\nreformatted) that:\n\"The occurrence of botulism in carnivores is very rare. Several\nreports of type C botulism in dogs (1), including one following\ncarrion consumption (2), and lions (3) have been published. To the\nbest of our knowledge, however, there are no reports of natural\nbotulism in cats, although these animals have been used as\nexperimental models (4). Interestingly, the cats were found to be\nmuch more susceptible to parenteral exposure to botulism toxin than\nto oral exposure (5). Attempts to elucidate the mechanism upon which\nthis difference in susceptibility is based using toxin neutralization\nby natural antibodies, tissues, and digestive enzymes were unsuccessful (5).\n1. Shelton, GD: Myasthenia gravis and disorders of the neuromuscular\ntransmission. Vet Clin N Am Small Anim Pract 2002;32: 189-206.\n2. Farrow BR, Murrell WG, Revington ML, et al: 1983. Type C botulism\nin young dogs. Aust Vet J 1983;60: 374-77.\n3. Greenwood AG: 1985. Diagnosis and treatment of botulism in lions.\nVet Rec 1985;117: 58-60.\n4. Dimitrova, DM, Shall MS, Goldberg SJ: Short-term effects of\nbotulinum toxin on the lateral rectus muscle of the cat. Exp Brain\nRes 2002;147: 449-55.\n5. Prevot AR, Sillioc R: Biological enigma: cat and botulism. Ann.\nInst. Pasteur 1955;89: 354-57.\"\nIndeed, it appears to be the case that this Israeli cat cluster was\nthe first natural cases of botulism in cats seen while alive.\nHowever, Galey and colleagues reported in 2000 that a cluster of type\nC botulism in dairy cattle was due ingestion of a rotten bale of oat\nhay that (in retrospect!) contained a dead cat. Testing of the cat\ncarcass did find the neurotoxin. Of note, the toxin was not found in\nthe cow's milk.\nCitation: Galey FD, Terra R. Walker R, et al: Type C botulism in\ndairy cattle from feed contaminated with a dead cat. J Vet Diagn\nInvest 2000;12: 204-209. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall (02) 20070720.2331\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall 20070719.2316\nBotulism, seafood - Canada (QC): recall 20070609.1889\nBotulism, olives - USA ex Italy: recall 20070329.1085\nBotulism, smoked uneviscerated fish - USA (NY): recall 20070326.1043\nBotulism, olives - Canada ex Italy: recall 20070326.1042\nBotulism, olives - USA: recall 20070311.0861\nBotulism, olives - USA (FL, GA, NY): recall 20070310.0847\nBotulism, baby food - North America: alert, recall (02) 20070220.0636\nBotulism, baby food - North America: alert, recall 20070218.0618\n2006\n----\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada) (03) 20061021.3026\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada) 20061012.2925\nBotulism, carrot juice - Canada (ON) ex USA 20061009.2899\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate) (02) 20061007.2880\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate): FL 20060930.2808\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (GA): alert 20060916.2638\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada (02): background 20060927.2760\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada: recall 20060926.2748\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\n...................................ll/ejp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Several\nreports of type C botulism in dogs (1), including one following\ncarrion consumption (2), and lions (3) have been published. Type C botulism\nin young dogs. Aust Vet J 1983;60: 374-77.\n3. Greenwood AG: 1985. Diagnosis and treatment of botulism in lions.\nVet Rec 1985;117: 58-60.\n4. Dimitrova, DM, Shall MS, Goldberg SJ: Short-term effects of\nbotulinum toxin on the lateral rectus muscle of the cat. Exp Brain\nRes 2002;147: 449-55.\n5. Prevot AR, Sillioc R: Biological enigma: cat and botulism. Ann.\nInst. Pasteur 1955;89: 354-57.\"\nIndeed, it appears to be the case that this Israeli cat cluster was\nthe first natural cases of botulism in cats seen while alive.\nHowever, Galey and colleagues reported in 2000 that a cluster of type\nC botulism in dairy cattle was due ingestion of a rotten bale of oat\nhay that (in retrospect!) contained a dead cat. Testing of the cat\ncarcass did find the neurotoxin. Of note, the toxin was not found in\nthe cow's milk.\nCitation: Galey FD, Terra R. Walker R, et al: Type C botulism in\ndairy cattle from feed contaminated with a dead cat. J Vet Diagn\nInvest 2000;12: 204-209. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall (02) 20070720.2331\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall 20070719.2316\nBotulism, seafood - Canada (QC): recall 20070609.1889\nBotulism, olives - USA ex Italy: recall 20070329.1085\nBotulism, smoked uneviscerated fish - USA (NY): recall 20070326.1043\nBotulism, olives - Canada ex Italy: recall 20070326.1042\nBotulism, olives - USA: recall 20070311.0861\nBotulism, olives - USA (FL, GA, NY): recall 20070310.0847\nBotulism, baby food - North America: alert, recall (02) 20070220.0636\nBotulism, baby food - North America: alert, recall 20070218.0618\n2006\n----\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada) (03) 20061021.3026\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada) 20061012.2925\nBotulism, carrot juice - Canada (ON) ex USA 20061009.2899\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate) (02) 20061007.2880\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate): FL 20060930.2808\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (GA): alert 20060916.2638\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada (02): background 20060927.2760\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada: recall 20060926.2748\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\n...................................ll/ejp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "1983-03-15 00:00:00", "1985-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Myasthenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "QC", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Yas - Natan E", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "18714", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=18714", "date": "2007-07-24 16:00:08", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED FOOD, HUMAN, PET - USA (02)\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 24 Jul 2007\nFrom: Alan Shlosberg\n<alans@moag.gov.il>\n\nThe FDA wrote about botulism\n(<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/NEWS/2007/NEW01670.html>) that \"the\ndisease has only been seen occasionally in dogs and has not been\nreported in cats.\nIn fact a fatal such toxicosis has been reported in cats:\n1. Shlosberg A, Elad D, Greenberg K, et al: Mortality in a group of\ncats probably caused by Clostridium botulinum type C toxin. World\nCongress on Animal, Plant and Microbial Toxins, Adelaide, Australia, 2003.\n2. Elad D, Yas-Natan E, Aroch I, et al: Natural Clostridium botulinum\ntype C toxicosis in a group of cats. J Clin Microbiol 2004;42: 5406-408.\n--\nDr. Alan Shlosberg\nKimron Veterinary Institute\nIsrael\n<alans@moag.gov.il>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Shlosberg for pointing out the misstatement in the\nFDA report and indeed neurotoxin type C botulism has been reported in\ncats. The citations refer to botulism that developed in a group of 8\n\"backyard\" cats that were feed meat from a dead pelican that was\nthought to have been accidentally electrocuted by a high-tension wire.\nIn this discussion part of the paper, the authors (including Dr.\nShlosberg) state (with citation numbers changed to be consecutive and\nreformatted) that:\n\"The occurrence of botulism in carnivores is very rare. Several\nreports of type C botulism in dogs (1), including one following\ncarrion consumption (2), and lions (3) have been published. To the\nbest of our knowledge, however, there are no reports of natural\nbotulism in cats, although these animals have been used as\nexperimental models (4). Interestingly, the cats were found to be\nmuch more susceptible to parenteral exposure to botulism toxin than\nto oral exposure (5). Attempts to elucidate the mechanism upon which\nthis difference in susceptibility is based using toxin neutralization\nby natural antibodies, tissues, and digestive enzymes were unsuccessful (5).\n1. Shelton, GD: Myasthenia gravis and disorders of the neuromuscular\ntransmission. Vet Clin N Am Small Anim Pract 2002;32: 189-206.\n2. Farrow BR, Murrell WG, Revington ML, et al: 1983. Type C botulism\nin young dogs. Aust Vet J 1983;60: 374-77.\n3. Greenwood AG: 1985. Diagnosis and treatment of botulism in lions.\nVet Rec 1985;117: 58-60.\n4. Dimitrova, DM, Shall MS, Goldberg SJ: Short-term effects of\nbotulinum toxin on the lateral rectus muscle of the cat. Exp Brain\nRes 2002;147: 449-55.\n5. Prevot AR, Sillioc R: Biological enigma: cat and botulism. Ann.\nInst. Pasteur 1955;89: 354-57.\"\nIndeed, it appears to be the case that this Israeli cat cluster was\nthe first natural cases of botulism in cats seen while alive.\nHowever, Galey and colleagues reported in 2000 that a cluster of type\nC botulism in dairy cattle was due ingestion of a rotten bale of oat\nhay that (in retrospect!) contained a dead cat. Testing of the cat\ncarcass did find the neurotoxin. Of note, the toxin was not found in\nthe cow's milk.\nCitation: Galey FD, Terra R. Walker R, et al: Type C botulism in\ndairy cattle from feed contaminated with a dead cat. J Vet Diagn\nInvest 2000;12: 204-209. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food, human, pet - USA: alert, recall 20070723.2366\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall (02) 20070720.2331\nBotulism, chili sauce - USA: alert, recall 20070719.2316\nBotulism, seafood - Canada (QC): recall 20070609.1889\nBotulism, olives - USA ex Italy: recall 20070329.1085\nBotulism, smoked uneviscerated fish - USA (NY): recall 20070326.1043\nBotulism, olives - Canada ex Italy: recall 20070326.1042\nBotulism, olives - USA: recall 20070311.0861\nBotulism, olives - USA (FL, GA, NY): recall 20070310.0847\nBotulism, baby food - North America: alert, recall (02) 20070220.0636\nBotulism, baby food - North America: alert, recall 20070218.0618\n2006\n----\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada) (03) 20061021.3026\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada) 20061012.2925\nBotulism, carrot juice - Canada (ON) ex USA 20061009.2899\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate) (02) 20061007.2880\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate): FL 20060930.2808\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (GA): alert 20060916.2638\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada (02): background 20060927.2760\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada: recall 20060926.2748\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\n...................................ll/ejp/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Assoc.Mod.NP, edited]\n<http://www.annews.ru/news/detail.php?ID=94247>\n\nA cluster of botulism cases has been reported in the Dubovsky\ndistrict of the Rostov region. The Territorial management of\nRospotrebnadzor (Federal Service for Surveillance of Consumer Rights\nand Human Welfare - Mod.NP) in the Rostov region reported that on Mon\n16 Apr 2007, 6 local residents were hospitalized in the Central\nRegional Hospital of the Dubovsky district with symptoms of botulism.\nIt was established that all patients had consumed home-canned\nmushrooms that had been picked in a forest belt near the village\nAccording to data from Rospotrebnadzor, since the beginning of 2007,\n8 persons have been hospitalized with botulism in hospitals in the\nRostov region, where annually 25-30 persons contract the disease.\nDuring 2005-2006, 10 inhabitants of the Rostov region died from\nbotulism. As yet, no deaths have been registered in 2007.\nRospotrebnadzor stressed that the vehicles for transmission of the\ndisease, as a rule, are canned mushrooms and vegetables and smoked\nfish prepared in domestic conditions.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to the latest information, botulinum toxin type A has been\nfound in the blood of the patients.\n<http://www.dontr.ru/Environ/WebObjects/dontr.woa/wa/Main?textid=23626>\n(in Russian).\nBotulinum toxin type E, usually associated with marine sources,\nprevails in the region. More than 20 cases of botulism, including 5\nfatalities were reported in the Rostov region in 2006. Most\nfrequently, lethal outcomes were connected with late access to\nmedical care (2-3 days after onset). Cases of the disease related to\nthe consumption of dried and smoked fish are prevalent in the\nsouthern areas of the region located in a steppe zone in the mouth of\nthe river Don and on the coast of the Taganrog Gulf of the Azov sea.\nBotulism associated with the consumption of canned mushrooms more\noften is reported in the northern forest-steppe areas. The disease\nlinked to the consumption of home-canned vegetables occurs everywhere.\nThe Rostov-on-Don Region is located in the southern part of the\nEast-European plateau and partly in the North Caucasian region. It\ncan be found on a map at\n<http://www.rbcc.co.uk/images/rostov_map.gif>. - Assoc.Mod.NP]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Kazakhstan (Mangiustauskaya): RFI 20070222.0655\nBotulism, fatal, canned food - Azerbaijan 20070124.0321\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Dagestan) 20070115.0196\n2006\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, canned food, fish - Russia (Lipetsk) 20060916.2640\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nBotulism, canned salad - Kyrgyzstan (Kant) 20050406.099\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\n1999\n----\nBotulism - Azerbaijan (Baku) 19991222.2193\n.............................................np/ll/mj/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-04-18 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Mangiustauskaya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Baku", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "17561", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, dried fish, canned vegetables - Russia (Rostov)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=17561", "date": "2007-04-20 13:00:02", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED MUSHROOMS - RUSSIA (ROSTOV)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 18 April 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Annews.ru News agency [trans. Assoc.Mod.NP, edited]\n<http://www.annews.ru/news/detail.php?ID=94247>\n\nA cluster of botulism cases has been reported in the Dubovsky\ndistrict of the Rostov region. The Territorial management of\nRospotrebnadzor (Federal Service for Surveillance of Consumer Rights\nand Human Welfare - Mod.NP) in the Rostov region reported that on Mon\n16 Apr 2007, 6 local residents were hospitalized in the Central\nRegional Hospital of the Dubovsky district with symptoms of botulism.\nIt was established that all patients had consumed home-canned\nmushrooms that had been picked in a forest belt near the village\nAccording to data from Rospotrebnadzor, since the beginning of 2007,\n8 persons have been hospitalized with botulism in hospitals in the\nRostov region, where annually 25-30 persons contract the disease.\nDuring 2005-2006, 10 inhabitants of the Rostov region died from\nbotulism. As yet, no deaths have been registered in 2007.\nRospotrebnadzor stressed that the vehicles for transmission of the\ndisease, as a rule, are canned mushrooms and vegetables and smoked\nfish prepared in domestic conditions.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to the latest information, botulinum toxin type A has been\nfound in the blood of the patients.\n<http://www.dontr.ru/Environ/WebObjects/dontr.woa/wa/Main?textid=23626>\n(in Russian).\nBotulinum toxin type E, usually associated with marine sources,\nprevails in the region. More than 20 cases of botulism, including 5\nfatalities were reported in the Rostov region in 2006. Most\nfrequently, lethal outcomes were connected with late access to\nmedical care (2-3 days after onset). Cases of the disease related to\nthe consumption of dried and smoked fish are prevalent in the\nsouthern areas of the region located in a steppe zone in the mouth of\nthe river Don and on the coast of the Taganrog Gulf of the Azov sea.\nBotulism associated with the consumption of canned mushrooms more\noften is reported in the northern forest-steppe areas. The disease\nlinked to the consumption of home-canned vegetables occurs everywhere.\nThe Rostov-on-Don Region is located in the southern part of the\nEast-European plateau and partly in the North Caucasian region. It\ncan be found on a map at\n<http://www.rbcc.co.uk/images/rostov_map.gif>. - Assoc.Mod.NP]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Kazakhstan (Mangiustauskaya): RFI 20070222.0655\nBotulism, fatal, canned food - Azerbaijan 20070124.0321\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Dagestan) 20070115.0196\n2006\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, canned food, fish - Russia (Lipetsk) 20060916.2640\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nBotulism, canned salad - Kyrgyzstan (Kant) 20050406.099\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\n1999\n----\nBotulism - Azerbaijan (Baku) 19991222.2193\n.............................................np/ll/mj/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-04-18 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Mangiustauskaya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Baku", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "17489", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - USA (NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=17489", "date": "2007-04-20 13:00:02", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED MUSHROOMS - RUSSIA (ROSTOV)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 18 April 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Annews.ru News agency [trans. Assoc.Mod.NP, edited]\n<http://www.annews.ru/news/detail.php?ID=94247>\n\nA cluster of botulism cases has been reported in the Dubovsky\ndistrict of the Rostov region. The Territorial management of\nRospotrebnadzor (Federal Service for Surveillance of Consumer Rights\nand Human Welfare - Mod.NP) in the Rostov region reported that on Mon\n16 Apr 2007, 6 local residents were hospitalized in the Central\nRegional Hospital of the Dubovsky district with symptoms of botulism.\nIt was established that all patients had consumed home-canned\nmushrooms that had been picked in a forest belt near the village\nAccording to data from Rospotrebnadzor, since the beginning of 2007,\n8 persons have been hospitalized with botulism in hospitals in the\nRostov region, where annually 25-30 persons contract the disease.\nDuring 2005-2006, 10 inhabitants of the Rostov region died from\nbotulism. As yet, no deaths have been registered in 2007.\nRospotrebnadzor stressed that the vehicles for transmission of the\ndisease, as a rule, are canned mushrooms and vegetables and smoked\nfish prepared in domestic conditions.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to the latest information, botulinum toxin type A has been\nfound in the blood of the patients.\n<http://www.dontr.ru/Environ/WebObjects/dontr.woa/wa/Main?textid=23626>\n(in Russian).\nBotulinum toxin type E, usually associated with marine sources,\nprevails in the region. More than 20 cases of botulism, including 5\nfatalities were reported in the Rostov region in 2006. Most\nfrequently, lethal outcomes were connected with late access to\nmedical care (2-3 days after onset). Cases of the disease related to\nthe consumption of dried and smoked fish are prevalent in the\nsouthern areas of the region located in a steppe zone in the mouth of\nthe river Don and on the coast of the Taganrog Gulf of the Azov sea.\nBotulism associated with the consumption of canned mushrooms more\noften is reported in the northern forest-steppe areas. The disease\nlinked to the consumption of home-canned vegetables occurs everywhere.\nThe Rostov-on-Don Region is located in the southern part of the\nEast-European plateau and partly in the North Caucasian region. It\ncan be found on a map at\n<http://www.rbcc.co.uk/images/rostov_map.gif>. - Assoc.Mod.NP]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Kazakhstan (Mangiustauskaya): RFI 20070222.0655\nBotulism, fatal, canned food - Azerbaijan 20070124.0321\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Dagestan) 20070115.0196\n2006\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, canned food, fish - Russia (Lipetsk) 20060916.2640\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nBotulism, canned salad - Kyrgyzstan (Kant) 20050406.099\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\n1999\n----\nBotulism - Azerbaijan (Baku) 19991222.2193\n.............................................np/ll/mj/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Assoc.Mod.NP, edited]\n<http://www.annews.ru/news/detail.php?ID=94247>\n\nA cluster of botulism cases has been reported in the Dubovsky\ndistrict of the Rostov region. The Territorial management of\nRospotrebnadzor (Federal Service for Surveillance of Consumer Rights\nand Human Welfare - Mod.NP) in the Rostov region reported that on Mon\n16 Apr 2007, 6 local residents were hospitalized in the Central\nRegional Hospital of the Dubovsky district with symptoms of botulism.\nIt was established that all patients had consumed home-canned\nmushrooms that had been picked in a forest belt near the village\nAccording to data from Rospotrebnadzor, since the beginning of 2007,\n8 persons have been hospitalized with botulism in hospitals in the\nRostov region, where annually 25-30 persons contract the disease.\nDuring 2005-2006, 10 inhabitants of the Rostov region died from\nbotulism. Most\nfrequently, lethal outcomes were connected with late access to\nmedical care (2-3 days after onset). The disease\nlinked to the consumption of home-canned vegetables occurs everywhere.\nThe Rostov-on-Don Region is located in the southern part of the\nEast-European plateau and partly in the North Caucasian region. Cases of the disease related to\nthe consumption of dried and smoked fish are prevalent in the\nsouthern areas of the region located in a steppe zone in the mouth of\nthe river Don and on the coast of the Taganrog Gulf of the Azov sea.\nBotulism associated with the consumption of canned mushrooms more\noften is reported in the northern forest-steppe areas. The disease\nlinked to the consumption of home-canned vegetables occurs everywhere.\nThe Rostov-on-Don Region is located in the southern part of the\nEast-European plateau and partly in the North Caucasian region. It\ncan be found on a map at\n<http://www.rbcc.co.uk/images/rostov_map.gif>. - Assoc.Mod.NP]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Kazakhstan (Mangiustauskaya): RFI 20070222.0655\nBotulism, fatal, canned food - Azerbaijan 20070124.0321\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Dagestan) 20070115.0196\n2006\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, canned food, fish - Russia (Lipetsk) 20060916.2640\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nBotulism, canned salad - Kyrgyzstan (Kant) 20050406.099\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\n1999\n----\nBotulism - Azerbaijan (Baku) 19991222.2193\n.............................................np/ll/mj/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
