Assoc.Mod.NP, edited]\n<http://www.annews.ru/news/detail.php?ID=94247>\n\nA cluster of botulism cases has been reported in the Dubovsky\ndistrict of the Rostov region. The Territorial management of\nRospotrebnadzor (Federal Service for Surveillance of Consumer Rights\nand Human Welfare - Mod.NP) in the Rostov region reported that on Mon\n16 Apr 2007, 6 local residents were hospitalized in the Central\nRegional Hospital of the Dubovsky district with symptoms of botulism.\nIt was established that all patients had consumed home-canned\nmushrooms that had been picked in a forest belt near the village\nAccording to data from Rospotrebnadzor, since the beginning of 2007,\n8 persons have been hospitalized with botulism in hospitals in the\nRostov region, where annually 25-30 persons contract the disease.\nDuring 2005-2006, 10 inhabitants of the Rostov region died from\nbotulism. As yet, no deaths have been registered in 2007.\nRospotrebnadzor stressed that the vehicles for transmission of the\ndisease, as a rule, are canned mushrooms and vegetables and smoked\nfish prepared in domestic conditions.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to the latest information, botulinum toxin type A has been\nfound in the blood of the patients.\n<http://www.dontr.ru/Environ/WebObjects/dontr.woa/wa/Main?textid=23626>\n(in Russian).\nBotulinum toxin type E, usually associated with marine sources,\nprevails in the region. More than 20 cases of botulism, including 5\nfatalities were reported in the Rostov region in 2006. Most\nfrequently, lethal outcomes were connected with late access to\nmedical care (2-3 days after onset). Cases of the disease related to\nthe consumption of dried and smoked fish are prevalent in the\nsouthern areas of the region located in a steppe zone in the mouth of\nthe river Don and on the coast of the Taganrog Gulf of the Azov sea.\nBotulism associated with the consumption of canned mushrooms more\noften is reported in the northern forest-steppe areas. The disease\nlinked to the consumption of home-canned vegetables occurs everywhere.\nThe Rostov-on-Don Region is located in the southern part of the\nEast-European plateau and partly in the North Caucasian region. It\ncan be found on a map at\n<http://www.rbcc.co.uk/images/rostov_map.gif>. - Assoc.Mod.NP]\nSee Also\nBotulism - Kazakhstan (Mangiustauskaya): RFI 20070222.0655\nBotulism, fatal, canned food - Azerbaijan 20070124.0321\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Dagestan) 20070115.0196\n2006\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, canned food, fish - Russia (Lipetsk) 20060916.2640\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nBotulism, canned salad - Kyrgyzstan (Kant) 20050406.099\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\n1999\n----\nBotulism - Azerbaijan (Baku) 19991222.2193\n.............................................np/ll/mj/dk\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The information was provided by the ministry of emergency\nsituation of Kazakhstan. According to the ministry, the 6 people are\nmen and women between 17 and 37 years old.\nThe cause of the poisoning, according to the state department of\nepidemiological surveillance, was bad quality food (literal\ntranslation from Russian is \"food waste.\" - Mod.NR).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Little information is given in this posting. My\nguess is that the artichokes were in an oil dressing and received some heat\ntreatment after canning, and the _Clostridium botulinum_ toxin may be type B.\nI find it useful to restate the conclusion of my ProMED-mail submission on\nbotulism caused by garlic in oil (ProMED post 20030131.0267), which read:\n\"This case of botulism illustrates the need to be alert and not to rule out\nbotulism even in widely distributed convenience foods in developed\ncountries. It is, furthermore, a reminder to manufacturers and authorities\nto be careful, even today, that the conditions of production safeguard\nagainst growth of _Clostridium botulinum_.\"\nThe conditions in the jars of artichokes must have been similar to the\nbottled garlic; not assuring sufficient acidity and/or dissolved salt or\nsugar (low redox-potential), which in turn was sufficient for outgrowth of\nspores. Most importantly, anaerobic conditions are created by covering the\nvegetables with oil and pasteurizing or giving similar heat treatment\ninsufficient for the inactivation of spores but driving out residual oxygen.\nKnown cases of botulism from vegetables in oil, apart from garlic and\nartichokes, include eggplants, cucumbers and olives, but not tomatoes; Why?\nI assume the natural acidity of tomatoes prevents the outgrowth of\nbotulinum spores.\n--\nLars Krusell, MSc\nDanish Food Administration\nAarhus, Denmark\n<lakr@fvst.dk>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Mr Krusell for his comments regarding this area. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzcoa) 20070116.0203\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Dagestan) 20070115.0196\n2006\n---\nBotulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara)(02) 20061230.3652\nBotulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara) 20061227.3628\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, barbecue - Austria (northern) 20061214.3521\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism - Russia (Rostov) 20061108.3206\nBotulism, avian - USA (NY) 20061103.3161\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada)(03) 20061021.3026\n2005\n---\nBotulism, fermented salmon - USA (AK) 20050829.2555\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex. Georgia (02): susp. 20050426.1159\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex Georgia: susp 20050420.1108\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism during pregnancy - Kyrgyzstan (Chuysk) 20050218.0538\n2003\n---\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark 20030131.0267\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\n..................ll/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Canada)(03", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8164", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, nachos - Australia (VIC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8164", "date": "2007-01-20 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED ARTICHOKES - SPAIN (GUIPUZCOA) (02)\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 19 Jan 2007\nFrom: Lars Krusell <lakr@fvst.dk>\n\nIt would be useful to get further product information in this case. My\nguess is that the artichokes were in an oil dressing and received some heat\ntreatment after canning, and the _Clostridium botulinum_ toxin may be type B.\nI find it useful to restate the conclusion of my ProMED-mail submission on\nbotulism caused by garlic in oil (ProMED post 20030131.0267), which read:\n\"This case of botulism illustrates the need to be alert and not to rule out\nbotulism even in widely distributed convenience foods in developed\ncountries. It is, furthermore, a reminder to manufacturers and authorities\nto be careful, even today, that the conditions of production safeguard\nagainst growth of _Clostridium botulinum_.\"\nThe conditions in the jars of artichokes must have been similar to the\nbottled garlic; not assuring sufficient acidity and/or dissolved salt or\nsugar (low redox-potential), which in turn was sufficient for outgrowth of\nspores. Most importantly, anaerobic conditions are created by covering the\nvegetables with oil and pasteurizing or giving similar heat treatment\ninsufficient for the inactivation of spores but driving out residual oxygen.\nKnown cases of botulism from vegetables in oil, apart from garlic and\nartichokes, include eggplants, cucumbers and olives, but not tomatoes; Why?\nI assume the natural acidity of tomatoes prevents the outgrowth of\nbotulinum spores.\n--\nLars Krusell, MSc\nDanish Food Administration\nAarhus, Denmark\n<lakr@fvst.dk>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Mr Krusell for his comments regarding this area. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzcoa) 20070116.0203\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Dagestan) 20070115.0196\n2006\n---\nBotulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara)(02) 20061230.3652\nBotulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara) 20061227.3628\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, barbecue - Austria (northern) 20061214.3521\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism - Russia (Rostov) 20061108.3206\nBotulism, avian - USA (NY) 20061103.3161\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada)(03) 20061021.3026\n2005\n---\nBotulism, fermented salmon - USA (AK) 20050829.2555\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex. My\nguess is that the artichokes were in an oil dressing and received some heat\ntreatment after canning, and the _Clostridium botulinum_ toxin may be type B.\nI find it useful to restate the conclusion of my ProMED-mail submission on\nbotulism caused by garlic in oil (ProMED post 20030131.0267), which read:\n\"This case of botulism illustrates the need to be alert and not to rule out\nbotulism even in widely distributed convenience foods in developed\ncountries. It is, furthermore, a reminder to manufacturers and authorities\nto be careful, even today, that the conditions of production safeguard\nagainst growth of _Clostridium botulinum_.\"\nThe conditions in the jars of artichokes must have been similar to the\nbottled garlic; not assuring sufficient acidity and/or dissolved salt or\nsugar (low redox-potential), which in turn was sufficient for outgrowth of\nspores. Most importantly, anaerobic conditions are created by covering the\nvegetables with oil and pasteurizing or giving similar heat treatment\ninsufficient for the inactivation of spores but driving out residual oxygen.\nKnown cases of botulism from vegetables in oil, apart from garlic and\nartichokes, include eggplants, cucumbers and olives, but not tomatoes; Why?\nI assume the natural acidity of tomatoes prevents the outgrowth of\nbotulinum spores.\n--\nLars Krusell, MSc\nDanish Food Administration\nAarhus, Denmark\n<lakr@fvst.dk>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Mr Krusell for his comments regarding this area. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzcoa) 20070116.0203\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Dagestan) 20070115.0196\n2006\n---\nBotulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara)(02) 20061230.3652\nBotulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara) 20061227.3628\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, barbecue - Austria (northern) 20061214.3521\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism - Russia (Rostov) 20061108.3206\nBotulism, avian - USA (NY) 20061103.3161\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada)(03) 20061021.3026\n2005\n---\nBotulism, fermented salmon - USA (AK) 20050829.2555\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex. My\nguess is that the artichokes were in an oil dressing and received some heat\ntreatment after canning, and the _Clostridium botulinum_ toxin may be type B.\nI find it useful to restate the conclusion of my ProMED-mail submission on\nbotulism caused by garlic in oil (ProMED post 20030131.0267), which read:\n\"This case of botulism illustrates the need to be alert and not to rule out\nbotulism even in widely distributed convenience foods in developed\ncountries. It is, furthermore, a reminder to manufacturers and authorities\nto be careful, even today, that the conditions of production safeguard\nagainst growth of _Clostridium botulinum_.\"\nThe conditions in the jars of artichokes must have been similar to the\nbottled garlic; not assuring sufficient acidity and/or dissolved salt or\nsugar (low redox-potential), which in turn was sufficient for outgrowth of\nspores. Most importantly, anaerobic conditions are created by covering the\nvegetables with oil and pasteurizing or giving similar heat treatment\ninsufficient for the inactivation of spores but driving out residual oxygen.\nKnown cases of botulism from vegetables in oil, apart from garlic and\nartichokes, include eggplants, cucumbers and olives, but not tomatoes; Why?\nI assume the natural acidity of tomatoes prevents the outgrowth of\nbotulinum spores.\n--\nLars Krusell, MSc\nDanish Food Administration\nAarhus, Denmark\n<lakr@fvst.dk>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Mr Krusell for his comments regarding this area. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzcoa) 20070116.0203\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Dagestan) 20070115.0196\n2006\n---\nBotulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara)(02) 20061230.3652\nBotulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara) 20061227.3628\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, barbecue - Austria (northern) 20061214.3521\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism - Russia (Rostov) 20061108.3206\nBotulism, avian - USA (NY) 20061103.3161\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada)(03) 20061021.3026\n2005\n---\nBotulism, fermented salmon - USA (AK) 20050829.2555\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex. My\nguess is that the artichokes were in an oil dressing and received some heat\ntreatment after canning, and the _Clostridium botulinum_ toxin may be type B.\nI find it useful to restate the conclusion of my ProMED-mail submission on\nbotulism caused by garlic in oil (ProMED post 20030131.0267), which read:\n\"This case of botulism illustrates the need to be alert and not to rule out\nbotulism even in widely distributed convenience foods in developed\ncountries. It is, furthermore, a reminder to manufacturers and authorities\nto be careful, even today, that the conditions of production safeguard\nagainst growth of _Clostridium botulinum_.\"\nThe conditions in the jars of artichokes must have been similar to the\nbottled garlic; not assuring sufficient acidity and/or dissolved salt or\nsugar (low redox-potential), which in turn was sufficient for outgrowth of\nspores. Most importantly, anaerobic conditions are created by covering the\nvegetables with oil and pasteurizing or giving similar heat treatment\ninsufficient for the inactivation of spores but driving out residual oxygen.\nKnown cases of botulism from vegetables in oil, apart from garlic and\nartichokes, include eggplants, cucumbers and olives, but not tomatoes; Why?\nI assume the natural acidity of tomatoes prevents the outgrowth of\nbotulinum spores.\n--\nLars Krusell, MSc\nDanish Food Administration\nAarhus, Denmark\n<lakr@fvst.dk>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Mr Krusell for his comments regarding this area. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzcoa) 20070116.0203\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Dagestan) 20070115.0196\n2006\n---\nBotulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara)(02) 20061230.3652\nBotulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara) 20061227.3628\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, barbecue - Austria (northern) 20061214.3521\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism - Russia (Rostov) 20061108.3206\nBotulism, avian - USA (NY) 20061103.3161\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada)(03) 20061021.3026\n2005\n---\nBotulism, fermented salmon - USA (AK) 20050829.2555\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex. Georgia (02): susp. 20050426.1159\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex Georgia: susp 20050420.1108\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism during pregnancy - Kyrgyzstan (Chuysk) 20050218.0538\n2003\n---\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark 20030131.0267\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\n..................ll/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Canada)(03", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6794", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzoa) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6794", "date": "2007-01-20 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED ARTICHOKES - SPAIN (GUIPUZCOA) (02)\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 19 Jan 2007\nFrom: Lars Krusell <lakr@fvst.dk>\n\nIt would be useful to get further product information in this case. My\nguess is that the artichokes were in an oil dressing and received some heat\ntreatment after canning, and the _Clostridium botulinum_ toxin may be type B.\nI find it useful to restate the conclusion of my ProMED-mail submission on\nbotulism caused by garlic in oil (ProMED post 20030131.0267), which read:\n\"This case of botulism illustrates the need to be alert and not to rule out\nbotulism even in widely distributed convenience foods in developed\ncountries. It is, furthermore, a reminder to manufacturers and authorities\nto be careful, even today, that the conditions of production safeguard\nagainst growth of _Clostridium botulinum_.\"\nThe conditions in the jars of artichokes must have been similar to the\nbottled garlic; not assuring sufficient acidity and/or dissolved salt or\nsugar (low redox-potential), which in turn was sufficient for outgrowth of\nspores. Most importantly, anaerobic conditions are created by covering the\nvegetables with oil and pasteurizing or giving similar heat treatment\ninsufficient for the inactivation of spores but driving out residual oxygen.\nKnown cases of botulism from vegetables in oil, apart from garlic and\nartichokes, include eggplants, cucumbers and olives, but not tomatoes; Why?\nI assume the natural acidity of tomatoes prevents the outgrowth of\nbotulinum spores.\n--\nLars Krusell, MSc\nDanish Food Administration\nAarhus, Denmark\n<lakr@fvst.dk>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Mr Krusell for his comments regarding this area. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzcoa) 20070116.0203\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Dagestan) 20070115.0196\n2006\n---\nBotulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara)(02) 20061230.3652\nBotulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara) 20061227.3628\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, barbecue - Austria (northern) 20061214.3521\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism - Russia (Rostov) 20061108.3206\nBotulism, avian - USA (NY) 20061103.3161\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada)(03) 20061021.3026\n2005\n---\nBotulism, fermented salmon - USA (AK) 20050829.2555\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex. Georgia (02): susp. 20050426.1159\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex Georgia: susp 20050420.1108\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism during pregnancy - Kyrgyzstan (Chuysk) 20050218.0538\n2003\n---\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark 20030131.0267\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\n..................ll/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Canada)(03", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6678", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, canned artichokes - Spain (Guipuzcoa)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6678", "date": "2006-12-27 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, FATAL - BRAZIL (CEARA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 14 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-Port <promed-port@promedmail.org>\nSource: O Povo [in Portuguese, trans. & summarized by Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.opovo.com.br/opovo/fortaleza/655267.html>\n\nChild dies from botulism\n-----------------------------\nAfter 83 days of hospitalization in the ICU of the Dr. Jose Frota\nInstitute in Fortaleza, Ceara state, Brazil, a 10-year-old child died\nof botulism. Her 12-year-old sister is still in intensive care, but\nher mother was discharged after 22 days in intensive care.\nAccording to the children's stepfather, who works as a collector of\nrecyclable materials such as plastic bottles, he was given a frozen\nchicken pie by a person on his route. He ate it as did his wife and\nher 7 daughters on 24 Sep 2006. The 2 girls began to vomit and have\ndiarrhea, weakness and difficulty in speaking and breathing. They\nwent into the ICU that same day, and the mother followed them the\nnext day, spending almost 22 days unconscious and on a respirator.\nShe still suffers from weakness.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[What is interesting in this case is that only some members of the\nfamily became ill. If all members of the family consumed the same\ndish, then it would seem likely that all should be affected. As only\nsome members were affected, we are left to wonder about the\ndifference. Was the food left over and not refrigerated promptly, or\nnot heated thoroughly, so that the toxin was allowed to form? Did the\naffected members consume more of the product?\n_Clostridium botulinum_ is an anaerobic, gram-positive, spore-forming\nrod bacterium that produces a potent neurotoxin. The spores are\nheat-resistant and can survive in foods that are incorrectly or\nminimally processed. Seven types (A, B, C, D, E, F & G) of botulism\nare recognized based on the antigenic specificity of the toxin\nproduced by each strain. Types A, B, E and F cause human botulism.\nTypes C and D cause most cases of botulism in animals. Animals most\ncommonly affected are wildfowl and poultry, cattle, horses and some\nspecies of fish. Although type G has been isolated from soil in\nArgentina, no outbreaks involving it have been recognized.\nFoodborne botulism (as distinct from wound botulism and infant\nbotulism) is a severe type of food poisoning caused by the ingestion\nof foods containing the potent neurotoxin formed during growth of the\norganism. The toxin is heat labile and can be destroyed if heated at\n80 C for 10 minutes or longer. The incidence of the disease is low,\nbut the disease is of considerable concern because of its high\nmortality rate if not treated immediately and properly. Most of the\n10 to 30 outbreaks that are reported annually in the USA are\nassociated with inadequately processed, home-canned foods, but\noccasionally commercially produced foods have been involved in\noutbreaks. Sausages, meat products, canned vegetables and seafood\nproducts have been the most frequent vehicles for human botulism.\nThe organism and its spores are widely distributed in nature. They\noccur in both cultivated and forest soils, bottom sediments of\nstreams, lakes, and coastal waters, in the intestinal tracts of fish\nand mammals, and in the gills and viscera of crabs and other shellfish.\nThere are 4 types of botulism recognized: foodborne, infant, wound,\nand a form of botulism whose classification is as yet undetermined.\nCertain foods have been reported as sources of spores in cases of\ninfant botulism and the undetermined category; wound botulism is not\nrelated to foods.\nFoodborne botulism is the name of the disease (actually a foodborne\nintoxication) caused by the consumption of foods containing the\nneurotoxin produced by _C. botulinum_.\nThe undetermined category of botulism involves adult cases in which a\nspecific food or wound source cannot be identified. It has been\nsuggested that some cases of botulism assigned to this category might\nresult from intestinal colonization in adults, with in vivo\nproduction of toxin. Reports in the medical literature suggest the\nexistence of a form of botulism similar to infant botulism, but\noccurring in adults. In these cases, the patients had surgical\nalterations of the gastrointestinal tract and/or antibiotic therapy.\nIt is proposed that these procedures may have altered the normal gut\nflora and allowed _C. botulinum_ to colonize the intestinal tract.\nThe infective dose: a very small amount (a few nanograms) of toxin\ncan cause illness.\nOnset of symptoms in foodborne botulism is usually 18 to 36 hours\nafter ingestion of the food containing the toxin, although cases have\nvaried from 4 hours to 8 days. Early signs of intoxication consist of\nmarked lassitude, weakness and vertigo, usually followed by double\nvision and progressive difficulty in speaking and swallowing.\nDifficulty in breathing, weakness of other muscles, abdominal\ndistention, and constipation may also be common symptoms.\nThe types of foods involved in botulism vary according to food\npreservation and eating habits in different regions. Any food that is\nconducive to outgrowth and toxin production that when processed\nallows spore survival, and is not subsequently heated before\nconsumption, can be associated with botulism. Almost any type of food\nthat is not very acidic (pH above 4.6) can support growth and toxin\nproduction by _C. botulinum_. Botulinal toxin has been demonstrated\nin a considerable variety of foods, such as canned corn, peppers,\ngreen beans, soups, beets, asparagus, mushrooms, ripe olives,\nspinach, tuna fish, chicken and chicken livers and liver pate, and\nluncheon meats, ham, sausage, stuffed eggplant, lobster, and smoked\nand salted fish.\nThe incidence of the disease is low, but the mortality rate is high\nif not treated immediately and properly. Some cases of botulism may\ngo undiagnosed because symptoms are transient or mild, or\nmisdiagnosed as Guillain-Barre syndrome.\nBotulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking motor nerve\nterminals at the myoneural [nerve-muscle] junction. The flaccid\nparalysis progresses symmetrically downward, usually starting with\nthe eyes and face, to the throat, chest and extremities. When the\ndiaphragm and chest muscles become fully involved, respiration is\ninhibited and death from asphyxia results. Recommended treatment for\nfoodborne botulism includes early administration of botulinal\nantitoxin and intensive supportive care (including mechanical\nbreathing assistance).\nAll people are believed to be susceptible to the foodborne intoxication.\nAlthough botulism can be diagnosed by clinical symptoms alone,\ndifferentiation from other diseases may be difficult. The most direct\nand effective way to confirm the clinical diagnosis of botulism is to\ndemonstrate the presence of toxin in the serum or feces of the\npatient or in the food which the patient consumed. Determination of\nthe source of an outbreak is based on detection and identification of\ntoxin in the food involved. The most widely accepted method is the\ninjection of extracts of the food into passively immunized mice\n(mouse neutralization test). The test takes 48 hours. This analysis\nis followed by culturing all suspect food in an enrichment medium for\nthe detection and isolation of the causative organism. This test takes 7 days.\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cfsan.fda.gov/~mow/chap2.html>. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, barbecue - Austria (northern) 20061214.3521\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism - Russia (Rostov) 20061108.3206\nBotulism, avian - USA (NY) 20061103.3161\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada)(03) 20061021.3026\n.......................................................tg/msp/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-09-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Fortaleza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada)(03", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6649", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, canned food - Russia (Dagestan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6649", "date": "2006-12-27 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, FATAL - BRAZIL (CEARA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 14 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-Port <promed-port@promedmail.org>\nSource: O Povo [in Portuguese, trans. & summarized by Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.opovo.com.br/opovo/fortaleza/655267.html>\n\nChild dies from botulism\n-----------------------------\nAfter 83 days of hospitalization in the ICU of the Dr. Jose Frota\nInstitute in Fortaleza, Ceara state, Brazil, a 10-year-old child died\nof botulism. Her 12-year-old sister is still in intensive care, but\nher mother was discharged after 22 days in intensive care.\nAccording to the children's stepfather, who works as a collector of\nrecyclable materials such as plastic bottles, he was given a frozen\nchicken pie by a person on his route. He ate it as did his wife and\nher 7 daughters on 24 Sep 2006. The 2 girls began to vomit and have\ndiarrhea, weakness and difficulty in speaking and breathing. They\nwent into the ICU that same day, and the mother followed them the\nnext day, spending almost 22 days unconscious and on a respirator.\nShe still suffers from weakness.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[What is interesting in this case is that only some members of the\nfamily became ill. If all members of the family consumed the same\ndish, then it would seem likely that all should be affected. As only\nsome members were affected, we are left to wonder about the\ndifference. Was the food left over and not refrigerated promptly, or\nnot heated thoroughly, so that the toxin was allowed to form? Did the\naffected members consume more of the product?\n_Clostridium botulinum_ is an anaerobic, gram-positive, spore-forming\nrod bacterium that produces a potent neurotoxin. The spores are\nheat-resistant and can survive in foods that are incorrectly or\nminimally processed. Seven types (A, B, C, D, E, F & G) of botulism\nare recognized based on the antigenic specificity of the toxin\nproduced by each strain. Types A, B, E and F cause human botulism.\nTypes C and D cause most cases of botulism in animals. Animals most\ncommonly affected are wildfowl and poultry, cattle, horses and some\nspecies of fish. Although type G has been isolated from soil in\nArgentina, no outbreaks involving it have been recognized.\nFoodborne botulism (as distinct from wound botulism and infant\nbotulism) is a severe type of food poisoning caused by the ingestion\nof foods containing the potent neurotoxin formed during growth of the\norganism. The toxin is heat labile and can be destroyed if heated at\n80 C for 10 minutes or longer. The incidence of the disease is low,\nbut the disease is of considerable concern because of its high\nmortality rate if not treated immediately and properly. Most of the\n10 to 30 outbreaks that are reported annually in the USA are\nassociated with inadequately processed, home-canned foods, but\noccasionally commercially produced foods have been involved in\noutbreaks. Sausages, meat products, canned vegetables and seafood\nproducts have been the most frequent vehicles for human botulism.\nThe organism and its spores are widely distributed in nature. They\noccur in both cultivated and forest soils, bottom sediments of\nstreams, lakes, and coastal waters, in the intestinal tracts of fish\nand mammals, and in the gills and viscera of crabs and other shellfish.\nThere are 4 types of botulism recognized: foodborne, infant, wound,\nand a form of botulism whose classification is as yet undetermined.\nCertain foods have been reported as sources of spores in cases of\ninfant botulism and the undetermined category; wound botulism is not\nrelated to foods.\nFoodborne botulism is the name of the disease (actually a foodborne\nintoxication) caused by the consumption of foods containing the\nneurotoxin produced by _C. botulinum_.\nThe undetermined category of botulism involves adult cases in which a\nspecific food or wound source cannot be identified. It has been\nsuggested that some cases of botulism assigned to this category might\nresult from intestinal colonization in adults, with in vivo\nproduction of toxin. Reports in the medical literature suggest the\nexistence of a form of botulism similar to infant botulism, but\noccurring in adults. In these cases, the patients had surgical\nalterations of the gastrointestinal tract and/or antibiotic therapy.\nIt is proposed that these procedures may have altered the normal gut\nflora and allowed _C. botulinum_ to colonize the intestinal tract.\nThe infective dose: a very small amount (a few nanograms) of toxin\ncan cause illness.\nOnset of symptoms in foodborne botulism is usually 18 to 36 hours\nafter ingestion of the food containing the toxin, although cases have\nvaried from 4 hours to 8 days. Early signs of intoxication consist of\nmarked lassitude, weakness and vertigo, usually followed by double\nvision and progressive difficulty in speaking and swallowing.\nDifficulty in breathing, weakness of other muscles, abdominal\ndistention, and constipation may also be common symptoms.\nThe types of foods involved in botulism vary according to food\npreservation and eating habits in different regions. Any food that is\nconducive to outgrowth and toxin production that when processed\nallows spore survival, and is not subsequently heated before\nconsumption, can be associated with botulism. Almost any type of food\nthat is not very acidic (pH above 4.6) can support growth and toxin\nproduction by _C. botulinum_. Botulinal toxin has been demonstrated\nin a considerable variety of foods, such as canned corn, peppers,\ngreen beans, soups, beets, asparagus, mushrooms, ripe olives,\nspinach, tuna fish, chicken and chicken livers and liver pate, and\nluncheon meats, ham, sausage, stuffed eggplant, lobster, and smoked\nand salted fish.\nThe incidence of the disease is low, but the mortality rate is high\nif not treated immediately and properly. Some cases of botulism may\ngo undiagnosed because symptoms are transient or mild, or\nmisdiagnosed as Guillain-Barre syndrome.\nBotulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking motor nerve\nterminals at the myoneural [nerve-muscle] junction. The flaccid\nparalysis progresses symmetrically downward, usually starting with\nthe eyes and face, to the throat, chest and extremities. When the\ndiaphragm and chest muscles become fully involved, respiration is\ninhibited and death from asphyxia results. Recommended treatment for\nfoodborne botulism includes early administration of botulinal\nantitoxin and intensive supportive care (including mechanical\nbreathing assistance).\nAll people are believed to be susceptible to the foodborne intoxication.\nAlthough botulism can be diagnosed by clinical symptoms alone,\ndifferentiation from other diseases may be difficult. The most direct\nand effective way to confirm the clinical diagnosis of botulism is to\ndemonstrate the presence of toxin in the serum or feces of the\npatient or in the food which the patient consumed. Determination of\nthe source of an outbreak is based on detection and identification of\ntoxin in the food involved. The most widely accepted method is the\ninjection of extracts of the food into passively immunized mice\n(mouse neutralization test). The test takes 48 hours. This analysis\nis followed by culturing all suspect food in an enrichment medium for\nthe detection and isolation of the causative organism. This test takes 7 days.\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cfsan.fda.gov/~mow/chap2.html>. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, barbecue - Austria (northern) 20061214.3521\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism - Russia (Rostov) 20061108.3206\nBotulism, avian - USA (NY) 20061103.3161\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada)(03) 20061021.3026\n.......................................................tg/msp/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-09-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Fortaleza", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada)(03", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6600", "headline": "PRO> Infant botulism - USA (MD)(02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6600", "date": "2006-12-27 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, FATAL - BRAZIL (CEARA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 14 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-Port <promed-port@promedmail.org>\nSource: O Povo [in Portuguese, trans. & summarized by Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.opovo.com.br/opovo/fortaleza/655267.html>\n\nChild dies from botulism\n-----------------------------\nAfter 83 days of hospitalization in the ICU of the Dr. Jose Frota\nInstitute in Fortaleza, Ceara state, Brazil, a 10-year-old child died\nof botulism. Her 12-year-old sister is still in intensive care, but\nher mother was discharged after 22 days in intensive care.\nAccording to the children's stepfather, who works as a collector of\nrecyclable materials such as plastic bottles, he was given a frozen\nchicken pie by a person on his route. He ate it as did his wife and\nher 7 daughters on 24 Sep 2006. The 2 girls began to vomit and have\ndiarrhea, weakness and difficulty in speaking and breathing. They\nwent into the ICU that same day, and the mother followed them the\nnext day, spending almost 22 days unconscious and on a respirator.\nShe still suffers from weakness.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[What is interesting in this case is that only some members of the\nfamily became ill. If all members of the family consumed the same\ndish, then it would seem likely that all should be affected. As only\nsome members were affected, we are left to wonder about the\ndifference. Was the food left over and not refrigerated promptly, or\nnot heated thoroughly, so that the toxin was allowed to form? Did the\naffected members consume more of the product?\n_Clostridium botulinum_ is an anaerobic, gram-positive, spore-forming\nrod bacterium that produces a potent neurotoxin. The spores are\nheat-resistant and can survive in foods that are incorrectly or\nminimally processed. Seven types (A, B, C, D, E, F & G) of botulism\nare recognized based on the antigenic specificity of the toxin\nproduced by each strain. Types A, B, E and F cause human botulism.\nTypes C and D cause most cases of botulism in animals. Animals most\ncommonly affected are wildfowl and poultry, cattle, horses and some\nspecies of fish. Although type G has been isolated from soil in\nArgentina, no outbreaks involving it have been recognized.\nFoodborne botulism (as distinct from wound botulism and infant\nbotulism) is a severe type of food poisoning caused by the ingestion\nof foods containing the potent neurotoxin formed during growth of the\norganism. The toxin is heat labile and can be destroyed if heated at\n80 C for 10 minutes or longer. The incidence of the disease is low,\nbut the disease is of considerable concern because of its high\nmortality rate if not treated immediately and properly. Most of the\n10 to 30 outbreaks that are reported annually in the USA are\nassociated with inadequately processed, home-canned foods, but\noccasionally commercially produced foods have been involved in\noutbreaks. Sausages, meat products, canned vegetables and seafood\nproducts have been the most frequent vehicles for human botulism.\nThe organism and its spores are widely distributed in nature. They\noccur in both cultivated and forest soils, bottom sediments of\nstreams, lakes, and coastal waters, in the intestinal tracts of fish\nand mammals, and in the gills and viscera of crabs and other shellfish.\nThere are 4 types of botulism recognized: foodborne, infant, wound,\nand a form of botulism whose classification is as yet undetermined.\nCertain foods have been reported as sources of spores in cases of\ninfant botulism and the undetermined category; wound botulism is not\nrelated to foods.\nFoodborne botulism is the name of the disease (actually a foodborne\nintoxication) caused by the consumption of foods containing the\nneurotoxin produced by _C. botulinum_.\nThe undetermined category of botulism involves adult cases in which a\nspecific food or wound source cannot be identified. It has been\nsuggested that some cases of botulism assigned to this category might\nresult from intestinal colonization in adults, with in vivo\nproduction of toxin. Reports in the medical literature suggest the\nexistence of a form of botulism similar to infant botulism, but\noccurring in adults. In these cases, the patients had surgical\nalterations of the gastrointestinal tract and/or antibiotic therapy.\nIt is proposed that these procedures may have altered the normal gut\nflora and allowed _C. botulinum_ to colonize the intestinal tract.\nThe infective dose: a very small amount (a few nanograms) of toxin\ncan cause illness.\nOnset of symptoms in foodborne botulism is usually 18 to 36 hours\nafter ingestion of the food containing the toxin, although cases have\nvaried from 4 hours to 8 days. Early signs of intoxication consist of\nmarked lassitude, weakness and vertigo, usually followed by double\nvision and progressive difficulty in speaking and swallowing.\nDifficulty in breathing, weakness of other muscles, abdominal\ndistention, and constipation may also be common symptoms.\nThe types of foods involved in botulism vary according to food\npreservation and eating habits in different regions. Any food that is\nconducive to outgrowth and toxin production that when processed\nallows spore survival, and is not subsequently heated before\nconsumption, can be associated with botulism. Almost any type of food\nthat is not very acidic (pH above 4.6) can support growth and toxin\nproduction by _C. botulinum_. Botulinal toxin has been demonstrated\nin a considerable variety of foods, such as canned corn, peppers,\ngreen beans, soups, beets, asparagus, mushrooms, ripe olives,\nspinach, tuna fish, chicken and chicken livers and liver pate, and\nluncheon meats, ham, sausage, stuffed eggplant, lobster, and smoked\nand salted fish.\nThe incidence of the disease is low, but the mortality rate is high\nif not treated immediately and properly. Some cases of botulism may\ngo undiagnosed because symptoms are transient or mild, or\nmisdiagnosed as Guillain-Barre syndrome.\nBotulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking motor nerve\nterminals at the myoneural [nerve-muscle] junction. The flaccid\nparalysis progresses symmetrically downward, usually starting with\nthe eyes and face, to the throat, chest and extremities. When the\ndiaphragm and chest muscles become fully involved, respiration is\ninhibited and death from asphyxia results. Recommended treatment for\nfoodborne botulism includes early administration of botulinal\nantitoxin and intensive supportive care (including mechanical\nbreathing assistance).\nAll people are believed to be susceptible to the foodborne intoxication.\nAlthough botulism can be diagnosed by clinical symptoms alone,\ndifferentiation from other diseases may be difficult. The most direct\nand effective way to confirm the clinical diagnosis of botulism is to\ndemonstrate the presence of toxin in the serum or feces of the\npatient or in the food which the patient consumed. Determination of\nthe source of an outbreak is based on detection and identification of\ntoxin in the food involved. The most widely accepted method is the\ninjection of extracts of the food into passively immunized mice\n(mouse neutralization test). The test takes 48 hours. This analysis\nis followed by culturing all suspect food in an enrichment medium for\nthe detection and isolation of the causative organism. This test takes 7 days.\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cfsan.fda.gov/~mow/chap2.html>. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, barbecue - Austria (northern) 20061214.3521\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism - Russia (Rostov) 20061108.3206\nBotulism, avian - USA (NY) 20061103.3161\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada)(03) 20061021.3026\n.......................................................tg/msp/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-09-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Fortaleza", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada)(03", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209609", "headline": "PRO/ERR> Infant botulism - USA (MD): correction", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209609", "date": "2006-12-27 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, FATAL - BRAZIL (CEARA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 14 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-Port <promed-port@promedmail.org>\nSource: O Povo [in Portuguese, trans. & summarized by Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.opovo.com.br/opovo/fortaleza/655267.html>\n\nChild dies from botulism\n-----------------------------\nAfter 83 days of hospitalization in the ICU of the Dr. Jose Frota\nInstitute in Fortaleza, Ceara state, Brazil, a 10-year-old child died\nof botulism. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-09-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Fortaleza", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada)(03", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6568", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Infant botulism - USA (MD): correction", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6568", "date": "2006-12-27 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, FATAL - BRAZIL (CEARA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 14 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-Port <promed-port@promedmail.org>\nSource: O Povo [in Portuguese, trans. & summarized by Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.opovo.com.br/opovo/fortaleza/655267.html>\n\nChild dies from botulism\n-----------------------------\nAfter 83 days of hospitalization in the ICU of the Dr. Jose Frota\nInstitute in Fortaleza, Ceara state, Brazil, a 10-year-old child died\nof botulism. Her 12-year-old sister is still in intensive care, but\nher mother was discharged after 22 days in intensive care.\nAccording to the children's stepfather, who works as a collector of\nrecyclable materials such as plastic bottles, he was given a frozen\nchicken pie by a person on his route. He ate it as did his wife and\nher 7 daughters on 24 Sep 2006. The 2 girls began to vomit and have\ndiarrhea, weakness and difficulty in speaking and breathing. They\nwent into the ICU that same day, and the mother followed them the\nnext day, spending almost 22 days unconscious and on a respirator.\nShe still suffers from weakness.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[What is interesting in this case is that only some members of the\nfamily became ill. Was the food left over and not refrigerated promptly, or\nnot heated thoroughly, so that the toxin was allowed to form? Did the\naffected members consume more of the product?\n_Clostridium botulinum_ is an anaerobic, gram-positive, spore-forming\nrod bacterium that produces a potent neurotoxin. The spores are\nheat-resistant and can survive in foods that are incorrectly or\nminimally processed. Seven types (A, B, C, D, E, F & G) of botulism\nare recognized based on the antigenic specificity of the toxin\nproduced by each strain. Types A, B, E and F cause human botulism.\nTypes C and D cause most cases of botulism in animals. Animals most\ncommonly affected are wildfowl and poultry, cattle, horses and some\nspecies of fish. The incidence of the disease is low,\nbut the disease is of considerable concern because of its high\nmortality rate if not treated immediately and properly. The flaccid\nparalysis progresses symmetrically downward, usually starting with\nthe eyes and face, to the throat, chest and extremities. When the\ndiaphragm and chest muscles become fully involved, respiration is\ninhibited and death from asphyxia results. Recommended treatment for\nfoodborne botulism includes early administration of botulinal\nantitoxin and intensive supportive care (including mechanical\nbreathing assistance).\nAll people are believed to be susceptible to the foodborne intoxication.\nAlthough botulism can be diagnosed by clinical symptoms alone,\ndifferentiation from other diseases may be difficult. The most direct\nand effective way to confirm the clinical diagnosis of botulism is to\ndemonstrate the presence of toxin in the serum or feces of the\npatient or in the food which the patient consumed. Determination of\nthe source of an outbreak is based on detection and identification of\ntoxin in the food involved. The most widely accepted method is the\ninjection of extracts of the food into passively immunized mice\n(mouse neutralization test). The test takes 48 hours. This analysis\nis followed by culturing all suspect food in an enrichment medium for\nthe detection and isolation of the causative organism. This test takes 7 days.\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cfsan.fda.gov/~mow/chap2.html>. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, barbecue - Austria (northern) 20061214.3521\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism - Russia (Rostov) 20061108.3206\nBotulism, avian - USA (NY) 20061103.3161\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada)(03) 20061021.3026\n.......................................................tg/msp/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-09-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Fortaleza", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada)(03", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6547", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Infant botulism - USA (MD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6547", "date": "2006-12-27 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, FATAL - BRAZIL (CEARA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 14 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-Port <promed-port@promedmail.org>\nSource: O Povo [in Portuguese, trans. & summarized by Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.opovo.com.br/opovo/fortaleza/655267.html>\n\nChild dies from botulism\n-----------------------------\nAfter 83 days of hospitalization in the ICU of the Dr. Jose Frota\nInstitute in Fortaleza, Ceara state, Brazil, a 10-year-old child died\nof botulism. Her 12-year-old sister is still in intensive care, but\nher mother was discharged after 22 days in intensive care.\nAccording to the children's stepfather, who works as a collector of\nrecyclable materials such as plastic bottles, he was given a frozen\nchicken pie by a person on his route. He ate it as did his wife and\nher 7 daughters on 24 Sep 2006. The 2 girls began to vomit and have\ndiarrhea, weakness and difficulty in speaking and breathing. They\nwent into the ICU that same day, and the mother followed them the\nnext day, spending almost 22 days unconscious and on a respirator.\nShe still suffers from weakness.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[What is interesting in this case is that only some members of the\nfamily became ill. If all members of the family consumed the same\ndish, then it would seem likely that all should be affected. As only\nsome members were affected, we are left to wonder about the\ndifference. Was the food left over and not refrigerated promptly, or\nnot heated thoroughly, so that the toxin was allowed to form? Did the\naffected members consume more of the product?\n_Clostridium botulinum_ is an anaerobic, gram-positive, spore-forming\nrod bacterium that produces a potent neurotoxin. The spores are\nheat-resistant and can survive in foods that are incorrectly or\nminimally processed. Seven types (A, B, C, D, E, F & G) of botulism\nare recognized based on the antigenic specificity of the toxin\nproduced by each strain. Types A, B, E and F cause human botulism.\nTypes C and D cause most cases of botulism in animals. Animals most\ncommonly affected are wildfowl and poultry, cattle, horses and some\nspecies of fish. Although type G has been isolated from soil in\nArgentina, no outbreaks involving it have been recognized.\nFoodborne botulism (as distinct from wound botulism and infant\nbotulism) is a severe type of food poisoning caused by the ingestion\nof foods containing the potent neurotoxin formed during growth of the\norganism. The toxin is heat labile and can be destroyed if heated at\n80 C for 10 minutes or longer. The incidence of the disease is low,\nbut the disease is of considerable concern because of its high\nmortality rate if not treated immediately and properly. Most of the\n10 to 30 outbreaks that are reported annually in the USA are\nassociated with inadequately processed, home-canned foods, but\noccasionally commercially produced foods have been involved in\noutbreaks. Sausages, meat products, canned vegetables and seafood\nproducts have been the most frequent vehicles for human botulism.\nThe organism and its spores are widely distributed in nature. They\noccur in both cultivated and forest soils, bottom sediments of\nstreams, lakes, and coastal waters, in the intestinal tracts of fish\nand mammals, and in the gills and viscera of crabs and other shellfish.\nThere are 4 types of botulism recognized: foodborne, infant, wound,\nand a form of botulism whose classification is as yet undetermined.\nCertain foods have been reported as sources of spores in cases of\ninfant botulism and the undetermined category; wound botulism is not\nrelated to foods.\nFoodborne botulism is the name of the disease (actually a foodborne\nintoxication) caused by the consumption of foods containing the\nneurotoxin produced by _C. botulinum_.\nThe undetermined category of botulism involves adult cases in which a\nspecific food or wound source cannot be identified. It has been\nsuggested that some cases of botulism assigned to this category might\nresult from intestinal colonization in adults, with in vivo\nproduction of toxin. Reports in the medical literature suggest the\nexistence of a form of botulism similar to infant botulism, but\noccurring in adults. In these cases, the patients had surgical\nalterations of the gastrointestinal tract and/or antibiotic therapy.\nIt is proposed that these procedures may have altered the normal gut\nflora and allowed _C. botulinum_ to colonize the intestinal tract.\nThe infective dose: a very small amount (a few nanograms) of toxin\ncan cause illness.\nOnset of symptoms in foodborne botulism is usually 18 to 36 hours\nafter ingestion of the food containing the toxin, although cases have\nvaried from 4 hours to 8 days. Early signs of intoxication consist of\nmarked lassitude, weakness and vertigo, usually followed by double\nvision and progressive difficulty in speaking and swallowing.\nDifficulty in breathing, weakness of other muscles, abdominal\ndistention, and constipation may also be common symptoms.\nThe types of foods involved in botulism vary according to food\npreservation and eating habits in different regions. Any food that is\nconducive to outgrowth and toxin production that when processed\nallows spore survival, and is not subsequently heated before\nconsumption, can be associated with botulism. Almost any type of food\nthat is not very acidic (pH above 4.6) can support growth and toxin\nproduction by _C. botulinum_. Botulinal toxin has been demonstrated\nin a considerable variety of foods, such as canned corn, peppers,\ngreen beans, soups, beets, asparagus, mushrooms, ripe olives,\nspinach, tuna fish, chicken and chicken livers and liver pate, and\nluncheon meats, ham, sausage, stuffed eggplant, lobster, and smoked\nand salted fish.\nThe incidence of the disease is low, but the mortality rate is high\nif not treated immediately and properly. Some cases of botulism may\ngo undiagnosed because symptoms are transient or mild, or\nmisdiagnosed as Guillain-Barre syndrome.\nBotulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking motor nerve\nterminals at the myoneural [nerve-muscle] junction. The flaccid\nparalysis progresses symmetrically downward, usually starting with\nthe eyes and face, to the throat, chest and extremities. When the\ndiaphragm and chest muscles become fully involved, respiration is\ninhibited and death from asphyxia results. Recommended treatment for\nfoodborne botulism includes early administration of botulinal\nantitoxin and intensive supportive care (including mechanical\nbreathing assistance).\nAll people are believed to be susceptible to the foodborne intoxication.\nAlthough botulism can be diagnosed by clinical symptoms alone,\ndifferentiation from other diseases may be difficult. The most direct\nand effective way to confirm the clinical diagnosis of botulism is to\ndemonstrate the presence of toxin in the serum or feces of the\npatient or in the food which the patient consumed. Determination of\nthe source of an outbreak is based on detection and identification of\ntoxin in the food involved. The most widely accepted method is the\ninjection of extracts of the food into passively immunized mice\n(mouse neutralization test). The test takes 48 hours. This analysis\nis followed by culturing all suspect food in an enrichment medium for\nthe detection and isolation of the causative organism. This test takes 7 days.\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cfsan.fda.gov/~mow/chap2.html>. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, barbecue - Austria (northern) 20061214.3521\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism - Russia (Rostov) 20061108.3206\nBotulism, avian - USA (NY) 20061103.3161\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada)(03) 20061021.3026\n.......................................................tg/msp/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-09-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Fortaleza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada)(03", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6244", "headline": "PRO> Botulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6244", "date": "2006-12-27 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, FATAL - BRAZIL (CEARA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 14 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-Port <promed-port@promedmail.org>\nSource: O Povo [in Portuguese, trans. & summarized by Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.opovo.com.br/opovo/fortaleza/655267.html>\n\nChild dies from botulism\n-----------------------------\nAfter 83 days of hospitalization in the ICU of the Dr. Jose Frota\nInstitute in Fortaleza, Ceara state, Brazil, a 10-year-old child died\nof botulism. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-09-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Fortaleza", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada)(03", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6186", "headline": "PRO> Botulism, fatal - Brazil (Ceara)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6186", "date": "2006-12-27 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, FATAL - BRAZIL (CEARA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 14 Dec 2006\nFrom: ProMED-Port <promed-port@promedmail.org>\nSource: O Povo [in Portuguese, trans. & summarized by Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.opovo.com.br/opovo/fortaleza/655267.html>\n\nChild dies from botulism\n-----------------------------\nAfter 83 days of hospitalization in the ICU of the Dr. Jose Frota\nInstitute in Fortaleza, Ceara state, Brazil, a 10-year-old child died\nof botulism. Her 12-year-old sister is still in intensive care, but\nher mother was discharged after 22 days in intensive care.\nAccording to the children's stepfather, who works as a collector of\nrecyclable materials such as plastic bottles, he was given a frozen\nchicken pie by a person on his route. He ate it as did his wife and\nher 7 daughters on 24 Sep 2006. The 2 girls began to vomit and have\ndiarrhea, weakness and difficulty in speaking and breathing. They\nwent into the ICU that same day, and the mother followed them the\nnext day, spending almost 22 days unconscious and on a respirator.\nShe still suffers from weakness.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[What is interesting in this case is that only some members of the\nfamily became ill.
