Any food that is\nconducive to outgrowth and toxin production that when processed\nallows spore survival, and is not subsequently heated before\nconsumption, can be associated with botulism. Almost any type of food\nthat is not very acidic (pH above 4.6) can support growth and toxin\nproduction by _C. botulinum_. Botulinal toxin has been demonstrated\nin a considerable variety of foods, such as canned corn, peppers,\ngreen beans, soups, beets, asparagus, mushrooms, ripe olives,\nspinach, tuna fish, chicken and chicken livers and liver pate, and\nluncheon meats, ham, sausage, stuffed eggplant, lobster, and smoked\nand salted fish.\nThe incidence of the disease is low, but the mortality rate is high\nif not treated immediately and properly. Some cases of botulism may\ngo undiagnosed because symptoms are transient or mild, or\nmisdiagnosed as Guillain-Barre syndrome.\nBotulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking motor nerve\nterminals at the myoneural [nerve-muscle] junction. The flaccid\nparalysis progresses symmetrically downward, usually starting with\nthe eyes and face, to the throat, chest and extremities. When the\ndiaphragm and chest muscles become fully involved, respiration is\ninhibited and death from asphyxia results. Recommended treatment for\nfoodborne botulism includes early administration of botulinal\nantitoxin and intensive supportive care (including mechanical\nbreathing assistance).\nAll people are believed to be susceptible to the foodborne intoxication.\nAlthough botulism can be diagnosed by clinical symptoms alone,\ndifferentiation from other diseases may be difficult. The most direct\nand effective way to confirm the clinical diagnosis of botulism is to\ndemonstrate the presence of toxin in the serum or feces of the\npatient or in the food which the patient consumed. Determination of\nthe source of an outbreak is based on detection and identification of\ntoxin in the food involved. The most widely accepted method is the\ninjection of extracts of the food into passively immunized mice\n(mouse neutralization test). The test takes 48 hours. This analysis\nis followed by culturing all suspect food in an enrichment medium for\nthe detection and isolation of the causative organism. This test takes 7 days.\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cfsan.fda.gov/~mow/chap2.html>. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty) 20061223.3589\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya) 20061215.3527\nBotulism, barbecue - Austria (northern) 20061214.3521\nBotulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines 20061208.3463\nBotulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall 20061206.3439\nBotulism, olives - Canada (ON) ex Italy: recall 20061205.3430\nBotulism - Russia (Rostov) 20061108.3206\nBotulism, avian - USA (NY) 20061103.3161\nBotulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall 20061103.3155\nBotulism, canned crab - Canada: recall 20061031.3113\nBotulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada)(03) 20061021.3026\n.......................................................tg/msp/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-09-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Fortaleza", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Canada)(03", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6117", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, canned food - Kazakhstan (Almaty)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6117", "date": "2006-11-03 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - USA (NEW YORK)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 1 Nov 2006\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: Democrat and Chronicle.com [edited]\n<http://www.democratandchronicle.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20061101/NEWS01/611010366/1002/NEWS>\n\nType E botulism seems to be the cause of scores of bird deaths last\nmonth along a stretch of Lake Ontario shoreline, according to the\nstate Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC).\nAt least one sample taken from the bird carcasses has indicated that\ntype E was the cause of death, DEC spokeswoman Maureen Wren said;\nother samples are pending. The necropsies, which are complete\npostmortem examinations, also indicate that type E is the cause, she said.\nCaused by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, type E is a type of\nfood poisoning that typically affects fish-eating birds such as\nloons. But the state is warning that the bird-killing toxin could\nalso harm humans who eat sick birds.\nThe bodies of the loons, gulls and grebes were first discovered on 21\nOct 2006 between Wayne County's Sodus Bay and Deer Creek Marsh in\nOswego County. The DEC's Wildlife Pathology Unit is inspecting and\ntesting the birds.\nAvian botulism is a major cause of death in migratory birds,\naccording to New York Sea Grant. Type E botulism outbreaks have been\nseen on the Great Lakes as far back as the mid-1960s on Lake\nMichigan. But type E did not appear on Lake Ontario until 2002. And\nthis year has proven to be the most fatal to Lake Ontario wildlife,\nwith hundreds of birds dying in July from botulism along the coast of\nJefferson County on the eastern shore of Lake Ontario, according to the DEC.\nBotulism killed an estimated 5000 birds on Lake Erie in 2000, and the\nlake has seen bird deaths annually since then.\nThe state Health Department said in a statement it does not know of\nany human cases of botulism related to the loon deaths.\nThe spores for type E botulism are naturally found in soil and\naquatic sediment, as well as the intestinal tracts of healthy\nanimals, according to Sea Grant. Birds get sick by eating fish\ncontaminated with type E botulism.\nScientists still aren't sure why botulism flares up and dies down, or\nwhy recent outbreaks have been particularly calamitous, said Rod\nGetchell, a professor in Cornell University's aquatic animal health program.\nBut one hypothesis is that the recent introduction of invasive\nspecies such as gobies and zebra mussels might be changing the\necology of the lake's bottom, he said, allowing the type E spores to germinate.\n[Byline: Matthew Daneman]\n--\nBrent Barrett\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n[Botulism in avians is not usually type E, so this is an interesting case.\nThough avian botulism is seen more often in other regions, it will\noccur where the conditions are favorable.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_\nelaborates 7 types of antigenically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of which\naffect humans: type A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxins types A and B\nare highly poisonous proteins resistant to digestion by GI enzymes.\nApproximately 50 percent of foodborne outbreaks in the USA are caused\nby type A toxin, followed by types B and E.\nType C botulism occurs principally in waterfowl and other birds\nliving in an aquatic environment and causes tremendous losses, most\nnotably in waterfowl in the western US. In addition to North America,\nit has been reported in birds in Europe, South Africa, Uruguay, and\nAustralia. In the Great Lakes region, it was first identified in 1936\nin ducks on Green Bay of Lake Michigan and in 1941 in Monroe County\nmarshes along Lake Erie. Type C is most often associated with\nlimberneck paralysis in birds.\nType E botulism is connected with consumption of fish and occurs\nmainly in gulls and loons, and to a lesser extent in mergansers, mute\nswans, grebes, and shorebirds. It now appears that any birds or\nmammals susceptible to botulinum toxin run a risk of becoming\npoisoned if they scavenge dead fish. Evidence for this includes the\nidentification of type E toxin in a bald eagle, wood ducks, and\nmuskrats with fish remaining in their digestive tracts.\n_C. botulinum_ spores are relatively heat-resistant, though high\ntemperatures and/or exposure to moist heat will kill the spores.\nToxins, on the other hand, are readily destroyed by heat and by\ncooking food. Toxin production (especially type E) can occur at\ntemperatures as low as 3 degrees C (37.4 degrees F), i.e., inside a\nrefrigerator, and does not require strict anaerobic conditions.\nHuman illness from Type E is most often associated with improperly\nsmoked fish. Since the toxin is destroyed by heat, it appears that no\nproblem with botulism will result from eating cooked waterfowl.\n(above information extracted from the Michigan Department of Natural\nResources website at\n<http://www.michigan.gov/dnr/0,1607,7-153-10370_12150_12220-26493--,00.html>).\n- Mod.TG]\n...........tg/pg/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "1936-03-15 00:00:00", "1941-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Lake Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monroe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Great Lakes", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jefferson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wayne County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5711", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatiya)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5711", "date": "2006-11-03 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - USA (NEW YORK)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 1 Nov 2006\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: Democrat and Chronicle.com [edited]\n<http://www.democratandchronicle.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20061101/NEWS01/611010366/1002/NEWS>\n\nType E botulism seems to be the cause of scores of bird deaths last\nmonth along a stretch of Lake Ontario shoreline, according to the\nstate Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC).\nAt least one sample taken from the bird carcasses has indicated that\ntype E was the cause of death, DEC spokeswoman Maureen Wren said;\nother samples are pending. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "1936-03-15 00:00:00", "1941-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Lake Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monroe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Great Lakes", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jefferson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wayne County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5216", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism, bovine - UK: precautionary guidelines", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5216", "date": "2006-11-03 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - USA (NEW YORK)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 1 Nov 2006\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: Democrat and Chronicle.com [edited]\n<http://www.democratandchronicle.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20061101/NEWS01/611010366/1002/NEWS>\n\nType E botulism seems to be the cause of scores of bird deaths last\nmonth along a stretch of Lake Ontario shoreline, according to the\nstate Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC).\nAt least one sample taken from the bird carcasses has indicated that\ntype E was the cause of death, DEC spokeswoman Maureen Wren said;\nother samples are pending. The necropsies, which are complete\npostmortem examinations, also indicate that type E is the cause, she said.\nCaused by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, type E is a type of\nfood poisoning that typically affects fish-eating birds such as\nloons. But the state is warning that the bird-killing toxin could\nalso harm humans who eat sick birds.\nThe bodies of the loons, gulls and grebes were first discovered on 21\nOct 2006 between Wayne County's Sodus Bay and Deer Creek Marsh in\nOswego County. The DEC's Wildlife Pathology Unit is inspecting and\ntesting the birds.\nAvian botulism is a major cause of death in migratory birds,\naccording to New York Sea Grant. Type E botulism outbreaks have been\nseen on the Great Lakes as far back as the mid-1960s on Lake\nMichigan. But type E did not appear on Lake Ontario until 2002. And\nthis year has proven to be the most fatal to Lake Ontario wildlife,\nwith hundreds of birds dying in July from botulism along the coast of\nJefferson County on the eastern shore of Lake Ontario, according to the DEC.\nBotulism killed an estimated 5000 birds on Lake Erie in 2000, and the\nlake has seen bird deaths annually since then.\nThe state Health Department said in a statement it does not know of\nany human cases of botulism related to the loon deaths.\nThe spores for type E botulism are naturally found in soil and\naquatic sediment, as well as the intestinal tracts of healthy\nanimals, according to Sea Grant. Birds get sick by eating fish\ncontaminated with type E botulism.\nScientists still aren't sure why botulism flares up and dies down, or\nwhy recent outbreaks have been particularly calamitous, said Rod\nGetchell, a professor in Cornell University's aquatic animal health program.\nBut one hypothesis is that the recent introduction of invasive\nspecies such as gobies and zebra mussels might be changing the\necology of the lake's bottom, he said, allowing the type E spores to germinate.\n[Byline: Matthew Daneman]\n--\nBrent Barrett\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n[Botulism in avians is not usually type E, so this is an interesting case.\nThough avian botulism is seen more often in other regions, it will\noccur where the conditions are favorable.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_\nelaborates 7 types of antigenically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of which\naffect humans: type A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxins types A and B\nare highly poisonous proteins resistant to digestion by GI enzymes.\nApproximately 50 percent of foodborne outbreaks in the USA are caused\nby type A toxin, followed by types B and E.\nType C botulism occurs principally in waterfowl and other birds\nliving in an aquatic environment and causes tremendous losses, most\nnotably in waterfowl in the western US. In addition to North America,\nit has been reported in birds in Europe, South Africa, Uruguay, and\nAustralia. In the Great Lakes region, it was first identified in 1936\nin ducks on Green Bay of Lake Michigan and in 1941 in Monroe County\nmarshes along Lake Erie. Type C is most often associated with\nlimberneck paralysis in birds.\nType E botulism is connected with consumption of fish and occurs\nmainly in gulls and loons, and to a lesser extent in mergansers, mute\nswans, grebes, and shorebirds. It now appears that any birds or\nmammals susceptible to botulinum toxin run a risk of becoming\npoisoned if they scavenge dead fish. Evidence for this includes the\nidentification of type E toxin in a bald eagle, wood ducks, and\nmuskrats with fish remaining in their digestive tracts.\n_C. botulinum_ spores are relatively heat-resistant, though high\ntemperatures and/or exposure to moist heat will kill the spores.\nToxins, on the other hand, are readily destroyed by heat and by\ncooking food. Toxin production (especially type E) can occur at\ntemperatures as low as 3 degrees C (37.4 degrees F), i.e., inside a\nrefrigerator, and does not require strict anaerobic conditions.\nHuman illness from Type E is most often associated with improperly\nsmoked fish. Since the toxin is destroyed by heat, it appears that no\nproblem with botulism will result from eating cooked waterfowl.\n(above information extracted from the Michigan Department of Natural\nResources website at\n<http://www.michigan.gov/dnr/0,1607,7-153-10370_12150_12220-26493--,00.html>).\n- Mod.TG]\n...........tg/pg/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "1936-03-15 00:00:00", "1941-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Lake Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monroe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Great Lakes", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jefferson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wayne County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5120", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, canned uneviscerated fish - USA: recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5120", "date": "2006-11-03 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - USA (NEW YORK)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 1 Nov 2006\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: Democrat and Chronicle.com [edited]\n<http://www.democratandchronicle.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20061101/NEWS01/611010366/1002/NEWS>\n\nType E botulism seems to be the cause of scores of bird deaths last\nmonth along a stretch of Lake Ontario shoreline, according to the\nstate Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC).\nAt least one sample taken from the bird carcasses has indicated that\ntype E was the cause of death, DEC spokeswoman Maureen Wren said;\nother samples are pending. The necropsies, which are complete\npostmortem examinations, also indicate that type E is the cause, she said.\nCaused by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_, type E is a type of\nfood poisoning that typically affects fish-eating birds such as\nloons. But the state is warning that the bird-killing toxin could\nalso harm humans who eat sick birds.\nThe bodies of the loons, gulls and grebes were first discovered on 21\nOct 2006 between Wayne County's Sodus Bay and Deer Creek Marsh in\nOswego County. The DEC's Wildlife Pathology Unit is inspecting and\ntesting the birds.\nAvian botulism is a major cause of death in migratory birds,\naccording to New York Sea Grant. Type E botulism outbreaks have been\nseen on the Great Lakes as far back as the mid-1960s on Lake\nMichigan. But type E did not appear on Lake Ontario until 2002. And\nthis year has proven to be the most fatal to Lake Ontario wildlife,\nwith hundreds of birds dying in July from botulism along the coast of\nJefferson County on the eastern shore of Lake Ontario, according to the DEC.\nBotulism killed an estimated 5000 birds on Lake Erie in 2000, and the\nlake has seen bird deaths annually since then.\nThe state Health Department said in a statement it does not know of\nany human cases of botulism related to the loon deaths.\nThe spores for type E botulism are naturally found in soil and\naquatic sediment, as well as the intestinal tracts of healthy\nanimals, according to Sea Grant. Birds get sick by eating fish\ncontaminated with type E botulism.\nScientists still aren't sure why botulism flares up and dies down, or\nwhy recent outbreaks have been particularly calamitous, said Rod\nGetchell, a professor in Cornell University's aquatic animal health program.\nBut one hypothesis is that the recent introduction of invasive\nspecies such as gobies and zebra mussels might be changing the\necology of the lake's bottom, he said, allowing the type E spores to germinate.\n[Byline: Matthew Daneman]\n--\nBrent Barrett\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n[Botulism in avians is not usually type E, so this is an interesting case.\nThough avian botulism is seen more often in other regions, it will\noccur where the conditions are favorable.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_\nelaborates 7 types of antigenically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of which\naffect humans: type A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxins types A and B\nare highly poisonous proteins resistant to digestion by GI enzymes.\nApproximately 50 percent of foodborne outbreaks in the USA are caused\nby type A toxin, followed by types B and E.\nType C botulism occurs principally in waterfowl and other birds\nliving in an aquatic environment and causes tremendous losses, most\nnotably in waterfowl in the western US. In addition to North America,\nit has been reported in birds in Europe, South Africa, Uruguay, and\nAustralia. In the Great Lakes region, it was first identified in 1936\nin ducks on Green Bay of Lake Michigan and in 1941 in Monroe County\nmarshes along Lake Erie. Type C is most often associated with\nlimberneck paralysis in birds.\nType E botulism is connected with consumption of fish and occurs\nmainly in gulls and loons, and to a lesser extent in mergansers, mute\nswans, grebes, and shorebirds. It now appears that any birds or\nmammals susceptible to botulinum toxin run a risk of becoming\npoisoned if they scavenge dead fish. Evidence for this includes the\nidentification of type E toxin in a bald eagle, wood ducks, and\nmuskrats with fish remaining in their digestive tracts.\n_C. botulinum_ spores are relatively heat-resistant, though high\ntemperatures and/or exposure to moist heat will kill the spores.\nToxins, on the other hand, are readily destroyed by heat and by\ncooking food. Toxin production (especially type E) can occur at\ntemperatures as low as 3 degrees C (37.4 degrees F), i.e., inside a\nrefrigerator, and does not require strict anaerobic conditions.\nHuman illness from Type E is most often associated with improperly\nsmoked fish. Since the toxin is destroyed by heat, it appears that no\nproblem with botulism will result from eating cooked waterfowl.\n(above information extracted from the Michigan Department of Natural\nResources website at\n<http://www.michigan.gov/dnr/0,1607,7-153-10370_12150_12220-26493--,00.html>).\n- Mod.TG]\n...........tg/pg/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "1936-03-15 00:00:00", "1941-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Lake Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monroe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Great Lakes", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jefferson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wayne County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4278", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - USA (NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4278", "date": "2006-11-03 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN - USA (NEW YORK)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 1 Nov 2006\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: Democrat and Chronicle.com [edited]\n<http://www.democratandchronicle.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20061101/NEWS01/611010366/1002/NEWS>\n\nType E botulism seems to be the cause of scores of bird deaths last\nmonth along a stretch of Lake Ontario shoreline, according to the\nstate Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC).\nAt least one sample taken from the bird carcasses has indicated that\ntype E was the cause of death, DEC spokeswoman Maureen Wren said;\nother samples are pending. The DEC's Wildlife Pathology Unit is inspecting and\ntesting the birds.\nAvian botulism is a major cause of death in migratory birds,\naccording to New York Sea Grant. Type E botulism outbreaks have been\nseen on the Great Lakes as far back as the mid-1960s on Lake\nMichigan. But type E did not appear on Lake Ontario until 2002. And\nthis year has proven to be the most fatal to Lake Ontario wildlife,\nwith hundreds of birds dying in July from botulism along the coast of\nJefferson County on the eastern shore of Lake Ontario, according to the DEC.\nBotulism killed an estimated 5000 birds on Lake Erie in 2000, and the\nlake has seen bird deaths annually since then.\nThe state Health Department said in a statement it does not know of\nany human cases of botulism related to the loon deaths.\nThe spores for type E botulism are naturally found in soil and\naquatic sediment, as well as the intestinal tracts of healthy\nanimals, according to Sea Grant. Birds get sick by eating fish\ncontaminated with type E botulism.\nScientists still aren't sure why botulism flares up and dies down, or\nwhy recent outbreaks have been particularly calamitous, said Rod\nGetchell, a professor in Cornell University's aquatic animal health program.\nBut one hypothesis is that the recent introduction of invasive\nspecies such as gobies and zebra mussels might be changing the\necology of the lake's bottom, he said, allowing the type E spores to germinate.\n[Byline: Matthew Daneman]\n--\nBrent Barrett\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n[Botulism in avians is not usually type E, so this is an interesting case.\nThough avian botulism is seen more often in other regions, it will\noccur where the conditions are favorable.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_\nelaborates 7 types of antigenically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of which\naffect humans: type A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxins types A and B\nare highly poisonous proteins resistant to digestion by GI enzymes.\nApproximately 50 percent of foodborne outbreaks in the USA are caused\nby type A toxin, followed by types B and E.\nType C botulism occurs principally in waterfowl and other birds\nliving in an aquatic environment and causes tremendous losses, most\nnotably in waterfowl in the western US. In addition to North America,\nit has been reported in birds in Europe, South Africa, Uruguay, and\nAustralia. In the Great Lakes region, it was first identified in 1936\nin ducks on Green Bay of Lake Michigan and in 1941 in Monroe County\nmarshes along Lake Erie. Type C is most often associated with\nlimberneck paralysis in birds.\nType E botulism is connected with consumption of fish and occurs\nmainly in gulls and loons, and to a lesser extent in mergansers, mute\nswans, grebes, and shorebirds. It now appears that any birds or\nmammals susceptible to botulinum toxin run a risk of becoming\npoisoned if they scavenge dead fish. Evidence for this includes the\nidentification of type E toxin in a bald eagle, wood ducks, and\nmuskrats with fish remaining in their digestive tracts.\n_C. botulinum_ spores are relatively heat-resistant, though high\ntemperatures and/or exposure to moist heat will kill the spores.\nToxins, on the other hand, are readily destroyed by heat and by\ncooking food. Toxin production (especially type E) can occur at\ntemperatures as low as 3 degrees C (37.4 degrees F), i.e., inside a\nrefrigerator, and does not require strict anaerobic conditions.\nHuman illness from Type E is most often associated with improperly\nsmoked fish. Since the toxin is destroyed by heat, it appears that no\nproblem with botulism will result from eating cooked waterfowl.\n(above information extracted from the Michigan Department of Natural\nResources website at\n<http://www.michigan.gov/dnr/0,1607,7-153-10370_12150_12220-26493--,00.html>).\n- Mod.TG]\n...........tg/pg/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "1936-03-15 00:00:00", "1941-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Lake Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monroe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Great Lakes", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jefferson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wayne County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4266", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, crab cakes - Canada: recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4266", "date": "2006-10-09 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CARROT JUICE - CANADA (ON) ex USA\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 9 Oct 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Canadian Broadcasting Corp. [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/consumer/story/2006/10/09/botulism.html>\n\n\nTwo Toronto residents are paralyzed after drinking carrot juice that had\nbeen linked to a botulinum toxin, according to the city's public health\ndepartment.\n\n\"There are 2 adults who are severely ill in hospital, and they had a\nhistory of drinking the exact same juice that's been part of the carrot\njuice recall,\" Dr Elizabeth Rea, an associate medical officer of health,\ntold the Toronto Star on Sun 8 Oct 2006.\n\nThe juice, produced by Bolthouse Farms in Bakersfield, California, was\nordered off North American store shelves late in September 2006, after 4\ncases of botulism in the United States were linked to toxic carrot juice.\n\nToronto Public Health has warned the public to avoid drinking 3 brands of\ncarrot juice. The federal regulator, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency,\nissued a product recall covering the brands on 30 Sep 2006.\n\nBolthouse Farms bottles the 3 brands. The recalled products, all sold in\nboth one litre and 450 mL containers, are Bolthouse Farms 100 per cent\nCarrot Juice, Earthbound Farm Organic Carrot Juice, and President's Choice\nOrganics 100 per cent Pure Carrot Juice. Products with a \"best by\" date up\nto 11 Nov 2006 have been recalled. Consumers who have any brand should\n\"take it out of the fridge, dump it down the sink,\" Rae said.\n\nBolthouse said the cases may have resulted from improper refrigeration.\nCarrot juice is low in acids, so bacteria can grow unless it is kept in the\nrefrigerator.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The suspect carrot juice was distributed in all 50 states, Mexico, Canada,\nand Hong Kong. The posting does not say whether the Canadian cases were\nlinked to juice that, as in the cases in the United States, had not been\nrefrigerated.\n\nThe following statement was extracted from the recent MMWR Dispatch\nregarding the 4 USA cases: \"_Clostridium botulinum_ spores are found in the\nenvironment and can be present naturally in carrot juice and other foods\nthat have not undergone the retort canning process, which involves high\ntemperatures and high pressure. Anaerobic conditions, low acidity (pH\ngreater than 4.6), low salt and sugar concentrations, and temperatures\ngreater than 39 F (greater than 4 C) promote germination of _C. botulinum_\nspores and botulinum toxin production. Carrot juice has low acidity, with a\nnatural pH of approximately 6.0; therefore, in the absence of another\ninhibitor, refrigeration at temperatures less than 40 F (less than 4 C) is\nnecessary to prevent germination of _C. botulinum_ spores and production of\nbotulinum toxin. Inhibiting _C. botulinum_ growth in other ways, such as\nthrough acidification, can retard its growth in juice that is not properly\nrefrigerated.\n\n\"Acidification has been used as a solution to previous foodborne botulism\noutbreaks. In 1985, 36 patients in the USA and Canada were identified with\nbotulism after eating at a restaurant in Vancouver, British Columbia. A\ncase-control study implicated commercially produced, chopped garlic in\nsoybean oil stored at room temperature as the source of the outbreak (1).\nIn 1989, a 2nd outbreak of botulism associated with chopped garlic in oil\noccurred when 3 patients in New York were identified with botulism after\nconsuming a meal containing un-refrigerated, commercially produced, chopped\ngarlic in virgin olive oil (2). After these outbreaks, FDA rules were\naltered to require that garlic-in-oil products contain an acidifying agent\nsuch as phosphoric or citric acid.\n\n\"1. St Louis ME, Peck SH, Bowering D, et al. Botulism from chopped garlic:\ndelayed recognition of a major outbreak. Ann Intern Med 1998; 108: 363-8.\n\"2. Morse DL, Pickard LK, Guzewich JJ, et al. Garlic-in-oil associated\nbotulism: episode leads to product modification. Am J Public Health 1990;\n80: 1372-3.\" - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate) (02) 20061007.2880\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate): FL 20060930.2808\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (GA): alert 20060916.2638\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada (02): background 20060927.2760\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada: recall 20060926.2748\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\n2005\n---\nBotulism, fermented salmon - USA (AK) 20050829.2555\n2004\n---\nBotulism, prison brew - USA (CA) 20040806.2155\n2003\n---\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\n2002\n---\nBotulism, humans - USA (Alaska) 20020721.4823\nBotulism, canned clams - USA (Northeast): recall 20020112.3233\nBotulism, Canned Asparagus - USA: Recall 20020209.3521\n2001\n---\nBotulism - USA (Maryland) 20011102.2714\nBotulism, chili - USA (Texas): recall 20010904.2116\n\n..................ll/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/consumer/story/2006/10/09/botulism.html>\n\n\nTwo Toronto residents are paralyzed after drinking carrot juice that had\nbeen linked to a botulinum toxin, according to the city's public health\ndepartment.\n\n\"There are 2 adults who are severely ill in hospital, and they had a\nhistory of drinking the exact same juice that's been part of the carrot\njuice recall,\" Dr Elizabeth Rea, an associate medical officer of health,\ntold the Toronto Star on Sun 8 Oct 2006.\n\nThe juice, produced by Bolthouse Farms in Bakersfield, California, was\nordered off North American store shelves late in September 2006, after 4\ncases of botulism in the United States were linked to toxic carrot juice.\n\nToronto Public Health has warned the public to avoid drinking 3 brands of\ncarrot juice. The federal regulator, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency,\nissued a product recall covering the brands on 30 Sep 2006.\n\nBolthouse Farms bottles the 3 brands. The recalled products, all sold in\nboth one litre and 450 mL containers, are Bolthouse Farms 100 per cent\nCarrot Juice, Earthbound Farm Organic Carrot Juice, and President's Choice\nOrganics 100 per cent Pure Carrot Juice. Products with a \"best by\" date up\nto 11 Nov 2006 have been recalled. Consumers who have any brand should\n\"take it out of the fridge, dump it down the sink,\" Rae said.\n\nBolthouse said the cases may have resulted from improper refrigeration.\nCarrot juice is low in acids, so bacteria can grow unless it is kept in the\nrefrigerator.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The suspect carrot juice was distributed in all 50 states, Mexico, Canada,\nand Hong Kong. The posting does not say whether the Canadian cases were\nlinked to juice that, as in the cases in the United States, had not been\nrefrigerated.\n\nThe following statement was extracted from the recent MMWR Dispatch\nregarding the 4 USA cases: \"_Clostridium botulinum_ spores are found in the\nenvironment and can be present naturally in carrot juice and other foods\nthat have not undergone the retort canning process, which involves high\ntemperatures and high pressure. Anaerobic conditions, low acidity (pH\ngreater than 4.6), low salt and sugar concentrations, and temperatures\ngreater than 39 F (greater than 4 C) promote germination of _C. botulinum_\nspores and botulinum toxin production. Carrot juice has low acidity, with a\nnatural pH of approximately 6.0; therefore, in the absence of another\ninhibitor, refrigeration at temperatures less than 40 F (less than 4 C) is\nnecessary to prevent germination of _C. botulinum_ spores and production of\nbotulinum toxin. Inhibiting _C. botulinum_ growth in other ways, such as\nthrough acidification, can retard its growth in juice that is not properly\nrefrigerated.\n\n\"Acidification has been used as a solution to previous foodborne botulism\noutbreaks. In 1985, 36 patients in the USA and Canada were identified with\nbotulism after eating at a restaurant in Vancouver, British Columbia. A\ncase-control study implicated commercially produced, chopped garlic in\nsoybean oil stored at room temperature as the source of the outbreak (1).\nIn 1989, a 2nd outbreak of botulism associated with chopped garlic in oil\noccurred when 3 patients in New York were identified with botulism after\nconsuming a meal containing un-refrigerated, commercially produced, chopped\ngarlic in virgin olive oil (2). After these outbreaks, FDA rules were\naltered to require that garlic-in-oil products contain an acidifying agent\nsuch as phosphoric or citric acid.\n\n\"1. St Louis ME, Peck SH, Bowering D, et al. Botulism from chopped garlic:\ndelayed recognition of a major outbreak. Ann Intern Med 1998; 108: 363-8.\n\"2. Morse DL, Pickard LK, Guzewich JJ, et al. Garlic-in-oil associated\nbotulism: episode leads to product modification. Am J Public Health 1990;\n80: 1372-3.\" - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate) (02) 20061007.2880\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate): FL 20060930.2808\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (GA): alert 20060916.2638\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada (02): background 20060927.2760\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada: recall 20060926.2748\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\n2005\n---\nBotulism, fermented salmon - USA (AK) 20050829.2555\n2004\n---\nBotulism, prison brew - USA (CA) 20040806.2155\n2003\n---\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\n2002\n---\nBotulism, humans - USA (Alaska) 20020721.4823\nBotulism, canned clams - USA (Northeast): recall 20020112.3233\nBotulism, Canned Asparagus - USA: Recall 20020209.3521\n2001\n---\nBotulism - USA (Maryland) 20011102.2714\nBotulism, chili - USA (Texas): recall 20010904.2116\n\n..................ll/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The posting does not say whether the Canadian cases were\nlinked to juice that, as in the cases in the United States, had not been\nrefrigerated.\n\nThe following statement was extracted from the recent MMWR Dispatch\nregarding the 4 USA cases: \"_Clostridium botulinum_ spores are found in the\nenvironment and can be present naturally in carrot juice and other foods\nthat have not undergone the retort canning process, which involves high\ntemperatures and high pressure. Anaerobic conditions, low acidity (pH\ngreater than 4.6), low salt and sugar concentrations, and temperatures\ngreater than 39 F (greater than 4 C) promote germination of _C. botulinum_\nspores and botulinum toxin production. Carrot juice has low acidity, with a\nnatural pH of approximately 6.0; therefore, in the absence of another\ninhibitor, refrigeration at temperatures less than 40 F (less than 4 C) is\nnecessary to prevent germination of _C. botulinum_ spores and production of\nbotulinum toxin. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-09-15 00:00:00", "2006-09-30 00:00:00", "1985-03-15 00:00:00", "1989-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1990-03-15 00:00:00", "1372-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "pH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Bakersfield", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3626", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, carrot juice - North America (USA, Canada)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3626", "date": "2006-10-09 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CARROT JUICE - CANADA (ON) ex USA\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 9 Oct 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Canadian Broadcasting Corp. [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/consumer/story/2006/10/09/botulism.html>\n\n\nTwo Toronto residents are paralyzed after drinking carrot juice that had\nbeen linked to a botulinum toxin, according to the city's public health\ndepartment.\n\n\"There are 2 adults who are severely ill in hospital, and they had a\nhistory of drinking the exact same juice that's been part of the carrot\njuice recall,\" Dr Elizabeth Rea, an associate medical officer of health,\ntold the Toronto Star on Sun 8 Oct 2006.\n\nThe juice, produced by Bolthouse Farms in Bakersfield, California, was\nordered off North American store shelves late in September 2006, after 4\ncases of botulism in the United States were linked to toxic carrot juice.\n\nToronto Public Health has warned the public to avoid drinking 3 brands of\ncarrot juice. The federal regulator, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency,\nissued a product recall covering the brands on 30 Sep 2006.\n\nBolthouse Farms bottles the 3 brands. The recalled products, all sold in\nboth one litre and 450 mL containers, are Bolthouse Farms 100 per cent\nCarrot Juice, Earthbound Farm Organic Carrot Juice, and President's Choice\nOrganics 100 per cent Pure Carrot Juice. Products with a \"best by\" date up\nto 11 Nov 2006 have been recalled. Consumers who have any brand should\n\"take it out of the fridge, dump it down the sink,\" Rae said.\n\nBolthouse said the cases may have resulted from improper refrigeration.\nCarrot juice is low in acids, so bacteria can grow unless it is kept in the\nrefrigerator.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The suspect carrot juice was distributed in all 50 states, Mexico, Canada,\nand Hong Kong. The posting does not say whether the Canadian cases were\nlinked to juice that, as in the cases in the United States, had not been\nrefrigerated.\n\nThe following statement was extracted from the recent MMWR Dispatch\nregarding the 4 USA cases: \"_Clostridium botulinum_ spores are found in the\nenvironment and can be present naturally in carrot juice and other foods\nthat have not undergone the retort canning process, which involves high\ntemperatures and high pressure. Anaerobic conditions, low acidity (pH\ngreater than 4.6), low salt and sugar concentrations, and temperatures\ngreater than 39 F (greater than 4 C) promote germination of _C. botulinum_\nspores and botulinum toxin production. Carrot juice has low acidity, with a\nnatural pH of approximately 6.0; therefore, in the absence of another\ninhibitor, refrigeration at temperatures less than 40 F (less than 4 C) is\nnecessary to prevent germination of _C. botulinum_ spores and production of\nbotulinum toxin. Inhibiting _C. botulinum_ growth in other ways, such as\nthrough acidification, can retard its growth in juice that is not properly\nrefrigerated.\n\n\"Acidification has been used as a solution to previous foodborne botulism\noutbreaks. In 1985, 36 patients in the USA and Canada were identified with\nbotulism after eating at a restaurant in Vancouver, British Columbia. A\ncase-control study implicated commercially produced, chopped garlic in\nsoybean oil stored at room temperature as the source of the outbreak (1).\nIn 1989, a 2nd outbreak of botulism associated with chopped garlic in oil\noccurred when 3 patients in New York were identified with botulism after\nconsuming a meal containing un-refrigerated, commercially produced, chopped\ngarlic in virgin olive oil (2). After these outbreaks, FDA rules were\naltered to require that garlic-in-oil products contain an acidifying agent\nsuch as phosphoric or citric acid.\n\n\"1. St Louis ME, Peck SH, Bowering D, et al. Botulism from chopped garlic:\ndelayed recognition of a major outbreak. Ann Intern Med 1998; 108: 363-8.\n\"2. Morse DL, Pickard LK, Guzewich JJ, et al. Garlic-in-oil associated\nbotulism: episode leads to product modification. Am J Public Health 1990;\n80: 1372-3.\" - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate) (02) 20061007.2880\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate): FL 20060930.2808\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (GA): alert 20060916.2638\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada (02): background 20060927.2760\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada: recall 20060926.2748\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\n2005\n---\nBotulism, fermented salmon - USA (AK) 20050829.2555\n2004\n---\nBotulism, prison brew - USA (CA) 20040806.2155\n2003\n---\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\n2002\n---\nBotulism, humans - USA (Alaska) 20020721.4823\nBotulism, canned clams - USA (Northeast): recall 20020112.3233\nBotulism, Canned Asparagus - USA: Recall 20020209.3521\n2001\n---\nBotulism - USA (Maryland) 20011102.2714\nBotulism, chili - USA (Texas): recall 20010904.2116\n\n..................ll/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/consumer/story/2006/10/09/botulism.html>\n\n\nTwo Toronto residents are paralyzed after drinking carrot juice that had\nbeen linked to a botulinum toxin, according to the city's public health\ndepartment.\n\n\"There are 2 adults who are severely ill in hospital, and they had a\nhistory of drinking the exact same juice that's been part of the carrot\njuice recall,\" Dr Elizabeth Rea, an associate medical officer of health,\ntold the Toronto Star on Sun 8 Oct 2006.\n\nThe juice, produced by Bolthouse Farms in Bakersfield, California, was\nordered off North American store shelves late in September 2006, after 4\ncases of botulism in the United States were linked to toxic carrot juice.\n\nToronto Public Health has warned the public to avoid drinking 3 brands of\ncarrot juice. The federal regulator, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency,\nissued a product recall covering the brands on 30 Sep 2006.\n\nBolthouse Farms bottles the 3 brands. The recalled products, all sold in\nboth one litre and 450 mL containers, are Bolthouse Farms 100 per cent\nCarrot Juice, Earthbound Farm Organic Carrot Juice, and President's Choice\nOrganics 100 per cent Pure Carrot Juice. Products with a \"best by\" date up\nto 11 Nov 2006 have been recalled. Consumers who have any brand should\n\"take it out of the fridge, dump it down the sink,\" Rae said.\n\nBolthouse said the cases may have resulted from improper refrigeration.\nCarrot juice is low in acids, so bacteria can grow unless it is kept in the\nrefrigerator.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The suspect carrot juice was distributed in all 50 states, Mexico, Canada,\nand Hong Kong. The posting does not say whether the Canadian cases were\nlinked to juice that, as in the cases in the United States, had not been\nrefrigerated.\n\nThe following statement was extracted from the recent MMWR Dispatch\nregarding the 4 USA cases: \"_Clostridium botulinum_ spores are found in the\nenvironment and can be present naturally in carrot juice and other foods\nthat have not undergone the retort canning process, which involves high\ntemperatures and high pressure. Anaerobic conditions, low acidity (pH\ngreater than 4.6), low salt and sugar concentrations, and temperatures\ngreater than 39 F (greater than 4 C) promote germination of _C. botulinum_\nspores and botulinum toxin production. Carrot juice has low acidity, with a\nnatural pH of approximately 6.0; therefore, in the absence of another\ninhibitor, refrigeration at temperatures less than 40 F (less than 4 C) is\nnecessary to prevent germination of _C. botulinum_ spores and production of\nbotulinum toxin. Inhibiting _C. botulinum_ growth in other ways, such as\nthrough acidification, can retard its growth in juice that is not properly\nrefrigerated.\n\n\"Acidification has been used as a solution to previous foodborne botulism\noutbreaks. In 1985, 36 patients in the USA and Canada were identified with\nbotulism after eating at a restaurant in Vancouver, British Columbia. A\ncase-control study implicated commercially produced, chopped garlic in\nsoybean oil stored at room temperature as the source of the outbreak (1).\nIn 1989, a 2nd outbreak of botulism associated with chopped garlic in oil\noccurred when 3 patients in New York were identified with botulism after\nconsuming a meal containing un-refrigerated, commercially produced, chopped\ngarlic in virgin olive oil (2). After these outbreaks, FDA rules were\naltered to require that garlic-in-oil products contain an acidifying agent\nsuch as phosphoric or citric acid.\n\n\"1. St Louis ME, Peck SH, Bowering D, et al. Botulism from chopped garlic:\ndelayed recognition of a major outbreak. Ann Intern Med 1998; 108: 363-8.\n\"2. Morse DL, Pickard LK, Guzewich JJ, et al. Garlic-in-oil associated\nbotulism: episode leads to product modification. Am J Public Health 1990;\n80: 1372-3.\" - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate) (02) 20061007.2880\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate): FL 20060930.2808\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (GA): alert 20060916.2638\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada (02): background 20060927.2760\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada: recall 20060926.2748\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\n2005\n---\nBotulism, fermented salmon - USA (AK) 20050829.2555\n2004\n---\nBotulism, prison brew - USA (CA) 20040806.2155\n2003\n---\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\n2002\n---\nBotulism, humans - USA (Alaska) 20020721.4823\nBotulism, canned clams - USA (Northeast): recall 20020112.3233\nBotulism, Canned Asparagus - USA: Recall 20020209.3521\n2001\n---\nBotulism - USA (Maryland) 20011102.2714\nBotulism, chili - USA (Texas): recall 20010904.2116\n\n..................ll/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/consumer/story/2006/10/09/botulism.html>\n\n\nTwo Toronto residents are paralyzed after drinking carrot juice that had\nbeen linked to a botulinum toxin, according to the city's public health\ndepartment.\n\n\"There are 2 adults who are severely ill in hospital, and they had a\nhistory of drinking the exact same juice that's been part of the carrot\njuice recall,\" Dr Elizabeth Rea, an associate medical officer of health,\ntold the Toronto Star on Sun 8 Oct 2006.\n\nThe juice, produced by Bolthouse Farms in Bakersfield, California, was\nordered off North American store shelves late in September 2006, after 4\ncases of botulism in the United States were linked to toxic carrot juice.\n\nToronto Public Health has warned the public to avoid drinking 3 brands of\ncarrot juice. The federal regulator, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency,\nissued a product recall covering the brands on 30 Sep 2006.\n\nBolthouse Farms bottles the 3 brands. The recalled products, all sold in\nboth one litre and 450 mL containers, are Bolthouse Farms 100 per cent\nCarrot Juice, Earthbound Farm Organic Carrot Juice, and President's Choice\nOrganics 100 per cent Pure Carrot Juice. Products with a \"best by\" date up\nto 11 Nov 2006 have been recalled. Consumers who have any brand should\n\"take it out of the fridge, dump it down the sink,\" Rae said.\n\nBolthouse said the cases may have resulted from improper refrigeration.\nCarrot juice is low in acids, so bacteria can grow unless it is kept in the\nrefrigerator.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The suspect carrot juice was distributed in all 50 states, Mexico, Canada,\nand Hong Kong. The posting does not say whether the Canadian cases were\nlinked to juice that, as in the cases in the United States, had not been\nrefrigerated.\n\nThe following statement was extracted from the recent MMWR Dispatch\nregarding the 4 USA cases: \"_Clostridium botulinum_ spores are found in the\nenvironment and can be present naturally in carrot juice and other foods\nthat have not undergone the retort canning process, which involves high\ntemperatures and high pressure. Anaerobic conditions, low acidity (pH\ngreater than 4.6), low salt and sugar concentrations, and temperatures\ngreater than 39 F (greater than 4 C) promote germination of _C. botulinum_\nspores and botulinum toxin production. Carrot juice has low acidity, with a\nnatural pH of approximately 6.0; therefore, in the absence of another\ninhibitor, refrigeration at temperatures less than 40 F (less than 4 C) is\nnecessary to prevent germination of _C. botulinum_ spores and production of\nbotulinum toxin. Inhibiting _C. botulinum_ growth in other ways, such as\nthrough acidification, can retard its growth in juice that is not properly\nrefrigerated.\n\n\"Acidification has been used as a solution to previous foodborne botulism\noutbreaks. In 1985, 36 patients in the USA and Canada were identified with\nbotulism after eating at a restaurant in Vancouver, British Columbia. A\ncase-control study implicated commercially produced, chopped garlic in\nsoybean oil stored at room temperature as the source of the outbreak (1).\nIn 1989, a 2nd outbreak of botulism associated with chopped garlic in oil\noccurred when 3 patients in New York were identified with botulism after\nconsuming a meal containing un-refrigerated, commercially produced, chopped\ngarlic in virgin olive oil (2). After these outbreaks, FDA rules were\naltered to require that garlic-in-oil products contain an acidifying agent\nsuch as phosphoric or citric acid.\n\n\"1. St Louis ME, Peck SH, Bowering D, et al. The posting does not say whether the Canadian cases were\nlinked to juice that, as in the cases in the United States, had not been\nrefrigerated.\n\nThe following statement was extracted from the recent MMWR Dispatch\nregarding the 4 USA cases: \"_Clostridium botulinum_ spores are found in the\nenvironment and can be present naturally in carrot juice and other foods\nthat have not undergone the retort canning process, which involves high\ntemperatures and high pressure. Anaerobic conditions, low acidity (pH\ngreater than 4.6), low salt and sugar concentrations, and temperatures\ngreater than 39 F (greater than 4 C) promote germination of _C. botulinum_\nspores and botulinum toxin production. Carrot juice has low acidity, with a\nnatural pH of approximately 6.0; therefore, in the absence of another\ninhibitor, refrigeration at temperatures less than 40 F (less than 4 C) is\nnecessary to prevent germination of _C. botulinum_ spores and production of\nbotulinum toxin. Inhibiting _C. botulinum_ growth in other ways, such as\nthrough acidification, can retard its growth in juice that is not properly\nrefrigerated.\n\n\"Acidification has been used as a solution to previous foodborne botulism\noutbreaks. In 1985, 36 patients in the USA and Canada were identified with\nbotulism after eating at a restaurant in Vancouver, British Columbia. A\ncase-control study implicated commercially produced, chopped garlic in\nsoybean oil stored at room temperature as the source of the outbreak (1).\nIn 1989, a 2nd outbreak of botulism associated with chopped garlic in oil\noccurred when 3 patients in New York were identified with botulism after\nconsuming a meal containing un-refrigerated, commercially produced, chopped\ngarlic in virgin olive oil (2). After these outbreaks, FDA rules were\naltered to require that garlic-in-oil products contain an acidifying agent\nsuch as phosphoric or citric acid.\n\n\"1. St Louis ME, Peck SH, Bowering D, et al. Botulism from chopped garlic:\ndelayed recognition of a major outbreak. Ann Intern Med 1998; 108: 363-8.\n\"2. Morse DL, Pickard LK, Guzewich JJ, et al. Garlic-in-oil associated\nbotulism: episode leads to product modification. Am J Public Health 1990;\n80: 1372-3.\" - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate) (02) 20061007.2880\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate): FL 20060930.2808\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (GA): alert 20060916.2638\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada (02): background 20060927.2760\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada: recall 20060926.2748\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\n2005\n---\nBotulism, fermented salmon - USA (AK) 20050829.2555\n2004\n---\nBotulism, prison brew - USA (CA) 20040806.2155\n2003\n---\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\n2002\n---\nBotulism, humans - USA (Alaska) 20020721.4823\nBotulism, canned clams - USA (Northeast): recall 20020112.3233\nBotulism, Canned Asparagus - USA: Recall 20020209.3521\n2001\n---\nBotulism - USA (Maryland) 20011102.2714\nBotulism, chili - USA (Texas): recall 20010904.2116\n\n..................ll/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-09-15 00:00:00", "2006-09-30 00:00:00", "1985-03-15 00:00:00", "1989-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1990-03-15 00:00:00", "1372-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "pH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Bakersfield", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3390", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, carrot juice - Canada (ON) ex USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3390", "date": "2006-10-09 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CARROT JUICE - CANADA (ON) ex USA\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 9 Oct 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Canadian Broadcasting Corp. [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/consumer/story/2006/10/09/botulism.html>\n\n\nTwo Toronto residents are paralyzed after drinking carrot juice that had\nbeen linked to a botulinum toxin, according to the city's public health\ndepartment.\n\n\"There are 2 adults who are severely ill in hospital, and they had a\nhistory of drinking the exact same juice that's been part of the carrot\njuice recall,\" Dr Elizabeth Rea, an associate medical officer of health,\ntold the Toronto Star on Sun 8 Oct 2006.\n\nThe juice, produced by Bolthouse Farms in Bakersfield, California, was\nordered off North American store shelves late in September 2006, after 4\ncases of botulism in the United States were linked to toxic carrot juice.\n\nToronto Public Health has warned the public to avoid drinking 3 brands of\ncarrot juice. The federal regulator, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency,\nissued a product recall covering the brands on 30 Sep 2006.\n\nBolthouse Farms bottles the 3 brands. The recalled products, all sold in\nboth one litre and 450 mL containers, are Bolthouse Farms 100 per cent\nCarrot Juice, Earthbound Farm Organic Carrot Juice, and President's Choice\nOrganics 100 per cent Pure Carrot Juice. Products with a \"best by\" date up\nto 11 Nov 2006 have been recalled. Consumers who have any brand should\n\"take it out of the fridge, dump it down the sink,\" Rae said.\n\nBolthouse said the cases may have resulted from improper refrigeration.\nCarrot juice is low in acids, so bacteria can grow unless it is kept in the\nrefrigerator.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The suspect carrot juice was distributed in all 50 states, Mexico, Canada,\nand Hong Kong. The posting does not say whether the Canadian cases were\nlinked to juice that, as in the cases in the United States, had not been\nrefrigerated.\n\nThe following statement was extracted from the recent MMWR Dispatch\nregarding the 4 USA cases: \"_Clostridium botulinum_ spores are found in the\nenvironment and can be present naturally in carrot juice and other foods\nthat have not undergone the retort canning process, which involves high\ntemperatures and high pressure. Anaerobic conditions, low acidity (pH\ngreater than 4.6), low salt and sugar concentrations, and temperatures\ngreater than 39 F (greater than 4 C) promote germination of _C. botulinum_\nspores and botulinum toxin production. Carrot juice has low acidity, with a\nnatural pH of approximately 6.0; therefore, in the absence of another\ninhibitor, refrigeration at temperatures less than 40 F (less than 4 C) is\nnecessary to prevent germination of _C. botulinum_ spores and production of\nbotulinum toxin. Inhibiting _C. botulinum_ growth in other ways, such as\nthrough acidification, can retard its growth in juice that is not properly\nrefrigerated.\n\n\"Acidification has been used as a solution to previous foodborne botulism\noutbreaks. In 1985, 36 patients in the USA and Canada were identified with\nbotulism after eating at a restaurant in Vancouver, British Columbia. A\ncase-control study implicated commercially produced, chopped garlic in\nsoybean oil stored at room temperature as the source of the outbreak (1).\nIn 1989, a 2nd outbreak of botulism associated with chopped garlic in oil\noccurred when 3 patients in New York were identified with botulism after\nconsuming a meal containing un-refrigerated, commercially produced, chopped\ngarlic in virgin olive oil (2). After these outbreaks, FDA rules were\naltered to require that garlic-in-oil products contain an acidifying agent\nsuch as phosphoric or citric acid.\n\n\"1. St Louis ME, Peck SH, Bowering D, et al. Botulism from chopped garlic:\ndelayed recognition of a major outbreak. Ann Intern Med 1998; 108: 363-8.\n\"2. Morse DL, Pickard LK, Guzewich JJ, et al. Garlic-in-oil associated\nbotulism: episode leads to product modification. Am J Public Health 1990;\n80: 1372-3.\" - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate) (02) 20061007.2880\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate): FL 20060930.2808\nBotulism, carrot juice - USA (GA): alert 20060916.2638\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada (02): background 20060927.2760\nBotulism, gravy, chili sauce - Canada: recall 20060926.2748\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\n2005\n---\nBotulism, fermented salmon - USA (AK) 20050829.2555\n2004\n---\nBotulism, prison brew - USA (CA) 20040806.2155\n2003\n---\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\n2002\n---\nBotulism, humans - USA (Alaska) 20020721.4823\nBotulism, canned clams - USA (Northeast): recall 20020112.3233\nBotulism, Canned Asparagus - USA: Recall 20020209.3521\n2001\n---\nBotulism - USA (Maryland) 20011102.2714\nBotulism, chili - USA (Texas): recall 20010904.2116\n\n..................ll/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-09-15 00:00:00", "2006-09-30 00:00:00", "1985-03-15 00:00:00", "1989-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1990-03-15 00:00:00", "1372-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "pH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Vancouver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Bakersfield", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3305", "headline": "PRO> Botulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3305", "date": "2006-09-16 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED FOOD, FISH - RUSSIA (LIPETSK)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 10 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail Correspondent Artak S\nSource: IA Lipetsk News [Russian, trans. Mod.NR; edited]\n<http://www.lipetsknews.ru/polezno/?id=3618>\n\nAccording to Anna Dolgova, the deputy chief of the sanitary\nsurveillance center of the Lipetsk region, 7 people have suffered\nfrom botulism in Lipetsk. One of them, a 51-year-old man, had died.\nThe cause of the disease is usually domestically canned food. One of\nthe 7 affected individuals ate canned mushrooms; another one consumed\ncanned stewed meat, which proved fatal. The other 5 people with\nbotulism consumed domestically prepared fish.\nBotulinum toxin can be destroyed during heating. If canned food is\nboiled for 10-15 minutes [the botulinum toxin is destroyed]. It is\nrecommended not to use iron caps when mushrooms are canned. Mushrooms\nshould be carefully washed to rid them of various debris, since the\ndirt and other organic debris may contain spores of botulism.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Depending on the geography, the most common cause is either fish\n(canned, dried or salted, stockfish) or domestically cooked\nmushrooms. Canned meat and fruit are in 2nd place as causal factors\nof botulism.\nFish is the cause throughout the southern steppes of Russia, close to\nlarge rivers and in the regions along the Baykal river. Group\noutbreaks are registered more frequently. It is enough to boil food\nfor 10-15 minutes to destroy the botulinum toxin; boiling denatures\nthe proteins, as well as the toxin. - Mod.NP]\n[Botulism is most often caused by the pre-formed toxin produced by\nthe bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Animals are most often exposed\nto the organism through oral ingestion or through wound contamination.\nClassically, botulism is a food-borne disease caused by the ingestion\nof preformed toxin, although there also exists wound botulism (in\nwhich _C. botulinum_ spores germinate in a wound), and infant\nbotulism (in which the spores germinate in the intestinal tract).\nBotulism is a potentially fatal toxemia caused by ingestion of the\ntoxin of _C. botulinum_. There are 8 recognized types and subtypes of\nthe organisms.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_\nelaborates 7 types of antigenetically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of\nwhich affect humans: type A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxin types A\nand B are highly poisonous proteins resistant to digestion by\ngastro-intestinal enzymes.\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the most common. Although\neach type has a similar symptom complex, Hughes and colleagues report\nthat type E is much more likely to produce initial lethargic mental\nstatus and more autonomic dysfunction (2).\nThe method of diagnosis of botulism is not stated here nor is the\nmethod of testing for the food products discussed, assuming that the\npreserved food was not consumed in its entirety.\nIndividual cases of paralysis can be confused with other diseases,\nbut a cluster of such cases is certainly likely to be botulism. Type\nE botulism is the type frequently associated with fish products (1).\n1. Weber JT, Hibbs RG, Darwish A, et al: A massive outbreak of type E\nbotulism associated with traditional salted fish in Cairo. J Infect\nDis 1993;167: 451-4.\n2. Hughes JM, Hatheway CL, Ostroff SM: Botulism. In: Scheld WM,\nWhitley RJ, Durack DT, editors. Infections of the central nervous\nsystem. 2nd edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott-Raven, 1997, 615-28. - Mod.LL/TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, mushrooms - Russia (Tambov) 20060819.2317\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20060724.2036\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya) 20051017.3029\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20051014.2998\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nBotulism, canned salad - Kyrgyzstan (Kant) 20050406.099\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism during pregnancy - Kyrgyzstan (Chuysk) 20050218.0538\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\n2004\n----\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia)(04) 20041028.291\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (03) 20040908.2508\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (02) 20040825.2371\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20040817.2278\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n................................................tg/ll/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. One of them, a 51-year-old man, had died.\nThe cause of the disease is usually domestically canned food. One of\nthe 7 affected individuals ate canned mushrooms; another one consumed\ncanned stewed meat, which proved fatal. The other 5 people with\nbotulism consumed domestically prepared fish.\nBotulinum toxin can be destroyed during heating. If canned food is\nboiled for 10-15 minutes [the botulinum toxin is destroyed]. It is\nrecommended not to use iron caps when mushrooms are canned. Group\noutbreaks are registered more frequently. It is enough to boil food\nfor 10-15 minutes to destroy the botulinum toxin; boiling denatures\nthe proteins, as well as the toxin. - Mod.NP]\n[Botulism is most often caused by the pre-formed toxin produced by\nthe bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Animals are most often exposed\nto the organism through oral ingestion or through wound contamination.\nClassically, botulism is a food-borne disease caused by the ingestion\nof preformed toxin, although there also exists wound botulism (in\nwhich _C. botulinum_ spores germinate in a wound), and infant\nbotulism (in which the spores germinate in the intestinal tract).\nBotulism is a potentially fatal toxemia caused by ingestion of the\ntoxin of _C. botulinum_. There are 8 recognized types and subtypes of\nthe organisms.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_\nelaborates 7 types of antigenetically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of\nwhich affect humans: type A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxin types A\nand B are highly poisonous proteins resistant to digestion by\ngastro-intestinal enzymes.\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the most common. Type\nE botulism is the type frequently associated with fish products (1).\n1. Weber JT, Hibbs RG, Darwish A, et al: A massive outbreak of type E\nbotulism associated with traditional salted fish in Cairo. J Infect\nDis 1993;167: 451-4.\n2.
