For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Zaporozhye", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Hatheway", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Weber JT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lipetsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3051", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, carrot juice - USA (multistate): FL", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3051", "date": "2006-09-16 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED FOOD, FISH - RUSSIA (LIPETSK)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 10 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail Correspondent Artak S\nSource: IA Lipetsk News [Russian, trans. Mod.NR; edited]\n<http://www.lipetsknews.ru/polezno/?id=3618>\n\nAccording to Anna Dolgova, the deputy chief of the sanitary\nsurveillance center of the Lipetsk region, 7 people have suffered\nfrom botulism in Lipetsk. One of them, a 51-year-old man, had died.\nThe cause of the disease is usually domestically canned food. One of\nthe 7 affected individuals ate canned mushrooms; another one consumed\ncanned stewed meat, which proved fatal. The other 5 people with\nbotulism consumed domestically prepared fish.\nBotulinum toxin can be destroyed during heating. If canned food is\nboiled for 10-15 minutes [the botulinum toxin is destroyed]. It is\nrecommended not to use iron caps when mushrooms are canned. Mushrooms\nshould be carefully washed to rid them of various debris, since the\ndirt and other organic debris may contain spores of botulism.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Depending on the geography, the most common cause is either fish\n(canned, dried or salted, stockfish) or domestically cooked\nmushrooms. Canned meat and fruit are in 2nd place as causal factors\nof botulism.\nFish is the cause throughout the southern steppes of Russia, close to\nlarge rivers and in the regions along the Baykal river. Group\noutbreaks are registered more frequently. It is enough to boil food\nfor 10-15 minutes to destroy the botulinum toxin; boiling denatures\nthe proteins, as well as the toxin. - Mod.NP]\n[Botulism is most often caused by the pre-formed toxin produced by\nthe bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Animals are most often exposed\nto the organism through oral ingestion or through wound contamination.\nClassically, botulism is a food-borne disease caused by the ingestion\nof preformed toxin, although there also exists wound botulism (in\nwhich _C. botulinum_ spores germinate in a wound), and infant\nbotulism (in which the spores germinate in the intestinal tract).\nBotulism is a potentially fatal toxemia caused by ingestion of the\ntoxin of _C. botulinum_. There are 8 recognized types and subtypes of\nthe organisms.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_\nelaborates 7 types of antigenetically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of\nwhich affect humans: type A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxin types A\nand B are highly poisonous proteins resistant to digestion by\ngastro-intestinal enzymes.\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the most common. Although\neach type has a similar symptom complex, Hughes and colleagues report\nthat type E is much more likely to produce initial lethargic mental\nstatus and more autonomic dysfunction (2).\nThe method of diagnosis of botulism is not stated here nor is the\nmethod of testing for the food products discussed, assuming that the\npreserved food was not consumed in its entirety.\nIndividual cases of paralysis can be confused with other diseases,\nbut a cluster of such cases is certainly likely to be botulism. Type\nE botulism is the type frequently associated with fish products (1).\n1. Weber JT, Hibbs RG, Darwish A, et al: A massive outbreak of type E\nbotulism associated with traditional salted fish in Cairo. J Infect\nDis 1993;167: 451-4.\n2. Hughes JM, Hatheway CL, Ostroff SM: Botulism. In: Scheld WM,\nWhitley RJ, Durack DT, editors. Infections of the central nervous\nsystem. 2nd edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott-Raven, 1997, 615-28. - Mod.LL/TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, mushrooms - Russia (Tambov) 20060819.2317\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20060724.2036\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya) 20051017.3029\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20051014.2998\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nBotulism, canned salad - Kyrgyzstan (Kant) 20050406.099\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism during pregnancy - Kyrgyzstan (Chuysk) 20050218.0538\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\n2004\n----\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia)(04) 20041028.291\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (03) 20040908.2508\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (02) 20040825.2371\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20040817.2278\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n................................................tg/ll/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. One of\nthe 7 affected individuals ate canned mushrooms; another one consumed\ncanned stewed meat, which proved fatal. The other 5 people with\nbotulism consumed domestically prepared fish.\nBotulinum toxin can be destroyed during heating. If canned food is\nboiled for 10-15 minutes [the botulinum toxin is destroyed]. It is\nrecommended not to use iron caps when mushrooms are canned. Group\noutbreaks are registered more frequently. It is enough to boil food\nfor 10-15 minutes to destroy the botulinum toxin; boiling denatures\nthe proteins, as well as the toxin. - Mod.NP]\n[Botulism is most often caused by the pre-formed toxin produced by\nthe bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Animals are most often exposed\nto the organism through oral ingestion or through wound contamination.\nClassically, botulism is a food-borne disease caused by the ingestion\nof preformed toxin, although there also exists wound botulism (in\nwhich _C. botulinum_ spores germinate in a wound), and infant\nbotulism (in which the spores germinate in the intestinal tract).\nBotulism is a potentially fatal toxemia caused by ingestion of the\ntoxin of _C. botulinum_. There are 8 recognized types and subtypes of\nthe organisms.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_\nelaborates 7 types of antigenetically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of\nwhich affect humans: type A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxin types A\nand B are highly poisonous proteins resistant to digestion by\ngastro-intestinal enzymes.\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the most common. Although\neach type has a similar symptom complex, Hughes and colleagues report\nthat type E is much more likely to produce initial lethargic mental\nstatus and more autonomic dysfunction (2).\nThe method of diagnosis of botulism is not stated here nor is the\nmethod of testing for the food products discussed, assuming that the\npreserved food was not consumed in its entirety.\nIndividual cases of paralysis can be confused with other diseases,\nbut a cluster of such cases is certainly likely to be botulism. Type\nE botulism is the type frequently associated with fish products (1).\n1. Weber JT, Hibbs RG, Darwish A, et al: A massive outbreak of type E\nbotulism associated with traditional salted fish in Cairo. J Infect\nDis 1993;167: 451-4.\n2. There are 8 recognized types and subtypes of\nthe organisms.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_\nelaborates 7 types of antigenetically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of\nwhich affect humans: type A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxin types A\nand B are highly poisonous proteins resistant to digestion by\ngastro-intestinal enzymes.\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the most common. Animals are most often exposed\nto the organism through oral ingestion or through wound contamination.\nClassically, botulism is a food-borne disease caused by the ingestion\nof preformed toxin, although there also exists wound botulism (in\nwhich _C. botulinum_ spores germinate in a wound), and infant\nbotulism (in which the spores germinate in the intestinal tract).\nBotulism is a potentially fatal toxemia caused by ingestion of the\ntoxin of _C. botulinum_. Toxin types A\nand B are highly poisonous proteins resistant to digestion by\ngastro-intestinal enzymes.\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the most common. Although\neach type has a similar symptom complex, Hughes and colleagues report\nthat type E is much more likely to produce initial lethargic mental\nstatus and more autonomic dysfunction (2).\nThe method of diagnosis of botulism is not stated here nor is the\nmethod of testing for the food products discussed, assuming that the\npreserved food was not consumed in its entirety.\nIndividual cases of paralysis can be confused with other diseases,\nbut a cluster of such cases is certainly likely to be botulism. Type\nE botulism is the type frequently associated with fish products (1).\n1. Weber JT, Hibbs RG, Darwish A, et al: A massive outbreak of type E\nbotulism associated with traditional salted fish in Cairo. J Infect\nDis 1993;167: 451-4.\n2. Hughes JM, Hatheway CL, Ostroff SM: Botulism. In: Scheld WM,\nWhitley RJ, Durack DT, editors. Infections of the central nervous\nsystem. 2nd edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott-Raven, 1997, 615-28. - Mod.LL/TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, mushrooms - Russia (Tambov) 20060819.2317\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20060724.2036\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya) 20051017.3029\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20051014.2998\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nBotulism, canned salad - Kyrgyzstan (Kant) 20050406.099\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism during pregnancy - Kyrgyzstan (Chuysk) 20050218.0538\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\n2004\n----\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia)(04) 20041028.291\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (03) 20040908.2508\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (02) 20040825.2371\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20040817.2278\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n................................................tg/ll/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Zaporozhye", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Hatheway", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Weber JT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lipetsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2762", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Ireland (County Mayo) ex Poland", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2762", "date": "2006-09-16 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED FOOD, FISH - RUSSIA (LIPETSK)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 10 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail Correspondent Artak S\nSource: IA Lipetsk News [Russian, trans. Mod.NR; edited]\n<http://www.lipetsknews.ru/polezno/?id=3618>\n\nAccording to Anna Dolgova, the deputy chief of the sanitary\nsurveillance center of the Lipetsk region, 7 people have suffered\nfrom botulism in Lipetsk. One of them, a 51-year-old man, had died.\nThe cause of the disease is usually domestically canned food. One of\nthe 7 affected individuals ate canned mushrooms; another one consumed\ncanned stewed meat, which proved fatal. The other 5 people with\nbotulism consumed domestically prepared fish.\nBotulinum toxin can be destroyed during heating. If canned food is\nboiled for 10-15 minutes [the botulinum toxin is destroyed]. It is\nrecommended not to use iron caps when mushrooms are canned. Mushrooms\nshould be carefully washed to rid them of various debris, since the\ndirt and other organic debris may contain spores of botulism.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Depending on the geography, the most common cause is either fish\n(canned, dried or salted, stockfish) or domestically cooked\nmushrooms. Canned meat and fruit are in 2nd place as causal factors\nof botulism.\nFish is the cause throughout the southern steppes of Russia, close to\nlarge rivers and in the regions along the Baykal river. Group\noutbreaks are registered more frequently. It is enough to boil food\nfor 10-15 minutes to destroy the botulinum toxin; boiling denatures\nthe proteins, as well as the toxin. - Mod.NP]\n[Botulism is most often caused by the pre-formed toxin produced by\nthe bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Animals are most often exposed\nto the organism through oral ingestion or through wound contamination.\nClassically, botulism is a food-borne disease caused by the ingestion\nof preformed toxin, although there also exists wound botulism (in\nwhich _C. botulinum_ spores germinate in a wound), and infant\nbotulism (in which the spores germinate in the intestinal tract).\nBotulism is a potentially fatal toxemia caused by ingestion of the\ntoxin of _C. botulinum_. There are 8 recognized types and subtypes of\nthe organisms.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_\nelaborates 7 types of antigenetically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of\nwhich affect humans: type A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxin types A\nand B are highly poisonous proteins resistant to digestion by\ngastro-intestinal enzymes.\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the most common. Although\neach type has a similar symptom complex, Hughes and colleagues report\nthat type E is much more likely to produce initial lethargic mental\nstatus and more autonomic dysfunction (2).\nThe method of diagnosis of botulism is not stated here nor is the\nmethod of testing for the food products discussed, assuming that the\npreserved food was not consumed in its entirety.\nIndividual cases of paralysis can be confused with other diseases,\nbut a cluster of such cases is certainly likely to be botulism. Type\nE botulism is the type frequently associated with fish products (1).\n1. Weber JT, Hibbs RG, Darwish A, et al: A massive outbreak of type E\nbotulism associated with traditional salted fish in Cairo. J Infect\nDis 1993;167: 451-4.\n2. Hughes JM, Hatheway CL, Ostroff SM: Botulism. In: Scheld WM,\nWhitley RJ, Durack DT, editors. Infections of the central nervous\nsystem. 2nd edition. Philadelphia: Lippincott-Raven, 1997, 615-28. - Mod.LL/TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, mushrooms - Russia (Tambov) 20060819.2317\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20060724.2036\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya) 20051017.3029\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20051014.2998\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nBotulism, canned salad - Kyrgyzstan (Kant) 20050406.099\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism during pregnancy - Kyrgyzstan (Chuysk) 20050218.0538\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\n2004\n----\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia)(04) 20041028.291\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (03) 20040908.2508\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (02) 20040825.2371\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20040817.2278\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n................................................tg/ll/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Zaporozhye", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Hatheway", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Weber JT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lipetsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2694", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, canned food, fish - Russia (Lipetsk)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2694", "date": "2006-09-16 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED FOOD, FISH - RUSSIA (LIPETSK)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 10 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail Correspondent Artak S\nSource: IA Lipetsk News [Russian, trans. Mod.NR; edited]\n<http://www.lipetsknews.ru/polezno/?id=3618>\n\nAccording to Anna Dolgova, the deputy chief of the sanitary\nsurveillance center of the Lipetsk region, 7 people have suffered\nfrom botulism in Lipetsk. One of them, a 51-year-old man, had died.\nThe cause of the disease is usually domestically canned food. One of\nthe 7 affected individuals ate canned mushrooms; another one consumed\ncanned stewed meat, which proved fatal. The other 5 people with\nbotulism consumed domestically prepared fish.\nBotulinum toxin can be destroyed during heating. If canned food is\nboiled for 10-15 minutes [the botulinum toxin is destroyed]. It is\nrecommended not to use iron caps when mushrooms are canned. Mushrooms\nshould be carefully washed to rid them of various debris, since the\ndirt and other organic debris may contain spores of botulism.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Depending on the geography, the most common cause is either fish\n(canned, dried or salted, stockfish) or domestically cooked\nmushrooms. Canned meat and fruit are in 2nd place as causal factors\nof botulism.\nFish is the cause throughout the southern steppes of Russia, close to\nlarge rivers and in the regions along the Baykal river. Group\noutbreaks are registered more frequently. It is enough to boil food\nfor 10-15 minutes to destroy the botulinum toxin; boiling denatures\nthe proteins, as well as the toxin. - Mod.NP]\n[Botulism is most often caused by the pre-formed toxin produced by\nthe bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Animals are most often exposed\nto the organism through oral ingestion or through wound contamination.\nClassically, botulism is a food-borne disease caused by the ingestion\nof preformed toxin, although there also exists wound botulism (in\nwhich _C. botulinum_ spores germinate in a wound), and infant\nbotulism (in which the spores germinate in the intestinal tract).\nBotulism is a potentially fatal toxemia caused by ingestion of the\ntoxin of _C. botulinum_. There are 8 recognized types and subtypes of\nthe organisms.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_\nelaborates 7 types of antigenetically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of\nwhich affect humans: type A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxin types A\nand B are highly poisonous proteins resistant to digestion by\ngastro-intestinal enzymes.\nTypes A, B, and E of human botulism are the most common. Although\neach type has a similar symptom complex, Hughes and colleagues report\nthat type E is much more likely to produce initial lethargic mental\nstatus and more autonomic dysfunction (2).\nThe method of diagnosis of botulism is not stated here nor is the\nmethod of testing for the food products discussed, assuming that the\npreserved food was not consumed in its entirety.\nIndividual cases of paralysis can be confused with other diseases,\nbut a cluster of such cases is certainly likely to be botulism. Type\nE botulism is the type frequently associated with fish products (1).\n1. Weber JT, Hibbs RG, Darwish A, et al: A massive outbreak of type E\nbotulism associated with traditional salted fish in Cairo. J Infect\nDis 1993;167: 451-4.\n2. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Zaporozhye", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Hatheway", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Weber JT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lipetsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2696", "headline": "PRO/ALL> Botulism, carrot juice - USA (GA): alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2696", "date": "2006-07-21 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, SMOKED FISH - FINLAND EX CANADA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 20 July 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060720.asp#3>\n\nOn 29 Jun 2006, a 65-year-old woman fell ill with vomiting and\ndiarrhea in southern Finland. The next day she developed muscular\nweakness of her upper and lower limbs, and was admitted to hospital.\nShe developed difficulty in breathing and required mechanical\nventilation in an intensive care unit for a week.\nThe patient is now recovering, but still has some difficulties in\nswallowing, and is not yet able to walk. The patient did not receive\nbotulinum antitoxin, since the symptoms had already begun to resolve\nupon diagnosis. The patient's husband also had diarrhea on 29 Jun\n2006 and later had some difficulties in swallowing, but no other\nneurological symptoms were observed. He was admitted to hospital for\none night (1-2 Jul 2006) because of diarrhea.\nSerum samples from the female patient taken on 30 Jun and 1 Jul 2006\nwere positive for botulinum neurotoxin by mouse bioassay, and the\nneutralization test suggested that the patient's illness was caused\nby botulinum toxin type E. Gastric fluid and serum samples taken on 4\nJul 2006 did not yield neurotoxin or _Clostridium botulinum_. No\nspecimens were available from the husband, as botulism was not\ndiagnosed during his hospital stay, and he was not called back to\nhospital for specimens.\nAn interview with the husband revealed that the couple had eaten\nsmoked vacuum-packed whitefish on 28 Jun 2006. The wife had eaten\nmost of the fish, and the husband ate only a small portion. The\nwhitefish had been imported from Canada, but smoked and packed in\nFinland. There was no leftover fish for microbiological examination.\nFlush samples were taken from the fish's plastic packaging, but they\nwere negative for _C. botulinum_ by PCR (1) and culture.\nThe suspected fish product was recalled by the manufacturer, and\nproduction of the product was suspended. The national and local food\ncontrol authorities inspected the production plant and the\ndistribution center. The entire manufacturing process and storage\ntemperatures throughout the cold chain, including the retail outlet,\nwere investigated. The inspections did not reveal any factors that\ncould have created an increased risk of botulinum neurotoxin\nproduction. Microbiological analysis of 10 vacuum-packed fish made\nfrom the same raw fish batch that was used to make the product eaten\nby the patient, and from fish from earlier and later batches, were\nall negative for _C. botulinum_.\nThe investigators have therefore hypothesized that there may have\nbeen storage temperature abuse at a later stage, such as in the\nretail outlet or the home. After inspection of the facility and\nmicrobiological examination of fish samples, production of the\nproduct has started again.\n_C. botulinum_ type E is naturally highly prevalent in aquatic\nenvironments and fish (2,3), leading to a high risk of contamination.\nThe hot-smoking processes are usually too low to eliminate botulinum\nspores (4). Growth and toxin production from spores in vacuum-packed\nsmoked fish products with anaerobic atmosphere and limited\npreservative factors is likely during extended storage at\ntemperatures above 3 degrees C. Therefore the most important factors\ncontrolling _C. botulinum_ growth and toxin production are efficient\nheat treatments, restricted shelf life and continuous storage below 3\ndegrees C.\nHuman botulism is a very rare disease; the most recent case to be\nreported in Finland before the one mentioned here occurred in 1999\n(5). A similar outbreak that affected 2 people in Germany in 1997 is\ndescribed in the literature (1). However, it is of utmost importance\nthat physicians remain aware of the disease as a possible diagnosis.\nBotulism should be considered whenever a patient develops\nneurological symptoms that include blurred vision, difficulties in\nswallowing or speech and symptoms of descending flaccid paralysis.\nThis should be followed by appropriate epidemiological and laboratory\nanalyses to confirm the diagnosis and to improve the epidemiological\nunderstanding of the disease (6).\n1. Korkeala H, Stengel G, Hyytia E, et al: Type E botulism associated\nwith vacuum-packaged hot-smoked whitefish. Int J Food Microbiol\n1998;43: 1-5.\n2. Hielm S, Bjorkroth J, Hyytia E, Korkeala H: Prevalence of\nClostridium botulinum in Finnish trout farms: pulsed-field gel\nelectrophoresis typing reveals extensive genetic diversity among type\nE isolates. Appl Environ Microbiol 1998;64: 4161-4167.\n3. Hyytia E, Hielm S, Korkeala H. Prevalence of Clostridium botulinum\ntype E in Finnish fish and fishery products. Epidemiol Infect 1998;\n120: 245-50.\n4. Lindstrom M, Nevas M, Hielm S, et al: Thermal inactivation of\nnonproteolytic Clostridium botulinum type E spores in model fish\nmedia and in vacuum-packaged hot-smoked fish products. Appl Environ\nMicrobiol 2003;6: 4029-36.\n5. Lindstrom M, Hielm S, Nevas M, et al: Proteolytic Clostridium\nbotulinum type B in the gastric content of a patient with type E\nbotulism due to whitefish eggs. Foodborne Pathog Dis 2004;1: 53-57.\n6. Lindstrom M, Korkeala H: Laboratory diagnostics of botulism. Clin\nMicrobiol Rev 2006;19: 298-314.\n[Written by: Lindstrom M, Vuorela M, Hinderink K, et al\n<markku.kuusi@ktl.fi>]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report points out that storage temperature issues may also\ncontribute to botulism.\nProdromal symptoms of food-borne botulism often include nausea,\nvomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, which are absent from cases\nof wound botulism. It is not clear that these symptoms are related\nto botulism per se or other contaminants of the ingested food. A USA\npaper (1) reported vomiting in 59 percent of foodborne cases and\ndiarrhea in 19 percent; and one from the Republic of Georgia (2)\nreported vomiting in 56 percent and diarrhea in 25 percent.\n1. Hughes JM, Blumenthal JR, Merson MH, et al: Clinical features of\ntypes A and B food-borne botulism. Ann Intern Med 1981;95: 442-45.\n2. Varma JK, Katsitadze G, Moiscrafishvili M, et al: Signs and\nsymptoms predictive of death in patients with foodborne botulism -\nRepublic of Georgia, 1980-2002. Clin Infect Dis 2004;39: 357-62. -\nMod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, deer meat - Thailand (Phayao) 20060711.1901\nBotulism, bamboo shoots - Thailand (Nan)(03) 20060416.1131\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\nBotulism, human, bamboo shoots - Thailand (Nan) 20060320.0865\nBotulism - Armenia (Erevan) 20060216.0505\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya) 20051017.3029\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20051014.2998\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex. Georgia (02): susp. 20050426.1159\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex Georgia: susp 20050420.1108\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism during pregnancy - Kyrgyzstan (Chuysk) 20050218.0538\nBotulism, bamboo shoots - Canada (AB, BC): recall 20050110.0083\n2004\n----\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Kharkov) 20041030.2930\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (03) 20040908.2508\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20040817.2278\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n2000\n----\nBotulism, foodborne - Russia 1999 20000229.0277\n1999\n----\nBotulism, human - Russia (Burjatija) 19990907.1576\n1998\n----\nBotulism, human - Japan (Tokyo) 19980816.1632\n............................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-07-20 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-06-28 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-05 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bjorkroth J", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Environ", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "Finland"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "the Republic of Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Botulism - Armenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tokyo", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2437", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Undiagnosed duck die-off - Cyprus: botulism susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2437", "date": "2006-07-21 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, SMOKED FISH - FINLAND EX CANADA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 20 July 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060720.asp#3>\n\nOn 29 Jun 2006, a 65-year-old woman fell ill with vomiting and\ndiarrhea in southern Finland. The next day she developed muscular\nweakness of her upper and lower limbs, and was admitted to hospital.\nShe developed difficulty in breathing and required mechanical\nventilation in an intensive care unit for a week.\nThe patient is now recovering, but still has some difficulties in\nswallowing, and is not yet able to walk. The patient did not receive\nbotulinum antitoxin, since the symptoms had already begun to resolve\nupon diagnosis. The patient's husband also had diarrhea on 29 Jun\n2006 and later had some difficulties in swallowing, but no other\nneurological symptoms were observed. He was admitted to hospital for\none night (1-2 Jul 2006) because of diarrhea.\nSerum samples from the female patient taken on 30 Jun and 1 Jul 2006\nwere positive for botulinum neurotoxin by mouse bioassay, and the\nneutralization test suggested that the patient's illness was caused\nby botulinum toxin type E. Gastric fluid and serum samples taken on 4\nJul 2006 did not yield neurotoxin or _Clostridium botulinum_. No\nspecimens were available from the husband, as botulism was not\ndiagnosed during his hospital stay, and he was not called back to\nhospital for specimens.\nAn interview with the husband revealed that the couple had eaten\nsmoked vacuum-packed whitefish on 28 Jun 2006. The wife had eaten\nmost of the fish, and the husband ate only a small portion. The\nwhitefish had been imported from Canada, but smoked and packed in\nFinland. There was no leftover fish for microbiological examination.\nFlush samples were taken from the fish's plastic packaging, but they\nwere negative for _C. botulinum_ by PCR (1) and culture.\nThe suspected fish product was recalled by the manufacturer, and\nproduction of the product was suspended. The national and local food\ncontrol authorities inspected the production plant and the\ndistribution center. The entire manufacturing process and storage\ntemperatures throughout the cold chain, including the retail outlet,\nwere investigated. The inspections did not reveal any factors that\ncould have created an increased risk of botulinum neurotoxin\nproduction. Microbiological analysis of 10 vacuum-packed fish made\nfrom the same raw fish batch that was used to make the product eaten\nby the patient, and from fish from earlier and later batches, were\nall negative for _C. botulinum_.\nThe investigators have therefore hypothesized that there may have\nbeen storage temperature abuse at a later stage, such as in the\nretail outlet or the home. After inspection of the facility and\nmicrobiological examination of fish samples, production of the\nproduct has started again.\n_C. botulinum_ type E is naturally highly prevalent in aquatic\nenvironments and fish (2,3), leading to a high risk of contamination.\nThe hot-smoking processes are usually too low to eliminate botulinum\nspores (4). Growth and toxin production from spores in vacuum-packed\nsmoked fish products with anaerobic atmosphere and limited\npreservative factors is likely during extended storage at\ntemperatures above 3 degrees C. Therefore the most important factors\ncontrolling _C. botulinum_ growth and toxin production are efficient\nheat treatments, restricted shelf life and continuous storage below 3\ndegrees C.\nHuman botulism is a very rare disease; the most recent case to be\nreported in Finland before the one mentioned here occurred in 1999\n(5). A similar outbreak that affected 2 people in Germany in 1997 is\ndescribed in the literature (1). However, it is of utmost importance\nthat physicians remain aware of the disease as a possible diagnosis.\nBotulism should be considered whenever a patient develops\nneurological symptoms that include blurred vision, difficulties in\nswallowing or speech and symptoms of descending flaccid paralysis.\nThis should be followed by appropriate epidemiological and laboratory\nanalyses to confirm the diagnosis and to improve the epidemiological\nunderstanding of the disease (6).\n1. Korkeala H, Stengel G, Hyytia E, et al: Type E botulism associated\nwith vacuum-packaged hot-smoked whitefish. Int J Food Microbiol\n1998;43: 1-5.\n2. Hielm S, Bjorkroth J, Hyytia E, Korkeala H: Prevalence of\nClostridium botulinum in Finnish trout farms: pulsed-field gel\nelectrophoresis typing reveals extensive genetic diversity among type\nE isolates. Appl Environ Microbiol 1998;64: 4161-4167.\n3. Hyytia E, Hielm S, Korkeala H. Prevalence of Clostridium botulinum\ntype E in Finnish fish and fishery products. Epidemiol Infect 1998;\n120: 245-50.\n4. Lindstrom M, Nevas M, Hielm S, et al: Thermal inactivation of\nnonproteolytic Clostridium botulinum type E spores in model fish\nmedia and in vacuum-packaged hot-smoked fish products. Appl Environ\nMicrobiol 2003;6: 4029-36.\n5. Lindstrom M, Hielm S, Nevas M, et al: Proteolytic Clostridium\nbotulinum type B in the gastric content of a patient with type E\nbotulism due to whitefish eggs. Foodborne Pathog Dis 2004;1: 53-57.\n6. Lindstrom M, Korkeala H: Laboratory diagnostics of botulism. Clin\nMicrobiol Rev 2006;19: 298-314.\n[Written by: Lindstrom M, Vuorela M, Hinderink K, et al\n<markku.kuusi@ktl.fi>]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report points out that storage temperature issues may also\ncontribute to botulism.\nProdromal symptoms of food-borne botulism often include nausea,\nvomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, which are absent from cases\nof wound botulism. It is not clear that these symptoms are related\nto botulism per se or other contaminants of the ingested food. A USA\npaper (1) reported vomiting in 59 percent of foodborne cases and\ndiarrhea in 19 percent; and one from the Republic of Georgia (2)\nreported vomiting in 56 percent and diarrhea in 25 percent.\n1. Hughes JM, Blumenthal JR, Merson MH, et al: Clinical features of\ntypes A and B food-borne botulism. Ann Intern Med 1981;95: 442-45.\n2. Varma JK, Katsitadze G, Moiscrafishvili M, et al: Signs and\nsymptoms predictive of death in patients with foodborne botulism -\nRepublic of Georgia, 1980-2002. Clin Infect Dis 2004;39: 357-62. -\nMod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, deer meat - Thailand (Phayao) 20060711.1901\nBotulism, bamboo shoots - Thailand (Nan)(03) 20060416.1131\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\nBotulism, human, bamboo shoots - Thailand (Nan) 20060320.0865\nBotulism - Armenia (Erevan) 20060216.0505\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya) 20051017.3029\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20051014.2998\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex. Georgia (02): susp. 20050426.1159\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex Georgia: susp 20050420.1108\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism during pregnancy - Kyrgyzstan (Chuysk) 20050218.0538\nBotulism, bamboo shoots - Canada (AB, BC): recall 20050110.0083\n2004\n----\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Kharkov) 20041030.2930\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (03) 20040908.2508\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20040817.2278\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n2000\n----\nBotulism, foodborne - Russia 1999 20000229.0277\n1999\n----\nBotulism, human - Russia (Burjatija) 19990907.1576\n1998\n----\nBotulism, human - Japan (Tokyo) 19980816.1632\n............................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Armenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tokyo", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2361", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, mushrooms - Russia (Tambov)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2361", "date": "2006-07-21 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, SMOKED FISH - FINLAND EX CANADA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 20 July 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060720.asp#3>\n\nOn 29 Jun 2006, a 65-year-old woman fell ill with vomiting and\ndiarrhea in southern Finland. The next day she developed muscular\nweakness of her upper and lower limbs, and was admitted to hospital.\nShe developed difficulty in breathing and required mechanical\nventilation in an intensive care unit for a week.\nThe patient is now recovering, but still has some difficulties in\nswallowing, and is not yet able to walk. The patient did not receive\nbotulinum antitoxin, since the symptoms had already begun to resolve\nupon diagnosis. No\nspecimens were available from the husband, as botulism was not\ndiagnosed during his hospital stay, and he was not called back to\nhospital for specimens.\nAn interview with the husband revealed that the couple had eaten\nsmoked vacuum-packed whitefish on 28 Jun 2006. The inspections did not reveal any factors that\ncould have created an increased risk of botulinum neurotoxin\nproduction. After inspection of the facility and\nmicrobiological examination of fish samples, production of the\nproduct has started again.\n_C. botulinum_ type E is naturally highly prevalent in aquatic\nenvironments and fish (2,3), leading to a high risk of contamination.\nThe hot-smoking processes are usually too low to eliminate botulinum\nspores (4). Growth and toxin production from spores in vacuum-packed\nsmoked fish products with anaerobic atmosphere and limited\npreservative factors is likely during extended storage at\ntemperatures above 3 degrees C. Therefore the most important factors\ncontrolling _C. botulinum_ growth and toxin production are efficient\nheat treatments, restricted shelf life and continuous storage below 3\ndegrees C.\nHuman botulism is a very rare disease; the most recent case to be\nreported in Finland before the one mentioned here occurred in 1999\n(5). A similar outbreak that affected 2 people in Germany in 1997 is\ndescribed in the literature (1). However, it is of utmost importance\nthat physicians remain aware of the disease as a possible diagnosis.\nBotulism should be considered whenever a patient develops\nneurological symptoms that include blurred vision, difficulties in\nswallowing or speech and symptoms of descending flaccid paralysis.\nThis should be followed by appropriate epidemiological and laboratory\nanalyses to confirm the diagnosis and to improve the epidemiological\nunderstanding of the disease (6).\n1. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-07-20 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-06-28 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-05 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bjorkroth J", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Environ", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "Finland"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "the Republic of Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Botulism - Armenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tokyo", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2027", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2027", "date": "2006-07-21 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, SMOKED FISH - FINLAND EX CANADA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 20 July 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060720.asp#3>\n\nOn 29 Jun 2006, a 65-year-old woman fell ill with vomiting and\ndiarrhea in southern Finland. The next day she developed muscular\nweakness of her upper and lower limbs, and was admitted to hospital.\nShe developed difficulty in breathing and required mechanical\nventilation in an intensive care unit for a week.\nThe patient is now recovering, but still has some difficulties in\nswallowing, and is not yet able to walk. The patient did not receive\nbotulinum antitoxin, since the symptoms had already begun to resolve\nupon diagnosis. The patient's husband also had diarrhea on 29 Jun\n2006 and later had some difficulties in swallowing, but no other\nneurological symptoms were observed. He was admitted to hospital for\none night (1-2 Jul 2006) because of diarrhea.\nSerum samples from the female patient taken on 30 Jun and 1 Jul 2006\nwere positive for botulinum neurotoxin by mouse bioassay, and the\nneutralization test suggested that the patient's illness was caused\nby botulinum toxin type E. Gastric fluid and serum samples taken on 4\nJul 2006 did not yield neurotoxin or _Clostridium botulinum_. No\nspecimens were available from the husband, as botulism was not\ndiagnosed during his hospital stay, and he was not called back to\nhospital for specimens.\nAn interview with the husband revealed that the couple had eaten\nsmoked vacuum-packed whitefish on 28 Jun 2006. The wife had eaten\nmost of the fish, and the husband ate only a small portion. The\nwhitefish had been imported from Canada, but smoked and packed in\nFinland. There was no leftover fish for microbiological examination.\nFlush samples were taken from the fish's plastic packaging, but they\nwere negative for _C. botulinum_ by PCR (1) and culture.\nThe suspected fish product was recalled by the manufacturer, and\nproduction of the product was suspended. The national and local food\ncontrol authorities inspected the production plant and the\ndistribution center. The entire manufacturing process and storage\ntemperatures throughout the cold chain, including the retail outlet,\nwere investigated. The inspections did not reveal any factors that\ncould have created an increased risk of botulinum neurotoxin\nproduction. Microbiological analysis of 10 vacuum-packed fish made\nfrom the same raw fish batch that was used to make the product eaten\nby the patient, and from fish from earlier and later batches, were\nall negative for _C. botulinum_.\nThe investigators have therefore hypothesized that there may have\nbeen storage temperature abuse at a later stage, such as in the\nretail outlet or the home. After inspection of the facility and\nmicrobiological examination of fish samples, production of the\nproduct has started again.\n_C. botulinum_ type E is naturally highly prevalent in aquatic\nenvironments and fish (2,3), leading to a high risk of contamination.\nThe hot-smoking processes are usually too low to eliminate botulinum\nspores (4). Growth and toxin production from spores in vacuum-packed\nsmoked fish products with anaerobic atmosphere and limited\npreservative factors is likely during extended storage at\ntemperatures above 3 degrees C. Therefore the most important factors\ncontrolling _C. botulinum_ growth and toxin production are efficient\nheat treatments, restricted shelf life and continuous storage below 3\ndegrees C.\nHuman botulism is a very rare disease; the most recent case to be\nreported in Finland before the one mentioned here occurred in 1999\n(5). A similar outbreak that affected 2 people in Germany in 1997 is\ndescribed in the literature (1). However, it is of utmost importance\nthat physicians remain aware of the disease as a possible diagnosis.\nBotulism should be considered whenever a patient develops\nneurological symptoms that include blurred vision, difficulties in\nswallowing or speech and symptoms of descending flaccid paralysis.\nThis should be followed by appropriate epidemiological and laboratory\nanalyses to confirm the diagnosis and to improve the epidemiological\nunderstanding of the disease (6).\n1. Korkeala H, Stengel G, Hyytia E, et al: Type E botulism associated\nwith vacuum-packaged hot-smoked whitefish. Int J Food Microbiol\n1998;43: 1-5.\n2. Hielm S, Bjorkroth J, Hyytia E, Korkeala H: Prevalence of\nClostridium botulinum in Finnish trout farms: pulsed-field gel\nelectrophoresis typing reveals extensive genetic diversity among type\nE isolates. Appl Environ Microbiol 1998;64: 4161-4167.\n3. Hyytia E, Hielm S, Korkeala H. Prevalence of Clostridium botulinum\ntype E in Finnish fish and fishery products. Epidemiol Infect 1998;\n120: 245-50.\n4. Lindstrom M, Nevas M, Hielm S, et al: Thermal inactivation of\nnonproteolytic Clostridium botulinum type E spores in model fish\nmedia and in vacuum-packaged hot-smoked fish products. Appl Environ\nMicrobiol 2003;6: 4029-36.\n5. Lindstrom M, Hielm S, Nevas M, et al: Proteolytic Clostridium\nbotulinum type B in the gastric content of a patient with type E\nbotulism due to whitefish eggs. Foodborne Pathog Dis 2004;1: 53-57.\n6. Lindstrom M, Korkeala H: Laboratory diagnostics of botulism. Clin\nMicrobiol Rev 2006;19: 298-314.\n[Written by: Lindstrom M, Vuorela M, Hinderink K, et al\n<markku.kuusi@ktl.fi>]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report points out that storage temperature issues may also\ncontribute to botulism.\nProdromal symptoms of food-borne botulism often include nausea,\nvomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, which are absent from cases\nof wound botulism. It is not clear that these symptoms are related\nto botulism per se or other contaminants of the ingested food. A USA\npaper (1) reported vomiting in 59 percent of foodborne cases and\ndiarrhea in 19 percent; and one from the Republic of Georgia (2)\nreported vomiting in 56 percent and diarrhea in 25 percent.\n1. Hughes JM, Blumenthal JR, Merson MH, et al: Clinical features of\ntypes A and B food-borne botulism. Ann Intern Med 1981;95: 442-45.\n2. Varma JK, Katsitadze G, Moiscrafishvili M, et al: Signs and\nsymptoms predictive of death in patients with foodborne botulism -\nRepublic of Georgia, 1980-2002. Clin Infect Dis 2004;39: 357-62. -\nMod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, deer meat - Thailand (Phayao) 20060711.1901\nBotulism, bamboo shoots - Thailand (Nan)(03) 20060416.1131\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\nBotulism, human, bamboo shoots - Thailand (Nan) 20060320.0865\nBotulism - Armenia (Erevan) 20060216.0505\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya) 20051017.3029\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20051014.2998\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex. Georgia (02): susp. 20050426.1159\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex Georgia: susp 20050420.1108\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism during pregnancy - Kyrgyzstan (Chuysk) 20050218.0538\nBotulism, bamboo shoots - Canada (AB, BC): recall 20050110.0083\n2004\n----\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Kharkov) 20041030.2930\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (03) 20040908.2508\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20040817.2278\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n2000\n----\nBotulism, foodborne - Russia 1999 20000229.0277\n1999\n----\nBotulism, human - Russia (Burjatija) 19990907.1576\n1998\n----\nBotulism, human - Japan (Tokyo) 19980816.1632\n............................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-07-20 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-06-28 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-05 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bjorkroth J", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Environ", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "Finland"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "the Republic of Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Botulism - Armenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tokyo", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1985", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, smoked fish - Finland ex Canada", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1985", "date": "2006-07-21 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, SMOKED FISH - FINLAND EX CANADA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 20 July 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060720.asp#3>\n\nOn 29 Jun 2006, a 65-year-old woman fell ill with vomiting and\ndiarrhea in southern Finland. The next day she developed muscular\nweakness of her upper and lower limbs, and was admitted to hospital.\nShe developed difficulty in breathing and required mechanical\nventilation in an intensive care unit for a week.\nThe patient is now recovering, but still has some difficulties in\nswallowing, and is not yet able to walk. The patient did not receive\nbotulinum antitoxin, since the symptoms had already begun to resolve\nupon diagnosis. The patient's husband also had diarrhea on 29 Jun\n2006 and later had some difficulties in swallowing, but no other\nneurological symptoms were observed. He was admitted to hospital for\none night (1-2 Jul 2006) because of diarrhea.\nSerum samples from the female patient taken on 30 Jun and 1 Jul 2006\nwere positive for botulinum neurotoxin by mouse bioassay, and the\nneutralization test suggested that the patient's illness was caused\nby botulinum toxin type E. Gastric fluid and serum samples taken on 4\nJul 2006 did not yield neurotoxin or _Clostridium botulinum_. No\nspecimens were available from the husband, as botulism was not\ndiagnosed during his hospital stay, and he was not called back to\nhospital for specimens.\nAn interview with the husband revealed that the couple had eaten\nsmoked vacuum-packed whitefish on 28 Jun 2006. The wife had eaten\nmost of the fish, and the husband ate only a small portion. The\nwhitefish had been imported from Canada, but smoked and packed in\nFinland. There was no leftover fish for microbiological examination.\nFlush samples were taken from the fish's plastic packaging, but they\nwere negative for _C. botulinum_ by PCR (1) and culture.\nThe suspected fish product was recalled by the manufacturer, and\nproduction of the product was suspended. The national and local food\ncontrol authorities inspected the production plant and the\ndistribution center. The entire manufacturing process and storage\ntemperatures throughout the cold chain, including the retail outlet,\nwere investigated. The inspections did not reveal any factors that\ncould have created an increased risk of botulinum neurotoxin\nproduction. Microbiological analysis of 10 vacuum-packed fish made\nfrom the same raw fish batch that was used to make the product eaten\nby the patient, and from fish from earlier and later batches, were\nall negative for _C. botulinum_.\nThe investigators have therefore hypothesized that there may have\nbeen storage temperature abuse at a later stage, such as in the\nretail outlet or the home. After inspection of the facility and\nmicrobiological examination of fish samples, production of the\nproduct has started again.\n_C. botulinum_ type E is naturally highly prevalent in aquatic\nenvironments and fish (2,3), leading to a high risk of contamination.\nThe hot-smoking processes are usually too low to eliminate botulinum\nspores (4). Growth and toxin production from spores in vacuum-packed\nsmoked fish products with anaerobic atmosphere and limited\npreservative factors is likely during extended storage at\ntemperatures above 3 degrees C. Therefore the most important factors\ncontrolling _C. botulinum_ growth and toxin production are efficient\nheat treatments, restricted shelf life and continuous storage below 3\ndegrees C.\nHuman botulism is a very rare disease; the most recent case to be\nreported in Finland before the one mentioned here occurred in 1999\n(5). A similar outbreak that affected 2 people in Germany in 1997 is\ndescribed in the literature (1). However, it is of utmost importance\nthat physicians remain aware of the disease as a possible diagnosis.\nBotulism should be considered whenever a patient develops\nneurological symptoms that include blurred vision, difficulties in\nswallowing or speech and symptoms of descending flaccid paralysis.\nThis should be followed by appropriate epidemiological and laboratory\nanalyses to confirm the diagnosis and to improve the epidemiological\nunderstanding of the disease (6).\n1. Korkeala H, Stengel G, Hyytia E, et al: Type E botulism associated\nwith vacuum-packaged hot-smoked whitefish. Int J Food Microbiol\n1998;43: 1-5.\n2. Hielm S, Bjorkroth J, Hyytia E, Korkeala H: Prevalence of\nClostridium botulinum in Finnish trout farms: pulsed-field gel\nelectrophoresis typing reveals extensive genetic diversity among type\nE isolates. Appl Environ Microbiol 1998;64: 4161-4167.\n3. Hyytia E, Hielm S, Korkeala H. Prevalence of Clostridium botulinum\ntype E in Finnish fish and fishery products. Epidemiol Infect 1998;\n120: 245-50.\n4. Lindstrom M, Nevas M, Hielm S, et al: Thermal inactivation of\nnonproteolytic Clostridium botulinum type E spores in model fish\nmedia and in vacuum-packaged hot-smoked fish products. Appl Environ\nMicrobiol 2003;6: 4029-36.\n5. Lindstrom M, Hielm S, Nevas M, et al: Proteolytic Clostridium\nbotulinum type B in the gastric content of a patient with type E\nbotulism due to whitefish eggs. Foodborne Pathog Dis 2004;1: 53-57.\n6. Lindstrom M, Korkeala H: Laboratory diagnostics of botulism. Clin\nMicrobiol Rev 2006;19: 298-314.\n[Written by: Lindstrom M, Vuorela M, Hinderink K, et al\n<markku.kuusi@ktl.fi>]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report points out that storage temperature issues may also\ncontribute to botulism.\nProdromal symptoms of food-borne botulism often include nausea,\nvomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, which are absent from cases\nof wound botulism. It is not clear that these symptoms are related\nto botulism per se or other contaminants of the ingested food. A USA\npaper (1) reported vomiting in 59 percent of foodborne cases and\ndiarrhea in 19 percent; and one from the Republic of Georgia (2)\nreported vomiting in 56 percent and diarrhea in 25 percent.\n1. Hughes JM, Blumenthal JR, Merson MH, et al: Clinical features of\ntypes A and B food-borne botulism. Ann Intern Med 1981;95: 442-45.\n2. Varma JK, Katsitadze G, Moiscrafishvili M, et al: Signs and\nsymptoms predictive of death in patients with foodborne botulism -\nRepublic of Georgia, 1980-2002. Clin Infect Dis 2004;39: 357-62. -\nMod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, deer meat - Thailand (Phayao) 20060711.1901\nBotulism, bamboo shoots - Thailand (Nan)(03) 20060416.1131\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\nBotulism, human, bamboo shoots - Thailand (Nan) 20060320.0865\nBotulism - Armenia (Erevan) 20060216.0505\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya) 20051017.3029\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20051014.2998\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex. Georgia (02): susp. 20050426.1159\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex Georgia: susp 20050420.1108\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism during pregnancy - Kyrgyzstan (Chuysk) 20050218.0538\nBotulism, bamboo shoots - Canada (AB, BC): recall 20050110.0083\n2004\n----\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Kharkov) 20041030.2930\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (03) 20040908.2508\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20040817.2278\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n2000\n----\nBotulism, foodborne - Russia 1999 20000229.0277\n1999\n----\nBotulism, human - Russia (Burjatija) 19990907.1576\n1998\n----\nBotulism, human - Japan (Tokyo) 19980816.1632\n............................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-07-20 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-06-28 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-05 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bjorkroth J", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Environ", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "Finland"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "the Republic of Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Botulism - Armenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tokyo", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1926", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, deer meat - Thailand (Phayao)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1926", "date": "2006-07-21 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, SMOKED FISH - FINLAND EX CANADA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 20 July 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060720.asp#3>\n\nOn 29 Jun 2006, a 65-year-old woman fell ill with vomiting and\ndiarrhea in southern Finland. The next day she developed muscular\nweakness of her upper and lower limbs, and was admitted to hospital.\nShe developed difficulty in breathing and required mechanical\nventilation in an intensive care unit for a week.\nThe patient is now recovering, but still has some difficulties in\nswallowing, and is not yet able to walk. The patient did not receive\nbotulinum antitoxin, since the symptoms had already begun to resolve\nupon diagnosis. The patient's husband also had diarrhea on 29 Jun\n2006 and later had some difficulties in swallowing, but no other\nneurological symptoms were observed. He was admitted to hospital for\none night (1-2 Jul 2006) because of diarrhea.\nSerum samples from the female patient taken on 30 Jun and 1 Jul 2006\nwere positive for botulinum neurotoxin by mouse bioassay, and the\nneutralization test suggested that the patient's illness was caused\nby botulinum toxin type E. Gastric fluid and serum samples taken on 4\nJul 2006 did not yield neurotoxin or _Clostridium botulinum_. No\nspecimens were available from the husband, as botulism was not\ndiagnosed during his hospital stay, and he was not called back to\nhospital for specimens.\nAn interview with the husband revealed that the couple had eaten\nsmoked vacuum-packed whitefish on 28 Jun 2006. The wife had eaten\nmost of the fish, and the husband ate only a small portion. The\nwhitefish had been imported from Canada, but smoked and packed in\nFinland. There was no leftover fish for microbiological examination.\nFlush samples were taken from the fish's plastic packaging, but they\nwere negative for _C. botulinum_ by PCR (1) and culture.\nThe suspected fish product was recalled by the manufacturer, and\nproduction of the product was suspended. The national and local food\ncontrol authorities inspected the production plant and the\ndistribution center. The entire manufacturing process and storage\ntemperatures throughout the cold chain, including the retail outlet,\nwere investigated. The inspections did not reveal any factors that\ncould have created an increased risk of botulinum neurotoxin\nproduction. Microbiological analysis of 10 vacuum-packed fish made\nfrom the same raw fish batch that was used to make the product eaten\nby the patient, and from fish from earlier and later batches, were\nall negative for _C. botulinum_.\nThe investigators have therefore hypothesized that there may have\nbeen storage temperature abuse at a later stage, such as in the\nretail outlet or the home. After inspection of the facility and\nmicrobiological examination of fish samples, production of the\nproduct has started again.\n_C. botulinum_ type E is naturally highly prevalent in aquatic\nenvironments and fish (2,3), leading to a high risk of contamination.\nThe hot-smoking processes are usually too low to eliminate botulinum\nspores (4). Growth and toxin production from spores in vacuum-packed\nsmoked fish products with anaerobic atmosphere and limited\npreservative factors is likely during extended storage at\ntemperatures above 3 degrees C. Therefore the most important factors\ncontrolling _C. botulinum_ growth and toxin production are efficient\nheat treatments, restricted shelf life and continuous storage below 3\ndegrees C.\nHuman botulism is a very rare disease; the most recent case to be\nreported in Finland before the one mentioned here occurred in 1999\n(5). A similar outbreak that affected 2 people in Germany in 1997 is\ndescribed in the literature (1). However, it is of utmost importance\nthat physicians remain aware of the disease as a possible diagnosis.\nBotulism should be considered whenever a patient develops\nneurological symptoms that include blurred vision, difficulties in\nswallowing or speech and symptoms of descending flaccid paralysis.\nThis should be followed by appropriate epidemiological and laboratory\nanalyses to confirm the diagnosis and to improve the epidemiological\nunderstanding of the disease (6).\n1. Korkeala H, Stengel G, Hyytia E, et al: Type E botulism associated\nwith vacuum-packaged hot-smoked whitefish. Int J Food Microbiol\n1998;43: 1-5.\n2. Hielm S, Bjorkroth J, Hyytia E, Korkeala H: Prevalence of\nClostridium botulinum in Finnish trout farms: pulsed-field gel\nelectrophoresis typing reveals extensive genetic diversity among type\nE isolates. Appl Environ Microbiol 1998;64: 4161-4167.\n3. Hyytia E, Hielm S, Korkeala H. Prevalence of Clostridium botulinum\ntype E in Finnish fish and fishery products. Epidemiol Infect 1998;\n120: 245-50.\n4. Lindstrom M, Nevas M, Hielm S, et al: Thermal inactivation of\nnonproteolytic Clostridium botulinum type E spores in model fish\nmedia and in vacuum-packaged hot-smoked fish products. Appl Environ\nMicrobiol 2003;6: 4029-36.\n5. Lindstrom M, Hielm S, Nevas M, et al: Proteolytic Clostridium\nbotulinum type B in the gastric content of a patient with type E\nbotulism due to whitefish eggs. Foodborne Pathog Dis 2004;1: 53-57.\n6. Lindstrom M, Korkeala H: Laboratory diagnostics of botulism. Clin\nMicrobiol Rev 2006;19: 298-314.\n[Written by: Lindstrom M, Vuorela M, Hinderink K, et al\n<markku.kuusi@ktl.fi>]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report points out that storage temperature issues may also\ncontribute to botulism.\nProdromal symptoms of food-borne botulism often include nausea,\nvomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, which are absent from cases\nof wound botulism. It is not clear that these symptoms are related\nto botulism per se or other contaminants of the ingested food. A USA\npaper (1) reported vomiting in 59 percent of foodborne cases and\ndiarrhea in 19 percent; and one from the Republic of Georgia (2)\nreported vomiting in 56 percent and diarrhea in 25 percent.\n1. Hughes JM, Blumenthal JR, Merson MH, et al: Clinical features of\ntypes A and B food-borne botulism. Ann Intern Med 1981;95: 442-45.\n2. Varma JK, Katsitadze G, Moiscrafishvili M, et al: Signs and\nsymptoms predictive of death in patients with foodborne botulism -\nRepublic of Georgia, 1980-2002. Clin Infect Dis 2004;39: 357-62. -\nMod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, deer meat - Thailand (Phayao) 20060711.1901\nBotulism, bamboo shoots - Thailand (Nan)(03) 20060416.1131\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) (02) 20060410.1067\nBotulinum toxin, laboratory exposure - USA (MA) 20060408.1058\nBotulism, human, bamboo shoots - Thailand (Nan) 20060320.0865\nBotulism - Armenia (Erevan) 20060216.0505\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya) 20051017.3029\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20051014.2998\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex. Georgia (02): susp. 20050426.1159\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex Georgia: susp 20050420.1108\nBotulism, canned cucumbers - Russia (Samara) 20050228.0622\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Rostov) 20050118.0167\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Zaporozhye) 20050220.0557\nBotulism during pregnancy - Kyrgyzstan (Chuysk) 20050218.0538\nBotulism, bamboo shoots - Canada (AB, BC): recall 20050110.0083\n2004\n----\nBotulism, dried fish - Ukraine (Kharkov) 20041030.2930\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (03) 20040908.2508\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20040817.2278\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n2000\n----\nBotulism, foodborne - Russia 1999 20000229.0277\n1999\n----\nBotulism, human - Russia (Burjatija) 19990907.1576\n1998\n----\nBotulism, human - Japan (Tokyo) 19980816.1632\n............................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
