For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-07-20 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-06-28 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-01-05 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bjorkroth J", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Environ", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "Finland"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "the Republic of Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Botulism - Armenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tokyo", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1855", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism, bovine - Australia (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1855", "date": "2006-07-21 00:00:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, SMOKED FISH - FINLAND EX CANADA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 20 July 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060720.asp#3>\n\nOn 29 Jun 2006, a 65-year-old woman fell ill with vomiting and\ndiarrhea in southern Finland. The next day she developed muscular\nweakness of her upper and lower limbs, and was admitted to hospital.\nShe developed difficulty in breathing and required mechanical\nventilation in an intensive care unit for a week.\nThe patient is now recovering, but still has some difficulties in\nswallowing, and is not yet able to walk. The patient did not receive\nbotulinum antitoxin, since the symptoms had already begun to resolve\nupon diagnosis. The patient's husband also had diarrhea on 29 Jun\n2006 and later had some difficulties in swallowing, but no other\nneurological symptoms were observed. He was admitted to hospital for\none night (1-2 Jul 2006) because of diarrhea.\nSerum samples from the female patient taken on 30 Jun and 1 Jul 2006\nwere positive for botulinum neurotoxin by mouse bioassay, and the\nneutralization test suggested that the patient's illness was caused\nby botulinum toxin type E. Gastric fluid and serum samples taken on 4\nJul 2006 did not yield neurotoxin or _Clostridium botulinum_. No\nspecimens were available from the husband, as botulism was not\ndiagnosed during his hospital stay, and he was not called back to\nhospital for specimens.\nAn interview with the husband revealed that the couple had eaten\nsmoked vacuum-packed whitefish on 28 Jun 2006. The wife had eaten\nmost of the fish, and the husband ate only a small portion. The\nwhitefish had been imported from Canada, but smoked and packed in\nFinland. There was no leftover fish for microbiological examination.\nFlush samples were taken from the fish's plastic packaging, but they\nwere negative for _C. botulinum_ by PCR (1) and culture.\nThe suspected fish product was recalled by the manufacturer, and\nproduction of the product was suspended. The national and local food\ncontrol authorities inspected the production plant and the\ndistribution center. The entire manufacturing process and storage\ntemperatures throughout the cold chain, including the retail outlet,\nwere investigated. The inspections did not reveal any factors that\ncould have created an increased risk of botulinum neurotoxin\nproduction. Microbiological analysis of 10 vacuum-packed fish made\nfrom the same raw fish batch that was used to make the product eaten\nby the patient, and from fish from earlier and later batches, were\nall negative for _C. botulinum_.\nThe investigators have therefore hypothesized that there may have\nbeen storage temperature abuse at a later stage, such as in the\nretail outlet or the home. After inspection of the facility and\nmicrobiological examination of fish samples, production of the\nproduct has started again.\n_C. botulinum_ type E is naturally highly prevalent in aquatic\nenvironments and fish (2,3), leading to a high risk of contamination.\nThe hot-smoking processes are usually too low to eliminate botulinum\nspores (4). Growth and toxin production from spores in vacuum-packed\nsmoked fish products with anaerobic atmosphere and limited\npreservative factors is likely during extended storage at\ntemperatures above 3 degrees C. Therefore the most important factors\ncontrolling _C. botulinum_ growth and toxin production are efficient\nheat treatments, restricted shelf life and continuous storage below 3\ndegrees C.\nHuman botulism is a very rare disease; the most recent case to be\nreported in Finland before the one mentioned here occurred in 1999\n(5). A similar outbreak that affected 2 people in Germany in 1997 is\ndescribed in the literature (1). However, it is of utmost importance\nthat physicians remain aware of the disease as a possible diagnosis.\nBotulism should be considered whenever a patient develops\nneurological symptoms that include blurred vision, difficulties in\nswallowing or speech and symptoms of descending flaccid paralysis.\nThis should be followed by appropriate epidemiological and laboratory\nanalyses to confirm the diagnosis and to improve the epidemiological\nunderstanding of the disease (6).\n1. Korkeala H, Stengel G, Hyytia E, et al: Type E botulism associated\nwith vacuum-packaged hot-smoked whitefish. Int J Food Microbiol\n1998;43: 1-5.\n2. USA (WA): botulism susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1787", "date": "2006-02-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM - ARMENIA (EREVAN)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 13 Feb 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail Russian Correspondent <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Information agency ARMINFO [translated by Mod.NR, edited]\n<http://www.arminfo.am/news_ru_130206_5.shtml>\n\n4 people in Armenia affected by botulism\n----------------------------------------\nA family of 4 people were poisoned with botulism. According to a\ncorrespondent from the Rescue Service of Armenia, on Fri 10 Feb 2006\ninhabitants of Chiva village were admitted to the Yehegnadzor\ncity hospital. The ages of the family members were 34, 29, 19, and 13.\nAll of them were hospitalized in the Erevan medical center in\nArmenia. Physicians say that their condition is moderately severe.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[No information is given regarding the food source of the botulism, which is\nusually improperly canned food or dried or smoked fish -- see archives below.\nThere is a map at <http://francarmenie.free.fr/Pays/map.gif>\n- Mods.LL/JW]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nBotulism, canned food - Kyrgyzstan (Osh region) 20051219.3635\nBotulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya) 20051017.3029\nBotulism, salted fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20051014.2998\nBotulism, canned food - Russia (Rostov) 20050712.1980\nBotulism - Russia (Komi) 20050705.1897\nAdult colonization botulism - Czech Rep. ex. The ages of the family members were 34, 29, 19, and 13.\nAll of them were hospitalized in the Erevan medical center in\nArmenia. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-02-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Armenia", "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "Komi", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "chiva", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209059", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, wound, drug-related - Germany (NRW)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209059", "date": "2005-12-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - GERMANY (NORDRHEIN-WESTFALEN)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nVirology\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xr4zp>\nDate: Thu 15 Dec 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2005/051215.asp#4>\n\nOutbreak of wound botulism in injecting drug users in Germany, October -\nDecember 2005\n-----------------------------------------------\nA cluster of 14 cases of wound botulism (including 6 laboratory-confirmed\ncases) in injecting drug users has been reported from the federal state of\nNordrhein-Westfalen in the west of Germany. The 1st cases were reported in\nNovember 2005.\nThe earliest disease onset date recorded so far is 14 Oct 2005, and the\nlatest is 5 Dec 2005. To date, it remains unclear whether or not the\noutbreak has ended. A common source of infection has not yet been\nidentified, but it is suspected that the vehicle of infection is\ncontaminated heroin. Nearly all patients that investigators have so far\nbeen able to question have reported subcutaneous (\"skin popping\") or\nintramuscular (\"muscle popping\") injection of the drug, and presented with\nwound infections.\nThe Robert Koch-Institut (RKI) issued alerts through the European Early\nWarning System (EWRS) and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug\nAddiction (EMCDDA) on 14 Nov 2005. 2 notices on the outbreak have been\npublished in the national epidemiological bulletin [1,2].\nIf the vehicle of infection is contaminated heroin, it is possible that\nsimilar cases may be occurring elsewhere in Europe, and Dr. Katharina\nAlpers <AlpersK@rki.de> at RKI would be grateful to receive any related\ninformation.\n1. Zu einer Haufung von Wundbotulismus in Nordrhein-Westfalen.\nEpidemiologisches Bulletin 2005; (45): 420.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/45_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/45_05>\n2. Update zu einer Haufung von Wundbotulismus bei injizierenden\nDrogenkonsumenten in Nordrhein-Westfalen. Epidemiologisches Bulletin 2005;\n(48): 453.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/48_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/48_05>\n[Byline: Alpers A <AlpersK@rki.de>, van Treeck U, Frank C]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a wound,\ngerminate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the wound\nbotulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs). Those IDUs who\nintentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or intramuscularly may\nbe particularly vulnerable to infection.\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a febrile,\ndescending, flaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing\nthe severity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early in\nthe course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results of\nmicrobiological testing.\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical debridement\nare necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse after antitoxin\ntreatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl penicillin and metronidazole.\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of both\nfoodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by toxin\ntype A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis and a\nhigher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation. All toxin\ntypes exert their action on the cholinergic system at the presynapic\nmotor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine transmission across the\nneuromuscular junction. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, Drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\n2000\n----\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK (07) 20000820.1388\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: diagnosis 20000615.0977\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK 20000608.0922\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland & Scotland 20000531.0874\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland (Dublin) 20000525.0825\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) (09) 20000522.0807\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) 20000511.0717\n........................................ll/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-15 00:00:00", "2005-12-15 00:00:00", "2005-11-15 00:00:00", "2005-10-14 00:00:00", "2005-12-05 00:00:00", "2005-11-14 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "- Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209058", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, canned food - Nearly all patients that investigators have so far\nbeen able to question have reported subcutaneous (\"skin popping\") or\nintramuscular (\"muscle popping\") injection of the drug, and presented with\nwound infections.\nThe Robert Koch-Institut (RKI) issued alerts through the European Early\nWarning System (EWRS) and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug\nAddiction (EMCDDA) on 14 Nov 2005. 2 notices on the outbreak have been\npublished in the national epidemiological bulletin [1,2].\nIf the vehicle of infection is contaminated heroin, it is possible that\nsimilar cases may be occurring elsewhere in Europe, and Dr. Katharina\nAlpers <AlpersK@rki.de> at RKI would be grateful to receive any related\ninformation.\n1. Epidemiologisches Bulletin 2005;\n(48): 453.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/48_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/48_05>\n[Byline: Alpers A <AlpersK@rki.de>, van Treeck U, Frank C]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a wound,\ngerminate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the wound\nbotulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs). Those IDUs who\nintentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or intramuscularly may\nbe particularly vulnerable to infection.\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a febrile,\ndescending, flaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing\nthe severity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early in\nthe course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results of\nmicrobiological testing.\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical debridement\nare necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse after antitoxin\ntreatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl penicillin and metronidazole.\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of both\nfoodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by toxin\ntype A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis and a\nhigher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation. All toxin\ntypes exert their action on the cholinergic system at the presynapic\nmotor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine transmission across the\nneuromuscular junction. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, Drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\n2000\n----\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK (07) 20000820.1388\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: diagnosis 20000615.0977\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK 20000608.0922\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland & Scotland 20000531.0874\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland (Dublin) 20000525.0825\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) (09) 20000522.0807\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) 20000511.0717\n........................................ll/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Mexico (AG): botulism susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1488", "date": "2005-12-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - GERMANY (NORDRHEIN-WESTFALEN)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nVirology\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xr4zp>\nDate: Thu 15 Dec 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2005/051215.asp#4>\n\nOutbreak of wound botulism in injecting drug users in Germany, October -\nDecember 2005\n-----------------------------------------------\nA cluster of 14 cases of wound botulism (including 6 laboratory-confirmed\ncases) in injecting drug users has been reported from the federal state of\nNordrhein-Westfalen in the west of Germany. The 1st cases were reported in\nNovember 2005.\nThe earliest disease onset date recorded so far is 14 Oct 2005, and the\nlatest is 5 Dec 2005. To date, it remains unclear whether or not the\noutbreak has ended. A common source of infection has not yet been\nidentified, but it is suspected that the vehicle of infection is\ncontaminated heroin. Nearly all patients that investigators have so far\nbeen able to question have reported subcutaneous (\"skin popping\") or\nintramuscular (\"muscle popping\") injection of the drug, and presented with\nwound infections.\nThe Robert Koch-Institut (RKI) issued alerts through the European Early\nWarning System (EWRS) and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug\nAddiction (EMCDDA) on 14 Nov 2005. 2 notices on the outbreak have been\npublished in the national epidemiological bulletin [1,2].\nIf the vehicle of infection is contaminated heroin, it is possible that\nsimilar cases may be occurring elsewhere in Europe, and Dr. Katharina\nAlpers <AlpersK@rki.de> at RKI would be grateful to receive any related\ninformation.\n1. Zu einer Haufung von Wundbotulismus in Nordrhein-Westfalen.\nEpidemiologisches Bulletin 2005; (45): 420.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/45_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/45_05>\n2. Update zu einer Haufung von Wundbotulismus bei injizierenden\nDrogenkonsumenten in Nordrhein-Westfalen. Epidemiologisches Bulletin 2005;\n(48): 453.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/48_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/48_05>\n[Byline: Alpers A <AlpersK@rki.de>, van Treeck U, Frank C]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a wound,\ngerminate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the wound\nbotulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs). Those IDUs who\nintentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or intramuscularly may\nbe particularly vulnerable to infection.\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a febrile,\ndescending, flaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing\nthe severity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early in\nthe course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results of\nmicrobiological testing.\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical debridement\nare necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse after antitoxin\ntreatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl penicillin and metronidazole.\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of both\nfoodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by toxin\ntype A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis and a\nhigher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation. All toxin\ntypes exert their action on the cholinergic system at the presynapic\nmotor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine transmission across the\nneuromuscular junction. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, Drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\n2000\n----\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK (07) 20000820.1388\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: diagnosis 20000615.0977\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK 20000608.0922\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland & Scotland 20000531.0874\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland (Dublin) 20000525.0825\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) (09) 20000522.0807\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) 20000511.0717\n........................................ll/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-15 00:00:00", "2005-12-15 00:00:00", "2005-11-15 00:00:00", "2005-10-14 00:00:00", "2005-12-05 00:00:00", "2005-11-14 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "- Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208809", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, dried fish - Kazakhstan (Mangistauskaya)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208809", "date": "2005-12-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - GERMANY (NORDRHEIN-WESTFALEN)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nVirology\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xr4zp>\nDate: Thu 15 Dec 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2005/051215.asp#4>\n\nOutbreak of wound botulism in injecting drug users in Germany, October -\nDecember 2005\n-----------------------------------------------\nA cluster of 14 cases of wound botulism (including 6 laboratory-confirmed\ncases) in injecting drug users has been reported from the federal state of\nNordrhein-Westfalen in the west of Germany. The 1st cases were reported in\nNovember 2005.\nThe earliest disease onset date recorded so far is 14 Oct 2005, and the\nlatest is 5 Dec 2005. To date, it remains unclear whether or not the\noutbreak has ended. A common source of infection has not yet been\nidentified, but it is suspected that the vehicle of infection is\ncontaminated heroin. Nearly all patients that investigators have so far\nbeen able to question have reported subcutaneous (\"skin popping\") or\nintramuscular (\"muscle popping\") injection of the drug, and presented with\nwound infections.\nThe Robert Koch-Institut (RKI) issued alerts through the European Early\nWarning System (EWRS) and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug\nAddiction (EMCDDA) on 14 Nov 2005. 2 notices on the outbreak have been\npublished in the national epidemiological bulletin [1,2].\nIf the vehicle of infection is contaminated heroin, it is possible that\nsimilar cases may be occurring elsewhere in Europe, and Dr. Katharina\nAlpers <AlpersK@rki.de> at RKI would be grateful to receive any related\ninformation.\n1. Zu einer Haufung von Wundbotulismus in Nordrhein-Westfalen.\nEpidemiologisches Bulletin 2005; (45): 420.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/45_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/45_05>\n2. Update zu einer Haufung von Wundbotulismus bei injizierenden\nDrogenkonsumenten in Nordrhein-Westfalen. Epidemiologisches Bulletin 2005;\n(48): 453.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/48_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/48_05>\n[Byline: Alpers A <AlpersK@rki.de>, van Treeck U, Frank C]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a wound,\ngerminate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the wound\nbotulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs). Those IDUs who\nintentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or intramuscularly may\nbe particularly vulnerable to infection.\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a febrile,\ndescending, flaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing\nthe severity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early in\nthe course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results of\nmicrobiological testing.\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical debridement\nare necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse after antitoxin\ntreatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl penicillin and metronidazole.\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of both\nfoodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by toxin\ntype A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis and a\nhigher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation. All toxin\ntypes exert their action on the cholinergic system at the presynapic\nmotor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine transmission across the\nneuromuscular junction. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, Drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\n2000\n----\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK (07) 20000820.1388\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: diagnosis 20000615.0977\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK 20000608.0922\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland & Scotland 20000531.0874\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland (Dublin) 20000525.0825\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) (09) 20000522.0807\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) 20000511.0717\n........................................ll/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The 1st cases were reported in\nNovember 2005.\nThe earliest disease onset date recorded so far is 14 Oct 2005, and the\nlatest is 5 Dec 2005. To date, it remains unclear whether or not the\noutbreak has ended. A common source of infection has not yet been\nidentified, but it is suspected that the vehicle of infection is\ncontaminated heroin. Nearly all patients that investigators have so far\nbeen able to question have reported subcutaneous (\"skin popping\") or\nintramuscular (\"muscle popping\") injection of the drug, and presented with\nwound infections.\nThe Robert Koch-Institut (RKI) issued alerts through the European Early\nWarning System (EWRS) and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug\nAddiction (EMCDDA) on 14 Nov 2005. 2 notices on the outbreak have been\npublished in the national epidemiological bulletin [1,2].\nIf the vehicle of infection is contaminated heroin, it is possible that\nsimilar cases may be occurring elsewhere in Europe, and Dr. Katharina\nAlpers <AlpersK@rki.de> at RKI would be grateful to receive any related\ninformation.\n1. Zu einer Haufung von Wundbotulismus in Nordrhein-Westfalen.\nEpidemiologisches Bulletin 2005; (45): 420.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/45_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/45_05>\n2. Update zu einer Haufung von Wundbotulismus bei injizierenden\nDrogenkonsumenten in Nordrhein-Westfalen. Epidemiologisches Bulletin 2005;\n(48): 453.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/48_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/48_05>\n[Byline: Alpers A <AlpersK@rki.de>, van Treeck U, Frank C]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a wound,\ngerminate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the wound\nbotulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs). Those IDUs who\nintentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or intramuscularly may\nbe particularly vulnerable to infection.\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a febrile,\ndescending, flaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing\nthe severity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early in\nthe course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results of\nmicrobiological testing.\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical debridement\nare necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse after antitoxin\ntreatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl penicillin and metronidazole.\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of both\nfoodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by toxin\ntype A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis and a\nhigher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation. All toxin\ntypes exert their action on the cholinergic system at the presynapic\nmotor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine transmission across the\nneuromuscular junction. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, Drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\n2000\n----\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK (07) 20000820.1388\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: diagnosis 20000615.0977\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK 20000608.0922\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland & Scotland 20000531.0874\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland (Dublin) 20000525.0825\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) (09) 20000522.0807\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) 20000511.0717\n........................................ll/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Update zu einer Haufung von Wundbotulismus bei injizierenden\nDrogenkonsumenten in Nordrhein-Westfalen. Epidemiologisches Bulletin 2005;\n(48): 453.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/48_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/48_05>\n[Byline: Alpers A <AlpersK@rki.de>, van Treeck U, Frank C]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a wound,\ngerminate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the wound\nbotulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs). Those IDUs who\nintentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or intramuscularly may\nbe particularly vulnerable to infection.\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a febrile,\ndescending, flaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing\nthe severity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early in\nthe course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results of\nmicrobiological testing.\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical debridement\nare necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse after antitoxin\ntreatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl penicillin and metronidazole.\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of both\nfoodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by toxin\ntype A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis and a\nhigher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation. Russia (Rostov)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208250", "date": "2005-12-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - GERMANY (NORDRHEIN-WESTFALEN)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nVirology\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xr4zp>\nDate: Thu 15 Dec 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2005/051215.asp#4>\n\nOutbreak of wound botulism in injecting drug users in Germany, October -\nDecember 2005\n-----------------------------------------------\nA cluster of 14 cases of wound botulism (including 6 laboratory-confirmed\ncases) in injecting drug users has been reported from the federal state of\nNordrhein-Westfalen in the west of Germany. The 1st cases were reported in\nNovember 2005.\nThe earliest disease onset date recorded so far is 14 Oct 2005, and the\nlatest is 5 Dec 2005. To date, it remains unclear whether or not the\noutbreak has ended. A common source of infection has not yet been\nidentified, but it is suspected that the vehicle of infection is\ncontaminated heroin. Nearly all patients that investigators have so far\nbeen able to question have reported subcutaneous (\"skin popping\") or\nintramuscular (\"muscle popping\") injection of the drug, and presented with\nwound infections.\nThe Robert Koch-Institut (RKI) issued alerts through the European Early\nWarning System (EWRS) and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug\nAddiction (EMCDDA) on 14 Nov 2005. 2 notices on the outbreak have been\npublished in the national epidemiological bulletin [1,2].\nIf the vehicle of infection is contaminated heroin, it is possible that\nsimilar cases may be occurring elsewhere in Europe, and Dr. Katharina\nAlpers <AlpersK@rki.de> at RKI would be grateful to receive any related\ninformation.\n1. Zu einer Haufung von Wundbotulismus in Nordrhein-Westfalen.\nEpidemiologisches Bulletin 2005; (45): 420.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/45_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/45_05>\n2. Update zu einer Haufung von Wundbotulismus bei injizierenden\nDrogenkonsumenten in Nordrhein-Westfalen. Epidemiologisches Bulletin 2005;\n(48): 453.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/48_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/48_05>\n[Byline: Alpers A <AlpersK@rki.de>, van Treeck U, Frank C]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a wound,\ngerminate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the wound\nbotulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs). Those IDUs who\nintentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or intramuscularly may\nbe particularly vulnerable to infection.\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a febrile,\ndescending, flaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing\nthe severity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early in\nthe course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results of\nmicrobiological testing.\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical debridement\nare necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse after antitoxin\ntreatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl penicillin and metronidazole.\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of both\nfoodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by toxin\ntype A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis and a\nhigher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation. All toxin\ntypes exert their action on the cholinergic system at the presynapic\nmotor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine transmission across the\nneuromuscular junction. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, Drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\n2000\n----\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK (07) 20000820.1388\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: diagnosis 20000615.0977\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK 20000608.0922\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland & Scotland 20000531.0874\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland (Dublin) 20000525.0825\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) (09) 20000522.0807\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) 20000511.0717\n........................................ll/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-15 00:00:00", "2005-12-15 00:00:00", "2005-11-15 00:00:00", "2005-10-14 00:00:00", "2005-12-05 00:00:00", "2005-11-14 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "- Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208201", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism - Russia (Komi)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208201", "date": "2005-12-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - GERMANY (NORDRHEIN-WESTFALEN)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nVirology\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xr4zp>\nDate: Thu 15 Dec 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2005/051215.asp#4>\n\nOutbreak of wound botulism in injecting drug users in Germany, October -\nDecember 2005\n-----------------------------------------------\nA cluster of 14 cases of wound botulism (including 6 laboratory-confirmed\ncases) in injecting drug users has been reported from the federal state of\nNordrhein-Westfalen in the west of Germany. The 1st cases were reported in\nNovember 2005.\nThe earliest disease onset date recorded so far is 14 Oct 2005, and the\nlatest is 5 Dec 2005. To date, it remains unclear whether or not the\noutbreak has ended. A common source of infection has not yet been\nidentified, but it is suspected that the vehicle of infection is\ncontaminated heroin. Nearly all patients that investigators have so far\nbeen able to question have reported subcutaneous (\"skin popping\") or\nintramuscular (\"muscle popping\") injection of the drug, and presented with\nwound infections.\nThe Robert Koch-Institut (RKI) issued alerts through the European Early\nWarning System (EWRS) and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug\nAddiction (EMCDDA) on 14 Nov 2005. 2 notices on the outbreak have been\npublished in the national epidemiological bulletin [1,2].\nIf the vehicle of infection is contaminated heroin, it is possible that\nsimilar cases may be occurring elsewhere in Europe, and Dr. Katharina\nAlpers <AlpersK@rki.de> at RKI would be grateful to receive any related\ninformation.\n1. Zu einer Haufung von Wundbotulismus in Nordrhein-Westfalen.\nEpidemiologisches Bulletin 2005; (45): 420.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/45_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/45_05>\n2. Update zu einer Haufung von Wundbotulismus bei injizierenden\nDrogenkonsumenten in Nordrhein-Westfalen. Epidemiologisches Bulletin 2005;\n(48): 453.\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_335538/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/48_\n_05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/48_05>\n[Byline: Alpers A <AlpersK@rki.de>, van Treeck U, Frank C]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Wound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a wound,\ngerminate and produce botulinum neurotoxin in vivo. Most of the wound\nbotulism cases have been among injecting drug users (IDUs). Those IDUs who\nintentionally or accidentally inject subcutaneously or intramuscularly may\nbe particularly vulnerable to infection.\nClinicians should suspect botulism in any patient with a febrile,\ndescending, flaccid paralysis. Botulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing\nthe severity of symptoms for all forms of botulism if administered early in\nthe course of the disease and should not be delayed for the results of\nmicrobiological testing.\nIn cases of wound botulism, antimicrobial therapy and surgical debridement\nare necessary to remove the organism and avoid relapse after antitoxin\ntreatment. _C. botulinum_ is sensitive to benzyl penicillin and metronidazole.\nToxin type A (one of 7 types of botulinum toxin) causes most cases of both\nfoodborne and wound botulism in the USA. The syndrome produced by toxin\ntype A is most severe, with more rapid progression of paralysis and a\nhigher proportion of patients requiring mechanical ventilation. All toxin\ntypes exert their action on the cholinergic system at the presynapic\nmotor-neuron terminal by blocking acetylcholine transmission across the\nneuromuscular junction. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA) 20041219.3345\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England, Wales) 20040923.2627\n2002\n----\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK 20021116.5821\nBotulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland 20021101.5684\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK, Ireland 20021031.5675\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, Drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\n2000\n----\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK (07) 20000820.1388\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: diagnosis 20000615.0977\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK 20000608.0922\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland & Scotland 20000531.0874\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland (Dublin) 20000525.0825\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) (09) 20000522.0807\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) 20000511.0717\n........................................ll/msp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Georgia (02): susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207758", "date": "2005-01-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BAMBOO SHOOTS - CANADA (ALBERTA, BRITISH COLUMBIA): RECALL\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 7 Jan 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Canada NewsWire [edited]\n<http://press.arrivenet.com/bus/article.php/555436.html>\n\nWhole bamboo shoots imported by Canda Enterprise may contain botulism\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) and Canda Enterprise Co Ltd are\nwarning the public not to consume canned whole bamboo shoots, because the\nproduct may be contaminated with the bacteria responsible for botulism, a\nfoodborne illness in humans. The affected product, Whole Bamboo Shoots, is\nsold in a 400 g vacuum type package bearing UPC 6 921926966680. The\naffected product does not contain lot codes or \"best before\" dating.\nThe importer, Canda Enterprise Co Ltd, Burnaby, British Columbia, is\nvoluntarily recalling the affected product from the marketplace. The\naffected product has been distributed in Alberta and British Columbia.\nBotulism is a life-threatening illness caused by the ingestion of toxins\nproduced by _Clostridium botulinum_ bacteria. Food contaminated with _C.\nbotulinum_ may not look or smell spoiled. The product should not be\nconsumed by humans or animals. There have been no reported illnesses\nassociated with the consumption of this product.\nThe CFIA is monitoring the effectiveness of the recall. For more\ninformation, consumers and industry can call the CFIA at 1-800-442-2342.\n8:00 am to 4:00 pm local time -- Monday to Friday.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail does not post most food recalls unless human cases result.\nBotulism recalls are generally posted, however, because of the potential\nseverity of illness. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2004\n---\nBotulism, food recall - Canada: alert 20041129.3193\nBotulism, prison brew - USA (CA) 20040806.2155\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\nBotulism, fish-related 2003 - Norway, Germany 20040120.0224\n2003\n---\nBotulism, beef poultry sausage - France: recall 20030922.2391\nBotulism, canned sausage suspected - South Korea 20030629.1602\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark (03): discussion 20030209.0342\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark 20030131.0267\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\n2002\n---\nBotulism, blue cheese - Canada (Quebec): recall 20021213.6055\nBotulism, gefilte fish - Canada: recall 20020510.4153\nBotulism, type A, foodborne - South Africa (Gauteng) 20020305.3689\nBotulism, canned asparagus - USA: Recall 20020209.3521\nBotulism, canned clams - USA (Northeast): recall 20020112.3233\n2001\n---\nBotulism, canned organic beans - Kyrgyzstan (Kant)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207661", "date": "2005-01-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BAMBOO SHOOTS - CANADA (ALBERTA, BRITISH COLUMBIA): RECALL\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 7 Jan 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Canada NewsWire [edited]\n<http://press.arrivenet.com/bus/article.php/555436.html>\n\nWhole bamboo shoots imported by Canda Enterprise may contain botulism\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) and Canda Enterprise Co Ltd are\nwarning the public not to consume canned whole bamboo shoots, because the\nproduct may be contaminated with the bacteria responsible for botulism, a\nfoodborne illness in humans. The affected product, Whole Bamboo Shoots, is\nsold in a 400 g vacuum type package bearing UPC 6 921926966680. The\naffected product does not contain lot codes or \"best before\" dating.\nThe importer, Canda Enterprise Co Ltd, Burnaby, British Columbia, is\nvoluntarily recalling the affected product from the marketplace. The\naffected product has been distributed in Alberta and British Columbia.\nBotulism is a life-threatening illness caused by the ingestion of toxins\nproduced by _Clostridium botulinum_ bacteria. Food contaminated with _C.\nbotulinum_ may not look or smell spoiled. The product should not be\nconsumed by humans or animals. There have been no reported illnesses\nassociated with the consumption of this product.\nThe CFIA is monitoring the effectiveness of the recall. For more\ninformation, consumers and industry can call the CFIA at 1-800-442-2342.\n8:00 am to 4:00 pm local time -- Monday to Friday.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail does not post most food recalls unless human cases result.\nBotulism recalls are generally posted, however, because of the potential\nseverity of illness. - Russia (Rostov)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207182", "date": "2005-01-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BAMBOO SHOOTS - CANADA (ALBERTA, BRITISH COLUMBIA): RECALL\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 7 Jan 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Canada NewsWire [edited]\n<http://press.arrivenet.com/bus/article.php/555436.html>\n\nWhole bamboo shoots imported by Canda Enterprise may contain botulism\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) and Canda Enterprise Co Ltd are\nwarning the public not to consume canned whole bamboo shoots, because the\nproduct may be contaminated with the bacteria responsible for botulism, a\nfoodborne illness in humans. The affected product, Whole Bamboo Shoots, is\nsold in a 400 g vacuum type package bearing UPC 6 921926966680. The\naffected product does not contain lot codes or \"best before\" dating.\nThe importer, Canda Enterprise Co Ltd, Burnaby, British Columbia, is\nvoluntarily recalling the affected product from the marketplace. The\naffected product has been distributed in Alberta and British Columbia.\nBotulism is a life-threatening illness caused by the ingestion of toxins\nproduced by _Clostridium botulinum_ bacteria. Food contaminated with _C.\nbotulinum_ may not look or smell spoiled. The product should not be\nconsumed by humans or animals. There have been no reported illnesses\nassociated with the consumption of this product.\nThe CFIA is monitoring the effectiveness of the recall. For more\ninformation, consumers and industry can call the CFIA at 1-800-442-2342.\n8:00 am to 4:00 pm local time -- Monday to Friday.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail does not post most food recalls unless human cases result.\nBotulism recalls are generally posted, however, because of the potential\nseverity of illness. - USA (FL): alert"}, {"archive_id": "2207039", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, wound, drug-related - USA (CA)"}, {"archive_id": "2207020", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, human, botox related - USA (FL)(05)"}, {"archive_id": "2207016", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - South Africa", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207016", "date": "2004-10-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, DRIED FISH - UKRAINE (KHARKOV)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 30 Oct 2004\nFrom: Vadim Melnik, ProMED-mail correspondent in Ukraine\nSource: Objective Media group, Ukraine, 22 Oct 2004 [in Russian, translated\nby Mod.NR; edited]\n<http://news.media-objektiv.com/city/2004/18015.shtml>\nFor the last month there were 6 patients diagnosed with botulism in Kharkov.\nHealth officials are saying that this outbreak will not lead to an epidemic.\nBotulism is an acute infectious intestinal disease caused by a toxin. Humans\ningest it in infected foodstuffs, such as smoked fish or canned mushrooms\n[and canned corn -- see ref. below, and home-cooked dishes. - Mod.JW].\nAt present, 2 women are hospitalized with a diagnosis of botulism. They were\nadmitted on 12 Oct 2004. According to physicians they are still very weak and\nhave vision problems, but are not in a life-threatening situation. They\nreport eating dried fish they bought in a metro station.\nPhysicians stated that 5 out of 6 patients admitted to the infectious\ndiseases hospital with botulism were women. According to the physicians, men\ndrink alcohol with fish, and alcohol reduces the risk of getting infected [in\nfact, there is no infection with a microbe, it is poisoning from the toxin. -\nMod.JW]. Physicians are warning the population that it is hard to\ndistinguish a product infected with botulism from a clean one.\nThe sanitary epidemiological surveillance center reports that people in\nKharkov get botulism quite often due to their eating habits -- on average 10\ncases a year. According to their statistics 9 out of 10 cases are lethal.\nThis time, none of the 6 patients died. According to expert opinion, the most\ndangerous are the fish caught in the Kremenchug reservoir, because physicians\ndiscovered microbes there that produce the botulism toxin. According to\nValentina Gridina, chief of the hygiene department of the sanitary\nsurveillance center, before the reservoir was built there must have been a\nburial ground of cattle on the spot, or animals were herded there. [I am\nafraid she is confusing _Clostridium botulinum_ with anthrax. - Mod.JW]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Alcohol does NOT cure or prevent botulism. Alcohol is a diuretic and may\nmake the person drink copious amounts of fluids, which could potentially\nwash out the toxin/or cause solids to move faster out of the body. Alcohol\nwill work for ethelyne glycol poisoning, but NOT botulism. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (03) 20040908.2508\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (02) 20040825.2371\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20040817.2278\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n...............................nr/jw/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2004.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Humans\ningest it in infected foodstuffs, such as smoked fish or canned mushrooms\n[and canned corn -- see ref. below, and home-cooked dishes. - Mod.JW].\nAt present, 2 women are hospitalized with a diagnosis of botulism. They were\nadmitted on 12 Oct 2004. According to physicians they are still very weak and\nhave vision problems, but are not in a life-threatening situation. They\nreport eating dried fish they bought in a metro station.\nPhysicians stated that 5 out of 6 patients admitted to the infectious\ndiseases hospital with botulism were women. According to the physicians, men\ndrink alcohol with fish, and alcohol reduces the risk of getting infected [in\nfact, there is no infection with a microbe, it is poisoning from the toxin. -\nMod.JW]. Physicians are warning the population that it is hard to\ndistinguish a product infected with botulism from a clean one.\nThe sanitary epidemiological surveillance center reports that people in\nKharkov get botulism quite often due to their eating habits -- on average 10\ncases a year. According to their statistics 9 out of 10 cases are lethal.\nThis time, none of the 6 patients died. According to expert opinion, the most\ndangerous are the fish caught in the Kremenchug reservoir, because physicians\ndiscovered microbes there that produce the botulism toxin. According to\nValentina Gridina, chief of the hygiene department of the sanitary\nsurveillance center, before the reservoir was built there must have been a\nburial ground of cattle on the spot, or animals were herded there. [I am\nafraid she is confusing _Clostridium botulinum_ with anthrax. - Mod.JW]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Alcohol does NOT cure or prevent botulism. Alcohol is a diuretic and may\nmake the person drink copious amounts of fluids, which could potentially\nwash out the toxin/or cause solids to move faster out of the body. Alcohol\nwill work for ethelyne glycol poisoning, but NOT botulism. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (03) 20040908.2508\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (02) 20040825.2371\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20040817.2278\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n...............................nr/jw/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2004.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Humans\ningest it in infected foodstuffs, such as smoked fish or canned mushrooms\n[and canned corn -- see ref. below, and home-cooked dishes. - Mod.JW].\nAt present, 2 women are hospitalized with a diagnosis of botulism. They were\nadmitted on 12 Oct 2004. According to physicians they are still very weak and\nhave vision problems, but are not in a life-threatening situation. They\nreport eating dried fish they bought in a metro station.\nPhysicians stated that 5 out of 6 patients admitted to the infectious\ndiseases hospital with botulism were women. According to the physicians, men\ndrink alcohol with fish, and alcohol reduces the risk of getting infected [in\nfact, there is no infection with a microbe, it is poisoning from the toxin. -\nMod.JW]. Physicians are warning the population that it is hard to\ndistinguish a product infected with botulism from a clean one.\nThe sanitary epidemiological surveillance center reports that people in\nKharkov get botulism quite often due to their eating habits -- on average 10\ncases a year. According to their statistics 9 out of 10 cases are lethal.\nThis time, none of the 6 patients died. According to expert opinion, the most\ndangerous are the fish caught in the Kremenchug reservoir, because physicians\ndiscovered microbes there that produce the botulism toxin. According to\nValentina Gridina, chief of the hygiene department of the sanitary\nsurveillance center, before the reservoir was built there must have been a\nburial ground of cattle on the spot, or animals were herded there. [I am\nafraid she is confusing _Clostridium botulinum_ with anthrax. - Mod.JW]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Alcohol does NOT cure or prevent botulism. Alcohol is a diuretic and may\nmake the person drink copious amounts of fluids, which could potentially\nwash out the toxin/or cause solids to move faster out of the body. Alcohol\nwill work for ethelyne glycol poisoning, but NOT botulism. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (03) 20040908.2508\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (02) 20040825.2371\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20040817.2278\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n...............................nr/jw/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2004.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n*##########################################################*\n*##########################################################*", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kharkov", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206973", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, canned eggplant - Kyrgyzstan (Osh)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206973", "date": "2004-10-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, DRIED FISH - UKRAINE (KHARKOV)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 30 Oct 2004\nFrom: Vadim Melnik, ProMED-mail correspondent in Ukraine\nSource: Objective Media group, Ukraine, 22 Oct 2004 [in Russian, translated\nby Mod.NR; edited]\n<http://news.media-objektiv.com/city/2004/18015.shtml>\nFor the last month there were 6 patients diagnosed with botulism in Kharkov.\nHealth officials are saying that this outbreak will not lead to an epidemic.\nBotulism is an acute infectious intestinal disease caused by a toxin. Humans\ningest it in infected foodstuffs, such as smoked fish or canned mushrooms\n[and canned corn -- see ref. below, and home-cooked dishes. - Mod.JW].\nAt present, 2 women are hospitalized with a diagnosis of botulism. They were\nadmitted on 12 Oct 2004. According to physicians they are still very weak and\nhave vision problems, but are not in a life-threatening situation. They\nreport eating dried fish they bought in a metro station.\nPhysicians stated that 5 out of 6 patients admitted to the infectious\ndiseases hospital with botulism were women. According to the physicians, men\ndrink alcohol with fish, and alcohol reduces the risk of getting infected [in\nfact, there is no infection with a microbe, it is poisoning from the toxin. -\nMod.JW]. Physicians are warning the population that it is hard to\ndistinguish a product infected with botulism from a clean one.\nThe sanitary epidemiological surveillance center reports that people in\nKharkov get botulism quite often due to their eating habits -- on average 10\ncases a year. According to their statistics 9 out of 10 cases are lethal.\nThis time, none of the 6 patients died. According to expert opinion, the most\ndangerous are the fish caught in the Kremenchug reservoir, because physicians\ndiscovered microbes there that produce the botulism toxin. According to\nValentina Gridina, chief of the hygiene department of the sanitary\nsurveillance center, before the reservoir was built there must have been a\nburial ground of cattle on the spot, or animals were herded there. [I am\nafraid she is confusing _Clostridium botulinum_ with anthrax. - Mod.JW]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Alcohol does NOT cure or prevent botulism. Alcohol is a diuretic and may\nmake the person drink copious amounts of fluids, which could potentially\nwash out the toxin/or cause solids to move faster out of the body. Alcohol\nwill work for ethelyne glycol poisoning, but NOT botulism. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (03) 20040908.2508\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) (02) 20040825.2371\nBotulism, smoked fish - Russia (Buryatia) 20040817.2278\nBotulism, dried fish suspected - Russia (Volgograd) 20040526.1424\n2003\n----\nBotulism, canned corn - Ukraine 20031121.2888\n...............................nr/jw/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2004.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Humans\ningest it in infected foodstuffs, such as smoked fish or canned mushrooms\n[and canned corn -- see ref. below, and home-cooked dishes. - Mod.JW].\nAt present, 2 women are hospitalized with a diagnosis of botulism. They were\nadmitted on 12 Oct 2004. According to physicians they are still very weak and\nhave vision problems, but are not in a life-threatening situation. They\nreport eating dried fish they bought in a metro station.\nPhysicians stated that 5 out of 6 patients admitted to the infectious\ndiseases hospital with botulism were women. According to the physicians, men\ndrink alcohol with fish, and alcohol reduces the risk of getting infected [in\nfact, there is no infection with a microbe, it is poisoning from the toxin. -\nMod.JW]. Physicians are warning the population that it is hard to\ndistinguish a product infected with botulism from a clean one.\nThe sanitary epidemiological surveillance center reports that people in\nKharkov get botulism quite often due to their eating habits -- on average 10\ncases a year. According to their statistics 9 out of 10 cases are lethal.\nThis time, none of the 6 patients died. According to expert opinion, the most\ndangerous are the fish caught in the Kremenchug reservoir, because physicians\ndiscovered microbes there that produce the botulism toxin. According to\nValentina Gridina, chief of the hygiene department of the sanitary\nsurveillance center, before the reservoir was built there must have been a\nburial ground of cattle on the spot, or animals were herded there. Humans\ningest it in infected foodstuffs, such as smoked fish or canned mushrooms\n[and canned corn -- see ref. below, and home-cooked dishes. - Mod.JW].\nAt present, 2 women are hospitalized with a diagnosis of botulism. They were\nadmitted on 12 Oct 2004. According to physicians they are still very weak and\nhave vision problems, but are not in a life-threatening situation. They\nreport eating dried fish they bought in a metro station.\nPhysicians stated that 5 out of 6 patients admitted to the infectious\ndiseases hospital with botulism were women. According to the physicians, men\ndrink alcohol with fish, and alcohol reduces the risk of getting infected [in\nfact, there is no infection with a microbe, it is poisoning from the toxin. -\nMod.JW]. Physicians are warning the population that it is hard to\ndistinguish a product infected with botulism from a clean one.\nThe sanitary epidemiological surveillance center reports that people in\nKharkov get botulism quite often due to their eating habits -- on average 10\ncases a year. According to their statistics 9 out of 10 cases are lethal.\nThis time, none of the 6 patients died. According to expert opinion, the most\ndangerous are the fish caught in the Kremenchug reservoir, because physicians\ndiscovered microbes there that produce the botulism toxin. According to\nValentina Gridina, chief of the hygiene department of the sanitary\nsurveillance center, before the reservoir was built there must have been a\nburial ground of cattle on the spot, or animals were herded there. According to the physicians, men\ndrink alcohol with fish, and alcohol reduces the risk of getting infected [in\nfact, there is no infection with a microbe, it is poisoning from the toxin. -\nMod.JW]. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n*##########################################################*\n*##########################################################*", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kharkov", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206774", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206774", "date": "2003-11-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CANNED CORN - UKRAINE\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue, 18 Nov 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Unian Ukraine (translated by Mod. NR) [edited]\n<http://www.unian.net/index.php?section=arhiv&dayform=18&monthform=11&lang=rus&yearform=2003&arhiv=1>\n\n6 people diagnosed with botulism in Dnepropetrovsk, Ukraine.\n----------------------------------------------------------------\n6 people were admitted to the City of Dnepropetrovsk's infectious disease\nhospital with botulism after a birthday celebration. According to\nDnepropetrovsk Nutrition Hygiene department chief Ivan Dedayev, physicians\nthought that the source of the botulism cluster was homemade canned corn\nshared by the participants in the celebration.\nAccording to Ivan Dedayev, the hospitalized individuals are expected to\nsurvive, and their condition is satisfactory. Also according to Dedayev,\nthis year [2003], there were 13 cases of botulism reported, with dried fish\nand homemade canned mushrooms found to be the source of the toxin-induced\ndisease.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Botulism is an uncommon but potentially fatal disease due to one of 6\n(A,B,C,D,E,F) neurotoxins produced by strains of _Clostridium\nbotulinum_. Spores of the organism are quite ubiquitous in the\nenvironment, and the toxin is elaborated after the spores germinate and\ngrow in an anaerobic environment. The disease usually results from the\ningestion of preformed toxin in inadequately preserved food products. The\nvegetative organism and its toxin are readily inactivated by boiling, but\nthe spores must reach higher temperatures for inactivation. Home canning\nis a common vehicle for transmission of botulism (as in this posting), but\ncommercially produced canned food has also been implicated. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark (03): discussion 20030209.0342\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark (02) 20030201.0275\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark 20030131.0267\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\n2002\n----\nBotulism, blue cheese - Canada (Quebec): recall 20021213.6055\nBotulism, gefilte fish - Canada: recall 20020510.4153\nBotulism, type A, foodborne - South Africa (Gauteng) 20020305.3689\nBotulism, canned asparagus - USA: Recall 20020209.3521\nBotulism, canned clams - USA (Northeast): recall 20020112.3233\n2001\n----\nBotulism, canned organic beans - Canada: recall 20011115.2812\nBotulism, bread products - Canada: recall 20011031.2685\nBotulism, chili - USA (Texas): recall 20010904.2116\nBotulism, baby formula - UK, Ireland: recall 20010814.1919\nBotulism advisory, beef jerky - Canada (N.S.): recall 20010217.0313\n2000\n----\nBotulism, foodborne - Russia 1999 20000229.0277\n1999\n----\nBotulism, human - Russia (Burjatija) 19990907.1576\nBotulism advisory - Canada, USA: background 19990117.0071\nBotulism advisory - Canada, USA 19990115.0054\n1998\n----\nBotulism, human - Japan (Tokyo) 19980816.1632\nBotulism, risk from packaged vegetables: RFI 19980813.1600\nBotulism, human - Algeria 19980723.1393\n.............................................nr/ll/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
