NR) [edited]\n<http://www.unian.net/index.php?section=arhiv&dayform=18&monthform=11&lang=rus&yearform=2003&arhiv=1>\n\n6 people diagnosed with botulism in Dnepropetrovsk, Ukraine.\n----------------------------------------------------------------\n6 people were admitted to the City of Dnepropetrovsk's infectious disease\nhospital with botulism after a birthday celebration. According to\nDnepropetrovsk Nutrition Hygiene department chief Ivan Dedayev, physicians\nthought that the source of the botulism cluster was homemade canned corn\nshared by the participants in the celebration.\nAccording to Ivan Dedayev, the hospitalized individuals are expected to\nsurvive, and their condition is satisfactory. Also according to Dedayev,\nthis year [2003], there were 13 cases of botulism reported, with dried fish\nand homemade canned mushrooms found to be the source of the toxin-induced\ndisease.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Botulism is an uncommon but potentially fatal disease due to one of 6\n(A,B,C,D,E,F) neurotoxins produced by strains of _Clostridium\nbotulinum_. Spores of the organism are quite ubiquitous in the\nenvironment, and the toxin is elaborated after the spores germinate and\ngrow in an anaerobic environment. The disease usually results from the\ningestion of preformed toxin in inadequately preserved food products. The\nvegetative organism and its toxin are readily inactivated by boiling, but\nthe spores must reach higher temperatures for inactivation. Home canning\nis a common vehicle for transmission of botulism (as in this posting), but\ncommercially produced canned food has also been implicated. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark (03): discussion 20030209.0342\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark (02) 20030201.0275\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark 20030131.0267\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\n2002\n----\nBotulism, blue cheese - Canada (Quebec): recall 20021213.6055\nBotulism, gefilte fish - Canada: recall 20020510.4153\nBotulism, type A, foodborne - South Africa (Gauteng) 20020305.3689\nBotulism, canned asparagus - USA: Recall 20020209.3521\nBotulism, canned clams - USA (Northeast): recall 20020112.3233\n2001\n----\nBotulism, canned organic beans - Canada: recall 20011115.2812\nBotulism, bread products - Canada: recall 20011031.2685\nBotulism, chili - USA (Texas): recall 20010904.2116\nBotulism, baby formula - UK, Ireland: recall 20010814.1919\nBotulism advisory, beef jerky - Canada (N.S.): recall 20010217.0313\n2000\n----\nBotulism, foodborne - Russia 1999 20000229.0277\n1999\n----\nBotulism, human - Russia (Burjatija) 19990907.1576\nBotulism advisory - Canada, USA: background 19990117.0071\nBotulism advisory - Canada, USA 19990115.0054\n1998\n----\nBotulism, human - Japan (Tokyo) 19980816.1632\nBotulism, risk from packaged vegetables: RFI 19980813.1600\nBotulism, human - Algeria 19980723.1393\n.............................................nr/ll/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. NR) [edited]\n<http://www.unian.net/index.php?section=arhiv&dayform=18&monthform=11&lang=rus&yearform=2003&arhiv=1>\n\n6 people diagnosed with botulism in Dnepropetrovsk, Ukraine.\n----------------------------------------------------------------\n6 people were admitted to the City of Dnepropetrovsk's infectious disease\nhospital with botulism after a birthday celebration. According to\nDnepropetrovsk Nutrition Hygiene department chief Ivan Dedayev, physicians\nthought that the source of the botulism cluster was homemade canned corn\nshared by the participants in the celebration.\nAccording to Ivan Dedayev, the hospitalized individuals are expected to\nsurvive, and their condition is satisfactory. Spores of the organism are quite ubiquitous in the\nenvironment, and the toxin is elaborated after the spores germinate and\ngrow in an anaerobic environment. The disease usually results from the\ningestion of preformed toxin in inadequately preserved food products. The\nvegetative organism and its toxin are readily inactivated by boiling, but\nthe spores must reach higher temperatures for inactivation. NR) [edited]\n<http://www.unian.net/index.php?section=arhiv&dayform=18&monthform=11&lang=rus&yearform=2003&arhiv=1>\n\n6 people diagnosed with botulism in Dnepropetrovsk, Ukraine.\n----------------------------------------------------------------\n6 people were admitted to the City of Dnepropetrovsk's infectious disease\nhospital with botulism after a birthday celebration. According to\nDnepropetrovsk Nutrition Hygiene department chief Ivan Dedayev, physicians\nthought that the source of the botulism cluster was homemade canned corn\nshared by the participants in the celebration.\nAccording to Ivan Dedayev, the hospitalized individuals are expected to\nsurvive, and their condition is satisfactory. Also according to Dedayev,\nthis year [2003], there were 13 cases of botulism reported, with dried fish\nand homemade canned mushrooms found to be the source of the toxin-induced\ndisease.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Botulism is an uncommon but potentially fatal disease due to one of 6\n(A,B,C,D,E,F) neurotoxins produced by strains of _Clostridium\nbotulinum_. Spores of the organism are quite ubiquitous in the\nenvironment, and the toxin is elaborated after the spores germinate and\ngrow in an anaerobic environment. The disease usually results from the\ningestion of preformed toxin in inadequately preserved food products. The\nvegetative organism and its toxin are readily inactivated by boiling, but\nthe spores must reach higher temperatures for inactivation. Home canning\nis a common vehicle for transmission of botulism (as in this posting), but\ncommercially produced canned food has also been implicated. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark (03): discussion 20030209.0342\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark (02) 20030201.0275\nBotulism, bottled garlic - Denmark 20030131.0267\nBotulism, whale blubber, 2002 - USA (Alaska) 20030117.0142\n2002\n----\nBotulism, blue cheese - Canada (Quebec): recall 20021213.6055\nBotulism, gefilte fish - Canada: recall 20020510.4153\nBotulism, type A, foodborne - South Africa (Gauteng) 20020305.3689\nBotulism, canned asparagus - USA: Recall 20020209.3521\nBotulism, canned clams - USA (Northeast): recall 20020112.3233\n2001\n----\nBotulism, canned organic beans - Canada: recall 20011115.2812\nBotulism, bread products - Canada: recall 20011031.2685\nBotulism, chili - USA (Texas): recall 20010904.2116\nBotulism, baby formula - UK, Ireland: recall 20010814.1919\nBotulism advisory, beef jerky - Canada (N.S.): recall 20010217.0313\n2000\n----\nBotulism, foodborne - Russia 1999 20000229.0277\n1999\n----\nBotulism, human - Russia (Burjatija) 19990907.1576\nBotulism advisory - Canada, USA: background 19990117.0071\nBotulism advisory - Canada, USA 19990115.0054\n1998\n----\nBotulism, human - Japan (Tokyo) 19980816.1632\nBotulism, risk from packaged vegetables: RFI 19980813.1600\nBotulism, human - Algeria 19980723.1393\n.............................................nr/ll/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The disease usually results from the\ningestion of preformed toxin in inadequately preserved food products. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "N.S.", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Quebec", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dnepropetrovsk", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Gauteng", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Tokyo", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204600", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, beef poultry sausage - France: recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204600", "date": "2003-07-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN \u00ad USA (NEW JERSEY)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 25 Jul 2003\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Press of Atlantic City [edited]\n<http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/cumberland/071903GOOSEPOOP2.html>\n\nThe state Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) determined that\nbotulism caused 70 geese and ducks to die at local retention basins.\n\"It's avian botulism, which is [caused by] a [bacterium],\" said Jack\nKaskey, a DEP spokesman, Friday. \"It is not a health threat to people.\"\n[_Clostridium botulinum_ is one of the bacteria responsible for the\nproduction of the toxin botulinum, which is responsible for the toxic\ncondition known as botulism. \u00ad Mod.TG]\nThe determination came from blood samples investigators took from sick\nbirds at the 3 basins near Delsea Drive and Sarah Place. The basins, which\nare 3 feet deep, are located behind Lilliston Ford and Luther Acres, a\nsenior housing complex.\nThe birds' deaths last week prompted concerns and a DEP investigation.\nKaskey said conditions in the shallow basins were perfect for fostering\nincreased levels of the bacteria, noting that botulism naturally occurs in\nbodies of water. Those conditions included stagnant water, where oxygen\nlevels are low. A contributing factor was that the water was warmer, and\ncolder water holds oxygen better. The large number of birds also added to\nlow oxygen levels with their feces. And runoff into the basin likely\nincluded fertilizers, which added nutrients.\nThe nutrients created an algae bloom that traditionally creates oxygen. But\nas the bloom died, it further depleted the oxygen in the water.This caused\nthe fish to die, with Kaskey noting that even carp, considered a sturdy\nfish, were rising to the surface and gasping for air.\nKaskey said botulism thrives in dead fish. \"The next step is maggots in the\nfish, which are then concentrating botulism in their bodies. And the\nwaterfowl are eating the maggots and dying from it,\" he said. In order to\nstem the avian deaths, Kaskey said the city has been diligent about\nremoving dead fish and bird carcasses.\nWhile pesticides were considered culprits, an analysis of the birds' brains\nproved otherwise, Kaskey said. \"Ultimately, this should fade away,\" Kaskey\nsaid. \"In the long term, one could install a fountain in the basins to keep\nwater moving and keep oxygen at normal levels.\"\nKaskey noted that a similar situation in Millville was remedied that way.\nAlso, residents around the pond should strictly follow directions on\nfertilizers to make sure they are not overdoing it. Excess fertilizer will\nend up in the basins, contributing more nutrients. Lastly, feeding the\ngeese and ducks should be curbed. Fewer birds attracted to the basins would\nmean lower amounts of feces.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Avian botulism is seen most often in regions other than NJ. However, it\nwill occur where the conditions are favorable.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_ elaborates\n7 types of antigenically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of which affect humans:\ntype A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxins types A and B are highly poisonous\nproteins resistant to digestion by GI enzymes. Approximately 50 percent of\nfoodborne outbreaks in the USA are caused by type A toxin, followed by\ntypes B and E.\nType C botulism occurs principally in waterfowl and other birds living in\nan aquatic environment and causes tremendous losses, most notably in\nwaterfowl in the western US. In addition to North America, it has been\nreported in birds in Europe, South Africa, Uruguay, and Australia. In the\nGreat Lakes region, it was first identified in 1936 in ducks on Green Bay\nof Lake Michigan and in 1941 in Monroe County marshes along Lake Erie. Type\nC is most often associated with limberneck paralysis in birds.\nType E botulism is connected with consumption of fish and occurs mainly in\ngulls and loons, and to a lesser extent in mergansers, mute swans, grebes,\nand shorebirds. It now appears that any birds or mammals susceptible to\nbotulinum toxin run a risk of becoming poisoned if they scavenge dead fish.\nEvidence for this includes the identification of type E toxin in a bald\neagle, wood ducks, and muskrats with fish remaining in their digestive tracts.\n_C. botulinum_ spores are relatively heat-resistant, though high\ntemperatures and/or exposure to moist heat will kill the spores.\nToxins, on the other hand, are readily destroyed by heat and by cooking\nfood. Toxin production (especially type E) can occur at temperatures as low\nas 3 degrees C (37.4 degrees F), i.e., inside a refrigerator, and does not\nrequire strict anaerobic conditions.\nHuman illness from Type E is most often associated with improperly smoked\nfish. Since the toxin is destroyed by heat, it appears that no problem with\nbotulism will result from eating cooked waterfowl. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20030111.0097\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan 20030101.0001\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (02) 20030106.0045\n2002\n----\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(03) 20021209.6023\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(02 20021011.5519\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, Usa (Lake Erie) 20021010.5508\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20021228.6142\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\nBotulism, avian: cause & cure 19990719.1219\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, current status - USA 19980918.1879\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n................mpp/tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "1936-03-15 00:00:00", "1941-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Usa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monroe County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Great Lakes", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Millville", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204233", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - USA (NJ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204233", "date": "2003-07-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN \u00ad USA (NEW JERSEY)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 25 Jul 2003\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Press of Atlantic City [edited]\n<http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/cumberland/071903GOOSEPOOP2.html>\n\nThe state Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) determined that\nbotulism caused 70 geese and ducks to die at local retention basins.\n\"It's avian botulism, which is [caused by] a [bacterium],\" said Jack\nKaskey, a DEP spokesman, Friday. \"It is not a health threat to people.\"\n[_Clostridium botulinum_ is one of the bacteria responsible for the\nproduction of the toxin botulinum, which is responsible for the toxic\ncondition known as botulism. \u00ad Mod.TG]\nThe determination came from blood samples investigators took from sick\nbirds at the 3 basins near Delsea Drive and Sarah Place. The basins, which\nare 3 feet deep, are located behind Lilliston Ford and Luther Acres, a\nsenior housing complex.\nThe birds' deaths last week prompted concerns and a DEP investigation.\nKaskey said conditions in the shallow basins were perfect for fostering\nincreased levels of the bacteria, noting that botulism naturally occurs in\nbodies of water. Those conditions included stagnant water, where oxygen\nlevels are low. A contributing factor was that the water was warmer, and\ncolder water holds oxygen better. The large number of birds also added to\nlow oxygen levels with their feces. And runoff into the basin likely\nincluded fertilizers, which added nutrients.\nThe nutrients created an algae bloom that traditionally creates oxygen. But\nas the bloom died, it further depleted the oxygen in the water.This caused\nthe fish to die, with Kaskey noting that even carp, considered a sturdy\nfish, were rising to the surface and gasping for air.\nKaskey said botulism thrives in dead fish. \"The next step is maggots in the\nfish, which are then concentrating botulism in their bodies. And the\nwaterfowl are eating the maggots and dying from it,\" he said. In order to\nstem the avian deaths, Kaskey said the city has been diligent about\nremoving dead fish and bird carcasses.\nWhile pesticides were considered culprits, an analysis of the birds' brains\nproved otherwise, Kaskey said. \"Ultimately, this should fade away,\" Kaskey\nsaid. \"In the long term, one could install a fountain in the basins to keep\nwater moving and keep oxygen at normal levels.\"\nKaskey noted that a similar situation in Millville was remedied that way.\nAlso, residents around the pond should strictly follow directions on\nfertilizers to make sure they are not overdoing it. Excess fertilizer will\nend up in the basins, contributing more nutrients. Lastly, feeding the\ngeese and ducks should be curbed. Fewer birds attracted to the basins would\nmean lower amounts of feces.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Avian botulism is seen most often in regions other than NJ. However, it\nwill occur where the conditions are favorable.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_ elaborates\n7 types of antigenically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of which affect humans:\ntype A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxins types A and B are highly poisonous\nproteins resistant to digestion by GI enzymes. Approximately 50 percent of\nfoodborne outbreaks in the USA are caused by type A toxin, followed by\ntypes B and E.\nType C botulism occurs principally in waterfowl and other birds living in\nan aquatic environment and causes tremendous losses, most notably in\nwaterfowl in the western US. In addition to North America, it has been\nreported in birds in Europe, South Africa, Uruguay, and Australia. In the\nGreat Lakes region, it was first identified in 1936 in ducks on Green Bay\nof Lake Michigan and in 1941 in Monroe County marshes along Lake Erie. Type\nC is most often associated with limberneck paralysis in birds.\nType E botulism is connected with consumption of fish and occurs mainly in\ngulls and loons, and to a lesser extent in mergansers, mute swans, grebes,\nand shorebirds. It now appears that any birds or mammals susceptible to\nbotulinum toxin run a risk of becoming poisoned if they scavenge dead fish.\nEvidence for this includes the identification of type E toxin in a bald\neagle, wood ducks, and muskrats with fish remaining in their digestive tracts.\n_C. botulinum_ spores are relatively heat-resistant, though high\ntemperatures and/or exposure to moist heat will kill the spores.\nToxins, on the other hand, are readily destroyed by heat and by cooking\nfood. Toxin production (especially type E) can occur at temperatures as low\nas 3 degrees C (37.4 degrees F), i.e., inside a refrigerator, and does not\nrequire strict anaerobic conditions.\nHuman illness from Type E is most often associated with improperly smoked\nfish. Since the toxin is destroyed by heat, it appears that no problem with\nbotulism will result from eating cooked waterfowl. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20030111.0097\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan 20030101.0001\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (02) 20030106.0045\n2002\n----\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(03) 20021209.6023\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(02 20021011.5519\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, Usa (Lake Erie) 20021010.5508\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20021228.6142\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\nBotulism, avian: cause & cure 19990719.1219\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, current status - USA 19980918.1879\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n................mpp/tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "1936-03-15 00:00:00", "1941-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Usa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monroe County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Great Lakes", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Millville", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204082", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, bovine - Ireland: poultry litter origin", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204082", "date": "2003-07-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN \u00ad USA (NEW JERSEY)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 25 Jul 2003\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Press of Atlantic City [edited]\n<http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/cumberland/071903GOOSEPOOP2.html>\n\nThe state Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) determined that\nbotulism caused 70 geese and ducks to die at local retention basins.\n\"It's avian botulism, which is [caused by] a [bacterium],\" said Jack\nKaskey, a DEP spokesman, Friday. \"It is not a health threat to people.\"\n[_Clostridium botulinum_ is one of the bacteria responsible for the\nproduction of the toxin botulinum, which is responsible for the toxic\ncondition known as botulism. \u00ad Mod.TG]\nThe determination came from blood samples investigators took from sick\nbirds at the 3 basins near Delsea Drive and Sarah Place. The basins, which\nare 3 feet deep, are located behind Lilliston Ford and Luther Acres, a\nsenior housing complex.\nThe birds' deaths last week prompted concerns and a DEP investigation.\nKaskey said conditions in the shallow basins were perfect for fostering\nincreased levels of the bacteria, noting that botulism naturally occurs in\nbodies of water. Those conditions included stagnant water, where oxygen\nlevels are low. A contributing factor was that the water was warmer, and\ncolder water holds oxygen better. The large number of birds also added to\nlow oxygen levels with their feces. And runoff into the basin likely\nincluded fertilizers, which added nutrients.\nThe nutrients created an algae bloom that traditionally creates oxygen. But\nas the bloom died, it further depleted the oxygen in the water.This caused\nthe fish to die, with Kaskey noting that even carp, considered a sturdy\nfish, were rising to the surface and gasping for air.\nKaskey said botulism thrives in dead fish. \"The next step is maggots in the\nfish, which are then concentrating botulism in their bodies. And the\nwaterfowl are eating the maggots and dying from it,\" he said. In order to\nstem the avian deaths, Kaskey said the city has been diligent about\nremoving dead fish and bird carcasses.\nWhile pesticides were considered culprits, an analysis of the birds' brains\nproved otherwise, Kaskey said. \"Ultimately, this should fade away,\" Kaskey\nsaid. \"In the long term, one could install a fountain in the basins to keep\nwater moving and keep oxygen at normal levels.\"\nKaskey noted that a similar situation in Millville was remedied that way.\nAlso, residents around the pond should strictly follow directions on\nfertilizers to make sure they are not overdoing it. Excess fertilizer will\nend up in the basins, contributing more nutrients. Lastly, feeding the\ngeese and ducks should be curbed. Fewer birds attracted to the basins would\nmean lower amounts of feces.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Avian botulism is seen most often in regions other than NJ. However, it\nwill occur where the conditions are favorable.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_ elaborates\n7 types of antigenically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of which affect humans:\ntype A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxins types A and B are highly poisonous\nproteins resistant to digestion by GI enzymes. Approximately 50 percent of\nfoodborne outbreaks in the USA are caused by type A toxin, followed by\ntypes B and E.\nType C botulism occurs principally in waterfowl and other birds living in\nan aquatic environment and causes tremendous losses, most notably in\nwaterfowl in the western US. In addition to North America, it has been\nreported in birds in Europe, South Africa, Uruguay, and Australia. In the\nGreat Lakes region, it was first identified in 1936 in ducks on Green Bay\nof Lake Michigan and in 1941 in Monroe County marshes along Lake Erie. Type\nC is most often associated with limberneck paralysis in birds.\nType E botulism is connected with consumption of fish and occurs mainly in\ngulls and loons, and to a lesser extent in mergansers, mute swans, grebes,\nand shorebirds. It now appears that any birds or mammals susceptible to\nbotulinum toxin run a risk of becoming poisoned if they scavenge dead fish.\nEvidence for this includes the identification of type E toxin in a bald\neagle, wood ducks, and muskrats with fish remaining in their digestive tracts.\n_C. botulinum_ spores are relatively heat-resistant, though high\ntemperatures and/or exposure to moist heat will kill the spores.\nToxins, on the other hand, are readily destroyed by heat and by cooking\nfood. Toxin production (especially type E) can occur at temperatures as low\nas 3 degrees C (37.4 degrees F), i.e., inside a refrigerator, and does not\nrequire strict anaerobic conditions.\nHuman illness from Type E is most often associated with improperly smoked\nfish. Since the toxin is destroyed by heat, it appears that no problem with\nbotulism will result from eating cooked waterfowl. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20030111.0097\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan 20030101.0001\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (02) 20030106.0045\n2002\n----\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(03) 20021209.6023\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(02 20021011.5519\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, Usa (Lake Erie) 20021010.5508\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20021228.6142\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\nBotulism, avian: cause & cure 19990719.1219\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, current status - USA 19980918.1879\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n................mpp/tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. South Korea", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204063", "date": "2003-07-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN \u00ad USA (NEW JERSEY)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 25 Jul 2003\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Press of Atlantic City [edited]\n<http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/cumberland/071903GOOSEPOOP2.html>\n\nThe state Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) determined that\nbotulism caused 70 geese and ducks to die at local retention basins.\n\"It's avian botulism, which is [caused by] a [bacterium],\" said Jack\nKaskey, a DEP spokesman, Friday. \"It is not a health threat to people.\"\n[_Clostridium botulinum_ is one of the bacteria responsible for the\nproduction of the toxin botulinum, which is responsible for the toxic\ncondition known as botulism. \u00ad Mod.TG]\nThe determination came from blood samples investigators took from sick\nbirds at the 3 basins near Delsea Drive and Sarah Place. The basins, which\nare 3 feet deep, are located behind Lilliston Ford and Luther Acres, a\nsenior housing complex.\nThe birds' deaths last week prompted concerns and a DEP investigation.\nKaskey said conditions in the shallow basins were perfect for fostering\nincreased levels of the bacteria, noting that botulism naturally occurs in\nbodies of water. Those conditions included stagnant water, where oxygen\nlevels are low. A contributing factor was that the water was warmer, and\ncolder water holds oxygen better. The large number of birds also added to\nlow oxygen levels with their feces. And runoff into the basin likely\nincluded fertilizers, which added nutrients.\nThe nutrients created an algae bloom that traditionally creates oxygen. But\nas the bloom died, it further depleted the oxygen in the water.This caused\nthe fish to die, with Kaskey noting that even carp, considered a sturdy\nfish, were rising to the surface and gasping for air.\nKaskey said botulism thrives in dead fish. \"The next step is maggots in the\nfish, which are then concentrating botulism in their bodies. And the\nwaterfowl are eating the maggots and dying from it,\" he said. In order to\nstem the avian deaths, Kaskey said the city has been diligent about\nremoving dead fish and bird carcasses.\nWhile pesticides were considered culprits, an analysis of the birds' brains\nproved otherwise, Kaskey said. \"Ultimately, this should fade away,\" Kaskey\nsaid. \"In the long term, one could install a fountain in the basins to keep\nwater moving and keep oxygen at normal levels.\"\nKaskey noted that a similar situation in Millville was remedied that way.\nAlso, residents around the pond should strictly follow directions on\nfertilizers to make sure they are not overdoing it. Excess fertilizer will\nend up in the basins, contributing more nutrients. Lastly, feeding the\ngeese and ducks should be curbed. Fewer birds attracted to the basins would\nmean lower amounts of feces.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Avian botulism is seen most often in regions other than NJ. However, it\nwill occur where the conditions are favorable.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_ elaborates\n7 types of antigenically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of which affect humans:\ntype A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxins types A and B are highly poisonous\nproteins resistant to digestion by GI enzymes. Approximately 50 percent of\nfoodborne outbreaks in the USA are caused by type A toxin, followed by\ntypes B and E.\nType C botulism occurs principally in waterfowl and other birds living in\nan aquatic environment and causes tremendous losses, most notably in\nwaterfowl in the western US. In addition to North America, it has been\nreported in birds in Europe, South Africa, Uruguay, and Australia. In the\nGreat Lakes region, it was first identified in 1936 in ducks on Green Bay\nof Lake Michigan and in 1941 in Monroe County marshes along Lake Erie. Type\nC is most often associated with limberneck paralysis in birds.\nType E botulism is connected with consumption of fish and occurs mainly in\ngulls and loons, and to a lesser extent in mergansers, mute swans, grebes,\nand shorebirds. It now appears that any birds or mammals susceptible to\nbotulinum toxin run a risk of becoming poisoned if they scavenge dead fish.\nEvidence for this includes the identification of type E toxin in a bald\neagle, wood ducks, and muskrats with fish remaining in their digestive tracts.\n_C. botulinum_ spores are relatively heat-resistant, though high\ntemperatures and/or exposure to moist heat will kill the spores.\nToxins, on the other hand, are readily destroyed by heat and by cooking\nfood. Toxin production (especially type E) can occur at temperatures as low\nas 3 degrees C (37.4 degrees F), i.e., inside a refrigerator, and does not\nrequire strict anaerobic conditions.\nHuman illness from Type E is most often associated with improperly smoked\nfish. Since the toxin is destroyed by heat, it appears that no problem with\nbotulism will result from eating cooked waterfowl. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20030111.0097\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan 20030101.0001\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (02) 20030106.0045\n2002\n----\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(03) 20021209.6023\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(02 20021011.5519\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, Usa (Lake Erie) 20021010.5508\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20021228.6142\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\nBotulism, avian: cause & cure 19990719.1219\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, current status - USA 19980918.1879\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n................mpp/tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Taiwan (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203383", "date": "2003-07-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN \u00ad USA (NEW JERSEY)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 25 Jul 2003\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Press of Atlantic City [edited]\n<http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/cumberland/071903GOOSEPOOP2.html>\n\nThe state Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) determined that\nbotulism caused 70 geese and ducks to die at local retention basins.\n\"It's avian botulism, which is [caused by] a [bacterium],\" said Jack\nKaskey, a DEP spokesman, Friday. \"It is not a health threat to people.\"\n[_Clostridium botulinum_ is one of the bacteria responsible for the\nproduction of the toxin botulinum, which is responsible for the toxic\ncondition known as botulism. \u00ad Mod.TG]\nThe determination came from blood samples investigators took from sick\nbirds at the 3 basins near Delsea Drive and Sarah Place. The basins, which\nare 3 feet deep, are located behind Lilliston Ford and Luther Acres, a\nsenior housing complex.\nThe birds' deaths last week prompted concerns and a DEP investigation.\nKaskey said conditions in the shallow basins were perfect for fostering\nincreased levels of the bacteria, noting that botulism naturally occurs in\nbodies of water. Those conditions included stagnant water, where oxygen\nlevels are low. A contributing factor was that the water was warmer, and\ncolder water holds oxygen better. The large number of birds also added to\nlow oxygen levels with their feces. And runoff into the basin likely\nincluded fertilizers, which added nutrients.\nThe nutrients created an algae bloom that traditionally creates oxygen. But\nas the bloom died, it further depleted the oxygen in the water.This caused\nthe fish to die, with Kaskey noting that even carp, considered a sturdy\nfish, were rising to the surface and gasping for air.\nKaskey said botulism thrives in dead fish. \"The next step is maggots in the\nfish, which are then concentrating botulism in their bodies. And the\nwaterfowl are eating the maggots and dying from it,\" he said. In order to\nstem the avian deaths, Kaskey said the city has been diligent about\nremoving dead fish and bird carcasses.\nWhile pesticides were considered culprits, an analysis of the birds' brains\nproved otherwise, Kaskey said. \"Ultimately, this should fade away,\" Kaskey\nsaid. \"In the long term, one could install a fountain in the basins to keep\nwater moving and keep oxygen at normal levels.\"\nKaskey noted that a similar situation in Millville was remedied that way.\nAlso, residents around the pond should strictly follow directions on\nfertilizers to make sure they are not overdoing it. Excess fertilizer will\nend up in the basins, contributing more nutrients. Lastly, feeding the\ngeese and ducks should be curbed. Fewer birds attracted to the basins would\nmean lower amounts of feces.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Avian botulism is seen most often in regions other than NJ. However, it\nwill occur where the conditions are favorable.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_ elaborates\n7 types of antigenically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of which affect humans:\ntype A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxins types A and B are highly poisonous\nproteins resistant to digestion by GI enzymes. Approximately 50 percent of\nfoodborne outbreaks in the USA are caused by type A toxin, followed by\ntypes B and E.\nType C botulism occurs principally in waterfowl and other birds living in\nan aquatic environment and causes tremendous losses, most notably in\nwaterfowl in the western US. In addition to North America, it has been\nreported in birds in Europe, South Africa, Uruguay, and Australia. In the\nGreat Lakes region, it was first identified in 1936 in ducks on Green Bay\nof Lake Michigan and in 1941 in Monroe County marshes along Lake Erie. Type\nC is most often associated with limberneck paralysis in birds.\nType E botulism is connected with consumption of fish and occurs mainly in\ngulls and loons, and to a lesser extent in mergansers, mute swans, grebes,\nand shorebirds. It now appears that any birds or mammals susceptible to\nbotulinum toxin run a risk of becoming poisoned if they scavenge dead fish.\nEvidence for this includes the identification of type E toxin in a bald\neagle, wood ducks, and muskrats with fish remaining in their digestive tracts.\n_C. botulinum_ spores are relatively heat-resistant, though high\ntemperatures and/or exposure to moist heat will kill the spores.\nToxins, on the other hand, are readily destroyed by heat and by cooking\nfood. Toxin production (especially type E) can occur at temperatures as low\nas 3 degrees C (37.4 degrees F), i.e., inside a refrigerator, and does not\nrequire strict anaerobic conditions.\nHuman illness from Type E is most often associated with improperly smoked\nfish. Since the toxin is destroyed by heat, it appears that no problem with\nbotulism will result from eating cooked waterfowl. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20030111.0097\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan 20030101.0001\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (02) 20030106.0045\n2002\n----\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(03) 20021209.6023\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(02 20021011.5519\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, Usa (Lake Erie) 20021010.5508\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20021228.6142\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\nBotulism, avian: cause & cure 19990719.1219\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, current status - USA 19980918.1879\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n................mpp/tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "1936-03-15 00:00:00", "1941-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Usa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monroe County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Great Lakes", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Millville", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203328", "headline": "PRO> Botulism, bottled garlic - Denmark (03): discussion", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203328", "date": "2003-07-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN \u00ad USA (NEW JERSEY)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 25 Jul 2003\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Press of Atlantic City [edited]\n<http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/cumberland/071903GOOSEPOOP2.html>\n\nThe state Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) determined that\nbotulism caused 70 geese and ducks to die at local retention basins.\n\"It's avian botulism, which is [caused by] a [bacterium],\" said Jack\nKaskey, a DEP spokesman, Friday. \"It is not a health threat to people.\"\n[_Clostridium botulinum_ is one of the bacteria responsible for the\nproduction of the toxin botulinum, which is responsible for the toxic\ncondition known as botulism. \u00ad Mod.TG]\nThe determination came from blood samples investigators took from sick\nbirds at the 3 basins near Delsea Drive and Sarah Place. The basins, which\nare 3 feet deep, are located behind Lilliston Ford and Luther Acres, a\nsenior housing complex.\nThe birds' deaths last week prompted concerns and a DEP investigation.\nKaskey said conditions in the shallow basins were perfect for fostering\nincreased levels of the bacteria, noting that botulism naturally occurs in\nbodies of water. Those conditions included stagnant water, where oxygen\nlevels are low. A contributing factor was that the water was warmer, and\ncolder water holds oxygen better. The large number of birds also added to\nlow oxygen levels with their feces. And runoff into the basin likely\nincluded fertilizers, which added nutrients.\nThe nutrients created an algae bloom that traditionally creates oxygen. But\nas the bloom died, it further depleted the oxygen in the water.This caused\nthe fish to die, with Kaskey noting that even carp, considered a sturdy\nfish, were rising to the surface and gasping for air.\nKaskey said botulism thrives in dead fish. \"The next step is maggots in the\nfish, which are then concentrating botulism in their bodies. And the\nwaterfowl are eating the maggots and dying from it,\" he said. In order to\nstem the avian deaths, Kaskey said the city has been diligent about\nremoving dead fish and bird carcasses.\nWhile pesticides were considered culprits, an analysis of the birds' brains\nproved otherwise, Kaskey said. \"Ultimately, this should fade away,\" Kaskey\nsaid. \"In the long term, one could install a fountain in the basins to keep\nwater moving and keep oxygen at normal levels.\"\nKaskey noted that a similar situation in Millville was remedied that way.\nAlso, residents around the pond should strictly follow directions on\nfertilizers to make sure they are not overdoing it. Excess fertilizer will\nend up in the basins, contributing more nutrients. Lastly, feeding the\ngeese and ducks should be curbed. Fewer birds attracted to the basins would\nmean lower amounts of feces.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Avian botulism is seen most often in regions other than NJ. However, it\nwill occur where the conditions are favorable.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_ elaborates\n7 types of antigenically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of which affect humans:\ntype A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxins types A and B are highly poisonous\nproteins resistant to digestion by GI enzymes. Approximately 50 percent of\nfoodborne outbreaks in the USA are caused by type A toxin, followed by\ntypes B and E.\nType C botulism occurs principally in waterfowl and other birds living in\nan aquatic environment and causes tremendous losses, most notably in\nwaterfowl in the western US. In addition to North America, it has been\nreported in birds in Europe, South Africa, Uruguay, and Australia. In the\nGreat Lakes region, it was first identified in 1936 in ducks on Green Bay\nof Lake Michigan and in 1941 in Monroe County marshes along Lake Erie. Type\nC is most often associated with limberneck paralysis in birds.\nType E botulism is connected with consumption of fish and occurs mainly in\ngulls and loons, and to a lesser extent in mergansers, mute swans, grebes,\nand shorebirds. It now appears that any birds or mammals susceptible to\nbotulinum toxin run a risk of becoming poisoned if they scavenge dead fish.\nEvidence for this includes the identification of type E toxin in a bald\neagle, wood ducks, and muskrats with fish remaining in their digestive tracts.\n_C. botulinum_ spores are relatively heat-resistant, though high\ntemperatures and/or exposure to moist heat will kill the spores.\nToxins, on the other hand, are readily destroyed by heat and by cooking\nfood. Toxin production (especially type E) can occur at temperatures as low\nas 3 degrees C (37.4 degrees F), i.e., inside a refrigerator, and does not\nrequire strict anaerobic conditions.\nHuman illness from Type E is most often associated with improperly smoked\nfish. Since the toxin is destroyed by heat, it appears that no problem with\nbotulism will result from eating cooked waterfowl. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20030111.0097\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan 20030101.0001\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (02) 20030106.0045\n2002\n----\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(03) 20021209.6023\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(02 20021011.5519\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, Usa (Lake Erie) 20021010.5508\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20021228.6142\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\nBotulism, avian: cause & cure 19990719.1219\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, current status - USA 19980918.1879\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n................mpp/tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Denmark (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203279", "date": "2003-07-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN \u00ad USA (NEW JERSEY)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 25 Jul 2003\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Press of Atlantic City [edited]\n<http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/cumberland/071903GOOSEPOOP2.html>\n\nThe state Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) determined that\nbotulism caused 70 geese and ducks to die at local retention basins.\n\"It's avian botulism, which is [caused by] a [bacterium],\" said Jack\nKaskey, a DEP spokesman, Friday. \"It is not a health threat to people.\"\n[_Clostridium botulinum_ is one of the bacteria responsible for the\nproduction of the toxin botulinum, which is responsible for the toxic\ncondition known as botulism. \u00ad Mod.TG]\nThe determination came from blood samples investigators took from sick\nbirds at the 3 basins near Delsea Drive and Sarah Place. The basins, which\nare 3 feet deep, are located behind Lilliston Ford and Luther Acres, a\nsenior housing complex.\nThe birds' deaths last week prompted concerns and a DEP investigation.\nKaskey said conditions in the shallow basins were perfect for fostering\nincreased levels of the bacteria, noting that botulism naturally occurs in\nbodies of water. Those conditions included stagnant water, where oxygen\nlevels are low. A contributing factor was that the water was warmer, and\ncolder water holds oxygen better. The large number of birds also added to\nlow oxygen levels with their feces. And runoff into the basin likely\nincluded fertilizers, which added nutrients.\nThe nutrients created an algae bloom that traditionally creates oxygen. But\nas the bloom died, it further depleted the oxygen in the water.This caused\nthe fish to die, with Kaskey noting that even carp, considered a sturdy\nfish, were rising to the surface and gasping for air.\nKaskey said botulism thrives in dead fish. \"The next step is maggots in the\nfish, which are then concentrating botulism in their bodies. And the\nwaterfowl are eating the maggots and dying from it,\" he said. In order to\nstem the avian deaths, Kaskey said the city has been diligent about\nremoving dead fish and bird carcasses.\nWhile pesticides were considered culprits, an analysis of the birds' brains\nproved otherwise, Kaskey said. \"Ultimately, this should fade away,\" Kaskey\nsaid. \"In the long term, one could install a fountain in the basins to keep\nwater moving and keep oxygen at normal levels.\"\nKaskey noted that a similar situation in Millville was remedied that way.\nAlso, residents around the pond should strictly follow directions on\nfertilizers to make sure they are not overdoing it. Excess fertilizer will\nend up in the basins, contributing more nutrients. Lastly, feeding the\ngeese and ducks should be curbed. Fewer birds attracted to the basins would\nmean lower amounts of feces.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Avian botulism is seen most often in regions other than NJ. However, it\nwill occur where the conditions are favorable.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_ elaborates\n7 types of antigenically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of which affect humans:\ntype A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxins types A and B are highly poisonous\nproteins resistant to digestion by GI enzymes. Approximately 50 percent of\nfoodborne outbreaks in the USA are caused by type A toxin, followed by\ntypes B and E.\nType C botulism occurs principally in waterfowl and other birds living in\nan aquatic environment and causes tremendous losses, most notably in\nwaterfowl in the western US. In addition to North America, it has been\nreported in birds in Europe, South Africa, Uruguay, and Australia. In the\nGreat Lakes region, it was first identified in 1936 in ducks on Green Bay\nof Lake Michigan and in 1941 in Monroe County marshes along Lake Erie. Type\nC is most often associated with limberneck paralysis in birds.\nType E botulism is connected with consumption of fish and occurs mainly in\ngulls and loons, and to a lesser extent in mergansers, mute swans, grebes,\nand shorebirds. It now appears that any birds or mammals susceptible to\nbotulinum toxin run a risk of becoming poisoned if they scavenge dead fish.\nEvidence for this includes the identification of type E toxin in a bald\neagle, wood ducks, and muskrats with fish remaining in their digestive tracts.\n_C. botulinum_ spores are relatively heat-resistant, though high\ntemperatures and/or exposure to moist heat will kill the spores.\nToxins, on the other hand, are readily destroyed by heat and by cooking\nfood. Toxin production (especially type E) can occur at temperatures as low\nas 3 degrees C (37.4 degrees F), i.e., inside a refrigerator, and does not\nrequire strict anaerobic conditions.\nHuman illness from Type E is most often associated with improperly smoked\nfish. Since the toxin is destroyed by heat, it appears that no problem with\nbotulism will result from eating cooked waterfowl. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20030111.0097\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan 20030101.0001\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (02) 20030106.0045\n2002\n----\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(03) 20021209.6023\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(02 20021011.5519\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, Usa (Lake Erie) 20021010.5508\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20021228.6142\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\nBotulism, avian: cause & cure 19990719.1219\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, current status - USA 19980918.1879\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n................mpp/tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Denmark", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203273", "date": "2003-07-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, AVIAN \u00ad USA (NEW JERSEY)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 25 Jul 2003\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Press of Atlantic City [edited]\n<http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/cumberland/071903GOOSEPOOP2.html>\n\nThe state Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) determined that\nbotulism caused 70 geese and ducks to die at local retention basins.\n\"It's avian botulism, which is [caused by] a [bacterium],\" said Jack\nKaskey, a DEP spokesman, Friday. \"It is not a health threat to people.\"\n[_Clostridium botulinum_ is one of the bacteria responsible for the\nproduction of the toxin botulinum, which is responsible for the toxic\ncondition known as botulism. \u00ad Mod.TG]\nThe determination came from blood samples investigators took from sick\nbirds at the 3 basins near Delsea Drive and Sarah Place. The basins, which\nare 3 feet deep, are located behind Lilliston Ford and Luther Acres, a\nsenior housing complex.\nThe birds' deaths last week prompted concerns and a DEP investigation.\nKaskey said conditions in the shallow basins were perfect for fostering\nincreased levels of the bacteria, noting that botulism naturally occurs in\nbodies of water. Those conditions included stagnant water, where oxygen\nlevels are low. A contributing factor was that the water was warmer, and\ncolder water holds oxygen better. The large number of birds also added to\nlow oxygen levels with their feces. And runoff into the basin likely\nincluded fertilizers, which added nutrients.\nThe nutrients created an algae bloom that traditionally creates oxygen. But\nas the bloom died, it further depleted the oxygen in the water.This caused\nthe fish to die, with Kaskey noting that even carp, considered a sturdy\nfish, were rising to the surface and gasping for air.\nKaskey said botulism thrives in dead fish. \"The next step is maggots in the\nfish, which are then concentrating botulism in their bodies. And the\nwaterfowl are eating the maggots and dying from it,\" he said. In order to\nstem the avian deaths, Kaskey said the city has been diligent about\nremoving dead fish and bird carcasses.\nWhile pesticides were considered culprits, an analysis of the birds' brains\nproved otherwise, Kaskey said. \"Ultimately, this should fade away,\" Kaskey\nsaid. \"In the long term, one could install a fountain in the basins to keep\nwater moving and keep oxygen at normal levels.\"\nKaskey noted that a similar situation in Millville was remedied that way.\nAlso, residents around the pond should strictly follow directions on\nfertilizers to make sure they are not overdoing it. Excess fertilizer will\nend up in the basins, contributing more nutrients. Lastly, feeding the\ngeese and ducks should be curbed. Fewer birds attracted to the basins would\nmean lower amounts of feces.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Avian botulism is seen most often in regions other than NJ. However, it\nwill occur where the conditions are favorable.\nThe sporulating anaerobic gram-positive bacillus _C. botulinum_ elaborates\n7 types of antigenically distinct neurotoxins, 4 of which affect humans:\ntype A, B, E, or rarely type F. Toxins types A and B are highly poisonous\nproteins resistant to digestion by GI enzymes. Approximately 50 percent of\nfoodborne outbreaks in the USA are caused by type A toxin, followed by\ntypes B and E.\nType C botulism occurs principally in waterfowl and other birds living in\nan aquatic environment and causes tremendous losses, most notably in\nwaterfowl in the western US. In addition to North America, it has been\nreported in birds in Europe, South Africa, Uruguay, and Australia. In the\nGreat Lakes region, it was first identified in 1936 in ducks on Green Bay\nof Lake Michigan and in 1941 in Monroe County marshes along Lake Erie. Type\nC is most often associated with limberneck paralysis in birds.\nType E botulism is connected with consumption of fish and occurs mainly in\ngulls and loons, and to a lesser extent in mergansers, mute swans, grebes,\nand shorebirds. It now appears that any birds or mammals susceptible to\nbotulinum toxin run a risk of becoming poisoned if they scavenge dead fish.\nEvidence for this includes the identification of type E toxin in a bald\neagle, wood ducks, and muskrats with fish remaining in their digestive tracts.\n_C. botulinum_ spores are relatively heat-resistant, though high\ntemperatures and/or exposure to moist heat will kill the spores.\nToxins, on the other hand, are readily destroyed by heat and by cooking\nfood. Toxin production (especially type E) can occur at temperatures as low\nas 3 degrees C (37.4 degrees F), i.e., inside a refrigerator, and does not\nrequire strict anaerobic conditions.\nHuman illness from Type E is most often associated with improperly smoked\nfish. Since the toxin is destroyed by heat, it appears that no problem with\nbotulism will result from eating cooked waterfowl. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20030111.0097\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan 20030101.0001\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (02) 20030106.0045\n2002\n----\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(03) 20021209.6023\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, USA (Lake Erie)(02 20021011.5519\nBotulism, fish, birds \u00ad Canada, Usa (Lake Erie) 20021010.5508\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (03) 20021228.6142\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n2000\n----\nBotulism, avian - USA (New York) 20001206.2135\n1999\n----\nBotulism, avian, management - Canada & USA 19990720.1226\nBotulism, avian: cause & cure 19990719.1219\n1998\n----\nBotulism, avian, current status - USA 19980918.1879\nBotulism, avian, research - Canada & USA 19980808.1555\n................mpp/tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "1936-03-15 00:00:00", "1941-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Usa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monroe County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Great Lakes", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Millville", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203224", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203224", "date": "2002-12-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS - TAIWAN (03)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 27 Dec 2002\nFrom: Banks, A-Lan <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Taipei Times, 27 Dec 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2002/12/27/188742>\n\nNew task force set up to tackle spoonbill deaths\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Council of Agriculture (COA) yesterday established a national task\nforce that will seek international assistance and strengthen domestic\necological conservation to tackle the epidemic of botulism that has killed\n66 rare black-faced spoonbills.\nCOA Chairman Lee Chin-lung was urged yesterday by legislators,\nconservationists, bird watchers, and environmentalists to tackle more\nefficiently the recent deaths of the endangered birds, which winter at the\nChiku Lagoon in Tainan County, every October to April.\nAt a closed-door meeting held at the COA yesterday, DPP Legislator Eugene\nJao said a national-level task force was necessary because the possibility\nof receiving international assistance relied on the government's active\ninvolvement.\nIt is estimated the global population of the black-faced spoonbill does not\nexceed 1000. According to Taiwanese bird watchers, 705 black-faced\nspoonbills have already been observed this winter in Taiwan. As of 24 Dec\n2002, however, 66 of them had died from _C. botulinum_ poisoning.\nLocal authorities have asked for the COA's help because the lack of\nanti-_C.botulinum_ serum resulted in a delay in rescuing sick spoonbills.\nThe COA, however, has yet to solve serum shortage.\nJao contacted Japanese experts at Japan's National Institute of Infectious\nDiseases and received a positive response. \"They are waiting for an\nofficial invitation from the government,\" Jao said. According to Yang\nJiao-yen, assistant to Jao, Motohide Takahashi, a specialist at the\ninstitute, would like to offer related technologies. In addition, Shunji\nKozaki , a veterinary professor of Osaka Prefecture University, and Takeda\nMasato -- who has dealt with recent botulism cases in birds in Japan --\nwould like to offer their experience to Taiwan.\nCOA officials said yesterday they would contact the Japanese experts soon.\nAlthough the Tainan County Government has called on volunteers to pick up\ndead fish and animals and dismantle oyster racks in an area covering 2000\nhectares since 22 Dec 2002, the real factors that have been causing the\nenvironmental deterioration in the area that fueled the botulism outbreak\nremain uncertain.\nLegislators had asked the COA to map the area in question and remove all\nthe dead fish and animal corpses. Legislators said that the COA should ask\nfor help from the military or demand financial assistance from the Council\nof Labor Affairs for hiring workers for the temporary job.\nAt the meeting, ecological experts urged the COA to set up a standard\noperating procedure (SOP) for rescuing endangered species in Taiwan because\nthe recent deaths of the black-faced spoonbills exposed the government's\nlack of preparation to deal with such an outbreak.\n\"In addition to environmental monitoring, the SOP should be able to offer\nguidelines regarding epidemic survey, treatment, and control,\" said Charles\nCheng, president of the Wild Bird Federation of Taiwan. Chiau Wen-Yan,\npresident of Wetlands Taiwan, said that he'd suggested that the agriculture\ncouncil rezone the ecological reserve.\n\"The government should have let some fish farms near the lagoon close in\nwinter and provide buffering zones to ensure sources of food for the\nendangered bird,\" Chiau said.\n[Byline: Chiu Yu-Tzu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[From the said news-item, and specifically the reference to the need for\nbotulism antiserum, it may be deduced that the suspected role of\n_C.botulinum_ in the mortality of black-faced spoonbills in Taiwan, has\nbeen confirmed. Generally, botulism in avians is caused by _C.\nbotulinum_ types C and/or E. Information on the _C.botulinum_ type,\ninvolved in this event, will be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n...................arn/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (New York City)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203208", "date": "2002-12-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS - TAIWAN (03)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 27 Dec 2002\nFrom: Banks, A-Lan <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Taipei Times, 27 Dec 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2002/12/27/188742>\n\nNew task force set up to tackle spoonbill deaths\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Council of Agriculture (COA) yesterday established a national task\nforce that will seek international assistance and strengthen domestic\necological conservation to tackle the epidemic of botulism that has killed\n66 rare black-faced spoonbills.\nCOA Chairman Lee Chin-lung was urged yesterday by legislators,\nconservationists, bird watchers, and environmentalists to tackle more\nefficiently the recent deaths of the endangered birds, which winter at the\nChiku Lagoon in Tainan County, every October to April.\nAt a closed-door meeting held at the COA yesterday, DPP Legislator Eugene\nJao said a national-level task force was necessary because the possibility\nof receiving international assistance relied on the government's active\ninvolvement.\nIt is estimated the global population of the black-faced spoonbill does not\nexceed 1000. According to Taiwanese bird watchers, 705 black-faced\nspoonbills have already been observed this winter in Taiwan. As of 24 Dec\n2002, however, 66 of them had died from _C. botulinum_ poisoning.\nLocal authorities have asked for the COA's help because the lack of\nanti-_C.botulinum_ serum resulted in a delay in rescuing sick spoonbills.\nThe COA, however, has yet to solve serum shortage.\nJao contacted Japanese experts at Japan's National Institute of Infectious\nDiseases and received a positive response. \"They are waiting for an\nofficial invitation from the government,\" Jao said. According to Yang\nJiao-yen, assistant to Jao, Motohide Takahashi, a specialist at the\ninstitute, would like to offer related technologies. In addition, Shunji\nKozaki , a veterinary professor of Osaka Prefecture University, and Takeda\nMasato -- who has dealt with recent botulism cases in birds in Japan --\nwould like to offer their experience to Taiwan.\nCOA officials said yesterday they would contact the Japanese experts soon.\nAlthough the Tainan County Government has called on volunteers to pick up\ndead fish and animals and dismantle oyster racks in an area covering 2000\nhectares since 22 Dec 2002, the real factors that have been causing the\nenvironmental deterioration in the area that fueled the botulism outbreak\nremain uncertain.\nLegislators had asked the COA to map the area in question and remove all\nthe dead fish and animal corpses. Legislators said that the COA should ask\nfor help from the military or demand financial assistance from the Council\nof Labor Affairs for hiring workers for the temporary job.\nAt the meeting, ecological experts urged the COA to set up a standard\noperating procedure (SOP) for rescuing endangered species in Taiwan because\nthe recent deaths of the black-faced spoonbills exposed the government's\nlack of preparation to deal with such an outbreak.\n\"In addition to environmental monitoring, the SOP should be able to offer\nguidelines regarding epidemic survey, treatment, and control,\" said Charles\nCheng, president of the Wild Bird Federation of Taiwan. Chiau Wen-Yan,\npresident of Wetlands Taiwan, said that he'd suggested that the agriculture\ncouncil rezone the ecological reserve.\n\"The government should have let some fish farms near the lagoon close in\nwinter and provide buffering zones to ensure sources of food for the\nendangered bird,\" Chiau said.\n[Byline: Chiu Yu-Tzu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[From the said news-item, and specifically the reference to the need for\nbotulism antiserum, it may be deduced that the suspected role of\n_C.botulinum_ in the mortality of black-faced spoonbills in Taiwan, has\nbeen confirmed. Generally, botulism in avians is caused by _C.\nbotulinum_ types C and/or E. Information on the _C.botulinum_ type,\ninvolved in this event, will be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n...................arn/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
