USA (Alaska)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203206", "date": "2002-12-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS - TAIWAN (03)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 27 Dec 2002\nFrom: Banks, A-Lan <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Taipei Times, 27 Dec 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2002/12/27/188742>\n\nNew task force set up to tackle spoonbill deaths\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Council of Agriculture (COA) yesterday established a national task\nforce that will seek international assistance and strengthen domestic\necological conservation to tackle the epidemic of botulism that has killed\n66 rare black-faced spoonbills.\nCOA Chairman Lee Chin-lung was urged yesterday by legislators,\nconservationists, bird watchers, and environmentalists to tackle more\nefficiently the recent deaths of the endangered birds, which winter at the\nChiku Lagoon in Tainan County, every October to April.\nAt a closed-door meeting held at the COA yesterday, DPP Legislator Eugene\nJao said a national-level task force was necessary because the possibility\nof receiving international assistance relied on the government's active\ninvolvement.\nIt is estimated the global population of the black-faced spoonbill does not\nexceed 1000. According to Taiwanese bird watchers, 705 black-faced\nspoonbills have already been observed this winter in Taiwan. As of 24 Dec\n2002, however, 66 of them had died from _C. botulinum_ poisoning.\nLocal authorities have asked for the COA's help because the lack of\nanti-_C.botulinum_ serum resulted in a delay in rescuing sick spoonbills.\nThe COA, however, has yet to solve serum shortage.\nJao contacted Japanese experts at Japan's National Institute of Infectious\nDiseases and received a positive response. \"They are waiting for an\nofficial invitation from the government,\" Jao said. According to Yang\nJiao-yen, assistant to Jao, Motohide Takahashi, a specialist at the\ninstitute, would like to offer related technologies. In addition, Shunji\nKozaki , a veterinary professor of Osaka Prefecture University, and Takeda\nMasato -- who has dealt with recent botulism cases in birds in Japan --\nwould like to offer their experience to Taiwan.\nCOA officials said yesterday they would contact the Japanese experts soon.\nAlthough the Tainan County Government has called on volunteers to pick up\ndead fish and animals and dismantle oyster racks in an area covering 2000\nhectares since 22 Dec 2002, the real factors that have been causing the\nenvironmental deterioration in the area that fueled the botulism outbreak\nremain uncertain.\nLegislators had asked the COA to map the area in question and remove all\nthe dead fish and animal corpses. Legislators said that the COA should ask\nfor help from the military or demand financial assistance from the Council\nof Labor Affairs for hiring workers for the temporary job.\nAt the meeting, ecological experts urged the COA to set up a standard\noperating procedure (SOP) for rescuing endangered species in Taiwan because\nthe recent deaths of the black-faced spoonbills exposed the government's\nlack of preparation to deal with such an outbreak.\n\"In addition to environmental monitoring, the SOP should be able to offer\nguidelines regarding epidemic survey, treatment, and control,\" said Charles\nCheng, president of the Wild Bird Federation of Taiwan. Chiau Wen-Yan,\npresident of Wetlands Taiwan, said that he'd suggested that the agriculture\ncouncil rezone the ecological reserve.\n\"The government should have let some fish farms near the lagoon close in\nwinter and provide buffering zones to ensure sources of food for the\nendangered bird,\" Chiau said.\n[Byline: Chiu Yu-Tzu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[From the said news-item, and specifically the reference to the need for\nbotulism antiserum, it may be deduced that the suspected role of\n_C.botulinum_ in the mortality of black-faced spoonbills in Taiwan, has\nbeen confirmed. Generally, botulism in avians is caused by _C.\nbotulinum_ types C and/or E. Information on the _C.botulinum_ type,\ninvolved in this event, will be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n...................arn/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Taiwan (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203171", "date": "2002-12-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS - TAIWAN (03)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 27 Dec 2002\nFrom: Banks, A-Lan <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Taipei Times, 27 Dec 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2002/12/27/188742>\n\nNew task force set up to tackle spoonbill deaths\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Council of Agriculture (COA) yesterday established a national task\nforce that will seek international assistance and strengthen domestic\necological conservation to tackle the epidemic of botulism that has killed\n66 rare black-faced spoonbills.\nCOA Chairman Lee Chin-lung was urged yesterday by legislators,\nconservationists, bird watchers, and environmentalists to tackle more\nefficiently the recent deaths of the endangered birds, which winter at the\nChiku Lagoon in Tainan County, every October to April.\nAt a closed-door meeting held at the COA yesterday, DPP Legislator Eugene\nJao said a national-level task force was necessary because the possibility\nof receiving international assistance relied on the government's active\ninvolvement.\nIt is estimated the global population of the black-faced spoonbill does not\nexceed 1000. According to Taiwanese bird watchers, 705 black-faced\nspoonbills have already been observed this winter in Taiwan. As of 24 Dec\n2002, however, 66 of them had died from _C. botulinum_ poisoning.\nLocal authorities have asked for the COA's help because the lack of\nanti-_C.botulinum_ serum resulted in a delay in rescuing sick spoonbills.\nThe COA, however, has yet to solve serum shortage.\nJao contacted Japanese experts at Japan's National Institute of Infectious\nDiseases and received a positive response. \"They are waiting for an\nofficial invitation from the government,\" Jao said. According to Yang\nJiao-yen, assistant to Jao, Motohide Takahashi, a specialist at the\ninstitute, would like to offer related technologies. In addition, Shunji\nKozaki , a veterinary professor of Osaka Prefecture University, and Takeda\nMasato -- who has dealt with recent botulism cases in birds in Japan --\nwould like to offer their experience to Taiwan.\nCOA officials said yesterday they would contact the Japanese experts soon.\nAlthough the Tainan County Government has called on volunteers to pick up\ndead fish and animals and dismantle oyster racks in an area covering 2000\nhectares since 22 Dec 2002, the real factors that have been causing the\nenvironmental deterioration in the area that fueled the botulism outbreak\nremain uncertain.\nLegislators had asked the COA to map the area in question and remove all\nthe dead fish and animal corpses. Legislators said that the COA should ask\nfor help from the military or demand financial assistance from the Council\nof Labor Affairs for hiring workers for the temporary job.\nAt the meeting, ecological experts urged the COA to set up a standard\noperating procedure (SOP) for rescuing endangered species in Taiwan because\nthe recent deaths of the black-faced spoonbills exposed the government's\nlack of preparation to deal with such an outbreak.\n\"In addition to environmental monitoring, the SOP should be able to offer\nguidelines regarding epidemic survey, treatment, and control,\" said Charles\nCheng, president of the Wild Bird Federation of Taiwan. Chiau Wen-Yan,\npresident of Wetlands Taiwan, said that he'd suggested that the agriculture\ncouncil rezone the ecological reserve.\n\"The government should have let some fish farms near the lagoon close in\nwinter and provide buffering zones to ensure sources of food for the\nendangered bird,\" Chiau said.\n[Byline: Chiu Yu-Tzu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[From the said news-item, and specifically the reference to the need for\nbotulism antiserum, it may be deduced that the suspected role of\n_C.botulinum_ in the mortality of black-faced spoonbills in Taiwan, has\nbeen confirmed. Generally, botulism in avians is caused by _C.\nbotulinum_ types C and/or E. Information on the _C.botulinum_ type,\ninvolved in this event, will be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n...................arn/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Australia (NT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203143", "date": "2002-12-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS - TAIWAN (03)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 27 Dec 2002\nFrom: Banks, A-Lan <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Taipei Times, 27 Dec 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2002/12/27/188742>\n\nNew task force set up to tackle spoonbill deaths\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Council of Agriculture (COA) yesterday established a national task\nforce that will seek international assistance and strengthen domestic\necological conservation to tackle the epidemic of botulism that has killed\n66 rare black-faced spoonbills.\nCOA Chairman Lee Chin-lung was urged yesterday by legislators,\nconservationists, bird watchers, and environmentalists to tackle more\nefficiently the recent deaths of the endangered birds, which winter at the\nChiku Lagoon in Tainan County, every October to April.\nAt a closed-door meeting held at the COA yesterday, DPP Legislator Eugene\nJao said a national-level task force was necessary because the possibility\nof receiving international assistance relied on the government's active\ninvolvement.\nIt is estimated the global population of the black-faced spoonbill does not\nexceed 1000. According to Taiwanese bird watchers, 705 black-faced\nspoonbills have already been observed this winter in Taiwan. As of 24 Dec\n2002, however, 66 of them had died from _C. botulinum_ poisoning.\nLocal authorities have asked for the COA's help because the lack of\nanti-_C.botulinum_ serum resulted in a delay in rescuing sick spoonbills.\nThe COA, however, has yet to solve serum shortage.\nJao contacted Japanese experts at Japan's National Institute of Infectious\nDiseases and received a positive response. \"They are waiting for an\nofficial invitation from the government,\" Jao said. According to Yang\nJiao-yen, assistant to Jao, Motohide Takahashi, a specialist at the\ninstitute, would like to offer related technologies. In addition, Shunji\nKozaki , a veterinary professor of Osaka Prefecture University, and Takeda\nMasato -- who has dealt with recent botulism cases in birds in Japan --\nwould like to offer their experience to Taiwan.\nCOA officials said yesterday they would contact the Japanese experts soon.\nAlthough the Tainan County Government has called on volunteers to pick up\ndead fish and animals and dismantle oyster racks in an area covering 2000\nhectares since 22 Dec 2002, the real factors that have been causing the\nenvironmental deterioration in the area that fueled the botulism outbreak\nremain uncertain.\nLegislators had asked the COA to map the area in question and remove all\nthe dead fish and animal corpses. Legislators said that the COA should ask\nfor help from the military or demand financial assistance from the Council\nof Labor Affairs for hiring workers for the temporary job.\nAt the meeting, ecological experts urged the COA to set up a standard\noperating procedure (SOP) for rescuing endangered species in Taiwan because\nthe recent deaths of the black-faced spoonbills exposed the government's\nlack of preparation to deal with such an outbreak.\n\"In addition to environmental monitoring, the SOP should be able to offer\nguidelines regarding epidemic survey, treatment, and control,\" said Charles\nCheng, president of the Wild Bird Federation of Taiwan. Chiau Wen-Yan,\npresident of Wetlands Taiwan, said that he'd suggested that the agriculture\ncouncil rezone the ecological reserve.\n\"The government should have let some fish farms near the lagoon close in\nwinter and provide buffering zones to ensure sources of food for the\nendangered bird,\" Chiau said.\n[Byline: Chiu Yu-Tzu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[From the said news-item, and specifically the reference to the need for\nbotulism antiserum, it may be deduced that the suspected role of\n_C.botulinum_ in the mortality of black-faced spoonbills in Taiwan, has\nbeen confirmed. Generally, botulism in avians is caused by _C.\nbotulinum_ types C and/or E. Information on the _C.botulinum_ type,\ninvolved in this event, will be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n...................arn/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Taiwan (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203130", "date": "2002-12-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS - TAIWAN (03)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 27 Dec 2002\nFrom: Banks, A-Lan <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Taipei Times, 27 Dec 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2002/12/27/188742>\n\nNew task force set up to tackle spoonbill deaths\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Council of Agriculture (COA) yesterday established a national task\nforce that will seek international assistance and strengthen domestic\necological conservation to tackle the epidemic of botulism that has killed\n66 rare black-faced spoonbills.\nCOA Chairman Lee Chin-lung was urged yesterday by legislators,\nconservationists, bird watchers, and environmentalists to tackle more\nefficiently the recent deaths of the endangered birds, which winter at the\nChiku Lagoon in Tainan County, every October to April.\nAt a closed-door meeting held at the COA yesterday, DPP Legislator Eugene\nJao said a national-level task force was necessary because the possibility\nof receiving international assistance relied on the government's active\ninvolvement.\nIt is estimated the global population of the black-faced spoonbill does not\nexceed 1000. According to Taiwanese bird watchers, 705 black-faced\nspoonbills have already been observed this winter in Taiwan. As of 24 Dec\n2002, however, 66 of them had died from _C. botulinum_ poisoning.\nLocal authorities have asked for the COA's help because the lack of\nanti-_C.botulinum_ serum resulted in a delay in rescuing sick spoonbills.\nThe COA, however, has yet to solve serum shortage.\nJao contacted Japanese experts at Japan's National Institute of Infectious\nDiseases and received a positive response. \"They are waiting for an\nofficial invitation from the government,\" Jao said. According to Yang\nJiao-yen, assistant to Jao, Motohide Takahashi, a specialist at the\ninstitute, would like to offer related technologies. In addition, Shunji\nKozaki , a veterinary professor of Osaka Prefecture University, and Takeda\nMasato -- who has dealt with recent botulism cases in birds in Japan --\nwould like to offer their experience to Taiwan.\nCOA officials said yesterday they would contact the Japanese experts soon.\nAlthough the Tainan County Government has called on volunteers to pick up\ndead fish and animals and dismantle oyster racks in an area covering 2000\nhectares since 22 Dec 2002, the real factors that have been causing the\nenvironmental deterioration in the area that fueled the botulism outbreak\nremain uncertain.\nLegislators had asked the COA to map the area in question and remove all\nthe dead fish and animal corpses. Legislators said that the COA should ask\nfor help from the military or demand financial assistance from the Council\nof Labor Affairs for hiring workers for the temporary job.\nAt the meeting, ecological experts urged the COA to set up a standard\noperating procedure (SOP) for rescuing endangered species in Taiwan because\nthe recent deaths of the black-faced spoonbills exposed the government's\nlack of preparation to deal with such an outbreak.\n\"In addition to environmental monitoring, the SOP should be able to offer\nguidelines regarding epidemic survey, treatment, and control,\" said Charles\nCheng, president of the Wild Bird Federation of Taiwan. Chiau Wen-Yan,\npresident of Wetlands Taiwan, said that he'd suggested that the agriculture\ncouncil rezone the ecological reserve.\n\"The government should have let some fish farms near the lagoon close in\nwinter and provide buffering zones to ensure sources of food for the\nendangered bird,\" Chiau said.\n[Byline: Chiu Yu-Tzu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[From the said news-item, and specifically the reference to the need for\nbotulism antiserum, it may be deduced that the suspected role of\n_C.botulinum_ in the mortality of black-faced spoonbills in Taiwan, has\nbeen confirmed. Generally, botulism in avians is caused by _C.\nbotulinum_ types C and/or E. Information on the _C.botulinum_ type,\ninvolved in this event, will be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n...................arn/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Taiwan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203109", "date": "2002-12-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS - TAIWAN (03)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 27 Dec 2002\nFrom: Banks, A-Lan <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Taipei Times, 27 Dec 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2002/12/27/188742>\n\nNew task force set up to tackle spoonbill deaths\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Council of Agriculture (COA) yesterday established a national task\nforce that will seek international assistance and strengthen domestic\necological conservation to tackle the epidemic of botulism that has killed\n66 rare black-faced spoonbills.\nCOA Chairman Lee Chin-lung was urged yesterday by legislators,\nconservationists, bird watchers, and environmentalists to tackle more\nefficiently the recent deaths of the endangered birds, which winter at the\nChiku Lagoon in Tainan County, every October to April.\nAt a closed-door meeting held at the COA yesterday, DPP Legislator Eugene\nJao said a national-level task force was necessary because the possibility\nof receiving international assistance relied on the government's active\ninvolvement.\nIt is estimated the global population of the black-faced spoonbill does not\nexceed 1000. According to Taiwanese bird watchers, 705 black-faced\nspoonbills have already been observed this winter in Taiwan. As of 24 Dec\n2002, however, 66 of them had died from _C. botulinum_ poisoning.\nLocal authorities have asked for the COA's help because the lack of\nanti-_C.botulinum_ serum resulted in a delay in rescuing sick spoonbills.\nThe COA, however, has yet to solve serum shortage.\nJao contacted Japanese experts at Japan's National Institute of Infectious\nDiseases and received a positive response. \"They are waiting for an\nofficial invitation from the government,\" Jao said. According to Yang\nJiao-yen, assistant to Jao, Motohide Takahashi, a specialist at the\ninstitute, would like to offer related technologies. In addition, Shunji\nKozaki , a veterinary professor of Osaka Prefecture University, and Takeda\nMasato -- who has dealt with recent botulism cases in birds in Japan --\nwould like to offer their experience to Taiwan.\nCOA officials said yesterday they would contact the Japanese experts soon.\nAlthough the Tainan County Government has called on volunteers to pick up\ndead fish and animals and dismantle oyster racks in an area covering 2000\nhectares since 22 Dec 2002, the real factors that have been causing the\nenvironmental deterioration in the area that fueled the botulism outbreak\nremain uncertain.\nLegislators had asked the COA to map the area in question and remove all\nthe dead fish and animal corpses. Legislators said that the COA should ask\nfor help from the military or demand financial assistance from the Council\nof Labor Affairs for hiring workers for the temporary job.\nAt the meeting, ecological experts urged the COA to set up a standard\noperating procedure (SOP) for rescuing endangered species in Taiwan because\nthe recent deaths of the black-faced spoonbills exposed the government's\nlack of preparation to deal with such an outbreak.\n\"In addition to environmental monitoring, the SOP should be able to offer\nguidelines regarding epidemic survey, treatment, and control,\" said Charles\nCheng, president of the Wild Bird Federation of Taiwan. Chiau Wen-Yan,\npresident of Wetlands Taiwan, said that he'd suggested that the agriculture\ncouncil rezone the ecological reserve.\n\"The government should have let some fish farms near the lagoon close in\nwinter and provide buffering zones to ensure sources of food for the\nendangered bird,\" Chiau said.\n[Byline: Chiu Yu-Tzu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[From the said news-item, and specifically the reference to the need for\nbotulism antiserum, it may be deduced that the suspected role of\n_C.botulinum_ in the mortality of black-faced spoonbills in Taiwan, has\nbeen confirmed. Generally, botulism in avians is caused by _C.\nbotulinum_ types C and/or E. Information on the _C.botulinum_ type,\ninvolved in this event, will be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n...................arn/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Taiwan (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203096", "date": "2002-12-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS - TAIWAN (03)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 27 Dec 2002\nFrom: Banks, A-Lan <A-Lan.Banks@derwent.co.uk>\nSource: Taipei Times, 27 Dec 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2002/12/27/188742>\n\nNew task force set up to tackle spoonbill deaths\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Council of Agriculture (COA) yesterday established a national task\nforce that will seek international assistance and strengthen domestic\necological conservation to tackle the epidemic of botulism that has killed\n66 rare black-faced spoonbills.\nCOA Chairman Lee Chin-lung was urged yesterday by legislators,\nconservationists, bird watchers, and environmentalists to tackle more\nefficiently the recent deaths of the endangered birds, which winter at the\nChiku Lagoon in Tainan County, every October to April.\nAt a closed-door meeting held at the COA yesterday, DPP Legislator Eugene\nJao said a national-level task force was necessary because the possibility\nof receiving international assistance relied on the government's active\ninvolvement.\nIt is estimated the global population of the black-faced spoonbill does not\nexceed 1000. According to Yang\nJiao-yen, assistant to Jao, Motohide Takahashi, a specialist at the\ninstitute, would like to offer related technologies. In addition, Shunji\nKozaki , a veterinary professor of Osaka Prefecture University, and Takeda\nMasato -- who has dealt with recent botulism cases in birds in Japan --\nwould like to offer their experience to Taiwan.\nCOA officials said yesterday they would contact the Japanese experts soon.\nAlthough the Tainan County Government has called on volunteers to pick up\ndead fish and animals and dismantle oyster racks in an area covering 2000\nhectares since 22 Dec 2002, the real factors that have been causing the\nenvironmental deterioration in the area that fueled the botulism outbreak\nremain uncertain.\nLegislators had asked the COA to map the area in question and remove all\nthe dead fish and animal corpses. Legislators said that the COA should ask\nfor help from the military or demand financial assistance from the Council\nof Labor Affairs for hiring workers for the temporary job.\nAt the meeting, ecological experts urged the COA to set up a standard\noperating procedure (SOP) for rescuing endangered species in Taiwan because\nthe recent deaths of the black-faced spoonbills exposed the government's\nlack of preparation to deal with such an outbreak.\n\"In addition to environmental monitoring, the SOP should be able to offer\nguidelines regarding epidemic survey, treatment, and control,\" said Charles\nCheng, president of the Wild Bird Federation of Taiwan. Chiau Wen-Yan,\npresident of Wetlands Taiwan, said that he'd suggested that the agriculture\ncouncil rezone the ecological reserve.\n\"The government should have let some fish farms near the lagoon close in\nwinter and provide buffering zones to ensure sources of food for the\nendangered bird,\" Chiau said.\n[Byline: Chiu Yu-Tzu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[From the said news-item, and specifically the reference to the need for\nbotulism antiserum, it may be deduced that the suspected role of\n_C.botulinum_ in the mortality of black-faced spoonbills in Taiwan, has\nbeen confirmed. Generally, botulism in avians is caused by _C.\nbotulinum_ types C and/or E. Information on the _C.botulinum_ type,\ninvolved in this event, will be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02) 20021219.6095\nBotulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: suspected 20021211.6040\n...................arn/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-12-27 00:00:00", "2002-12-27 00:00:00", "2002-12-15 00:00:00", "2002-12-22 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tainan County", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "TAIWAN", "country": "Taiwan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203065", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, black-faced spoonbills - Taiwan: susp (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203065", "date": "2002-10-31 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - UK, IRELAND\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 31 Oct 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly Volume 6 / Issue 44 31 Oct 2001 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2002/021031.asp>\n\nCluster of wound botulism cases in injecting drug users in the United\nKingdom and the Republic of Ireland\n--------------------------------\nSince 1 Aug 2002, 6 cases of wound botulism in injecting drug users (IDUs)\nhave been reported by the Public Health Laboratory Service Food Safety\nMicrobiology Laboratory (PHLS FSML) in London (1). This brings the total\nnumber of clinically diagnosed cases of wound botulism in IDUs reported in\nthe United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland to 13 in 2002 (2, 3). The recent\ncases may be caused by a batch of drugs contaminated with the anaerobic\nbacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Reports of wound botulism in IDUs are a\nrelatively new phenomenon with no clinically diagnosed cases in the UK and\nRepublic of Ireland up to the end of 1999. There were, however, 6 reports\nin 2000 and 4 in 2001 (4 and references therein, 5 and references therein).\nCases of wound botulism in Europe, although rare, continue to be reported.\nIn recent years reports of suspected botulism in IDUs have come from Norway\n(6) and Switzerland (7).\nWound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a wound,\ngerminate, and produce botulinum toxin in vivo. The symptoms of botulism\nare caused by the toxin, which blocks the release of acetycholine at the\nneuromuscular junction resulting in a descending flaccid paralysis.\nPatients with botulism may present with blurred vision, drooping eyelids,\nslurred speech, difficulty swallowing, dry mouth, and muscle weakness.\nThere is usually no fever, no loss of sensation and no loss of awareness.\nIf untreated, paralysis may progress to the arms, legs, trunk and\nrespiratory muscles. If onset is very rapid, there may be no symptoms\nbefore sudden respiratory paralysis occurs. Clinicians should suspect\nbotulism in any patient with an afebrile, descending, flaccid paralysis.\nBotulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the severity of symptoms if\nadministered early in the course of the disease. _C. botulinum_ is\nsensitive to benzyl penicillin and metronidazole. In cases of wound\ninfection, antimicrobial therapy and surgical debridement should reduce the\norganism load and therefore toxin production, but circulating toxin can\nonly be neutralised by the early administration of antitoxin. Where there\nis a definite clinical suspicion of botulism, treatment with antitoxin\nshould not be delayed pending microbiological testing.\nIDUs are susceptible to wound botulism when anaerobic conditions exist at\ninjection sites. Injecting drug users should be advised to smoke heroin\nrather than inject and to avoid injecting into muscle or under the skin\n(skin popping). The injection of substances that increase tissue damage may\nfacilitate the growth of anaerobic bacteria and therefore IDUs should try\nto use as little citric acid as possible to dissolve heroin, and should\navoid the injection of mixtures of heroin and cocaine. They should also be\nadvised to seek urgent medical attention if they develop swelling, redness,\nor pain at injecting sites.\nInvestigators (see email addresses below) at the PHLS in England and Wales\nwould be interested to hear of any recent cases of botulism in IDUs in\nother European countries.\nReferences :\n1.CDSC. Cluster of wound botulism cases in injecting drug users. Commun Dis\nRep CDR Wkly 2002; 12(44): news.\n2. O'Brien S, Reid A, De Benoist A-C. Temporal cluster of wound botulism in\nthe United Kingdom. Eurosurveillance Weekly 2002 6:020228.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2002/020228.html>\n3. Barry J, Thornton L, Igoe D. Case of botulism in Ireland.\nEurosurveillance Weekly 2002; 6:020328.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2002/020328.html>\n4. Khan M, Chay S, Bonner S, Brett M. Wound botulism in injecting drug\nuser: second case in England. Eurosurveillance Weekly 2000; 4:000622.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2000/000622.htm#3>\n5.Goldberg D. Wound botulism in an injecting drug user in Scotland.\nEurosurveillance Weekly 2001; 5:021011\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2001/011011.htm>\n6.Jensen T, Jacobsen D, von der Lippe E, Heier MS, Selseth B. Clinical\nwound botulism in injecting drug addicts [in Norwegian]. Tidsskr Nor\nLaegeforen 1998; 118:4363-5.\n7. Sautter T, Herzog A, Hauri D, Schurch B. Transient paralysis of the\nbladder due to wound botulism. Eur Urol 2001; 39: 610-2.\nReported by Peter Horby (<phorby@phls.org.uk>) and Alison Brown\n(<abrown@phls.org.uk>) Public Health Laboratory Service Communicable\nDisease Surveillance Centre, London, England.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Borrowing from a prior ProMED-mail posting moderator comment (Botulism,\nwound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614), wound botulism has been\nreported in injecting drug users (IDUs) in the United States and in\nEurope. Association with drug injection was first reported in 1982 in New\nYork City (1). In 1995 there were 19 cases reported in California\nassociated with contaminated black tar heroin (2). In 1998 there was an\noutbreak of 5 cases reported in Switzerland, all associated with illicit\ninjection drug use.\nIn October 2001 ProMED reported a case of wound botulism in Scotland, and\nquestioned whether the heightened surveillance for unusual illness in IDUs,\nas an aftermath of the outbreak of _C. novyi_ associated with contaminated\nheroin might have led to isolated case reports. In this article there is\nmention of 13 cases since the beginning of the year, suggesting the\npossibility of a contaminated batch of heroin on the market in the UK,\nsomewhat reminiscent of the outbreak in California in 1995 (2). One wonders\nif other countries have been seeing a similar increase in wound botulism in\nrecent months.\n1. CDC. Wound Botulism Associated with Parenteral Cocaine Abuse -- New\nYork City. MMWR. 26 Feb 1982 /\n31(7);87-8 <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00000208.htm>\n2. CDC. Wound Botulism -- California, 1995. MMWR. 8 Dec 1995 /\n44(48);889-892 <http://www.cdc.gov/epo/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00039732.htm>\n- Mod. MPP]\nSee Also\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, Drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\n2000\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland & Scotland 20000531.0874\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland (Dublin) 20000525.0825\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK 20000608.0922\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK (07) 20000820.1388\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: diagnosis 20000615.0977\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) 20000511.0717\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) (09) 20000522.0807\n............................mpp/pg/dk\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-08-01 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1982-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-10-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1982-02-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norway", "country": "Norway"}, {"location": "New \n York City", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "York City", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hauri", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "Antarctica"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "London", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland", "country": "Antarctica"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "- Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203049", "headline": "PRO> Botulism, blue cheese - Canada (Quebec) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203049", "date": "2002-10-31 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - UK, IRELAND\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 31 Oct 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly Volume 6 / Issue 44 31 Oct 2001 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2002/021031.asp>\n\nCluster of wound botulism cases in injecting drug users in the United\nKingdom and the Republic of Ireland\n--------------------------------\nSince 1 Aug 2002, 6 cases of wound botulism in injecting drug users (IDUs)\nhave been reported by the Public Health Laboratory Service Food Safety\nMicrobiology Laboratory (PHLS FSML) in London (1). This brings the total\nnumber of clinically diagnosed cases of wound botulism in IDUs reported in\nthe United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland to 13 in 2002 (2, 3). The recent\ncases may be caused by a batch of drugs contaminated with the anaerobic\nbacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Reports of wound botulism in IDUs are a\nrelatively new phenomenon with no clinically diagnosed cases in the UK and\nRepublic of Ireland up to the end of 1999. There were, however, 6 reports\nin 2000 and 4 in 2001 (4 and references therein, 5 and references therein).\nCases of wound botulism in Europe, although rare, continue to be reported.\nIn recent years reports of suspected botulism in IDUs have come from Norway\n(6) and Switzerland (7).\nWound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a wound,\ngerminate, and produce botulinum toxin in vivo. The symptoms of botulism\nare caused by the toxin, which blocks the release of acetycholine at the\nneuromuscular junction resulting in a descending flaccid paralysis.\nPatients with botulism may present with blurred vision, drooping eyelids,\nslurred speech, difficulty swallowing, dry mouth, and muscle weakness.\nThere is usually no fever, no loss of sensation and no loss of awareness.\nIf untreated, paralysis may progress to the arms, legs, trunk and\nrespiratory muscles. If onset is very rapid, there may be no symptoms\nbefore sudden respiratory paralysis occurs. Clinicians should suspect\nbotulism in any patient with an afebrile, descending, flaccid paralysis.\nBotulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the severity of symptoms if\nadministered early in the course of the disease. _C. botulinum_ is\nsensitive to benzyl penicillin and metronidazole. In cases of wound\ninfection, antimicrobial therapy and surgical debridement should reduce the\norganism load and therefore toxin production, but circulating toxin can\nonly be neutralised by the early administration of antitoxin. Where there\nis a definite clinical suspicion of botulism, treatment with antitoxin\nshould not be delayed pending microbiological testing.\nIDUs are susceptible to wound botulism when anaerobic conditions exist at\ninjection sites. Injecting drug users should be advised to smoke heroin\nrather than inject and to avoid injecting into muscle or under the skin\n(skin popping). The injection of substances that increase tissue damage may\nfacilitate the growth of anaerobic bacteria and therefore IDUs should try\nto use as little citric acid as possible to dissolve heroin, and should\navoid the injection of mixtures of heroin and cocaine. They should also be\nadvised to seek urgent medical attention if they develop swelling, redness,\nor pain at injecting sites.\nInvestigators (see email addresses below) at the PHLS in England and Wales\nwould be interested to hear of any recent cases of botulism in IDUs in\nother European countries.\nReferences :\n1.CDSC. Cluster of wound botulism cases in injecting drug users. Commun Dis\nRep CDR Wkly 2002; 12(44): news.\n2. O'Brien S, Reid A, De Benoist A-C. Temporal cluster of wound botulism in\nthe United Kingdom. Eurosurveillance Weekly 2002 6:020228.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2002/020228.html>\n3. Barry J, Thornton L, Igoe D. Case of botulism in Ireland.\nEurosurveillance Weekly 2002; 6:020328.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2002/020328.html>\n4. Khan M, Chay S, Bonner S, Brett M. Wound botulism in injecting drug\nuser: second case in England. Eurosurveillance Weekly 2000; 4:000622.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2000/000622.htm#3>\n5.Goldberg D. Wound botulism in an injecting drug user in Scotland.\nEurosurveillance Weekly 2001; 5:021011\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2001/011011.htm>\n6.Jensen T, Jacobsen D, von der Lippe E, Heier MS, Selseth B. Clinical\nwound botulism in injecting drug addicts [in Norwegian]. Tidsskr Nor\nLaegeforen 1998; 118:4363-5.\n7. Sautter T, Herzog A, Hauri D, Schurch B. Transient paralysis of the\nbladder due to wound botulism. Eur Urol 2001; 39: 610-2.\nReported by Peter Horby (<phorby@phls.org.uk>) and Alison Brown\n(<abrown@phls.org.uk>) Public Health Laboratory Service Communicable\nDisease Surveillance Centre, London, England.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Borrowing from a prior ProMED-mail posting moderator comment (Botulism,\nwound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614), wound botulism has been\nreported in injecting drug users (IDUs) in the United States and in\nEurope. Association with drug injection was first reported in 1982 in New\nYork City (1). In 1995 there were 19 cases reported in California\nassociated with contaminated black tar heroin (2). In 1998 there was an\noutbreak of 5 cases reported in Switzerland, all associated with illicit\ninjection drug use.\nIn October 2001 ProMED reported a case of wound botulism in Scotland, and\nquestioned whether the heightened surveillance for unusual illness in IDUs,\nas an aftermath of the outbreak of _C. novyi_ associated with contaminated\nheroin might have led to isolated case reports. In this article there is\nmention of 13 cases since the beginning of the year, suggesting the\npossibility of a contaminated batch of heroin on the market in the UK,\nsomewhat reminiscent of the outbreak in California in 1995 (2). One wonders\nif other countries have been seeing a similar increase in wound botulism in\nrecent months.\n1. CDC. Wound Botulism Associated with Parenteral Cocaine Abuse -- New\nYork City. MMWR. 26 Feb 1982 /\n31(7);87-8 <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00000208.htm>\n2. CDC. Wound Botulism -- California, 1995. MMWR. 8 Dec 1995 /\n44(48);889-892 <http://www.cdc.gov/epo/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00039732.htm>\n- Mod. MPP]\nSee Also\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, Drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\n2000\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland & Scotland 20000531.0874\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland (Dublin) 20000525.0825\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK 20000608.0922\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK (07) 20000820.1388\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: diagnosis 20000615.0977\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) 20000511.0717\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) (09) 20000522.0807\n............................mpp/pg/dk\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. In cases of wound\ninfection, antimicrobial therapy and surgical debridement should reduce the\norganism load and therefore toxin production, but circulating toxin can\nonly be neutralised by the early administration of antitoxin. Where there\nis a definite clinical suspicion of botulism, treatment with antitoxin\nshould not be delayed pending microbiological testing.\nIDUs are susceptible to wound botulism when anaerobic conditions exist at\ninjection sites. Injecting drug users should be advised to smoke heroin\nrather than inject and to avoid injecting into muscle or under the skin\n(skin popping). The injection of substances that increase tissue damage may\nfacilitate the growth of anaerobic bacteria and therefore IDUs should try\nto use as little citric acid as possible to dissolve heroin, and should\navoid the injection of mixtures of heroin and cocaine. They should also be\nadvised to seek urgent medical attention if they develop swelling, redness,\nor pain at injecting sites.\nInvestigators (see email addresses below) at the PHLS in England and Wales\nwould be interested to hear of any recent cases of botulism in IDUs in\nother European countries.\nReferences :\n1.CDSC. Cluster of wound botulism cases in injecting drug users. Commun Dis\nRep CDR Wkly 2002; 12(44): news.\n2. O'Brien S, Reid A, De Benoist A-C. Temporal cluster of wound botulism in\nthe United Kingdom. Eurosurveillance Weekly 2002 6:020228.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2002/020228.html>\n3. Barry J, Thornton L, Igoe D. Case of botulism in Ireland.\nEurosurveillance Weekly 2002; 6:020328.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2002/020328.html>\n4. Khan M, Chay S, Bonner S, Brett M. Wound botulism in injecting drug\nuser: second case in England. Eurosurveillance Weekly 2000; 4:000622.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2000/000622.htm#3>\n5.Goldberg D. Wound botulism in an injecting drug user in Scotland.\nEurosurveillance Weekly 2001; 5:021011\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2001/011011.htm>\n6.Jensen T, Jacobsen D, von der Lippe E, Heier MS, Selseth B. Clinical\nwound botulism in injecting drug addicts [in Norwegian]. Tidsskr Nor\nLaegeforen 1998; 118:4363-5.\n7. Sautter T, Herzog A, Hauri D, Schurch B. Transient paralysis of the\nbladder due to wound botulism. Eur Urol 2001; 39: 610-2.\nReported by Peter Horby (<phorby@phls.org.uk>) and Alison Brown\n(<abrown@phls.org.uk>) Public Health Laboratory Service Communicable\nDisease Surveillance Centre, London, England.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Borrowing from a prior ProMED-mail posting moderator comment (Botulism,\nwound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614), wound botulism has been\nreported in injecting drug users (IDUs) in the United States and in\nEurope. Association with drug injection was first reported in 1982 in New\nYork City (1). In 1995 there were 19 cases reported in California\nassociated with contaminated black tar heroin (2). In 1998 there was an\noutbreak of 5 cases reported in Switzerland, all associated with illicit\ninjection drug use.\nIn October 2001 ProMED reported a case of wound botulism in Scotland, and\nquestioned whether the heightened surveillance for unusual illness in IDUs,\nas an aftermath of the outbreak of _C. novyi_ associated with contaminated\nheroin might have led to isolated case reports. In this article there is\nmention of 13 cases since the beginning of the year, suggesting the\npossibility of a contaminated batch of heroin on the market in the UK,\nsomewhat reminiscent of the outbreak in California in 1995 (2). One wonders\nif other countries have been seeing a similar increase in wound botulism in\nrecent months.\n1. CDC. Wound Botulism Associated with Parenteral Cocaine Abuse -- New\nYork City. MMWR. 26 Feb 1982 /\n31(7);87-8 <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00000208.htm>\n2. CDC. Wound Botulism -- California, 1995. MMWR. 8 Dec 1995 /\n44(48);889-892 <http://www.cdc.gov/epo/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00039732.htm>\n- Mod. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-08-01 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1982-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-10-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1982-02-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norway", "country": "Norway"}, {"location": "New \n York City", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "York City", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hauri", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "Antarctica"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "London", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland", "country": "Antarctica"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "- Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203015", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, fish, birds - Canada, USA (Lake Erie) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203015", "date": "2002-10-31 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - UK, IRELAND\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 31 Oct 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly Volume 6 / Issue 44 31 Oct 2001 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2002/021031.asp>\n\nCluster of wound botulism cases in injecting drug users in the United\nKingdom and the Republic of Ireland\n--------------------------------\nSince 1 Aug 2002, 6 cases of wound botulism in injecting drug users (IDUs)\nhave been reported by the Public Health Laboratory Service Food Safety\nMicrobiology Laboratory (PHLS FSML) in London (1). This brings the total\nnumber of clinically diagnosed cases of wound botulism in IDUs reported in\nthe United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland to 13 in 2002 (2, 3). The recent\ncases may be caused by a batch of drugs contaminated with the anaerobic\nbacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Reports of wound botulism in IDUs are a\nrelatively new phenomenon with no clinically diagnosed cases in the UK and\nRepublic of Ireland up to the end of 1999. There were, however, 6 reports\nin 2000 and 4 in 2001 (4 and references therein, 5 and references therein).\nCases of wound botulism in Europe, although rare, continue to be reported.\nIn recent years reports of suspected botulism in IDUs have come from Norway\n(6) and Switzerland (7).\nWound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a wound,\ngerminate, and produce botulinum toxin in vivo. The symptoms of botulism\nare caused by the toxin, which blocks the release of acetycholine at the\nneuromuscular junction resulting in a descending flaccid paralysis.\nPatients with botulism may present with blurred vision, drooping eyelids,\nslurred speech, difficulty swallowing, dry mouth, and muscle weakness.\nThere is usually no fever, no loss of sensation and no loss of awareness.\nIf untreated, paralysis may progress to the arms, legs, trunk and\nrespiratory muscles. If onset is very rapid, there may be no symptoms\nbefore sudden respiratory paralysis occurs. Clinicians should suspect\nbotulism in any patient with an afebrile, descending, flaccid paralysis.\nBotulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the severity of symptoms if\nadministered early in the course of the disease. _C. botulinum_ is\nsensitive to benzyl penicillin and metronidazole. In cases of wound\ninfection, antimicrobial therapy and surgical debridement should reduce the\norganism load and therefore toxin production, but circulating toxin can\nonly be neutralised by the early administration of antitoxin. Where there\nis a definite clinical suspicion of botulism, treatment with antitoxin\nshould not be delayed pending microbiological testing.\nIDUs are susceptible to wound botulism when anaerobic conditions exist at\ninjection sites. Injecting drug users should be advised to smoke heroin\nrather than inject and to avoid injecting into muscle or under the skin\n(skin popping). The injection of substances that increase tissue damage may\nfacilitate the growth of anaerobic bacteria and therefore IDUs should try\nto use as little citric acid as possible to dissolve heroin, and should\navoid the injection of mixtures of heroin and cocaine. They should also be\nadvised to seek urgent medical attention if they develop swelling, redness,\nor pain at injecting sites.\nInvestigators (see email addresses below) at the PHLS in England and Wales\nwould be interested to hear of any recent cases of botulism in IDUs in\nother European countries.\nReferences :\n1.CDSC. Cluster of wound botulism cases in injecting drug users. Commun Dis\nRep CDR Wkly 2002; 12(44): news.\n2. O'Brien S, Reid A, De Benoist A-C. Temporal cluster of wound botulism in\nthe United Kingdom. Eurosurveillance Weekly 2002 6:020228.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2002/020228.html>\n3. Barry J, Thornton L, Igoe D. Case of botulism in Ireland.\nEurosurveillance Weekly 2002; 6:020328.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2002/020328.html>\n4. Khan M, Chay S, Bonner S, Brett M. Wound botulism in injecting drug\nuser: second case in England. Eurosurveillance Weekly 2000; 4:000622.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2000/000622.htm#3>\n5.Goldberg D. Wound botulism in an injecting drug user in Scotland.\nEurosurveillance Weekly 2001; 5:021011\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2001/011011.htm>\n6.Jensen T, Jacobsen D, von der Lippe E, Heier MS, Selseth B. Clinical\nwound botulism in injecting drug addicts [in Norwegian]. Tidsskr Nor\nLaegeforen 1998; 118:4363-5.\n7. Sautter T, Herzog A, Hauri D, Schurch B. Transient paralysis of the\nbladder due to wound botulism. Eur Urol 2001; 39: 610-2.\nReported by Peter Horby (<phorby@phls.org.uk>) and Alison Brown\n(<abrown@phls.org.uk>) Public Health Laboratory Service Communicable\nDisease Surveillance Centre, London, England.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Borrowing from a prior ProMED-mail posting moderator comment (Botulism,\nwound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614), wound botulism has been\nreported in injecting drug users (IDUs) in the United States and in\nEurope. Association with drug injection was first reported in 1982 in New\nYork City (1). In 1995 there were 19 cases reported in California\nassociated with contaminated black tar heroin (2). In 1998 there was an\noutbreak of 5 cases reported in Switzerland, all associated with illicit\ninjection drug use.\nIn October 2001 ProMED reported a case of wound botulism in Scotland, and\nquestioned whether the heightened surveillance for unusual illness in IDUs,\nas an aftermath of the outbreak of _C. novyi_ associated with contaminated\nheroin might have led to isolated case reports. In this article there is\nmention of 13 cases since the beginning of the year, suggesting the\npossibility of a contaminated batch of heroin on the market in the UK,\nsomewhat reminiscent of the outbreak in California in 1995 (2). One wonders\nif other countries have been seeing a similar increase in wound botulism in\nrecent months.\n1. CDC. Wound Botulism Associated with Parenteral Cocaine Abuse -- New\nYork City. MMWR. 26 Feb 1982 /\n31(7);87-8 <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00000208.htm>\n2. CDC. Wound Botulism -- California, 1995. MMWR. 8 Dec 1995 /\n44(48);889-892 <http://www.cdc.gov/epo/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00039732.htm>\n- Mod. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-08-01 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1982-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-10-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1982-02-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norway", "country": "Norway"}, {"location": "New \n York City", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "York City", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hauri", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "Antarctica"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "London", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland", "country": "Antarctica"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "- Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202878", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, wound drug-related - UK"}, {"archive_id": "2202793", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, wound drug-related - UK not Ireland", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202793", "date": "2002-10-31 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - UK, IRELAND\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 31 Oct 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly Volume 6 / Issue 44 31 Oct 2001 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2002/021031.asp>\n\nCluster of wound botulism cases in injecting drug users in the United\nKingdom and the Republic of Ireland\n--------------------------------\nSince 1 Aug 2002, 6 cases of wound botulism in injecting drug users (IDUs)\nhave been reported by the Public Health Laboratory Service Food Safety\nMicrobiology Laboratory (PHLS FSML) in London (1). This brings the total\nnumber of clinically diagnosed cases of wound botulism in IDUs reported in\nthe United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland to 13 in 2002 (2, 3). The recent\ncases may be caused by a batch of drugs contaminated with the anaerobic\nbacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. Reports of wound botulism in IDUs are a\nrelatively new phenomenon with no clinically diagnosed cases in the UK and\nRepublic of Ireland up to the end of 1999. There were, however, 6 reports\nin 2000 and 4 in 2001 (4 and references therein, 5 and references therein).\nCases of wound botulism in Europe, although rare, continue to be reported.\nIn recent years reports of suspected botulism in IDUs have come from Norway\n(6) and Switzerland (7).\nWound botulism occurs when spores of _C. botulinum_ contaminate a wound,\ngerminate, and produce botulinum toxin in vivo. The symptoms of botulism\nare caused by the toxin, which blocks the release of acetycholine at the\nneuromuscular junction resulting in a descending flaccid paralysis.\nPatients with botulism may present with blurred vision, drooping eyelids,\nslurred speech, difficulty swallowing, dry mouth, and muscle weakness.\nThere is usually no fever, no loss of sensation and no loss of awareness.\nIf untreated, paralysis may progress to the arms, legs, trunk and\nrespiratory muscles. If onset is very rapid, there may be no symptoms\nbefore sudden respiratory paralysis occurs. Clinicians should suspect\nbotulism in any patient with an afebrile, descending, flaccid paralysis.\nBotulinum antitoxin is effective in reducing the severity of symptoms if\nadministered early in the course of the disease. _C. botulinum_ is\nsensitive to benzyl penicillin and metronidazole. In cases of wound\ninfection, antimicrobial therapy and surgical debridement should reduce the\norganism load and therefore toxin production, but circulating toxin can\nonly be neutralised by the early administration of antitoxin. Where there\nis a definite clinical suspicion of botulism, treatment with antitoxin\nshould not be delayed pending microbiological testing.\nIDUs are susceptible to wound botulism when anaerobic conditions exist at\ninjection sites. Injecting drug users should be advised to smoke heroin\nrather than inject and to avoid injecting into muscle or under the skin\n(skin popping). The injection of substances that increase tissue damage may\nfacilitate the growth of anaerobic bacteria and therefore IDUs should try\nto use as little citric acid as possible to dissolve heroin, and should\navoid the injection of mixtures of heroin and cocaine. They should also be\nadvised to seek urgent medical attention if they develop swelling, redness,\nor pain at injecting sites.\nInvestigators (see email addresses below) at the PHLS in England and Wales\nwould be interested to hear of any recent cases of botulism in IDUs in\nother European countries.\nReferences :\n1.CDSC. Cluster of wound botulism cases in injecting drug users. Commun Dis\nRep CDR Wkly 2002; 12(44): news.\n2. O'Brien S, Reid A, De Benoist A-C. Temporal cluster of wound botulism in\nthe United Kingdom. Eurosurveillance Weekly 2002 6:020228.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2002/020228.html>\n3. Barry J, Thornton L, Igoe D. Case of botulism in Ireland.\nEurosurveillance Weekly 2002; 6:020328.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2002/020328.html>\n4. Khan M, Chay S, Bonner S, Brett M. Wound botulism in injecting drug\nuser: second case in England. Eurosurveillance Weekly 2000; 4:000622.\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2000/000622.htm#3>\n5.Goldberg D. Wound botulism in an injecting drug user in Scotland.\nEurosurveillance Weekly 2001; 5:021011\n<http://www.eurosurv.org/2001/011011.htm>\n6.Jensen T, Jacobsen D, von der Lippe E, Heier MS, Selseth B. Clinical\nwound botulism in injecting drug addicts [in Norwegian]. Tidsskr Nor\nLaegeforen 1998; 118:4363-5.\n7. Sautter T, Herzog A, Hauri D, Schurch B. Transient paralysis of the\nbladder due to wound botulism. Eur Urol 2001; 39: 610-2.\nReported by Peter Horby (<phorby@phls.org.uk>) and Alison Brown\n(<abrown@phls.org.uk>) Public Health Laboratory Service Communicable\nDisease Surveillance Centre, London, England.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Borrowing from a prior ProMED-mail posting moderator comment (Botulism,\nwound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614), wound botulism has been\nreported in injecting drug users (IDUs) in the United States and in\nEurope. Association with drug injection was first reported in 1982 in New\nYork City (1). In 1995 there were 19 cases reported in California\nassociated with contaminated black tar heroin (2). In 1998 there was an\noutbreak of 5 cases reported in Switzerland, all associated with illicit\ninjection drug use.\nIn October 2001 ProMED reported a case of wound botulism in Scotland, and\nquestioned whether the heightened surveillance for unusual illness in IDUs,\nas an aftermath of the outbreak of _C. novyi_ associated with contaminated\nheroin might have led to isolated case reports. In this article there is\nmention of 13 cases since the beginning of the year, suggesting the\npossibility of a contaminated batch of heroin on the market in the UK,\nsomewhat reminiscent of the outbreak in California in 1995 (2). One wonders\nif other countries have been seeing a similar increase in wound botulism in\nrecent months.\n1. CDC. Wound Botulism Associated with Parenteral Cocaine Abuse -- New\nYork City. MMWR. 26 Feb 1982 /\n31(7);87-8 <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00000208.htm>\n2. CDC. Wound Botulism -- California, 1995. MMWR. 8 Dec 1995 /\n44(48);889-892 <http://www.cdc.gov/epo/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00039732.htm>\n- Mod. MPP]\nSee Also\nBotulism, wound, drug-associated (02) 20020305.3690\nBotulism, wound, drug-related 20020303.3670\nBotulism, Wound, Drug-related - USA (California) 20020228.3655\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\n2000\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland & Scotland 20000531.0874\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - Ireland (Dublin) 20000525.0825\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK 20000608.0922\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK (07) 20000820.1388\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: diagnosis 20000615.0977\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) 20000511.0717\nUnexplained deaths, human - UK (Scotland) (09) 20000522.0807\n............................mpp/pg/dk\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-08-01 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1982-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-10-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1982-02-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norway", "country": "Norway"}, {"location": "New \n York City", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "York City", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hauri", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "Antarctica"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "London", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland", "country": "Antarctica"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "- Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202716", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism, blue fox - Finland: confirmed (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202716", "date": "2002-06-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CATTLE - ISRAEL\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 18 Jun 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Jerusalem Post, 16 Jun 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.jpost.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?pagename=JPost/A/JPArticle/PrinterFull&cid=1023716498996>\n\nThe Veterinary Services yesterday confirmed in lab tests that 460 cows in\nthe Lachish area had died of botulinum type D infections. The disease,\nspread by bacteria, and for which all local cattle are vaccinated, is not\nharmful to man. \"It is not clear\", said Dr Oded Nir, Director of the\nVeterinary Services, \"how the affected cattle took sick, as they had been\nvaccinated\". In rare occasions, the vaccine does not \"take.\"\nOnly a handful of cows in the area have died in recent days. When the\ndeaths stop, the Veterinary Services will allow the moshavim [collective\nfarms] involved to resume sale of their milk even though the disease is not\nknown to pass to milk.\nThe deaths of the cows caused significant financial harm to the\nLachish-area moshavim, but insurance companies should reimburse the farmers\nfor the dead cows. Each cow is worth 4500 to 5000 NIS [900 to 1000 US\ndollars]. The Israel Dairy Board, Nir said, will also compensate them, at\nleast for the milk that was destroyed.\n[Byline: Judy Siegel-Itzkovich]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Major outbreaks of Botulism types C and D have been described in various\ncountries during recent years. In January 1990, during an outbreak in 2\nbeef feedlots on the Darling Downs in Queensland, Australia, 5500 head of\ncattle from a total population of approximately 30 000 head were reported\nto have died of Botulism type D (see reference 19980428.0813). During an\noutbreak in a dairy farm in California in April 1998, more than 400 head\nwere reported to have died; type C was involved. Outbreaks have been\nreported in various other countries.\nIsrael has witnessed several such outbreaks throughout the years. In 1978,\na major outbreak of botulism type D caused the deaths and emergency\nslaughter of more than 1000 animals, most of them dairy cattle. Spores of\n_Cl. botulinum_ type D spread to many farms from 2 central animal feed\nplants by recycled, non-sterilized poultry manure that included remains of\navian cadavers. Subsequently, annual botulism vaccinations of cattle and of\nother vulnerable animals with a vaccine, including toxoids of _Cl.\nbotulinum_ types C and D adsorbed onto aluminum hydroxide gel, have been\nintroduced and are routinely applied in most parts of the country. Sporadic\ncases involving unvaccinated animals (mainly young cows) have been reported\nto occur every year.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol3no2/shimshon.htm>\nSince 1996, the feeding of milking cows, sheep, and goats with poultry\nmanure was officially banned, while feeding of all animals was prohibited\nduring 15 days prior to slaughter.\nThe above press information on the current outbreak is rather limited;\nclarifications from the professionals involved on the suspected source of\ncontamination, detection of toxin and/or bacteria in feed and in the\ndiseased animals, as well as detailed epidemiological and clinical data\nwill be useful. Of particular interest would be confirmation (or otherwise)\nof the vaccine allegedly used: its manufacture, testing, and vaccination\nregime.\nThe veterinary and public-health authorities involved are to be commended\nfor the early diagnosis and their timely extra safety measure in\nwithdrawing the milk from the food chain (despite the fact that botulinum\ntype D is generally regarded as non-pathogenic to humans).\n\nAdditional, recently summarized data on Botulism in cattle may be found in\ncomments to reference 20020315.3750. - Mod. AS]\nSee Also\nBotulism, cattle, suspected - UK (Northern Ireland) 20020315.3750\nAnthrax, livestock - Australia (Queensland) (03) 20020112.3231\n2000\n----\nUndiagnosed mortality, dairy cattle - Belgium (04) 20000204.0169\n1999\n----\nFaeces as animal feeds - Europe (02) 19990923.1701\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) 19990524.0871\n1998\n----\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) (04) 19980428.0813\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) (03) 19980424.0765\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) (02) 19980424.0763\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) 19980421.0748\n...............................as/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail.
