If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-06-18 00:00:00", "2002-06-16 00:00:00", "1990-01-15 00:00:00", "1998-04-15 00:00:00", "1978-03-15 00:00:00", "1996-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202691", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism, blue fox - Finland: confirmed (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202691", "date": "2002-06-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CATTLE - ISRAEL\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 18 Jun 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Jerusalem Post, 16 Jun 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.jpost.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?pagename=JPost/A/JPArticle/PrinterFull&cid=1023716498996>\n\nThe Veterinary Services yesterday confirmed in lab tests that 460 cows in\nthe Lachish area had died of botulinum type D infections. The disease,\nspread by bacteria, and for which all local cattle are vaccinated, is not\nharmful to man. \"It is not clear\", said Dr Oded Nir, Director of the\nVeterinary Services, \"how the affected cattle took sick, as they had been\nvaccinated\". In rare occasions, the vaccine does not \"take.\"\nOnly a handful of cows in the area have died in recent days. When the\ndeaths stop, the Veterinary Services will allow the moshavim [collective\nfarms] involved to resume sale of their milk even though the disease is not\nknown to pass to milk.\nThe deaths of the cows caused significant financial harm to the\nLachish-area moshavim, but insurance companies should reimburse the farmers\nfor the dead cows. Each cow is worth 4500 to 5000 NIS [900 to 1000 US\ndollars]. The Israel Dairy Board, Nir said, will also compensate them, at\nleast for the milk that was destroyed.\n[Byline: Judy Siegel-Itzkovich]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Major outbreaks of Botulism types C and D have been described in various\ncountries during recent years. In January 1990, during an outbreak in 2\nbeef feedlots on the Darling Downs in Queensland, Australia, 5500 head of\ncattle from a total population of approximately 30 000 head were reported\nto have died of Botulism type D (see reference 19980428.0813). During an\noutbreak in a dairy farm in California in April 1998, more than 400 head\nwere reported to have died; type C was involved. Outbreaks have been\nreported in various other countries.\nIsrael has witnessed several such outbreaks throughout the years. In 1978,\na major outbreak of botulism type D caused the deaths and emergency\nslaughter of more than 1000 animals, most of them dairy cattle. Spores of\n_Cl. botulinum_ type D spread to many farms from 2 central animal feed\nplants by recycled, non-sterilized poultry manure that included remains of\navian cadavers. Subsequently, annual botulism vaccinations of cattle and of\nother vulnerable animals with a vaccine, including toxoids of _Cl.\nbotulinum_ types C and D adsorbed onto aluminum hydroxide gel, have been\nintroduced and are routinely applied in most parts of the country. Sporadic\ncases involving unvaccinated animals (mainly young cows) have been reported\nto occur every year.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol3no2/shimshon.htm>\nSince 1996, the feeding of milking cows, sheep, and goats with poultry\nmanure was officially banned, while feeding of all animals was prohibited\nduring 15 days prior to slaughter.\nThe above press information on the current outbreak is rather limited;\nclarifications from the professionals involved on the suspected source of\ncontamination, detection of toxin and/or bacteria in feed and in the\ndiseased animals, as well as detailed epidemiological and clinical data\nwill be useful. Of particular interest would be confirmation (or otherwise)\nof the vaccine allegedly used: its manufacture, testing, and vaccination\nregime.\nThe veterinary and public-health authorities involved are to be commended\nfor the early diagnosis and their timely extra safety measure in\nwithdrawing the milk from the food chain (despite the fact that botulinum\ntype D is generally regarded as non-pathogenic to humans).\n\nAdditional, recently summarized data on Botulism in cattle may be found in\ncomments to reference 20020315.3750. - Mod. AS]\nSee Also\nBotulism, cattle, suspected - UK (Northern Ireland) 20020315.3750\nAnthrax, livestock - Australia (Queensland) (03) 20020112.3231\n2000\n----\nUndiagnosed mortality, dairy cattle - Belgium (04) 20000204.0169\n1999\n----\nFaeces as animal feeds - Europe (02) 19990923.1701\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) 19990524.0871\n1998\n----\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) (04) 19980428.0813\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) (03) 19980424.0765\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) (02) 19980424.0763\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) 19980421.0748\n...............................as/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Sporadic\ncases involving unvaccinated animals (mainly young cows) have been reported\nto occur every year.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol3no2/shimshon.htm>\nSince 1996, the feeding of milking cows, sheep, and goats with poultry\nmanure was officially banned, while feeding of all animals was prohibited\nduring 15 days prior to slaughter.\nThe above press information on the current outbreak is rather limited;\nclarifications from the professionals involved on the suspected source of\ncontamination, detection of toxin and/or bacteria in feed and in the\ndiseased animals, as well as detailed epidemiological and clinical data\nwill be useful. Of particular interest would be confirmation (or otherwise)\nof the vaccine allegedly used: its manufacture, testing, and vaccination\nregime.\nThe veterinary and public-health authorities involved are to be commended\nfor the early diagnosis and their timely extra safety measure in\nwithdrawing the milk from the food chain (despite the fact that botulinum\ntype D is generally regarded as non-pathogenic to humans).\n\nAdditional, recently summarized data on Botulism in cattle may be found in\ncomments to reference 20020315.3750. - Mod. The disease,\nspread by bacteria, and for which all local cattle are vaccinated, is not\nharmful to man. \"It is not clear\", said Dr Oded Nir, Director of the\nVeterinary Services, \"how the affected cattle took sick, as they had been\nvaccinated\". In rare occasions, the vaccine does not \"take.\"\nOnly a handful of cows in the area have died in recent days. When the\ndeaths stop, the Veterinary Services will allow the moshavim [collective\nfarms] involved to resume sale of their milk even though the disease is not\nknown to pass to milk.\nThe deaths of the cows caused significant financial harm to the\nLachish-area moshavim, but insurance companies should reimburse the farmers\nfor the dead cows. Each cow is worth 4500 to 5000 NIS [900 to 1000 US\ndollars]. The Israel Dairy Board, Nir said, will also compensate them, at\nleast for the milk that was destroyed.\n[Byline: Judy Siegel-Itzkovich]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Major outbreaks of Botulism types C and D have been described in various\ncountries during recent years. In January 1990, during an outbreak in 2\nbeef feedlots on the Darling Downs in Queensland, Australia, 5500 head of\ncattle from a total population of approximately 30 000 head were reported\nto have died of Botulism type D (see reference 19980428.0813). During an\noutbreak in a dairy farm in California in April 1998, more than 400 head\nwere reported to have died; type C was involved. Outbreaks have been\nreported in various other countries.\nIsrael has witnessed several such outbreaks throughout the years. In 1978,\na major outbreak of botulism type D caused the deaths and emergency\nslaughter of more than 1000 animals, most of them dairy cattle. Spores of\n_Cl. botulinum_ type D spread to many farms from 2 central animal feed\nplants by recycled, non-sterilized poultry manure that included remains of\navian cadavers. Subsequently, annual botulism vaccinations of cattle and of\nother vulnerable animals with a vaccine, including toxoids of _Cl.\nbotulinum_ types C and D adsorbed onto aluminum hydroxide gel, have been\nintroduced and are routinely applied in most parts of the country. Sporadic\ncases involving unvaccinated animals (mainly young cows) have been reported\nto occur every year.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol3no2/shimshon.htm>\nSince 1996, the feeding of milking cows, sheep, and goats with poultry\nmanure was officially banned, while feeding of all animals was prohibited\nduring 15 days prior to slaughter.\nThe above press information on the current outbreak is rather limited;\nclarifications from the professionals involved on the suspected source of\ncontamination, detection of toxin and/or bacteria in feed and in the\ndiseased animals, as well as detailed epidemiological and clinical data\nwill be useful. Of particular interest would be confirmation (or otherwise)\nof the vaccine allegedly used: its manufacture, testing, and vaccination\nregime.\nThe veterinary and public-health authorities involved are to be commended\nfor the early diagnosis and their timely extra safety measure in\nwithdrawing the milk from the food chain (despite the fact that botulinum\ntype D is generally regarded as non-pathogenic to humans).\n\nAdditional, recently summarized data on Botulism in cattle may be found in\ncomments to reference 20020315.3750. - Mod. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-06-18 00:00:00", "2002-06-16 00:00:00", "1990-01-15 00:00:00", "1998-04-15 00:00:00", "1978-03-15 00:00:00", "1996-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202197", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, humans - USA (Alaska)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202197", "date": "2002-06-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CATTLE - ISRAEL\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 18 Jun 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Jerusalem Post, 16 Jun 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.jpost.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?pagename=JPost/A/JPArticle/PrinterFull&cid=1023716498996>\n\nThe Veterinary Services yesterday confirmed in lab tests that 460 cows in\nthe Lachish area had died of botulinum type D infections. The disease,\nspread by bacteria, and for which all local cattle are vaccinated, is not\nharmful to man. \"It is not clear\", said Dr Oded Nir, Director of the\nVeterinary Services, \"how the affected cattle took sick, as they had been\nvaccinated\". In rare occasions, the vaccine does not \"take.\"\nOnly a handful of cows in the area have died in recent days. When the\ndeaths stop, the Veterinary Services will allow the moshavim [collective\nfarms] involved to resume sale of their milk even though the disease is not\nknown to pass to milk.\nThe deaths of the cows caused significant financial harm to the\nLachish-area moshavim, but insurance companies should reimburse the farmers\nfor the dead cows. Each cow is worth 4500 to 5000 NIS [900 to 1000 US\ndollars]. The Israel Dairy Board, Nir said, will also compensate them, at\nleast for the milk that was destroyed.\n[Byline: Judy Siegel-Itzkovich]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Major outbreaks of Botulism types C and D have been described in various\ncountries during recent years. In January 1990, during an outbreak in 2\nbeef feedlots on the Darling Downs in Queensland, Australia, 5500 head of\ncattle from a total population of approximately 30 000 head were reported\nto have died of Botulism type D (see reference 19980428.0813). During an\noutbreak in a dairy farm in California in April 1998, more than 400 head\nwere reported to have died; type C was involved. Outbreaks have been\nreported in various other countries.\nIsrael has witnessed several such outbreaks throughout the years. In 1978,\na major outbreak of botulism type D caused the deaths and emergency\nslaughter of more than 1000 animals, most of them dairy cattle. Spores of\n_Cl. botulinum_ type D spread to many farms from 2 central animal feed\nplants by recycled, non-sterilized poultry manure that included remains of\navian cadavers. Subsequently, annual botulism vaccinations of cattle and of\nother vulnerable animals with a vaccine, including toxoids of _Cl.\nbotulinum_ types C and D adsorbed onto aluminum hydroxide gel, have been\nintroduced and are routinely applied in most parts of the country. Sporadic\ncases involving unvaccinated animals (mainly young cows) have been reported\nto occur every year.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol3no2/shimshon.htm>\nSince 1996, the feeding of milking cows, sheep, and goats with poultry\nmanure was officially banned, while feeding of all animals was prohibited\nduring 15 days prior to slaughter.\nThe above press information on the current outbreak is rather limited;\nclarifications from the professionals involved on the suspected source of\ncontamination, detection of toxin and/or bacteria in feed and in the\ndiseased animals, as well as detailed epidemiological and clinical data\nwill be useful. Of particular interest would be confirmation (or otherwise)\nof the vaccine allegedly used: its manufacture, testing, and vaccination\nregime.\nThe veterinary and public-health authorities involved are to be commended\nfor the early diagnosis and their timely extra safety measure in\nwithdrawing the milk from the food chain (despite the fact that botulinum\ntype D is generally regarded as non-pathogenic to humans).\n\nAdditional, recently summarized data on Botulism in cattle may be found in\ncomments to reference 20020315.3750. - Mod. AS]\nSee Also\nBotulism, cattle, suspected - UK (Northern Ireland) 20020315.3750\nAnthrax, livestock - Australia (Queensland) (03) 20020112.3231\n2000\n----\nUndiagnosed mortality, dairy cattle - Belgium (04) 20000204.0169\n1999\n----\nFaeces as animal feeds - Europe (02) 19990923.1701\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) 19990524.0871\n1998\n----\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) (04) 19980428.0813\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) (03) 19980424.0765\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) (02) 19980424.0763\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) 19980421.0748\n...............................as/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-06-18 00:00:00", "2002-06-16 00:00:00", "1990-01-15 00:00:00", "1998-04-15 00:00:00", "1978-03-15 00:00:00", "1996-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202000", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, cattle - Israel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202000", "date": "2002-06-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, CATTLE - ISRAEL\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 18 Jun 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Jerusalem Post, 16 Jun 2002 [edited]\n<http://www.jpost.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?pagename=JPost/A/JPArticle/PrinterFull&cid=1023716498996>\n\nThe Veterinary Services yesterday confirmed in lab tests that 460 cows in\nthe Lachish area had died of botulinum type D infections. The disease,\nspread by bacteria, and for which all local cattle are vaccinated, is not\nharmful to man. \"It is not clear\", said Dr Oded Nir, Director of the\nVeterinary Services, \"how the affected cattle took sick, as they had been\nvaccinated\". In rare occasions, the vaccine does not \"take.\"\nOnly a handful of cows in the area have died in recent days. When the\ndeaths stop, the Veterinary Services will allow the moshavim [collective\nfarms] involved to resume sale of their milk even though the disease is not\nknown to pass to milk.\nThe deaths of the cows caused significant financial harm to the\nLachish-area moshavim, but insurance companies should reimburse the farmers\nfor the dead cows. Each cow is worth 4500 to 5000 NIS [900 to 1000 US\ndollars]. The Israel Dairy Board, Nir said, will also compensate them, at\nleast for the milk that was destroyed.\n[Byline: Judy Siegel-Itzkovich]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Major outbreaks of Botulism types C and D have been described in various\ncountries during recent years. In January 1990, during an outbreak in 2\nbeef feedlots on the Darling Downs in Queensland, Australia, 5500 head of\ncattle from a total population of approximately 30 000 head were reported\nto have died of Botulism type D (see reference 19980428.0813). During an\noutbreak in a dairy farm in California in April 1998, more than 400 head\nwere reported to have died; type C was involved. Outbreaks have been\nreported in various other countries.\nIsrael has witnessed several such outbreaks throughout the years. In 1978,\na major outbreak of botulism type D caused the deaths and emergency\nslaughter of more than 1000 animals, most of them dairy cattle. Spores of\n_Cl. botulinum_ type D spread to many farms from 2 central animal feed\nplants by recycled, non-sterilized poultry manure that included remains of\navian cadavers. Subsequently, annual botulism vaccinations of cattle and of\nother vulnerable animals with a vaccine, including toxoids of _Cl.\nbotulinum_ types C and D adsorbed onto aluminum hydroxide gel, have been\nintroduced and are routinely applied in most parts of the country. Sporadic\ncases involving unvaccinated animals (mainly young cows) have been reported\nto occur every year.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol3no2/shimshon.htm>\nSince 1996, the feeding of milking cows, sheep, and goats with poultry\nmanure was officially banned, while feeding of all animals was prohibited\nduring 15 days prior to slaughter.\nThe above press information on the current outbreak is rather limited;\nclarifications from the professionals involved on the suspected source of\ncontamination, detection of toxin and/or bacteria in feed and in the\ndiseased animals, as well as detailed epidemiological and clinical data\nwill be useful. Of particular interest would be confirmation (or otherwise)\nof the vaccine allegedly used: its manufacture, testing, and vaccination\nregime.\nThe veterinary and public-health authorities involved are to be commended\nfor the early diagnosis and their timely extra safety measure in\nwithdrawing the milk from the food chain (despite the fact that botulinum\ntype D is generally regarded as non-pathogenic to humans).\n\nAdditional, recently summarized data on Botulism in cattle may be found in\ncomments to reference 20020315.3750. - Mod. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-06-18 00:00:00", "2002-06-16 00:00:00", "1990-01-15 00:00:00", "1998-04-15 00:00:00", "1978-03-15 00:00:00", "1996-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201765", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, gefilte fish - Canada: recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201765", "date": "2002-02-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\n1999\n-----\nBotulism, wound - Switzerland 19990225.0263\nDate: Mon 25 Feb 2002 5:18 PM\nFrom: Ben Werner <bwerner@dhs.ca.gov>\n\nIn follow-up to your posting of Friday, February 22, 2002, [Botulism,\nwound, drug-related - UK: alert you may want to update your figures\non wound botulism (WB) from the State of California (CA),\nparticularly among injecting drug users (IDUs) with our published\nfigures (in Clinical Infectious Diseases 2000;31:1018-24).\nTherein, we reported a total of 127 cases of WB identified in CA from\n1951-1998, 105 of them occurring in injecting drug users. These cases\nprimarily used black tar heroin (BTH) that originated in Mexico.\nSince that publication we have identified more cases in this ongoing\nproblem: specifically, in 1999 we identified another 37 lab-confirmed\ncases of WB in IDUs, 14 more in 2000, and 20 more in 2001.\nThese cases represent at least 75 percent of cases of WB in IDUs\nidentified to date in the US, and they reflect an ongoing epidemic of\nWB in IDUs that began in CA about 1994. Cases here have occurred\ndisproportionately in Hispanics and women, and major risk factors\nhave been the route of administration (e.g., by \"skin popping\") and\nthe amount of BTH injected subcutaneously.\nWB in IDUs is now being reported in other states and other countries.\nWe have observed frequent misdiagnosis and diagnostic delays of up to\n64 days in WB cases. The above CID article discusses BTH, the\nclinical and laboratory features that distinguish botulism from other\nconditions that can mimic it, the relative value of diagnostic\nlaboratory tests for botulism, and its treatment.\nAs an aside, we have also learned of cases of necrotizing fasciitis\n(NF) in CA that have occurred in BTH users in recent times; and, in\nsome who had anaerobic cultures taken, a variety of _Clostridium_\nspecies has been recovered. We don't know the extent to which NF is\noccurring in CA, or the extent to which NF cases might be associated\nwith BTH, since NF is not a reportable disease in this state.\n--\nS. B. Werner, M.D., Chief\nDisease Investigations Section\nDivision of Communicable Disease Control\nCalifornia Department of Health Services\n2151 Berkeley Way\nBerkeley, California 94704\nTelephone (510) 540-2566\nFax (510) 540-2570\n<bwerner@dhs.ca.gov> (note that there is no \"s\" before the \"b\" in my\ne-mail address)\n[Thank you Dr. Werner for this update. The full text of this article\ncan be read on-line at:\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v31n4/994092/994092.html>\nIn this article the authors present the review of the 127 cases of\nwound botulism reported in this period, of which 93 had been reported\nin the period 1993 to 1998. The epidemic curve presented in Figure 1\nof this article clearly supports the conclusion that there is a newly\nemerging problem of wound botulism associated with injecting drug use\nin California\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v31n4/994092/994092.fg1.html>\n- Mod.MPP\n.......................mpp/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-02-25 00:00:00", "2002-02-22 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the State of California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "M.D.", "country": "Dominican Republic"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201516", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism, cattle, suspected - UK (Northern Ireland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201516", "date": "2002-02-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\n1999\n-----\nBotulism, wound - Switzerland 19990225.0263\nDate: Mon 25 Feb 2002 5:18 PM\nFrom: Ben Werner <bwerner@dhs.ca.gov>\n\nIn follow-up to your posting of Friday, February 22, 2002, [Botulism,\nwound, drug-related - UK: alert you may want to update your figures\non wound botulism (WB) from the State of California (CA),\nparticularly among injecting drug users (IDUs) with our published\nfigures (in Clinical Infectious Diseases 2000;31:1018-24).\nTherein, we reported a total of 127 cases of WB identified in CA from\n1951-1998, 105 of them occurring in injecting drug users. These cases\nprimarily used black tar heroin (BTH) that originated in Mexico.\nSince that publication we have identified more cases in this ongoing\nproblem: specifically, in 1999 we identified another 37 lab-confirmed\ncases of WB in IDUs, 14 more in 2000, and 20 more in 2001.\nThese cases represent at least 75 percent of cases of WB in IDUs\nidentified to date in the US, and they reflect an ongoing epidemic of\nWB in IDUs that began in CA about 1994. Cases here have occurred\ndisproportionately in Hispanics and women, and major risk factors\nhave been the route of administration (e.g., by \"skin popping\") and\nthe amount of BTH injected subcutaneously.\nWB in IDUs is now being reported in other states and other countries.\nWe have observed frequent misdiagnosis and diagnostic delays of up to\n64 days in WB cases. The above CID article discusses BTH, the\nclinical and laboratory features that distinguish botulism from other\nconditions that can mimic it, the relative value of diagnostic\nlaboratory tests for botulism, and its treatment.\nAs an aside, we have also learned of cases of necrotizing fasciitis\n(NF) in CA that have occurred in BTH users in recent times; and, in\nsome who had anaerobic cultures taken, a variety of _Clostridium_\nspecies has been recovered. We don't know the extent to which NF is\noccurring in CA, or the extent to which NF cases might be associated\nwith BTH, since NF is not a reportable disease in this state.\n--\nS. B. Werner, M.D., Chief\nDisease Investigations Section\nDivision of Communicable Disease Control\nCalifornia Department of Health Services\n2151 Berkeley Way\nBerkeley, California 94704\nTelephone (510) 540-2566\nFax (510) 540-2570\n<bwerner@dhs.ca.gov> (note that there is no \"s\" before the \"b\" in my\ne-mail address)\n[Thank you Dr. Werner for this update. The full text of this article\ncan be read on-line at:\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v31n4/994092/994092.html>\nIn this article the authors present the review of the 127 cases of\nwound botulism reported in this period, of which 93 had been reported\nin the period 1993 to 1998. The epidemic curve presented in Figure 1\nof this article clearly supports the conclusion that there is a newly\nemerging problem of wound botulism associated with injecting drug use\nin California\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v31n4/994092/994092.fg1.html>\n- Mod.MPP\n.......................mpp/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. USA (CALIFORNIA)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\n1999\n-----\nBotulism, wound - Switzerland 19990225.0263\nDate: Mon 25 Feb 2002 5:18 PM\nFrom: Ben Werner <bwerner@dhs.ca.gov>\n\nIn follow-up to your posting of Friday, February 22, 2002, [Botulism,\nwound, drug-related - UK: alert you may want to update your figures\non wound botulism (WB) from the State of California (CA),\nparticularly among injecting drug users (IDUs) with our published\nfigures (in Clinical Infectious Diseases 2000;31:1018-24).\nTherein, we reported a total of 127 cases of WB identified in CA from\n1951-1998, 105 of them occurring in injecting drug users. These cases\nprimarily used black tar heroin (BTH) that originated in Mexico.\nSince that publication we have identified more cases in this ongoing\nproblem: specifically, in 1999 we identified another 37 lab-confirmed\ncases of WB in IDUs, 14 more in 2000, and 20 more in 2001.\nThese cases represent at least 75 percent of cases of WB in IDUs\nidentified to date in the US, and they reflect an ongoing epidemic of\nWB in IDUs that began in CA about 1994. Cases here have occurred\ndisproportionately in Hispanics and women, and major risk factors\nhave been the route of administration (e.g., by \"skin popping\") and\nthe amount of BTH injected subcutaneously.\nWB in IDUs is now being reported in other states and other countries.\nWe have observed frequent misdiagnosis and diagnostic delays of up to\n64 days in WB cases. The above CID article discusses BTH, the\nclinical and laboratory features that distinguish botulism from other\nconditions that can mimic it, the relative value of diagnostic\nlaboratory tests for botulism, and its treatment.\nAs an aside, we have also learned of cases of necrotizing fasciitis\n(NF) in CA that have occurred in BTH users in recent times; and, in\nsome who had anaerobic cultures taken, a variety of _Clostridium_\nspecies has been recovered. We don't know the extent to which NF is\noccurring in CA, or the extent to which NF cases might be associated\nwith BTH, since NF is not a reportable disease in this state.\n--\nS. B. Werner, M.D., Chief\nDisease Investigations Section\nDivision of Communicable Disease Control\nCalifornia Department of Health Services\n2151 Berkeley Way\nBerkeley, California 94704\nTelephone (510) 540-2566\nFax (510) 540-2570\n<bwerner@dhs.ca.gov> (note that there is no \"s\" before the \"b\" in my\ne-mail address)\n[Thank you Dr. Werner for this update. The full text of this article\ncan be read on-line at:\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v31n4/994092/994092.html>\nIn this article the authors present the review of the 127 cases of\nwound botulism reported in this period, of which 93 had been reported\nin the period 1993 to 1998. The epidemic curve presented in Figure 1\nof this article clearly supports the conclusion that there is a newly\nemerging problem of wound botulism associated with injecting drug use\nin California\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v31n4/994092/994092.fg1.html>\n- Mod.MPP\n.......................mpp/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\n1999\n-----\nBotulism, wound - Switzerland 19990225.0263\nDate: Mon 25 Feb 2002 5:18 PM\nFrom: Ben Werner <bwerner@dhs.ca.gov>\n\nIn follow-up to your posting of Friday, February 22, 2002, [Botulism,\nwound, drug-related - UK: alert you may want to update your figures\non wound botulism (WB) from the State of California (CA),\nparticularly among injecting drug users (IDUs) with our published\nfigures (in Clinical Infectious Diseases 2000;31:1018-24).\nTherein, we reported a total of 127 cases of WB identified in CA from\n1951-1998, 105 of them occurring in injecting drug users. These cases\nprimarily used black tar heroin (BTH) that originated in Mexico.\nSince that publication we have identified more cases in this ongoing\nproblem: specifically, in 1999 we identified another 37 lab-confirmed\ncases of WB in IDUs, 14 more in 2000, and 20 more in 2001.\nThese cases represent at least 75 percent of cases of WB in IDUs\nidentified to date in the US, and they reflect an ongoing epidemic of\nWB in IDUs that began in CA about 1994. Cases here have occurred\ndisproportionately in Hispanics and women, and major risk factors\nhave been the route of administration (e.g., by \"skin popping\") and\nthe amount of BTH injected subcutaneously.\nWB in IDUs is now being reported in other states and other countries.\nWe have observed frequent misdiagnosis and diagnostic delays of up to\n64 days in WB cases. The above CID article discusses BTH, the\nclinical and laboratory features that distinguish botulism from other\nconditions that can mimic it, the relative value of diagnostic\nlaboratory tests for botulism, and its treatment.\nAs an aside, we have also learned of cases of necrotizing fasciitis\n(NF) in CA that have occurred in BTH users in recent times; and, in\nsome who had anaerobic cultures taken, a variety of _Clostridium_\nspecies has been recovered. We don't know the extent to which NF is\noccurring in CA, or the extent to which NF cases might be associated\nwith BTH, since NF is not a reportable disease in this state.\n--\nS. B. Werner, M.D., Chief\nDisease Investigations Section\nDivision of Communicable Disease Control\nCalifornia Department of Health Services\n2151 Berkeley Way\nBerkeley, California 94704\nTelephone (510) 540-2566\nFax (510) 540-2570\n<bwerner@dhs.ca.gov> (note that there is no \"s\" before the \"b\" in my\ne-mail address)\n[Thank you Dr. Werner for this update. The full text of this article\ncan be read on-line at:\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v31n4/994092/994092.html>\nIn this article the authors present the review of the 127 cases of\nwound botulism reported in this period, of which 93 had been reported\nin the period 1993 to 1998. The epidemic curve presented in Figure 1\nof this article clearly supports the conclusion that there is a newly\nemerging problem of wound botulism associated with injecting drug use\nin California\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v31n4/994092/994092.fg1.html>\n- Mod.MPP\n.......................mpp/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\n1999\n-----\nBotulism, wound - Switzerland 19990225.0263\nDate: Mon 25 Feb 2002 5:18 PM\nFrom: Ben Werner <bwerner@dhs.ca.gov>\n\nIn follow-up to your posting of Friday, February 22, 2002, [Botulism,\nwound, drug-related - UK: alert you may want to update your figures\non wound botulism (WB) from the State of California (CA),\nparticularly among injecting drug users (IDUs) with our published\nfigures (in Clinical Infectious Diseases 2000;31:1018-24).\nTherein, we reported a total of 127 cases of WB identified in CA from\n1951-1998, 105 of them occurring in injecting drug users. These cases\nprimarily used black tar heroin (BTH) that originated in Mexico.\nSince that publication we have identified more cases in this ongoing\nproblem: specifically, in 1999 we identified another 37 lab-confirmed\ncases of WB in IDUs, 14 more in 2000, and 20 more in 2001.\nThese cases represent at least 75 percent of cases of WB in IDUs\nidentified to date in the US, and they reflect an ongoing epidemic of\nWB in IDUs that began in CA about 1994. Cases here have occurred\ndisproportionately in Hispanics and women, and major risk factors\nhave been the route of administration (e.g., by \"skin popping\") and\nthe amount of BTH injected subcutaneously.\nWB in IDUs is now being reported in other states and other countries.\nWe have observed frequent misdiagnosis and diagnostic delays of up to\n64 days in WB cases. The above CID article discusses BTH, the\nclinical and laboratory features that distinguish botulism from other\nconditions that can mimic it, the relative value of diagnostic\nlaboratory tests for botulism, and its treatment.\nAs an aside, we have also learned of cases of necrotizing fasciitis\n(NF) in CA that have occurred in BTH users in recent times; and, in\nsome who had anaerobic cultures taken, a variety of _Clostridium_\nspecies has been recovered. We don't know the extent to which NF is\noccurring in CA, or the extent to which NF cases might be associated\nwith BTH, since NF is not a reportable disease in this state.\n--\nS. B. UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\n1999\n-----\nBotulism, wound - Switzerland 19990225.0263\nDate: Mon 25 Feb 2002 5:18 PM\nFrom: Ben Werner <bwerner@dhs.ca.gov>\n\nIn follow-up to your posting of Friday, February 22, 2002, [Botulism,\nwound, drug-related - UK: alert you may want to update your figures\non wound botulism (WB) from the State of California (CA),\nparticularly among injecting drug users (IDUs) with our published\nfigures (in Clinical Infectious Diseases 2000;31:1018-24).\nTherein, we reported a total of 127 cases of WB identified in CA from\n1951-1998, 105 of them occurring in injecting drug users. These cases\nprimarily used black tar heroin (BTH) that originated in Mexico.\nSince that publication we have identified more cases in this ongoing\nproblem: specifically, in 1999 we identified another 37 lab-confirmed\ncases of WB in IDUs, 14 more in 2000, and 20 more in 2001.\nThese cases represent at least 75 percent of cases of WB in IDUs\nidentified to date in the US, and they reflect an ongoing epidemic of\nWB in IDUs that began in CA about 1994. Cases here have occurred\ndisproportionately in Hispanics and women, and major risk factors\nhave been the route of administration (e.g., by \"skin popping\") and\nthe amount of BTH injected subcutaneously.\nWB in IDUs is now being reported in other states and other countries.\nWe have observed frequent misdiagnosis and diagnostic delays of up to\n64 days in WB cases. The above CID article discusses BTH, the\nclinical and laboratory features that distinguish botulism from other\nconditions that can mimic it, the relative value of diagnostic\nlaboratory tests for botulism, and its treatment.\nAs an aside, we have also learned of cases of necrotizing fasciitis\n(NF) in CA that have occurred in BTH users in recent times; and, in\nsome who had anaerobic cultures taken, a variety of _Clostridium_\nspecies has been recovered. We don't know the extent to which NF is\noccurring in CA, or the extent to which NF cases might be associated\nwith BTH, since NF is not a reportable disease in this state.\n--\nS. B. Werner, M.D., Chief\nDisease Investigations Section\nDivision of Communicable Disease Control\nCalifornia Department of Health Services\n2151 Berkeley Way\nBerkeley, California 94704\nTelephone (510) 540-2566\nFax (510) 540-2570\n<bwerner@dhs.ca.gov> (note that there is no \"s\" before the \"b\" in my\ne-mail address)\n[Thank you Dr. Werner for this update. The full text of this article\ncan be read on-line at:\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v31n4/994092/994092.html>\nIn this article the authors present the review of the 127 cases of\nwound botulism reported in this period, of which 93 had been reported\nin the period 1993 to 1998. The epidemic curve presented in Figure 1\nof this article clearly supports the conclusion that there is a newly\nemerging problem of wound botulism associated with injecting drug use\nin California\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v31n4/994092/994092.fg1.html>\n- Mod.MPP\n.......................mpp/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. USA (California)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201452", "date": "2002-02-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, WOUND, DRUG-RELATED - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert 20020223.3614\n2001\n----\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (Scotland) 20011005.2414\nUnexplained deaths, drug addicts - UK: report 20011003.2398\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - UK (England) 20000518.0777\nBotulism, wound, drug-related - Worldwide: background 20000521.0802\n1999\n-----\nBotulism, wound - Switzerland 19990225.0263\nDate: Mon 25 Feb 2002 5:18 PM\nFrom: Ben Werner <bwerner@dhs.ca.gov>\n\nIn follow-up to your posting of Friday, February 22, 2002, [Botulism,\nwound, drug-related - UK: alert you may want to update your figures\non wound botulism (WB) from the State of California (CA),\nparticularly among injecting drug users (IDUs) with our published\nfigures (in Clinical Infectious Diseases 2000;31:1018-24).\nTherein, we reported a total of 127 cases of WB identified in CA from\n1951-1998, 105 of them occurring in injecting drug users. These cases\nprimarily used black tar heroin (BTH) that originated in Mexico.\nSince that publication we have identified more cases in this ongoing\nproblem: specifically, in 1999 we identified another 37 lab-confirmed\ncases of WB in IDUs, 14 more in 2000, and 20 more in 2001.\nThese cases represent at least 75 percent of cases of WB in IDUs\nidentified to date in the US, and they reflect an ongoing epidemic of\nWB in IDUs that began in CA about 1994. Cases here have occurred\ndisproportionately in Hispanics and women, and major risk factors\nhave been the route of administration (e.g., by \"skin popping\") and\nthe amount of BTH injected subcutaneously.\nWB in IDUs is now being reported in other states and other countries.\nWe have observed frequent misdiagnosis and diagnostic delays of up to\n64 days in WB cases. The above CID article discusses BTH, the\nclinical and laboratory features that distinguish botulism from other\nconditions that can mimic it, the relative value of diagnostic\nlaboratory tests for botulism, and its treatment.\nAs an aside, we have also learned of cases of necrotizing fasciitis\n(NF) in CA that have occurred in BTH users in recent times; and, in\nsome who had anaerobic cultures taken, a variety of _Clostridium_\nspecies has been recovered. We don't know the extent to which NF is\noccurring in CA, or the extent to which NF cases might be associated\nwith BTH, since NF is not a reportable disease in this state.\n--\nS. B. Werner, M.D., Chief\nDisease Investigations Section\nDivision of Communicable Disease Control\nCalifornia Department of Health Services\n2151 Berkeley Way\nBerkeley, California 94704\nTelephone (510) 540-2566\nFax (510) 540-2570\n<bwerner@dhs.ca.gov> (note that there is no \"s\" before the \"b\" in my\ne-mail address)\n[Thank you Dr. Werner for this update. The full text of this article\ncan be read on-line at:\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v31n4/994092/994092.html>\nIn this article the authors present the review of the 127 cases of\nwound botulism reported in this period, of which 93 had been reported\nin the period 1993 to 1998. The epidemic curve presented in Figure 1\nof this article clearly supports the conclusion that there is a newly\nemerging problem of wound botulism associated with injecting drug use\nin California\n<http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/CID/journal/issues/v31n4/994092/994092.fg1.html>\n- Mod.MPP\n.......................mpp/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-02-25 00:00:00", "2002-02-22 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the State of California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "M.D.", "country": "Dominican Republic"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201430", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Botulism, wound, drug-related - UK: alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201430", "date": "2001-10-31 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BREAD PRODUCTS - CANADA: RECALL\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nBotulism advisory, beef jerky - Canada (N.S.): recall 20010217.0313\nBotulism, baby formula - UK, Ireland: recall\n20010814.1919\nBotulism, chili - USA (Texas): recall\n20010904.2116\nDate: 30 Oct 2001 03:16\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Canada Newswire via COMTEX [edited\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) and INDIANLife Food\nCorporation are warning the public not to consume INDIANLife brand\nRoti Wraps and 6 varieties of Naan Breads. It is possible that these\nproducts may support growth of bacteria responsible for botulism in\nhumans. These products should not be consumed.\nAll Best Before codes of the following products are affected by this\nalert.\n1. Coriander & Herbs Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00120 9\n2. Garlic Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 7762 00102 5\n3. Onion Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00100 1\n4. Spinach Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00121 6\n5. Tandoori Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00101 8\n6. Whole Wheat Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00110 0\n7. Roti Wraps, 250 g, UPC 7 77762 00108 7\nThese products manufactured by INDIANLife Food Corp., Burnaby, British\nColumbia, have been distributed in British Columbia, Alberta,\nSaskatchewan, and Manitoba. The manufacturer is voluntarily recalling\nthe affected products from the marketplace.\nThere have been no reported illnesses associated with the consumption\nof these products.\nFoods contaminated with _C. botulinum_ bacteria may not look or smell\nspoiled. Botulism is a life-threatening illness caused by toxins\nproduced by _Clostridium botulinum_ bacteria. Consumers should dispose\nof remaining product immediately or return products to the point of\npurchase for a refund.\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency is monitoring the effectiveness of\nthe recall.\nFor more information, consumers and industry can call INDIANLife Food\nCorporation or the CFIA at one of the following numbers:\nINDIANLife Food Corporation\nRakesh Raniga\n604-205-9176\nCFIA\nIn the province of Quebec 1-800-561-3350; or\nIn other provinces and territories 1-800-442-2342.\nFor information on receiving recalls by electronic mail, or for other\nfood safety facts, visit our web site at:\n\nVIEW ADDITIONAL COMPANY-SPECIFIC INFORMATION:\n<http://www.newswire.ca/cgi-bin/inquiry.cgi?OKEY=23502>\nCONTACT: For further information:\nMedia enquiries:\nDavendra Sharma (English)\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency\nOffice of Food Safety and Recall,\n(613) 755-2890\nBenoit Blangez (French)\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency\nOffice of Food Safety and Recall\n(613) 760-4068\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n...............................mpp/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It is possible that these\nproducts may support growth of bacteria responsible for botulism in\nhumans. These products should not be consumed.\nAll Best Before codes of the following products are affected by this\nalert.\n1. Coriander & Herbs Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00120 9\n2. Garlic Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 7762 00102 5\n3. Onion Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00100 1\n4. Spinach Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00121 6\n5. Tandoori Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00101 8\n6. The manufacturer is voluntarily recalling\nthe affected products from the marketplace.\nThere have been no reported illnesses associated with the consumption\nof these products.\nFoods contaminated with _C. botulinum_ bacteria may not look or smell\nspoiled. Botulism is a life-threatening illness caused by toxins\nproduced by _Clostridium botulinum_ bacteria. Consumers should dispose\nof remaining product immediately or return products to the point of\npurchase for a refund.\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency is monitoring the effectiveness of\nthe recall.\nFor more information, consumers and industry can call INDIANLife Food\nCorporation or the CFIA at one of the following numbers:\nINDIANLife Food Corporation\nRakesh Raniga\n604-205-9176\nCFIA\nIn the province of Quebec 1-800-561-3350; or\nIn other provinces and territories 1-800-442-2342.\nFor information on receiving recalls by electronic mail, or for other\nfood safety facts, visit our web site at:\n\nVIEW ADDITIONAL COMPANY-SPECIFIC INFORMATION:\n<http://www.newswire.ca/cgi-bin/inquiry.cgi?OKEY=23502>\nCONTACT: For further information:\nMedia enquiries:\nDavendra Sharma (English)\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency\nOffice of Food Safety and Recall,\n(613) 755-2890\nBenoit Blangez (French)\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency\nOffice of Food Safety and Recall\n(613) 760-4068\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n...............................mpp/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It is possible that these\nproducts may support growth of bacteria responsible for botulism in\nhumans. These products should not be consumed.\nAll Best Before codes of the following products are affected by this\nalert.\n1. Coriander & Herbs Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00120 9\n2. Garlic Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 7762 00102 5\n3. Onion Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00100 1\n4. Spinach Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00121 6\n5. Tandoori Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00101 8\n6. Whole Wheat Naan, 500 g, UPC 7 77762 00110 0\n7. Roti Wraps, 250 g, UPC 7 77762 00108 7\nThese products manufactured by INDIANLife Food Corp., Burnaby, British\nColumbia, have been distributed in British Columbia, Alberta,\nSaskatchewan, and Manitoba. The manufacturer is voluntarily recalling\nthe affected products from the marketplace.\nThere have been no reported illnesses associated with the consumption\nof these products.\nFoods contaminated with _C. botulinum_ bacteria may not look or smell\nspoiled. Botulism is a life-threatening illness caused by toxins\nproduced by _Clostridium botulinum_ bacteria. Consumers should dispose\nof remaining product immediately or return products to the point of\npurchase for a refund.\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency is monitoring the effectiveness of\nthe recall.\nFor more information, consumers and industry can call INDIANLife Food\nCorporation or the CFIA at one of the following numbers:\nINDIANLife Food Corporation\nRakesh Raniga\n604-205-9176\nCFIA\nIn the province of Quebec 1-800-561-3350; or\nIn other provinces and territories 1-800-442-2342.\nFor information on receiving recalls by electronic mail, or for other\nfood safety facts, visit our web site at:\n\nVIEW ADDITIONAL COMPANY-SPECIFIC INFORMATION:\n<http://www.newswire.ca/cgi-bin/inquiry.cgi?OKEY=23502>\nCONTACT: For further information:\nMedia enquiries:\nDavendra Sharma (English)\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency\nOffice of Food Safety and Recall,\n(613) 755-2890\nBenoit Blangez (French)\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency\nOffice of Food Safety and Recall\n(613) 760-4068\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n...............................mpp/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Analysis of domestic botulism morbidity for the\n9-month period of 1999. \"Public Health and Environment\" Bulletin, Issue\n#11, November 1999, p.29\n\nIn Russia 80% of all food poisoning cases are due to botulism. In 1998, 374\noutbreaks of botulism were registered; 501 people were sick and 41 died.\nIn the period January-September 1999, 168 outbreaks were registered, 242\npeople were sick, including 23 children; 21 died, including 1 child under 1\nyear old.\nIn 1999, 169 infected people were in urban and 72 in rural areas. People of\n30-50 years old were most affected. The majority of botulism cases are the\nresult of eating fish (34%), mushrooms (33,8%) and canned vegetables\n(25,8%). In lab investigations the type of botulinum toxin isolated from\nmushrooms and meat is most often type B, from fish type E, and from\nvegetables type A.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n...........................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. In 1998, 374\noutbreaks of botulism were registered; 501 people were sick and 41 died.\nIn the period January-September 1999, 168 outbreaks were registered, 242\npeople were sick, including 23 children; 21 died, including 1 child under 1\nyear old.\nIn 1999, 169 infected people were in urban and 72 in rural areas. People of\n30-50 years old were most affected. The majority of botulism cases are the\nresult of eating fish (34%), mushrooms (33,8%) and canned vegetables\n(25,8%). Analysis of domestic botulism morbidity for the\n9-month period of 1999. \"Public Health and Environment\" Bulletin, Issue\n#11, November 1999, p.29\n\nIn Russia 80% of all food poisoning cases are due to botulism. In 1998, 374\noutbreaks of botulism were registered; 501 people were sick and 41 died.\nIn the period January-September 1999, 168 outbreaks were registered, 242\npeople were sick, including 23 children; 21 died, including 1 child under 1\nyear old.\nIn 1999, 169 infected people were in urban and 72 in rural areas. People of\n30-50 years old were most affected. The majority of botulism cases are the\nresult of eating fish (34%), mushrooms (33,8%) and canned vegetables\n(25,8%). In lab investigations the type of botulinum toxin isolated from\nmushrooms and meat is most often type B, from fish type E, and from\nvegetables type A.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n...........................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Pollack\" <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Inside Denver. Com,\nhttp://insidedenver.com/news/0724bird8.shtml (Edited)\n\nMore than 1000 waterfowl, shorebirds and songbirds have died of\na suspected outbreak of avian botulism at Milton Reservoir in Weld\nCounty, Colorado, USA.\n\"We have sent samples to Oregon to be analyzed and won't have\nresults for a couple of days, but everything is consistent with avian\nbotulism,\" said Colorado Division of Wildlife spokesman Fred\nQuartarone.\nThe disease isn't harmful to humans. Biologists say it is a bacterial\npoison birds contract the same way humans do -- by eating tainted\nfood.\nThe bacteria are found in wetlands in spore form resistant to heat\nand drying, the Audubon Society's Encyclopedia of North American\nBirds says.\n_Clostridium botulinum_ type C occurs naturally in soil. It thrives on\ndecaying plants and dead animals in warm water where there is an\nabundance of decaying animal matter, maggots and a lack of\noxygen.\nAs there are more dead birds, more flies lay their eggs which hatch\ninto botulism-infested maggots that birds eat. The toxin paralyses\nthe neurological system of the bird, which then dies.\nAn outbreak of type C in the U.S. and Canada a few years ago\nkilled millions of birds.\nOfficers have almost cleaned up the carcasses. They are being\nburied in a landfill. \"The good news is after scooping up dead birds,\nwe now are starting to see more and more live birds on the water\nand the shoreline, so we are hopeful we've cleaned it up,\" he said.\n..........................................tg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Biologists say it is a bacterial\npoison birds contract the same way humans do -- by eating tainted\nfood.\nThe bacteria are found in wetlands in spore form resistant to heat\nand drying, the Audubon Society's Encyclopedia of North American\nBirds says.\n_Clostridium botulinum_ type C occurs naturally in soil. The toxin paralyses\nthe neurological system of the bird, which then dies.\nAn outbreak of type C in the U.S. and Canada a few years ago\nkilled millions of birds.\nOfficers have almost cleaned up the carcasses. They are being\nburied in a landfill. \"The good news is after scooping up dead birds,\nwe now are starting to see more and more live birds on the water\nand the shoreline, so we are hopeful we've cleaned it up,\" he said.\n..........................................tg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Pollack\" <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Inside Denver. Com,\nhttp://insidedenver.com/news/0724bird8.shtml (Edited)\n\nMore than 1000 waterfowl, shorebirds and songbirds have died of\na suspected outbreak of avian botulism at Milton Reservoir in Weld\nCounty, Colorado, USA.\n\"We have sent samples to Oregon to be analyzed and won't have\nresults for a couple of days, but everything is consistent with avian\nbotulism,\" said Colorado Division of Wildlife spokesman Fred\nQuartarone.\nThe disease isn't harmful to humans. Biologists say it is a bacterial\npoison birds contract the same way humans do -- by eating tainted\nfood.\nThe bacteria are found in wetlands in spore form resistant to heat\nand drying, the Audubon Society's Encyclopedia of North American\nBirds says.\n_Clostridium botulinum_ type C occurs naturally in soil. It thrives on\ndecaying plants and dead animals in warm water where there is an\nabundance of decaying animal matter, maggots and a lack of\noxygen.\nAs there are more dead birds, more flies lay their eggs which hatch\ninto botulism-infested maggots that birds eat. The toxin paralyses\nthe neurological system of the bird, which then dies.\nAn outbreak of type C in the U.S. and Canada a few years ago\nkilled millions of birds.\nOfficers have almost cleaned up the carcasses. They are being\nburied in a landfill. \"The good news is after scooping up dead birds,\nwe now are starting to see more and more live birds on the water\nand the shoreline, so we are hopeful we've cleaned it up,\" he said.\n..........................................tg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Com,\nhttp://insidedenver.com/news/0724bird8.shtml (Edited)\n\nMore than 1000 waterfowl, shorebirds and songbirds have died of\na suspected outbreak of avian botulism at Milton Reservoir in Weld\nCounty, Colorado, USA.\n\"We have sent samples to Oregon to be analyzed and won't have\nresults for a couple of days, but everything is consistent with avian\nbotulism,\" said Colorado Division of Wildlife spokesman Fred\nQuartarone.\nThe disease isn't harmful to humans. Biologists say it is a bacterial\npoison birds contract the same way humans do -- by eating tainted\nfood.\nThe bacteria are found in wetlands in spore form resistant to heat\nand drying, the Audubon Society's Encyclopedia of North American\nBirds says.\n_Clostridium botulinum_ type C occurs naturally in soil. It thrives on\ndecaying plants and dead animals in warm water where there is an\nabundance of decaying animal matter, maggots and a lack of\noxygen.\nAs there are more dead birds, more flies lay their eggs which hatch\ninto botulism-infested maggots that birds eat. The toxin paralyses\nthe neurological system of the bird, which then dies.\nAn outbreak of type C in the U.S. and Canada a few years ago\nkilled millions of birds.\nOfficers have almost cleaned up the carcasses. They are being\nburied in a landfill. \"The good news is after scooping up dead birds,\nwe now are starting to see more and more live birds on the water\nand the shoreline, so we are hopeful we've cleaned it up,\" he said.\n..........................................tg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Pollack\" <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Inside Denver. Com,\nhttp://insidedenver.com/news/0724bird8.shtml (Edited)\n\nMore than 1000 waterfowl, shorebirds and songbirds have died of\na suspected outbreak of avian botulism at Milton Reservoir in Weld\nCounty, Colorado, USA.\n\"We have sent samples to Oregon to be analyzed and won't have\nresults for a couple of days, but everything is consistent with avian\nbotulism,\" said Colorado Division of Wildlife spokesman Fred\nQuartarone.\nThe disease isn't harmful to humans. Biologists say it is a bacterial\npoison birds contract the same way humans do -- by eating tainted\nfood.\nThe bacteria are found in wetlands in spore form resistant to heat\nand drying, the Audubon Society's Encyclopedia of North American\nBirds says.\n_Clostridium botulinum_ type C occurs naturally in soil. It thrives on\ndecaying plants and dead animals in warm water where there is an\nabundance of decaying animal matter, maggots and a lack of\noxygen.\nAs there are more dead birds, more flies lay their eggs which hatch\ninto botulism-infested maggots that birds eat. The toxin paralyses\nthe neurological system of the bird, which then dies.\nAn outbreak of type C in the U.S. and Canada a few years ago\nkilled millions of birds.\nOfficers have almost cleaned up the carcasses. They are being\nburied in a landfill. \"The good news is after scooping up dead birds,\nwe now are starting to see more and more live birds on the water\nand the shoreline, so we are hopeful we've cleaned it up,\" he said.\n..........................................tg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Modesto Bee On-line (edited) Wed 2 June, 1999\n\nFour more cows died last weekend at the Hibma Dairy near Ballico,\nCalifornia, USA, but state officials believe the worst part of the botulism\nincidence that killed 140 animals is over.\n\"Some cows survived the botulism, but they are in a weakened condition and\nare stressed,\" state Department of Agriculture spokesman Oscar Hidalgo\nsaid. \"Even as summer approaches others may die, not directly from the\nbotulism, but from symptoms related to the outbreak.\"\nThe remaining healthy cows at the dairy are being milked, and their milk is\nbeing processed at high-heat into products such as butter and milk powder.\nRichard Breitmeyer, state veterinarian and director of Animal Health and\nFood Safety Services, said although laboratory tests remain inconclusive,\neverything points to one large bale of hay as the source of the botulism.\n\"We are quite certain the hay is the source. How it came to be inside the\nhay, we don't know,\" he said.\nWhen several hundred cows died from botulism at the Genasci Brothers Dairy\nin Modesto last year, the source was tracked to a cat carcass that had been\nmixed in with the hay.\n\"We have had no such luck in this case,\" Breitmeyer said. \"All the things\nwe've tested have come back negative for the botulism toxin.\"\nHe said it is likely all the suspect feed was consumed before state\nscientists arrived at the dairy. Some rodent and bird bones were found in\nthe hay, but Breitmeyer said that is not unusual in large bales.\nBreitmeyer said there has been some speculation that big, tightly packed\nbales of hay can provide an environment for botulism, even without the\npresence of an animal carcass.\n\"But we must be careful not to jump to some assumption,\" Breitmeyer said.\n\"I think we really need to get some research, and one of our goals is to\ntake a hard look at this.\"\nOrganizers are now trying to help make sure the dairy can start accepting\nsome donations of animals, Hidalgo said. Joe Ramos, a field representative\nwith Western United Dairymen, said the association is sending a statewide\nmailer to all Grade A dairies informing them about the Hibmas' situation.\nWestern United Dairymen is collecting the names of people interested in\ndonating animals to the dairy. People wishing to donate money are asked to\nmake checks payable to the Hibma Dairy Trust Fund, and send the checks to\nWestern United Dairymen, 1315 K St., Modesto, California, USA 95354.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n.......................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-06-02 00:00:00", "1315-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ballico", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "Hibmas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Modesto", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2196085", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism, avian: cause & cure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2196085", "date": "1999-06-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - USA (CALIFORNIA) (04)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) 990524234503\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) (02) 990526223010\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) (03) 990528220003\nDate: Thu, 03 Jun 1999 03:00:17 -0400\nFrom: Marjorie P. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Modesto Bee On-line (edited) Wed 2 June, 1999\n\nFour more cows died last weekend at the Hibma Dairy near Ballico,\nCalifornia, USA, but state officials believe the worst part of the botulism\nincidence that killed 140 animals is over.\n\"Some cows survived the botulism, but they are in a weakened condition and\nare stressed,\" state Department of Agriculture spokesman Oscar Hidalgo\nsaid. \"Even as summer approaches others may die, not directly from the\nbotulism, but from symptoms related to the outbreak.\"\nThe remaining healthy cows at the dairy are being milked, and their milk is\nbeing processed at high-heat into products such as butter and milk powder.\nRichard Breitmeyer, state veterinarian and director of Animal Health and\nFood Safety Services, said although laboratory tests remain inconclusive,\neverything points to one large bale of hay as the source of the botulism.\n\"We are quite certain the hay is the source. How it came to be inside the\nhay, we don't know,\" he said.\nWhen several hundred cows died from botulism at the Genasci Brothers Dairy\nin Modesto last year, the source was tracked to a cat carcass that had been\nmixed in with the hay.\n\"We have had no such luck in this case,\" Breitmeyer said. \"All the things\nwe've tested have come back negative for the botulism toxin.\"\nHe said it is likely all the suspect feed was consumed before state\nscientists arrived at the dairy. Some rodent and bird bones were found in\nthe hay, but Breitmeyer said that is not unusual in large bales.\nBreitmeyer said there has been some speculation that big, tightly packed\nbales of hay can provide an environment for botulism, even without the\npresence of an animal carcass.\n\"But we must be careful not to jump to some assumption,\" Breitmeyer said.\n\"I think we really need to get some research, and one of our goals is to\ntake a hard look at this.\"\nOrganizers are now trying to help make sure the dairy can start accepting\nsome donations of animals, Hidalgo said. Joe Ramos, a field representative\nwith Western United Dairymen, said the association is sending a statewide\nmailer to all Grade A dairies informing them about the Hibmas' situation.\nWestern United Dairymen is collecting the names of people interested in\ndonating animals to the dairy. People wishing to donate money are asked to\nmake checks payable to the Hibma Dairy Trust Fund, and send the checks to\nWestern United Dairymen, 1315 K St., Modesto, California, USA 95354.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n.......................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Modesto Bee On-line (edited) Wed 2 June, 1999\n\nFour more cows died last weekend at the Hibma Dairy near Ballico,\nCalifornia, USA, but state officials believe the worst part of the botulism\nincidence that killed 140 animals is over.\n\"Some cows survived the botulism, but they are in a weakened condition and\nare stressed,\" state Department of Agriculture spokesman Oscar Hidalgo\nsaid. \"Even as summer approaches others may die, not directly from the\nbotulism, but from symptoms related to the outbreak.\"\nThe remaining healthy cows at the dairy are being milked, and their milk is\nbeing processed at high-heat into products such as butter and milk powder.\nRichard Breitmeyer, state veterinarian and director of Animal Health and\nFood Safety Services, said although laboratory tests remain inconclusive,\neverything points to one large bale of hay as the source of the botulism.\n\"We are quite certain the hay is the source. How it came to be inside the\nhay, we don't know,\" he said.\nWhen several hundred cows died from botulism at the Genasci Brothers Dairy\nin Modesto last year, the source was tracked to a cat carcass that had been\nmixed in with the hay.\n\"We have had no such luck in this case,\" Breitmeyer said. \"All the things\nwe've tested have come back negative for the botulism toxin.\"\nHe said it is likely all the suspect feed was consumed before state\nscientists arrived at the dairy. Some rodent and bird bones were found in\nthe hay, but Breitmeyer said that is not unusual in large bales.\nBreitmeyer said there has been some speculation that big, tightly packed\nbales of hay can provide an environment for botulism, even without the\npresence of an animal carcass.\n\"But we must be careful not to jump to some assumption,\" Breitmeyer said.\n\"I think we really need to get some research, and one of our goals is to\ntake a hard look at this.\"\nOrganizers are now trying to help make sure the dairy can start accepting\nsome donations of animals, Hidalgo said. Joe Ramos, a field representative\nwith Western United Dairymen, said the association is sending a statewide\nmailer to all Grade A dairies informing them about the Hibmas' situation.\nWestern United Dairymen is collecting the names of people interested in\ndonating animals to the dairy. People wishing to donate money are asked to\nmake checks payable to the Hibma Dairy Trust Fund, and send the checks to\nWestern United Dairymen, 1315 K St., Modesto, California, USA 95354.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n.......................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
