Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Modesto Bee On-line (edited) Wed 2 June, 1999\n\nFour more cows died last weekend at the Hibma Dairy near Ballico,\nCalifornia, USA, but state officials believe the worst part of the botulism\nincidence that killed 140 animals is over.\n\"Some cows survived the botulism, but they are in a weakened condition and\nare stressed,\" state Department of Agriculture spokesman Oscar Hidalgo\nsaid. \"Even as summer approaches others may die, not directly from the\nbotulism, but from symptoms related to the outbreak.\"\nThe remaining healthy cows at the dairy are being milked, and their milk is\nbeing processed at high-heat into products such as butter and milk powder.\nRichard Breitmeyer, state veterinarian and director of Animal Health and\nFood Safety Services, said although laboratory tests remain inconclusive,\neverything points to one large bale of hay as the source of the botulism.\n\"We are quite certain the hay is the source. How it came to be inside the\nhay, we don't know,\" he said.\nWhen several hundred cows died from botulism at the Genasci Brothers Dairy\nin Modesto last year, the source was tracked to a cat carcass that had been\nmixed in with the hay.\n\"We have had no such luck in this case,\" Breitmeyer said. \"All the things\nwe've tested have come back negative for the botulism toxin.\"\nHe said it is likely all the suspect feed was consumed before state\nscientists arrived at the dairy. Some rodent and bird bones were found in\nthe hay, but Breitmeyer said that is not unusual in large bales.\nBreitmeyer said there has been some speculation that big, tightly packed\nbales of hay can provide an environment for botulism, even without the\npresence of an animal carcass.\n\"But we must be careful not to jump to some assumption,\" Breitmeyer said.\n\"I think we really need to get some research, and one of our goals is to\ntake a hard look at this.\"\nOrganizers are now trying to help make sure the dairy can start accepting\nsome donations of animals, Hidalgo said. Joe Ramos, a field representative\nwith Western United Dairymen, said the association is sending a statewide\nmailer to all Grade A dairies informing them about the Hibmas' situation.\nWestern United Dairymen is collecting the names of people interested in\ndonating animals to the dairy. People wishing to donate money are asked to\nmake checks payable to the Hibma Dairy Trust Fund, and send the checks to\nWestern United Dairymen, 1315 K St., Modesto, California, USA 95354.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n.......................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Joe Ramos, a field representative\nwith Western United Dairymen, said the association is sending a statewide\nmailer to all Grade A dairies informing them about the Hibmas' situation.\nWestern United Dairymen is collecting the names of people interested in\ndonating animals to the dairy. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Modesto Bee On-line (edited) Wed 2 June, 1999\n\nFour more cows died last weekend at the Hibma Dairy near Ballico,\nCalifornia, USA, but state officials believe the worst part of the botulism\nincidence that killed 140 animals is over.\n\"Some cows survived the botulism, but they are in a weakened condition and\nare stressed,\" state Department of Agriculture spokesman Oscar Hidalgo\nsaid. \"Even as summer approaches others may die, not directly from the\nbotulism, but from symptoms related to the outbreak.\"\nThe remaining healthy cows at the dairy are being milked, and their milk is\nbeing processed at high-heat into products such as butter and milk powder.\nRichard Breitmeyer, state veterinarian and director of Animal Health and\nFood Safety Services, said although laboratory tests remain inconclusive,\neverything points to one large bale of hay as the source of the botulism.\n\"We are quite certain the hay is the source. How it came to be inside the\nhay, we don't know,\" he said.\nWhen several hundred cows died from botulism at the Genasci Brothers Dairy\nin Modesto last year, the source was tracked to a cat carcass that had been\nmixed in with the hay.\n\"We have had no such luck in this case,\" Breitmeyer said. \"All the things\nwe've tested have come back negative for the botulism toxin.\"\nHe said it is likely all the suspect feed was consumed before state\nscientists arrived at the dairy. Some rodent and bird bones were found in\nthe hay, but Breitmeyer said that is not unusual in large bales.\nBreitmeyer said there has been some speculation that big, tightly packed\nbales of hay can provide an environment for botulism, even without the\npresence of an animal carcass.\n\"But we must be careful not to jump to some assumption,\" Breitmeyer said.\n\"I think we really need to get some research, and one of our goals is to\ntake a hard look at this.\"\nOrganizers are now trying to help make sure the dairy can start accepting\nsome donations of animals, Hidalgo said. Joe Ramos, a field representative\nwith Western United Dairymen, said the association is sending a statewide\nmailer to all Grade A dairies informing them about the Hibmas' situation.\nWestern United Dairymen is collecting the names of people interested in\ndonating animals to the dairy. Some rodent and bird bones were found in\nthe hay, but Breitmeyer said that is not unusual in large bales.\nBreitmeyer said there has been some speculation that big, tightly packed\nbales of hay can provide an environment for botulism, even without the\npresence of an animal carcass.\n\"But we must be careful not to jump to some assumption,\" Breitmeyer said.\n\"I think we really need to get some research, and one of our goals is to\ntake a hard look at this.\"\nOrganizers are now trying to help make sure the dairy can start accepting\nsome donations of animals, Hidalgo said. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-06-02 00:00:00", "1315-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ballico", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "Hibmas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Modesto", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195769", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism, bovine - USA (California) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2195769", "date": "1999-06-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM, BOVINE - USA (CALIFORNIA) (04)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) 990524234503\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) (02) 990526223010\nBotulism, bovine - USA (California) (03) 990528220003\nDate: Thu, 03 Jun 1999 03:00:17 -0400\nFrom: Marjorie P. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: Modesto Bee On-line (edited) Wed 2 June, 1999\n\nFour more cows died last weekend at the Hibma Dairy near Ballico,\nCalifornia, USA, but state officials believe the worst part of the botulism\nincidence that killed 140 animals is over.\n\"Some cows survived the botulism, but they are in a weakened condition and\nare stressed,\" state Department of Agriculture spokesman Oscar Hidalgo\nsaid. \"Even as summer approaches others may die, not directly from the\nbotulism, but from symptoms related to the outbreak.\"\nThe remaining healthy cows at the dairy are being milked, and their milk is\nbeing processed at high-heat into products such as butter and milk powder.\nRichard Breitmeyer, state veterinarian and director of Animal Health and\nFood Safety Services, said although laboratory tests remain inconclusive,\neverything points to one large bale of hay as the source of the botulism.\n\"We are quite certain the hay is the source. How it came to be inside the\nhay, we don't know,\" he said.\nWhen several hundred cows died from botulism at the Genasci Brothers Dairy\nin Modesto last year, the source was tracked to a cat carcass that had been\nmixed in with the hay.\n\"We have had no such luck in this case,\" Breitmeyer said. \"All the things\nwe've tested have come back negative for the botulism toxin.\"\nHe said it is likely all the suspect feed was consumed before state\nscientists arrived at the dairy. Some rodent and bird bones were found in\nthe hay, but Breitmeyer said that is not unusual in large bales.\nBreitmeyer said there has been some speculation that big, tightly packed\nbales of hay can provide an environment for botulism, even without the\npresence of an animal carcass.\n\"But we must be careful not to jump to some assumption,\" Breitmeyer said.\n\"I think we really need to get some research, and one of our goals is to\ntake a hard look at this.\"\nOrganizers are now trying to help make sure the dairy can start accepting\nsome donations of animals, Hidalgo said. Joe Ramos, a field representative\nwith Western United Dairymen, said the association is sending a statewide\nmailer to all Grade A dairies informing them about the Hibmas' situation.\nWestern United Dairymen is collecting the names of people interested in\ndonating animals to the dairy. People wishing to donate money are asked to\nmake checks payable to the Hibma Dairy Trust Fund, and send the checks to\nWestern United Dairymen, 1315 K St., Modesto, California, USA 95354.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n.......................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Airmail would have been\nfaster! - Mod.JW]\nEuropewide alert over Italian bottled vegetables\n---------------------------------------------------------\nA warning has gone to all Member States of the European Union after a\npatient was treated for botulism at the Istituto Superiore Di Sanita,\nRome. Botulinum toxin was apparently detected in the product eaten by\nthe patient [in Aug 1998].\nThe product is marketed under two different names -- either\n\"Ribollita Toscana\", or \"Minestrone Di Verdure\". It is manufactured\nand packed by \"Fattorie Toscana Riunite SRL (Lucca) at a factory in\nBolgheri-Bibbona (Livorno), Italy. It is contained in glass jars with\na net weight of either 340g or 640g, and has a 'best before' date of\n31/12/2002.\nThe product is distributed within France, Germany, and Switzerland.\n.....................jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-09-02 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Lucca", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2194238", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - Canada (Alberta)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194238", "date": "1998-08-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM FROM PEYOTE - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nBotulism - Canada and Alaska? 971003000744\nDate: Mon, 3 Aug 1998 17:04:13 GMT-3\nSource: New England Journal of Medicine online\n<http://www.nejm.org/content/1998/0339/0003/0203b.asp>\nVia: ProMED-PORT <promed-port@usa.healthnet.org>\n\nThirteen members of the Native American Church of Navajoland drank peyote\ntea from a communal jar during a religious ceremony. Peyote is a cactus\nwith hallucinogenic properties; its use is legal in traditional American\nIndian ceremonies.\nThree of the 13, all men aged 40, 42 & 72, came down with bilateral,\nsymmetric weakness in all extremities 2-4 days later. In addition, 2 had\nspeech disturbances and double vision. The peyote was found to contain type\nB botulinum toxin by an assay at CDC, Atlanta.\nOne case was hospitalized and required parenteral nutrition for 14 days.\nAll recovered in 4-12 weeks. None were treated with antibotulinum toxin,\nsince that is reserved for people whose condition deteriorates seriously.\nThe peyote tea was made from cactus buttons ground with alkali and stored\nunder water in a closed jar for 2 months in the refrigerator. This is not\nthe traditional way of preparation, and it allowed spores of _Clostridium\nbotulinum_, which were on the cactus (since they are found in the\nenvironment) to germinate and produce the toxin.\n[Authored by: H. Hashimoto, V.J.Clyde & K.L.Parko\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[Foodborne botulism, generally caused by type E botulinum toxin, occurs\nwith an unusually high incidence among native populations in northern\nCanada and Alaska as well. This problem has been recognized for decades,\nand is often associated with inappropriate modifications of traditional\nfermentation/preservation practices applied to seal, whale, or other meats.\nReference: Shaffer, N. et al., West. J. Med 153(4):390-393, 1990. - Mod.ES\n....................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Peyote is a cactus\nwith hallucinogenic properties; its use is legal in traditional American\nIndian ceremonies.\nThree of the 13, all men aged 40, 42 & 72, came down with bilateral,\nsymmetric weakness in all extremities 2-4 days later. In addition, 2 had\nspeech disturbances and double vision. The peyote was found to contain type\nB botulinum toxin by an assay at CDC, Atlanta.\nOne case was hospitalized and required parenteral nutrition for 14 days.\nAll recovered in 4-12 weeks. None were treated with antibotulinum toxin,\nsince that is reserved for people whose condition deteriorates seriously.\nThe peyote tea was made from cactus buttons ground with alkali and stored\nunder water in a closed jar for 2 months in the refrigerator. This is not\nthe traditional way of preparation, and it allowed spores of _Clostridium\nbotulinum_, which were on the cactus (since they are found in the\nenvironment) to germinate and produce the toxin.\n[Authored by: H. Hashimoto, V.J.Clyde & K.L.Parko\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[Foodborne botulism, generally caused by type E botulinum toxin, occurs\nwith an unusually high incidence among native populations in northern\nCanada and Alaska as well. This problem has been recognized for decades,\nand is often associated with inappropriate modifications of traditional\nfermentation/preservation practices applied to seal, whale, or other meats.\nReference: Shaffer, N. et al., West. J. None were treated with antibotulinum toxin,\nsince that is reserved for people whose condition deteriorates seriously.\nThe peyote tea was made from cactus buttons ground with alkali and stored\nunder water in a closed jar for 2 months in the refrigerator. None were treated with antibotulinum toxin,\nsince that is reserved for people whose condition deteriorates seriously.\nThe peyote tea was made from cactus buttons ground with alkali and stored\nunder water in a closed jar for 2 months in the refrigerator. This is not\nthe traditional way of preparation, and it allowed spores of _Clostridium\nbotulinum_, which were on the cactus (since they are found in the\nenvironment) to germinate and produce the toxin.\n[Authored by: H. This problem has been recognized for decades,\nand is often associated with inappropriate modifications of traditional\nfermentation/preservation practices applied to seal, whale, or other meats.\nReference: Shaffer, N. et al., West. J. Med 153(4):390-393, 1990. - Mod.ES\n....................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2040-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2193810", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, human - Algeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2193810", "date": "1997-10-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOTULISM - CANADA AND ALASKA?\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nSee Also\nBotulism - Canada 970921121301\nBotulism - Canada (02) 970926004444\nDate: Mon, 29 Sep 1997 13:33:00 PST8PDT\nFrom: gcantor@vetmed.wsu.edu\n\nAre you sure that the botulism cases were associated with muktuk? I don't\nknow if the terminology in the Canadian arctic is different from that in\nAlaska. In Alaska, at any rate, \"muktuk\" refers to whale skin and fat which\nis eaten fresh (raw) or is frozen and then, when thawed, either eaten raw\nor boiled. It is quite tasty.\n\"Mikiuk\" or \"mikiuq\" or \"mikigaq\" refers to the fermented whale meat and\nfat. In Alaska, this material has been associated with botulism cases.\n--\nGlenn H. Cantor\nDepartment of Veterinary Microbiology/Pathology\nWashington State University\nPullman WA 99164-7040\ngcantor@vetmed.wsu.edu\nphone 509-335-6042; fax 509-335-8529\n........................................pc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Taylor\" <JTAYLOR@DISCON.TDH.STATE.TX.US>\nOrganization: Texas Department of Health\nDate: Fri, 26 Jan 1996 16:34:19 -0600 (CST)\n\nFOODBORNE BOTULISM - TEXAS, USA\n===============================\nTwo cases of adult foodborne botulism have been identified in Texas.\nThe patients, a 65-year-old female and her 60-year-old brother, had\nonset of symptoms on 1/12/96 and 1/10/96, respectively. The\npatients were hospitalized at different hospitals in\nVictoria, Texas. Both had respiratory impairment in addition to\ndifficulty swallowing, voice changes, and double vision. Botulism\nwas suspected on 1/18/96 by the pulmonologist who saw both patients.\nSerum collected from both patients on 1/18/96 is negative for\nbotulinal toxin by the mouse assay. Stool collected 1/18/96 from the\nbrother is negative for toxin but is culture positive for Clostridium\nbotulinium. Stool has not be collected from the sister.\nBoth patients have a history of consuming home-canned asparagus. The\nsister was given 12 jars of asparagus by a relative. She gave 1 jar\nto her brother. The brother consumed one spear the evening of\n1/9/96, the asparagus tasted bad, the jar contents were discarded.\nThe sister tasted asparagus from another jar on the evening of\n1/10/96, this asparagus also tasted bad. Contents of her 11 jars\nwere discarded. The jars were not washed after the contents were\ndiscarded. A pooled washing of these 11 jars was culture\npositive for Clostridium botulinium. Botulinal toxin was also\ndetected in this washing. The relative who canned the asparagus\nresides in Washington state. Home-canned asparagus in her possession\nalso have been positive for botulinal toxin. All remaining jars\n(35) of asparagus have been destroyed.\nBoth patients are recovering. These are the first foodborne botulism\ncases reported in Texas since April 1994.\n--\nJeffery P. Taylor\ne-mail: JTAYLOR@DISCON.TDH.STATE.TX.US\nTexas Department of Health\n.............................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). The brother consumed one spear the evening of\n1/9/96, the asparagus tasted bad, the jar contents were discarded.\nThe sister tasted asparagus from another jar on the evening of\n1/10/96, this asparagus also tasted bad. Botulinal toxin was also\ndetected in this washing. The relative who canned the asparagus\nresides in Washington state. Home-canned asparagus in her possession\nalso have been positive for botulinal toxin. All remaining jars\n(35) of asparagus have been destroyed.\nBoth patients are recovering. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1996-01-26 00:00:00", "1994-04-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "Seychelles"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2191907", "headline": "PRO/AH> Botulism - Canada", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2191907", "date": "1996-01-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "From: \"Jeffery P. Taylor\" <JTAYLOR@DISCON.TDH.STATE.TX.US>\nOrganization: Texas Department of Health\nDate: Fri, 26 Jan 1996 16:34:19 -0600 (CST)\n\nFOODBORNE BOTULISM - TEXAS, USA\n===============================\nTwo cases of adult foodborne botulism have been identified in Texas.\nThe patients, a 65-year-old female and her 60-year-old brother, had\nonset of symptoms on 1/12/96 and 1/10/96, respectively. The\npatients were hospitalized at different hospitals in\nVictoria, Texas. Both had respiratory impairment in addition to\ndifficulty swallowing, voice changes, and double vision. Botulism\nwas suspected on 1/18/96 by the pulmonologist who saw both patients.\nSerum collected from both patients on 1/18/96 is negative for\nbotulinal toxin by the mouse assay. Stool collected 1/18/96 from the\nbrother is negative for toxin but is culture positive for Clostridium\nbotulinium. Stool has not be collected from the sister.\nBoth patients have a history of consuming home-canned asparagus. The\nsister was given 12 jars of asparagus by a relative. She gave 1 jar\nto her brother. The brother consumed one spear the evening of\n1/9/96, the asparagus tasted bad, the jar contents were discarded.\nThe sister tasted asparagus from another jar on the evening of\n1/10/96, this asparagus also tasted bad. Contents of her 11 jars\nwere discarded. The jars were not washed after the contents were\ndiscarded. A pooled washing of these 11 jars was culture\npositive for Clostridium botulinium. Botulinal toxin was also\ndetected in this washing. The relative who canned the asparagus\nresides in Washington state. Home-canned asparagus in her possession\nalso have been positive for botulinal toxin. All remaining jars\n(35) of asparagus have been destroyed.\nBoth patients are recovering. These are the first foodborne botulism\ncases reported in Texas since April 1994.\n--\nJeffery P.
